column2: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The Citizens Crusade Against Poverty intervened today to try to save Mississippi's Head Start project from prospective curtailment or extinction.

The master of the HamburgAmerican liner Hanseatic testified yesterday that "it would be difficult to sahy now" whether the fire that broke out on the vessel here last Wednesday could have "been contained at sea."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The real reason the Senate probably will not impose closure tomorrow on those filibustering the 1966 civil rights bill is that there is not enough public support for it. There is active opposition to the bill's open-housing provisions, however watered down, and there is unmistakable indignation among numerous whites at what they believe is a rising tide of Negro extremism.
PHOENIX, Sept. 13 (AP)-- Gov. Samuel P. Goddard and United States Representative George F. Senner Jr. were in tight races tonight for the Democratic renomination in the primary election.

Charles E. Reilly Jr. has been named executive director of the National Catholic Office for Radio and Television, a broadcast information and service agency established here last December by the Roman Catholic Church.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 13-- The Michigan Court of Appeals ruled today that a cemetery had violated the civil rights law when it refused to let a Negro undertaker bury his mother in an all-white burial ground.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 13 (AP)--A charge of carrying a concealed weapon against Robert DePugh, leader of the Minutemen, a militant antiCommunist organization, was dismissed in Magistrate Court today by Judge Harold Whitney.
About 400 of the city's 900 inspectors in the Buildings Department gathered on the steps of City Hall yesterday afternoon to protest alleged "harassment" by their Commissioner, Charles G. Moerdler.

Capt. Patrick Kelly, docking pilot of the Texaco Massachusetts when that tanker collided with the tanker Alva Cape off Staten Island last June 16, entered a denial yesterday to eight counts of negligence.

THE Asbury Park Regional Championships last week end set one major record. The entry of 774 pairs in the Open Pair Championship was the biggest in a single event at any regional championship. Although tournaments on the West Coast are often bigger, many of the players prefer side games to the main championships.
GEORGETOWN, Del., Sept. 13--A 27-year-old parachutist, testing a technique that could be used in Vietnam, was snatched safely from the air in midfall today by a plane flying at 120 miles an hour.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 13 (UPI)--A.J. Foyt, a two-time Memorial Day 500-mile race winner, said today he was quitting the auto racing circuit for the remainder of the season.
The spot rate on the British pound made one of its best recent gains in active trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it was ready to pay the equivalent of more than $9.2-million for 15-100ths of 1 per cent of the Western Electric Company's stock. That would give A.T. T. 100 per cent ownership of the subsidiary.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 13--The United States made a record number of air sorties--attacks by single planes --over North Vietnam yesterday. It was thought likely that the total was about 500.
For the second time in three months, the heavily Democratic City Council overrode Mayor Lindsay yesterday, but nobody seemed quite sure what the result would be.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 13 --Bill Luders of the sponsoring Stamford Yacht Club added a victory to his second-place finish yesterday and became the leader in the United States 5.5meter sailing championship today during a morning and afternoon of upside-down activity today.

MARTYRDOM and its triumph provided the noble theme for Eugene Loring's ballet "These Three," which was given its premiere at the New York City Center by the City Center Joffrey Ballet last night. This marked Mr. Loring's first new ballet to be seen in New York since 1953, but unfortunately its aspirations outmeasured its achievements.

Charles William King, internal auditor of New York University and treasurer of the N.Y.U. Christian Foundation, died Monday of a heart attack in Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived at 13 Gildare Drive, East Northport, L.I.
WINDSOR, N.C., Sept. 13 (UPI)--Twenty-four Negroes were arrested for disrupting classes at Southwestern High School here today, the State Highway Patrol reported.
CONCORD, N.H., Wednesday, Sept. 14--A retired Air Force general was nominated for the United States Senate today by New Hampshire Republicans.

CAIRO, Sept. 13--The unexpected Cabinet shake-up last weekend was the result of a top-level dispute over economic relations with the West and international demands for economic reform, informed sources reported today.

The Landmarks Preservation Commission held a public hearing at City Hall yesterday on a proposed landmark designation for the Conference, or Billopp, House at the foot of Hylan Boulevard in Staten Island. Dating from 1680, the house was the scene of a futile peace conference that took place between British and American representatives during the Revolutionary War.
THE home furnishings collections of fabrics and wall coverings for fall are as far-out as glow-in-the-dark vinyls or as conservative as reproductions that could grace a Queen Anne chair.

MOSCOW, Sept. 13--A former Roman Catholic priest from Chicago said tonight that "a growing threat of fascism" in the United States and Government persecution of opponents of the war in Vietnam had forced him to ask the Soviet Union for asylum.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 13--While nearby billboards urging Vietnamese to vote came down, carpenters were busy today refurbishing the old white Municipal Theater on Lamson Square in downtown Saigon.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 13--Dr. Joseph Millett, former president of the Medical Board of Nassau County's Meadowbrook Hospital, died today in Nassau Hospital, Mineola. He was 59 years old and lived at 76 Garden Street.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. proposed a $1-million limit yesterday as a "reasonable" amount for each party to spend in the campaign for Governor. He suggested that the limit be worked out in a four-party conference along with a campaign code of ethics.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 13-- Howard Schanzer of Metropolis was the medalist today in sectional qualifying for the United States Golf Association's senior amateur golf championship.
PAPEETE, Tahiti, Sept. 13 (Reuters)--France will set off another nuclear device tomorrow if the weather is suitable at the South Pacific testing site, informed sources said today.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 13-- President Jomo Kenyatta, looking vigorous and in a fighting mood, stepped onto a platform here today and challenged anyone who dared to come up and take a poke at him.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 13--Breathing in gasps and blinded in one eye by perspiration, Lieut. Comdr. Richard F. Gordon Jr. of the Navy was forced today to cut short his working excursion outside the orbiting Gemini 11 spacecraft.
Prices on the London stock market continued to advance on a broad front yesterday.
WARREN, Ohio, Sept. 13 (UPI)--City officials backed down today after having threatened to invoke the Ferguson Act in the seven-day-old strike by 240 municipal employes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The contempt of Congress trial of the nation's top Ku Klux Klan leader, Robert M. Shelton Jr., moved ahead quickly today as the defense rested its case without offering any evidence.
A Chicago chemist described here today an inexpensive means of making reconstituted meat proteins from mushrooms.

YONKERS, Sept. 13--A string of four straight winning favorites was broken when Lester Pullen steered Becker Hanover to a half-length victory over High Gun in the featured Class A-2 one-mile pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
The Campbell Soup Company announced yesterday that it achieved record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended July 31.
BOGALUSA, La., Sept. 13 (AP)--Negro leaders called off plans tonight for a protest march that would have defied the city's ban on nighttime demonstrations.
The Senate has an obligation today to do justice for the Southern Negro. The clamor about "black power" does not touch the real issue, and neither does the outcry about the rights of property owners.
BROOKSIDE, N.J., Sept. 13 --Otto August Badenhausen, a director and retired executive vice president of P. Ballantine Sons, brewers, of Newark, died today in his home, Hilsfarm.

One minute before four yesterday afternoon, Captain Joseph Fink stepped behind the desk at the East Fifth Street stationhouse and removed some lecture notes from his pocket. Sergeant Anthony Zitis peeked into the precinct's "sitting room" and barked "Roll call!" and Patrolman Leroy Brathwaite lined up with 21 other patrolmen and waited.

In selecting Assemblyman Percy E. Sutton to succeed Mrs. Constance Baker Motley as the interim Borough President of Manhattan until Jan. 1, the Manhattan members of the City Council have made the logical--and appropriate--choice. Mr. Sutton had already been nominated by the Democratic organization to run in the Nov. 8 election as its candidate for the remaining three years of Mrs. Motley's term.

In a move it described as its first major diversification step, Eastern Air Lines, Inc., announced plans yesterday to acquire a St. Louis concern heavily engaged, in the growing business of general aviation for about $13.8-million in stock.
Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan proposed yesterday that funds for 27, rather than 14, additions to high schools be included in next year's capital budget.

Federal District Court Judge Richard H. Levet reserved decision yesterday on the question of whether pier terminal operators here who perform truck loading and unloading services are required to honor a Federal Maritime Commission subpoena calling for the production of certain business documents.
BOSTON, Sept. 13--In 1964 Warren Schmakel took the post of head football coach at Boston University. He inherited a murderous schedule, a spirit of defeatism and an almost complete lack of talent.

The National Football League issued its first statistics of the season yesterday, and one figure was a whopper Homer Jones of the New York Giants leads in pass-catching production, averaging 86.5 yards a reception.

Georg Philipp Telemann, a contemporary and friend of J.S. Bach, died in 1767 after a career that made him one of the most famous and fashionable composers of the first half of the 18th century. After his death his fame diminished rapidly, and soon his reputation became that of an incredibly prolific composer of little or no interest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The value of total business inventories rose by about $950million in July, as manufacturers, inventories increased by nearly $1-billion and wholesalers' stocks increased by $100million and retailers' inventories declined by about the same amount.

Arthur J. Goldberg, United States representative at the United Nations, lent his good offices last night in an attempt to re-establish harmony between the White House and some segments of the Jewish community.

DETROIT, Sept. 13 (UPI)-- Home runs by Willie Horton and Bill Freehan spoiled Jim Kaat's bid for his 24th victory tonight and lifted the Detroit Tigers back into second place in the American League with a 6-5 victory over the Minnesota Twins.
MINNEAPOLIS, Wednesday, Sept. 14--Gov. Karl F. Rolvaag won a stunning victory last night over Democratic-FarmerLabor party leaders who tried to deny him renomination for a second term.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 13-- The explosive tensions that followed the army mutiny July 29 are easing.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 13--Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. McFadden have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Barbara Adams McFadden, to Henry Ames Cushman of Stowe, Vt., son of Mrs. Robert A. Cushman of Rye Beach, N.H., and the late Mr. Cushman.
LONDON, Sept. 13 (AP)-- Britain will take on the United States in the little America's Cup Catamaran series at Thorpe Bay, Essex, starting tomorrow.
Louis Broido has resigned as Commissioner of the city's Department of Commerce and Industrial Development.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 --The convention of the Episcopal Diocese of California was deadlocked tonight on the election of a bishop to succeed the Right Rev. James A. Pike.

MALVERNE, L.I., Sept. 13-- A Negro minister asked the Malverne school board tonight to send his son to a school in a Negro neighborhood instead of to an integrated school. Then civil rights leaders tried to shout him down as he charged that some Negro leaders here were "black supremecists and American bigots."
The New York Philharmonic conducted by Leonard Bernstein, opened a two-week tour of nine cities last night with a concert at the Academy of Music in Philadelphia.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 13--Pakistani sources indicated today that Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union might visit Pakistan in November.
South Africa nationalist leaders have flouted world opinion in the most dramatic manner possible by selecting Balthazar J. Vorster as their new Prime Minister.
The American Stock Exchange continued to move forward yesterday although the number of advances was not as large as on Monday when the list made its widest gains since May.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) --Robert Watts, an 18-year-old New York high school student, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of threatening President Johnson's life.
When the bugle sounded the call to the post for yesterday's Aqueduct feature, Priceless Gem cocked her ears as if to day, "I'm ready."

IVRY, Que., Sept. 13 (AP)-- Percival Talbot Molson, 45-yearold president of Molson Breweries, Ltd., was found shot dead yesterday in his summer cottage near this community 45 miles north of Montreal, a spokesman aid today.
BALTIMORE, Wednesday, Sept. 14--Late returns from metropolitan Baltimore County gave George P. Mahoney the Democratic nomination for Governor of Maryland early today.
L'Aiglon Apparel, Inc., once at the top of the women's better-dress industry, reported yesterday its first six-month profit in five years for the period ended June 30.

The financial records of 61 harness drivers, trainers, owners and track officials were subpoenaed yesterday in the investigation into whether races were fixed at Yonkers, Roosevelt and Monticello Raceways.
The City Council passed last night legislation to permit New York City's 3,000 disabled drivers who work or go to school to park free at meters throughout the city. The vote was 35 to 0.
ASHAROKEN, L.I. Sept. 13 --Is it possible for a quietly affluent community to be threatened by a subdivision of houses selling for $50,000 and up?
Richard M. Nixon predicted yesterday that after the November elections President Johnson "will find it necessary to announce a substantial increase in our forces in Vietnam."

Warren W. Wilentz, a member of one of New Jersey's leading political families and a loyal supporter of President Johnson's Vietnam policy, won an overwhelming vic tory yesterday in the Democratic primary, in which the war in Vietnam was the dominant issue. Mr. Wilentz, the 42-year-old son of Democratic National Committeeman David T. Wilentz, defeated David Frost, an outspoken critic of the President's Vietnam policy, and three other insurgents.
Mrs. Olive Downie Beers, a soft-voiced brunette dressed in blue, took the bus down to 65 Broadway yesterday morning and before the day was over she had bought and sold $70,000 worth of stock.

Sydney Gruson, foreign news editor of The New York Times, has been named editor of the International Edition of The Times, it was announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher. Mr. Gruson, who will be the chief executive officer of the International Edition, will take up his duties in Paris at the end of this month.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 13 (UPI)--A Mexican newsman quoted Premier Fidel Castro as having said that Cuba was now supplying only sugar to North Vietnam but "is disposed to send troops with military equipment whenever they are requested."
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13-- The Los Angeles Dodgers won their sixth straight game tonight--and clung to their 1 game lead in the National League pennant race--by defeating the New York Mets, 8-3.
Two electrical unions currently negotiating with the General Electric Company indicated yesterday that they expected contract offers from the company soon.

SARASOTA, Fla., Sept. 13 (UPI)--Dr. Carl Coppolino, facing murder indictments in Florida and New Jersey, brought preliminary hearings to a sudden halt late today when he suffered an apparent heart seizure.

A junior high school was boycotted yesterday because its renovation had not been completed while the Board of Education struggled with the problem of ending an integration dispute that has delayed the opening of a new East Harlem intermediate school.
A New York County grand jury yesterday accused LeRoi Jones, playwright, of third-degree assault and petit larceny in an attack last July on the editor of a literary magazine.

Senator Wayne Morse, campaigning here for Councilman Theodore S. Weiss in a Congressional race, charged last night that President Johnson had broken election pledges and "out-Goldwatered Goldwater" in escalating the war in Vietnam.

Signed the Peace Corps authorization bill; saw Agriculture Secretary Freeman; awarded Medal of Honor posthumously to Seabee Marvin Glenn Shields; lunched with Secretary of State Rusk and Defense Secretary McNamara; nominated Senator Case and Senator Church as representatives to the 21st session of the United Nations General Assembly.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 13--Miss Lynne Newhouse and Edward David Segal will be married in December. Their engagement has been made known by Mr. and Mrs. Nahman B. Newhouse, parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Segal is the son of Albert N. Segal of Albany and the late Mrs. Segal.
Oscar Bonavena, the South American heavyweight boxing champion with the classic profile of a Roman gladiator, said yesterday he would like to add some lawyers and bankers to his retinue.

The city's Finance Department announced yesterday that the first income-tax returns for corporations keeping their books on a fiscal-year basis would be due Nov. 1, instead of Sept. 15, as originally announced.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)--Marvin Glen Shields, a Seabee from Port Townsend, Wash., was awarded the Medal of Honor posthumously today for heroism in Vietnam.
MILAN, Italy, Sept. 13 (UPI)--Rocky Marciano, a 43-year-old, former world heavyweight champion, said today "It's not impossible" that he might return to the ring.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (UPI)-- A spokesman for the Chicago Roman Catholic Archdiocese said today that the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Com mittee would not be permitted to use a church hall for a rally in support of Stokely Carmichael, its National Chairman.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 13--South Af rica has had four Prime Ministers since the Nationalist party came to power in 1948 on a wave of Afrikaner nationalism and racial fear. Each has seemed more extreme than his predecessor.

OTTAWA, Sept. 13--The Canadian Government proposed tonight "a new order of fiscal relations" giving the provinces greater responsibilities in social services but asserting federal dominance in national economic affairs.
A move by major trucking companies serving the New York area to raise transportation charges for interstate shipments has been halted by the Suspension Board of the Interstate Commerce Commmission.
William C.T. Winckelmann, a retired grocer, died on Sunday at his home at 205 West 89th Street. He was 93 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13--A pontifical requiem mass was held this morning at St. Matthew's Cathedral for Msgr. Frederick G. Hochwalt, a leading spokesman for Roman Catholic education who died Sept. 5 aboard ship on his way to Venice. His age was 56.
The New York Credit Men's Adjustment Bureau, an affiliate of the New York Credit and Financial Management Association, announced the election yesterday of J. George Jay as president.

NBC Enterprises Inc., one of the five operating entities of the National Broadcasting Company, is planning more extensive backing of the Broadway theater, primarily musicals. To implement the new policy, it has invested $100,000 in the $500,000 musical, "Walk ing Happy," arriving Nov. 26 at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater under the aegis of Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- President Johnson nominated a 10-member delegation today to represent the United States at the United Nations General Assembly, which opens Sept. 20.
"If only," mused Phil Ortega, "I could be that good all the time."
The Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday it had picked up a New Jersey man on a Manhattan street corner carrying $300,000 worth of negotiable securities stolen last May.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 13-- Col. Selim Hatoum, a Syrian Army officer who has found asylum in Jordan, denounced tonight as a Communist front the regime in Dasmascus that he tried to overthrow last week.

MAMARONECK, N.Y. Sept. 13--The Westchester section qualified 39 players today for the 51st Metropolitan Golf Association's open championship tournament from a field of 82 professionals and amateurs competing at Winged Foot Golf Club.
Union musicians voted yesterday to strike the Metropolitan Opera, but they said that they would perform at the opening of the new house on Friday night.
DETROIT, Sept. 13--The Buick division of the General Motors Corporation introduced its 1967 models today, with the regular-size lines getting most of the design changes.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 13--Governor Rockefeller said today that he would go along reluctantly with "reasonable" legislation setting up a state lottery if the voters approved the idea in November.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) --The Senate confirmed today the nomination of John A. Carver Jr. to be a member of the Federal Power Commission.

GRENADA, Miss., Sept. 13-- Heavily armed state highway patrolmen dispersed a crowd of jeering, rock-throwing whites who tried to attack. Negro marchers here tonight as a Federal judge was issuing an order directing Grenada officials to protect Negro school children against violence.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 13 --Prof. Herluf Olsen, former dean of the Amos Tuck Graduate School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College, died here yesterday after a heart attack. He was 67 years old.

FOR seven years Dick Lynch started at right cornerback for the New York Giants. This year he lost his starting job to Clarence Childs and Lynch, a sensitive man, has been upset. Yesterday, injury was added to insult.

DETROIT, Sept. 13--United States steamship companies will have more than $300-million invested in trailerships by 1970 in the race to capture a major share of containerized traffic on trans-Atlantic routes, according to a Maritime Administration study made public today.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 108.1 on Monday from 108.4 on Friday.

The boys and girls of the Cranford, N.J., High School band were obviously not on Candid Camera when this picture was taken earlier this week. Instead they were starring in a one-minute commercial produced for the Campbell Soup Company by Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc.
PARIS, Sept. 13--Formalities were virtually completed today for a start this week on the building of a new military headquarters of the North Atlantic alliance at Casteau, Belgium.

BONN, Sept. 13--Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin, the leader of the Opposition Social Democratic party in West Germany, called today for a constitutional amendment that would allow the Bundestag, or lower house of Parliament, to dissolve itself by a two-thirds majority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen declared today that neither President Johnson nor a majority of his Senate colleagues could persuade him to reverse his opposition to the Administration's civil rights bill.
The United States Agency for International Development will hold a drive here later this month to recruit civilians for 700 posts in Vietnam, it was announced yesterday.

As the American Motors Corporation was announcing yesterday a realignment of its top executive staff, the Small Business Corporation announced a policy change that could bring substantial benefits to the nation's fourth largest auto producer.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 13 (UPI)--United States attorneys, defending the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a $4.5-million wiretapping suit, subpoenaed Nevada gamblers and bankers today to give the Government information.

CAPETOWN, Sept. 13--Balthazar J. Vorster, Minister of Justice, Police and Prisons, was unanimously chosen Prime Minister of South Africa today to succeed Hendrik F. Verwoerd. When the 164member parliamentary caucus of the Nationalist party met this morning, the only other contender for the position, Barend J. Schoeman, Minister of Transport and Leader of the House, announced that he had withdrawn from the race.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Sept. 13 (AP)--The Oak Ridge graphite reactor, the world's oldest existing nuclear reactor, was dedicated today as a national historic landmark.
The Columbia Broadcasting System is expanding into publishing.
OTTAWA, Sept. 13-- Canada's largest steel producer raised prices today on three major product categories, stirring a swift Government demand that the increases be rescinded.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 13 --This East Bay metropolis, California's fourth largest city, is making a determined bid for recognition in the arts. Long a sufferer in the shadow of San Francisco, whose residents traditionally direct not-too-subtle gibes in this direction, Oakland welcomed last night a new extension of its cultural horizon.
Dow Jones Co., Inc., said yesterday it had begun discussions with The Associated Press on the establishment of a new business and financial news service for distribution outside North America.
Mrs. Joy Ivey Carter Dickerman St. John of Greenwich, Conn., was married to Christopher Wheaton Hurd of Cambridge, Mass., on Sept. 2 in St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 13 (AP)--Harold A. Pierson of 54 Western Avenue, a former state senator and assemblyman, died yesterday in All Souls Hospital. He was 65 years old.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 (AP)--An American physician and a German chemist are the first winners of the annual $50,000 Stouffer Prize, it was announced today.
PLANDOME, L.I., Sept. 13 --A luncheon and fashion show at the Plandome Country Club on Sept. 22 will benefit the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 13--Three pros set the pace with two-under-par 69's today as 36 New Jerseyans qualified for the 51st Metropolitan open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- Twice in the last few days President Johnson has mentioned an idea which deserves the serious consideration of all the people in this country who are concerned about war abroad and strife in the cities at home.

TOKYO, Sept. 13--Japan's determination to play a large and effective role in aiding the economic development of less advanced countries was the dominant theme today at the opening of a three-day regional conference of the national development banks of Asian nations.
RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 13 (AP)--An order placing stiff restrictions on information released to the press in criminal cases has been issued by two Wake County Superior Court judges.
MILWAUKEE, Wednesday, Sept. 14--Lieut. Gov. Patrick J. Lucey won a four-way contest today for Wisconsin's Democratic governorship nomination.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 13 (AP)--A German-born United States Navy flier who escaped from a North Vietnamese prison camp said today that American prisoners had been beaten, shot at and hung upside down from trees, with ants put on their faces, in a campaign of harassment.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sept. 13(AP)--A United States Navy Hercules transport equipped with skis landed at stormwhipped Byrd Station in the Antarctic today and took aboard an American scientist with acute appendicitis.

Rosh ha-Shanah, the beginning of the 10-day period of the Jewish High Holy Days and the Jewish year of 5727, will start at sundown today with solemn services in temples and synagogues throughout the world.

FRESNO, Calif., Sept. 13 (AP)--An offer of $20,000 for the late President Franklin D. Roosevelte's yacht, Shangri-La, was rejected at an auction here today. The 165-foot vessel was built ate a cost of $1.25-million in 1934.
ALBANY, Sept. 13 (AP)-- The state won a court decision today favoring its new program of medical assistance to needy persons in the first legal battle over the controversial issue.

LONDON, Sept. 13--Developments on two economic fronts buoyed the pound and the spirits of the British financial community today. Financial circles took them as marking the end of this summer's talk about devaluing the pound and of speculation against the pound.
HOUSTON, Sept. 13--The breathing systems to be used by astronauts during maneuvers outside orbiting spacecraft will probably be redesigned for the Apollo space shots that begin late this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)--The Senate passed by voice vote today and sent to President Johnson a bill to authorize one officer of the Army Medical Service Corps to hold the rank of brigadier general. Previously the highest officer had been a colonel.
ALBANY, Sept. 13 (AP)-- The state won a court decision today favoring its new program of medical assistance to needy persons in the first legal battle over the controversial issue.

LONDON, Sept. 13--Developments on two economic fronts buoyed the pound and the spirits of the British financial community today. Financial circles took them as marking the end of this summer's talk about devaluing the pound and of speculation against the pound.
HOUSTON, Sept. 13--The breathing systems to be used by astronauts during maneuvers outside orbiting spacecraft will probably be redesigned for the Apollo space shots that begin late this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)--The Senate passed by voice vote today and sent to President Johnson a bill to authorize one officer of the Army Medical Service Corps to hold the rank of brigadier general. Previously the highest officer had been a colonel.

ALTHOUGH no trumpets sounded, the new art sea son was initiated last night with the private preview of an extraordinarily pleasant exhibition that opens to the public today, a selection or Colonial and Federal portraits, unexpectedly combined with a group of old-master drawings, all from the collection of the Bowdoin College Museum of Art in Brunswick, Me. The exhibition will remain on view at Wildenstein Co., 19 East 64th Street, until Oct. 15.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP)-- Dr. Benjamin C. Willis, who recently retired as Superintendent of Chicago Public Schools, started work in a new post at Purdue University's Calumet Campus in nearby Hammond, Ind., yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14--The American Nazi party and its leader, George Lincoln Rockwell, were prohibited by a Federal court orders today from staaging demonstrations in Jewash neighborhoods during the Jewish High Holy Days.

The most important part of the New York Yankee future will be on display at Yankee Stadium today when Stan Bahnsen and Mel Stottlemyre face the Washington Senators in a double-header starting at 1 P.M.

TOKYO, Sept. 14--Major changes in the leadership of Communist China under Chairman Mao's rule was "absolute" announced gradually to "avoid confusion," according to a report from the Peking correspondent of Asahi, the Japanese newspaper.
New Orleans--Jerry Pellegrini, 147 pounds, St. Bernard, La., outpointed Charlie Scott, 150, Philadelphia, 10 rounds.
CAPETOWN, Sept, 14-- Within a day of taking office South Africa's Prime Minister, Balthazar J. Vorster, firmly endorsed the policy of separate racial development followed by Dr. Hendrik F. Verwoerd.
There will be an added starter in next year's America's Cup festivities at Newport, R.I.-- the schooner America.
Mrs. Frank D. O'Connor enlisted three women yesterday --Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy, Mrs. Robert F. Wagner and Mrs. Orin Lehman--to work actively for the election of her husband as Governor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- president Johnson was reported to be pleased today at evidence of voter support for his Vietnamese policy but disturbed at the "white backlash" that helped George P. Mahoney apparently win the Democratic nomination for Governor of Maryland.
The appointment of Charles H. Bell as vice president for traffic of Seaboard World Airlines Inc., was announced ysterday by Richard M. Jackson, president of the lines.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 (AP) --John (Blue Moon) Odom scattered five singles as the Kansas City Athletics blanked the Cleveland Indians, 3-0, tonight for their sixth straight victory.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 14-- Harrison R. Thyng, a retired Air Force general on the far political right, emerged today as New Hampshire's Republican nominee for Senator. He won, analysts here said, because conservatives concentrated their forces and moderates scattered theirs.
The city of Chicago is to have the first sculpture to be expressly designed by Pablo Picasso for a civic project in this country.

The Most Rev. John P. Cody, Archbishop of Chicago, has expressed a hope that the Rev. Peter O'Reilly, a leader of the teachers' strike at St. John's University, will accept an assignment as an assistant in an archdiocesan parish, it was learned yesterday.
Eight-hundred nurses, who enjoy bicycling and boating, and Shakespeare plays and carousels, are giving Thomas P.F. Hoving an illustrated thank-you-note for improving their front lawn.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 14--An American Negro "Porgy and Bess" company with a Maori from New Zealand playing the male lead completed a tour of Israel last night in Jerusalem.
The Internal Revenue Service is pressing its be-kindto-taxpayers drive.
Temple Israel, one of the city's leading Reform synagogues, chose the beginning of Rosh ha-Shanah yesterday to move into its new $3-million home at 112 East 75th Street.

The Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association and the Edgewater Savings and Loan Association announced yesterday that the Federal Home Loan Bank Board had given preliminary approval for a merger of the two.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines began a two-week state visit here today by praising President Johnson for accepting "loneliness" and rejecting the counsel of friends in order to

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)--The Bureau of Operating Rights, has told its parent agency, the Civil Aeronautics Board, that Overseas National Airlines, New York City, and Standard Airways, Miami, have become sufficiently rehabilitated to be given certificates as supplemental airlines.

Child Guidance Toys, Inc., has started construction of a 200,000-square-foot plant at Bronx River Avenue and Watson Avenue, the Bronx, in an expansion program under which the company will move from its current plant at near-by 1125 Close Avenue.
EASTON, Pa., Sept. 14--Carroll Huntress, the head football coach at Bucknell, said recently that Lafayette had a good chance to succeed his team as champion of the Middle Atlantic Conference.

HOUSTON, Sept. 14--Richard Francis Gordon Jr. may be the most determined of the 48 United States astronauts. In a profession where competition is fierce, Lieutenant Commander Gordon thrives, conditioned by a lifetime of the pursuit of success, he is a completely disciplined
A report made available here by a United States Jewish organization says the police of Riga, Latvia, committed acts considered anti-Semitic last July.

The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit in Federal Court here yesterday in an attempt to compel The World Journal Tribune to open to competitive, bidding by other New York newspapers the syndicated columns and features that it Inherited from the defunct Herald Tribune.
LONDON, Sept. 14 (Reuters) --Mike Davies of Britain upset Earl Buchholz, an American, in the London indoor professional tennis championships tonight.
DETROIT, Sept. 14--Henry Ford 2d, board chairman of the Ford Motor Company, endorsed President Johnson's anti-inflationary proposals in a statement issued today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14--To women anywhers in the country who are pining for an original Paris fashion Marshall Field Co. offers the suggestion: Leave the flying to us.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 14 --Five high-school boys who have been isolated from their classmates for five days because of their long hair received support today from a group of 12 college students.
Drivers for the United Parcel Service returned to their jobs yesterday, ending a twoweek wildcat strike.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 14 --The present split in the producer price of copper will be maintained and the over-all price of the metal will tend to rise over the long term, a Wall Street executive told miners here today.

Leonard H. Goldenson, president of the American Broadcasting Companies, and Juan T. Trippe, chairman and chief executive officer of Pan American World Airways, will be recipients this year of the Avenue of the America's Association Gold Key Awards.
Following are texts of a letter to President Johnson from the Educational Committee to Halt Atomic Weapons Spread and of a statement by the committee:

ATLANTA, Thursday, Sept. 15--Former Gov. Ellis Arnall, an unabashed national Democrat and racial moderate, led a field of six tonight in the primary race for the Democratis nomination for Governor of Georgia.

Capt. Pete Dawkins, back from Vietnam, and Maj. Gen. D.V. Bennett, the superintendent of the United States Military Academy, were among the notables at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday for a reception in honor of the selec-...
To A LARGE degree, the appeal of the mutual fund is that it allows the investor to place his investment eggs in several baskets.
PEKING--Truckloads of troops have been moved into Peking to bolster security measures after reports of clashes causing death and injury in several places outside the capital.
The Lindsay administration is on the right track in seeking to substitute the Cross-Brooklyn Expressway for the Bushwick Expressway in the New York area's Interstate Highway system.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- Washington sloshed through its heaviest rainfall in years today as a drought came to an end.
After two frantic days of liquidation soybeans bowed out as the star commodity performer in futures trading, and potatoes moved to center stage.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 14--Government spokesmen denied today that former Foreign Minister Subandrio, a close political and personal associate of President Sukarno, would be tried before a military tribunal convening Oct. 1.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- A State Department spokesman said today that the United States attached "great importance" to the immediate release of Thomas R. Dawson.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- Strong pressure for special exemptions from the Administration's anti-inflation tax bill developed today as business representatives presented their views to Congress.

Larry Khohl, considered by the Government to be a major fence and banker for the underworld, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy to five years in prison following his conviction on a charge of obstruction of justice. He was freed in $20,000 bail pending appeal.
Seventeen demonstrators seeking increased clothing allowances for school children were arrested yesterday as they blocked the doorways of the Department of Welfare.
ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 14--"This hotel," one vis itor remarked over a breakfast menu, "is like a grounded ocean liner surrounded by a golf course as far as the eye can see."

The opening tomorrow evening of the new Metropolitan Opera House in Lincoln Center, it has been widely noted, will be both the occasion for a world premiere of an American opera and one of the social highlights of the season.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (UPI)-- Conrad N. Hilton, chairman, and 18 officers and directors of the Hilton Hotels Corporation have been ordered to stand trial Dec. 13 on charges in a civil suit that they had sold stock back to the corporation at inflated prices.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 --A new Episcopal Bishop of the Diocese of California was elected early this morning in Grace Cathedral on Nob Hill. The change was of one ecclersiastic liberal for another.
BOGALUSA, La., Sept. 14-- On a fine sunny day this paper mill town has the peaceful, folksy look of a thousand other towns across the land.

The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts--a cluster of architectural jewels flung down in the midst of a less-thanpicturesque slum--now is virtually complete, but an era of dramatic change is just beginning for the neighborhood that surrounds it.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 14-- Governor Rockefeller said tonight, that he supported the drive to keep New York City's civilian-dominated police review board but that he would not campaign for it.

BOSTON, Sept. 14--A 1924 newspaper clipping came back today to haunt Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican from the 10th District, who was defeated for nomination to a 22d term in yesterday's primary.
Seymour Topping, chief New York Times correspondent in the Far East, has been appointed foreign news editor of The Times, it was announced yesterday by Turner Catledge, executive editor.
ATLANTA, Sept. 14 (AP)-- Five Negroes--one under a $10,000 bond--have been bound over to the Fulton County grand jury on charges arising from Monday night's racial outbreak.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Sept. 14 (Reuters)--President Joseph D. Mobutu today announced a Government reshuffle affecting nine ministries and establishing new portfolios, for a total of 21.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP)-- Ty Cline and Felipe Alou each drove in a run in the 10th inning today to give the Atlanta Braves a 3-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs. The triumph was the eighth straight for the Braves.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 14 (AP)--Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon campaigned through Ohio for Republican Congressional candidates today, saying that unless the party gained this year "the two-party system will have suffered a blow from which it might not recover."
About a month ago, while Mai Zetterling, the Swedish actress-turned-film director, and David Hughes, her novelisthusband, were on a holiday in France, their country House in England was burglarized.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) and one of its affiliates announced yesterday they had approved credits totaling $31-million for Iceland and Tunisia.

BOSTON, Sept. 14--Massachusetts Democrats closed ranks today behind a ticket of former officeholders whose endorsements by a party convention in June were confirmed by the voters in yesterday's primary.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- France was the only nation that converted dollars into gold in significant volume in the second quarter of this year, the Treasury disclosed today.
Joseph Koret has been elected chairman and Jere N. Helfat has been elected president of Koret of California, Inc., it was announced in San Francisco yesterday.

James Justin Thackara has been appointed a vice president of the Bank of America International, the Edge Act subsidiary of the Bank of America, San Francisco. The Edge Act, authorized under the Federal Reserve Act, permits United States banks to operate abroad.

By CHARLES G. BENNETT Several top-level city officials have received salary raises that were made known yesterday. These were the presidents of the city and community colleges and George F. McGrath, Commissioner of Correction.
HOUSTON, Sept. 14--"It's fantastic," said Comdr. Charles Conrad Jr., the command pilot of Gemini 11. "I've got India at the left window and Borneo under our nose."

BETHESDA, Ohio, Sept. 14 (UPI)--A raging fire, touched off by a short circuit and fed by tons of coal, roared through a small stope mine near this eastern Ohio community today, trapping three workers more than 1,000 feet from the pit entrance.
The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that it would defend a man's right to be a conscientious objector to the war in Vietnam without being opposed to all wars.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 14-- Prime Minister Wilson of Britain was accused by Zambia's Foreign Minister today of being a racialist and a man of no principle, interested only in creating in Rhodesia a fascist-like replica of South Africa's Government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- A study that proposes steps toward the economic integration of Latin America has aroused strong interest at the White House.
A Markets Department hearing officer imposed fines totaling $200 yesterday against three supermarket chains accused of having offered short-weight packages of butter for sale.

STANLEY, Idaho, Sept. 14 (UPI)--Charles Herndon, the Democratic candidate for Governor of Idaho, died while rescuers carried him from the heart of a wilderness area in central Idaho tonight, bringing to three the number of victims in an airplane crash earlier in the day.
MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- Soviet border guards have arrested an American Peace Corps teacher on the frontier with Iran and are detaining him, the United States Embassy reported today.

TORONTO, Sept. 14--This city and others in Canada have become havens for young men from the United States who want to dodge the draft. Estimates of the number of draft dodgers now in Canada range as high as 400.
The Board of Education announced yesterday that it would purchase textbooks for parochial as well as public school students under the controversial new state Textbook Loan Law.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (UPI)-- Mrs. Katherine Woodruff Field and Lawrence S. Fanning were married yesterday in suburban Bensenville.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- A vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company acknowledged before a Senate subcommittee today that company employes listened in on 36 million long-distance calls last Year.
YONKERS, Sept. 14--Miss Ruth Leszynski, a teacher in the Yonkers public schools, died Thursday evening in St. Vincent's Hospital, New York, of complications following ileitis. Her age was 31.

GRENADA, Miss., Sept. 14 --Local policemen, under Federal court order to protect Negro children attending previously all-white, schools, arrested six white men today. All six are natives of Grenada and one of them, Jerome...
PORTSMOUTH, Va. Sept. 14 (UPI)--Three ships and two planes searched the rough Atlantic today for five persons who abandoned the sailing sloop Mary Lee in darkness off the Virginia Capes.
MOSCOW, Sept. 14--The Soviet Government announced today the expulsion of a United States diplomat "for activities incompatible with his diplomatic status."
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 14 (AP)--Thousands of students battled policemen tonight in downtown Buenos Aires.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday monthly changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.
Playing politics to the end, the City Council passed this week, over Mayor Lindsay's veto, a bill transferring $83.4 million to the Transit Authority.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell was ordered yesterday to stand trial next Wednesday for disobeying court orders to satisfy a $162,000 judgment that he owes a Harlem widow.
Sam DeLuca talked like an unaccountably calm little boy about to be beaten up again by the neighborhood bully.
Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg has apparently succeeded in mollifying leaders of the Jewish community who have been disturbed by recent statements attributed to President Johnson.

With their offensive line in a critical state, the New York Giants made a trade yesterday that brought back a favorite player, Darrell Dess, who had been a member of four championship teams here between 1959 and 1963.

LONDON, Sept. 14--Britain tonight gave the Rhodesian regime of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith what amounted to an ultimatum: End your rebellion or Britain will withdraw all settlement proposals and never agree to Rhodesian independence before there is majority African rule.
Robert T. MacDonald, former executive vice president of The New York Herald Tribune, has been appointed publisher of the New York Herald TribuneWashington Post in Paris.
BONN, Sept. 14--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard pledged today that his Government would not impose "freedom-limiting measures" such as wage and price freezes, currency controls or drastic tax increases.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14-- Karl Stangl's Serendipity, with a substitute skipper, John Welch, at the helm, won the second race in the international Dragon Class series for the English Speaking Union Cup today.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 14--Governor Rockefeller has decided to soft-pedal, at least for now, any direct criticism of City Council President Frank D. O'Connor, his Democratic rival.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 14-- The engagement of Miss M. Susan O'Reilly to Lawrence Bruce Rabuffo has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard T. O'Reilly. Mr. Rabuffo is the son of Mrs. Vincent M. Rabuffo of Brooklyn.

ISTANBUL, Sept. 14--Gen. Cemal Gursel, Turkey's former President and the leader of the 1960 armed forces revolution, died in a military hospital in Ankara early today at the age of 71. He had been in a coma for 218 days.

Mayor Lindsay's national search for the best man to direct the city's drought-troubled water supply system has ended right where it began--in the office of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity on the 23d floor of the Municipal Building.
DETROIT, Sept. 14--The Pontiac Division of the General Motors Corporation rolled out its 1967 model cars today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- The President, who deliberately turned the spotlight of publicity on his effort to force Senator Dirksen to retreat from a position the Senator had publicly attributed to basic principle, committed the very blunder he was careful never to make when he was Senate majority leader.
John D. Murchison resigned yesterday as a director of Holt, Rinehart Winston, Inc., and the two senior executives of the Columbia--Broadcasting System, Inc., were named to the publisher's board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- Robert M. Shelton Jr., imperial wizard of the United Kians of America, was found guilty today of contempt of Congress for refusing to produce records for the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

The Equity Theater will present free experimental offerings in the 212-seat auditorium at the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts in Lincoln Center. In addition, the organization will continue to give regular performances at the inti mate Master Theater, Riverside Drive and 103d Street, where contributions are accepted.

HARTFORD, Sept. 14--The police arrested 17 persons today after a clash at the offices of Bernard Shapiro, state welfare commissioner, where they had gone to demand increased welfare payments and standards.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- Mrs. Elmer B. Collins has an- nounced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Carole Patricia Collins, to James Patrick Neeves, son of Mrs. Archibald A. Neeves of New York and the late Mr. Neeves.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 14 --India and Pakistan agreed today to withdraw their troops from forward positions along the West and East Pakistan borders.
The State Mediation Board may move to help settle the strike of union musicians against the Metropolitan Opera.

The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, Boston, has elected two senior vice presidents and a vice president in the campany's financial operations, Byron K. Elliott, chairman, announced yesterday after a meeting of the directors. The elections take effect Oct. 1.

The American Motors Corporation announced yesterday in Detroit the election of William S. Pickett as vice president in charge of international automotive operations. Mr. Pickett has served as director of automotive exports since joining the company in 1960.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- The total volume of world trade grew sharply in the second quarter of this year and passed the previous record reached in the final quarter of last year, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

Officials of the Continental Football League said yesterday that a playoff would be held on Nov. 27 between the top two teams in each division to determine the participants in the championship game the following week.
BONN, Sept. 14--Lieut, Gen. Johannes Steinhoff, the new Inspector General of the West German Air Force, gave its Starfighter squadrons permission today to resume "low" flights and night flights.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- Encouraged by what he called a "vote of confidence" from the people of South Vietnam, President Johnson hailed today the "real progress and growing momentum" in that nation's economic and social rehabilitation.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 14--Two American soldiers of the InterAmerican Peace Force were shot tonight, one fatally, in downtown Santo Domingo. [The wounded soldier died later in a hospital, The Associated Press reported.]
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 14--The Soviet--Union demanded today as a "test of sincerity" that a proposed treat on space exploration give all states tracking facilities under equal conditions.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 14--An Independent candidate for the State Assembly accused the Mount Pleasant Town Board last night of failing to collect taxes on assessable submerged property held largely by the Rockefeller family at the Hudson River shoreline.

THORPE BAY, England, Sept. 14, (AP)--Gamecock, the American challenger, won the first race from Britain today in the International Catamaran Challenge Trophy series when the Lady Helmsman's main beam buckled and she could not continue.
CAIRO, Sept. 14--A group of Yemen's republican leaders have come here to appeal to President Gamal Abdel Nasser to call back President Abdullah alSallal from Yemen, it was disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- The Senate dealt a heavy and perhaps fatal blow today to the Administration's civil rights bill when it failed, by a margin of 10 votes, to cut off a filibuster against the measure.
The outcome of Tuesday's primaries suggests that in intraparty elections, as in physics, inertia is an important principle.

Two hundred ninety citizens, including 12 Nobel laureates, warned President Johnson yesterday that the "imminent spread of atomic weapons among nonnuclear powers, by manufacture or acquisition," represented an even greater danger to the national security of the United States than the war in Vietnam.

THE Vermont fish and game people have been pondering for years the question of shooting antlerless deer. They were trying to refute the old wives' tale that shooting does would harm the health of the Green Mountain state's herd.

Alcohol tax agents from the Treasury Department raided a still in a garage in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn yesterday and arrested three men who, the agents said were loading 120 gallons of illicit whisky on a trick.

DJIBOUTI, French Somaliland, Sept. 14 (AP)--Crowds shouting for independence from France rioted in Djibouti today and ransacked the home of Ali Aref Bourhan, vice president of the ruling Government Council.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. warned that New York City subway and bus riders faced increases in the present 20-cent fare unless what he called the "Dewey law" was changed.

The directors of Delta Air Lines, Inc., designated Charles H. Dolson yesterday as the carrier's chief executive officer. Mr. Dolson has been president of the airline since last Nov. of the airline since last Nov. 1. The chief executive title had been held by C. E. Woolman, chairman, who died on Sunday.
READY-TO WEAR with a French touch had a patri otic launching last night as Saks Fifth Avenue introduced its Nina Ricci boutique collection aboard the S.S. France.
More than 150 members of New York society and the motion-picture industry are serving as committee members for the world premiere of "Hawaii," and the "Hoolaulea Ball" on Oct. 10.
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 15 --Communist China today ordered a suspension of the cultural revolution it launched six months ago so that the people might concentrate on bringing in the fall harvest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)--Representative Paul A. Fino asserted today--and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare denied --that the Administration was considering a bill specifically proposing school busing and redistricting school districts to achieve racial balance.
FORT WORTH, Sept. 14 (AP)--Ronnie Barnes of Brazil and Cliff Drysdale of South Africa gained the quarter-finals of the Colonial national invitation tennis tournament today.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 4-- Broad and possibly irreconcilable differences of opinion emerged here today at the conference to decide Nigeria's political future.
Detectives are investigating the possibility that a key witness in a murder during a Brooklyn racial disturbance may repudiate an affidavit used to build up the case against the defendant.

DETROIT, Sept. 14--Sharply divergent views on the role the Government should play in waterfront labor disputes were expressed today by the principal negotiators of longshore labor pacts on the East and Gulf Coasts.

The Board of Education announced last night that all children assigned to the controversial new Intermediate School 201 in East Harlem would be shifted on Monday to an old, closed school building in the neighborhood.

The heads of city agencies were told in a memorandum received yesterday from the Mayor's press office that "Mayor Lindsay has requested that from now on all major news announcements be cleared through City Hall."

A senior Fire Department official denied yesterday earlier reports that the Firs Department's apparatus was not equipped with foam to fight the oil fire that raged through the engine room and other parts of the Hamburg-Atlantic liner Hanseatic here last Wednesday.
MIAMI, Sept. 14--Thousands of Cubans, delinquent in their rent payments, were told today to settle their arrears by Sept. 20 or face attachment of their salaries, according to the Havana radio.

Spooky Joe closed like a flat runner to win the Rouge Dragon Hurdle Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Milton Ritzenberg's consistent 4-year-old seemed to be beaten at the final jump of the 2 -mile event, but under the urging of Doug Small he flashed enough speed at the finish to win by half a length.

David Haweeli was appointed yesterday as president of the Federated Department Stores International Company, which was established last November by Federated Department Stores, Inc., to broaden its European activities.

A ten-week course on the economic aspects of building and construction will be given on Wednesday evenings beginning Sept. 28 at the Management Institute of New York University's School of Continuing Education.

LONDON, Sept. 14--Joe Louis sat in a recently opened Piccadilly gambling casino last night sipping Dom Perignon champagne and watching himself on film battering opponents to the canvas in bygone years.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 14--A record outpouring of white "backlash" votes appeared today to have handed a narrow victory in the Democratic governorship primary to a candidate whose major issue was opposition to open housing legislation.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 14-- Lieut. Gov. Patrick J. Lucey, the Democratic gubernatorial primary yesterday, will have to overcome opposition within his party as well as outside it if he is to defeat Gov. Warren P. Knowles, the Republican incumbent, in the general election on Nov. 8.
LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP)-- Militant trade unions threatened today a revolt against Prime Minister Wilson's Labor Government because of the prospect of widespread layoffs in the nation's auto industry.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14 (AP)-- Lin-Drake Farm's Harmony Again won the sevenfurlong Mays Landing Purse today at Atlantic City race track by four lengths. Greek Princess was second and Cap'n Shorty third.

The chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Miss Ann Hamilton McCauley, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Corran McCauley Jr. of 7 Gracie Square and Willsboro, N.Y., to Robert Renfrew Trostle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne M. Trostle of Rocky River, Ohio.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 (Ap)--Jim Bunning pitched a five-hitter and Richie Allen drove in both runs with his 38th homer and a sacrifice fly as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated San Francisco today, 2-0.

ALPINE, N.J., Sept. 14-- Mr. and Mrs. William F. Wells have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wells's daughter, Miss Nancy Edwina Grubb, to Lieut. Robert B.H.D. Schrijver of the Netherlands Navy. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. G.H. Schrijver-van Gelder of Bennebroek, the Netherlands.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 14--The Gemini 11 astronauts set an altitude record of 850 miles today, took photographs of stars through an open hatch and spun in tandem with their Agena companion vehicle at the end of a 100foot tether.

WHEN Bobby Richardson was still a comparatively new Yankee, he was so quiet that his teammates did not realize that this model young man was a lofty-minded idealist of almost evangelistic fervor. Realization came, perhaps, on the day when the breezy and boisterous Hank Bauer made a well-meaning attempt to break through the shell of dignified reserve.
The spot rate on the British pound continued a marked strengthening trend yesterday in active trading on foreign exchange markets here.
Dr. Nico Mirosevitch-Sorgo, former Yugoslav Minister to the Vatican and a minister in the Yugoslav Government-in-Exile in World War II, died on Tuesday in London. His age was 81.

YONKERS, Sept. 14--If Samuel Huttenbauer's Best of All can handle the four turns of a half-mile track as well as the two-turn ovals at Du Quoin, Ill., and Indianapolis, local harness racing fans may be in for a treat tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 14 --Ernest B. Fay, a little Texan with a big name in sailing, acquired all the honors available for today in the national championship for the International 5.5-Meter class.
Stephen Loidl Jr., treasurer of the Leeds Northrup Company, was elected yesterday as a director of the electronic instrtuments producer.

Joseph R. Baradel, who retired in 1953 as chief of the New York Division intelligence unit of the Internal Revenue Service, died of cancer at Physicians Hospital in Jackson Heights, Queens, yesterday. He was 75 years old.

A massive Medicaid enrollment program that excludes 25 per cent of the city's practicing specialist physicians and requires most general practitioners to update their training was announced yesterday by city officials.

FRANCE won the European Bridge Championships, which ended last Saturday in Warsaw, and will represent Europe in the World Championship next April in Miami Beach. The other contenders will be North America, the defending Italian champions, and the representatives of South America and the Far East.

Fred Gwynne, known to television fans for his roles in such situation comedies as "Car 5 Where Are You?" and "The Munsters," will appear in a Eugene Ionesco play, "The Lesson, on Channel 13. He will portray a psychopathic professor who cannot resist murdering his students.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept.14-- In the face of mounting opposition from university students, the Brazilian Government of President Humberto Castelo Branco offered financial support today for a national organization similar to the United States Peace Corps.

The Standardbred Owners Association which represents horse owners and trainers, criticized the States Harness Racing Commission yesterday for cooperating with a grand jury inquiry into whether races were fixed at Yonkers, Roosevelt and Monticello Raceways.

Gertrude Berg, known to millions of Americans as the original Jewish mother of radio, television, stage and screen, died yesterday of heart failure at Doctors Hospital after a brief illness. She was 66 years old.

A Federal judge sent the case of Eugene Rodriguez, a Democratic State Senate candidate, to Bronx Supreme Court yesterday. He was indicted last July on charges of attempted grand larceny, misconduct as a lawyer and perjury.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- The profits of manufacturing companies, on both investment and sales, rose in the second quarter of this year, the Federal Trade Commission and Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The filing of a $10-million damage suit against the Teamsters Union and its local affiliates has had its desired effect of forcing a swift end to the wildcat strike of United Parcel Service drivers in the Metropolitan area.

WESTWOOD, N.J., Sept. 14 --Mr. and Mrs. John W. Kollar have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Therese Kollar, to Dr. Ronald C. Monticone, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles R. Monticone of Manhasset Hills and Southampton. L.I.
Stock prices rallied strongly in late trading yesterday, extending the market's advance into the fourth consecutive session.

John Moody Sr., a Hoboken official of the International Longshoremen's Association, whose trade union activities involved him in a landmark Federal criminal law decision, died yesterday at the age of 66.
DETROIT, Sept. 14 (UPI)-- Denny McClain won his 19th game of the year with a fourhitter as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Minnesota Twins, 3-2, tonight.

Miss Linda Balding, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ivor Balding of Old Westbury, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Hartley Parker Shearer, son of Mrs. Clifford Roberts of New York and F. Hartley Shearer of Naples, Fla.
The Commonwealth conference devoted a major portion of its discussions to the problem of Rhodesia.
MADAME Calderon de la Barca's great book about Mexico is a splendid phoenix of world literature. Its ap pearance in this sumptuous new version should be greeted with enthusiastic Oles!
The price of standard railroad rails was advanced $5 a ton yesterday by the C.F. I. Steel Corporation, which also increased tie plates and splice bars by $10 a ton.
British Government bonds rose strongly on the London stock market yesterday, but share prices generally reversed a recent upward trend.

Mrs. David C. Morgan Jr. of Ardmore, Okla., has announced the engagement of her daugh- ter, Miss Jan Morgan of Glen Cove, L.I., to Albert Rosen, son of Joseph Rosen of the Bronx and the late Mrs. Rosen.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 14-- Vice, President Humphrey took the lead today in organizing emergency repairs for his Democratic-Farmer-Labor party to avert a second disastrous defeat in less than two months.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 14-- Premier Levi Eshkol broadcast a Yiddish message to the Jews of Europe today on the eve of Rosh ha-Shana.

An increase of 2,027,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 178,150,000 barrels, compared with 176,123,000 a week earlier and 182,295,000 year ago.

"Victory has a hundred fathers and defeat is an orphan," President Kennedy once remarked. But it is not difficult to trace the parentage of yesterday's defeat in the Senate of the closure resolution in behalf of the civil rights bill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- Eighteen-year-old Tom Pete Tom of East Flat Falls, Tex., was crowned Master America here tonight amid cries of "Fix!" and "Fraud!" from other contestants in the first annual Master America Pageant.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 14--The Central Committee of the Serbian Communist party opened a two-day meeting today to purge leaders associated with the faction led by Aleksandar Rankovic, the ousted Vice President.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 14--Vietcong guerrillas overran a construction company motor pool six miles north of Saigon early today, killing at least two persons and blowing up more than 60 trucks.

Prices of Government bonds and Treasury bills dropped yesterday in the first sharp downward move since the credit markets began to advance Aug. 30 in expectation of the Administration's program to fight inflation and curb high interest rates.

RAIN PELTED Wall Street yesterday, but wary smiles appeared under the umbrellas. The main reason, of course, was another strong rally in the stock market. One conservative member of the New York Stock Exchange said that he foresaw the possibility of a new bull market...
NEWARK, Sept. 1--The City of Newark won a vast increase today in the annual rent that the Port of New York Authority will pay for cityowned property operated as Port Newark and Newark Airport.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 14 --The Brazilian Foreign Min istry said today, that a recent shipment of 12,000 tons of Corn to Cuba was "an act of charity" that would not be repeated.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 14-- Mr. and Mrs. J. Paul Stabler have announced the engagement of Mrs. Stabler's daughter, Miss Beverly Alexander Bowers, to Keith Slater Jennings, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Jennings of New Canaan.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- The Selective Service System is unable to do anything immediately about draft eligibles who leave the country to avoid service its officials have said.

CHARM, pure, simple and sweet, is the basic char acteristic of Robert Joffrey's "Gamelan," given in a revised version by the City Center York City Center last night. Charm--in such unassertive abundance--does not precisely cloy, but it certainly disConcerts. Mr Joffrey calls his ballet "eight choreographic essays."

PHOENICIA, N.Y., Sept. 19 --Mr. and Mrs. Philip Gordon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Olivia Gordon, to Lieut Stephen Paul Krosner, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Krosner of Kingston.

Dr. Philip Bovier Hawk, a biochemist, an authority on foods and nutrition, and three times winner of the national veterans' tennis championship, died Tuesday at the Miami Heart Institute in Miami Beach. He was 92 years old.
A special law enacted last June that was designed to save the old Metropolitan Opera House from demolition was declared unconstitutional yesterday by State Supreme Court Justic Arthur G. Klein.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)--A top Administration official cautioned today against expectation of any miracles in highway safety stemming from the Government's new auto safety program.
DALLAS, Sept.14 (AP)--Ernie Koy has not been called up for induction into the Army, Don Smith, the publicity director of the Giants, said today.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 14 --A plan to give the names of unwed parents seeking welfare benefits for their illegitimate children to the Monmouth County Prosecutor for criminal action was unanimously approved by the county's Welfare Board today.
The American Stock Exchange was on a seesaw yesterday, with most stocks falling in the morning and then rising in the afternoon.
In 22 million homes, studios, clubs and concert halls, pianists' hands are moving with zest up and down black and white keys.
The appointment of Alvin Shapiro as executive director of the jointly administered National Maritime Union deep sea pension, welfare and other security plans was announced here yesterday.

SARASOTA, Fla., Sept. 14 (UPI)--Judge Lynn Silvertooth set a $l5,000 bond here tonight for Dr. Carl Coppolino and cleared the way for the return of the 34-year-old physician to New Jersey.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14-- "A baseball pennant race is like a horse race," said Walter Alston, surveying the pennant race from first place in the National League. "It changes from moment to moment."
OTTAWA, Sept. 14--Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip will attend ceremonies in Canada next July 1 to mark the 100th anniversary of Canadian Federation, it was announced today.

THE debut of the American Broadcasting Company's "Stage '67," the most eagerly awaited event of the television season, occurred last night in conformance with the promise of Leonard H. Goldenson, head of the network's parent company, to try to lift video programing to a more reassuring level.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 14-- Gov. Samuel J. Goddard, seeking re-election to a second twoyear term, eked out a victory in yesterday's Democratic primary.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J. Sept. 14 (AP)--The Right Rev. Alfred A. Gilman, retired Bishop of the Episcopal Missionary District of Hankow, China, died here yesterday in Chilton Memorial Hospital. His age was 88.
The United States Military Academy has suggested auto routes to West Point for persons driving to Army football games. The cadets open at home Saturday against Kansas state.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 14 --At the end of last season many considered Hofstra's stock as a 1966 Middle Atlantic Conference football power giltedged. The edges, however, have become somewhat tarnished because of unexpected losses in personnel.
Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery put out a fire last night on his way home from one.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 14 --Mrs. Doris Holmes Niemeyer, widow of Alfred H. Niemeyer, was married today to Samuel Graham of Nottingham, England. The Rev. Dudley J. Stroup performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less.
Dr. Julius Schaffer, a dentist who specialized in root canal therapy, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home, 381 West End Avenue. He was 51 years old.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)--The nation's interstate pipeline companies sold 14.7 trillion cubic feet of natural gas in 1965, the Federal Power Commission reported today.
The Rev. Billy Graham has announced that his request for a visa to visit Poland later this month has been denied.

The Legislature of the Virgin Islands has approved a supplemental agreement with the Hess Oil Virgin Islands Corporation, a subsidiary of the Hess Oil and Chemical Corporation, which is building an oil refinery on the island of St. Croix.

PARIS, Sept. 14--France today cut another tie with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. She announced that on Oct. 1 she would withdraw from the Military Committee, NATO's highest military authority.

Democratic party leaders agreed yesterday to put three Liberal party members on the Democratic slate of 15 at-large delegates to the state constitutional convention.

A charge that the state police Had illegally tapped the telephones of state employes who were critical of any part of Governor Rockefeller's administration was made yesterday by Representative Joseph Y. Res-...
All hazardous building violations against public schools have been corrected, Eugene E. Hult, in charge of all school buildings, said yesterday.
MOSCOW, Sept. 14--Nikolai K. Cherkasov, one of the Soviet Union's leading actors, died today in Leningrad at the age of 63.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 14 (UPI)--Gregory F. Abbott, a New York businessman, went on trial in Saigon today on charges of violating Vietnamese currency restrictions.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (AP)--The Girard College trustees voted unanimously today to fight a Federal Court ruling opening the doors of the previously all-white institution to Negroes.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14-- Plans for the creation of a merged university with a $120million endowment and a $200million plant were announced today by the Carnegie Institute of Technology and the Mellon Institute. The new Carnegie University will be the result of a proposed merger of the two existing institutions.

WHAT happened to the world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, at Santa Monica during the recent Piatigorsky Cup Tournament? Why did the top player in the world achieve only an even score? This is the subject that baffles chess buffs these days.

TANNERSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 14--Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary and Chief Inspector Sanford D. Garelik were given a standing ovation today by 800 members of New York City's' Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)--The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Leo S. Packer, a former engineering official with the Xerox Corporation, to be an assistant Postmaster General. He formerly lived in Rochester. N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)--The White House announced today that President Johnson had signed a bill authorizing $19.7-billion in Federal grants to continue the nation's highway program for the next five years.
WASHINGTN, Sept. 14--An Administration bill increasing the minimum wage and extending coverage to about 8 million workers cleared Congress tonight and was sent to the White House.

James J. Pelts was elected yesterday as president of the Eckmar Corporation, a producer of Christmas ornaments and electric components, which was formerly known as the Phillips-Eckart Electronic Cor poration.
The General Electric Company offered yesterday a wage package totaling 12 per cent over three years to unions representing more than 100,000 G.E. employes.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 14 (AP)--Richard A. Snelling was chosen yesterday as the Republican to try to return the Vermont governorship to the party that held it for more than a century before Philip H. Hoff came along.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 15 (AP) Four golfers, including Bill Casper and Pete Brown, carded five-under-par 67's today and shared the first-round lead in the $50,000 Portland open tournament.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 Fearless Fab, who will relate any of the outstanding occasions in the football history of the University of Pennsylvania, spoke to Cornell Benny Monday to inform his Ivy League friend how Penn played a 34-12 game with East Stroudsburg Saturday in the Quakers' last big scrimmage before the season.
MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 15 (AP) George Burdon quit his race for re-election as president of the United Rubber Workers Union today. Peter Bommarito was chosen by acclamation to succeed him.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 15 (UPI) A rookie right-hander, Tom- my Phoebus, pitched a four-hit shutout in the opener and Charlie Lau's two-out pinch single drove in the winning run in the second game as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the California Angels tonight, 2-0 and 4-3.
With the revenue from the city's new tax program beginning to flow in, New York's fiscal experts are instituting a hard-nosed examination of the yield of the taxes.

Supporters of the New York City Mission Society will gather at the Charles Barzansky Galleries, 1071 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, the evening of Sept. 26 for a cocktail preview of portraits by Zita Davisson.

BONN, Sept. 15 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's trusted special minister, Dr. Dudger Westrick, offered his resignation today in a move that shocked Bonn political circles. He has been a close associate of the Chancellor for more than 15 years.
BOGALUSA, La., Sept. 15 School officials in this racially tense mill town are moving gingerly, fearful of new flareups over school desegregation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals upheld today a Federal Communications Commission ruling that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is charging too little for its Telpak service.

ALBANY, Sept. 15 (AP) Governor Rockefeller disclosed today that he had directed the State Motor Vehicle Department to permit New Yorkers who speak and write only in Spanish to take their written examinations for operator's licenses in that language.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 16 (Reuters) Thich Tri Quang, the militant Buddhist monk, announced today that he was ending his 100-day-old hunger strike to enable him to continue his struggle against the Saigon Government.
PARIS, Sept. 15 The steady evacuation of the population from Hanoi has produced a buyer's market for foreigners seeking Vietnamese antiques and art treasures, a French reporter said yesterday.
