A.N. McFarlane, chairman of the Corn Products Company, was elected yesterday as chairman of the Business Council for International Understanding. The council is a nonprofit group that seeks to foster a better business climate around the globe.
The city's cigarette smokers will have to spend an additional one cent a pack within the next week, tobacco distributors said yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15 The cost of living in Saigon shot up 16 per cent in the last week, an unofficial survey showed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Senate Democratic leadership decided today to keep the Administration's ailing civil rights bill alive for a few more days. But no one on Capitol Hill seriously expects the patient to survive.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 A fundamental change in the rules of the New York Stock Exchange permitting certain transactions to be made off the exchange floor was formally proposed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission and "conditionally adopted ... with great reluctance" by the exchange's board of governors.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (UPI) The Chicago Cubs sent 11 men to the plate in the seventh inning today. They made six hits, got a pair of walks and scored six runs to help gain an 8-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves. The setback ended the Braves, eight-game winning streak.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 15 Belgium will pay about $13-million of the $43-million expense of the transfer of NATO military headquarters from Rocquencourt, near Paris, to the southern Belgian village of Casteau, it was officially announced today.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has ordered "some cutbacks" in research and production personnel at its Federal Laboratories in Nutley, N.J., the company reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) Interior Secretary Stewart L. Udall said today they could no longer afford not to stop the creeping corruption of its waters.

BONN, Sept. 15 The West German Government, through its embassy in Washington, has attempted on several occasions to keep German citizens serving in the United States Army from being sent to Vietnam, Foreign Minister Gerhard Schroder disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The House Appropriations Committee approved two grants today for the Brookhaven National Laboratory at Upton, L.I.
The Federal Aviation Agency has reported that a campaign to reduce general, or private, aviation accidents over the Labor Day weekend was a success.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, who entered the Walter Reed Army Medical Center late yesterday for what was described as a routine checkup, is spending a second night there.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The total of American military personnel killed in Vietnam by enemy action since Jan. 1, 1961, has passed the 5,000 mark, the Defense Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The man who is raising the most money, addressing the most meetings and scoring the most points for the Republican party in this year's Congressional elections is none other than that familiar figure, Richard Milhous Nixon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The Senate sent to President Johnson today a bill giving Federal regulatory agencies temporary powers to limit interest rates paid on deposits in savings institutions.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 15 A pair of horses from Virginia were double winners at the Piping Rock horse show today.

FORT THOMPSON, S.D., Sept. 15 (AP) Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the United States must act with firmness in the Vietnam war "without sliding down the suppery slope to a greater confrontation."

Perhaps politicians, like housewives, are in need of protection against deceptive practices. CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 (AP) Bert Campaneris's run-scoring sacrifice fly in the 11th inning gave the Kansas City Athletics a 1-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight, extending the Athletics' winning streak to seven games.
A portrait of a stern-looking young Theodore Roosevelt his hair reddish, his sandy mustache bristling was hung yesterday over the fireplace in the Police Commissioner's office.

Benjamin W. Blakey, an insurance man active in Brooklyn civic and community affairs for more than 60 years, died Tuesday at his home, 91 Rugby Road, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 84 years old.
The London stock market closed quietly firm yesterday after making a partial rally from the previous day's slump.

ROME, Sept. 15 The Italian Government won parliamentary backing today for a policy of extensive autonomy of Germanspeaking Bolzano Province and vigorous military and diplomatic action against separatist terrorism there.
DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 15 (AP) The Ford Motor Credit Company today diversified its financing operations by entering the commercial and industrial financing market.

BIG BROTHER was not only watching the City Center Joffrey Ballet last night but actually helping. For this company's very friendly Big Brother is George Balanchine, director of New York City Ballet, its predecessor in residence at the New York City Center, and it was there, last night, that the Joffrey Ballet gave the first performance of a new gift production of Balanchine's "Donizetti Variations."

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 15 President Julius K. Nyerere said today that Prime Minister Wilson had made it clear at the Commonwealth conference that Britain was still prepared to grant independence to Rhodesia without majority rule.
HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 15 (Reuters) Chinese Communist officials complied with a Finnish request and removed all political literature before today's opening of Helsinki's international trade fair.
LONDON, Sept. 15 (AP) an official of a society for mothers-to-be said today that automobile manufacturers should design cars with pregnant drivers in mind.

BURLINGTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept. 15 (AP) Mrs. Sharon Shanbrom, 18 years old, of Hamilton Square, was killed today when a truck went out of control, overturned and landed on the car she was returning to an automobile rental agency where she and her husband worked.

Bold and Brave contributed a polished performance in winning the $58,100 Jerome Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The Wheatley Stable's colt was a mild favorite with the crowd of 33,397 in the one-mile test for 3-year-olds, but he won with positiveness and authority.
Led by the blue-chip issues, the stock market posted another substantial advance, its fifth consecutive gain, in moderate trading yesterday.
The Actors Equity Association and the new League of Resident Theaters have reached an agreement on their first standard contract covering performers in resident theaters.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The American Farm Bureau Federation urged the Government today to break off tariff negotiations with the European Common Market in the Kennedy round in Geneva.

"JERICHO," which had its premiere last night, rep resents an attempt by the Columbia Broadcasting System to capitalize on the enduring appeal of underground commandos who worked behind Nazi lines, preferably with a touch of comedy as a bonus. The start was very thin and shaky, but future installments might turn out to be a massive spin-off from the general theme of "Hogan's Heroes."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Railroad ton-miles generated by carloadings and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Sept. 10, which included the Labor Day holiday were both ahead of the corresponding period of last year.

LIVINGSTON, N.J., Sept. 15 Adm. Herbert Gladstone Hopwood, who was commander in chief of the United States Pacific Fleet at his retirement from the Navy in 1960, died this morning in St. Barnabas Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 68 Tennyson Drive in Short Hills.

FEDERAL Judge Claude Feemster Clayton found himself yesterday once again trying to deal even-handedly between his white and Negro neighbors in Mississippi, and he thought of his son, Claude Jr., a freshman at Tulane University where he is beginning pre-law studies.
Delivery of parcels from metropolitan department stores was back at the normal rate yesterday following a two-week wildcat strike against United Parcel Service.
RUMSON, N.J., Sept. 15 Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Wilson have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gale Wilson, to William Lang Shaw Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Shaw of Coral Gables, Fla.

LINDRICK, England, Sept. 15 (UPI) Christy O'Connor, a British Ryder Cup player, tied the course-record of 68 today to take a one-stroke lead in the first round of the $16,240 Dunlop Master golf tournament.

"The Random House Dictionary of the English Language," the first big dictionary compiled since "Webster's Third New International Dictionary" in 1961, will be published Oct. 24. It is also the first dictionary organized by computer.
Stocks advanced for the fifth day in moderate trading. Investment grade and special situation issues were strongest; volume, 6.14 million shares.
The American Civil Liberties Union pledged its legal support yesterday to help overturn the contempt of Congress conviction of the head of the Ku Klux Klan.
The New York Giants placed Dick Lynch on the waiver injured list yesterday and filled his place on the 40-man roster with Danny Lewis, an offensive running back.
BOSTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)--The Boston Celtics acquired Wayne Embry from the Cincinnati Royals today for a future draft choice and an undisclosed amount of cash.
HOUSTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) Cassius Clay, the busiest world heavyweight champion in 25 years, signed today to defend his title against Cleveland Williams, in the Astrodome Nov. 14.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 LeRoy Collins plans to run in 1968 for the Senate seat now held by George A. Smathers.

CAIRO, Sept. 15 Kuwait's mediation between Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Republic has so far failed to resolve basic disagreements that have blocked permanent settlement of tie political conflict in Yemen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of Robert Bowie, a Harvard professor, to be State Department counselor. Mr. Bowie was once a policy planner for John Foster Dulles, the late Secretary of State.
DETROIT Sept. 15 (AP) Jim Northrup's grand-slam home run capped an unusual fifth inning and lifted the Detroit Tigers to an 8-5 victory over the Minnesota Twins today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15 Fifteen hundred United States marines went ashore in South Vietnam's northernmost province before dawn today only three miles south of the demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam.
Columbia and Cambridge Universities announced yesterday an exchange program in criminal justice and criminology.

The spot rate on the British pound continued its strengthening trend yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here. The final quotation of $2.7903 was 8 points higher than a day earlier.

ERIE, Pa., Sept. 15 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Comper of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Penelope Comper, to Donald Martin Alstadt, son of Rheinhold L. Alstadt and the late Mrs. Alstadt.

SARASOTA, Fla., Sept. 15 (AP) A prosecutor said today that New Jersey could try Dr. Carl Coppolino an a first-degree murder charge next month, but an attorney for Dr. Coppolino said that would be too soon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 United States officials warned today that major troop cuts in Europe as recently proposed by the Senate Democratic Policy Committee might precipitate Soviet "probes" and thereby en- danger the West's defensive flank.

The suggestion that the "entire Jewish community" can be singled out for its opposition to the war in Vietnam is "malicious and misleading," Rabbi Israel Margolies said yesterday in his Rosh ha-Shanah sermon.

The United Shoe Machinery Corporation achieved record sales and earnings for the three and six months ended Aug. 31, according to the company report issued today. The profit mark covers a five-year period since 1961, when the concern began reporting on a completely consolidated basis.

EVEN before William Plunkett arrived in New York last week to the blare of bagpipes, British furniture designers had been quietly shipping their styles here. Leaning back against the sausage-like upholstery of one of his weighty, chromed-metal armchairs being introduced as part of Gimbels' "Britain Today" promotion, Mr. Plunkett discussed English modern furniture and its relationship to clothing fashions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Representative L. Mendel Rivers suggested tonight that the United States might complete its military withdrawal from France by bringing home the bodies of 60,501 American soldiers now buried in that nation.

Dr. Janet Henderson Robb, president of the New York chapter of the American Association of University Women from 1961 until last year, died Wednesday at her home, 39 East 79th Street. She was 70 years old.

The election of Kenneth B. Cutler, Theodore W. Noon Jr. and Willard P. Whitlock 3d as vice presidents of Affiliated Fund, Inc., and American Business Shares, Inc., was announced yesterday. The two open-end investment companies are part of the Lord, Abbett investment manager group.

PARIS, Sept. 15--First reports of storm damage to the 1966 Beaujolais crop vastly overstated the extent of the loss, although they may have understated the anguish of the peasants.

BONN, Sept. 15 (AP) The new head of West Germany's armed forces said today he must have the means to fire tactical nuclear weapons.

MANY tournament players like to be able to study the deals they have played after the game is over and at the recent Summer Nationals the American Contract Bridge League made copies of the hands available to players in some leading events. The Metropolitan Opera will open its first season at Lincoln Center in a blaze of glamour tonight. Tomorrow the new house will be dark again, and it will remain dark for at least a week because the Met's musicians are on strike.

LINDEN, N.J., Sept. 15 Workmen digging the foundation for a factory here today dug up a whale instead, but they quickly buried it again, keeping out for proof only one vertebra said to be a foot in diameter.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 15 The Gemini 11 astronauts let their computer take over today to steer them automatically to a safe and accurate splashdown in the Atlantic 700 miles southeast of here.
MOSCOW, Sept. 15 (AP) The United States Embassy said today that the Soviet Government has made no reply to a request for the release of Thomas Rozelle Dawson.
Anne Nichols, author of "Abie's Irish Rose," died of a heart attack yesterday morning at the Cliff House Nursing Home in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. She was 75 years old.

The Hofstra University String Quartet of Hempstead, L.I., will open its season of concerts Oct. 21 at the Hofstra Playhouse. The instrumentalists are Harry Glickman, violin; Seymour Benstock, cello; Jack Braunstein, viola, and Raymond Kunicki, violin.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 15 When C.W. Post College opens its season here against Northeastern on Saturday it will unveil a new gridiron, an experienced defense and probably the smallest collegiate player in the nation.

The Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue Hospital will benefit from a dinner dance to be held on Oct. 6 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. John V. Lindsay, wife of the Mayor, is honorary chairman of the 18th annual event.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 15 Julian Bond, a young Negro twice refused a seat in the Georgia House of Representatives for opposing the war in Vietnam, won nomination for the same seat in yesterday's Democratic primary.
BARROW-IN-FURNESS, England, Sept. 15 (AP) Queen Mother Elizabeth was sponsor today as the Royal Navy's first Polaris submarine, the 7,000-ton nuclear-powered Resolution, was launched.

NEWPORT, R.I, Sept. 15 Brownlow Eve of Point Shares, Bermuda, won the third race in the International Dragon Class series today and tightened the standing in competition for the English Speaking Union trophy.

LADUE, Mo., Sept. 15 Mr. and Mrs. Wesley J. Barta have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole Joyce Barta, to John Whittemore Less, son of Mrs. William L. Less 2d of New York, and the late Mr. Less. A November wedding is planned.

A coastal storm that dropped 2.19 inches of rain on the city, and 1.5 inches on the reservoirs upstate held the decline in New York's water supply to 300 million gallons for the 24 hours up to 8 A.M. yesterday.
ROME, Sept. 15 (UPI) The Italian Soccer Federation today officially dismissed Italian national team manager, Edmondo Fabbri, following Italy's defeat in the World Cup competition.

Hallcraft Homes, of Phoenix, one of the largest realty developers west of the Mississippi River, has merged with the Ashton Kies Company of Phoenix and San Diego. The two companies, which have combined assets of $15-million, will do business under the name of Hallcraft Homes.
LONDON, Sept. 15 London's Festival Ballet came up with a surprising success at the Royal Festival Hall tonight in the first performance by any British company of Serge Lifar's "Noir et Blanc."

Tommy Burns, who was thrown from Sad Nick at the sixth jump of yesterday's hurdles race at Aqueduct, expressed disillusionment with his career as a jump rider. The 31-year-old jockey said he was planning to retire.
The Lindsay administration is considering not only tolls on the now free East River bridges but also rush hour increases on river crossings on which tolls are now charged.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The nation's manufacturers expect to increase their inventories during the third quarter at the same rate as in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15 The Committee of 24 on Decolonization adopted a report today recommending that South Africa's mandate over her neighboring territory of South-West Africa be revoked.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The new convention for conciliation and arbitration of disputes between nations and foreign private investors will come into effect Oct. 14, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced today.

YONKERS, Sept. 15 Nardin's Byrd, a low-priced colt from Bye Bye Byrd's initial crop, was within one final warm-up of being scratched from tonight's $100,000 Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace at Yonkers Raceway.
Creation of a department of economic and research within the C.B.S. Broadcast Group of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., was announced yesterday by John A. Schneider, president of the group.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 15 State officials told the Monmouth County Welfare Board today that any move to report unwed parents of child-welfare recipients for the purpose of criminal prosecution would destroy the county's and, in turn, the entire state's childwelfare programs.
PARIS, Sept, 15 The theatrical season of Paris opened with a hit Wednesday evening when two new Francoise Sagan plays "L'Echarde" ("The Splinter") and "Le Cheval Evanoui" ("The Fainted...

EVERYTHING in Texas is bigger and better than anything anywhere. If you don't believe it, you merely have to ask a Texan. He will tell you and he won't spare a superlative. In addition to an impressive amount of hot air the Lone Star State manufactures football teams, some of which are almost as good as the residents claim they are.

ALBANY, Sept. 15 (AP) A thorough study of nursing home rates is being made to help develop rate schedules for the Federal Medicare program and the state's new medical aid program, Governor Rockefeller's office reported today.
There were three important developments in the cigar industry yesterday.

Theodore W. Kheel said yesterday that labor-management relations here were improving despite such recent troubles as the 140-day shutdown of The World Journal Tribune, the airline strike and the city's transit strike earlier this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Johnson Administration's strategy for the Vietnam war is now full grown. It may yet call for more fighting men to make it effective, but this would be a matter of degree and magnitude, not of fundamental change.

Zestful, dark-eyed mariachis (street troubadours) and dimpled senoritas filled a small gray platform on the steps of Federal Hall on Wall Street yesterday with a whirling display of Mexican music and folk dancing.

The Columbia Society of Real Estate Appraisers and Adelphi University will stage a re-enactment of a condemnation proceeding at 2 P.M. on Sunday, Oct. 2, in the Waldorf Auditorium at the university in Garden City. Howard T. Hogan, Administrative Judge of the State Supreme Court, will preside.

President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines, in his glowing praise of President Johnson and his fervent support before Congress of Washington's policies in Vietnam, has given the United States the strongest boost that has yet come from an Asian statesman.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 15 The bodies of two United States soldiers, Spec. 4 George Ford, 21,years old, of Elmsford, N.Y. and Pfc. Ricki L. Kreitzman, 20, of Reeseville, Wis., were flown to Fort Bragg, N.C., by an army transport plane last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Despite pressure for quick action, the Commerce Department will not be stampeded into issuing hastily prepared automobile and highway safety regulations, a Federal official said today.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System were trapped with excess lending capacity in the week ended Wednesday, apparently because business failed to increase its borrowing for tax installments and dividend payments as much as the banks had expected.
HOUSE OF VIENNA, 320 East 79th Street. Marika Boyer, singer; the Grace Dorian and Tony Bujka ensemble.

The Suburban League will present its third annual Ebony Fashion Fair Colorballoo at the Huntington Town House in Huntington Station, L.I., this evening. Proceeds will aid NOAH (Negro Opportunities at Hofstra), a scholarship program at the university.

On a soggy day near the end of a dreary season, the New York Yankees lost and regained eighth place as they split a double-header with Washington before a paid crowd of 3,456, the second lowest of the year.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 15 Reginald Martine, controller of Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., securities underwriters in New York, from 1939 to 1954, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 67 Beverly Road. He was 76 years old.
LONDON, Sept. 15 The British Overseas Airways Corporation is purchasing the Cunard Steamship Company's share in the airline for the equivalent of $32.2-million.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Johnson Administration, confident that the United States continues to have majority support within the United Nations, will renew its opposition to the admission of Communist China at the forthcoming session of the General Assembly.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday he was pleased that Governor Rockefeller favored a civilian complaint review board for the Police Department.

The Freeport Sulphur Company, the world's largest sulphur producer, will acquire the Consolidation Coal Company's 50 per cent interest in the National Potash Company, Robert C. Hills, president of Freeport, announced yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept 15 The New York Mets continued to offer aid and comfort to the National League pennant contenders today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Representative Adam Clayton Powell of Harlem, whose support could be pivotal in a close gubernatorial race, refused today to come out for the Democratic candidate for Governor, Frank D. O'Connor.
LONDON, Sept. 15 An Illinois hospital recently lured a neurosurgeon from a major hospital in the north of England by offering him a salary of $18,000 a year, which it said would quickly be doubled.

A record 36.5 million pounds of acetate yarn was shipped by United States producers during August, according to the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. This was 23 per cent above the 29.7 million pounds shipped in July and 10 per cent above the amount shipped in August, 1965.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, the Senate Republican leader, questioned the effective ness of the Administration's anti-inflation tax bill today, but said that he would support it.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 (AP) A Federal Appeals Court ordered the school district of Morrilton, Ark., today to offer jobs to Negro teachers who were dismissed when the district integrated its schools last year.

While the astronauts on Gemini 11 have been setting new firsts in the cosmos, negotiators from twentyeight countries have run into disturbing new snags in their attempts to eliminate the tough problems that must still be resolved if a space treaty is to win general acceptance before men land on the moon.
When you look at this ad it may at first appear that it's a picture of "what's-hisname playing the Hohner whatchamacallit." It's not. It's really what-do-you-callhim playing the thingamagig.

"Perry Mason's" farewell performance last May on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network may not have been a permanent fadeaway. Although 195 one-hour films starring Raymont Burr as the celebrated defense attorney have been placed in syndication to stations, it was learned yesterday that the network held back 40 other episodes for its own use.
A Manhattan psychologist who heads suicide prevention work at the Queens Hospital Center put his skill to use again yesterday morning while driving to work across the Triborough Bridge.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 107.8 on Wednesday from 108.3 on Tuesday.

Norton Simon, chairman of Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., increased that company's holdings in the Crucible Steel Company last month, the New York Stock Exchange insider list disclosed yesterday. The list showed that Hunt Foods purchased 32,900 shares, increasing its total holdings to 865,704 shares of the 4,255,434 shares outstanding.
An international investors' group has started a $7-million expansion program that will more than double production capacity, of Nigerian Textile Mills, Ltd., near Lagos, by the middle of next year.

Space historians will have to invent new superlatives to describe the contributions of Gemini 11 and astronauts Conrad and Gordon to man's entry into the cosmos. From the link-up with the Agena in the very first orbit to the incredibly accurate automatic return to earth, the three-day flight demonstrated a new level of capability far surpassing that shown in any previous space flight by any nation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Senator Edward V. Long, chairman of a subcommittee investigating invasions of privacy, accused the Justice Department today of failing to prosecute wiretapping cases referred to it.
LANSING, Mich., Sept. 15 The Oldsmobile division of the General Motors Corporation offered 1967 automobiles today that showed the influence of its highly styled Toronado model.
For the first time in its 94-year history, the Grand Union Company, the large Eastern retail food chain, has elected a woman as a director, it was announced yesterday.
Two important world commodities--cocoa and sugar--made news yesterday, and prices for their futures contracts declined under the impact of the reports.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. disclosed the economic phase of the Chicago Freedom Movement tonight, announcing plans for "no buying" campaigns and the organization of Negro employes in downtown stores.
The bond market, weighted down by mediocre sales of the $119,875,000 of housing bonds sold at competitive bidding Wednesday, declined slightly yesterday.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation is rapidly expanding its investments in land development projects in California.
Ten governors of the New York Stock Exchange divided equally between the trading floor and the brokerage offices will recommend a successor to Keith Funston as president of the Big Board.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 15 Student demonstrators shouting "Down with dictatorship" battled the police today and snarled evening rush-hour traffic on downtown streets.

The Rev. Vincent J. Powell, diocesan director of the Catholic Youth Organization in Brooklyn, replied yesterday to an assertion by Christopher Weeks, assistant director of the city's summer antipoverty program, that the Diocese of Brooklyn "was trying to charge admission to their day camps we had to put a stop to that right away."
The Police Department stepped up its drive on illegal parking in midtown Manhattan yesterday as a fleet of 39 tow trucks hauled off 146 illegally parked cars between 8 A.M. and 9 P.M.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 15 The hair-breadth plurality of George P. Mahoney, the antiopen-housing candidate who stirred national interest with his apparent white backlash victory in the Democratic governorship primary here, waxed and waned perilously today on a trickle of late and corrected returns.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Sept. 15 (AP) Maj. Armando Fleites, a Cuban anti-Castro leader and three other members of the Alpha 66 exile organization captured on a Bahamian island by a landing party from a British frigate were found guilty of illegal entry today and were ordered to pay fines of $200 or serve three months in jail.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The Central Intelligence Agency served a one-month dismissal notice today on Hans V. Tofte, a long-time agent who has been at odds with his superiors.
ATLANTA, Sept. 15 Former Gov. Ellis Gibbs Arnall, a liberal, will meet Lester G. Maddox, a stanch segregationist, in a runoff primary for the Democratic nomination for Governor Sept. 28.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 (AP) Bernie Parrish, a defensive halfback, became a free agent today, the Cleveland Browns said.

CAIRO, Sept. 15 The Indonesian Foreign Minister, Adam Malik said tonight that if President Sukarno were implicated in the attempted Communist coup d'etat of last Oct. 1 he would be called to testify before court.

IT was strictly guess-what? night at the New York Film Festival yesterday. Chances are that more than a few spectators are still baffled as to exactly what they did see on the screen of Philharmonic Hall. For Robert Bresson's "Balthazar" and Agnes Varda's "Les Creatures," the early and late shows on last night's program, are the latest works by two of France's most individualistic technically sure and determinedly original writer-directors.
LONDON, Sept. 15 Edward Heath, the leader of the Conservative party, said today that the British Government's new ultimatum to Rhodesia was likely to produce the response, "Go to hell."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15 Secretary General Thant told the United Nations today to start finding a successor instead of pressing him to remain in office.

STOCKTON, Calif., Sept. 15 Ronald Reagan placed an arm around an attractive young Mexican-American worker in a noisy tomato cannery here today and spoke indistinguishable words into a radio microphone.

Louis E. Marron of Palm Beach, Fla., a retired oil-company executive and one of the country's better-known sports fishermen, died yesterday of a heart attack at the apartment of relatives here. His age was 67.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 15 The Central Committee of the Serbian Communist party expelled two of its leading members today.
THE question that Al Sherman, coach of the New York Giants, hears the most and it frequently drives him wild is this: "Why don't you Shift Henry Carr to offense? With his speed ..."
AREA A Fishing has been slow primarily because of heavy weather. But along the Banegat Beach surfline a few bluefish are being picked up. The best time is at dusk.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has become the first diocese outside of Rome to carry out instructions by the Second Vatican Council on the new office of episcopal vicar, a spokesman for the Archdiocese said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers struck for five runs in the first inning tonight and weathered successive ninth-inning homers by Roberto Clemente and Willie Stargell for a 5-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates that extended their winning streak to seven and their National League lead to 2 games.
Most Republican professionals willing to stand up and be counted this early in the game think former Vice President Richard M. Nixon will be their Presidential nominee in 1968.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15--It is now "perfectly possible technically for all the world to have good schools, pure water, clean air" and livable cities, the head of the Communications Satellite Corporation told 200 foreign educators today.

Democratic State Chairman John J. Burns said yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's reported plan to use Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. as a "hatchetman" against Frank D. O'Connor was symbolic of the Governor's "political desperation and cynical use of the low road in political campaigns."

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 15 Former President Arturo U. Illia spoke out yesterday to defend the United States against charges that it had encouraged the June 28 military coup d'etat under pressure from business interests here. It was his first interview since being removed from office in the coup.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 16 --Private investment banks are appearing in Brazil for the first time to fill an acute need in the capital market for longterm development financing.
A group of Europeans went underground here yesterday. But they always do--it's their business.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 16-- Plaquemines Parish (County) opened the first of several planned private schools today in an attempt to soften the impact of a hotly contested public school desegregation order.
The executive council of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers recommended yesterday that the local support Governor Rockefeller for re-election.

THORPE BAY, England, Sept. 16 (AP)--Lady Helmsman, the British defender of the Little America's Cup Catamaran Trophy, had to retire today during the race with the American challenger, Gamecock, because of a damaged mainbeam. It was the second successive race there was trouble with the mainbeam.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 18.3 per cent in production for the week ended Sept. 10, com pared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.
Not all the musical action was at Lincoln Center last eight. Two good musicians collaborated on a recital at Town Hall that had some fine moments.

Most of the investing public knows nothing at all about the New York Stock Exchange's Rule 394; but the battle over Rule 394 has embroiled the entire securities industry. It has now been settled by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has made modifications in the rule that are of great significance to investors as well as to Wall Street.

When the Board of Education decided it would not open its new $5-million windowless school in East Harlem on Monday, it signified a victory for Mrs. Helen Testamark, president of the parents' council of School District 4.

NORWICH, Conn., Sept. 16-- Mrs. G. Wyman Carroll Jr. of Norwich and Siesta Key, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sarah Blaisdell Carroll, to Thomas Albert Herring, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Herring of Springfield, Ill. A December wedding is planned.
The Chun King Corporation, a producer of Orientalstyle food, has announced in Duluth, Minn., the appointment of James F. Laneville to the new post of financial vice president.
HOUSTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)-- Chuck Harrison's grand-slam homer paced an 18-hit Houston attack tonight against four Philadelphia pitchers and gave the Astros a 6-4 victory.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (UPI)--Lou Johnson hit a three-run homer while Sandy Koufax hurled his 24th victory of the season tonight as the league--leading Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-1, and stretched their victory streak to eight games.
Dr. Lujo Toncic-Sorinj, Foreign Minister of Austria, arrived at City Hall about 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon for a scheduled courtesy call on Mayor Lindsay.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 16 --The right places to go on Long Island Sound on an afternoon of light, confused breezes were the places that A. E. (Bill) Luders went with Bingo today in the final race for the United States championship of the International 5.5-Meter Class.

WHAT makes pro football so exceptional and often exciting according to Sonny Werblin, the chief of the Jets, is that each game stands as a special occasion. Repetition is out because no two teams play twice on the same field or under the same circumstances in a given season.
BOGALUSA, La., Sept. 16 (AP)--City Attorney Robert Rester called for a grand jury investigation today of the objectives of the all-Negro Bogalusa Voters League and the Deacons for Defense.

BONN, Sept. 16--West German defense authorities held out virtually no hope today that any of the 13 seamen who sank in the North Sea on the training submarine Hai Wednesdays were still alive.

WARREN, Pa., Sept. 16 (AP) --Gov. William W. Scranton dedicated the controversial Kinzua Dam today, calling it "the perfect mating of beauty and brawn to the everlasting benefit of all the people of western Pennsylvania."

LONDON, Sept. 16--One thousand men staged a wildcat strike, scores of thousands of others prepared to go on short time or to lose their jobs, and Prime Minister Wilson called a meeting of the Cabinet today as Britain's economic squeeze began to hurt.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 16--Kathy Kusner of Arlington, Va., a member of the United States Equestrian Team, won both open jumper classes at the Piping Rock horse show today.

SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, Sept. 16 (UPI)--A Spanish airliner ditched in the Atlantic near here today with 27 people aboard. All were rescued by fishermen, except for one passenger who refused to leave the sinking plane and presumably drowned.

IN "The Glory of Their Times," Lawrence Ritter has fashioned an authentic piece of Americana, and if there is a youngster over 50 who does not respond to it, he must have a heart of stone. Crowell Collier and Macmillan, Inc., one of the country's largest publishers of books and educational materials, began last night to move its offices from six locations here into a justcompleted building at 866 Third Avenue named for the company.
WALL STREET'S traders never tire of the airline stocks, partly because they're more responsive than most stocks to news developments.
The American Stock Exchange just managed to achieve a sixth consecutive advance yesterday as some late buying edged most issues into the plus column.
Arrests for prostitution in the city have reached their highest point in at least 10 years because of a police cleanup campaign in the midtown area.
The minds of traders in commodity futures grow uneasy as a weekend approaches, especially when they have positions in a market where a shake-out has occurred during the week.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 16--The rulers of Indonesia have warned Communist China, Indonesia's former ally, against aiding local Communists and insulting the nation's leadership.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 16--The Dean of Salisbury, the Very Rev. S.M. Wood, rejected today as "near to blasphemy" a request of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith that churches throughout the country participate in a day of "rededication" on Nov. 11, the first anniversary of Rhodesia's proclamation of independence from Britain.

The newly formed Educational Committee to Halt Atomic Weapons Spread may be right in believing that the proliferation of nuclear weapons is a greater danger to world peace and security than the war in Vietnam.
THE 50TH ANNIVERSARY Exhibition of the Cleve land Museum is as impressive for its decorative arts as for its more publicized acquisitions in painting and sculpture.
TAYNINH, South Vietnam, Sept. 16--Filipino soldiers began setting up camp today on the plain north of here, six miles from the Cambodian border.

Dr. and Mrs. Renato J. Almansi of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Beth Almansi, to Edward Gootzait, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Gootzait of New York. An August, 1967, wedding is planned.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)--A German-born United States Navy flier who escaped from a North Vietnamese prison camp got a standing ovation from the Senate Armed Services Committee today.

YONKERS, Sept. 16--Effective Sept. 26, all harness racing tracks in this state will be prohibited from offering twindouble wagering to the public unless an option to cash in a successful first-half ticket is included.
DETROIT, Sept. 16 (UPI)-- Hank Aguirre scattered eight hits in pitching the Detroit Tigers to their fourth straight victory, 3-1, over the Cleveland Indians tonight.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 16-- Thirty-three union leaders in Zambia's strike-crippled copper mining area were arrested today.
Rallying around the slogan "I've had enough," the Conservative party will open its statewide campaign today with more than its usual optimism.

Jim Bouton has been the losing pitcher for the New York Yankees 23 times in the last two years, but none was harder to take than the 2-1 decision he dropped to the Minnesota Twins in the ninth inning at Yankee Stadium last night.

Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the Superintendent of Schools, has offered to give East Harlem residents substantial influence over the operation of Intermediate School 201, which has been kept closed by a threat- ened boycott.
The premiere of Samuel Barber's "Antony and Cleopatra" was only one of the diversions at the super-gala opening of the new $45.7-million Metropolitan Opera House in Lincoln Center last night.
Wholesale prices on more than 500 brands of liquor will be reduced in New York State next month, with reductions amounting to as much as $5 a case for Scotch and $12.03 for a case of Canadian whisky.
The city's Health Services Administration will mail identification cards on Oct. 1 to 175,000 heads of families eligible for the state Medicaid program.
A police lieutenant, in an apparent suicide attempt, shot himself in the right temple yesterday with his service revolver in his office at the Division of Licenses, 56 Worth Street.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept. 17--A United States Air Force pilot shot down one of 14 Communist MIG's that was sighted by American fighter-bombers yesterday afternoon as they attacked northeast of Hanoi.

In stepping down as president of the New York Stock Exchange Keith Funston can point to many accomplishments. He was most successful in convincing the American public to own shares in American industry. A compelling, articulate propagandist, he stressed the values of stock ownership to an increasingly affluent nation, with the result that the Exchange has enjoyed an enormous expansion in its business under his stewardship.

HONG KONG, Sept. 16-- Peking charged today that two American planes attacked Chinese territory a week ago and wounded three peasants. One of the raiders was damaged in a battle with Chinese aircraft, according to Peking.

OMAHA, Sept. 16 (AP)-- John F. Johnson, a former television announcer here whose earlier life as Lawrence Bader, a salesman of Akron Ohio, was revealed in February, 1965, died of cancer today. He was 39 years old.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 16--The Gemini 11 astronauts returned here today to find preparations already under way for the next and last Gemini flight--now scheduled for Oct. 31, Halloween.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16--United States officials here believe the enemy is plan- ning a bold series of military attacks, to occur before the Congressional elections in November and to be aimed at undercutting American resolve to continue the war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)--Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio, has charged that the United States is "footing the bill for a $2million, 200-room palace" in Saigon for Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam.

OTTAWA, Sept. 16--The Canadian Government, disturbed at what it believes is a misinterpretation of its position by independent gas producers in the United States, is letting it be known that it still favors large natural gas exports.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 16 Stepped up mining activity in the intermountain area of Utah has brought a boom to the Salt Lake City Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)--President Johnson today proclaimed Oct. 9 as Leif Erikson Day in honor of the Viking explorer credited by some scholars with the discovery of America.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16--South Vietnam's national election Sunday demonstrated that the military Government could conduct the balloting fairly even though it was designed to get rid of the junta as an institution.

SAMUEL BARBER'S stock has been steadily rising through his career. The highest peak was no doubt reached when the 56-yearold American composer's new opera. "Antony and Cleopatra," was chosen by the Metropolitan Opera to open the new house at Lin- coln Center last.
BONN, Sept. 16--The West German Defense Ministry announced today the most sweeping changes in high-ranking military leadership since the nation's armed forces were built nearly a decade ago.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 16--Edmund P. Rogers, former chairman of the board of the Fulton Trust Company, died yesterday in his home on Duck Pond Road. He was 84 years old and also lived at 825 Fifth Avenue in New York.
George W. Murphy, the chairman of Reed International, Inc., announced yesterday his purchase of about 35,000 Reed common shares worth approximately $1.55-million.

Texas Instruments, Inc., began offering its stockholders rights yesterday to subscribe to 599,031 common shares at $92 a share. Holders of record yesterday may buy the new stock in a ratio of one additional share for each 17 held.
The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday it would raise the price of train rails by $5 a ton and of track accessories by $10 a ton.
SAN MATEO, Calif., Sept. 16 (UPI)--T.S. Petersen, a retired president of the Standard Oil Company of California, died today at the Mills Memorial Hospital here. He was 69 years old.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 16-- Dr. Laszlo Schwartz, clinical professor of dentistry at Columbia University and a staff member of Presbyterian Hospital, died yesterday at White Plains Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 106 Davis Avenue.
Robert D. Stuart Jr., president of the Quaker Oats Company since 1962, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer, the cereal producer has announced.
DETROIT, Sept. 16--The Ford Division of the Ford Motor Company introduced a redesigned Thunderbird and its other 1967 models today at a local dealership.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 16--William F. Matthews, a landscape artist, mural painter, scenic designer and art teacher, died here Wednesday at the age of 98.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 --The New York Mets dug out from under the debris of their worst slump of the season tonight by scoring three runs in the ninth inning to defeat the San Francisco Giants, 5-4.
Mexico City, Sept. 16 (Reuters)--Mexico City celebrated Mexico's Independence Day today without is Governor for the last 14 years, Ernesto P. Uruchurtu.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 16--The Soviet bloc ap- peared today to be assessing the possibility of using U Thant's threatened retirement as United Nations Secretary General as a psychological lever to get concessions from the United States on Vietnam.

ALBANY, Sept. 16--Three Republican candidates for dele- gates-at-large to the 1967 state Constitutional Convention have agreed to run on the Conserva- tive party's slate as well, a Conservative spokesman said tonight.

The three witnesses whose testimony before a grand jury led to the indictment of a 17year-old Negro for a murder during a Brooklyn racial disturbance were taken into protective custody yesterday after two of them repudiated parts of that testimony.

THE Harlem Institute of Fashion opened this week with several hundred rolls of damaged fabric, three sewing machines that don't always sew, and 15 eager students. The institute, housed in three small rooms on the second floor of 217 West 125th Street, is run by Negroes to teach other Negroes the skills that will enable them to find jobs in New York's garment industry.

A modernized, unified international plan for medical assistance on the high seas has been completed by a joint committee of the International Labor Office and the World Health Organization after five years of study and research.
Dr. Paul Saville's superior in a London hospital told him his chances for advancement were "excellent--perhaps 50-50."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today the United States had no information to confirm Peking's charge of an attack on Chinese territory but was checking further to determine whether there had been a mistake by American planes.
FORT WORTH, Sept. 16 (UPI)--Manuel Santana of Spain led the way into the semi- finals of the Colonial national invitation tennis tournament today.

A $300-million civil antitrust suit charging monopoly of the variety entertainment field was filed yesterday in Federal Court by the American Guild of Variety Artists, one of the industry's major unions, against an association and the "big five" talent agencies.

Dr. Charles A. Greenhouse, a dermatologist who practiced at 900 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, and was associate professor of dermatology at New York Medical College, died of a stroke yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 115 Central Park West.
The Widorf League of Forest Hills, Queens, will hold a luncheon at the Travelers Hotel in East, Elmhurst, Queens, on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines said today that the nonmilitary aspects of the war in Vietnam were "an apparent failure."

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 16 --Vessels of shipping companies that have carried cargoes to enemy ports during the Vietnamese war should be "barred from entry to our harbors," former Vice President Richard M. Nixon told Utah Republicans today.

CAIRO, Sept. 16 (Reuters)-- President Abdullah al-Salal of Yemen has accepted the resignation of members of the Republican Council and the Cabinet of the Premier, Maj. Gen. Hassan al-Amri, the Middle East News Agency reported tonight.

A JAMES BONDIAN figure who can abbreviate his name to catch attention in the television listings made his debut last night on the network of the National Broadcasting Company. The gentleman is Thomas Hewitt Edward Cat, otherwise identified as "T.H.E. Cat."

BALLET'S share of the great evening was modest. An Olympic athlete can run a mile in four minutes--a choreographer can do a good deal less. Alvin Ailey making his debut as a Metropolitan choreographer in "Antony and Cleopatra" has been given comparatively little opportunity by Samuel Barber and his librettist to display his wares.
BONN, Sept. 16--Three men were sentenced today by a court in Frankfurt for their part in mass murders at the Auschwitz concentration camp.
Stock prices dawdled in quiet trading yesterday as the market paused to catch its breath after the sharp advances earlier in the week.
The Fluor Corporation announced yesterday in Los Angeles sharply higher sales and earnings in the third fiscal quarter and first nine months of 1966 than in the 1965 periods.

CHIANGMAI, Thailand--"A year ago, I knew every American in town--now I can't keep track, there are so many," said a civil engineer from the Midwest. "It would be a shame to turn this place into another G.I. town."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) --President Johnson nominated today Harold Barefoot Sanders Jr. of Dallas for promotion from Assistant Deputy Attorney General to Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's Civil Division.

An estimated total of 3,000 Erie Lackawanna commuters on seven of the line's New Jersey routes will be without service beginning Oct. 3, according to new suburban passenger train schedules issued by the road yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- (UPI)--The Senate Republican leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, announced today he would move Monday to force a vote on his constitutional amendment to support voluntary school prayers.
SAIGON, Sept. 16 (AP)--The United States military command acknowledged today that American troops had burned down a South Vietnamese village that it described as a hostile, fortified complex.
The owner of a Manhattan restaurant and his wife were robbed of $2,300 in cash and more than $14,400 in jewelry yesterday morning in front of their Forest Hills home.
The Metropolitan Opera opened its new home in Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts last night in circumstances worthy of a dramatic opera libretto.
Open Fire, the 5-year-old mare who annihilated a track record at Saratoga her last time out, heads a field of 11 for today's $85,950 Beldame.

WARREN, N.J.--Capt. Earl G. Young Jr. is equally at ease turning a ship's wheel to direct a vessel or to make a table. The 39-year-old sailor is a New York harbor pilot by profession, a maker of nautical furniture by avocation.
A famous 3-year-old filly's second start in four days and a neglected 45-year-old jockey's third and fourth winners in two days marked yesterday's action at Aqueduct.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16--Howard West, pioneer pilot and veteran American Airlines captain who was known as Pop to three generations of aviators, died Wednesday night in the Evangelical Hospital. He was 71 years old.
Charles Cantor, an actor who played the part of Finnegan for many years in the "Duffy's Tavern" radio show, died on Sunday in Beverly Hills, Calif., where he resided. His age was 68.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16--The United States Steel Corporation announced today that construction of an 84-inch, cold-rolled steel sheet mill will begin "as soon as possible" this fall at the Irvin Works in West Mifflin Borough on the Monongahela River, about 15 miles south of Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)--The merged labor federation gave its unqualified support today to President Johnson's anti-inflation proposals. It said that industry had been on the "gravy train" long enough and that it was "time to take care of the American people as a whole."
NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 16--In the gardens of the home of Dana Andrews, the actor, and Mrs. Andrews, Miss Susan Henderson Cole was married this afternoon to Christopher M. Carson.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16-- Robert Whitehead, the Broadway producer, has been named general adviser to the Center Theater Group, a new organization that will stage productions at two new theaters to be opened here this spring, it was disclosed today.
Salary increases for more than 3,200 field staff employes of the Division of Employment of the State Department of Labor were announced yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.
The London stock market maintained firmness yesterday with small gains predominant at the close.

THANKS to the miracle of radio, the opening of the Metropolitan Opera House and the premiere of Samuel Barber's "Antony and Cleopatra" were shared last night with a national listening audience through the facilities of the Texaco-Metropolitan Opera Network. It accounted for approximately 130 AM and FM radio stations from here to the West Coast.
WASHINGTON, Sept, 16-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that he saw no present basis on which the United Nations would be prepared to vote Communist China into the world organization.
Mel Silverman, painter, collagist, and maker of prints and lithographs, died of cancer yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 35 years old and lived at 276 Riverside Drive.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16-- Karl Stangl of Montreal easily won the fourth race in the International Dragon Class series off Newport today and increased his lead in the competition for the English Speaking Union trophy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)--The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, said today that recent critics of a proposed Senate resolution calling for a reduction of United States troops in Europe should have the courage to identify themselves.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Sept. 16--The Governor of the Congo's East Katanga province has been temporarily suspended by the central Government.

A wine-tasting and dinner has been arranged at the Westbury for the evening of Sept. 28 by the Manhattan Society for Mental Health, whose supporters then will go on to the 68th Street Playhouse at Third Avenue for the local premiere of "Bolshoi Ballet 67." The movie, produced by Paramount Pictures, features the Soviet ballet company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- Personal income recorded its largest rise of the year in August, largely because of the advent of Medicare payments. Industrial production also continued to rise strongly.
The appointment of A.J. Ashe to the new post of director of business research and planning has been announced by the B.F. Goodrich Company.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 16 (UPI)--Bob Goalby of Belleville, Ill., shot his second straight five-under-par 67 today for a 36-hole total of 134 and took the lead at the halfway point of the $50,000 Portland open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)--The Census Bureau unveiled today a new population counter--a mechanism of flashing lights, clocklike dials, and numbers that now read in excess of 197 million. WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- The United States has agreed to a West German request for a review of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's 1962 strategic embargo on sales of large-gauge oil pipeline to the Soviet Union.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16--Thich Tam Chau returned to Saigon from "sick leave" today as Thich Tri Quang, his chief rival for power in the Unified Buddhist Church, ended a 100-day hunger strike against the Government.
Prints and drawings depicting bygone operatic splendor are on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art to salute the opening of the city's and the world's newest opera house.

BONN, Sept. 16--Dr. Otto John, former West German security chief, has won another round in his fight for a retrial on charges of treasonable conspiracy. The West German Supreme Court has agreed to reopen the case and review the evidence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- Angel Rosa of the Bronx, 18 years old, sat enthralled on the kind of folding metal chair his father helps to make and listened to Hubert Humphrey talk about the American dream. The setting was a splendid Victorian room across the street from the White House.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 16--The latest effort to draft the world's first treaty on space exploration ended in failure today with the United States holding the Soviet Union responsible for the impasse.
The West German Vice Chancellor Dr. Erich Mende, said yesterday that there had been "an escalation of terror action" by East German border guards in Berlin that had begun to worry West Berliners.
Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson received the first copy of a massive new work on American wildflowers at a ceremony here yesterday.
ALGIERS, Sept. 16--Algeria has asked the United States for more wheat to help meet a severe shortage this year, reliable sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16--A prominent Maryland Democrat called today for public repudiation of George P. Mahoney, the party's apparent nominee for Governor, on the ground that his campaign appeal against open housing legislation had been "spattered with bigotry."
Money is tight throughout the United States now, and it appears to be tightest of all in the big, normally credit-rich New York market.

THE New York Film Festival, playing its pitch in Philharmonic Hall, was definitely on the sidelines of the Lincoln Center plaza last night. All the sables and diamonds and chichi people were sweeping right past it to the opera house. And well they might, because the two programs offered were scarcely what you might call topdrawer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- Congressional investigators reported today that Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara's widely publicized cost-reduction program had produced "significant" savings since its inception in 1962.

A joint management-labor effort may be made soon to obtain Federal funds to help defray the expenses of training about 2,000 newcomers to the port of New York's longshore industry. They are expected to start joining the dock labor force in about two weeks.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 16--The first public appearance of the new Chevroletpowered Chaparrals and a record-shattering practice run by John Surtees of England marked practice today for Sunday's 200mile Canadian American Challenge Cup race here.
Angry motorists streamed into a West Side towaway depot yesterday where nearly 1,000 cars of parking violators have been taken since an accelerated drive opened Sept. 8.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 107.7 on Thursday from 107.8 on Wednesday.
BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP)-- Carl Yastrzemski's two-run double with two out in the ninth inning gave the Boston Red Sox a 5-4 victory over the California Angels tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)--President Johnson sent Government bureau chiefs a new economy directive today, urging that purchases be kept to a minimum and that all agencies adopt a "make do" attitude.

HONG KONG, Sept. 16 (UPI) --The United States Seventh fleet carrier Oriskany, taking a brief respite from the Vietnam war, sent its rescue helicopters to remove 46 crewmen from a merchant vessel breaking up on a reef in the South China Sea today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (UPI)--The Los Angeles Rams, led by Roman Gabriel, who threw one touchdown pass, and Dick Bass, who ran for two scores, upset the Chicago Bears tonight by 31-17 in a National Football League game, It was Chicago's second straight defeat.

HOUSTON, Sept. 16--The National Aeronautics and Space Administration began releasing tonight photographs taken by Comdr. Charles Conrad Jr. and Lieut. Comdr. Richard F. Gordon Jr. of the Navy on their Gemini 11 flight.

OXFORD, Miss., Sept. 16-- Federal District Judge Claude Clayton issued an injunction tonight ordering officials of Grenada and Grenada County to protect Negro children who are integrating two Grenada city schools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- The House Appropriations Committee said today that economic and military foreign aid had "paid dividends" in the world struggle against Communism. It then voted $3.09-billion for this year's program.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16-- Some of the leading grass-racing horses in the country will compete for the first-place purse of $65,000 tomorrow in the $100,000 United Nations Handicap at Atlantic City. The 13-16-mile invitation event on the turf has developed into one of the more popular fixtures on the thoroughbred racing calendar and its 14th running is expected to attract a crowd of 25,000 customers.

Michigan State, Nebraska, Arkansas and the University of California, Los Angeles, all ranked among the top five a year ago and tapped for leadership again, join today in raising the curtain on the first big Saturday of the 1966 intercollegiate football season, which is expected to set an attendance mark in excess of 25 million.
United Parcel Service and Teamsters Local 804 yesterday designated Eric Schmertz, a management professor of Hofstra College, to arbitrate a dispute highlighted by a recent two-week wildcat strike.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 16--Large tents will be erected on the grounds of The Reader's Digest headquarters here for the largest one-day fair ever held in this area. WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- The index of primary market prices remained unchanged at 106.8 during the week ended Sept. 13, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products moved up in price while processed foods and industrial commodities declined.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- A retired New York manufacturer, who at 86 suffers from arthritis and weak knees, has invented a collapsible crutch that, he says, enables the user to walk up and down stairs with both hands free. Patent 3,272,210 was granted this week to Otto Boruvka, a World War I veteran.

THE distance between stage and screen and Broadway, and Hollywood having narrowed to the point where these twains often meet, it is newsworthy to note that another Broadway operative is joining the film fold.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Sept. 17 --The Greenfield Hill Congregational Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Alexandra Squiers Rousseau and Karl Johann Stark.

ATHENS, Sept. 17--The minority Government of Premier Stephanos Stephanopoulos today completed one year in power, and the Premier asserted that his regime had already accomplished incomparably more than his predecessor's had in 18 months.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 17 --Mr. and Mrs. Raymond H. Carter of Princeton and Camden, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Gribbel Carter, to Kenneth C. Avanzino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Avanzino of Tenafly.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 17 (AP)--Jon Brittenum raced 11 yards for the winning touchdown with 3 minutes 13 seconds remaining to give Arkansas a 14-10 victory over Oklahoma State tonight.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 17--Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Dodd Osborne Jr. of Liewellyn Park and Edgartown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Lea Osborne, to Irving Jackson Angell Jr. of Montclair, son of Mr. and Mrs. Angell of Summit.

THE oldest and most familiar concept of de fensive play in contract bridge is the signal with a high card to encourage the play of a particular suit, and its converse--the use of a low spot card to discourage a suit. This dates back to the days of whist, and its prototype was originated by Lord Henry Bentinck in 1834.
STAMFORD, Sept. 17--Representative Donald J. Irwin has become the underdog in what Connecticut Democratic leaders regard as the least promising of this year's Congressional campaigns.

AS a character in more than one of Roger Corman's horror films has enunciated in post-climax benediction: There Are Some Things That Are Simply Beyond Man's Comprehension.

Holiday Lake, an unusual development in Montague, N.J., is offering the concept of condominium living for vacation and retirement home ownership.

OXFORD, Pa., Sept. 17--Mr. and Mrs. William Q. Johnston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Whitney Johnston, to Robert M. Shaw Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Shaw of New York.

CANTON, N.Y., Sept. 17-- Bates turned on the power in the second half to defeat St. Lawrence, 33-19, here today.

BECAUSE even the best quality varnish will not stand up as well as a paint when used outdoors, homeowners must remember that varnished surfaces will need re-doing at least once every year or two.

AMERICAN colleges and universities are wondering whether they are entering an era of basic change in the relations between students and their professors. The rules of student life are probably going to be greatly liberalized; militant undergraduates, viewing themselves not without reason as an "exploited class," will ask for more than an advisory role in the formation of courses and curriculums.
In today's tight money market, the sale of many homes is being expedited by mortgage assumption: the buyer assumes the seller's mortgage instead of seeking a new loan of his own.

Print advertisements usually appear on the same page as those of competitors. Five people besides the client may have veto power over parts of the ad. A new campaign begins every month or every two weeks with no continuity with the previous one.

Heyworth of Libertyville, Ill., and Winston Elting of Chicago.

Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam said elatedly after last week's national election that the balloting had provided "the conditions for final victory" over his Government's enemies. LONDON. ORDINARILY, the "D" train runs an orderly course through the New York subways from the Bronx to Coney Island. Recently, however, it --or a reasonable facsimile-- turned up in a movie studio outside London to serve as the single set for the filming of LeRoi Jones's "Dutchman."

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 17-- Residents of Nassau County can expect a "substantial" increase in property taxes next year, according to County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson. A two-and-a-half-hour meeting yesterday between representatives of the Board of Education and parent groups in Harlem failed to resolve differences over Intermediate School 201, which was not opened when the school year began last Monday.

WASHINGTON. THE "new economics" has fallen on hard times. Not the theory but the results. This has been a trying year for a group of men in government whose management of the American economy once seemed, and was, brilliant. They have not changed, nor have their ideas. But the image of success has flown away.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has called for volunteers to serve as unpaid inspectors at the polls Nov. 8 to insure a "fraud-free" election. THE exhibition called "Systemic Painting," organized by Lawrence Alloway and opening on Wednesday at the Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue at 88th Street, offers us a new name for some familiar pictorial practices that have lately gained the ascendancy among the younger generation of abstract painters in this country. Geometrical painting, hard-edge painting, shaped canvases, color-field painting, and the optical school are all represented in this survey of 28 recent pictures by 28 artists.

A wave of terrorism in which two American soldiers have lost their lives is accompanying the last days of the Inter-American Peace Force in the Dominican Republic. The leftists are being blamed, but the principal victims of violence in recent weeks have been the ex-rebels, or Constitutionalists. The last of the American and Brazilian soldiers will be out of Santo Domingo by Tuesday.

THE toughness of Beatrix Potter is extraordinary. Arthur J. Goldberg, the United States representative to the United Nations, reiterated yesterday that he had acted on his own when he met with about 40 leaders of American Jewish organizations last Tuesday.

WHEELING, W.Va., Sept. 18 --The Brooklyn Dodgers posted their first Continental Football League victory tonight with a 45-27 decision over the Wheeling Ironmen on three touchdown passes by Tom Kennedy and two scoring runs by Charlie Browning. The victory broke a four-game losing streak.

The Rev. Donald S. Harrington, the Liberal party candidate for Lieutenant Governor, emphasized yesterday that the church of which he was spiritual leader would not "be used for partisan political purposes."

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 18--The Texas State Bar, embarrassed by the presence of three lawyers in the state penitentiary who are still licensed to practice, is pressing for better enforcement of the profession's ethical canons.
GENEVA, Sept. 18 (Reuters) --International trade expanded in value by more than 8 per cent last year to a record of $184-billion, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade reported today.

A man wielding a shotgun and a pistol was killed in a duel with the police in Highbridge Park yesterday afternoon after an hour-long chase in which he opened fire on his pursuers three times in crowded areas of the Bronx and Manhattan.

ROME, Sept. 18--Pope Paul VI appealed today for the prayers of the faithful to help resolve many issues of the age, "particularly those deriving from the Ecumenical Council and those favoring peace in the world."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 18 --Brazil is overtaking Venezuela as the South American country with the biggest holding of dollars and other convertible reserves.
Beth Israel Medical Center dedicated a new $3.5-million residence for 300 student nurses yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 18 (UPI) --The Chicago White Sox, getting clutch relief pitching from Hoyt Wilhelm, completed a three-game sweep of the Baltimore Orioles today with a 4-3 victory.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 (UPI)--Ron Smith replaced the injured Bill Nelsen at quarterback today and threw two touchdown passes, one for 84 yards, to pace the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 17-3 National Football League triumph over the Detroit Lions.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18-- An expert professional pitcher named Larry Jackson threw a handful of sand into the Los Angeles Dodgers' pennant gears today.

MIDLAND, Tex., Sept. 18 (UPI)--Arthur Ashe of the United States scored an upset over Roy Emerson of Australia today in a Davis Cup exhibition match. Fred Stolle of Australia defeated Dennis Ralston of the United States in the other singles match.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18--Jim Taylor never wiggled, scrambled or fought harder for seven yards of gridiron than he did today as he carried the football over for the touchdown that enabled the Green Bay Packers to beat the Cleveland Browns, 21-20.

The management of the fourth New York Film Festival has canceled "La Chienne" ("The Bitch"), the 1931 French drama directed by Jean Renoir, because the owner of the rights to the movie has refused permission for the showing.

DUBLIN, Sept. 18 (AP)-- Kipchoge Keino of Kenya failed in a bid for the world mile record today when he won in 3 minutes 57.4 seconds in a race run between the halves of a soccer match. The record, held by Jim Ryun of the United States, is 3:51.3.

MRS. Ferdinand E. Marcos, First Lady of the Philippines, took time out from her crowded schedule of official functions Saturday to get a quick look at the latest fall fashions. The lissome brunette, who arrived here late Friday afternoon in time for the opening of the Metropolitan Opera, was treated to a capsule showing of 26 designs representing Bergdorf Goodman's various departments including children's clothes.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 18--Dan Gurney of Costa Mesa, Calif., won the CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup race here today, beating Chris Amon, a young New Zealand driving star, by less than a car length at the end of a thrilling 200 miles.

Businesses in the theatrical arts field and in related lines of endeavor are beginning to move to the Lincoln Square area, expanding the West Side theater district northward and even bringing a bit of Tin Pan Alley along.

BORDENTOWN TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept 18 (AP)--Three teen-age boys were killed and two others critically injured early today when their car was hit from behind by a tractortrailer after they had stopped to offer help to a parked car.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 18--South Vietnamese officials have concluded that there have been serious deficiencies in the rural pacification program this year and that reforms are needed in 1967, highly reliable sources disclosed today.
LONDON, Sept. 18 (UPI)-- Warsaw Pact nations are to begin combined military maneuvers tomorrow, the biggest Communist bloc war games since the end of World War II.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 18 --Senator Robert F. Kennedy made political forays into four states this weekend telling crowds of admirers that the major accomplishments of the Democratic party in the last six years were innovations of President Kennedy.

Diane Davila, an 18-year-old actress who got her start last year as Juliet in a Spanish version of "Romeo and Juliet," will portray the title role in a television adaptation of "The Diary of Anne Frank."
FAIRHOPE, Ala., Sept. 18 (AP)--Tommy Torbert, representing the Mobile (Ala.) Yacht Club, won the fourth annual championship sailing regatta of the national Rhodes19 Class today.

Controller Arthur Levitt questioned anew yesterday the need for the state's leasing two million square feet in the projected World Trade Center in light of Governor Rockefeller's plan to build a state office building in Harlem.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 18 (AP)--United Nations peace force chiefs expressed fear today that there might be fresh outbreaks of shooting between the rival Greek and Turkish factions.

For openers Saturday, intercollegiate football came up with kick returns of 108 yards and 95 yards for touchdowns, three safeties in a single game, the scoring of 17 points in 67 seconds in another and the bursting of the bubble of fame for such powers as Texas, Colorado and Illinois.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 18 (UPI)--Johnny Unitas threw four touchdown passes today and set a National Football League record as he led the Baltimore Colts to a 38-23 victory over the Minnesota Vikings before 47,426 fans.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 18-- Former President Cemal Gursel was buried today with full military honors after one of the largest funeral processions in Turkey's history.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 18--The marriage of Miss Laurie Ann Sanford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Sanford of Larchmont, to John J. Walsh Jr. took place here this evening.

The city's Traffic Commissioner, Henry A. Barnes, declared yesterday that the Lindsay administration had no plans to impose tolls on East River bridges and tunnels, or to close them to inbound commuter traffic in the early morning hours.

Voters will be confronted by a situation of utter confusion in selecting the fifteen delegates at large to next year's state constitutional convention. An attempt to work out a nonpartisan slate that would be backed by the major parties was balked by Republican intransigence. The Democrats and the Liberals agreed on a coalition embracing ten Democrats and three Liberals, but the two other Liberal designations went to Republicans.
Joe Namath, the New York Jets and the crowd all got into the record book yesterday as the Jets overwhelmed the Houston Oilers, 52-13, at Shea Stadium.
