WITH one exception, all New York Championships are completed within the space of a weekend or a week. The one exception, which will probably be followed by others in future seasons, is the Double Knockout Team of Four.

The Women's Prison Association of New York will open a campaign to raise $100,000 for its Isaac T. Hopper home on Oct. 3. A week-long series of open house gatherings will begin on that day in the home at 110 Second Avenue.

Warren Wilentz, Democratic Senate candidate in New Jersey, last night criticized a plan to give the names of unwed mothers, seeking welfare benefits for their children, to the Monmouth County Prosecutor for criminal action.

St. John's University will open its 1966-67 academic year today in the face of a continuing strike by members of the United Federation of College Teachers. With the university apparently adamant in its refusal to meet the union's demands, the familiar picket line is scheduled to resume at the Jamaica and Brooklyn campuses.

The director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation expressed his support yesterday for the Ford Foundation's plan for a nationwide system of live noncommercial television in the United States.

HARTFORD, Sept. 15--Dan Jessee leaned back in his chair, chuckled and said: "Problems --that's what I like to give those other coaches. As soon as they get on that bus and head for Trinity, they begin to wonder what problems I'll have for 'em."

BALBOA, C.Z., Sept. 18-- Record individual ship cargoes have gone through the Panama Canal in recent months as a result of the 39-foot draft allowance currently permissible. The allowance has been increased because the level of Gatun Lake is more than 86 feet above sea level. Its rated altitude is 85 feet.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18-- Dr. John Kenneth Galbraith forecast here today that the next great political debate would be over the merits of a guaranteed annual wage versus what he described as "our undignified, bureaucratic welfare system."
Foremost Dairies, Inc., of San Francisco will purchase today 550,000 shares of the common stock of McKesson Robbins, Inc., Rudolph J. Drews, chairman of Foremost, announced over the weekend.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 18 (UPI)--Len Dawson threw three touchdown passes and Mike Garrett ran 42 yards for another score today in leading the Kansas City Chiefs to a 32-10 American Football League victory over the Oakland Raiders. The loss spoiled the Raiders' debut in their new stadium.
The New Jersey Turnpike Authority will make its second attempt this week to sell bonds to expand the northern portion of the heavily used toll road.
PARIS, Sept. 18--Twentyeight men were arrested yesterday at a secluded farm in southern France described as a recruiting camp for white mercenaries bound for the former Belgian Congo.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Federal Reserve monetary policy is continuing as tough as before, but no tougher, in the wake of President Johnson's message to Congress proposing tax and other changes to halt inflationary excess in the economy.

THE number of duplicate bridge clubs in the United States continues to grow steadily. The present total is 4,320 according to the American Contract Bridge League, and this figure increases by more than 100 each year. This represents one club for each 45 tournament players.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) --With the primaries virtually completed, three senators and at least 49 nominees for the House appear to be home free in the November elections.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--L. Corrin Strong, a philanthropist, former banker and ambassador, died today at the Greater Baltimore Medical Center, Towson, Md. He was 73 years old and lived outside of Annapolis, Md.

With the dignified air of a grande dame who doesn't kick up her heels in public even when she feels like it, the Metropolitan Museum is putting on exhibition today three acquisitions that would have had any other museum in the country turning handsprings.

More than a score of fraternal, religious and civil rights leaders in Harlem will hold a closed meeting today at the A. Philip Randolph Institute, 217 West 125th Street, to determine what action, if any, the community should take on behalf of Mr. Powell.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- The crucial durable-goods manufacturing sector of the economy registered a definite downturn in August, the Commerce Department reported today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19--Investigators questioned about 30 persons today in the puzzling murder of Valerie Jeanne Percy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)--The House voted today to repeal the so-called "coolie trade laws"--a body of 19thcentury statutes designed to regulate the flow of Oriental servants into the United States.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP)--Lou Johnson drove in three runs with two homers and a single and Don Drysdale pitched a five-hitter as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 6-1, tonight.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis Johnson of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anitra Johnson, to Elliot Michael Feit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Feit, also of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for December.
Dr. Timothy Leary, the leading exponent of the controversal drug LSD, said yesterday that he had founded a new religion based on the sacramental use of that drug and of peyote and marijuana.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 19--James D. Johnson has ended a month of virtual silence to give the state a preview of his upcoming campaign for Governor against Winthrop Rockefeller, Republican.

NASHVILLE, Sept. 19 (UPI) --The Kroger Company filed Federal suits today for $4.65million against four trucking concerns that the grocery chain contends caused an outbreak of botulism in 1963 that killed seven persons and hospitalized 14 others.
Twenty-two American scientists, including seven Nobel laureates, are calling on President Johnson to halt the use of antipersonnel and anticrop chemical weapons in the Vietnam war.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)--President and Mrs. Johnson and many high Government officials attended a funeral service today for James H. Moyers, an assistant to the President.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 19 (Reuters)-- Archbishop Emmanuel Mbathoana, the African Roman Catholic primate of Basutoland, died this morning aboard a commercial aircraft between Bloemfentien and here.

The recently announced reorganization of the control structure for the city's antipoverty program should eliminate much of the overlapping and planlessness that prompted Helen M. Harris of the United Neighborhood Houses to resign in frustration as chairman of the program's over-all coordinating board last April.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 (AP)-- The Boston Maine Railroad told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that its efforts to negotiate a merger with the Norfolk Western system "were met with procrastination and delay."

VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, Sept. 19 (Reuters)--About 5,000 men and women were graduated in a torchlight ceremony here tonight from South Vietnam's "revolutionary development" school, after a 13-week course in fighting the Vietcong guerrillas at the village level.

Roger M. Blough and George Meany spoke here yesterday to the same conference about the same problem--inflation-- touching on what is causing it and what to do about it. And that was where the sameness ended.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)--Senate-House conferees agreed tonight on a $5-billion, two-year extension of the Food for Peace program.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 19--Six American soldiers were killed and 23 were wounded in three combat accidents early today and yesterday, a United States military spokesman said tonight.
The Bank of New York announced yesterday the appointment of Joseph F. Glibert as a vice president in the investment counsel department.

The nominating committee of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has refused to renominate four prominent members of its board of directors, among them Walter P. Reuther and Bishop Stephen Gill Spottswood.
Two high-ranking officials of the City Housing Authority-- one now retired--were indicted yesterday on charges of sharing in $420,000 in bribes to rig painting contracts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) --The Federal Trade Commission, in separate consent orders issued tonight, has banned the American Bakeries Company of Chicago, and Winn-Dixie Stores, Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., from acquiring any more companies in the same line of business for 10 years without prior commission approval.
DETROIT, Sept. 19--Gov. George Romney, a leading Republican moderate, got some widespread encouragement today from a series of national and statewide political polls.
THORPE BAY, England, Sept. 19 (UPI)--Britain won the fourth race of the international catamaran trophy series today and tied the United States at 2-all in the four-ofseven Little Americas Cup races.
Dr. Samuel Rosenfeld, an internist and hematologist at 1902 Avenue K, Brooklyn, died yesterday at Coney Island Hospital. His age was 67.
The Columbia Broadcasting System announced last night that it had decided to postpone Friday night's telecast of Alfred Hitchcock's "Psycho" to a later date.

HOUSTON, Sept. 19--The director of the Office of Economic Opportunity's legal aid agency here, stung by criticism of its involvement in a school desegregation case, said today that the agency would avoid future civil rights cases.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday swore in three trustees of the City University Construction Fund, which will undertake a $500-million senior college expansion program.
Mayor Lindsay proposed yesterday that Congress exempt industrial development in the ghettos of the nation's cities from inflation curbs on business investment urged by President Johnson.

DENVER, Sept. 19 (UPI)-- The Denver Broncos named Ray Malavasi, the offensive line coach, as the interim head coach today to replace Mac Speedie, who resigned yesterday from the American Football League's losingest team.
ALBANY, Sept. 19--Governor Rockefeller said today that the state was seeking $300,000 in Federal funds to design a prototype safety car.
FREEHOLD, N.J. Sept. 19 (UPI)--The highest daily-double payoff at Freehold Raceway in 10 years rewarded 34 bettors with $1,095 each today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)--President Johnson signed today a bill authorizing cooperation with Mexico in solving the problem of too much salt water in the lower Rio Grande.
Stock prices slipped in quiet trading yesterday as the market sustained its first setback in six sessions.

In pricing changes in the United States, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it would follow last week's actions of the United States Steel Corporation and C.F. Steel Corporation in increasing prices on railroad rails and track accessories.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Friday the level it reached on Thursday, which was 107.7.
The Board of Education will consider reviewing its policy of not building new high schools in segregated areas.

ONE of the youngest, the most successful and possibly the most human of the French haute couturiers, 34-year-old Michel Goma, who designs for Jean Patou, arrived in New York Sunday on his fourth visit here.
A Bowery drifter was doused with kerosene and set afire by two youths in a doorway on Mercer Street last night,
The election of Francis B. Wadelton as a trustee was announced here yesterday by the Williamsburgh Savings Bank, Brooklyn, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- The United States acknowledged today that American planes might have intruded inadvertently over Communist China twice this month.
Nicol Williamson, the 29-yearold British actor whose first appearance here last season, in "Inadmissible Evidence," won critical approval, has agreed to return in March as Macbeth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- Representative Adam Clayton Powell, the Manhattan Democrat who is already confronting a mutiny on the House Education and Labor Committee, now faces an attack from another Congressional quarter.
GILBERTSVILLE, Ky., Sept. 19--Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama moved a step closer today to announcing his candidacy for the Presidency.

ROME, Sept. 19--Senator Umberto Terracini, a Jewish Communist, charged today that the rights of Jews had been violated in the Soviet Union. He called for the full "reapplication" of Soviet constitutional measures guaranteeing fair treatment to Jews and other minority groups.
Special Committee on Colonialism--Adopted sections of draft report on SouthWest Africa, Basutoland, Bechuanaland and Swaziland.
Miss Elizabeth R. Hammer, a retired elementary school teacher, died Sunday at her home in Milford, Conn. She was 82 years old.

The Knickerbocker International Business and Professional Women's Society will hold its dinner dance cotillion Friday at the Waldorf-Astoria. Proceeds of the evening, at which 53 young women will be presented, will go to scholarships for college students.

The electronics stocks took the spotlight yesterday on a somewhat depressed American Stock Exchange. Although several such issues showed sharp 10 most active stocks all advanced, the overall number of losers exceeded the gainers by 346 to 214.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 19 (UPI)--The Selective Service System's highest appeals board upheld today the 1-A draft clas sifications of six University of Michigan students who lost their deferments for participating in a protest sit-in against the Vietnam war.
SECAUCUS, N.J., Sept. 19-- Three persons were killed today when a tractor-trailer truck crashed through a metal divider on the New Jersey Turnpike, collided with one car and crushed a second car.
Gennaro Galtieri was arrested today in a Manhattan lunchroom with an alleged Mafia chieftain and was charged with conspiracy in a $2-million Miami hotel holdup.
ST. LOUIS--The postal clerk, an earnest young man with a day's growth of beard, straightened up from work on his small front lawn and cast a proprietary glance down the street of modest brick houses.

The engagement of Miss Birgitte Knaak to George Smart Jobson has been announced here by her parents, Mrs. Guenther W. Raydt and Alfred J. Knaak of Hamburg, Germany. Mr. Jobson is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Jobson of Haverstraw, N.Y. A winter wedding is planned.

CAPETOWN, Sept. 19 (Reuters)--Former Chief Justice Albert van der Sandt Centlivres, whose decisions often ran counter to the South African Government's policy of apartheid, died here today at the age of 79.
The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it would begin publication of a regular monthly report on "the status and quality of security credit" before the end of 1966.
St. John's University quietly opened a new academic year yesterday, despite a small picket line of dismissed teachers and former students.
The psychological "impact of President Johnson's program for fighting inflation appeared yesterday to have run its course in the bond and money markets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- The concept that those who participate in the lawful processes of a political convention or primary are under a moral obligation to support the nominee they had opposed has come almost to the vanishing point in both the Democratic and Republican parties. The latest instance was supplied in Maryland by losers in a primary to choose the Democratic nominee for Governor.

Existing monetary arrangements have been strengthened by the agreement between the Federal Reserve Board and ten foreign central banks calling for an expansion in the amount of credits they will extend to each other in combating speculative attacks. This new agreement does not change the kind of currency defenses now in place, but it enlarges their scope and thus provides a significant increase to the cushion of reserves now automatically available.

A plot of 9,000 square feet of land at 239-45 East 44th Street, between Second and Third Avenues, has been assembled by Chatham Associates, one of the holding companies of the Sol Goldman-Alex DiLorenzo real estate investment partnership.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 19--Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said in the Assembly today that his Government had no intention at the moment of proclaiming Rhodesia a republic.

The United Artists Corporation, which was prevented from merging with the Consolidated Foods Corporation this summer partially because of the displeasure of United's stockholders, has found another potential partner.

PARIS, Sept. 19--The roundup of a ring recruiting white mercenaries for Africa has brought in a former Congolese Cabinet minister, a French adventurer and a retired colonel of the United States Air Force. It is still not clear who paid for the recruitment and why.
NEWPORT, Ky., Sept. 19 (UPI)--City Manager Oscar Hesch died of a heart attack at his home shortly before midnight yesterday. His age was 61.

RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 19-- A treaty published here today makes Morocco and Senegal "associate countries." President Leopold Sedar Senghor of Senegal said it would be the basis for a new regional grouping in West Africa, linking black and white countries.
The Board of Education made peace yesterday with East Harlem parents who had blocked the opening of the new Intermediate School 201, but the board ran into a revolt by the school's teachers.

TRENTON, Sept. 19--Gov. Richard J. Hughes announced today that the bipartisan leadership of the State Legislature had committed New Jersey to a $60-million medical education program over the next six years.

New York State voters will be asked to approve a $200 million bond issue in November as part of a tenyear program for improving and enlarging recreational facilities. This far-sighted project, proposed by Governor Rockefeller and approved by the Legislature, is essential if adequate outdoor space is to be preserved for the state's growing population.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 19--William Haywood Kinsey, 24 years old, a volunteer in the United States Peace Corp. was found not guilty today of the murder of his wife, Peverley, on March 27, near Maswa, where they both taught in the local school.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 --The Pittsburgh Pirates exploded for five runs in the 11th inning today to defeat the San Francisco Giants, 6-1, for their third straight victory in the tightening National League pennant race.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19--Secretary General Thant, despite his anxiety over restraints placed on his initiatives, volunteered today to remain at his post through the coming General Assembly session if a successor "acceptable to all" has not been found in the next few weeks.
BEFORE Georges Kaplan's fall fur show yesterday, his son, Jacques Kaplan, the designer, was concerned about only one thing: a short circuit. Not in the wiring of the salon, but in the fur coats.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- The council of the Organization of American States laid the groundwork today for a meeting of Presidents to discuss Latin-American economic development.

Paul VI's fourth encyclical strikes a singularly anguished note in its reference to the Vietnamese war. Writing to "all those responsible," he says: "We cry to them in God's name to stop." And in the next sentence he adds: "A settlement should be reached now, even at the expense of some inconvenience or loss."
WHAT'S the solution for a stockholder who is con vinced he had a good stock even though it tumbled in the bear market? One theory is to buy more of the same.
CARTERET, N.J., Sept. 19-- Mrs. Helen Rickey Chester of 24 Post Boulevard, wife of Thomas Chester, and former director of the Carteret Welfare Board, died yesterday at her home. She was 56 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19-- Members of the Philadelphia Orchestra went on strike today for higher salaries.
A change in senior management was announced here yesterday by the Hertz Corporation, the automotive rental concern.

Mr. and Mrs. Gregory P. Fitzpatrick of New York and Redding, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Fitzpatrick's daughter, Miss Susan McCormack Sipp to William Amory Potter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warwick Potter of New ...
LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP)-- Floyd Patterson, the former world heavyweight champion, is a 2-1 favorite over Henry Cooper, the British champion, in tomorrow night's 10round fight at Wembley Stadium.

HOUSTON, Sept. 19--A wild pitch by Carroll Sembera, a rookie, on his first delivery in relief of Chris Zachary in the 10th inning enabled Ed Kranepool to score from third base and give the New York Mets a 1-0 victory over the Houston Astros tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- Democratic leaders from Massachusetts--and one from New York--staged a unity meeting today in the office of House Speaker McCormack.

The Liberal party's troubled first independent race for Governor has run into a boycott by two potent locals of the garment union. The union's international president was also disclosed to have been rebuffed on a bid to get Liberal backing ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- Walt W. Rostow, Special Assistant to President Johnson, expressed the hope today that the Soviet Union would give Jews the rights accorded to them in the other nations of Eastern Europe.

The Brooklyn District Attorney, Aaron E. Koota, will ask the State Supreme Court today to begin the murder trial of 17-year-old Ernest Gallashaw within two weeks instead of waiting the usual three months.
Metro-Goldwn-Mayer's Leo the Lion, one of the most familiar trademarks in the American motion-picture industry, has been given what almost amounts to a "Mod" look.
NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 19 (UPI)--Italy won seven of 10 amateur boxing matches against a team from the United States tonight, but the Americans protested that the verdicts had been unfair.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 19--The Monmouth County Welfare director has been told not to begin reporting to the county prosecutor the names of unwed mothers who apply for benefits for their children.
A 19-trip cruise program, the most extensive in the history of the Italian Line, has been announced by the carrier for the 1966-1967 season.
The fire-damaged West German passenger liner Hanseatic is scheduled to leave here today for Hamburg, where she will be repaired. She will be towed by two German salvage tugs.

GRENADA, Miss., Sept. 19-- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. came to this Mississippi mill town tonight and declared: "We're going to remain working here until Grenada comes to terms with its conscience."

The good news from Turtle Bay is that U Thant has budged ever so slightly from his original determination to retire Nov. 3. The hope survives that he will finally accede to the wishes of nearly all United Nations member governments and accept another full term as Secretary General. If Mr. Thant responds to such a draft he will lift one of many shadows hanging over the 21st General Assembly as it meets today.
ROME, Sept. 19--"We cry to them in God's name to stop."

YONKERS, Sept. 19--The sudden snapping of the rear axle of the 1966 Chrysler automobile, which transports the mobile starting gate, caused a freakish accident at Yonkers raceway tonight. However, the eight trotters in the race and their drivers managed to escape injury.

Certified Grocers of California, Ltd., the Brown-Jordan Company, manufacturer of metal furniture, and Instantizers, Inc., developer of a hair treatment for men, to the Bowes Company, Los Angeles, for advertising and public relations.
The Senate's refusal to take up the civil rights bill is a serious defeat for the American Negro, for the Senate itself, and for the nation.

The nation's steel mills continued to increase their pourings last week. The extent of the weekly rise also continued to gain, although production in the year to date was still trailing the 1965 pace by 2.9 per cent.
Civil rights leaders denounced yesterday the Senate's failure to pass the 1966 civil rights bill as a surrender to wrong, a blow to American Negroes and an incitement to racial turmoil.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 19-- The last United States troops departed today after 17 months of peacekeeping on this island. There were no formal good-bys.

THE sight of Milton, McIntosh and greening apples in local markets is a call for home bakers to get rolling. Inspiration can be found in new paperback, "Apple Kitchen Cook Book" (Popular Library, 75 cents), by Demetria Taylor for the National Apple Institute.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 19 (UPI) --Premier Tage Erlander said today that his Government would consider dissolving Parliament because of heavy losses in the Swedish municipal elections yesterday.

CAPETOWN, Sept. 19--The Government introduced a bill in Parliament today that would abolish multracial political parties and make illegal any mixed groups that "propagate, discuss, study or encourage political views."
BOSTON, Sept. 19--Senator Edward M. Kennedy has begun to assume a more active role as head of the Democratic party in Massachusetts for the final drive toward the election in November.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- Treasury bill rates rose sharply again at today's auction to set records, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

On the top floor of the 12story New York Telephone Company building at 230 West 36th Street, near Seventh Avenue, women sit at three switchboards listening, if only briefly, to a sampling of calls placed in Manhattan and the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- The Interstate Commerce Commission, rejecting appeals for delay from the Justice Department and practically every small railroad in the East, reaffirmed today Sept. 30 as merger day for the New York Central and Pennsylvania railroads.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 19 --Harry N. McConnell of 152 Union Street, former commercial manager for Ebasco International Corporation, a subsidiary of American and Foreign Power Co., Inc., died today in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge. He was 85 years old.
The introduction of two new cold-type machines for composition of printing type was announced yesterday by the International Business Machines Corporation.

Desmond H. O'Connell, chairman of the board of the American Bakeries Company, Chicago, said that the consent agreement was "extremely important because we will retain the Langendorf business, which we acquired in 1964.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Sept. 19 (AP)--John C. Doyle, former president of Canadian Javelin, Ltd., who resigned after being convicted in the United States of illegal use of the mails in connection with stock sales, has been elected chairman of Javelin's executive committee, it was announced today.

After hovering slightly above normal most of the summer, gallonage in the city's reservoirs has slipped to slightly below normal. Considering that the summer's rainfall was only one-third of what statistically it should have been, the wonder is that the reservoirs are still about 70 per cent full. This supply can be credited in part to the tapping of the Hudson River; partly it is a tribute to compulsory and voluntary conservation.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 19--The boyhood home of Charles E. Ives, the composer who won the Pulitzer Prize in music in 1947, was moved in two sections today from its site on Chapel Place to Rogers Park, Danbury's principal municipal park.
WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 19 (AP)--Theodore A. Bruninsma who joined the Lear Jet Corporation earlier this month, was named president and chief executive officer at a stockholders meeting here today.

RAHWAY, N.J., Sept. 19 --A motorist being chased by the police as a speeder here today suddenly played the role of Good Samaritan when he stopped, turned around and went to the aid of his pursuers when their car crashed into a tree.
The public should be wary of political promises of lower food prices in the near future, Charles B. Shuman, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- The continuing fall in President Johnson's popularity is probably due in large part to the slump in the news boom. News, like business, flows in cycles, and voter attitudes toward administrations change with changes in the news cycle.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- Reluctantly caught up in one of the most emotional issues of the session, the Senate quietly opened debate today on school prayers.

Venerable brothers: Patriarchs, primates, archbishops, bishops and other local ordinaries who are in peace and communion with the Apostolic See: During the month of October, prayers to the Blessed Virgin Mary are to be said.
The appointment of Edward C. Leibig as assistant to the president of Corning Glass Works was announced yesterday after he resigned as chairman of Corhart Refractories Company, a Corning subsidiary.
FALSTAFF'S famous remark that he is not only witty in himself, "but the cause that wit is in other men," applies equally to his creator.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)--Scientists have designed a collapsible space liferaft equipped with parachute and survival gear to be used by astronauts to bail out of crippled space ships when there is no other way to rescue them.
The $3-billion boys' wear industry will put on its spring face this week at its semiannual trade show.

The Rapid-American Corporation, which operates through several diversified divisions, announced yesterday a net proft of $310,000 for the six months ended July 31. This contrasts with a net loss of $668,000 in the 1965 period. Sales advanced to $306,996,000 from $229,540,000 the year before.

A damage suit, alleging a price-fixing conspiracy, was filed yesterday in Wheeling, W.Va., by the Wheeling Steel Corporation. The antitrust suit in Federal District Court ac-- cuses the Hanna Mining Company, the M.A. Hanna Company subsidiary, and the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company.
A Brooklyn taxicab driver's plan for having one curtain time for Broadway musicals and another for straight plays will soon be submitted to the Legitimate Theater Industry Exploratory Commission.
The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association charged yesterday that Communists were supporting the civilian-controlled police review board in the current referendum fight.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 19--Frank D. O'Connor, the Democratic candidate for Governor, sketched the outline of his campaign in an easy-going upstate visit today, the first since he won his party's nomination.
A day of moderate trading in most commodities was highlighted yesterday by heavy losses in soybean and grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- Supersonic airliners will mean "a better way of life for all" by bringing closer together the industrialized and the developing nations, Gen. William F. McKee, Administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency, said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)--Retail sales averaged $1,480 for each man, woman or child in the United States last year, up 7 per cent from the level in 1964, the Census Bureau reported today.
LONDON, Sept. 19--A psychiatrist from Grand Forks, N.D., today added two 15-minute classical music recordings to his private collection for $4,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- The national commander of the Jewish War Veterans of the U.S.A. said today that President Johnson had urged him to work for "Jewish evaluation and support" of American policy in Vietnam but did not "link" this to United States support for Israel.

Dr. Ralph A. Straetz, executive director of the state commission preparing for next year's Constitutional Convention, sent a one-sentence letter of resignation yesterday to Sol Neil Corbin, chairman of the commission.
Washington Square Press will bring out on Sept. 29 a new translation of "The Divine Comedy," by Dante.

Caseworkers dumped thousands of folders on the desks of administrators at 15 of the city's welfare centers yesterday, contending that the files were in excess of the 60 to be processed by each worker under their contract with the city.
Seven Arts Productions, Ltd., a producer and distributor of motion picture and TV films, announced yesterday in Toronto record profits and sharply higher revenues in the fiscal year ended June 30.
JOE NAMATH might have thrown a sixth touchdown pass for the New York Jets on Sunday except that his receiver, Don Maynard, had to run downhill in the end zone.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 19--The police assigned a 24-hour plainclothes bodyguard today to George P. Mahoney, the apparent winner of the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

TORONTO, Sept. 19--James Callaghan, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today the prospect of a 1967 balance-ofpayments surplus for the sterling area as a whole should stimulate the International Monetary Fund to take action on international liquidity problems.

Bobby Stovall, riding the Shamrock Farm's Francis Xavier in the second race, was thrown as the field was in the stretch. The one horse trailing him, John J.G., ridden by Ronald Roland, just missed stepping on him. Taken to the first aid room by ambulance, Stovall was found to be unhurt.
The spot rate on the British pound renewed its recent strengthening trend yesterday in active trading on foreignexchange markets here.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 19 --Mr. and Mrs. Gerard T. Baxter have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Patricia Baxter, to Lieut (jg.) George Gordon Baxter 3d, U.S.N., her second cousin and son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gordon Baxter Jr. of Freeport.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 (UPI) --Frank Robinson drove in five runs with a double and his 46th homer today as the Baltimore Orioles moved closer to the American League pennant by outslugging the California Angels, 11-9.

Employment opportunities in the transportation industry in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut metropolitan area will not grow significantly over the next two decades, the Port of New York Authority predicted yesterday.
The son of an Irishman who came to the United States to attend Yale Law School, Michael Burke, the new president of the New York Yan kees, has more than matched his father's adventurous spirit.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 19--Upsala may have problems playing two-platoon football. Not enough coaches and not enough depth are the reasons, though the Vikings have 50 players, making up one of the biggest squads John Hooper has had in his 10 years as head coach.

LONDON, Sept. 19--Oldtimers can hardly imagine London without big red doubledecker buses. A ride on one is as much as matter of ritual for visitors as watching the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace.
A new Surveyor televisionbearing spacecraft is poised at Cape Kennedy, Fla., to make the long leap toward a difficult soft landing on a rough, craterpocked plain on the visible face of the moon.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19--Indonesia notified Secretary General Thant today that she had decided to "resume full cooperation" with the United Nations tomorrow after an absence of nearly 19 months.

RICHMOND, Calif., Sept. 19 --A Superior Court judge tonight signed an order directing 200 instructors in the city's schools to halt the strike they began this morning--the first major strike of California teachers.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19-- The United Steelworkers of America overrode today a decision by the union leadership and invited David J. McDonald, the union's former president, to address the meeting this week.
MELBOURNE, Australia Sept. 19 (UPI)--The Lawn Tennis Association of Australia resolved a dispute between the United States and Brazil today by stipulating that they play their Davis Cup interzone ten
Mayor Lindsay charged here yesterday that Soviet publications contained "anti-Jewish propaganda which often is blatantly racist."

A Federal grand jury indicted yesterday Louis E. Wolfson, the industrialist, on charges of selling, with others, $3.5-million worth of unregistered stock of Continental Enterprises, Inc., between late 1960 and January, 1962.
GENEVA, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP)--George Burbank Williams, editor and publisher of The Geneva Times, died today in Geneva Hospital. His age was 93.

AS the Columbia Broadcasting System takes over full control of the New York Yankees by acquiring the last 10 per cent interest from Dan Topping to complete a $14million purchase begun in 1964, how dreary is the Yankee picture? Dreary, indeed.

A PHENOMENON of the current television season is the scarcity of war dramas. Out of 34 premieres there is only one half-our intrigue in the category that traditionally has enpoyed such sustained popularity.
An Appellate Division justice refused yesterday to block a Supreme Court trial scheduled for tomorrow of criminal contempt of court charges against Representative Adam Clayton Powell.

Stanley A. Diana, who retired three years ago as an assistant regional commissioner of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, died Sunday at a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He was 63 years old and lived in Cheverly, Md.
COLD SPRING, N.Y., Sept. 19--The chukars looked like small, fat, gray stones bobbing in the brush as Dutchess, a pointer, caught their scent on the crisp morning air and froze on point.
Beech-Nut Life Savers, Inc., a producer of baby food and candy products, announced yesterday the election of James K. Dobbs Jr. as a director.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) --President Johnson signed today the $3.5-billion foreign aid authorization bill but expressed concern over new restrictions attached by Congress on the administration of the program.

UCHINOURA, Japan, Sept. 19 --Japanese space scientists held today what was called a "perfect rehearsal" of a rocket shot that may in the next few days make Japan the fourth country to place an artificial satellite in orbit around the earth.

Julie Harris will perform a one-time-only one-woman show called "The Life, Letters and Poems of Emily Dickinson" at the Booth Theater on Oct. 9 as a benefit for the Episcopal Mission Society's Protestant chaplaincy program.
THE shop within a store seems to be the latest trend in department store merchandising.
Mayor Lindsay pinpointed last night three slum areas of the city that will receive most of the combined city and Federal urban renewal funds.
BONN, Sept. 19--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard appeared on a nationwide television program tonight to defend his slowness in reconstructing his Cabinet.

The appointment of Ralph W. Morhard as assistant regional administrator for New York of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, has been announced in Washington by Robert C. Weaver, the department's secretary.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 19--Carl H. Lester, former president of Lester Co., jewelers here, died yesterday at his home in Short Hills. His age was 91.
W.C. Goulden named executive vice president of Gaynor Ducas of California, Inc., Los Angeles.

The East New York Savings Bank and the Manhattan Savings Bank have filed an application with the New York State Banking Department for permission to merge, Frank Willie, State Superintendent of Banks, confirmed yesterday.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 19 --Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison refused today to sign a contract for a county office building with an architect he contends was politically chosen.
The International Finance Corporation announced yesterday that it was making available $12-million to the privately owned Manila Electric Company, the leading power producer in the Philippines.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 19--President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines declared today that if the struggle for freedom in Vietnam was abandoned or lost it would mean that the free world had been "fighting to preserve an illusion."

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 With the California surf crashing and glinting at her back, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson dedicated the Point Reyes National Seashore today on the first stop of a three-day beautification tour of the West.

Dr. Frank J. Cohen, executive director of the Lavanburg Corner House Fund, a philanthropic fund at 30 East 42d Street, and a leader in child welfare work, died Monday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 4 Washington Mews.

Joe Frazier, the 1964 Olympic heavyweight boxing champion, will meet Oscar Bonavena, the South American champion, tonight in a scheduled 10-round main event at Madison Square Garden, Frazier is favored, 2-1.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 Damages of $3-million were sought against the City of Los Angeles and Patrolman Jerold M. Bova today in a Superior Court suit by the widow and four children of Leonard Deadwyler, a 25-year-old Negro who was shot by Mr.Bova last May 7 following a high-speed chase.
LONDON, Sept. 20 Seretse Khama, first Prime Minister of Bechuanaland, has been appointed a Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire.

ALGIERS, Sept. 20 The Algerian Government disclosed today its revised investment code, the latest step in its drive to attract private Western capital to spur a revival of the country's depressed economy.
Stock prices declined yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as the volume of trading increased.
ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 20--Dr. Otto Kinkeldey, an internationally known musicologist, died yesterday in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at 19 Glenside Road, South Orange.

By reinstating Stanley R. Lisser as principal of Intermediate School 201, the Board of Education has taken a vital first step in safeguarding the integrity of the city's school system. His earlier "voluntary" resignation, in apparent capitulation by the Board of Education to demands by East Harlem parents that he be replaced by a Negro or Puerto Rican, introduced an intolerably anarchic element into the selection of teachers and administrators.

Mr. and Mrs. George DeWolf Wever of 163 East 81st Street and the Onteora Club in Tannersville, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Claire Wever, to Bartolo Bracaglia of New York and Rome.

David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, urged last night the establishment of a Council on Business and the Arts to "provide impetus and clearly defined di rection" to corporate financial contributions to cultural activities.
BUFFALO, Sept. 20 Three men accused of transporting military planes to Portugal in violation of the Munitions Control Act went on trial her today in Federal Court.
Light infantry brigades, units of a type new to the United States Army, are entering combat in South Vietnam.

Taking a leaf from the President's Council of Economic Advisers, Frank D. O'Connor yesterday called for establishment of a permanent body to provide information and guidance on New York State's economy. He also advanced a number of other useful suggestions to counter what he describes as the state's "economic decline," but none of his proposals deals with the most pressing of all state problems the continuing financial distress of New York City.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) Ozark Air Lines and Central Airlines announced today plans to merge, subject, to approval by the Civil Aeronautics Board.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Mass screening programs are only as good as the follow-up measures used with them, specialists said today at a Senate hearing on early detection of disease.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 20 (AP) Frank Robinson walloped a two-run homer, his 47th of the season, tonight as the Baltimore Orioles moved closer to the American League pennant with a 4-0 triumph over the Kansas City Athletics.
The spot rate on the British pound continued a firming trend yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.

Redemptions of mutual fund shares increased during August for the first time since April, the Investment Company Institute disclosed yesterday. Purchases of new shares declined for the fifth consecutive month.
Prices in the nation's credit markets seesawed up and down late yesterday afternoon, reacting to news that the Federal Government will have to borrow has much as $55-billion by the end of the year.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 20 (AP) Thousands of students demonstrated in Jakarta today against President Sukarno for the second successive day, and again the army did not interfere.
LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP) An American professor contended today that Scotland's Loch Ness monster was really a giant sea slug.
IVY LEAGUE gridirons will resound with the clash of nonleague battles this weekend and there may be some cries of anguish in the league's lower echelon before nightfall Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The House Commerce Committee resurrected a so-called "truth in packaging" bill today, but prospects were dim that strong legislation would emerge this year.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) George Lincoln Rockwell, 46 years old, leader of the American Nazi party, pleaded guilty and paid a $400 fine today for his anti-integration activities in Chicago.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 A Soviet newspaper urged today that the country's legal procedures be revised to enhance the authority of lawyers and to enable them to present a more vigorous defense of persons on trial.
The New York Giants, now in troubled times, began their weekly rehearsals yesterday at Fort Schuyler, and Al Sherman, the coach in charge of solutions, announced a significant line-up change.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Senator J. W. Fulbright, dissatisfied with a private explanation by the State Department of American policies in Thailand, moved today toward a public confrontation with the Administration on its objectives there.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) Pentagon sources reported today that the number of United States tanks in Vietnam had increased to 450 and might rise higher pending performance studies this fall and winter.

HONG KONG, Sept. 20 The Shanghai home of Soong Chingling, widow of Dr.Sun Yat-sen, founder of the Chinese Republic, has been ransacked by Red Guards, who confiscated everything in sight, it was reported today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 Investigators in the Valerie Percy murder case centered attention today on persons familiar with the Percy home in suburban Kenilworth.

Dan Lacy, managing director of the American Book Publishers Council, will leave on Oct. 31 to become senior vice president of the McGraw-Hill Bock Company. He will join the book concern on Nov. 7 after 13 years with the council.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 A caucus of Democrats on the House Education and Labor Committee approved today a plan that would strip Adam Clayton Powell of his powers as chairman and leave him only his title and clerical functions.

LONDON, Sept. 20--Floyd Patterson kept alive tonight his slender hopes of a return meeting with Cassius Clay by knocking out the British heavyweight champion, Henry Cooper, in 2 minutes 20 seconds of the fourth round, at the Empire Pooi, Wembley.
GENEVA, Sept. 20 (AP) The world's major trading nations completed today the initial phase of talks for lowering agricultural tariffs within the Kennedy Round negotiations.
RECIFE, Brazil, Sept. 19 Birth-control programs are developing in Latin America in response to growing public awareness of population problems.
ROME, Sept. 20. (AP) The Vatican daily newspaper, Losservatore Romano, said today the United Nations should overcome "passivity" and play a key role in ending the Vietnam war.

BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 20 An almost evenly divided Idaho Democratic State Central Committee today nominated a liberal State Senator to run for Governor. The vote was 84 to 82, with the prestige of the state's national Democratic officeholders on the line.
DETROIT, Sept. 20 The Ford Motor Company disclosed today that its 1967 model automobiles would cost consumers an average of $112 more than last year.
Frank D. O'Connor accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of attempting to "mask" the state's economic decline, and offered a program to "put the economic development of New York back on the track."

After research on 10,000 babies over 10 years, a pediatrician told a scientific meeting here yesterday that most of the widely prescribed medications for diaper rash did no good and in some cases were harmful.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 20 James F. Oates Jr., chairman of the board of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, has replaced Harold H. Helm, chairman of the executive committee of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, as head of Princeton University's board of trustees, it was announced today.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 20 (UPI) The Inter-American Peace Force ended today nearly 17 months of service in the Dominican Republic.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 20 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith met two representatives of the British Government today on grounds of their choosing in what was widely interpreted here as an attempt by Mr.Smith to demonstrate his willingness to come to terms with Britain.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 20 (UPI) A Federal judge postponed indefinitely today the trials of 17 white men accused of conspiracy in connection with the slaying of three civil rights workers at Philadelphia, Miss., in 1964.

MUTTONTOWN, L.I., Sept. 20 Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedar Brook opened the defense of her Women's Cross County Golf Association match-play championship with a 4-and-3 victory over Mrs. Jerome Covey of Fresh Meadow at the Muttontown Golf and Country Club today.
BLOOMINGDALE'S unveils its storewide promotion today the final one in a spate of similar events mounted by the city's department stores.

Howard J. Samuels, Demo cratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, called on Governor Rockefeller yesterday to obtain the resignation of Sol Neil Cor bin, chairman, and two other top Republicans on the commission preparing for next year's Constitutional Convention.

LONDON, Sept. 20 Three plainclothes men of the Obscene Publications Branch of Scotland Yard walked into the Robert Fraser Art Gallery on Duke Street, near Piccadilly Square. this morning and confiscated 21 pictures by Jim Dine, the American pop artist.

Roland Martini, a former radio writer and a vice president and director of the Gardner Advertising Company, died yesterday at Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 63 years old and lived at 50 Sutton Place South.
The Vick Chemical Company went into the cough-counting business last fall in New York's theaters and at Carnegie Hall in a major sampling campaign for its Formula 44 Cough Discs.

ALL of the top-ranking United States Auto Club drivers are entered in the 200-mile Indianapolis-car race to be run at Trenton Sunday. All of them will be pushing for the top share of the more than $30,000 guaranteed purse, but three of them will be going for more than that ...

Michael Burke, the new president and chairman of the New York Yankees, said yesterday, he had no plans to change the, bseball club's broadcasting staff. In recent weeks there had been rumors that one or more of the four announcers on the staff now might not be back next year.

The New York Produce Exchange filed a $60-million counterclaim against the bankrupt Ira Haupt Co. yesterday, charging that the broker age firm's "carelessness and negligence" had "ruined" the market in cottonseed oil futures.
The medical profession was castigated yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice for "shifting the burden of its responsibilities to the courts" in decisions involving surgery.

Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League said yesterday it was "very doubtful" that the proposed championship game between the National and American League winners could be played this season unless special legislation was passed by Congress.
FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Sept 20 Miss Susan Anne Hanley and DeWitt Clinton Howell Jr., son of Mrs. Howell and the late Mr. Howell, plans to be married on Oct. 29 in Sudbury.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept.20 The 21st session of the United Nations General Assembly opened today with a call by the Assembly's retiring President, Amintore Fan fani of Italy, for constructive negotiations that would lead to an honorable peace in Vietnam.

Michael Burke, setting an exceptionally high standard for literacy among top baseball executives, made his first appearance as the president of the New York Yankees yesterday, and declared his position on the following matters:
The Scott Paper Company announced yesterday in Philadelphia the election of Ralph Lazarus as a director.

Top honors in college football's first 1966 round of intersectional and interconference competition between majorrated teams were carried off by the Southeastern Conference, perennially the chief supplier of postseason bowl teams.

Now that North Korea's defection from Peking has become plain enough to earn what amounts to public applause in Pravda, the question arises: how and why did Pyongyang decide to change its position? As recently as 1963, Chinese and North Korean leaders were signing documents proclaiming their "complete identity of views," and only two years ago the Pyongyang press was alleging that the Soviet Union had cheated North Korea in their economic relations.
The first four buildings of the fine-arts center at the University of Rhode Island opened yesterday in Kingston. The $600,000 construction cost was paid for by state funds.
John J. Loughlin, a stock broker with missionary zeal, arose at 5:10 A.M. yesterday in Princeton, N.J., raced through breakfast and drove toward his Manhattan office as dawn was breaking.
HOUSTON, Sept. 20 The New York Mets passed another milestone in their five years tonight by capturing their first season series.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Only 20 of 758 industrial companies that use credit financing of exports found their operations hampered last year by the Government's program of voluntary restraint on bank lending to foreigners, a new Treasury survey disclosed today.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 20 (UPI) The Nevada Gaming Commission called today for changes in the state law that would clamp tighter controls on accounting and counting procedures in Nevada casinos.

There is a new kind at public school in Queens in which luncheons roll out on conveyor belts, room dividers disappear at the turn of a key, curtains of lead shut off noises, observers watch classes through one-way windows, pupils are not segregated by age or grade and children may sprawl on broadloom during classes.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 20 (UPI) Former Gov. A. B. (Happy) Chandler formally filed today for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in 1967, declaring that the people of Kentucky "are fed up with the loose way their government is being administered."
New York's official recognition in music as a Fun City occurred yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 Vice President Humphrey and Secretary of State Dean Rusk spent 30 minutes today mingling with diplomats in the crowded Delegates' Lounge.

The board of directors of the Motion Picture Association of America voted unanimously yesterday to adopt a new Production Code. The code is the set of regulations by which the major American film companies attempt to control the content and the treatment of their films.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 A Superior Court jury convicted a key defendant today in the shotgun assassination of Dow Wilson, an official of the San Francisco Painters Union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Rev. Adam Clayton Powell is down on his luck and millions of Americans who normally are willing to live and let live probably are smirking at the sight. Few people ruffle more feathers white feathers than the debonair minister from Harlem who turned a safe Congressional seat into a splendidly appointed refuge from the cares, responsibilities and details that turn most men's lives a dull shade of gray.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 Splendid Sandy Koufax won his 25th game of the season tonight, pitching the Los Angeles Dodgers to a cakewalking 11-1 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies.

THERE was a tinge of irony in reports yesterday that the rampaging Red Guards, bitter foes of everything Western, had vandalized the Shanghai home of Soong Ching-ling, the 75year-old widow of Dr.Sun Yat-sen, founder of the Chinese Republic.

Dr. Karl Lilienfeld, president of Van Diemen-Lilienfeld Galleries, Inc., 21 East 57th Street, paintings, died Aug. 23 in Cademario, Switzerland, according to word received here yesterday. He was 81 years old and lived at 200 East 57th Street.
Officially-approved events at which, among other things, dirty laundry was washed in the Central Park Observatory Lake, were criticized with restrained fury yesterday by Robert M. Moses.
SEATTLE, Sept. 20 (UPI) All seven incumbent United States Representatives were renominated for new terms today in the state primary election.
The civilian-controlled police review board has reviewed about 50 cases so far and found more than 40 of them to be either unsubstantiated or results of misunderstandings.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Sept. 20 Governor Rockefeller proposed today the creation of a single state department to bring together a half-dozen agencies that deal with criminal justice, including the State Police.

With a state election coming up, Governor Rockefeller's administration has decided to permit New Yorkers who speak and write only in Spanish to take their written examinations for driver's licenses in Spanish. This may be good politics, but it does not make for good driving.

WASHINGTON, Sept 20 (AP) House Republican leaders accused President Johnson's Administration today of "deception and lack of credibility" and said plans for a major escalation of the Vietnam war were being withheld until after the election Nov. 8.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 A Congressional subcommittee called unanimously today for a world conference of governments at a high political level to get stalled international negotiations on trade, world monetary reform and aid to the poor countries "off dead center."
The Transit Authority announced plans yesterday to provide New Yorkers with prettier subway cars.
THE HAGUE, Sept. 20 (AP) Fighting in the streets and a scuffle in the Parliament building marked the opening of a new legislative session today by Queen Juliana.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) The death of James H. Moyers, a Presidential assistant, was officially attributed today to "an overdose of medically prescribed drugs."
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 The stewardesses aboard the American Airlines 727 jet carrying Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson and 63 other passengers to San Francisco merited, at the very least, the Air Medal.

Mrs. Samuel J. Rosensohn, former national president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America and a noted civic leader and philanthropist, died yesterday at Madison Avenue Hospital. She was 81 years old and resided at 135 Central Park West.

Paperboard production rose 7.3 per cent with 465,000 tons in the week ended Sept. 17 from 434,000 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

THE interviewer was trying to put words into the mouth of George Halas, but the tough old Papa Bear refused to buy them: "Would you say that Gale Sayers is better than George McAfee?" was the question.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that outstanding bankers' dollar acceptances during August increased by $18 million to a total of $3,387,000,000.
H. Morgan Shattuck, 51 years old, president of the Frank G. Shattuck Company, has been named chief executive officer.

YONKERS, Sept. 20 Yonkers Raceway will comply with last week's dictum by the New York State Harness Racing Commission, which ordered that any of the eight tracks in this state offering the twin double would do so on an optional basis, or not at all.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 20 Jerome Chester Cuppia, a retired financial consultant and former member of the New York Stock Exchange, the old New York Curb Exchange and a former vice president and director of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., died yesterday at his home, 144 Summit Avenue, Upper Montclair. He was 76 years old.

BELGRADE,Yugoslavia,Sept. 20 The fabric of Yugoslav political life appeared frayed this week as accusations flew back and forth between Communist leaders and tensions sharpened among the country's ethnic groups.

Decrying the "evil power" of "obstructionist" Southern legislators, leaders in the Harlem community rallied behind Representative Adam Clayton Powell yesterday to fight the move to strip him of his power as chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20 (AP) Saudi Arabia's oil income will rise by about 25million ($70-million), because of a new agreement with the Arabian American Oil Company, according to Saudi Arabia newspaper reports.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The United States needs a naval and commercial shipbuilding program of more than 300 new ships a year over the next five years to correct "known infirmities" in seapower capability, a shipyard expert declared here today.
FOUR snappy young members of the European aris tocracy shook their shoulderlength manes yesterday at Alexander's press show of its import collection and then paid rapt attention.
The Welfare Department agreed yesterday to live up to its contract with the Social Service Employes Union and limit to 60 the number of clients assigned to each caseworker.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Housing starts, seriously affected by a lack of money to finance both builders and wouldbe purchasers, fell again in August, the Census Bureau reported today.

Dr. John L. Herma, a clinical psychologist and author of studies on human resources, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home at Mohegan Lake, near Peekskill, N.Y. He was 55 years old and maintained offices at 120 Central Park West.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Sept. 20 Vast stretches of contaminated clam beds and waterfront homes discolored by foul gases were described today at a conference on pollution of Long Island's Great South Bay.
Without a dissenting vote, the City Council approved late yesterday a $3-million increase in pension payments to 9,500 retired city employes to help them meet the rising cost of living.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Wednesday, Sept. 21 Nelson G. Gross, 24-year-old lawyer and former State Assemblyman, was elected Bergen County Republican chairman early today after a bitter four-way battle.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 The foreign ministers of the Latin-American states took a practical step today toward organizing in summit meeting of American Presidents before the end of the year.
RICHMOND, Calif., Sept. 20 About 200 teachers returned to work here today under court order to end a one-day walkout, California's first major strike by teachers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Johnson Administration is taking a definite, if guarded, interest in reports that North Vietnam may be willing to use proposals advanced by Secretary General Thant as a basis for peace talks, reliable sources said today.
GRENADA, Miss., Sept. 20 Nearly 300 prominent white citizens issued today a statement of principles promising "all of our influence to the support of law and order."

TRENTON, Sept. 20 (AP) State Attorney General Arthur J. Sills announced today the appointment of a full-time deputy attorney general and a law assistant to the Division on Civil Rights to handle an increased volume of cases.

Yesterday morning the board and the Superintendent unanimously agreed that Mr. Lisser should stay on with his entire staff at I.S. 201. This message was conveyed to Mr. Lisser and to the representatives of the parents and other community groups. Subsequently Mr. Lisser sent word to the Superintendent asking for immediate reassignment to another position. The Superintendent acceded to his request.
Sutton Terrace, one of the city's largest luxury apartment complexes, was sold yesterday for all cash subject to $10million in mortgages.

The trustees of the Old Met Opera House Corporation, a nonprofit organization whose existence has been ruled unconstitutional in State Supreme Court, will announce tomorrow if they intend to appeal the verdict to higher courts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The House adopted a $3.04 billion foreign aid appropriation bill today after voting a cut of $45-million from the economic aid total recommended by its Appropriations Committee.
The City Council appropriated $5-million yesterday to enable the city to collect its new personal and corporate income and earnings taxes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 "Go into Chicago today in any home, any bar, any barber shop and you will find people are not talking about Vietnam or rising prices or prosperity. They are talking about Martin Luther King and how they [Negroes] are moving in on us and what's going to happen to our neighborhoods."

The United States Court of Appeals affirmed yesterday the conviction more than a year ago of 72-year-old Percy C. Magnus, former president of the New York Board of Trade, for willful failure to pay income taxes.
WHILE it may be too early to think about selling stocks for tax losses, there is at least one tax-loss transaction that gets popular this time of year.

The new Madison Square Garden Center, which will present boxing, basketball, hockey, track and field, ice shows, horse shows, dog shows, wrestling and other circuses, added a new attraction yesterday. It will play host to the Professional Bowlers Association national championship for six years, starting in late 1967.

Fotochrome, Inc., has reason to hope it can persuade the American Stock Exchange than the company's outlook has brightened, and thus avert its scheduled delisting Oct. 18, the company's annual meeting was told yesterday.

A general 5 per cent increase in the retail price of men's suits is shaping up for the fall of 1967. A numher of leading manufacturers including some who also own men's wear specialty stores said yesterday that they expected suit prices to advance on both the wholesale and retail level because of scheduled wade increases.
Robert Stovall, his neck still sore from a spill on Monday, had a more pleasant afternoon yesterday. In his only trip to the post, he brought home Kathy Kiely ($35.20) in the first race.
The short-interest position of shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange rose to a record of 12,090,993 shares in the month ended Sept. 15, the exchange reported yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 20 The Labor Government opened the first breach in the pay freeze tonight by allowing a pay raise for 3,320 shipbuilding workers as part of a productivity pact.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 The San Francisco Giants lost their third straight game to the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight and dropped almost out of sight in the National League pennant race.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) All male applicants for jobs in the State Department are being asked, "Have you ever engaged in a homosexual act?"
TEL AVIV, Sept. 20 Israeli trade unions decided today to hold down wage demands for three years.
PARIS, Sept. 20 A former Congolese Minister of Information was released today in the investigation of the ring that recruited white mercenaries for Africa.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 20 About 850 liberal delegates bolted the Texas State Democratic convention today and threatened to endorse Republican Senator John G. Tower, a Barry Goldwater supporter, for re-election in November.

There are a lot of sophomores on Grymes Hill, Staten Island, where Wagner College sits, overlooking the Lower Bay. Too many of them may be on the football team to make the Seahawks a threat this season.
The Jewish Museum opened an exhibition last night that is a magnificent recollection of one of the major waystops on what used to be called the Eternal Road.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) Mental standards for inducting men into the armed forces were lowered slightly today in a move intended to make 20,000 more draftees available each year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Defense Department officials said today that there would be no relaxation of the defoliation and crop-destruction program in South Vietnam despite protests by 22 leading American scientists.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (AP) The Soviet Union directed a withering attack on China's "cultural revolution" today, branding it a "tragedy for the Chinese people" and accusing Peking of warring on all Communists in the world who reject its line.
A State Supreme Court Justice held yesterday that the courts could not order the city to turn over to the Transit Authority $84.3-million.

THE French team laid the foundation for its recent European Championship victory in Warsaw by defeating its chief rivals, Italy and Britain, in early rounds. Wild distributions abounded, and gave rise to complaints about the way the hands were being pre-dealt by the organizers. A sample that appeared freakish to only one of the four players occurred in the FranceBritain match and is shown in the diagram.
For the first time in its 111year history, the Miller Brewing Company will brew High Life beer outside Milwaukee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Securities and Exchange Commission is studying new rules that will require diversified corporations to disclose more information about the operations of their various divisions, chairman Manuel F. Cohen told Congress today.

PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 20 Surveyor 2, representing America's second attempt at a soft-landed photographic mission on the moon, began tumbling through space tonight after a midcourse maneuver. Scientists here said the tumbling posed a potentially serious problem.
Operations of the American Enka Corporation in the 12 weeks and 36 weeks ended Sept. 11 brought record sales and earnings, Philip B. Stull, chairman and president, reported yesterday.
The best laid civic plans are seldom made in New York; but when they are, in the words of the old saw, they often go astray.

The executive director of the National Urban League, Whitney M. Young Jr., called yesterday for a "massive education program for whites, to convince them of their responsibility in supporting democracy."
Two union officials were sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy to one year in prison for taking money from employers in violation of the Taft-Hartley Act.
More than 1,200 tape-watchers remained downtown well after the closing bell last night to near a senior security analyst deliver a bearish short-term appraisal of the stock market and the economy.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 20 After 11 days of debate, the tonsorial rebellion of five high school students here has apparently ended in a truce.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The State Department announced today that a Soviet defector who had changed his mind left for home yesterday. At the same time, the department expressed hope that the Soviet Union would release an imprisoned Peace Corps teacher.

THE writings of Shirley Jackson, who died in 1965 at the age of 46, can be divided into three parts. One genre includes the whole wide spectrum of the macabre, the violent, the gruesome, the spectral. Another is that of the wry humorist, the creator of the patient, long-suffering wife and mother, put upon by a cunning horde of children, who....

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 20 "For the first time in two years," said Coach Hal Lahar today, speaking at a football luncheon at the Colgate Inn, "the members of our defensive unit wanted to look at the films of our offense when we reviewed the game with Boston University."

John P. McGrath, vice president and chairman of the executive committee of the East New York Savings Bank, was named yesterday as president and chief administrative officer of the Metropolitan Savings Bank, an institution that would result from the proposed merger of the East New York and the Manhattan Savings Bank.
Some of the losses in soybean and corn futures on Monday were recovered yesterday, but other grains futures prices, wheat included, continued to fall on the Chicago Board of Trade.

THE establishment of permanent performing ensem bles in the music faculties of colleges and universities around the country has become standard practice, and at Town Hall last night another of these groups presented itself for a New York hearing. It was the Antioch String Quartet of Antioch College in Yellow Springs, Ohio. The members are Myron Kartman and Almita Hyman-Vamos, violinists; Roland Vamos, violist, and David Cowley, cellist.
A pension of $19,331,88 a year is scheduled to be approved by the Board of Estimate tomorrow for former Mayor Robert F. Wagner.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 20 The conference of regional leaders called to decide Nigeria's political future reconvened here today after a weekend of intense lobbying.

THE fourth New York Film Festival, not especially extraordinary or surprising up to this point, kept its record intact with the showing last night of Luis Bunuel's "Simon of the Desert" and the Belgian feature, "The Man With the Shaven Head." These are highly stylized efforts, whose approach is labyrinthine and whose appeal seems limited to the dedicated who dote on mystical movies.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 President Johnson disclosed today a plan to sell new savings notes to the public to help pay for the war in Vietnam and to combat inflation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 President Johnson announced today that he would nominate Vice Adm. Rufus L. Taylor to be the new deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 20 United States marines continued a sharp series of clashes with North Vietnamese troops just south of the demilitarized zone that separates North Viet nam from South Vietnam, and United States planes heavily bombed the buffer strip, spokesmen said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) The Commerce Department opposed today a bill sponsored by 15 Senators to prevent an increase in tolls for the St. Lawrence Seaway and to refinance its operations
A white principal who had resigned Monday under attack from some Negro community leaders was restored to his post at Intermediate School 201 late yesterday.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 20 When Suleyman Demirel was elected Premier of Turkey nearly a year ago he was a political unknown facing serious problems. Now things seemed to have changed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) The Senate Labor Committee has raised the authorization bill for the antipoverty program to almost $2.5-billion, members reported today.
Five boys, aged 12 to 15, were arrested last night on charges of setting fire to two derelicts in the Bowery. Each boy was charged with juvenile delinquency, felonious assault and arson.

The presidents of the two new and competing professional soccer leagues in the United States have worked out terms for a merger and the circuits will vote on the proposal late this month, the governing body of the sport said yesterday.
CAFE AU GO GO, 152 Bleecker Street. The Blues Project and Jr. Wells with the Buddy Guy Trio, blues bands.

ATLANTA, Sept. 20 (UPI) Mack Jones supported the five-hit pitching of Tony Cloninger with a home run and a sensational fielding play to give the Atlanta Braves a 5-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight: The victory was the Braves' 17th in their last 19 games.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 20 The echoes of last year's fight for control of the United Steelworkers of America continued today to haunt the union at its convention here.
PHUCUONG, South Vietnam, Sept. 20 In the midst of war, 130 Saigon University students have been operating as a miniature vacation-time Peace Corps in the countryside.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) A House of Representatives Commerce subcommittee has approved legislation to permit the return to Germany of three stolen paintings.

Hearings for 12 electrical inspectors in the Fire Department who were suspended on charges of taking payoffs will begin at 10 A.M. Friday at the department office at Pier A on the Hudson River, Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery announced today.
HENRY ARONSTEIN, president of Christian Dior Millinery of New York, believes the millinery industry and hat-wearing need promotion.
The Board of Education, in trying to achieve peace at Intermediate School 201, paid so much for a truce with neighborhood parents that it found itself in a new war with its own professional staff.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The House Rules Committee called today for a Congressional investigation to determine whether the United States Office of Education exceeded its authority in fixing guidelines for school desegregation.
The Board of Education, in a move to reorganize the office of secretary to the board and create a new office of legal counsel, announced far-reaching changes last night in top-level personnel.

An expert on city slums suggested in a book published yesterday the creation of "new towns," outside the suburban ring, to break the "airtight cage of poverty, frustration and fear" that imprisons the urban poor.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 107.3 on Monday from 107.7 on Friday.
Three recent incidents have raised serious questions about the adequacy of existing controls over radioactive materials.

WEST CALDWELL, N.J., Sept. 20 Mike Fetchick and Stan Mosel played the best golf through the rain and mist today in the first found of the metropolitan open championship. With scores of 68, three under par, they shared the lead at the Mountain Ridge Country Club course.
TOKYO, Sept. 20 Eight non-Communist countries, including the United States, agreed today to reschedule the payment of extensive debts owed to them by Indonesia.
Gymbel Brothers, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Herbert. Alan Leeds as vice president and a director of the departmentstore chain.
HARTFORD, Sept. 20 (UPI) Senator Robert F. Kennedy, has agreed to campaign in behalf of Gov. John N. Dempsey, it was announced today.

The trial of 17-year old Ernest Gallashaw for a murder during racial violence last July in Brooklyn was tentatively scheduled yesterday to begin Oct. 3, ahead of 30 other pending first-degree murder trials.
A tomboy filly who terrorizes colts on the New England circuit made her fourth New York shopping trip of the season yesterday at Aqueduct.
The London market continued its recent improvement in quiet trading yesterday, cheered by the firmness of the pound.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) California, which surpassed New York two years ago as the nation's most populous state, increased its lead during the last year to more than half a million persons, the Census Bureau reported today.

THIS writer had occasion to shoot over some of the 3,000 acres of the new Nimrod Valley Club preserve in Putnam County the other day, and one conclusion reached was that this type of gunning setup will be an important part of American shooting of the future.
Kingston, Ont., Sept. 20 The 35-year-old Boomer, Bernie Geoffrion, returned to hockey today, barreled past his new Ranger teammates, and opened a four-stitch cut on a luckless defenseman.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 20 (UPI) Former Mayor Art Hanes said today he would defend Eugene Thomas, a Ku Klux Klansman, next Monday when the Klansman goes on trial in the murder of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo of Detroit, a white civil rights worker.

PARIS, Sept. 20 The French Government announced today that it would provide severance pay and special allowances for some of the 18,000 Frenchmen whose jobs are vanishing with the eviction of North Atlantic bases from France.

IMBABA, United Arab Republic, Sept. 20 The United States and the United Arab Republic inaugurated today the largest single American industrial aid project here $40million electric power plant that will nearly double the capacity available to Cairo.

The International Union of Electrical Workers asked the General Electric Company yesterday for an upward revision in its wage offer and for inclusion of a standard cost-of-living clause in its next contract.

Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter of the Supreme Court of New York called on Arthur J. Goldberg yesterday to persuade President Johnson to make himself entirely clear about the relationship among the Jewish community, support for the war in Vietnam and aid to Israel

CAIRO, Sept. 19 In a bold political power play, President Gamal Abdel Nasser has moved to squelch a growing movement among Yemen's republican leaders to reduce Egyptian domination over their country and to reopen peace talks with the Yemeni royalists.
