United States Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach declared yesterday that antitrust policy was part and parcel of the Government's antiinflation arsenal.
The Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York, representing 255,000 workers, unanimously endorsed Governor Rockefeller for reelection yesterday.

DALLAS, Sept. 20 A substantial enlargement of the Vietnam conflict or the need for significant military intervention in some other area of the world will probably require the complete mobilization of the nation's merchant fleet, Frank A. Nemec, president of the Lykes Bros. Steamship Company, Inc., said today.

PARIS, Sept. 20 The government-owned Renault Antomobile Company, France's biggest, has contracted with Bulgaria for the assembly of its cats there, it was reported here today. This will be Bulgaria's first automobile production unit and Renault's third deal in with eastern Europe in recent months, although it is the smallest of the three.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson attended the gala opening of the 44th annual opera season tonight. But instead of entering at the fashionable carriage entrance in front of the opera house, where the president of the San Francisco Opera Association and other dignitaries were waiting to greet her, the First Lady was whisked around to the back stairs by her Secret Service escort.
The stock market continued in a slow-paced retreat yesterday as modest selling pressure again nibbled away at the gains made last week.

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 20 Thomas W. Sweeney, head of Sweeney Bell, Inc., New York insurance brokers, and former Mayor of this township, died yesterday at Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 16 Maryland Road here.,

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 20 (UPI) Art Arfons hit 443 miles an hour today in a test run on western Utah's salt flats, but the weight on his jet-powered racer shifted during the run and gouged chunks of rubber from his rear tires.

Some of the new economists on the Federal Reserve Board would like to see a full restoration of "coordination" between its monetary policy and the Administration's fiscal policy that had been standard operating procedure until late last year.
WASHINGTON, Sept, 20 Project Eros, an ambitious program to study the earth's natural resources from space, was announced today by Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.'s Liberal campaign for Governor got off to a dismal start in Harlem yesterday a fizzle in a drizzle.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 The United Nations has started its second twenty years on a melancholy note. "The relationship between the big powers," said the Secretary General, U Thant, "has dropped to a new low. To my knowledge, there has not been any meaningful dialogue between Washington and Moscow for a long time. I think it is a very regrettable situation."

A YOUNG girl lost in the abyss of madness is the key to Gerald Arpino's starkly dramatic "Incubus," which was danced by the City Center Joffrey Ballet last night at the New York City Center, at the start of the third and last week of the company's current New York season.

CAIRO, Sept. 21--With Egyptian backing, President Abdullah al-Salal of Yemen is apparently preparing a purge of his leading political rivals by putting them on trial for offenses against the state in an effort to solidfy his control of the republican regime.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)--Senator Frank J. Lausche, Democrat of Ohio, broke with his Midwest colleagues today, advising them that Congress could not look "with indifference and cynicism" on the obligations it made in financing the St. Lawrence Seaway.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (AP) --Vern Fuller's first major league home run--a tie-breaking shot in the fifth inning off Jim Kaat--sparked the Cleveland Indians to a 6-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins tonight.
At long last the House of Representatives seems to be coming to grips with Representative Adam Clayton Powell.

TRENTON, Sept. 21--A Monmouth County social caseworker, told a State Migrant Labor Board hearing today that at one Monmouth camp a group of migrants and their small children ate potatoes and nothing else for a week.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 22--Lieut. Col. Nguyen Van Luan, the stocky chief of the Saigon police, gave his departing visitor a word of advice.

New collective bargaining procedures aimed at improving municipal labor relations and resolving deadlocks without strikes received strong support yesterday from a majority of speakers at an all-day hearing before the City Council.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 21--Mr. and Mrs. George Proctor Wanty have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Primrose Wanty, to Peter Lunt Goldsmith. He is the son of Mrs. Sybil Graham Goldsmith of Darien, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., and Samuel Lunt Goldsmith Jr. of New York.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)--The House Commerce Committee increased chances for a "truth-in-packaging" bill today by killing a major provision opposed by Republicans and industry.

IF THINGS are as like as two peas in a pod, it is equally valid to say they are as unlike as two pairs of chopsticks. Mrs. Grace Chu, author of "The Pleasures of Chinese Cooking" and the woman who might be called the doyenne of those who teach Chinese cookery in New York, has an impressive collection of the eating utensils that range in make from bamboo to gold.
MOSCOW, Sept. 21 (AP)-- held in Baku is well and a Soviet investigation of his case is continuing, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

THERE are some ballets where all the characters, or noncharacters, seem to be searching for something and never find it. Gloria Contreras's "Vitalitas," seen for the first time in a new production by the City Center Joffrey Ballet at the New York City Center last night, turned out to be one of those ballets. In a red light.
Secretary of State Dean Rusk said yesterday that the United States was doing "what we can to increase contacts with the Soviet people to blunt disputes and to reduce the danger of a great war."
The election of William J. Shields, vice president of Barber Steamship Lines, Inc., as president was announced here yesterday by the Foreign Commerce Club of New York, Inc.
The annual Lighthouse Award Luncheon will be held at the Plaza on Oct. 20. The co-chairmen are Mrs. Donald S. Stralem and Fred Rudge.
OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 21--Miss Elaine Greenfield and Gary Allen Gerstein plan to marry in December.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--The House voted today to give the Reserves specific status as a military force and to allow the President to call many of them into active duty without declaring a national emergency.
The use of the electronic computer in matching a job applicant with the right employer is making rapid gains.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies opened its 49th annual campaign last night with a record goal of $24.2-million for the support of 130 New York institutions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- The Securities and Exchange Commission informed an appeals court today that it was working on the problem of reducing New York Stock Exchange commissions for large-volume purchases of stock.

MASTER Anthony Santasiere, a retired New York high school teacher now living in Coral Gables, Fla., won the first of his 14 chess titles in 1922 when he became champion of the Marshall Chess Club. He won his most recent first prize this year in the Coral Gables Open.
While two men lay horribly burned in St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday, five boys accused of setting them afire appeared with their tearful parents in Children's Court.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 21--E. Stanley Turnbull, a portrait painter and the former director of the Old Mill Art School at Elizabethtown, died in a hospital here on Saturday. His age was 78.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- The Treasury started using a new financing device today to raise additional funds.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 21 (UPI)--A program to provide medical care, educational opportunities and entertainment to villages bordering the Mekong River between Laos and Thailand was announced today by Shirley MacLaine, the actress, and Dr. Verne E. Chaney.
DETROIT, Sept. 21--The Chrysler Corporation increased prices today on its 1967 model automobiles, a day after the Ford Motor Company announced similar action.
"Requiem Canticles," a new 15-minute work by Igor Stravinsky for chorus, orchestra and four solo voices, will be given its first performance Oct. 8 in Princeton University's McCarter Theater.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)--J. Edgar Hoover today deplored hairdos and clothing styles that he said sometimes made it difficult to tell the boys from the girls.

The New York Telephone Company is converting some lots adjoining its building at 50 Thayer Street in the Inwood section of upper Manhattan into a vest pocket park with walks and benches amidst shade trees, bushes and grass.
CAPETOWN, Sept. 21-- Prime Minister Balthazar J. Vorster announced today that he planned to continue South Africa's policy of strict formal neutrality on Rhodesia.

THOUGH the New York Jets trounced the Hous ton Oilers, 52-13, last Sunday, they are not, simple arithmetic notwithstanding, 39 points better than the Oilers. But the Jets did prove that they had become a good team, certainly better than the Jet teams that stumbled to 5-8-1 ...
The Lindsay administration has increased salaries for nine city jobs and created two new positions at a total cost of $52,650 a year.
The directors of American Airlines, Inc., approved plans yesterday offering the company's stockholders the right to subscribe to an issue of 25-year convertible subordinated debentures.
PRESIDENT JOHNSON'S proposal to suspend accel erated depreciation on buildings for 16 months has purveyors of investment real estate--and their clients--up in arms.
BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 21--A wiretap expert said today that he believed Congressional telephone lines had been monitored, possibly by a Government agency.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- The Johnson Administration took action against the nation's economic ailments today with restrictions on interest rates, a freeze on Federal hiring, criticism of increased automobile prices and another hint about possible tax increases to come.

BLOOMFIELD, Conn., Sept. 21--Connecticut's leading judges, prosecutors, police officers and newspaper editors spent the day here discussing criminal justice in a symposium that saw several basic splits along traditional lines.

THE man who created the Yankee dynasty was Ed Barrow, perhaps the greatest empire-builder that baseball has ever produced. He was a big, broad-shouldered man who feared no one and could argue as forcefully with his fists as with his tongue. He was such a complete dictator that he merely had to mutter, "Close the window," and subordinates fell over themselves to close the window.

The Cities Service Company and the United Nuclear Corporation announced yesterday that they had mutually agreed to terminate discussion and studies on the acquisition of United Nuclear by Cities Service.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 21-- The Nigerian leaders' talks headed for a showdown today over whether the Eastern Region would bow to a new formula creating small ethnic states within a tight federation.

Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara has been asked to explain his Department's policy of eliminating overtime, which in some cases has led to higher shipping costs, Senator Daniel B. Brewster disclosed yesterday.
The city will reduce the number of beds for acutely ill general patients by 1,000, or 10 per cent, in its hospitals, Dr. Howard J. Brown, Health Services Administrator, said yesterday.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Sept. 21 --Mr. and Mrs. Roy Milford Kime have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bonnie Burton Kime, to Thomas Russell Scott Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott of Norwood, Pa.
Prices on the London stock market closed yesterday with a predominance of small losses.
PARIS, Sept. 21 (AP)--A Trans World Airlines spokesman said tonight that TWA's New York-Zurich flight last night was buzzed by a French warplane southwest of Paris.
The Lindsay administration is preparing legislation to provide tax relief for industries establishing production facilities in four ghetto areas of the city.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler declared yesterday that the 7 per cent investment tax credit would be restored even before its scheduled resumption at the end of next year if economic conditions warranted such a move.

ATLANTA, Sept. 21 (AP)-- Denis Menke drove in four runs with two homers and Dick Kelley, a rookie, pitched a three-hitter as the Atlanta Braves blanked the Cardinals, 4-0, tonight. It was the Braves' fifth straight victory.

PORT CHICAGO, Calif., Sept. 21 (AP)--Pistol shots rang out today in the streets of nearby Clyde, patrolled by armed vigilantes reminiscent of the Old West since Vietnam war demonstrators established a headquarters in the hamlet.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 21-- Combating disaffection within the Republican party has become a major problem for Gov. Mark O. Hatfield in his bid for a United States Senate seat. The disaffection arises from his stand on the Vietnam war.
Expiration day often brings declines in current futures contracts, as longs rush to even out their positions. Yesterday was no exception for the major grains and soybeans.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- A bill to preserve coastal fish and wildlife areas throughout the country, and on Long Island in particular, moved a big step closer today to passage by Congress.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 21--The purge in the ruling Communist party spread to the Montenegro today as members of that republic's Central Committee met in Titograd.
David Amram has been named the first composer-in-residence of the New York Philharmonic.

LONDON, Sept. 21--Communist China is buying gold here and on the Continent, banking sources said today. They attributed some of the activity on the London gold market today-- which carried the price up 1 cents, from $35.17 7/8 to $35.19 1/8 an ounce--to purchases made on Chinese account.

WAHINGTON, Sept. 21-- The Soviet Union has protested to the United States over American plans to conduct underwater explosions off the Kurile Islands as part of a research program to improve detection of underground nuclear explosions.

In selecting Attorney General Nicholas Katzenbach as Under Secretary of State, President Johnson has accomplished one of those surprises in which he delights. He has also chosen an able man to fill a difficult post.

DALLAS, Sept. 21--Juan Trippe, chairman and chief executive officer of Pan American World Airways, urged the United States Government today to allow two prototypes of the American supersonic transport to be built instead of one.

PARIS, Sept. 21--"Marat/ Sade," the recent hit play in London and New York, opened here last night to a commotion raised by the descendants of the revolutionary, Marat, and a descendant of the notorious Marquis de Sade, but to the evident delight of the audience.

YONKERS, Sept. 21--If the weather continues on the soggy side, the 14 juvenile standardbreds set to start tomorrow night in the E. Roland Harriman Trot, a $100,000 item for 2-year-olds, are likely to find themselves trotting one mile over the most pronounced offtrack they have been asked to tour so far.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 21--Mrs. Winston H. Hagen has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Audrey Ramsay Hagen, to James Bertch Patterson, son of Mrs. Harold H. Patterson of Tulsa, Okla., and the late Mr. Patterson.
Egypt's President Nasser has taken some substantial risks by sanctioning the recent coup in Yemen that makes the new republican government there his transparent puppet.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (UPI)-- A New York firm that spent a year studying Chicago's cultural needs handed in a 180page report yesterday and recommended a $31-million program, through 1980, to subsidize the arts.
HONG KONG, Sept. 21--The Chinese Communist press has been reorganized to insure its loyalty to Mao Tse-tung and his chief deputy, Lin Piao.
Dr. D. William Scotti, professor of clinical pediatrics at the New York University School of Medicine, died yesterday in his home at 8 Peter Cooper Road. He was 67 years old.
The inability of many people to drink milk without suffering ill effects may be a clue to how evolution adapted man to his environment, two Baltimore doctors report.

A formal complaint against new rates for electricity and steam slated to be collected by the Consolidated Edison Company beginning Monday was filed by Mayor Lindsay yesterday with the state Public Service Commission.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 21--A major political issue has developed in South Korea over a smuggling scandal in which the country's biggest industrial concern, Samsung, is alleged to have been involved.
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 22 (AP)--Communist China has asked foreign students to leave by the end of this month, a Japanese report from Peking said today.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 21--A small group of poets and writers who believe that wine is "the drink of the gods and the bards" are challenging India's official prohibition policy.

The president of the Aquafilter Corporation, a Massachusetts company that manufactures filtering devices for cigarettes, was sentenced here yesterday by Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman to 30 days in prison and fined $3,000. He was also placed on probation for one year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--A House Judiciary subcommittee today approved a bill overhauling the nation's copyright system for the first time since 1909.
A 40-year-old woman, trapped in the bedroom of her burning Park Avenue apartment, was saved yesterday by instructions telephoned by a Fire Department dispatcher.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Urbane, eloquent and cultivated, a scholar with a taste for jaunty bow ties, gaudy waistcoats, and fine foods and wine, a man with insatiable intellectual curiosity and deep compassion.

Thirty Roman Catholic laymen and priests and a nun announced yesterday the formation of a national Institute for Freedom in the Church, designed to open channels of "democratic communication and mediation."

The moon-bound Surveyor 2, crippled by an inoperative steering rocket, raced out of control last night toward a probable crash landing on the lunar surface.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Republicans will probably lose a little strength in the Senate while making an average offyear gain in the House in this fall's Congressional elections, a national survey finds.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., and National Airlines, Inc., both grounded through Aug. 19 by the machinists strike, reported yesterday deficit operations for August.
The sharp debate in the West German Parliament over the Government's military policies emphasized that the German Army has reached the end of a troubled era and faces an uncertain future.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 21 --Sydney Griswold Berry of 53 Gordonhurst Avenue, in Upper Montclair, a partner of Berry Crews, patent lawyers in New York, died of a heart attack on Monday in Beirut, Lebanon. He was 72 years old.

Funk Wagnalls will publish tomorrow its "Standard Desk Dictionary." The work contains 100,000 entries, has a thumb index and is priced at $4.95. Funk Wagnalls is a division of Reader's Digest Books, Inc.
VIENNA, Sept. 21--Pote Sarasin of Thailand was elected president today of the International Atomic Energy Agency for the coming year at the opening of its 10th general conference.

Judge Arthur A. Klotz, presiding over a jury trial in Queens Civil Court over the validity of a contract between a union and its dismissed business manager, refused yesterday to allow testimony about alleged looting of the union's welfare funds
The Rev. Francis K. Shepherd, well known in Greenwich Village as pastor of the former North Baptist Church, died Tuesday in his home at 2 Bank Street. His age was 80.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 21--The engagement of Miss Ann Brewster to Frank E. Toole Jr., son of Mrs. Frank Edward Toole of New Haven, and the late Dr. Toole, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. O.H. Brewster.

MONTREAL, Sept. 21 (Canadian Press)--The National Hockey League's 50th anniversary season will get under way Wednesday, Oct. 19, with the four United States teams swinging into action three days ahead of their Canadian counterparts.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 21--Mrs. Kinta des Mare Merrill de Rham of Southampton and New York, widow of S. Whitney de Rham, was married today to Count Alfredo di Carpegna of Rome. Msgr. G.H. Killeen performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart.
PARIS, Sept. 21--Paul Reynaud, Premier of France during the debacle of 1940, died this morning. He would have been 88 years old on Oct. 15.

Dr. Herbert Aptheker, a leading theoretician of the Communist party in the United States, formally entered the race for Representative from Brooklyn's 12th Congressional District yesterday.

Angry Negro demonstrators broke through a police barricade and attempted to prevent the white principal from entering Intermediate School 201 in East Harlem yesterday morning.
MARK HARRIS pursues his own moral substitutes for war. In "Twentyone Twice," he dramatizes them exuber antly as dialogues, monologues, and travelogues.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach was chosen by President Johnson today as the longsought replacement for George W. Ball, the Under Secretary of State.

Heinz Arntz, the world's champion marathon pianist, arpeggioed into New York yesterday aboard the liner United States, looking glazed but game after 816 hours of steady pounding on the keys.

CHATHAM'S MITZIE was the top-winning standard Manchester terrier in the United States in 1965. "She is the result of 20 years of breeding," said Mrs. Ruth Turner, of Newtown Square, Pa., who, with 70 dogs, owns the largest kennel of the breed in America.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--The Senate Agriculture Committee approved today a bill that would expand a rural renewal program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--After shouting down 17 attempts to cut funds, the House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill that would appropriate $4,110,932,000 to finance several hundred public works projects scattered throughout the country.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 21--The South Vietnamese Government has decided to expand the scope of its rural pacification program to include more emphasis on land reform and on eradicating disease and illiteracy, informed sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- A special House subcommittee has been assigned to examine Representative Adam Clayton Powell's use of Congressional funds for salaries, travel and other expenses.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. has declared himself "concerned" over the nonunion status of a plastics plant founded by Howard J. Samuels, Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor. In turn, Mr. Samuels asserted yesterday he was "one of the most progressive, positive friends American labor has."
Eleven officials, including the sometimes feuding Robert Moses and Mayor Lindsay, made speeches yesterday at the opening of the city's Hall of Science at the Flushing Meadow site of the World's Fair.

Vice President Humphrey was in Manhattan yesterday, pausing long enough to applaud the rise in milk prices, to justify large defense budgets with references to the "continuing Communist threat," to endorse the role of the small-business man and to commend insurance agents.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday it had started a multimilliondollar expansion program to double the production of Corfam at its plant in Old Hickory, Tenn. Corfam is du Pont's synthetic material for shoe uppers.
Charles S. Murphy, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said yesterday that his agency was moving back from Dec. 31 to next April 23 a decision on airline fare levels.
The spot rate on the British pound continued firmer in moderate trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.

MOST thriving duplicate bridge clubs go to some trouble to provide enthusiasts with some variety in the schedule of games. One of the most active innovators is William Lifton, who manages the Duplicate Bridge Club of Brooklyn, which holds its Club Pair Championship at 7:45 o'clock tonight. In its first few months of existence at 1474 East 31st Street, this club has been flourishing, and it recently absorbed the Manhattan Beach Bridge Club.

SEATTLE, Sept. 21 (AP)-- A newswoman, a pacifist author, a doctor and a retired Navy carrier skipper won the four contested Congressional nominations that highlighted Washington's primary election yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 21--Frank D. O'Connor called tonight for immediate outright repeal of the controversial Condon-Wadlin Law, which prohibits strikes by public employes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 --The National League tossed coins and drew straws today to determine a playoff timetable in case the Los Angeles Dodgers, Pittsburgh Pirates and San Francisco Giants finished the baseball season in a dead heat.

JEAN-LUC Godard dropped his other shoe at the fourth New York Film Festival last night. His second film to be shown--his muchtalked-about "Pierre le Fou" ("Peter the Crazy")--was a wet night's sole attraction in Philharmonic Hall. The other film scheduled for the evening, Jean Renoir's 1931 drama, "La Chienne" ("The Bitch"), had been canceled.

MIAMI, Sept. 21--Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba has made a statement strongly opposing birth control.

ALBANY, Sept. 21--A debate over the relationship between church and state at a Board of Regents convocation today may have been a preview of arguments at next year's Constitutional Convention.

PINOMPENH, Cambodia, Thursday, Sept. 22 (UPI)-- Cambodia accused the United States today of having attacked a Cambodian guard post near the frontier with South Vietnam on Tuesday, killing a Cambodian sentry. An official statement said two other guards were gravely wounded and that two women were less seriously hurt.

LAFAYETTE, La., Sept. 21 (AP)--Volunteers worked hours without a break today to load a mercy train with food, medicine, clothing and other supplies donated for Indians reported starving in northern Mexico.

A New York garment manufacturer said to have connections with drivers and harness track operators is being sought for questioning in the inquiry on whether races were rigged at Yonkers, Roosevelt and Monticello Raceways.

A decline of 1,080,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

BUFFALO, Sept. 21--The attorney for a British pilot accused of illegally flying war planes to Portugal accused the United States today of having secretly sponsored the flights in contradiction of its own policy.

A northeaster hit the metropolitan area with high winds yesterday and brought the heaviest 24-hour rainfall here in 63 years. The storm flooded roads, stalled commuter and subway lines and caused isolated power failures over a wide area.

NEWCASTLE-ON-TYNE, England, Sept. 21 (AP)--Ross Newdick, a 29-year-old New Zealander, sank long putts on the 16th and 17th holes today and gave a British Isles and Commonwealth golf team a 15-9 victory over the rest of the world.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21--President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines appealed to the Soviet Union and all Asian countries today for a bold initiative to end the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)--Twelve pharmaceutical concerns filed suit in Federal Court here today to prevent the Food and Drug Administration from adopting strict new controls over the manufacture of vitamins.

GENEVA, Sept. 21--Dr. Robert S. Aries, a chemical engineer, was sentenced in his absence today by a Geneva court to 30 months imprisonment on charges of having sold to Swiss companies trade secrets stolen from United States companies.

Plagued by tight money, the Administration has embarked on a series of fiscal actions to ease the pressure. Mr. Johnson's announcement that the Treasury plans to sell new savings certificates to the public is one such measure. The rollback of interest rates announced by Federal banking authorities is another. Taken together, they represent an attempt to maintain or increase the flow of consumer savings while bringing about a decline in interest rates.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- President Johnson welcomed today peace efforts by Pope Paul and U Thant, but expressed doubt that North Vietnam was ready to respond to those efforts.

MADRID, Thursday, Sept. 22 --The Moiseyev ballet, the first Soviet artistic group to perform in Spain since the outbreak of the Civil War more than 30 years ago, won standing ovations and shouts of "Ole, Ole" from a gala audience early today.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 21 (UPI)--Frank Robinson hit his 48th and 49th homers and a seven-run eighth-inning rally gave the pennant-bound Baltimore Orioles a 10-8 victory over the Kansas City Athletics tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, L.I., Sept. 21--A former Wall Street broker who was a key figure in an investigation into allegedly fraudulent land sales involving millions of dollars was found shot to death on the Long Island Expressway last night.
ALGIERS, Sept. 21--The Soviet Union is handing out antiAmerican literature at its pavilion at the Algiers International Fair, which opened last weekend.

THE new weekly series called "ABC Stage '67" turned its hand last night to suspense drama. "Dare I Weep, Dare I Mourn," an adaptation of an original story by John LeCarre, author of "The Spy Who Came In From the Cold." The hour was a competent effort, often tautly told with sound characterization, excellent playing by James Mason and a background of tension.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 21 --John W.R. Beecroft, former editor in chief of the Literary Guild of America, died here today after a short illness. He was 64 years old and lived on Norfolk Lane.
CLARKSTON, Mich., Sept. 21--The American Motors Corporation today introduced a newly styled line of 1967 models aimed at a reversal of the manufacturer's declining fortunes.
UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 21--Hank Ferris, the former Michigan State star, must be rated as a leading example of how to become a head football coach without really trying.
DETROIT, Sept. 21 (AP)-- Willie Horton's two-run homer with two out in the bottom of the ninth gave the Detroit Tigers a 2-1 victory over Dean Chance and the California Angels tonight.
Executives of thrift institutions had mixed feelings yesterday about the Government's new interest-rate ceilings on individual savings.

The complexity of the Federal Medicare program, which went into effect last July 1, has caused much confusion among the older persons it was designed to protect against the economic hazards of illness.
BONN, Sept. 21--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard has conceded that the war in Vietnam may make it necessary to reduce United States forces in West Germany.

Two detectives known for their disguises retired from the Police Department yesterday. They were Jerry Valente, 46 years old, and Alfred Spinosa, 49. In their 20 years on the force they had earned 19 citations each.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 21 (AP)--Dr. Hubert L. Eaton, founder of California's Forest Lawn Memorial Parks, which attract 2-million tourists and are the settings for 5,000 funerals a year, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 85 years old.
LONDON, Sept. 21--Britain now favors a United Nations move to ask the International Court of Justice for a new advisory opinion on South-West Africa, informed sources said today.

MONTREAL, Sept. 21--The strains of "Scotland the Brave" skirled through the elegant Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton Hotel here yesterday as 450 women finished their luncheon dessert of bavaroise kirsch and settled back to watch a kilted piper open the international import show staged by Ogilvy's.
WHY does everybody care what Ohrbach's bought in Paris?

The huge barn of a building that once housed many of the rides in Coney Island's Steeplechase began to crumble under a wrecker's bulldozer yesterday. But, in spite of the rain, it crumbled with Coney Island class--there were food, drink and six--count 'em--six bikinied beauties.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21-- Rick Wise, 21-year-old Philadelphia Phillies right-hander, checked the Los Angeles Dodgers' attempt to widen their National League lead tonight by outpitching Claude Osteen for a 3-2 triumph.
The Nation's electric power production rose 3.9 per cent in the week ended Sept. 17 from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 21--The Liberal party began its annual convention here today by seeking to clarify the issues facing the nation and almost immediately ran into disagreement.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- President Johnson indicated today that next year he would again seek passage of a civil rights bill that included a fairhousing provision.

The parent who wants to know what is going on in his child's school and who wants to take part in the life of the school has two established means: the parents association at his school and the local school board in his district.

PARIS, Sept. 21--The French Government, responding to the riots in French Somaliland during and since President de Gaulle's recent visit, announced today that a referendum on the territory's future status would be held before July 1.
Following is a transcript of President Johnson's news conference at the White House yesterday as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:
The New York Council of the United Negro College Fund will hold a Latin-American Fiesta on Sept. 30 at the Park Sheraton.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 21--Four ponies from Canada captured five blue ribbons as the Eastern States Exposition Horse Show opened today.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 21--Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and two British Ministers broke off today, at least for the time being, their discussions on a way out of the impasse over Rhodesia's independence.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 22--If there are two better quarterbacks operating in college football than Terry Southall of Baylor and Gary Beban of the University of California, Los Angeles, Ben Schwartzwalder would like to know their names. Syracuse, the Orange coach laments, had to draw the as opponents in its first two games.

The downturn in residential construction as yet has not had a material effect on the operations of U.S. Plywood Corporation, Gene C. Brewer, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21--Is September really necessary? The Assyrians, who invented it, seemed to think so. The Assyrians were perhaps the nastiest organization of people in history until the rise of the modern nation-state, and when they finally became so unpleasant that they couldn't even stand themselves, one of their rulers thought up September.
GILBERTSVILLE, Ky., Sept. 21--The Southern Governors Conference passed a resolution today attacking the Federal guidelines for speeding school desegregation.

Mrs. Frances Mead Hoepli, executive secretary of the Nightingale-Bamford School Alumnae Association, died yesterday in the Doylestown (Pa.) Hospital after a long illness. She was 63 years old and was the wife of M. Henry Hoepli, a management consultant.
KINGSTON, Ont., Sept. 21-- The road back for Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion starts here, at the New York Rangers' training camp, where his severest critic is himself.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--The Johnson Administration was requested today by Representative Albert H. Quie to halt "partisan" showings of the movie about President Kennedy, "Years of Lightning, Day of Drums."
PLAZA 9, Plaza Hotel, Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. Nancy Dussault, singer; Ullett and Hendra, English satirists; One and Two Thirds, song trio.
SAIGON, Sept. 21--The result of a United States military investigation made public today indicated that American planes may have bombed a South Vietnamese hamlet in the demilitarized zone Aug. 13.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--The Government wants to form teams of "aviation pathologists" to perform autopsies on victims of noncommercial aircraft accidents.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (UPI)--Mrs. Billie Jean King, the Wimbledon champion, was eliminated from the 40th annual Pacific Southwest tennis championships today by 17-year-old Valerie Jean Ziegenfuss of San Diego. The scores were 3-6, 7-5, 6-3.
A State Supreme Court justice entered a plea of not guilty yesterday on behalf of Eugene Rodriguez, Democratic candidate for the State Senate from the Bronx, who is accused of perjury.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 21--The chairman of the Texas State Republican party said today that Texas really has three political parties--the Democrats, the Republicans and the liberals--and that Republicans would welcome support from liberals.

Newton N. Minow, former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission who once called television a "vast wasteland," said yesterday that commercials had improved considerably but that he could not say the same for entertainment programing.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said yesterday that the Ku Klux Klan had increased in strength by about 10,000 members since the first of the year, with many new recruits in the North and Middle West.
The Maritime Administration reported yesterday that it had received 86 bids for the 25 C-4 type troopships it plans to make available to unsubsidized shipping companies.
HONG KONG, Sept. 21-- Peking has greeted the opening of the United Nations General Assembly with a bitter attack and a new declaration that the world body should be reorganized.
HANOVER, Germany, Sept. 21 (UPI)--Franz Josef Kemper of West Germany equaled the world record of 2 minutes 16.2 seconds for the 1,000-meter run today.
It was just as dreary inside the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the weather outside and the market showed its biggest loss in almost three weeks in moderate trading.
"We like to reward those who have done well for us," said Ralph Houk, in announcing the elevation of Loren Babe to the New York Yankee coaching staff yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) --Vice President Humphrey told Democratic candidates today that on the basis of his campaign soundings he was convinced they were "headed for victory" in November.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) --Dr. James Goddard told President Johnson today that by next August the Food and Drug Administration will have eliminated a backlog of applications pertaining to the safety of drugs.
At least two presidents have red telephones. The other one is John de Garmo, of de Garmo, Inc.

"Fiddler on the Roof," the musical based on Sholom Aleichem's Yiddish stories, enters its third year tonight at the Imperial. The show has also won popularity in Finland. The first European presentation has been a fixture in Helsinki since February, another has been on the boards at Pori and a third opens tonight at Tampere.

A State Supreme Court Justice refused yesterday to permit a trial of Representative Adam Clayton Powell on the issue of his "willfulness" in defying a defamation of character judgment until a higher court had resolved "certain questions."

Roy Anderson, president of the Save the Met Foundation, Inc., said last night that he had filed a petition in the State Supreme Court yesterday to halt the planned destruction of the old Metropolitan Opera House.

The controversy at Intermediate School 201, restricted until this week to local battles between pro-integration parents and the Board of Education, has been expanded to the point where some of the most militant and anti-integration Negro groups are now actively supporting the parents.
LONDON, Sept. 21 (Reuters) --Airliners from the United States and Europe were diverted today when thick fog closed down London Airport for most of the morning.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 21-- Scandals and near-scandals have emerged as the backdrop for Arizona's campaign, and the question is whether they will hurt the re-election bid of a Democratic Governor and the political future of Barry Goldwater.
Stock prices tumbled yesterday as the decline of the preceding two sessions took on added breadth and depth.
BIRMINGHAM, England, Sept. (UPI)--Johnny Prescott, a British heavyweight scored a fourth-round technical knockout over Franco Badalassi of Italy tonight.

Harold Krensky, chairman of Filene's stores in Boston, will return to Bloomingdale's here as chairman and managing director, Ralph Lazarus, president of Federated Department Stores, Inc., announced yesterday. Both Filene's and Bloomingdale's are Federated divisions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--Justice John M. Harlan of the Supreme Court cleared the way today for resumption of talks between the General Electric Company and a group of union representatives over a new working agreement with the electrical workers union.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 21-- A. Philip Randolph warned today that growing racial tension could "escalate into a race war in this nation which could become catastrophic to the Negro and to America."
The election of Arthur F. McGinness as a senior vice president of Chemical Bank New York Trust Company was announced yesterday by William S. Renchard, chairman.

George Gallup, the pollster, reported in a copyright article in The World Journal Tribune and other newspapers yesterday that the nation was about evenly divided between those who approve and those who disapprove of President Johnson's handling of the war in Vietnam.
Bond prices, buffeted by a rapid-fire series of news developments, closed with gains yesterday while Treasury bills ended with declines.

The Senate's decision to reject the school prayer amendment yesterday was no vote against religion. It was a vote to keep intact the Bill of Rights and, specifically, the First Amendment, which has served the country well as a protector of freedom to worship and freedom to choose in the religious field.
KENILWORTH, Ill., Sept. 21 Coastguardsmen using an improvised dragline found an object in Lake Michigan today that may be one of the weapons used in the Valerie Percy slaying.
The city's Hall of Science, dedicated at Flushing Meadow yesterday is not yet a true museum. Rather it is a leftover from the recent World's Fair-- and a hope for the future.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Senator Robert Griffin, Republican of Michigan, changed today that there had been a breakdown in the Social Security Administration's processing of new claims.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Americans generally get "mediocre to poor" service in clinical chemistry testing, a laboratory director told a Senate subcommittee hearing today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Interest rate ceilings that will reduce but not eliminate the present geographical disparities in rates and the competition for savings among financial institutions were announced today.
Joe Frazier, twice knocked down in the second round, indefatigably pressed and battered Oscar Bonavena and gained a 10-round split decision at Madison Square Garden last night.

An auctioneer banged his gavel in the grand ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday morning, signaling the change in ownership of a Manhattan elementary school and bringing closer construction of a 50-story office tower. The sale also set in motion plans by the New York Hilton Hotel to open four of its northermost doors.
Sixty-two Dutch paintings dating back to the days when New York was a Dutch outpost arrived here yesterday bound for San Francisco.
The plans of the New York Central and Pennsylvania railroads to merge Oct. 1 were upset yesterday by a three-judge Federal court here after holding hearings for four hours.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Did President Johnson infuse the State Department with new ideas today, or did he strengthen the influence of Dean Rusk and established policy?
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- The cost of the war in Vietnam has reached $1.2-billion a month and is still rising.
WINTON, Australia, Sept. 21 (UPI)--An Australian National Airways Viscount airliner with 23 persons aboard crashed near here, 700 miles northwest of Brisbane, early today.

The marriage of Miss Anne Handly Joyce to Dr. Joseph Cornelis Wijman took place yesterday afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, assisted by the Rev. George A. Trowbridge, performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Colony Club.
SAN SIMEON, Calif., Sept. 21--William Randolph Hearst would have approved.

BONN, Sept. 21--Half a week before their scheduled departure for Washington, Chancellor Ludwig Erhard and Defense Minister Kai-Uwe von Hassel were forced to defend their military policies today before a heavy barrage of parliamentary criticism.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)--What would you expect a soft drink cooled with ice formed almost 2,000 years ago to taste like?
A long-awaited Richmond County grand jury report on the Willowbrook State School for the mentally retarded was made public yesterday by Supreme Court Justice James C. Crane.
The Regional Council of Bennington College will present a benefit fashion show of Tzaims Luksus's first full collection of fall couture clothes on Tuesday at Bonwit Teller.
Mayor Lindsay declared last night that New York City kept racial tensions under control this summer largely because the civilian review board was "operating well, effectively and quietly."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Interest rate ceilings that will reduce but not eliminate the present geographical disparities in rates and the competition for savings among financial institutions were announced today.

Saul Raskin, an artist who was widely known for his paintings of Jewish lift and religious subjects, died of a heart attack yesterday in his doctor's office at 16 West 16th Street. He was 88 years old and lived at 5 West l6th Street, where he maintained his studio.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 22 The engagement of Miss Sandra Janney Sayen to Eberhard M. Rosenblad has been announced by Miss Sayen's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Sayen 3d. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Curt F. Rosenblad.

THORPE BAY, England, Sept. 22 (AP) The United States catamaran, Gamecock, retired with a damaged main halyard today and left Lady helmsman, the British defender, to sail over the course and take a 3-2 lead in the Little America's Cup series.
PASADENA. Calif., Sept. 22 (AP) Surveyor 2 smashed into the moon at 6,000 miles an hour tonight a violent end caused by a small rocket motor that refused to fire on command.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) The Senate Appropria tions Committee approved today one of the session's biggest money bills $10.5-billion appropriation for two Cabinet departments. It was $390-million larger than President Johnson's budget estimates.

Copenhagen, 68 West 58th Street, MU 8-3690. For a herring fancier there should be nothing but unreserved enthusiasm for the Copenhagen's remarkable assortment. There is herring with mustard, herring with curry, herring with horse-radish plus six or seven more, and all of them are a joy. The remainder of the Copenhagen's food is not on a par with the best that Denmark has to offer, but it is palatable nonetheless and will cosset the appetite.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 22 Norman Rite's Wildwind of Altadena, Calif., a 32-foot Class catamaran carrying 500 square feet of sail, shared the lead with a Shearwater of 16 feet sailed by Walter Hall in the first division that was part of the first world championship regatta for multi-hull boats that started today.
Monte Carlo will be added as a port of call next year by three ships of the American Export Isbrandtsen Lines, Admiral John M. Will, chairman of the board, announced last night.
The eviction of about 400 tenants from the site of the proposed Civic Center in downtown Manhattan was blocked indefinitely yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Charles A. Loreto.
One of the largest corporate mergers in the history of American retailing was sealed yesterday with approval by shareholders of the deal between E. J. Korvette, Inc., and Spartans Industries, Inc.
A. DePinna, Company, a Fifths Avenue store founded 81 years ago by a London merchant, is planning to take a new lease on life through an accent on youth.
The mysterious theft of $407,400 worth of blank American Express Company travelers checks last Aug. 26 from Kennedy International Airport was disclosed in Federal Court yesterday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 21-- Amid a dozen other preoccupations ranging from flying to writing, Barry Goldwater is working away methodically at his campaign to get re-elected to the United States Senate in 1968?or sooner.

KENILWORTH, Ill, Sept. 22 An Army bayonet found last night in Lake Michigan not far from the lakeside residence of Charles M. Percy was all but ruled out today as the weapon used in the murder of Valerie Jeanne Percy, the 21-year-old daughter of the Republican senatorial candidate.
CHICAGO, Friday, Sept. 23 (AP) Seven persons were killed early today in a fire in a South Side building, the police reported.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith has filed a $1,047,782 counterclaim against Ira Haupt Co.'s bankruptcy trustee, apparently in an effort to recoup the amount of money it was assessed to help bail out the brokerage firm's customers when the salad-oil swindle broke three years ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22 Arthur J. Goldberg, the United States representative, called on South Africa today to accept United Nations supervision of her mandate over the neighboring territory of South-West Africa.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 22 The United Steelworkers of America said today that the steel industry's performance in the 1968 contract negotiations could determine whether industrywide bargaining in steel survives.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The House Commerce Committee unanimously approved today a so-called "truth-in-packaging" bill after stripping it of Federal authority to standardize packages and their contents.

In a surprise move yesterday, E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., cut the price of Dacron polyester staple fiber by about 14 per cent. Du Font is the largest producer of polyester fiber, which is used widely in wash-and-wear and durable press apparel.

The National Hockey League, the last of the major sports conferences without network affiliation, publicly pledged itself to the Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday. C.B.S. brought an estimated $3.5-million into the three-year agreement, the N.H.L. brought a promise of burgeoning national interest in a hitherto Eastern sport.

The Maybrook, N. Y., National Bank has ended merger talks with the Marine Midland Trust Company of Rockland County, Nyack, N.Y., bat the Maybrook probably will announce plans to accept a share-exchange offer from a third bank "within a few days," Arthur Maharay, Maybrook president, said yesterday.

IN "Almost a Man," Vittorio de Seta has projected such a keen, quicksilver flow of dazzling imagery that the New York Film Festival's second-to-last feature was a stunning eyeful for every one of its 120 minutes. As a highly introspective drama of a tormented man searching out the roots of an enveloping psychosis, it also rings true. The catch to him and to the picture-is what ails him.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 (AP) The 59-foot sloop Sirius from the Del Rey (Calif.) Yacht Club took the lead yesterday in the St. Francis Perpetual Trophy series in San Francisco Bay.

THE big game in the National Football League this Sunday brings together the Los Angeles Rams and the Packers at Green Bay. Both are unbeaten, and the Rams, thoroughly improved by their new coach, George Allen, may turn out to be the Packers' chief challenger

CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 (UPI) The Most Rev. Edward Francis Hoban, a shoemaker's son who rose to be Archbishop of the Cleveland Roman Catholic diocese, died early today at his home here. He was 88 years old.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that parents should not be given "veto power" over the appointment of school principals and teachers.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 22 (UPI) Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr. gave his backing today to the board of trustees of the Mississippi Hospital School for Cerebral Palsy in refusing to sign a civil rights compliance pledge.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 22 For a newly installed coach heading into a tough opening game Saturday without benefit of equalizing spring practice, Jack Musick is surprisingly serene and communicative in counting his blessings at Cornell.
A father and son, both architects, were indicted yesterday on charges of attempted grand larceny and conspiracy to bribe two commissioners of the Bureau of Standards and Appeals.
DENVER, Sept. 22 (UPI) A 12-story office building on the edge of downtown Denver has been purchased by a New York City investment syndicate for $9-million.
TEMPE, Ariz., Sept. 22 (AP) An Arizona State University coed was stabbed to death outside a downtown hotel last night.
Mrs. Allison Choate of Rye, N.Y., and the Apawamis Club, scored 42,38 80 at Westchester Country Club today to win the 41st annual tournament of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association.

The election of Capt. John H. Gibson, whose flying career began in 1933, to the newly created position of vice president-flying training for American Airlines, was announced yesterday by Marion Sadler, president of the carrier.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 22 Dr. Carl Coppolino, who is awaiting trial in Florida on the charge that he murdered his wife there last year, may stand trial first in New Jersey. The 34-year-old physician is also accused of the 1963 murder of a neighbor in Middletown Township, retired Army Lieut. Col. William E. Farber.

PICKING the right moment to lead a trump is one of the most difficult areas in the game. Lew Mathe, the Californian star, goes so far as to insist that his partners should never lead a trump, although he magnanimously overlooks the misdemeanor if the lead happens to work well.

Vincent DeBellis was 80 years old yesterday and although old friends and customers stopped by to pay their respects, he spent the day, like most, cutting hair in his barbershop in the Port of New York Authority Building.

The United States Customs Service needs the cooperation of the nation's importing community to make the major reorganization of the service a complete success, Lester D. Johnson, Commissioner of Customs, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22--A modified version of the Administration's anti-inflation tax bill was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

The dismay occasioned in Democratic ranks by the strong support Governor Rockefeller is receiving from many major unions seems to be driving Frank D. O'Connor into dangerous demagogy on strikes against the community. The Democratic candidate has told a union conference that he believes public workers should have the same legal right to strike as employer in private industry.
The Old Met Opera House Corporation, beset by litigation in court, started a campaign yesterday to raise $10-million to save the old building on Broadway at West 39th Street.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22 The United States proposed today a step-by-step de-escalation of the war in Vietnam by both sides, starting with a halt in the bombing of North Vietnam.
BONN, Sept. 22 The submarine Hai, which sank in the North Sea last week, was "completely seaworthy," naval officials are reported to have told the Defense Committe of the West German Bundestag today.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 22 Fred Ritchie of Southward Ho took the lead with a 36, 38 74 in the opening-round today of the 15th annual Long Island Senior Golf Association's 36hole championship. The play was over the par 35, 36 71, 6,436-yard Southward Ho Country Club.
Bampton Castle was not too speedy getting around the 2 miles in the Charles L. Appleton Memorial Steeplechase at Aqueduct yesterday, but Mrs. William C. Riker's 9-year-old jumper got the job done.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 The savage slaying Sunday of 21year-old Valarie Jeanne Percy has added a new element in one of the nation's most important political contests this fall.
A group of Livingston Oil Company stockholders is suing for $1-million in damages.

AREA A--Fishing of all kinds went blowing away on the winds of the northeast storm that hit Monday and kept the seas aboil until yesterday when calm returned. However, there was a positive factor. The bluefishing was

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) House leaders today postponed until later in the session consideration of a bill aimed at activities of some critics of the war in Vietnam. The legislation had been scheduled for debate and expected passage today. The Administration has opposed the measure.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The Bureau of Labor Statistics is going to call in experts from other Government agencies to help it determine whether consumers will be getting more or less value for their money when they buy the new 1967 cars at their higher prices.
Takeo Fukuda, Japanese Minister of Finance, said here yesterday he expected his Government to announce next month a program to encourage more foreign investment in Japan.
The Lindsay administration is planning to expand the city's land bank program so it can provide parcels for housing construction by private developers.

Miss Susan Fleschner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Fleschner of 1049 Park Avenue, was married last evening to Edmond Charles Semel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Semel of Brooklyn. The ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel was performed by the Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El.
North American newsprint producers turned out 941,307 tons in August, 9.6 per cent, more than in August, 1965, and a record to date, the Newsprint Service Bureau reported yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 22 The United States Air Force pilots who shot down two enemy MIG's yesterday described the action today. Their encounters were part of the heaviest day of aerial dueling in the war over North Vietnam.
MINOT, N.D., Sept. 22 You couldn't find a nicer man in all of North Dakota today than Richard Milhous Nixon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The cost of the Vietnamese war, in dollars the American taxpayer must shell out, is now running at an annual rate of $14.5 billion. By the second quarter of 1967 the cost of the war, by present projections, will rise to an annual rate of about $20 billion.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 President Johnson said today that Arthur J. Goldberg's Vietnam peace proposals to the United Nations General Assembly had been made with his "full approval."
George Sanders will make his Broadway debut in "Dinner With Sherry," the $500,000 song-and-dance version of "The Man Who Came to Dinner."
NEWBERRY, S.C., Sept. 22 (UPI) Two former polcemen charged with having beaten a young Negro prisoner were acquitted today on a directed verdict by Judge John Grimball in Circuit Court.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Casher of the Bronx have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susannah Deborah Casher, to Marvin Rosenberg, son of Mrs. Martin Rosenberg of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Rosenberg.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 22 Britain's Commonwealth Secretary, Herbert Bowden, decided tentatively today to stay here until Tuesday or Wednesday, apparently in the hope that he can get another round of talks started between Britain and Rhodesia.

Miss Martha E. Urquia, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. M. Rafael Urquia of San Salvador, El Salvador, and Arlington, Va., was married in Guatemala City on Saturday to Eduardo Dao Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dao of Caracas, Venezuela. The Most. Rev. Mario Casarego, Archbishop of Guatemala, performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mercy.
The wholesale commodity price index fell on Wednesday to 106.2, from 106.6, on Tuesday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 22 Mihajlo Mihajlov pleaded not guilty in a Zadar court today to charges that he had spread false information about Yugoslavia and distributed his own banned writings.

A shouting, stomping crowd of demonstrating taxpayers, screaming abuse and invective at Mayor Lindsay, repeatedly disrupted the Board of Estimate yesterday as it struggled to clear a heavy, 192-page calendar at its first fall meeting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The State Department today mildly reproached President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic for having interfered with the solution of the civil war in Yemen by his apparent maneuvers to install a new pro-Egyptian government there.
PANAMA, Sept. 22 (AP) Students demonstrating against the United States threw red paint at Ambassador Charles W. Adair Jr. as he was leaving a ceremony on the University of Panama campus tonight.

ATLANTA, Sept. 22 (UPI) Pat Jarvis pitched a five-hitter and Hank Aaron led the Atlanta attack with his 40th home run as the Braves routed Pittsburgh, 14-1, tonight. The loss dropped the second-place Pirates two games behind the Los Angeles Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) The House Rules Committee rescinded today its call for a Congressional inquiry into the controversial guidelines on school desegregation that have been issued by the Office of Education.
A tempest over an Egyptian temple developed yesterday when the Metropolitan Museum of Art charged the Smithsonian Institution with a conflict of interest. Who, us? was the Smithsonian's reply.
After half a day of indecision, Parks Comissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving yesterday canceled last night's free concert in Central Park by Herb Alpert and The Tijuana Brass, rescheduled from Wednesday.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 22 Wilt Chamberlain, professional basketball's most valuable player last season, was fined $1,050 tonight for reporting seven days late to the Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 China's Red Guards have threatened to tear off the skin and burn the bodies of Soviet diplomats in Peking, it was reported today.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Asa Gunhild Orngrim to Martin Crane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Crane of Williston Park, L.I. Miss Orngrim is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Orngrim of Karlstad, Sweden.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (UPI) J. Howard Wood was elected chairman of the board and Harold . Grumhaus was elected president of the Tribune Company, publishers of The Chicago Tribune and six other newspapers, the board of directors announced today.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 22 The West German donor of a $1million auditorium and library for the Israel Museum resolved today a dispute over whether any part of the building should bear his name.
The American Stock Exchange yesterday tried hard to end its losing streak, but fell somewhat short as declines outnumbered advances for the fourth consecutive session.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22 The Congo asked today for a Security Council meeting "at the earliest opportunity" on charges that European mercenaries in neighboring Portuguese territories were preparing to overthrow the Government in Kinshasa (formmerly Leopoldville).

The big sticking point with Negro civil rights workers here yesterday, in commenting on the House Education and Labor Committee's action against Representative Adam Clayton Powell, was that the Negro was the only committee chairman stripped of powers.
The Agency for International Development will begin a weeklong drive here Monday to recruit 700 professional men and women for the Administration's civic action program in South Vietnam.

John E. Postley, president and founder of John E. Postley, Inc., at 350 Fifth Avenue, distributor of home-furnishings and furniture, died Wednesday in Chicago of a heart attack. He was 64 years old and lived at the Carleton House, Madison Avenue at 61st Street.
Three utilities and a railroad system announced new plans for expansion yesterday.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Sayles B. Clark of Glen Cove and Erieville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynda Louise Clark, to Randolph Frank Stolz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Stolz of West Hempstead.
Two harness race horse owners refused yesterday to sign waivers of immunity in the Brooklyn grand jury investigation of possible rigging of races at the Yonkers, Roosevelt and Monticello tracks.
LONDON, Sept. 22 The pirate radio stations that beam "pop" music to Britain's teenagers may at last, after years of Government talk without action, be in danger of suppression.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 22--Leonid I. Brezhnev landed here today to start a three-day visit at the invitation of President Tito.

PAGE, Ariz., Sept. 22 The tiny figure dressed in bright green was almost lost atop the colossal concrete plug that is Glen Canyon Dam. As far away as the eye could see was an empty landscape of savage splendor, bright red, treeless, dotted with sculptured sandstone spires and flat-topped mesas.
The 50 demonstrators picketing Intermediate School 201 in East Harlem yesterday rep resented a variety of interests, philosophies and racial backgrounds.

In one of the largest mortgage transactions for a project in New York City since the recent tightening of building funds began, Aetna Life and Casualty has agreed to make a $24-million leasehold mortgage loan on a 40-story office building to be erected at 437 Madison Avenue, on the site of the former New Weston Hotel.

As its first item of political business, the General Assembly in extraordinary debate will try to decide what the United Nations should try to do about South Africa's League of Nations mandate over South-West Africa.
MONTREAL, Sept. 22 (Canadian Press) Albert Leslie Lawes, former president of the Montreal Shipping Company, Ltd., died Sunday at his home. He was 70 years old.

FOLLANSBEE, W.Va., Sept. 22 Senator Robert F. Kennedy returned tonight to the state that, more than any other, helped catapult his brother into the Presidency six years ago and the Senator himself into national political prominence.

PARIS, Sept. 22 The Algerian co-producer of the motion picture that won the highest award at the Venice Film Fesival this month was barred from France yesterday upon landing at Orly Airport. He is Yacef Saadi, who was a prominent guerrilla leader in the French-Algerian war.

CAIRO, Sept. 22 President Gamal Abdel Nasser, who has received a gloomy financial report from Western economists, has invited a top-level team of Soviet experts to evaluate the performance of the United Arab Republic's hard-pressed economy.
The election of Howard W. Blauvelt as a director and executive vice president of the Continental Oil Company was announced yesterday.
The pace of trading in egg futures quickened yesterday and the September delivery, which expires today, set a new lifetime high. The other contracts also advanced.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced here yesterday the election of Robert H. Kenmore as a vice president. He continues as director of acquisition analysis and investments.
Salary increases and new jobs granted by the Lindsay adminstration last week and this have totaled $123,650 a year.

THE PRESIDENT Met with Cabinet; saw Lieut. Gov. Patrick Lucey of Wisconsin, Democratic nominee for Governor; signed Columbus Day proclamation; saw Veterans Administrator Driver to report on V.A. medical research; held informal news conference.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. A Chinese ship arrived in the north Sumatran port of Belawan today to transport about 700 Chinese back to China.

INCREDIBLY enough, the Christmas season is once more upon us, and in the world of books there is no time like Santa Claus time. Of course, in recent years publishers have learned to spread their wares more evenly over 10 of the 12 months (July and August remain unloved); but Christmas meaning from mid-September on is still the time when most of the books, or products, are sold and most of the money is made.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 22 (UPI) There is finally joy in "Mudville."

MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 21 Vermont Democrats are planning to use a railroad foliage excursion around the state next month as a whistle stop campaign effort for Gov. Philip H. Hoff, who is seeking a third term.

Sales of new cars, which rebounded sharply near the end of August and then fell in the first 10 days of September, continued to fall in the second 10day period of this month, two domestic auto manufacturers reported yesterday.

BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 22 The Liberal party conference, in a resolution that was questioned by only one delegate, condemned today the Labor Government's freeze on wages and prices as shortsighted and dangerous.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 22 (AP) The ashes of the cremated body of an American citizen were scattered in the Bosporus today at request of his widow.

The feasibility of building a new pipeline to carry oil products from the Texas-Lousiana coast to the Chicago area is being studied by 11 oil companies. The Cities Service Company is understood to be the leading sponsor of the project.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 22 Canadian entries continued to lead the way in the harness divisions at the Eastern States Exposition horse show today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22 The United States offered today to provide tracking facilities on American soil for Soviet satellite launchings, if a "mutually beneficial agreement" could be made.
The Cunard Line fleet of passenger liners has been scheduled to make 131 trans-Atlantic crossings in 1967.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) The Senate Government Operations Committee unanimously approved today a compromise version of the bill to create a new department of transportation in the Cabinet.
CUSTOM furriers had their day yesterday as two long-established houses showed how their wares could fit into any social gathering from a tennis game to a safari.
THE center of controversy at Intermediate School 201 could be presiding today over a quiet school in one of the city's untroubled neighborhoods.
A FEW blocks from Times Square is an island of 19th-century peace surround ed by a sea of 20th-century hurly-burly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Intercity truck tonnage and freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended Sept. 17 were both considerably ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1965.
The spot rate on the British pound continued its firming trend yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
A change in senior management was announced here yesterday by John Nuveen Co., investment bankers.
A college student, a wig salesman and a raincoat salesman were arrested yesterday by Federal narcotics agents on charges of possessing 100 kilograms of marijuana worth $20,000 wholesale.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 22 (UPI) Mickey Wright, not bothered by 100-degree heat and high humidity, shot a twounder-par 35, 34 69 today to take a one-stroke lead in the first round of the 12th annual 72-hole national Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

VIENNA, Sept. 22 (AP) President, Johnson told the international Atomic Energy Agency today that it "has a crucial responsibility to see that the vast beneficial uses of nuclear energy are not diverted for military purposes."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) A medical examiner Said yesterday that the death of James H. Moyers, an assistant to President Johnson, was a suicide caused by an overdose of prescribed drugs.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 A dispute has flared among Soviet economists over proposals that the Government end its rigid control over agriculture and permit the law of supply and demand to regulate crop production.
For the first time in 15 years, Gian Carlo Menotti's "Amahl and the Night Visitors" will not be seen on television this Christmas season.

Mrs. Katherine Hollis Rice, widow of Grantland Rice, the sports writer, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. Her husband died on July 13, 1954. He was then writing a column for The Mirror, and had written sports columns for many years for The New York Herald Tribune and the North American Newspaper Alliance.
MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 22 The Town of North Hempstead, concerned over noisy, restless children who tend to disrupt public hearings, opened a Town Hall nursery today.

The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., reported yesterday that first-half net income rose to $106,400,000, or 31 cents a share on the ordinary stock, from $98-million, or 29 cents a share, a year earlier.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 23 (AP) American infantrymen accidentally detonated four land mines in their own minefield yesterday and killed seven United States soldiers and wounded 14, the United States military command said today.
An industrialist, 11 other persons and three corporations were indicted yesterday in a stock fraud said to have cost investors $1.5-million.
Gold mining shares and Government bonds advanced yesterday in an otherwise quiet London stock market.
Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, chastised the Liberal party yesterday for having nominated Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for governor.
LONDON, Sept. 22 Allied forces in Vietnam have a 4-to-1 numerical advantage over Communist forces according to calculations by the Institute for Strategic Studies.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 President Johnson denied today that he planned to make Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman the Attorney General.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 22 An agreement by the Federal Resources Corporation of Salt Lake City and Metal Mines, Ltd., of Toronto, looking toward Federal's acquisition of the majority interest in the Faraday Corporation's uranium mine and mill in Ontario was announced here today.
From Hebrew National to Frank D. O'Connor. That's the leap just taken by Richard K. Manoff, Inc., in its growing client roster.
LAFAYETTE, La., Sept. 22 A train rumbled out of here this afternoon with 10 boxcars with food and supplies for thousands of Indians who are reported destitute in Mexico's mountains.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Friday, Sept. 23 (UPI) A 100-pound snow leopard that slipped away from the Lincoln Park Zoo Wednesday night was shot with a tranquilizer pellet and recaptured early today atop a building.

All sections of the bond market climbed to higher levels again yesterday. Prices opened above those at Wednesday's close, dipped slightly in mid-morning and then rose sharply throughout the afternoon. Closing prices were near the best levels of the day.

After a strike lasting only a few hours yesterday, the orchestra members of the New York City Opera ratified a twoyear contract by a vote of 31 to 2. The old contract for the 54-man orchestra, members of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, expired July 1.
George Milburn, a popular short story writer of the late 1920's and 1930's, died at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday afternoon. He was 60 years old, and lived at 33 West Eighth Street.

BONN, Sept. 22 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard angrily walked out of a meeting of West German civil servants today after the chairman accused him of having broken a promise to give federal workers adequate wages.

The first emergence of upstate Democrats backing Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. as the Liberal party candidate for Governor was announced yesterday, including the formation of nine Democratic or independent committees for him in eight counties.

Woodmere, L.I., Sept. 22 Woodmere Academy used a powerful ground attack to score 20-6 victory over Englewood School today in a football-game played in intermittent rain. The triumph was the first in 15 games for Woodmere.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 22 India agreed today to lend Indonesia 100 million rupees [$13.3-million].

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The House Banking Committee approved today Senate-passed legislation giving bank supervisory authorities more power to halt unsound practices of banks and savings and loan associations.

Yom Kippur, the most sacred of the Jewish holidays, will Begin at sundown today and last through sundown tomorrow. It will be marked by fasting and prayers in temples and synagogues throughout the world.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 22 (AP) United States District Judge Herbert W. Christenberry ordered the Plaquemines Parish School Board today to assign 30 Negro children enrolled in Woodlawn School boycotted by whites to other parish schools.
The General Electric Company offered two contract improvements yesterday to the International Union of Electrical Workers, but they were quickly rejected.

NEWCASTLE-ON-TYNE, England, Sept. 22 (AP) Claude King, a 33-year-old professional from Virginia Beach, finished with four birdies today, to share the lead with Keith MacDonald of England after the first round of a 72-hole, $36,500 golf tournament.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22 Adam Malik, Indonesia's Foreign Minister, conferred today with United Nations leaders on his country's desire to resume full membership in the world body.
Borrowing by business from, major New York banks soared $428-million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

EVERETT Wash., Sept. 22 (UPI) Bob Goalby of Belleville, Ill., used a sizzling putter to card a six-under-par 65 today for a competitive course record and the first-round lead in the Greater Seattle Everett golf tournament.

A group of dissident Crucible Steel Company stockholders, headed by Morris J. Rubin, was granted leave yesterday by the Illinois Supreme Court to appeal a ruling of the Appellate Division in the matter of the company's annual meeting.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 Dr. Vladimir I. Veksler, a leading Soviet physicist, died today at the age of 59, the press agency Tass reported.

One more indignity in a season filled with indignities was heaped on the New York Yankees yesterday when a hardy group of only 413 reported at the Stadium and watched the Yanks lose to the Chicago White Sox, 4-1.
PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., Sept. 22--Governor Rockefeller, who has been actively defending the 2 per cent state sales tax, proposed today to make it easier for businesses to collect the levy.
Edward J. OHara Sr., 73 years old, of 43-60 Douglaston Parkway, Douglaston, Queens, was killed yesterday by a hitand-run driver who later surrendered to the police.
DETROIT, Sept. 22 The General Motors Corporation raised prices today on its 1967 model automobiles, but heavily undercut its major competition in the process.
A new Italian-built compact car that embodies the American styling theme popularized by Lincoln-Continental was introduced here and in Europe yesterday by the Fiat Motor Company.
THE NEW rules skimming some of the cream off the interest paid by savings institutions also contain a drastically shortened grace period for late depositors at New York City Mutual Savings Banks.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 22 (AP) Romeo Hanover scored two impressive triumphs today in capturing the $75,000 Little Brown Jug for 3-year-old pacers in straight heats.

YONKERS, Sept. 22 Approaching the final quarter in tonight's $100,000 E. Roland Harriman Trot for 2-year-olds, Halifax Hanover, with the capable Joe O'Brien driving, looked like "money in the bank." With a three-Length lead over his closest pursuer, Halifax Hanover, it seemed, needed only to remain on stride to wrap up the victory and the winner's share of $55,000 for the Armstrong brothers of Brampton, Ont.
William M. Batten, chairman of the J.C. Penney Company, has been named the 1966 recipient of the "Green Thumb" award of the Boys' and Young Men's Apparel Manufacturers Association.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 22 (AP) The United States Fish and Wildlife Service ended its goose truce with Wisconsin today, and explosions boomed out over the open water of the vast Horicon National Wildlife Refuge before sundown, to drive away migrating geese.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday changes in the shareholding of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.
