Jerry F. Hardy of Sokol New York has been elected 1966-67 president of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union.
DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, by John Dos Passos (Houghton Mifflin, $12.50). One-volume edition of "Adventures of a Young Man," "Number One" and "The Grand Design."
HONK KONG, Sept. 22 (Reuters) Jenmin Jih Pao, the Peking daily, said today China would strike back if United States aircraft intruded in its territory again.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 22 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles clinched their first American League pennant today with a 6-1 victory over the Kansas City Athletics. A crowd of only 5,250 watched Jim Palmer hurl a fivehitter for Baltimore's 95th triumph.

The Royal Highland Fusiliers have landed again 152 years after their lineal ancestors burned down the White House (during the War of 1812). This time their objective was Madison Square Garden, and yesterday evening the huge Scottish company took over the place with a blaze of color and a roar of sound.
The Consolidated Edison Company has agreed to postpone for 60 days the rate changes that it proposed to put into effect Monday, the Public Service Commission announced yesterday.

YONKERS, Sept. 22 Mayor Lindsay and representatives of large cities upstate agreed today to make a joint statement on their common problems to the candidates for Governor and ask what they proposed to do about them.
Paul L. Adams, the Conservative party candidate for Governor, called yesterday for drastic reductions in state spending, starting with a 5 per cent cut across the board.
OTTAWA, Sept. 22 (UPI) A bomb exploded in front of the Cuban Embassy today, splintering the front door, gouging the front lawn and shattering windows over a two-block area. No one was injured.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 22 A campaign denouncing the Israeli Government for allowing autopsies has been organized by ultra-Orthodox Jews. Rabbinical law forbids the dissection of bodies, which it considers desecration of the dead.

PONCHIELLI's "La Gioconda" was one of the operas presented during the first Metropolitan Opera season, in 1883. Following Rudolf Bing's precept of the Metropolitan Opera being a museum, the silly old piece turned up once again last night as the second presentation in the new Lincoln Center auditorium.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today legislation that would give antitrust immunity to the proposed merger of the National and American Football Leagues.
Marion E. Fitzhugh, who was long active in social service work, died Wednesday in Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, at the age of 73. She lived at 200 East 66th Street.

Crews totaling almost 1,000 men were assigned to work through the night in Brooklyn and Queens to repair thousands of telephones that were knocked out by Wednesday's 5.54-inch rainfall, the heaviest in the city in 63 years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The House Education and Labor Committee took away today most of the power of its chairman, Adam Clayton Powell, to act alone in matters of substance. The vote was 27 to 1, with three members merely voting "present."
GANTON, England, Sept. 22 (AP) Pam Fox of Corvallis, Ore., moved into the round of 16 today in the women's British open golf championship with a 3-and-2 victory over Lily Guermont of England.
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters plans to begin a drive Monday to organize nonunion drivers serving Port of New York piers.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP) Johnny Podres pitched a fivehitter and doubled in two runs in leading the Detroit Tigers to a 7-0 victory over California today after the Angels had taken the first game of the double-header, 5-3.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 22 (AP) Leftist mobs resorted to violence today in largely successful attempts to enforce a 48hour general strike in Calcutta and the rest of West Bengal State.

As the General Assembly convenes in this 21st year of the United Nations, we of the United States are aware, as indeed every delegation must be, of the great responsibilities which all of us share who work in this world organization for peace.

The American Broadcasting Company television network was reported yesterday to be considering several changes in its program schedule, including the cancellation of "The Tammy Grimes Show." The situation comedy made its debut Sept. 7 and failed to receive favorable critical reaction and ratings.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Sept, 22 Dr. and Mrs. Frederick C. MeLellan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Isabel McLellan, to James Otis Rodgers 3d, son of Mrs. Rodgers Jr. and the late Mr. Rodgers.

PHANRANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 18 A radar device designed more than 15 years ago as a training aid to improve the accuracy of strategic bombing is playing a new role in thwarting the Vietcong's monsoon offensive in South Vietnam.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 22--Vice President Humphrey made a strong appeal here today to the nation's intellectuals for support of President Johnson's policies in Vietnam.
The New Yorker League for Cerebral Palsy has arranged a tour of six Manhattan residences known for their unusual decor and their art collections. The tour will take place on the afternoon of Oct. 4.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 22 (AP) A motion was entered in Federal court today asking that Gov. George C. Wallace be directed to show cause why he should not be held in contempt of an earlier court order forbidding him to interfere with court-ordered school desegregation.
Frontier Airlines has announced that it will introduce the Boeing 727 jetliner on its routes Sept. 30.

The New York Continental Society will hold its annual Bums Ball next Friday in the National Maritime Union hall at 36 Seventh Avenue. Proceeds will be shared by organizations serving underprivileged children in the city.
IT WAS so nice to have grand opera back where it be longs that this intrusive footnote, or rather feetnote, on the ballet might sound unduly sour.

The Very Rev. John D. Sheehy, a member of the council of the Roman Catholic order of the Society of African Missions in Rome, died yesterday in the home of a sister, Mrs. Nora O'Shea, at 1542 East 51st Street, Brooklyn. His age was 66.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a bill to restrict mail order sales of sidearms, instead of a broader measure sponsored by Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.
A Civil Court judge ruled yesterday that the estranged wife of a multimillionaire was liable for more than $100,000 in bills she ran up because of her "cruel and inhuman treatment" of her husband.
President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife left here at 3 P.M., yesterday by Air Force jet for San Francisco after a seven day state visit to New York.

TS. ELIOT once said, "I will show you fear in a handful of dust," and then he did it. In "A Delicate Bal ance." Edward Albee talks about it and talks about it and talks about it, sometimes wittily, sometimes ruefully, sometimes truthfully. But showing might have done better.

AN unusual union of the literary and television worlds was demonstrated by National Educational Television last night on Channel 13. Prof. John Unterecker, a member of the English department in Columbia University's Graduate Faculties, is preparing a biography on Hart Crane, the poet, and N.E.T. hit upon the happy notion of having camera crews accompany him on his interviews.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara announced today an increase of about 30 per cent in the planned production of fighter and fighter-bomber air-
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 22 The first split in the military regime's ranks became apparent today after a group of officers offered to pay former university teachers not to leave the country.
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday after an afternoon rally wiped out many of the losses that developed during another sinking spell in early trading.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged yesterday that David M. Milton, head of the Equity Corporation until last February, had been "guilty of gross misconduct and abuse of trust" in administering the operations of that closed end investment company, which he founded more than 30 years ago.
Ambassador Goldberg's address on Vietnam to the United Nations General Assembly is the best and most conciliatory presentation of the American position yet made.

Another big breach in the Administration's battered wall against inflation has been made by the Big Three automobile companies. Their decision to push up prices on their 1967 models is part of a chain reaction that began with the White House failure to defend its wage-price guideposts in the auto union negotiations two years ago.

The Graduate School of Business of Columbia University marked the 50th anniversary of its founding yesterday with a convocation at which three internationaly known leaders in government and industry were honored.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) The Senate Labor Committee approved today a $2,496,000,000 authorization bill to continue the antipoverty program for a third year.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Young have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janice Andrea Young, to Burton T. Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Cohen of Woodmere, L.I.

A new set of recommendations aimed at improving the competitive position of statechartered commercial banks with Federally licensed banks was proposed yesterday by the Advisory Committee on Commercial Bank Supervision in its second report to the State Banking Superintendent.
We had a Cabinet meeting this morning. I reviewed with them the legislative program and the fiscal policy program with which you are generally familiar.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 22 In a mood of calm and some exhilaration today, this country spent the first day in nearly 17 months with no foreign troops on its soil.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday appointed Anthony C. Russo, a career man in the city's service, as assistant director of labor relations at $18,500 a year.

BOSTON, Sept. 22--Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. George P. Whitelaw of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Whitelaw, to Robert John Stanton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanton of Tulsa, Okla.
IF Elizabeth Arden has her way, her customers will be painting their lips bright red and pinning artificial braids to their heads.
A 15-member board of inquiry was announced yesterday to investigate charges made against the Child Development Group Program in Mississippi.
An influential, internationally oriented economist called yesterday for a $7-billion across-the-board Federal income-tax increase as the best way to deal with inflation in the United States economy.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 28 Premier Chung II Kwon and his Cabinet submitted their resignations today because their "authority and dignity" had been hurt by "insults and assault" in the National Assembly.

A State Supreme Court Justice was told yesterday that if the state obtained a preliminary injunction banning alleged pricefixing in milk sales it would interfere with collective bargaining and lead to "the biggest milk strike the city ever had."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 State Department policy is made along what is called "the dog run" on the seventh floor of the main building on "C" Street. This is an inside corridor, flanked by oil portraits of liberated Secretaries of State, where Secretary Rusk, the Under Secretaries and the Under Under Secretaries may pass unnoticed to their private offices and elevators.
STRATFORD, Conn., Sept 22 Clayton Gengras and Gov. John N. Dempsey each introduced a new tactic today in Connecticut's gubernatorial campaign.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) Glenn Beckert's three-run double in the second inning paced the Chicago Cubs to a 7-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today. Dave Dowling, a 24-year-old rookie pitcher, gained credit for the victory, his first in the major leagues.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The Consumer Price Index recorded another substantial rise in August as food prices, which normally decline during that month, continued to climb.
The American Electric Power Company reported a record net income yesterday of $84.8-million, equal to $1.88 a share, for the 12 months ended Aug. 31.
Ethel Merman is stopping the show again with "Old Fashioned Wedding," the new song that Irving Berlin wrote for the revival of "Annie Get Your Gun."
The Corn Products Company announced here yesterday the election of Beverly W. Warner as a director and Bennett E. Kline as a vice president.

CATSKILL, N.Y., Sept 22 The marriage of Mrs. Edith Cole Hill, widow of Milt Dean Hill, to Howard E. Silberstein, a widower, took place here today The Rev. Wilbur E. Ivins, pastor of the First Reformed Church of Catskill, performed the ceremony at the bride's home before members of the immediate families.
The people at Mercury have come up with yet another promotion gimmick to build awareness of its newest entry in the new-car rodeo the Cougar.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 The post of United States Ambassador in Moscow falls vacant at a low point in relations with the Soviet Government a situation that, it seems, is depressing to officials on both sides.

PORT CHICAGO, Calif., Sept. 22 (AP) The Sheriff and District Attorney last night talked gun-carrying vigilantes into halting the patrols that members said had been set up at nearby Clyde as protection against anti-Vietnam war pacifists.

The police broke up what was apparently a meeting of top Mafia leaders from all over the country in the basement of an Italian restaurant in Queens yesterday afternoon, and seized 13 underworld figures.
Columbia will open its 76th season of intercollegiate football at Baker Field this afternoon against a Colgate squad that already has been tested. The kickoff is scheduled for 1:30.
The Rev. Charles A. Berger, professor and chairman of the biology department at Fordham University for 24 years, died Thursday in a faculty residence hall on the Bronx campus. He was 64 years old.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 21 --The Republican party hopes to pick up a Utah seat in the United States House of Representatives by exploiting concern over rising foods costs and a vote for repeal of "right-towork" laws.

VIENNA, Sept. 23--Three persons who, by their discoveries, ushered in the atomic age, were honored here today in the historic Hofburg Palace. They received this year's Enrico Fermi Award before a distinguished audience of 800 guests including Josef Klaus, the Austrian Chancellor.
SIXTY-TWO-YEAR-OLD Cecil Beaton, whose cam era, costumes and sets have made him a legend, has not lost a bit of his elegant British sting.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 23--Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from an address by Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union to the General Assembly:
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 9.4 per cent in production for the week ended Sept. 17, compared with the level in the corresponding 1964 week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) --The median family income of Cleveland Negroes increased 9 per cent between 1959 and 1964, but the proportion living in poverty was substantially unchanged, the Census Bureau said today.
Gino Landi, considered one of Italy's top directors, is a slim, soft-spoken, 33-year-old man with an abundance of black hair who might easily be mistaken for a music teacher.

Having revived the truth-in-packaging bill after it had been tabled, the majority on the House Commerce Committee has now reported it out in compromise form. The lobbyists for the soap companies and the food industry have not been successful in killing the bill, but they have scored some real gains at the expense of the consumer.
Robert M. Moses can upgrade a "happening" scheduled tomorrow in a Queens park into an "event" by accepting Park Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving's invitation to attend.

The Syntex Corporation, an international company engaged in the development, production and marketing of pharmaceutical, chemical and animal-health products, achieved an 81 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 56 per cent in the fiscal year ended July 31.
"The Abyssinian Baptist Church is Adam's refuge," said a Harlem social worker.
Two hundred people are spending their days in the Commodore Hotel plotting the overthrow of Nelson Rockefeller as Governor of New York.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other Negro leaders today obtained a change of venue removing from Circuit Court Judge Cornelius J. Harrington an injunction proceeding drastically limiting civil rights marches in Chicago.
LONDON, Sept. 23--This week's talks with Prime Min ister Smith, it was said here tonight, have given no ground for believing that a BritishRhodesian settlement is near.
"I was always visible," Martin Tananbaum said yesterday. "It was just that nobody used to be looking at me."
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 23 (AP)--Another group joined today a growing list of educational organizations opposed to a statewide lottery as a means of raising money for schools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- President Johnson called on state and local governments today to join the fight against inflation by delaying the sales of bonds for new highways, schools and other construction that is supported by Federal grants and loans.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- A little computer that was patented this week has produced a volume figure that is highly gratifying to its inventors.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sep 23 (UPI)--Mickey Wright continued her bid for a fifth national Ladies Professional Golfers' Association championship today when she added a three-underpar 34, 34-68 to yesterday's 69 for a 137.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--In St. Margaret's Episcopal Church here this afternoon Mrs. Camille Waldron Fitzhugh, widow of Thomas Fitzhugh, was married to Clyde T. Ellis.
Thirteen "executives" of the underworld were freed in bail totaling $1.3-million last night, 32 hours after they had been arrested in a Queens restaurant.
PARIS, Sept. 23--A microphone was hidden behind a Picasso in a reception room for distinguished visitors at Orly Airport, or so it was testified today.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 23 (AP) --Summit County's Democratic Party chairman said today the film "John F. Kennedy: Years of Lightning, Day of Drums" would be shown next Wednesday without requiring viewers to contribute money to the party.
ALBANY, Sept. 23--The State Board of Regents has agreed to establish a three-year term for its chancellor and vice chancellor to provice opportunity for rotation of the positions.
ST.-TROPEZ, France--This tourist resort on the Riviera has endured.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained Thursday the level it reached on Wednesday, which was 106.2.

UP and down the avenue last week, the dealers were girding up such loins as they have and getting the season under way. There was a lot of unease, having to do with the stock market, since the art sales graph follows the Wall Street graph rather closely.
Two suspended detectives from the 80th Squad were arrested yesterday on charges of extortion, bribery, accepting unlawful fees and coercion after being indicted by a Brookly grand jury.

Two spiritual leaders of American Reform Judaism, in a Yom Kippur statement, yesterday called on their fellow Jews to join with other religious forces, including Pope Paul, to halt the war in Vietnam.
Governor Rockefeller won another victory yesterday in his battle for labor support of his re-election when the Uniformed Firemen's Association announced its endorsement of him.

That wasn't a bad little shower this city had last Wednesday. It may even give rise to legends about the "monsoon of 1966." But old-time New Yorkers know that it can't bear comparison with the deluge of Oct. 8-9, 1903, when New York really came close to being drowned under more than ten inches of rain in somewhat more than 24 hours.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP)--The limited endorsement of abortion by the California Bar Association has caused a clash between a Roman Catholic Cardinal and a Protestant Episcopal Bishop.
THE STOCK of the Itek Corporation has had a hectic week in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, with very little hard news to explain the activity.
The Federal Reserve Board gave quick approval yesterday to an emergency merger of the Public Bank of Detroit into Bank of the Commonwealth, also in Detroit.
The Manhattan Democratic organization took up the touchy issue of separation of church and state yesterday with a call for a liberalized rule on state aid to church schools.

EVERETT, Wash., Sept. 23 (UPI)--Homero Blancas fired a six-under-par 65 today to take the second-round lead in the $50,000 Greater Seattle-Everett open golf tournament with an 11-under-par two-day total of 131.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 23--Elements of another North Vietnamese division have crossed the demilitarized zone into South Vietnam and engaged in combat with United States marines, authoritative sources said today.

Francis W.H. Adams, a founder and former leader of one Democratic Reform movement, charged yesterday that the movement has become "a political organization interested only in its own political power."

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Sept. 23 (AP)--Attorney General Richmond M. Flowers's office notified the trial judge today that the state would seek to dismiss an assault charge growing out of the wounding of a civil rights worker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24-- World Airways, Inc., of Oakland, Calif., the world's largest charter airline, and Berry World Travel, Inc., of Kansas City, Mo., have applied to the Civil Aeronautics Board for authority to conduct what they describe as the largest domestic inclusive tour program in civil aviation history.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)--Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. said today that personality testing of Peace Corps volunteers called for true-or-false answers to statements that were an invasion of privacy.
EASTCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 23--The White Plains women's auxiliary of the White Plains Hospital will sponsor a benefit luncheon, bridge and fashion show at Schrafft's restaurant here Sept. 28.

H. Lawrence Bogert, a general partner of Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co., has been nominated for president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, Albert Pratt, the current president, announced yesterday.
Allen Gates, a 28-year-old barber, was indicted for first-degree murder yesterday in the slaying of a 9-year-old crippled girl.
The resignation of a senior housing inspector in the Bronx was accepted yesterday after he refused to waive immunity in a grand jury investigation into bribery.

Joseph Anthony Pepitone, the handsome, fidgety first baseman of the New York Yankees, and his mother are suing the Board of Education for $100,000 because a classmate shot him in a Brooklyn high school eight years ago.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 23-- The police cleared out today 300 students who barricaded themselves in the medical school of the Federal university overnight.
Three new Civil Court Judges who will sit in Brooklyn were sworn in yesterday by Mayor Lindsay at City Hall.

NEW VERNON, N.J., Sept. 23--George E. Vreeland of Sand Spring Road, president of the Vreeland International Corporation, chemical importers and exporters, New York City, died yesterday at Morristown Memorial Hospital after a short illness. He was 62 years old.
When the driver of a big truck is injured in a highway accident, the chance of the injury being fatal or serious is nearly twice that of an automobile driver, Cornell University reported yesterday.
The nation's major chain stores and mail order houses experienced a sharp rise in sales during August, a survey by The New York Times disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)--A campaign to get Stores to keep aspirin and other dangerous drugs out of the reach of the youngsters was started today by Dr. James L. Goddard, Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)--The Civil Aeronautics Board rejected today a mutual aid agreement between American Airlines and a local service airline, Mohawk, of Utica, N.Y.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Jack W. Edson of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Ruth Edson, to Louis S. Freeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Freeman of Cincinnati.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 23--Sunnyside, Washington Irving's picturesque home here that he called his "little snuggery that I wouldn't exchange for any chateau in Christendon," became National Historic Landmark 688 of the National Park Service today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)--Senator Clifford P. Case today challenged President Johnson's statement that he could not decide whether a tax increase was needed until he learned how much spending Congress would approve.

ATHENS, Sept. 23--Litton Industries, which had been managing a $1-billion program of rapid regional development for the Greek Government, today cancelled its contract and announced it was pulling out of Greece.
The pouring of concrete and the tossing of coins into a 60-foot-deep trench for a telephone vault marked the first step yesterday in the construction of the $525-million World Trade Center.

THERE'S no predicting bestsellers. According to Jean Wong, one of Best Co.'s bright young buyers for its new "Cosmo 7" floor, she is hard put to keep junior petite sizes (3 to 13) on the floor these days.
The London stock market closed firm yesterday after a final burst of activity on news of Premier Ian Smith's hint that a settlement of the Rhodesian dispute might be near.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 23-- Mr. and Mrs. Clement J. Clark have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Sarah Clark, to Vogt Daniel Wilkison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Wilkison of Shaker Heights, Ohio. The wedding is planned for May.

Alexander Kipnis, former bass with the Metropolitan Opera, has been named to the voice faculty of the Juilliard School of Music. Mr. Kipnis has had a long and distinguished career in opera and has appeared inconcert with Arturo Toscanini, Wilhelm Furtwangler, Richard Strauss and other conductors.
The price of fasteners, used in large numbers to hold wood and metal together, is going up by 9 per cent.

PEWTER has entered the seller's market. When it was first made, pewter was not highly regarded and it was collected because it was inexpensive, but today American pewter prices often rival those of silver.

WASHINGTON, Sept.23-- House investigators said today that they were getting no substantial cooperation from public and private agencies in their attempt to determine how official the travels of Representative Adam Clayton Powell have been.
DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP)-- Gov. George Romney's picture will stay on the Nov. 8 ballot, Wayne County Circuit Judge Harry J. Dingeman Jr. has ruled.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (UPI) --Robin Roberts, right-hander of the Chicago Cubs, was hospitalized today with gastrointestinal bleeding and will be unable to play for the remainder of the season.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 --Students from New England scored the highest and students from the South the lowest in tests last May and June, the Selective Service headquarters announced here today.

The city is seeking a dozen pet skunks that were exposed to rabies in Iowa before their shipment here. Three persons in the metropolitan area have been bitten by skunks since they arrived in late August.
Jubilant nurses in the city's hospitals and health centers received back pay of up to $2,000 yesterday, four months after they signed new contracts with the city.

YONKERS, Sept. 23--Art Troilo's debut as head coach at Harrison High was a success today when the Huskies rallied in the second half to defeat Yonkers High School, 26-19. Yonkers had taken a 19-0 lead in the first half at Gorton Field. Harrison.............. 0 0 7 19--26 Yonkers............... 0 19 0 0--19

DETROIT, Sept. 23 (UPI)-- Auto production has slowed and the six-millionth passenger car of 1966 will not roll off the assembly line this week as previously expected, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
The executive director and three high staff members of Bedford-Stuyvesant's $8-million antipoverty program have resigned in a dispute with the agency's board of directors.
The Department of Defense has instructed its Military Traffic Management and Terminal Service to disregard a previous ban on operational overtime costs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)--A Mississippi Democrat who is scheduled to become chairman of the House Rules Committee has put House leaders on the spot by insisting on consideration of a bill aimed at some antiwar activities.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 23--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harlow W. Gage of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Gage, to Lieut. Walter Elliot Nelson Jr., U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson of Old Saybrook.

Ben W. Heineman, chairman and president of the Chicago North Western Railway confirmed yesterday that he had sold 14,100 shares of the railroad's common stock last month. This reduces his investment in the issue to 10,000 shares. On July 21, Mr. Heineman also sold 900 shares.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- The Federal Aviation Agency has stirred a tempest in a teapot by trying to keep competitors who are seeking to build a supersonic airliner from trying their case in newspaper advertisements.

Martin Tananbaum, president of Yonkers Raceway, said yesterday that Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. had tried twice this year to get him to contribute to his campaign to win the Democratic nomination for Governor.
DORTMUND, Germany, Sept. 23 (UPI)--Japan retained its world gymnastics team championships today, but failed for the third straight year to win an individual crown.
KINSHASA, the Congo Sept. 23--Heavy fighting broke out in Kisangani, the former Stanleyville, today when Katangese troops were attacked by units of the Congolese National Army.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (AP) --An $18-million damage suit was filed today against the majority stockholders of the Ambassador Hotel Company by minority stockholders.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 23 --The New York Air National Guard was notified today by the Defense Department that its airlift unit and its headquarters at the Westchester County airport here would be continued for at least another year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 --Jeanne Minter, an attractive blonde widow from St. Joseph, Mich., is not surprised to find herself surrounded by men in her visit to San Francisco. In fact, the males--the men who print Alka-Seltzer labels, trading stamps, stock certificates and church-offering envelopes --are more surprised to find themselves surrounding her.

MONTREAL, Sept. 23--The developing nations in the British Commonwealth appear willing to let European industrial countries have a special role in planning international monetary reform--if such a concession is needed for faster progress.
Aaron H. Singer of 30 Park Avenue, who retired in 1963 as sales manager of the Adolph Lewisohn Selling Corporation, 61 Broadway, died yesterday of pneumonia at French Hospital. He was 77 years old.
World sugar futures bumped along near their recent low levels yesterday without any news to stir interest. The spot price continued at 1.50 cents a pound, the lowest level in 25 years.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 23 (AP) --Ivan, the snow leopard that escaped from the Oklahoma City zoo Wednesday night, died early today, about two hours after he was captured. Dr. Phil Ogilvie, director of the zoo, said death was caused by a reaction to a tranquilizing drug used to capture Ivan.

Carl Sandburg married Lillian Paula Steichen in 1908. "My sister," Edward Steichen writes, "acquired a husband; I acquired a brother." Now Steichen, one of our great photographers, has put together a portrait of the photogenic poet. It is not a biography or appraisal. All it professes to be is a pictorial evocation of a distinguished personality. The pictures were made by Steichen and more than 50 other photographers, and the book is handsomely printed.
Producing for nonprofit is catching on off Broadway, which has not been doing so well producing for profit.
MONTREAL, Sept. 23--A fugitive from United States justice is being visited here this week by bankers, engineers and paper company executives from France, Britain, Switzerland and the United States.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 23--Prime Minister Ian D. Smith declared today that Rhodesia was prepared to keep talks going at least as long as Britain wants them in an effort to settle their differences.

The fourth New York Film Festival, which closed Thursday evening with a sold-out performance for the Alain Resnais film "La Guerre Est Finie," had total ticket sales of $120,183, according to Schuyler Chapin, vice president in charge of programing for Lincoln Center.

The Douglaston Yacht Squadron's annual Commodore Douglas Trophy race today will end the day-race competition for the DeCoursey Fales Trophy A fleet of 40 cruising-type sailboats will start in Eastchester Bay at 10:30 and sail a course of 26.9 miles to Little Captain Island and back to Stepping Stones Light.

TWO girls groveled with ladders, etc., on the floor of dance's parish church last night, in a performance that seemed under par, even for course. The church, of course, was the Judson Memorial Church in Washington Square (who was this Judson that he should be so memorialized?) and the performance, of course, was sponsored by the Judson Dance Theater. The two girls were Carla Blank and Suzushi Hanayagi.

ROME, Sept. 23--Secretary of Defence Robert S. McNamara told a North Atlantic Treaty Organization working party today that the United States now had about 7,000 nuclear warheads in inventory for NATO forces in Europe. This, he said, is an increase of more than 100 per cent since 1961.

BARTLESVILLE, Okla., Sept. 23--Six months ago, Richard M. Nixon was advising every Republican Congressional candidate to run against either his Democratic opponent or President Johnson, whichever was weaker in his area.
Julius Haber, a Zionist leader, died on Thursday in Doctors Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 711 West End Avenue.

OTTAWA, Sept. 23--Ever since he lost control of the House of Commons and thus the Canadian Government in the 1963 elections, John George Diefenbaker has been described by editorial writers as being in the twilight of his stormy political career.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)--The appointment of True Davis, an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, as United States executive director of the Inter-American Development Bank was announced today by Secretary of Treasury Henry H. Fowler. Mr. Davis was sworn in this afternoon.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (AP)--The Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association asked waivers today on two backcourtmen, Bob Weiss and Don Freeman.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23--The Los Angeles Dodgers closed in on a second straight National League pennant today by sweeping a double-header with the lastplace Chicago Cubs.
There was reaction yesterday from several of the defendants named in the $1-million damage suit filed in Federal court, here Thursday by 94 Livingston Oil Company stockholders.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 24 --North Vietnam rejected yesterday as "another U.S. peace swindle" the latest American proposals for ending the Vietnamese war. Communist China issued a similar rejection today.
Transit Authority detectives are patrolling bus routes in several areas of the city where bus drivers have been assaulted, according to Daniel T. Scannell, a member of the authority.

St. James Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Kezia Trevitt Keeble, daughter of Mrs. George Mehaffey Mott of Bronxville, N.Y., and Edwin Augustus Keeble of Nashville, to Chandler Hovey 3d. He is a son of Mr. Hovey ...

WAPAKONETA, Ohio, Sept. 23 (UPI)--A young Democrat who vigorously opposes President Johnson's civil rights program is waging a lively election campaign against the program's chief Republican Congressional supporter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--The Government, rather than commercial banks, may have been the prime gainer in this year's fight to attract the savings of individuals, Government statistics indicated today.

Notre Dame opens its football season today in the spotlight of television cameras mirroring the action on millions of screens across the country as the Fighting ,Irish engage the dangerous Boilermakers of Purdue in South Bend, Ind.
PARIS, Sept. 23--Maurice Cardinal Feltin, the Archbishop of Paris, announced last night that he had asked to be retired.

The New York Philharmonic will open its 1966-67 season at Philharmonic Hall on Wednesday with a nonsubscription concert for the benefit of the orchestra's pension fund. The concert will be sponsored by the New York Philharmonic's auxiliary board.

Msgr. Thomas F. Little, executive secretary of the National Catholic Office for Motion Pictures, will relinquish his post Friday to become pastor of St. Batholomew's Church in Elmhurst, Queens, it was announced yesterday by Archbishop John J. Krol, chairman of the Bishops Committee for Motion Pictures.
The right of the Port of New York Authority to restrict jet flights on one runway at La Guardia Airport as a community noise abatement measure will probably be decided next week.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 23-- It's a free reading course in the King James or Douay Version of the Bible, it's Alice in Wonderland, Belgian waffles at 50 cents each, and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration--it's the 125th annual version of the Long Island Fair, which opened today at Roosevelt Raceway.
A part-time teen-age Sanitation Department worker became flustered yesterday when a caller felt that he did not answer the telephone courteously. The caller was Mayor Lindsay.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 23--Narcotics charges were dropped today against Dr. Timothy Leary, a leading exponent of the hallucinatory drug LSD, on the ground that recent court decisions affecting confessions and search warrants made it "extremely unlikely" that he could have been successfully prosecuted.
BONN, Sept. 23--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard will leave for Washington tomorrow amid general pessimism about the result of his pending talks with President Johnson.
MUNICH, Sept. 23 (Reuters) --Gerda Munsinger tonight described the report of her association with Pierre Sevigny as "ridiculous."

MONTE CARLO, Sept. 23 (AP)-- Aristotle S. Onassis apparently has given up on his long effort to control the Monte Carlo casino and other major resort properties that largely support the economy of the Mediterranean realm of Prince Rainier.
BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 23--Britain's Liberals called today for stronger measures against Rhodesia that would "not necessarily exclude" the use of force to restore constitutionality there.
Hart Schaffner Marx registered records in sales and earnings for the three, nine and 12 months ended Aug. 31.
Two civilian Fire Department inspectors refused to waive immunity from prosecution when summoned to testify on charges that they had taken gratuities.

Eleven Negro and white demonstrators, seeking the ouster of the white principal of Intermediate School 201 in Harlem were arrested three blocks from the school yesterday for what the police called "a series of disorderly acts."

The cafeteria manager at the New York Coliseum was shot twice and critically wounded yesterday, the police said, by a dishwasher he had dismissed a day earlier. The police were still searching for the assailant late yesterday afternoon.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 23--Black Africa opened today its campaign in the General Assembly to remove SouthWest Africa from domination by the white-minority Government of South Africa.
THE sea was gray and choppy. The breeze smelled of salt and held the threat of winter.

CHAUPHU, South Vietnam, Sept. 23--Rising flood waters may turn at least four provinces in South Vietnam's broad, low Mekong delta into a disaster area in the next 5 to 10 days, the authorities believe.
KUCHING, Malaysia, Sept. 23 (AP)--Sarawak's legislative council voted no confidence today in chief minister, Dato Stephen Kalong Ningkan.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP)--Charlie Vinson's seventh inning double--the first California hit in the game--drove in two runs and gave the Angels a 2-0 victory tonight over the American League-champion Baltimore Orioles.

A BUMPER crop of Western Bartlett pears, 80 per cent bigger than last year according to the United States Department of Agriculture, is now reaching local markets at reasonable prices. Known as a "butter type" pear, the Bartlett is excellent eaten raw or in cooked recipes such as the one for pear mince pastries that follows.
Dr. Franklin P. Radest, a chiropractor, died yesterday at his home at 538 Rockaway Parkway, Brooklyn, of a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The International Monetary Fund announced today a new program aimed at solving a major problem of the world's poorer countries: sudden declines in export earnings because of a collapse in the price of such commodities as cocoa or sugar or copper.
William F. Quinn, a production manager for N.B.C. News, died Wednesday at the Memorial Hospital. He Was 41 years old and lived at 217 Franklin Street in Massapequa Park, L.I.
ATLANTA, Sept. 23 (AP)-- Bob Veale shut out Atlanta on four hits and homes runs by Willie Stargell and Don Clendenon provided all the runs as Pittsburgh defeated the Braves, 3-0, tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 23--J.D. Silberman, founder and retired president of White Cross Chemicals, Inc., of Stamford, died this morning at Greenwich Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at Riversville Road.
ERNAKULAM, India, Sept. 23--Forty thousand people staged a massive anti-Government demonstration today as India's ruling Congress party opened a three-day meeting here.

Rosel H. Hyde, in his first major address to members of the broadcasting industry since becoming chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said yesterday that he would not be a commissioner of the status quo.

GANTON, England, Sept. 23 (AP)--Catherine Lacoste, a 21year-old French star, overcame two British Curtis Cup players today and moved into the semifinals of the British women's amateur golf championship.
ELIZABETH, N.J. Sept. 23 (AP)--An anonymous donor offered a $5,000 reward today for information leading to the arrest of the person who killed an elderly junk dealer and his wife.

Cardinal Spellman will preside at 5:30 P.M. tomorrow at a special mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral celebrating 1,000 years of Christianity in Poland Msgr. Vincent J. Raith, vicechairman of the Polish Millennium Committee announced last night.

TO write for a people scattered over the face of the earth, a people with no political center, in a language associated with Scripture, and even among his own folk known fluently by few; to write creatively under such conditions was surely an act of moral courage and of sublime--perhaps even blind--confidence.

OTTAWA, Sept. 23--John G. Diefenbaker, the former Consenvative Prime Minister of Canada, was harshly criticized today in a judicial report that charged him with having mishandled the Gerda Munsinger sex and security case six years ago.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23--The Zadar District Court today sentenced Mihajlo Mihajlov, the writer, to a year in prison after having convicted him of incitement of the Yugoslav public through his articles published abroad.
MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (AP)-- The Red Guards of Communist China are beating and murdering party officials, Pravda reported today from Peking.
MADISON, Wis., Sept. 23-- Attorney General Bronson LaFollette announced a legal response tonight to the Federal Government's ending yesterday of its goose truce with the state.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 23--Harry Florian Wolf, national amateur squash tennis champion from 1929 to 1940, playing for the New York Athletic Club, died of a heart attack yesterday on the golf course here. He was 59 years old and lived in Shrewsbury.

SANTA FE, N.M., Sept. 23-- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson wound up a spectacular three-day beautification trip in the West today with a visit to a 14thcentury Indian village within view of the atomic city of Los Alamos.

Sylvia Shirley, a short-story writer who taught writing at the New School for Social Research, 66 West 12th Street, died there of a heart attack last night while conducting a class. She was 53 years old and lived at 38 West Gun Hill Road in the Bronx.

Rate-conscious depositors rushed to several suburban New York banks yesterday to purchase savings certificates at rates above 5 per cent. New Federal regulations, effective Monday, force banks and thrift institutions to limit interest rates to 5 per cent.
The stock market turned downward yesterday following news that North Vietnam and the Soviet Union had rejected the new United States proposals for de-escalation of the war in Vietnam.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 23--Thanat Khoman, Thailand's Foreign Minister, said today that his country bitterly resented Senator J.W. Fulbright's efforts to challenge the Johnson Administration on its policy in Thailand.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 23--San Miguel, owned by Susan Peverly of Greenwich, Conn., won two divisions at the Eastern States Exposition Horse Show today.
EMDEN, Germany, Sept. 23 (AP)--The submarine Hai was towed into port today. Experts will try to determine the cause of its sinking in a North Sea gale 10 days ago.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 23--Gov. George C. Wallace charged today that a request for a Federal court contempt citation against him was "another long step toward the eventual jailing of political prisoners in this country."
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 23 --Vice President Humphrey today coupled an appeal for wage-price restraint with a contention that the election of a Republican Congress would throw the economy into reverse.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (UPI)-- An American official said today that the United States had made a new plea for the release of a Peace Corpsman, Thomas Dawson, who was arrested by Soviet border guards, Sept. 11, while he hunted for seashells on a Caspian Sea beach at the Iranian border.
BONN, Sept. 23--Prince Michael of Prussia, 26-year-old great-grandson of Wilhelm II, the last German Kaiser, married Miss Jutta Joern, 24, in Dusseldorf today in a simple civil ceremony.

MOSPORT PARK, Ont., Sept. 23--Dan Gurney of Costa Mesa, Calif., will be in the No. 1 starting position for the 209-mile Canadian-American Challenge Cup for sports cars tomorrow. But Gurney did not have the fastest time and will not have his regular Gurney-Weslake engine for the race.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 23--A six-run first inning against Dennis Ribant and Darrell Sutherland was all the cushion Jim Maloney needed as he pitched the Cincinnati Reds to a 7-0 victory over the New York Mets tonight.
HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 23 (UPI)--Mr. and Mrs. William Sorokey mourned today for a Korean orphan baby who was their daughter for only a few hours.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 23--United States military spokesmen said today that defoliation chemicals were being sprayed on North Vietnamese infiltration routes just south of the demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam.

NEWCASTLE-ON-TYNE England, Sept, 23 (AP)--Cobie LeGrange of South Africa carded seven birdies today and held a two-stroke lead over Hugh Boyle of Ireland and a three-stroke edge over, Dave Ragan of Orlando, Fla., at the halfway point of the $36,500 Senior Service golf tournament.

The attempt to operate the preparatory commission for next year's constitutional convention on a bipartisan basis is collapsing. Dr. Ralph A. Straetz, who, although not a political activist, was appointed under Democratic sponsorship, has resigned as executive director of the commission after an angry disagreement with Sol Corbin, who is commission chairman and a Republican.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 23--Mrs. Warren B. Heilman has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Shirley Virginia Heilman, an actress known professionally as Sherry Bennett, to Robert E. Salisbury, son of Mrs. Margaret Cameron Salisbury of Port St. Lucie, Fla., and Maplewood.
TENAFLY, N.J., Sept. 23-- Mrs. J.B. Cralle 2d of Montclair scored a 38, 43-81 today and won a Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament at the Knickerbocker Country Club.

In his first major policy statement since completing his tour of foreign heavyweight capitals, Muhammad Ali indicated a willingness to renegotiate with Floyd Patterson. Of his own long-range goals, he said: "All I want is to retire unmarked, unscratched, and with a good mind."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- Andrew F. Brimmer, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, expressed some concern today that the Government's new interest rate ceilings might result in a flow of funds out of financial institutions and into securities. I
PARIS, Sept. 23--The autumn art season of Paris has begun in distinguished style with the exhibition "In the Light of Vermeer--Five Centuries of Painting" at the Orangerie des Tuileries.

Back on Aug. 15, 1964, the names of 1,023 weanlings were submitted to The Jockey Club, for participation in today's feature race--the Futurity. The dreams of the owners of almost all those horses for success today have ended, and only seven colts are left to compete in the 6 -furlong test for 2-year-olds.
The spot rate on the British pound eased yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
Building inspectors and firemen reported yesterday that the Faweett Building is as solid as it looks after they spent a night investigating the mysterious vibrations that shook up the place Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- With evident personal and political satisfaction, President Johnson today signed a law that will raise the minimum wage to $1.60 an hour in 1968.
Two more auto makers reported yesterday that their sales of new cars declined in midSeptember from the same period last year.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 (UPI)-- Bob Holthus of Hot Springs, Ark., a trainer, was banned from the Detroit Race Course yesterday after track officials had found traces of a forbidden drug in one of his horses.
The New York Civil Liberties Union charged the police yesterday with "gross abuse" in denying a loudspeaker permit to the neo-Nazi National Renaissance Party for a scheduled meeting last night.

THE year is 1854. The locale is Paris. The Lady of the Camellias is giving a party. The setting is sumptuous, as befits the quarters of the most talented courtesan of the day. Crowds of elegantly dressed people mill around. On the sideboard is an assortment of vintage wines. Butlers and footmen take care of the guests. One of them is dressed a l'artiste, and has hair flowing to his shoulders. He is Franz Liszt.

VARTO, Turkey, Sept. 24-- This earthquake-stricken village has a new town hall. The accordion-roofed structure which was made in Pennsylvania, was erected in three hours as dozens of skeptical villagers looked on.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 26 (UPI)--Communist China charged today that a United States warship and two United States military planes intruded into Chinese territory yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25--The Los Angeles Dodgers will long remember how they lost, 2-1, today to a University of Illinois senior named Ken Holtzman who pitches on weekends for the Chicago Cubs.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25--Charles H. Percy's Senatorial campaign moved toward revival today with a call to his supporters to attend a $100-a-plate Republican fund raising dinner here next Friday.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 25--Anthony d'Ambrosio Jr. of Pelham Manor, N.Y., won both the championship and reserve crown in the junior jumper division at the Stratford Farm horse show today.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 (UPI)-- Milt Plum completed more passes today than he had all season, throwing for two touchdowns and setting up two others as the Detroit Lions handed the Atlanta Falcons their third straight National Football League loss, 28-10. The victory was Detroit's second in three games.

MADRID, Sept. 25--Spanish workers and employers will begin voting tomorrow in elections for posts in the officially controlled trade union, which is the key to the regime's plans to maintain the existing political system once Generalissimo Francisco Franco steps down.

DENVER, Sept. 25--The New York Jets, who had no trouble last Sunday beating a strong opponent, fought for their lives today against the Denver Broncos, one of the American Football League's weak sisters.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25-- When the New York Giants were going so well three and four years ago, they invariably won the kind of game that was played on Franklin Field today. WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- The finance ministers of the Group of Ten, representing leading financial nations reaffirmed today their willingness to invite representatives of the less-developed countries to the next stage of negotiation on world monetary reform.

Schools have been closed and teachers persecuted, the Soviet correspondent added.

PARIS, Sept. 25--The increase in conservative political strength in Socialist Scandinavia is stirring up talk, even among the Socialists, of a Scandinavian bid for membership in the European Common Market.

NEWARK, Sept. 25 (AP)-- United States Labor Secretary Willard Wirtz has filed a new suit to set aside the elections last year of three Newark locals of the Operating Engineers Union.

BLANCO, Tex., Sept. 25-- President Johnson spent the morning today chauffeuring family and friends to church, and by the time he was through he had attended both Protestant and Roman Catholic services 25 miles apart.

MARIANNA, Fla., Sept. 24-- In a courtroom of the county courthouse here this week, Mayor Robert King High of Miami came forth to answer questions from about 75 voters.
TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 26-- Japan failed today in an attempt to orbit an artificial satellite.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 25 --The New Haven polo team scored two goals in each of the fifth and sixth chukkers today to defeat Fairfield, 7-5, at Blind Brook Polo Club and win the William Westerlund Memorial Trophy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)--Georgia and Hawaii bring to an end this week the 1966 primaries.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 25 (AP)--Tony Oliva's leadoff home run in the ninth inning gave the Minnesota Twins a 1-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy has denounced Governor Rockefeller for assertedly having made no effort "to do anything" to prepare for New York's Constitutional Convention next year.

A House Judiciary subcommittee has concluded work on a bill of major importance to the nation's writers and composers. It would provide copyright protection for the life of the person holding the copyright, plus fifty years. Present law limits copyrights to fifty-six years--a cut-off point that can impose a major hardship on creative people.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of not being "alert" in preventing what he described as "one major scandal after another" at the trotting tracks.

Miss Susan M. Bisco, daughter of Leonard G. Bisco of New York and Roquebrune-Cap-Martin, France, and of the late Mrs. Loretta V. Bisco, was married yesterday to Michael D. Aaron. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Aaron of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I.
Profits of General Mills, Inc., during the 13 weeks ended Aug. 28 totaled $6,592,000, 10 per cent more than the $5,994,000 earned in the same period last year, the company announced yesterday.
The appointment of Dr. Edward J. Beattie Jr. to the new position of chief medical officer of Memorial Hospital was announced yesterday.

JASCHA HEIFETZ, Gregor Piatigorsky Co. re turned to Carnegie Hall last night for the first of three concerts. As last time, they chose the unusual hour of 7, and selected a program of chamber music. It was a program of unusual interest, containing three seldom-heard pieces, one of which--the Double Quartet by Ludwig Spohr--must have been a novelty to almost everybody in the audience. Apparently the work has not even been recorded, ever.

LAST night's showing of "The Bridge on the River Kwai" probably represented a record investment in a single television presentation. The Ford Motor Company paid about $1.2-million for the right to present the 1957 award-winning film and $600,000 more for air time on the American Broadcasting Company network.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 25--Negroes threw rocks at automobiles tonight after an unsuccessful attempt by white segregationists to march through the Negro section. A white woman suffered a cut from flying glass when a rock broke her automobile windshield.
MICHEL GOMA, of Patou, the Paris couture house, stepped up to the microphone on Lord Taylor's third floor Friday, his face wreathed in smiles, and said, "Bonjour."

HOUSTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)-- Bob Aspromonte's clutch single and the San Francisco Giants' porous defense allowed the Houston Astros to defeat the Giants, 5-4, today, virtually eliminating the Giants from the National League pennant race.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 25 (UPI)--About 20,000 people, some sitting on folding chairs and some wrapped in blankets, lined up around the main post office today to apply to the Baltimore Orioles for World Series tickets. Many had been there since Friday afternoon.
ATLANTA, Sept. 25--The Pittsburgh Pirates muffed their opportunity to move within half a game of the National League lead by losing to the Atlanta Braves today, 6-2.
The body of George Skakel Jr., who was killed in a plane crash in Idaho Friday with four others, is reposing at the Frank M. Reilly Funeral Home in Greenwich, Conn.
ALGIERS, Sept. 25--The Soviet Union has begun to deliver 152mm. self-propelled cannon to Algeria, it was reported here today.

A Unitarian official yesterday endorsed the right of the Rev. Donald S. Harrington to run for Lieutenant Governor, saying that seeking "political office is indeed a new frontier of religious social action."

Governor Rockefeller accepted a bid yesterday to debate three of his gubernatorial rivals on Nov. 6, two days before the elections. But he rejected a two-man debate that his Democratic opponent, Frank D. O'Connor, had proposed to pay for. Mr. O'Connor, in turn, renewed his challenge for a two-man debate in either of two half hours on which he had taken an option on the evening of Oct. 7 over television station WPIX.

RICHMONDVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 25 (AP)--A truck driver was praised today for jackknifing his tractor-trailer on a steep hill leading to the downtown section of this village, to avoid hitting several shoppers.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (UPI) --Two touchdown passes by Sonny Jurgensen and four field goals by Charlie Gogolak set the pace for the Washington Redskins today as they gained a 33-27 National Football League victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers. It was the Steelers' first defeat in three games.

"I think we have only about $700,000 to go," said Mrs. G. Macculloch Miller, president of the board of trustees of the Whitney Museum of American Art. "But I'm crazy to get away from all the talk about money and begin again on some of the interesting things that a museum does."

Combined shipments of iron ore, coal and grain on the Great Lakes last month totaled 21,788,423 short tons, the highest August figure in nine years, the Lake Carriers' Association reported. The record, set in August, 1957 is 21,927,352 tons.

INVERNESS, Scotland, Sept. 25 (UPI)--An American professor said today his suggestion that the fabled Loch Ness monster was a giant sea slug was no more than a guess to explain "the presence of a living phenomenon" in the lake.

A Columbia University research ship that is plumbing the depths of the North Atlantic is fixing its exact position on the ocean by means of orbiting satellites in the first fullfledged civilian use of space navigation systems for oceanographic research.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25--The St. Louis Cardinals overcame a half-time deficit for the third week in a row and beat the Cleveland Browns, 34-28, today to become the only team in the National Football League's Eastern Conference with a 3-0 won-lost record.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 25 --Henry Leonard Smithers, who retired in 1954 as an assistant vice president of the United States Trust Company, died today in his home at 74 Durand Road. He was 73 years old.

A champagne fashion show to benefit the Kips Bay Boys Club will be held Oct. 4 in the Park Avenue Room of Saks Fifth Avenue. Guests will donate a variety of items, which will be sold at the Autumn Boutique on Oct. 17 from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the club's auditorium, 301 East 52d Street.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 25--At midnight tomorrow Rhodesia Railways will take over the control and operation of the rail line through Bechuanaland, Rhodesia's most direct rail link with South Africa.

The marriage of Miss Lois Ann Eidinoff, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maxwell Eidinoff of New Hyde Park, L.I., to Bernard Ira Weinstein took place here yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Weinstein of Brooklyn.
Sonia Vargas, a Peruvian pianist who made her New York debut in Town Hall in 1950 and who also played there in 1960 and 1962, returned yesterday afternoon.

Allen C. Siebens, executive assistant to Frank Pace Jr., president of the International Executive Service Corps, died of cancer Saturday at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. He was 48 years old and lived in Essex Fells, N.J.

Fifty-six properties in Northern Jersey that stand in the way of future construction of portions of the Interstate System and the Route 24 Freeway will be offered at an auction Thursday by the New Jersey State Highway Department. The auction will be held at 10:30 A.M. in the State Highway Building at the itersection of Routes 1, 21, and 22 in Newark.

Harriet Jackson, a mezzosoprano who has toured with the Katharine Dunham Company and the Hall Johnson Choir and also has appeared on Broadway, made her solo debut late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.

TRW, Inc., a Cleveland-based diversified manufacturer announced over the weekend that it had entered into an agreement to acquire Scientific Electronic Products, Inc., for "an undisclosed amount" of common stock.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 25--The backdrop for the airport rally could have been the Rocky Mountains that thrust suddenly up out of the plains here and the spectacular Garden of the Gods rock croppings at their feet.

THE best thing to be said about opera ballet is that they rarely hurt anyone, and they give me personally an excuse to be indulged in my grand passion for opera (or is it merely a passion for grand opera?) free. So, long live opera ballets, may their days never grow shorter or their lengths longer.

IPSWICH, England, Sept. 25 (AP)--Billy Smart, a circus owner and one of Britain's most flamboyant showmen, collapsed and died today after conducting a band in his favorite tune, "I've Got a Lovely Bunch of Coconuts."

SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, Sept. 26--President Chung Hee Park rejected today the resignation of Premier Chung II Kwon and 14 of his Ministers, which was tendered Thursday after the Cabinet was "insulted" by an Opposition lawmaker who threw human waste on the Premier and his Ministers during a National Assembly session.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 25 --Mrs. Edda Mennen, president of Philip J. Bowers Co., a Newark real-estate concern, and the wife of William G. Mennen, board chairman of the Mennen Company, shaving cream and lotions concern, died today at her home, 256 South Mountain Avenue.

TOKYO, Sept. 25--More than 300 people have been killed or are missing and property damage is estimated to be in the millions of dollars today after two typhoons that ravaged the Tokyo area and southern Japan.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 25 (UPI)--John Hadl passed for one touchdown and scored another in leading the unbeaten San Diego Chargers to a 29-20 victory over the Oakland Raiders today in an American Football League game.

American Airlines said yesterday it had offered 12,000 employes a record contract. The Transport Workers Union, which had said it would take new strike votes across the nation after what it considered a breakdown of negotiations Saturday night, had no comment on the new offer.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)-- Len Dawson threw five touchdown passes today--three to Chris Burford--to lead the Kansas City Chiefs to a 43-24 victory over the Boston Patriots in an American Football League game.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 (UPI)--Richie Allen's single to center sent home the winning run in the 13th inning as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-3, today.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 25 (UPI)--The Green Bay Packers struck early on two touchdowns by Paul Hornung and then wrapped things up with Bart Starr's 80-yard touchdown toss to Elijah Pitts today to down the Los Angeles Rams, 24-13, in a battle for the National Football League Western Division lead.
Cardinal Spellman presided at a high potinfical mass in Saint Patrick's Cathedral yesterday commemorating the 1,000th anniversary of Poland's christianity.

A proposal for settling the dispute involving 17 municipal ferry officers, unemployed as a result of their participation in the May, 1965, strike on the... Staten Island ferries, was made yesterday by State Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky.
Sixty law officers from city, county and Federal agencies plotted strategy yesterday on how to deal with 13 Mafia leaders under orders to appear before a Queens grand jury this morning.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- More American scientists and enginers are being sought to go into space and even to explore the surface of the moon.

Bruce E. Shepherd, who retired two years ago as president of the Life Insurance Association of America, died yesterday while playing golf at the Rock Spring Country Club in West Orange, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived at 15 Lee Terrace, Short Hills, N.J.

It will be second time around tomorrow for Democratic voters in Manhattan's Nineteenth Congressional District. The primary there last June wound up in a vote so close and confused that the courts ordered a rerun to determine whether the designation should go to Representative Leonard Farbstein, an old-line organization stalwart, or to Councilman Theodore S. Weiss, his Reform challenger.
Louis Nagel, a young pianist from Louisville, Ky., who received a master's degree from the Juilliard School of Music this year, made an impressive New York recital debut in Town Hall last night.
Domestic airlines must provide for a $500 minimum liability for loss or damage to passengers' baggage, under a new ruling by the Civil Aeronautics Board.
Representatives of the rich and poor nations that are members of the World Bank will join together to conduct this week's annual meeting in Washington. But the gap between them is wider than ever.

In his last major professional act, Mr. St. Sure negotiated for the shipowners last month a five-year contract with dock workers of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union. He noted with satisfaction that the agreement had been achieved without Government intervention.

When John Collier's short story about night people living secretly in a department store ("Evening Primrose") was published years ago, everyone thought it was fantasy. But it can be told authoritatively that night people inhabited their strange world last night in the Stern Brothers store at 42d Street and the Avenue of the Americas. Sunday strollers had no inkling of what was going on behind locked doors and the window displays they stopped to study.

Mayor Lindsay, appointed yesterday a 17-man Operations Research Council to Advise the city on administrative reform and reorganization and lead a "revolution in the management of municipal government."

BUFFALO, Sept. 25 (AP)-- Hagood Clarke intercepted a pass thrown by George Blanda and raced 66 yards for a touchdown with 27 seconds left to give the Buffalo Bills a 27-20 American Football League victory today over the Houston Oilers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) complained in its annual report today that "there is often a considerable gap" between the professed policy of the industrial countries to extend more help to the poor countries "and actual performance."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 25--A Navy officer described today how a tactic called "interdiction in depth" had in six days destroyed 229 railroad cars and more than 200 trucks and had apparently caused serious disruption of military traffic through two important North Vietnamese cities.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell announced yesterday that he would send the longdelayed antipoverty bill to the House today and that he expected action on it to be completed by next Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)--The Senate rackets subcommittee will begin hearings Tuesday into alleged labor racketeering in the NewYork metropolitan area.
A 19-year-old college sophomore was found injured early yesterday on the Sixth Avenue IND tracks north of the downtown 14th Street station.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 25--Miss Karen Auster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Auster, was married today at her parents' home to Arthur Smith Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Levy of New York.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 25 --Miss Beverly Paige Drapkin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Isadore Drapkin of Albany, was married here today to Dr. Donald Stewart Horsburgh of Philadelphia. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon S. Horsburgh of London, formerly of Buenos Aires.

Members of the International Jugglers Association spent the afternoon in Central Park yesterday, gossiping, swapping stunts, practicing and, incidentally, amusing and enthralling several thousand passers-by.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said yesterday that 370 billboards, 20 storefronts and thousands of doorbell ringers would be used in a "mammoth" campaign to defeat the civilian-controlled police review board.
DORTMUND, Germany, Sept. 25 (AP)--Natalia Kutshinskaya, a Soviet Union teen-ager, shared the glory today with the Japanese men's team as the world gymnastic championships ended.
Rockwell, Quinn Wall, Inc., is a young agency that is exactly one month shy of being a year old. It started in business with no accounts, but with a great deal of optimism.

A long and painful home season came to a close for the New York Yankees yesterday. The end brought some measure of comfort, though, for the Yankees of the future, cheered on by a loyal gathering of 16,647 at the Stadium, downed the Boston Red Sox, 3-1.

SACRAMENTO, Calif. Sept. 25 (AP)--California's Republican Chairman was accused today of receiving more than $30,000 from a "secret slush fund" maintained by financial backers of the Republican candidate for Governor, Ronald Reagan.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 25--A strong Republican challenge for Louisiana's Sixth Congressional District seat appeared in the making today following the defeat of Representative James H. Morrison in a run-off election.

The Adela Investment Company, a young concern that backs private enterprise in Latin America, reported yesterday a $159,108 profit in its first full year of operations. The earnings came from operational investments and interest on convertible and straight loans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)--Gen. Nathan F. Twining, former Air Force Chief of Staff, said in a book published today that Congress should determine whether the Defense Department was phasing out its strategic bombers to appease the Soviet Union.
ALBI, France, Sept. 25 (Reuters)--Jack Brabham, Australia's world champion racing driver, won the Albi Formula Two Grand Prix today for the 12th victory in a row for Brabham-Honda cars.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 25--Residents of this city's "most blighted block" have appealed to Washington to hold back more than $700,000 in urban renewal funds to improve their neighborhood. They said they would rather do it themselves.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)--Two top officials strongly indicated today that the Johnson Administration would seek tax increases to dampen America's inflationary economy.
President Johnson's conduct of the war in Vietnam was sharply debated yesterday in the climax of the campaign for the Democratic nomination for Congress in Manhattan's 19th District.
The New York State Department of Motor Vehicles will mail registration forms starting today to 900,000 automobile owners whose 1966 vehicle registrations expire at the end of October.
BERLIN, Sept. 25--Walter Ulbricht, the East German leader, left today by rail for a state visit to Yugoslavia, where he will talk with President Tito and tour the country.

NEWARK, Sept. 25--Miss Muriel B. Lechter of Newark and Lake Mahopac, N.Y., was married today to David L. Wiesen, son of Mrs. Louis P. Rocker of Jerusalem and the late Nissan Wiesen, who had been editor of The Bronx Home News. The bride's parents are the late Dr. and Mrs. Maximilian C. Lechter of Elizabeth.

When 13 underworld leaders keep their date today with 23 private citizens of Queens they will be meeting a panel whose origins are centuries deep in English common law and whose chief function is the protection of the people from the abuses of public officials.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 25--Psychological warfare specialists have moved into the newspaper business in an effort to get their message to the enemy.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Sept. 25 --Stanley Mach's Shenanigan, from the Sea Cliff, L.I., Yacht Club, won by a boat length today and captured the Triton Class national sailing championship on Long Island Sound.
TOKYO, Sept. 25 (UPI)-- Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam said today that the only way to peace was through a Communist victory in the Vietnamese war.
Some Negro parents called yesterday for a "teacher review board" patterned after the civilian-dominated police review board.

CLEMENTON, N.J., Sept. 25 --Billy Joe Patton of Morgan ton, N.C., won the 42d annual George Arthur Crump Cup memorial golf tournament by defeating William Hyndman 3d, a former runner-up for the United States and British amateur championships, 4 and 3, today at the Pine Valley Golf Club. It was a swift final between the two former Walker Cup players, lasting only 2 hours 25 minutes.
The grass is greener on the other side of the fence at Columbia University's Baker Field these days, thanks to a water engineer who has been dowsing on the job.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 25 (UPI)--Vic Davalillo's sacrifice fly scored Chuck Hinton with the decisive run today as the Cleveland Indians rallied for three runs in the ninth inning and a 4-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)--Two university presidents agreed today that there was a great deal of uneasiness on campuses--much of it due to student concern over the nation's affairs.

TRENTON, Sept. 25--Mario Andretti set a race record of 105.127 miles an hour today in winning the 200-mile United States Auto Club race over Trenton's one-mile paved oval. He also moved to within 50 points of clinching his second straight national title and pocketed approximately $10,000 of the $37,500 purse.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 25 (AP) --Five field goals by Lou Michaels and brilliant defensive play by Alvin Haymond led the Baltimore Colts to a 36-14 victory over the San Francisco 49ers today in a National Football League game.

SEVENTH Avenue denizens, whose creativity ap parently knows no bounds, joined hands with the American Ballet Theatre Company last night to present what is expected to be the season's (and perhaps the century's) only fashion show ballet.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25-- New orders for steel continued to lag last week. The order slowdown, which began early in September, was starting to cause a little concern by the end of this week. Some of the more optimistic forecasts for the fourth quarter were being trimmed by as much as a million tons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- Since 1929, Elizabeth Achelis has devoted most of her time and a great part of a considerable private fortune to promoting an international calendar that would remain the same from year to year.
Governor Rockefeller urged yesterday that New York City consider electing its Board of Education rather than having it appointed by the Mayor.
ST. JAMES, L.I., Sept. 25-- The horsemanship championship of the Long Island Professional Horsemen's Association junior show was won by Lauren Di Napoli of Old Brookville today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 25 --A small-town mayor accused of embezzlement involving United States aid funds was removed from office today and shorn of his political rights for 10 years.
The restored Ford's Theater in Washington is expected to be dedicated next April 14, the 102d anniversary of Lincoln's assassination there.

THE City Center Joffrey Ballet ended its first sea son as the resident ballet company of the New York City Center at its new home last night with a program consisting of "Olympics," Gamelan," "Nightwings' and "Cakewalk."
CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (AP) --Clergymen in suburban Westlake today deplored from their pulpits the burning of a home that had been purchased by a Negro minister from Cincinnati.
The Pioneer Finance Company of Detroit, a concern that not so long ago was the model of an American success story, has emerged as the first major corporate casualty of tight money during 1966.

MACON, Ga., Sept. 25 (UPI) --The pastor and two of his assistants at the Tatnall Square Baptist Church on the campus of Mercer University were dismissed Sunday in a dispute over seating of Negroes at worship services.

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 25 --Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Cockerill of Manhasset and East Quogue have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dina Cockerill, to Richard H. Burke of Philadelphia. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Howard Burke of Southern Pines, N.C., formerly of Manhasset.
