LONDON, Sept. 25--The Warren Commission report on the assassination of President Kennedy is undergoing another round of scrutiny in Britain. Critics and defenders seem about equally divided.

PRAGUE, Sept. 25 (Reuters) --The Soviet Union displayed "a new kind of tactical-operational rocket" today for the first time during a parade of four Warsaw Pact armies, Ceteka, the Czechoslovak press agency, reported.
Recent technological advances are bringing an effective three-dimensional X-ray--long only an idea on the drawing boards--to the doctor's doorstep.
DALLAS, Sept. 25--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. charged all of America's religious bodies tonight with "unfaithfulness" to their mission on the question of racial justice.
The Transport Workers Union predicted yesterday that its members working for American Airlines would "reject overwhelmingly" the latest contract proposal by that company.
Stock prices on the American Stock Exchange eased yesterday in quiet trading.
A Manhattan woman, who lost more than $450 on her 100share investment in the old Buckeye Corporation, went to Federal court here yesterday in quest of restitution.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 26 Nikolai P. Firyubin, a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, had two meetings with President Mohammad Ayub Khan today. They met at Saidu Sharif, capital of the state of Swat, in northwestern West Pakistan,
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 A House subcommittee investigating the accounts of Representative Adam Clayton Powell said today that an audit was under way and that counsel would be hired.
United Air Lines reported yesterday a net loss of $634,000 for August, compared with a net profit of $9,040,000 in August of last year.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Beau Creek, at $213.20 for $2, and Spanish Countess, $17.60, won the first two races at Suffolk Downs today and combined for a $2,711.20 daily double. Their post positions were 4 and 11.

PEKING Red columns crowned by symbolic burning torches or neon-lit stars and scores of scarlet billboards proclaiming the thoughts of Chairman Mao Tse-tung are sprouting in this capital. The nation is preparing to celebrate on Saturday the l7th anniversary of the establishment of Chinese Communist power.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 106 on Friday from 106.2 on Thursday.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Sept. 26 Dr. Oliver Cromwell Carmichael, a former president of the University of Alabama, died yesterday after a long illness. His age was 74.

LONDON, Sept. 26 More than 600 men who deliver Austin cars from the British Motor Corporation factory near Birmingham struck today to protest their employers' plans to dismiss half of them. They demanded that work should be shared, half working one week and half the next.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The awesome complex of political power that is represented by the large majority of the incumbents of public office in the United States was busily engaged in the process of selfpreservation before the most recent of several indications of a serious threat against its long domination of official acts and policies. PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 (UPI) The Westinghouse Electric Corporation submitted new wage contract proposals today to four major unions with which it is bargaining nationally.

DONGHA, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 27 Gen. William C. Westmoreland, commander of United States forces in South Vietnam, has asked for Washington's permission to defoliate 50 square miles of the demilitarized zone that divides North and South Vietnam. A final decision is up to President Johnson.
The acquisition-minded Consolidated Foods Corporation has now turned its interests to the home decorating and furnishing field.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 26 United States fighter-bombers battered four surface-to-air missile sites yesterday during 127 missions of several planes each in North Vietnam, a military spokesman said tonight.

Assistant United States Attorney Michael F. Armstrong said yesterday that a Federal grand jury was investigating the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 26 (AP) Paul L. Adams, Conservative party candidate for Governor, disclosed proposals tonight for solving state problems that he said were "the heritage of years of both Democrat and Republican misrule."
BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Sept. 26 Frank D. O'Connor campaigned across the Southern Tier today, quoting Nelson Rockefeller at every stop.

A group of 100 business and professional people in Harlem applauded Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday when he said that "black power" should be rejected if the term meant "segregation by white exclusion."
The Certain-teed Products Corporation announced yesterday in Ardmore, Pa., the election of J.O. Biggs as executive vice president.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 26 Richard M. Nixon declared here tonight that the American people wanted "no part of the rest of the way with L.B.J."

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would raise its rates to Telpak subscribers rather than continue a court dispute with the Federal Communications Commission.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Sept. 26--The South African Government agreed today to shelve a drastic apartheid bill introduced Sept. 16 that would have abolished multiracial political parties and made illegal any mixed groups that even discussed politics.

HARTFORD, Sept. 26. Clayton Gengras, the Republican candidate for Governor, proposed today that the state's public colleges be reorganized to provide "the best for each student's individual needs and abilities."

Dr. Louis Jay Siegal of 155 East 34th Street, a neuropsychiatrist and a specialist in forensic medicine, died Sunday evening at Beth Israel Medical Center of a stroke. He was 76 years old.

TOKYO, Sept. 26 Japanese scientists, who failed today in their first attempt to put a satellite into orbit around the earth, plan to try again in December.
The spot rate on the British pound was slightly firmer in quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Preliminary success with a new chemical treatment for dissolving one form of kidney stones was reported today by a French physician.
The nation's merchandisers of something for nothing the premium industry put on a display of their latest wares at the New York Coliseum yesterday.

A dinner at Leone's Wine Cellar will precede a theater party planned by the board of trustees and benefit committee of the Union Settlement for Thursday at the opening of the Mounted Carabinieri and Arezzo Tournament in Madison Square Garden.

A young mother yesterday escaped trial in Brooklyn in the killing of her 4-year-old son because, the judge ruled, the police had failed to inform her of her rights before she confessed.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26--For four hours the Pittsburgh Pirates held off defeat tonight, but in the last minute they finally succumbed to the Philadelphia Phillies and had their championship hopes further squashed.

Certain remarks about the Board of Education which you made at your press conference last Friday gave the board much concern, for they were out of keeping with the close working relationship which has hitherto prevailed between us.
PLATTE, S. D., Sept. 26 (AP) A small jet airplane exploded in the air today, killing the five occupants, including a Detroit industrialist, his wife and son.

Representative Leonard Farbstein and Councilman Theodore S. Weiss, both Democrats, meet today in a runoff Congressional primary that will provide another sampling of voter sentiment on the war in Vietnam.

The Westec Corporation, citing the "uncertainties" that have been hanging over it for the last month and "inability to arrange satisfactory short-term financing," filed yesterday a petition for a reorganization under Chapter X of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 26 Viscount Brookeborough, 75-year-old former Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, said today he had been asked to head a caretaker government to resolve the current political crisis but had refused.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman today allocated $209,730,000 in agricultural conservation funds among the 50 states, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
The Port of New York Authority asked Congress yesterday to authorize $12.9-million in major improvements, to the Federal navigation channels in Newark Bay and the Hackensack River.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26--South Africa denied in the General Assembly today that she had been false to her "sacred trust" in administering the neighboring territory of South-West Africa.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 26 The dialogue the Government says it is prepared to open with Brazil's angry university students got off to a lame start today.

It was the day of the new look for 19 tellers at the Great Neck and Manhasset, L.I., branches of the Meadow Brook National Bank yesterday. The women wore stylish, new dresses and the men sported new blazers.
GREENBACK, Tenn., Sept. 26 Stockholders of the Merchants and Farmers Bank approved today a recommendation by the directors to issue a 33 1-3 per cent stock dividend to holders of record of Sept. 13.
A 23-year-old harness-racing handicapper, who is reported to have won more than $250,000 in twin doubles, was indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to defraud the Government.
DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP) Auto production lines rolled at full speed this week as the industry hurried toward its goal of 600,000 cars before new models go on display.
A pianist from Pittsburgh and a piano from Germany made their New York debuts at Town Hall last night in a recital that began beautifully and ended doubtfully.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 26 (AP) Bart M. Rogers's Conviviality, who had been racing on the grass, found the switch to the main track no barrier and scored a hard-earned victory in today's R.CA.A. Purse. The 4year-old daughter of Correlation rallied from last to win top money in the seven-furlong feature.
Banks in New York, which have been struggling to keep up with loan demand to finance business expansion, are facing credit pressure from a new quarter.
Helen Kane, the boop-boop-adoop girl of the nineteen-twenties and thirties who converted a babyish singing voice into a fortune and lost the fortune in a dress firm bankruptcy, died yesterday.

THE trouble with flamenco dancers is very largely flamenco dances, for you have to be very devoted to the latter to take a complete recital by the former. The limitations of the art form were spotlighted last night when the flamenco dancer Manuela Vargas opened her first Broadway season at the ANTA Theater with a small company of eight flamenco dancers together with singers and guitarists.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The proposed merger of the two major professional football leagues, which will feature a championship game between the National and American League winners, took a step closer to reality in Congress today. But there were more steps ahead.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 26 (Reuters) Celebrations marking the 80th birthday of former Premier David Ben-Gurion began today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 26 Dr. Paul Tillett, associate director of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, died today of a heart attack in his home at 552 Ewing Street, Princeton. He was 43 years old.

VIENNA, Sept. 26 The state began a retrial today of Franz Novak, known as the "stationmaster of death" because as chief transport officer for Adolf Eichmann he is said to have sent hundreds of thousands of Jews to the gas chambers of Auschwitz during the war.
Ten minutes after Louis Warren slammed down the phone yesterday and cried "No," the phone rang again. He picked it up. He listened. He smiled.
WHEN Virginia Jerome climbed off the bus from Miami six years ago, she had $15 in her purse. Today she owns $300,000 worth of furniture, and pays $20,000 a month in rent.

A loan exhibition, "The Nudes of Modigliani," opening Oct. 11 at the perls Galleries, 1016 Madison Avenue, will benefit the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library. The 20 works in the show come from museums and collectors. William S. Lieberman of the Museum of Modern Art has written a catalogue introduction.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Sept. 26 A state court judge threw out an assault charge today against a former special deputy sheriff accused of wounding a civil rights worker during an outbreak of racial violence in Lowndes County last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 President Johnson began some tough bargaining with Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany today, but soothed his politically troubled guest by arranging to show him around the Cape Kennedy space center tomorrow.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 26(AP) Hurricane Inez moved toward a chain of small vacation isles in the warm tropical Atlantic tonight with her peak winds clocked at 95 miles an hour.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 President Johnson is expected to accept tomorrow an invitation to meet in Manila next month with the leaders of six nations allied in the military effort in South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Yields on new issues of Treasury bills declined from last week's levels, particularly on the six month bills, the Treasury announced tonight.
The stock market ended in a standoff yesterday. A small but steady advance in the afternoon erased losses registered when prices drifted downward in the morning.
The First Boston Corporation, investment bankers, announced here yesterday the election of J. Squier Reimer as vice president and manager of the syndicate department.

THE authorities recommend that a partnership should hold 25 or 26 high-card points to attempt three no-trump with balanced hands. This is true enough as far as it goes, but the manner in which the points are divided between the two hands is significant.
ERNAKULAM, India, Sept. 25 As dawn lit up Ernakulam's blue-green harbor today, delegates to the Congress party conference lined the shores to watch Kerala's traditional snake-boat race.
Assistant Chief Inspector Lloyd G. Sealy was promoted yesterday to the highest post ever held by a Negro in the Police Department.
The Board of Higher Education last night elected Porter R. Chandler its chairman.

HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I., Sept. 26 Ray Scott's goal in the final minute was the highlight of a second-half rally as the Detroit Pistons defeated the New York Knicks, 107-105, in a National Basketball Association exhibition game tonight at Walt Whitman High School.
The beginning of the end of the Mets' most successful season starts tonight at Shea Stadium, where the New Yorkers face the Chicago Cubs.
A civil rights leader charged yesterday that the pattern of anti-Negro practices in the skilled craft unions was continuing.
THE two giants in the linefor-line copying of Eu ropean couture fashions met head-on yesterday. Both emerged clutching laurels.

BONN, Sept. 26--Publishers from the United States make up the largest foreign contingent at the Frankfurt Book Fair, which ends its six-day showing tomorrow. Representatives of 240 American concerns are exhibiting their books and engaging in the off-the-floor trading that goes with the fair.

A group of Chicago investors headed by Marshall Barnes, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Howe Barnes Co., plans to challenge plans of the trustees of the bankrupt New Haven Railroad for selling the carrier's assets to a merged Pennsylvania and New York Central railroad system.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 26 North Vietnam can be expected to launch an offensive in South Vietnam and Laos before the end of this year, the Laotian high command said in a communique today.

TOKYO, Sept. 26 The leaders in Peking wish to settle all differences with the United States by talking but feel that Washington his failed to reciprocate in a peaceful approach, according to an exposition of Chinese Communist policy given to an influential Japanese mission this month by Foreign Minister Chen Yi.
PARIS, Sept. 26 (Reuters) Yves Saint Laurent in augurated today his longawaited Left Bank boutique, to be followed shortly by a chain of ready-to-wear shops in university towns throughout France.
As of Jan. 1, Clyne Maxon, Inc., will have a new president and at least $17-million less in billings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--One of the less appealing aspects of American life these days is the rising opportunity to be shot. Some days the newspapers are a hail of lead: children shooting parents, parents shooting children, wives shooting husbands, hunters bagging their best friends, thugs mowing down policemen, toddlers wounding their playmates, madmen shooting airline pilots, and on and on.
DETROIT, Sept. 26 Up on a wall in Romney headquarters is a sign exhorting the faithful to "Remember the Rose Bowl," and virtually everyone in Michigan knows what that means.
The nation's steel mills halted their upward trend in pourings last week.

SOME critics have opened fire on the field goal in professional football, blasting it as timid, safety-first strategy that even tually will drain off much of the inherent drama of a basically exciting sport. The viewers-with-alarm even found substantial support in the first seven National Football League games, which produced 21 field goals as contrasted with 29 touchdowns--a lopsided proportion.
PANAMA, Sept. 26 Four Americans and two Panamanians whose plane crashed on a survey flight Friday were rescued from the jungle today. The pilot, a Panamanian, died of injuries in the crash.

HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif., Sept. 26 (UPI) Southern Californians dominated the final round of the two days of competition in the eighth annual United States surfing championships yesterday by winning all six major division titles.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Sept. 27 (Reuters) South Vietnam's constituent assembly, elected earlier this month to draft a constitution for civilian rule, was formally inaugurated today.
The association of Felix Candela of Mexico City with the New York firm of Praeger-Kavanagh-Waterbury, engineers-architects, for joint building assignments has been disclosed here.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday it had won a contract worth about $18-million to build two 540kilowatt turbine generators for the Allegheny Power System.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Sept. 26 Mr. and Mrs. George Arthur Hodgkinson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Taylor Hodgkinson, to Stephen Greeley Wilkerson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Arthur Wilkerson Jr. of Colonia.
Mrs. Helen Brown Chanler, poet and the wife of Ashley Chanler, died on Saturday at New York Hospital. She was 48 years old and lived at 2 Rochelle Avenue, City Island, the Bronx.

Earlie Fires was a happy 19year-old jockey after the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. "Boy, that felt good," he said as he returned to the winner's circle aboard the Harbor View Farm's Sammyren. The success of Sammyren was not too unexpected, he was the third choice in a field of eight and paid $9 for $2 to those in the crowd of 28,087 who backed him.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 26 The annual sale by the Stamford branch of the American Association of University Women for its scholarship fund will take place Friday and Saturday at 319 Atlantic Street.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to sell a million shares, or about one-half of its holdings, in the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation.

Jane Morgan did not take part in Sunday night's fashion show ballet as reported in late editions of The New York Times yesterday. Shortly before curtain time, after the last dress rehearsal, the singer said she did not feel well enough to go on, that she was hoarse and tired.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Sept. 26 (Reuters) Parliament approved today a motion calling on the Government to break off diplomatic relations with Portugal and to close all foreign consulates in the Congo.
A muscular, 24-year-old bricklayer was arrested last night on charges of having assaulted three policemen at the southwest corner of Broadway and 43d Street.
Loehmann's, Inc., the New York-based women's apparel discount chain, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the fourth quarter and fiscal year ended July 31.
The Arab-bloc nations decided yesterday to boycott a dinner-dance Mayor Lindsay will hold next Monday in honor of the chiefs of mission attending the United Nations General Assembly meeting.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) The Federal Government opened a three-day conference by telephone today to coordinate state and national manpower programs.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 26 (Reuters) Two persons suffered bullet wounds and dozens more were injured when soccer fans clashed with the police yesterday at a game at Barranquilla, about 500 miles north of Bogota.
FORT WORTH, Sept. 26 (AP) The Van Cliburn International Piano Competition began here today, with 50 contestants participating in the quadrennial event. The first prize is $10,000.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 26 Renewal of war in Yemen by royalist forces by mid-November is probable, Prince Abderrahman Ben Yahia, the Royalist Deputy Premier, said tonight.
BUFFALO, Sept. 26. Five times today, in each of five upstate cities, Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. assailed Governor Rockefeller for "broken promises" and criticized the Democratic party for "bossism."
Governor Rockefeller charged yesterday that Frank D. O'Connor was "woefully misinformed or willfully misrepresenting" the state's new narcotics program and "totally irresponsible."
THE THEORY that a company's convertible bonds do not fall as much as its common stocks has like many other theories been inapplicable during the present market decline.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 26 An anonymous gift of $1.5-million to Williams College for support of the humanities was announced yesterday by John E. Sawyer, president.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 The Los Angeles Dodgers finally made a breakthrough in the National League pennant race tonight. They defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-3, while the Pittsburgh Pirates were losing to the Philadelphia Phillies, and extended their lead to 2 games with six games to play.
HOUSTON, Sept. 25 Lieut. Comdr. Richard F. Gordon Jr. said today that astronauts could do much useful work in space if they could figure out a way to keep from floating away from the work site.
RAINBOW GRILL, R.C.A. Building, Avenue of the Americas and 50th Street. Peter Duchin and his orchestra.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 26 (UPI) Dave Bristol was rehired as manager of the Cincinnati Reds today, and immediately announced, "We're going to make some trades this winter, but we're sure not going to rip this team apart in doing so."
Allan Atlas fainted on stage during his concertina recital last night at Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Don Lock's two-run homer in the seventh inning today gave the Washington Senators a 3-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox in the second game of a double-header watched by only 485 paying spectators.

The board of directors of Bedford-Stuyvesant's antipoverty program yesterday named Walter C. Pinkston as acting executive director to succeed Mrs. Dorothy Orr, who, along with three other high staff members, resigned last week in a dispute with the board.

The Republican and Liberal candidates for Governor have both raised the issue of bossism against their Democratic opponent in the current state campaign. Although this issue lends itself more easily to slogans and oversimplification than to careful definition, it is still true that troublesome questions of political integrity and responsible leadership remain.

Governor Rockefeller's call for a study to determine whether New York City should have an elected rather than an appointed Board of Education is certain to become controversial before any recommendations for action are submitted. How touchy his suggestion is was immediately illustrated...

"CARAVAN 66," a traveling fashion show organ ized by a group of intrepid Ivy League undergraduates, will make its second stop on a whirlwind tour of 27 universities and women's colleges tonight at Marymount College, Tarrytown, N.Y.
The Duke Power Company, Charlotte, N.C., was licensed yesterday by the Federal Power Commission to build a hydro-electric power project at a cost of more than $86million near Clemson, S.C.

YONKERS, Sept. 26 Dr. and Mrs. Irving J. Stone have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Candice Diane Stone, to Stephen Mark Drimmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Drimmer of New Rochelle.
ATHENS, Sept. 26--Litton Industries has agreed to discuss with the Turkish Government plans for rapid economic development for Turkey, a spokesman for the company said here tonight.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 26 Mr. and Mrs. John Douglas Maxwell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marcia Elise Maxwell, to John Franklin Dennis-Browne of Grange-over-Sands in Lancashire, England, and New York. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Sidney DennisBrowne.

Sales and earnings of the Avco Corporation for the three and nine months ended Aug. 31 were the highest in the company's 37-year history, the producer of industrial and defense equipment reported yesterday.
South Africa's new Prime Minister has decided to back away for the present from one of the most drastic extensions of apartheid yet proposed by the Nationalist Government.

TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 26 (AP) George F. Kerrigan, a 58-year-old player from Fairfax, Calif., took the lead on the first day of qualifying for the United States Golf Association senior tournament at the Tucson National Golf Club course.

THORPE BAY, England, Sept. 26 (AP) Britain won the International Catamaran Challenge Trophy for the fifth straight time today when the double-hulled craft, Lady Helmsman, beat Gamecock, the American craft, in the sixth and clinching race of the series.
WANTAGH, L.I., Sept. 26 An $8-million Nassau County park is taking unusual shape on what was formerly 112 acres of marsh land here.

The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that Representative Adam Clayton Powell must stand trial for criminal contempt of court for failing to satisfy a defamation-of-character judgment he lost more than three years ago.

Nearly 300 members of Quality Bakers of America Cooperative, Inc., met yesterday with Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, and the Assistant Majority Leader of the United States Senate and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.
The New York Yankees, now in last place in the American League, began a shake-up yesterday by dismissing Red Barber, the senior broadcaster on their radio and television staff.

BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 26 Dr. and Mrs. Edward J. Driscoll have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Yvonne Driscoll, to Guillermo Sevilla-Somoza, son of Dr. Guillermo Sevilla-Sacasa, Ambassador of Nicaragua, and Mrs. Sevilla-Sacasa. A January wedding is planned.

PARIS, Sept. 26 A voice from the grave today accused Gen. Mohammed Oufkir, Moroccan Interior Minister, of having pressed a dagger to the throat of Mehdi Ben Barka, kidnapped Opposition leader, in a French villa last October.

Last night, as on every Monday during the National Football League season, Coach Allie Sherman of the New York Giants suffered second-guessers gladly. Only this time he needed a little more aplomb. On Sunday, his team dropped a 35-17 decision to the Eagles at Philadelphia.
Prices moved narrowly in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

The National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., said yesterday it had revoked the registration of William H. Bodfish, a salesman formerly employed by a securities firm in Philadelphia, after he was found to have sold counterfeit bonds.
Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority, has agreed to serve as an advisory member of the Committee for a Greater Jamaica.
An office building will soon rise from the depths of the Hudson River, 300 feet offshore from an abandoned ferry slip at Exchange Place in Jersey City.
The appointment of Robert L. Pennock Jr. as vice president of the photographic products division of Honeywell, Inc., was announced yesterday.

The American Broadcasting Company's telecast of "The Bridge on the River Kwai" was reported yesterday to have changed the viewing habits of millions of persons on Sunday evening. The network said rating samples indicated that 60million persons throughout the country had watched the motion picture or some parts of it.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 The North Vietnamese Government might accept the opening of peace negotiations in exchange for a United States commitment to a scheduled withdrawal of its forces, according to a former French Cabinet minister.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 More policemen were added today to the contingent investigating the murder of Valerie Percy and the command post for the investigation was moved from the cramped Kenilworth police station to the police station in Winnetka, three miles north. Police Chief Robert M. Daley of Kenilworth said there were now more than 30 investigators on the case.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Senator Wayne Morse said today that the cut in national Teacher Corps funds in a $10.5billion money bill before the Senate was "a sad thing" and a blow to educational opportunities for underprivileged children.
DETROIT, Sept. 26.--The Ford Motor Company, under heavy competitive pressure rescinded tonight a substantial portion of the price uncreases it announced last week for its 1967 models.
ATLANTA, Sept. 26 (AP) Willie McCovey and Tom Haller accounted for five runs on homers as the third-place San Francisco Giants routed the Atlanta Braves, 8-2, tonight.
A spokesman for major milk interests stormed out of a City Council hearing on rising prices yesterday charging that the line of inquiry was "prejudging the industry."

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 (AP) The executive secretary of Painters Union District Council 16 was arrested today and charged with conspiracy to commit murder in connection with the slaying of Dow Wilson, a union leader.
Lee Hastings Bristol Jr., president of Westminster Choir College of Princeton, N.J., has been elected to the board of directors of the New York Philharmonic.

AFTER a series of three introductory performances, in each of which a new production was offered, the Metropolitan Opera last night turned its new stage over to one of its previous productions, Puccini's "Turandot," and its new auditorium over to its first subscription audience.

The Department of Hospitals is seeking to transfer to the City University the operation of its four nursing schools, in keeping with a national trend toward moving nursing education from hospital control to the campus.
The teamsters blockaded two downtown Hudson River piers yesterday to halt nonunion drivers from working for what the union termed less than contract rates.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 26 Mrs. Kaisley Blake has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Charlotte Hayes Blake, to William Lowman Gallagher, son of Mrs. Armen Sarafian of Pasadena, Calif., and William Charles Gallagher of California, Pa.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Administration hopes that North Vietnam might respond favorably to the latest American peace proposals faded today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The White House said today that President Johnson's schedule was clear of any political events at this time a month and a half before the November elections.
DALLAS, Sept. 26 The Disciples of Christ put themselves in the mainstream of American Protestantism today.

The merger of two of the city's oldest real estate companies Nassoit-Sulzberger Co., Inc., and Phillips, Wood Dolson, Inc. was announced yesterday by Edward Sulzberger, president of Nassoit-Sulzberger and Adrian H. Phillips, head of Phillips, Wood Dolson,...

A Coast Guard board of investigation issued a preliminary report yesterday stating that a fire aboard the German passenger liner Hanseatic on Sept. 7 would have been a major disaster had it occurred at sea.

The principal of an East Harlem public school where vandals committed "thousands of dollars" worth of damage on Sunday, said yesterday he would ask the school board to provide a night watchman or burglar alarm system.

THE late F. Scott Fitzgerald once suggested that New Yorkers became neurotic the day the Empire State Building opened. The view from the top provided the rather disturbing evidence that beyond Manhattan there existed another world. How long it had been there, no one could tell.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 (UPI) A Negro couple, whose home in West Lake, a wealthy allwhite suburb, was burned, should have warned local officials they were moving into the neighborhood, Mayor Alexander R. Roman said today.

The experts estimate that hospital costs in this country are going to rise by 10 to 30 per cent next year alone. Continuation of such rates of increase over the years immediately ahead would mean that hospital costs in the early 1970's would be double or more than double the existing high levels.
The bumper harvest of wheat now under way apparently discouraged traders yesterday. Prices moved down quite sharply for all deliveries.
Short-term interest rates tended to decline yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The United States Government has developed a comic-strip type of political poster that appears to work equally well on both sides of the globe.
"Daphne in Cottage D," the two-character play starring Sandy Dennis that was to open Nov. 30 at the Music Box, has been postponed to February.
Peter Nero, pianist, gave a benefit concert last night at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin F. Buttenwieser, 450 East 52d Street. About 150 persons, who paid $50 a ticket, attended.

The relationship between the Board of Education and the city administration is too important to New York's future to be permitted to degenerate into either a name-calling match or a petulant defense of established routines. The crisis of Intermediate School 201, which brought the conflict into the open, is merely an incidental indication of problems deeply rooted in the total urban dilemma.

City Hall moved yesterday to reduce steep increases in rent and carrying charges that had been projected for 20,000 families in 60 middle-income housing projects. The increases were to have gone into effect during the next six months.

GLENDALE, Calif., Sept. 26 Dr. Hubert L. Eaton, founder of the vast Forest Lawn Memorial-Parks, was entombed today in an elaborate ceremony in which he was formally inducted as an Immortal of Forest Lawn Memorial Court of Honor.
The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday major expansions in its five-year, 50,000mile warranty plan to make it the broadest in the automotive industry.

LISBON, Sept. 26 The Portuguese press bitterly criticized the United States Embassy in Kinshasa today for not having helped Portuguese Embassy personnel to defend themselves against last Saturday's mob attack.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 26 (UPI) Four awards for $1,000 each for excellence in businessnews writing were announced here yesterday at the annual convention of the Independent Natural Gas Association of America.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 A Superior judge today described the purported autobiography of Hedy LaMarr, "Ecstasy and Me," as "filthy, nauseating and revolting," but refused to halt its publication as requested by the former film star.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Fearful that their bickering might have endangered the $1.75-billion antipoverty bill, Democrats sought to close ranks today as the embattled measure reached the House floor.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 26 American photo reconnaissance planes, a computer and a handful of technicians pushing buttons in Washington are expected to play a major role in the future of the South Vietnamese peasant behind the plow.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 (UPI) Federal District Judge Joseph S. Lord 3d today set Oct. 3 for a hearing on a preliminary injunction to prevent Girard College from barring Negro youths.

Dr. and Mrs. Rafael Montoro of New York and Coral Gables, Fla., have announced the engagement of Dr. Montoro's daughter, Miss Victoria Montoro, to John Frederick Smithies, son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Smithies of New York, formerly of Havana. A Dec. 17 wedding is planned.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 26 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and Britain's Commonwealth Secretary, Herbert Bowden, held a brief and private meeting tonight before breaking off their discussions on the impasse over Rhodesia's independence.

ROME, Sept. 26 Pope Paul VI told a international gathering of Roman Catholic theologians today that it was their task to protect the faith from subversion by "erroneous modern ideologies" in a "grave hour."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The Commerce Department said today that United States companies planned to spend $9.16-billion abroad for plant and equipment this year. This is 21 per cent more than was spent last year and slightly above the estimate made earlier this year.

HONOLULU, Sept. 26 Miss Anne MacNaughton, daughter of Malcolm MacNaughton and the late Mrs. Elizabeth Grelle MacNaughton, was married Saturday afternoon to Dr. John Jacob Keyser. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Keyser of Arlington, Va.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 Vice President Humphrey chose today to praise Gov. Edmund G. Brown rather than ridicule Ronald Reagan as he pitched into California's bitterly contested governorship race.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The managing director of the International Monetary Fund warned today of possible dangers in the "dramatic" rise in interest rates in nearly all of the industrial countries. He strongly hinted that countries ought to be willing to raise taxes instead of using tight money to fight inflation.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 26 (UPI) Four awards for $1,000 each for excellence in businessnews writing were announced here yesterday at the annual convention of the Independent Natural Gas Association of America.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 A Superior judge today described the purported autobiography of Hedy LaMarr, "Ecstasy and Me," as "filthy, nauseating and revolting," but refused to halt its publication as requested by the former film star.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Fearful that their bickering might have endangered the $1.75-billion antipoverty bill, Democrats sought to close ranks today as the embattled measure reached the House floor.

Cigarette shipments fell 4.5 per cent in July from the level in the corresponding month last year. The latest total was the smallest for any month this year, according to Internal Revenue Service statistics.

If anyone is thinking of building a nice five-room house with ballroom in the 18th-century style, with appropriate authentic furnishings of the period, he'd better have $800,000. That is the price tag of the new Gracie Mansion reception wing. And let it be said right now that it is worth every penny that the city did not spend.

COOKING schools have proliferated in the New York area with the enthusiasm of moist mung peas producing bean sprouts. Whereas 10 years ago there may have been three or four "schools" where the public could go for kitchen instruction, there are today more than a score where home cooks may learn the nuances of French cuisine, the scrutables of Chinese cooking and the rich delights of Viennese pastries.
ROCHESTER, Sept. 27 Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner is expected to endorse Frank D. O'Connor for governor in an attempt to give the Democratic candidate significant impetus in his campaign.

ROSELLE, N.J., Sept. 27 (UPI) The Detroit Pistons overcame a huge first-half deficit for the second straight time and defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 120-117, tonight in an exhibition game between National Basketball Association teams.
GENEVA, Sept. 27 The United States told major cotton textile exporting nations today that its imports soared by more than a third in the last 12 months.

Mrs. G. Macculloch Miller, whose mother opened the first Whitney Museum of American Art in a Greenwich Village studio 58 years ago, looked around the lobby of the new $6-million Whitney Museum at Madison Avenue and 75th Street yesterday and said that her mother's dream had come true.
WANTAGH, L.I., Sept. 27 Mr. and Mrs. William Kehlhem have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Lynn Kehlhem to George William Knight Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Knight of New York.
THERE is one thing about a dinner party, no matter how it is going. You can always get off in a corner with someone you like.

THINGS were happening at Maximilian yesterday. By 9:30 A.M., the 57th Street fur salon was filled with about 150 members of the press and a few eager guests who couldn't wait for the customer showing of the new collection later in the afternoon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 Charles H. Percy will resume his Republican campaign for the United States Senate in midOctober, aides said today. But his schedule will be curtailed and altered as a result of the unsolved murder of his 21-yearold daughter Valerie.

The head of a national public opinion polling organization said last night that white resentment over the Negro civil rights movement was growing and could cost the Democratic party heavily in the November elections.

ATLANTA, Sept. 27--Former Gov. Ellis Arnall, a racial moderate, is favored to defeat Lester Maddox, the Atlanta segregationist who won national renown trying to keep his restaurant from being integrated, in tomorrow's runoff primary for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 (UPI) A gasoline barge, ripped open by an underwater piling, burst into a huge fireball on the San Francisco waterfront early today, apparently killing six sailors.

The Sarah Lawrence College Chorus, recently returned from a tour of Europe during which it sang 15 concerts in 7 countries, performed at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. Directed by Harold Aks, the group of 31 girls sang a program that ranged from Palestrina's "Hodie Christus Natus Est to Bartok's "The Wooing of a Girl." The list included Brahms's "Marienlieder," and Stravinsky's Four Russian Peasant Songs.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 27 New York State and Connecticut proposed today that they take over commuter service on the New Haven Railroad between New York City and New Haven and then spend $80million improving it.
Mrs. Phyllis Simmons stood under the words "CASEWORKER ORIENTATION" on the green blackboard and asked her first question: "How many of you have ever been in a welfare center?"

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27--Indonesia is scheduled to resume her seat in the United Nations tomorrow with no more ceremony than a brief acknowledgement by the President of the General Assembly, Abdul Rahman Pazhwak of Afghanistan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--President Johnson's forthcoming trip to the Philippines should be a useful combination of good politics and good diplomacy. It will help correct the blunders of his last Pacific conference at Hawaii, and meanwhile enable him to dominate the news in the critical days before the November Congressional elections.
HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Sept. 27 A jury of eight Negroes and four whites acquitted Eugene Thomas, a Ku Klux Klansman, of murder tonight in the death of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo.

The Actors Studio Theater has canceled plans to resume this reason. The reason given is shortage of funds. One official of the organization said yesterday that it would be activated again next year. Another reported that $100,000 had been contributed or pledged toward a goal of $1-million.
Avis, Inc., said yesterday it planned to extend car-rental rate increases to various major cities next year.

ASAD, thoughtful little documentary about a real life school drop-out named Jimmy was carried on Channel 13 last night. Unlike so many programs that form the staple of commercial television it did not have a happy ending.

There will be no more Ballantine blasts at Yankee Stadium. P. Ballantine Sons, the brewery that has sponsored radio and television broadcast of New York Yankees baseball games for many years, will not continue its sponsorship next year.

BONN, Sept. 27 The six-day Frankfurt Book Fair, the largest in the world, closed today. It was considered the most successful since the fair started in 1949, with 2,499 publishers from 52 countries represented.

TELEVISION'S calmest and most bening series ever began last night on Channel 13. There were no guns, no horses, no fist fights, no private eyes, no white tornadoes and no politicians. Once the unhurried introduction was out of the way, all that could be heard were soothing guitar sounds and a few quiet comments spoken by the elder statesman of his instrument, Andres Segovia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--The Justice Department agreed today to the dismissal of Federal indictments against 17 white men accused of conspiracy in the murder of three civil rights workers two years ago in Neshoba County, Mississippi.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Senate voted today to open the door for hospital segregation in cases involving the physical and mental well-being of patients.
The standings of the National Football League show that the Cleveland Browns, without Jim Brown, have lost two of three games. Think nothing of it.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 27 The Prime Minister, Capt. Terence M. O'Neill, won a unanimous vote of confidence tonight for the liberal policies of his three-year-old Government.
Samuel C. Johnson, 38, was elected yesterday as the fifth president in the 80-year history of S.C. Johnson Son, Inc., the producer of Johnson's Wax and other home products.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 27 (AP) Brandy's Play, ridden by Phil Grimm, wore down the leaders in the stretch to win the Elmer Purse today and return a meet record payoff of $97 for $2 to win.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 The whole subject of open housing and "white backlash" has become a key issue, either stated or implied, as an increasingly bitter California campaign for the governorship enters its final six weeks.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) The United States abandoned plans today to test a 160-pound space flight back pack for astronauts on the final Gemini flight, scheduled for Oct. 31.
A roadway elevated 80 feet above the street is being seriously considered by the city as one of the possible alternatives to Robert Moses' plan for the lower Manhattan expressway.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis Kernan of 163 East 65th Street and Fishers Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Tilton Kernan, to Patrick F.J. Macrory, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick A. Macrory of Waltonon-the-Hill in Surrey, England, and Ardmore, Northern Ireland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The heads of a dozen or so major television and electronics companies will meet tomorrow with Government officials, presumably to discuss the possibility of holding their... price lines.

EDWIN O'CONNOR has written one fine novel, "The Last Hurrah" (1956). It was about the last campaign of Frank Skeffington, an Irish political boss of an unnamed New England city. Of course, "everybody knew" that "The Last Hurrah" was based on the extraordinary career of the late James Michael Curley and that the city was the maligned.

Five men were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges that they had defrauded the public of $67,500, in what United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said was the "most brazen-type boilerroom operation."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 Thanat Khoman, Thailand's Foreign Minister, declared today that the United Nations and its officials did not have the right to barter South Vietnam's freedom and sovereignty for dubious promises of peace.
The Irving Trust Company will unveil a 48-foot mural depicting the history of the textile and apparel trades at its new branch at 1440 Broadway, which opens today.

The Transport Workers Union said yesterday it would strike American Airlines at 6:45 A.M. today unless the airline replied "more realistically" to its demands for a 30 per cent wage increase and other contract gains.

As American art grew from small informal beginnings, the Whitney Museum of American Art has grown from the showings of unrecognized artists in the Greenwich Village studio of Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney into the formidable institution that opens its striking new home to the public today.

AZADPUR, India, Sept. 27 Shibhu Shambhu Bhonsle wriggled his toes this morning in the hot sand on the shoulder of the Grand Trunk Road. "It's good to be back on the road again," he said. "If you stop for too long your legs get rusty."

Miss Nicole Rouchon, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samson Rauchon of Port-auPrince, Haiti, has become the fiancee of Dr. Jerome Averette. He is the son of William Averette of Birmingham, Ala., and the late Mrs, Bessie Averette.

MICHAEL BURKE, the new president of the Yankees, appears as though he might be an admirable road-company choice for the Rex Harrison part in "My Fair Lady." But the dapper and debonair boss of the defused Bombers doesn't have to go on the stage to find drama.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 North Vietnam, with Soviet aid, is responding to an increase in United States bombing raids by developing a formidable antiaircraft defense system, American military analysts say.
New orders for machine tools continued to decline in August but still stayed slightly above the year-earlier level.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 27--The Army football team, victorious in its two games under its new head coach, Tom Cahill, will face Penn State here Saturday before a sell-out crowd of 31,000 in Michie Stadium.

GABERONES, Bechuanaland, Sept. 27 Bechuanaland's Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, Richard Mannathoko, has just completed a British Government-sponsored curse in diplomacy. He will need all he learned to try to persuade a planeload of visitors to Bechuanaland's independence celebrations that there just is no room for them.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Treasury auctioned its first issue of nine-month bills today at an average discount rate of 5.807 per cent. The issue was for $500-million.
The spot rate on the British pound eased slightly yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 A Senate investigator testified today that a New York labor relations consultant had arranged "sweetheart," (collusive) contracts for management with unions whose leadership was dominated either by himself, his business associates or his relatives.

William Ricketts, an Australian who landed here several weeks ago with four and a half tons of sculpture only to find that what he thought was an invitation wasn't, has found a place to exhibit his work in Knoxville, Tenn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Gold continues to retain a magnetic appeal for the world's financial statesmen. The lure of gold was evident in talks with finance ministers and... central bankers here for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund. Gold is especially prized by the Europeans, who have built up their gold reserves under the present monetary system and who insist that it must be an important part of any new system.
The state should tap the revenues of road, bridge and tunnel authorities to help mass transit and commuter railroads, Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said yesterday.
SAN DIEGO, Sept. 27 (AP) Joyce Hoffman of Capistrano Beach, Calif., was the first winner today in preliminaries at the world surfing championships.
A 15-story building of the New York University Medical Center complex at 435 East 30th Street was dedicated yesterday as the William B. and Cele H. Rubin Hall of Residence.

A lawyer for the chief investigator of the House Education and Labor Committee spent the day in court here yesterday trying to prevent newsmen from hearing testimony on his client's financial dealings with Representative Adam Clayton Powell.

A net inflow of $180-millon in savings into the nation's 4,500 Federally insured savings and loan associations during August was reported yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. But the inflow was less than one-third of the $543million influx reported for the corresponding month of 1965.
A training program run by the Workers Defense League is helping to open the doors of building trade unions to young Negroes.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 27 (AP) Airport workers found a 17-year-old boy in the wheel well of a jet airliner today. The boy said he had traveled in the unpressurized compartment from Bogota, Columbia, a distance of nearly 2,000 air miles.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 (AP) Hundreds of Negroes, mostly teen-agers, set fires, broke store windows and threw rocks at the police tonight a few hours after a white patrolman fatally shot a Negro youth.
City Council President O'Connor received the support of the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday, it was announced by the union's president, Thomas W. Gleason.

MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (UPI) Excavators have accidentally discovered a moat filled with the skulls and bones of men, women and children shot by German forces 120 miles east of Riga, the Soviet press agency, Tass, said today.
Finland must temporarily restrict her economic growth to gain a sound basis for renewed expansion, her Finance Minister, Mauno Koivisto, said here yesterday.
HOUSTON, Sept. 27--Orville S. Carpenter, retired president of the Texas Eastern Transmission Company, was appointed today as trustee to reorganize the beleagured Westec Corporation.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) Eddie Stanky, manager of the Chicago White Sox, released three coaches, Ray Berres, Tony Cuccinello and Don Gutteridge, today.

Paperboard production rose 4.9 per cent with 455,100 tons in the week ended Sept. 24, from 433,900 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

Following are some samples of original and revised 1967 Ford and Chrysler prices compared with General Motors new prices, which have not been revised. Models are comparable in category, but standard equipment differs. Prices are F.O.B. Detroit.

Archbishop John J. Krol, chairman of the Roman Catholic Bishops' Committee for Motion Pictures, yesterday issued a statement applauding the Motion Picture Association of America for adopting a new Production Code.
The Senate of the United States has turned its back on the 1966 Civil Rights Bill. And injustice rolls on, unchanged and unashamed.
Soybeans, which opened the week with a steady showing in futures trading after a long downward drift, managed to turn in some slight gains yesterday.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 27 (Reuters) India has asked the United States for five million more tons of grain to be delivered by the end of March, a Food Ministry spokesman said today.

PARIS, Sept. 27 (Reuters) Sweden's Trade Minister, Gunnar Lange, rejected tonight the Danish proposal for a Scandinavian effort to join the Common Market. He said in a Stockholm broadcast that any such move should include a bid by Britain.
Irving Goldstein of Butterfield House, 37 West 12th Street, died of a heart attack Monday in the East Side upholstery store that he had operated for 20 years. He was 50 years old.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 27 Paul H. Stoutt, advertising sales representative of the National Geographic Magazine, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 177 White Plains Road. He was 53 years old.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 27 Mrs. Vera Weizmann, widow of Dr. Chaim Weizmann, the first President of Israel, was buried today with state honors.
An amateur photographer was charged with killing a man who objected to allowing his girl friend to pose in the nude yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The United States has agreed to sell Saudi Arabia $100 million in vehicles to modernize the Saudi army, State Department officials said tonight.

Federal Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr. took under consideration here yesterday a request by Sylvester K. Stevens that Miss Helen C. Frick be forced to give up a Pennsylvania court case involving a history written by Mr. Stevens.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 27 A December wedding is planned by Miss Marguerite Cynthia Agathon and James Alfred Keeshan. Their engagement has been made known by Dr. and Mrs. Oshin Agathon, parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Keeshan is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Keeshan of Stamford, Conn.

FOR the last 21 seasons, Princeton teams have made gridiron life miserable for Columbia's Lions. This Saturday in Palmer Stadium Dick Colman's Tigers will face a Columbia squad still "down" from its opening-game, 38-0 loss to Colgate. Colman said yesterday: "I don't think...
"One of these days," Willie Shoemaker said yesterday at Aqueduct, jabbing at a foamcovered stubble of beard, "I'm really going to break out with a bunch of winners. Things are bound to improve."

American Export Isbrandtsen Lines announced yesterday that it would begin a new express service between United States east coast ports and Far East ports via the Panama Canal. The first ship assigned to the service is the Export Builder, which will begin the monthly service Oct. 27.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27 President Johnson appealed to the Soviet people today for a new era of friendship and understanding between the United States and the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Albert J. Redway, a retired financial representative for the Export-Import Bank here, died today at the George Washington University Hospital. He was 70 years old.
Store No. 1550 of the F.W. Woolworth Company chain, a Manhattan landmark that has attracted "five and ten" customers for the last 42 years, is due to become a campus for candidates for Ph.D. degrees.

Representative Leonard Farbstein has won renomination for a sixth term in the run-off Democratic primary in the Nineteenth Congressional District. The result was disappointing to us, but not particularly surprising. Mr. Farbstein has served the district faithfully for many years, has a liberal voting record, and strong alliances with the regular party organization.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 Next year, anyone in Los Angeles who wants to paint his house will have to use paint approved by the county. The county will tell retailers what kind of paint they can sell, which, in effect, is the same as telling manufacturers what kind of paint they can make if they are interested in the big Los Angeles market.
DETROIT, Sept. 27 The Chrysler Corporation cut back on the increased prices of its 1967 model automobiles today by an average of $24 a car.

The Justice Department, which for more than four years has been fighting the merger of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central railroads, told a Federal Court here yesterday that it had no position now on a move of nine other railroads in seeking to delay the merger.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 27 Gus Edson, who for many years drew the popular comic strip "The Gumps," died last night of a heart attack at his home at 149 Weed Avenue. He was 65 years old.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 27 The military junta hinted today that it might consult the new constitution-drafting assembly concerning Government policy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 President Johnson formally accepted today an invitation to attend a conference on Vietnam to be held by Asian allies of the United States. Senator J.W. Fulbright immediately criticized the acceptance as a politically motivated gesture.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Foreign Minister Adam Malik of Indonesia indicated today that he favored a halt in United States bombing of North Vietnam.

Jim Seymour of Notre Dame, a sophomore, made a sensationa varsity debut last Saturday. Seymour gained 276 yards with passes he caught against Purdue, the most ever collected in major college ranks with one exception.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Use of a special diet can postpone, sometimes for several years, the fatal deterioration in health of some victims of incurable kidney disease, scientists reported today.
The 400-member Bolshoi Opera will perform in North America for the first time next summer, at Expo 67, the Canadian World's Fair in Montreal.
DALLAS, Sept, 27 The Protestant Denomination of which President Johnson is a member refused today to take a clear-cut stand on the war in Vietnam.

YONKERS, SEpt. 27 Bands played "For He's a Jolly Good Fellow." Buttons proclaimed slogans like "Bella Bella Rockafella." Girls showed up in red fire hemets, along with a shiny antique fire truck emblazoned "Rockefeller Volunteer Company."
ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 27--The Government ordered the immediate closure cf the Cuban Embassy today and asserted that it had evidence that Cuba was interfering in the internal affairs of Ghana.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 (UPI) Top-seeded players had little difficulty today in the third round of the Pacific Coast international tennis championships at the Berkeley Tennis Club.

EL PASO, Tex., Sept. 27 (UPI) Two El Paso lawyers said today that the Governor of the Mexican state of Chihuahua had decided to allow a 10-car train loaded with food and equipment to cross the United States-Mexican border and be sent to the Tarahumara Indians.

Porter R. Chandler, newly elected chairman of the Board of Higher Education, said yesterday that the goal of the City University was to provide "some kind of education for all high school graduates who desire it."
Ronald Anderson's modestly billed trumpet recital at Town Hall last night was a combination survey of literature for the instrument, symposium on contemporary music and one-man music festival.
A jury will decide whether the two sisters of Billy Rose, the late theatrical entrepreneur, are entitled to break his will, which left most of his estimated $50-million estate to charity.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., Sept. 27 Mrs. George Van Tassel of Glen Ridge and Mrs. Thomas McDarby of Deal tied for the gross lead today in the first round of the 36-hole Neilsen Memorial tournament at the Shawnee Country Club.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 27 Tribal violence has spread to Nigeria's Eastern Region, with reports of Ibo attacks on Hausa traders in Enugu, the Eastern region's capital.
Max Siegal, who retired four years ago as co-owner of the Monarch Wash Suit Company, New Bedford, Mass., boys' clothing manufacturers, died on Monday at Woodridge, N.Y.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 27 President Johnson and Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany agreed here today to undertake a "searching reappraisal" of the needs and cost of European defense.
A computer system that can cut clothing patterns of all sizes from a single, original design has been developed by the International Business Machines Corporation.

The Lerner Stores Corporation, which is controlled by the McCrory Corporation, expects to earn $1.30 a share for the fiscal year ending Jan. 31, Harold M. Lane Sr., chairman of the executive committee and chief executive officer, told a group of security analysts at the Bankers Club here yesterday.

NEW JERSEY is the latest state to conduct special waterfront hunts aimed at teaching youngsters the proper and sportsmanlike way of gunning for ducks and geese. New York and Massachusetts previously had instituted such projects.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) The president of the Air Transport Association said today that airlines, airport operators and other aviation interests must prepare to handle the forthcoming expansion of passenger and cargo air traffic.
The week-long Jewish Festival of Succoth, the Feast of Tabernacles, begins at sundown today with services in synagogues and temples.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Competitive pressures and Government urging both played a role in the decisions of automobile manufacturers to raise prices this year by less than they had planned. But no official involved in the Government's hold-the-line conversations with industry would attempt to say which had been the more important.
PHIL HILL, the only American on the list of world road racing champions, hasn't had a ride on the elite Formula One circuit this year.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary accused the supporters of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday of making charges in the civilian review board fight that were "totally without foundation."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Fourteen countries, rich and poor, supported today the future creation of a new international money to supplement gold, but France termed the idea "intoxication" and "an illusion."
The Justice Department sued the General Electric Company yesterday, charging it was fixing the prices of light bulbs.

THE Whitney Museum's friends have started breathing again: The new building is going to work just fine. And to show off the new quarters at their best, the Whitney is beginning its new life with an exhibition called "Art of the United States: 1670-1966" that begins with Colonial portraits on the first floor and winds up on the fourth with a summary of what is going on today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 The American merchant marine could be and should be used as a "transportation tourniquet" to stem the outflow of dollars and to arrest the nation's persistent unfavorable balance of payments, Representative William S. Mailliard said today.
Thomas J. Egan, a retired police lieutenant and once the "most popular cop in the Bronx," died yesterday in his home at 1245 Bradford Avenue, the Bronx. He was 81 years old.
COPACABANA, 10 East 60th Street, Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme, singers; Pat Cooper, comedian.

Carl A. Richter, who retired at the end of 1951 as a vice president, secretary and a member of the board of trustees of the Manhattan Savings Bank, 385 Madison Avenue, died Monday at the Albany Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived at 4 Ruskin Road, Fair Lawn, N.J., and Shelter Island, N.Y.
United Air Lines will resume showing movies on its transcontinental flights today.
R. Stanley Laing, president of the National Cash Register Company, was elected yesterday to the board of the Mead Corporation, a Dayton, Ohio, producer of white paper and paperboard.

The impressive new $6-million Whitney Museum of American Art, an inverted and modified ziggurat that will send a lot of people to their dictionaries for a definition, had the biggest, most festive and last of its pre-opening previews in the rain last night, and thousands besides the Whitneys and Mrs. John F. Kennedy, were there unaware of a bomb scare.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 27 (UPI) Bill Rigney agreed tonight to accept a new oneyear contract to manage the California Angels again next season.
Litton Industries, Inc., the West Coast electronics glant, is expanding into the electricmotors and drive-systems business through the proposed acquisition of the Louis Allis Company.
Hornblower Weeks-Hemphill, Noyes, members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the election of James F. Clardy as a partner.

PARIS, Sept. 27 Denmark's Premier, Jens Otto Krag, announced today that his country would seek to persuade Norway and Sweden to join in a Scandinavian bid for membership in the European Common Market.
Hyman Goldman, treasurer of one of the largest painting companies in the country, was indicted yesterday on charges of perjury and contempt in a multimillion-dollar paint scandal.
ERZURUM, Turkey, Sept, 22 The accent of America's Midwest is not a sound that one expects to hear in the remoteness of East Turkey. It is here, nevertheless, at Ataturk University.
ATLANTA, Sept. 27 (AP) Willie Mays drove in four runs with his 36th homer and a single tonight, leading the San Francisco Giants to a 6-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves.
A warning that the water emergency continues in the city was issued yesterday as James L. Marcus was sworn into office as Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
R.H. Macy Co. raised its sales and earnings to the highest levels in its 108-year history in the final quarter and in the fiscal year ended July 30, according to its annual statement yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27 Like Old Man River, the Los Angeles Dodgers kept rolling along tonight.

The Police Department's newly strengthened Civilian Complaint Review Board aids law enforcement by improving the climate of public confidence in which policemen work. Unfortunately, the opponents of the board have embarked on a campaign of misrepresentation that, despite some comic elements, is already undermining that confidence and exploiting fear.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 "I get this identification with John Foster Dulles and brinkmanship; it is wholly unjust," Robert Richardaon Bowie said not long ago.
ALBANY, Sept. 27--Pressure groups seeking to influence legislation at the 1966 session of the Legislature have reported spending more than $100,000 a month.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 Leonard T. Beale, former president and board chairman of the Pennsylvania Salt Manufacturing Company, died yesterday in Chestnut Hill Hospital. He was 85 years old.

Representative Leonard Farbstein won an undisputed victory over City Councilman Theodore S. Weiss last night in their runoff primary for the Democratic Congressional nomination in Manhattan's 19th District.

The New York Civil Liberties Union accused the police and the Queens District Attorney yesterday of "many violations" of the rights of 13 alleged Mafia leaders who were seized last week and reld in bail of $100,000 each.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 27 James M. Quigley, the Federal Water Pollution Control Commissioner, would like to pass out more than $1-million a week between now and Dec. 31.
Winter heating requirements for apartment houses in the city, which go into effect on Saturday, have been tightened this year.
Two industrialists and two lawyers were elected yesterday as directors of VTR, Inc., a tire and soft-drink franchise concern.

Mrs. Maude Fowler Cornwell, who taught at Public School 33, Ninth Avenue and West 28th Street, for nearly 50 years until her retirement 13 years ago, died on Monday in her home at 455 West 34th Street. Her age was 83. She was the widow of Robert H. Cornwell, an executive in the millinery industry.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 House Republicans hammered at the $1.75-billion antipoverty bill for two hours today.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 27 (AP) Harmon Killebrew hit his 37th home run and Jim Perry pitched a three-hitter as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Cleveland Indians today, 5-1.
Jack Tinker Partners is picking up where it left off last fall on the Gillette Techmatic razor. The agency was assigned the account as part of a major shift by Gillette of its product assignments.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP)--A two-run sixth inning gave the Boston Red Sox a 2-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight after Chicago had taken the opener of a double-header, 1-0. By a quirk of scheduling, the twin bill ended the season for the Red Sox.
PARIS, Sept. 27 Accounts of bribes, torture and assassination attempts by the Moroccan secret police were given at the Ben Barka trial today.
The debate about television debates in the campaign for Governor reached a tentative resolution yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton, pastor of the Broadway Temple, died of a heart attack Monday night, while on a church call to Pleasantville, N.J. He would have been 65 years old Saturday. His home was at 636 West 174th Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 The rain and gloom that forced postponement of tonight's game with the Philadelphia Phillies formed an appropriate atmosphere for the slow death of the pennant hopes of the Pittsburgh Pirates.
ROME, Sept. 27 Pope Paul VI sent a close friend and associate to South Vietnam today on a church errand that may also be a Vatican mission to explore the prospects for peace.

The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company sold yesterday $100-million of debentures priced to give investors a yield of 5.95 per cent. This was the same yield placed on the preceding telephone company financing made three weeks ago.
American Airlines, Inc., announced here yesterday the election of Donald J. LloydJones, 35, as vice president for corporate planning.
Seven was apparently a lucky number for most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

The summit meeting in Manila next month of the United States and her six Asian and Pacific allies in the Vietnam war is a perfectly acceptable idea but extremely badly timed. Despite the welcome stress on discussions of ways to achieve peace and on political and economic subjects, such a meeting now will almost inevitably take on, in the eyes of the world, the coloration of a war council.

Dr. Victor Kuhn La Mer, emeritus professor of chemistry at Columbia University and an international authority on colloid chemistry, died Monday in Nottingham, England. He was 71 years old and lived at 353 Moore Avenue, Leonia, N.J.
"Finian's Rainbow," the noted E. Y. Harburg-Burton Lane-Fred Saidy musical fantasy about an Irish-American chase for a pot of gold, appears to be reaching that shining goal.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 Forty-nine countries joined today in a demand that the General Assembly take over the administration of Southwest Africa.

MIAMI, Sept. 27 (AP) Hurricane Inez swept across the tropic islands of Guadeloupe today and roared into the Caribbean, where she began threatening the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico with her furious, 120 mile-an-hour winds.
MINNIE CUSHING of the Newport Cushings set the pace for the day's fashion events at 10:30 A.M. yesterday when she stepped into the Jane Derby showroom in a white linen pants suit.
A subcommittee of the Manhattan Democratic organization said yesterday that judicial conventions should be abolished and replaced by an open primary to nominate candidates for state court judges.

The auxiliary of the New York Infirmary will benefit from the Champagne Ball at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof on Friday. Mrs. Robert F. Wagner and Mrs. Eric B. Outwater are honorary chairmen for the event. Proceeds will be used for the hospital's nursery.

YONKERS, Sept. 27 Billy Hudson of Whitestone, Queens, and Jim McCasland of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., both of whom have been driving standardbreds for 20 or more years, accounted for tonight's winners in the New York Sire Stakes competition at rain-soaked Yonkers Raceway.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Sept. 27 Gene Borek of Pine Hollow shot a 36, 33-69 today to win the fifth Port Jefferson open golf tournament with a two-round total of 140.

"THE BIBLE," the dramatization of the Book of Genesis from the Creation through the story of Abraham, produced by Dino De Laurentiis, directed by John Huston and presented by 20th Century-Fox, has its world premiere at 8 P.M. at Loew's State Theater, Broadway and 45th Street.
The Xerox Corporation has leased 55,000 square feet of office space for its education division in 600 Madison Avenue, a 12-story building at the southwest corner of 58th Street.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (Reuters) Young Red Guards from Peking stormed and sacked Communist party offices in the Chinese port of Foochow, the Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda reported today.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 27 The British Government has warned Clifford W. Dupont, Rhodesia's chief administrative official, that he will be charged as an accessory to murder if any pending death sentences are carried out.
Mr. and Mrs. Burton Lane have announced the engagement of Mrs. Lane's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Daroff Kaye, to Matthew Chait, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Chait.
HONG KONG, Sept. 27 China will celebrate 17 years of Communist rule on Saturday with no sign of an end to the political upheaval in progress during the last year.

The $5-million from the television network sale of "Cleopatra," revealed yesterday, immediately guarantees the picture a profit of almost $2.5-million. The 20th Century-Fox film cost $31,115,000 and is the most expensive motion picture ever made.

The rain disrupted a garden party at Gracie Mansion yesterday. So the 400 guests scurried indoors for an advance look at the splendidly furnished $800,000 wing to the official home of New York's Mayors.
Mrs. Anne Bush Mackenzie of 1172 Park Avenue, widow of Charles S. Mackenzie, a lawyer, died Monday in New York Hospital at the age of 82.

"The Tammy Grimes Show" yesterday became the first casualty of the new television season. The American Broadcasting Company confirmed earlier reports that it was planning to cancel the situation comedy series by announcing that the show on Thursday will be the last. Starting Oct. 6 the network will substitute a color version of the popular daytime series, "The Dating Game," in the 8:30 P.M. time slot on Thursdays.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 28 Two United States Marine Corps planes bombed a friendly village in South Vietnam by mistake yesterday, killing 28 mountain tribesmen and wounding 17, a Marine spokesman said today.
MOUNT VERNON. N. Y., Sept. 27--The Board of Education, after a stormy meeting, voted 5 to 4 last night to accept the resignation of Dr. John H. Martin, the Superintendent of Schools.
The Meadow Brook National Bank announced yesterday in West Hempstead, L.I., the election of Joseph P. Repecka as vice president in charge of research and development.

Frank Wille, New York State Superintendent of Banks, pressed his drive yesterday to eliminate competitive advantages enjoyed by national or Federally chartered banks and savings and loan associations over statechartered financial institutions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The United States Information Agency has reversed its policy of keeping secret the titles of books and manuscripts it subsidizes. Editorial supervision of authors has also been relaxed.
New York's entry in the new North American Soccer League will be owned and operated by the Madison Square Garden Corporation, Garden officials announced yesterday.

Investors eagerly purchased four issues of common stock offered for sale yesterday and by the close of trading not a share was left at the offering price. There have been very few recent sales of secondary offerings or new issues.

MUTTONTOWN, L. I., Sept. 27--Mrs. Vincent Larkin of Nassau defeated Mrs. Karl Clement, also of Nassau, 8 and 6, today in the 36-hole final of the 11th Women's Cross County Golf Association match play championship at the Muttontown Golf and Country Club.

GENEVA, Sept. 27 The executive officer of California's Motor Vehicle Pollution Control Board said today that European automobile manufacturers should not expect any exemption from requirements tha cars be equipped with antismog devices.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 27U Thant, Secretary General of the United Nations, has been awarded the Jawaharlal Nehru Award for International Understanding for 1965, it was announced today.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 27 The natural gas industry was told here today that the honeymoon was over as far as guaranteed growth was concerned.

The General Tire and Rubber Company achieved a 23 per cent increase in earnings in the nine months ended Aug. 31 on a sales gain of 6 per cent. In reporting the results yesterday for the three and nine months' periods, T.F. O'Neil, chairman, and M.G. O'Neil, president, said that the figures surpassed all earlier records.
RICHMOND, Sept. 27 Indications that Harry F. Byrd Jr. would handily win election to the remaining four years of his father's Senate term have taken a sudden and, to many Virginians, a shocking turn.
State legislators, shocked and made ill by what they saw on an early-morning tour of Bellevue Hospital, yesterday vowed to seek legislation to correct conditions in the city's hospitals.

City College announced yesterday that Prof. Abraham Schwartz had been appointed director of its School of General Studies, and that Prof. Robert L. Taylor, registrar for 25 years, would be assistant to the president.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 27 American fighterbombers continued to pound North Vietnamese supply lines yesterday, a United States military spokesman said here tonight.
The Lindsay Administration started a quiet diplomatic effort yesterday to head off an Arab boycott of the Mayor's supper dance for the United Nations missions on Monday.
