The State Education Commissioner has invited officials of the Board of Education and at least two citywide organizations to a special meeting tomorrow to discuss the controversy over Intermediate School 201.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 27 The engagement of Miss Ilenel Rubin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving I. Rubin, to Dr. Irving Fish of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Fish of Montreal, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz of New York State urged the Supreme Court today to reject Delaware's challenge to the constitutionality of the present system of electing Presidents.

Two television networks are investing a total of $92.3-million to acquire more feature-length motion pictures for showing at prime evening hours. The transactions are among the largest in the history of show business.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Following is the text of an interview with President Johnson appearing in the current issue of the Russian-language magazine Amerika, which is published by the United States Information Agency and distributed in the Soviet Union by an official Soviet agency, Soyuzpechat.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 27 (AP) Private oil companies will be invited again to develop petroleum deposits in Argentina, the Government said today.

Shortly before 9 o'clock last night one of Councilman Theodore S. Weiss's workers telephoned the Reform Independent Democrats' club to report that a number of Weiss sympathizers had not voted in the 69th Election District.
Nearly everyone who buys stocks has a few favorites that he likes through the years bear markets to the contrary notwithstanding.
A $30-million contract for the construction of a fertilizer plant in Saudi Arabia was awarded yesterday to the Chemical Construction Company of New York.
The stock market held onto a narrow gain yesterday after selling pressure in the afternoon trimmed advances scored in a brisk morning rally.

Cardinal Spellman yesterday blessed the facilities for the Archdiocese of New York's new closed-circuit instructional television network. The transmitter atop the Empire State building will beam programs to its New York City parochial schools starting Oct. 3.
Safeway Stores, Inc., reported yesterday record sales and profits for the 36 weeks ended Sept. 10 as well as a sharp rise in results for the 12 weeks ended on that date.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 A United Nations treaty prohibiting all forms of racial discrimination was signed today by the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Senator Jacob K. Javits implied today that Senator Robert F. Kennedy was "coaching from the sidelines" and evading his responsibilities on next year's New York Constitutional Convention.

A test case involving the Securities and Exchange Commission and a group of stockholders may wind up in Federal court. The group, organized last spring as the AT Committee of 100,000, said yesterday it was preparing an ad for submission to the S.E.C.

LONDON, Sept. 28 Lord Thomson of Fleet, who started an afternoon "computer newspaper" at Reading a year ago, announced plans today to set up two more afternoon papers of the same kind on the outskirts of London.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 28 A psychiatrist formerly on the staff of Yale-New Haven Hospital has been charged with possession of an estimated $35,000 worth of equipment stolen from the hospital and the Yale University Medical School.

The election of two new directors of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., was announced yesterday. They are William F. Remmert, president of Remmert-Werner, Inc., and Gen. Bernard A. Schriever, retired, former commander of the Air Force Systems Command.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Money, or the lack of it, did this week what logic and diplomacy have not been able to do for many years in relations between the United States and West Germany. As American officials and foreign observers reviewed the tough two-day bargaining here between President Johnson...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Representative Carlton R. Sickles of Maryland conceded today his narrow defeat in a bitter primary fight for the nomination for Governor. He said the fight had been turned decisively against him by "an emotional appeal" to white backlash opposition to open housing legislation.
Edward Albee's new play, "A Delicate Balance," which opened Sept. 22 at the Martin Beck after a dozen previews, will distribute the first payment of $33,333 to 48 backers today.

THERE are, by careful count, five killings in "The Psychopath," which, for obvious reasons, stealthily crept into local theaters yesterday. For reasons as transparent as bad dialogue and worse acting, "The Psychopath," written by Robert Bloch, who set a fairly high mark in shockers with "Psycho," generates 10 yawns to one mildly macabre effect.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 28 (UPI) Al Kaline hit a two-run homer, his second of the game, in the 10th inning tonight to give the Detroit Tigers a 5-4 victory over the California Angels.

Four men, two with pistols and one with handcuffs, were arrested yesterday by a dozen detectives as they allegedly attempted to hold up the paymaster of the Beverly Hotel, at Lexington Avenue and 50th Street.
City College will put up emergency pre-fabricated classrooms and offices on "every available spot" of the college's South Campus, Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, the college president, said yesterday.
Arnold R. Deutsch is obviously a persistent advertising man, apparently convinced he has a mission to perform in upgrading the advertising business.

DELHI, N.Y., Sept. 28 Governor Rockefeller outlined a new program today to train local government employes. He did so as he found himself warmly greeted at upstate colleges and in Republican rallies in his re-election campaign.
President Johnson and Chancellor Erhard achieved no miracles in two days of talks in Washington, but they may have cleared the way for progress in two important areas.
The prospect of new peace efforts in Vietnam and a stiff fight to cut the United States international payments deficit caused bond prices to rise yesterday.
In the final meeting of the season and by the narrowest possible margin, the New York Mets clinched the season series with the Chicago Cubs, 10 victories to eight, in Shea Stadium yesterday.
A new award honoring the outstanding tennis player of the year and ranking the amateurs of the world was announced yesterday.
The spot rate for the British pound improved moderately yesterday in active trading on foreign exchange markets here.
Clifton W. Phalen announced yesterday plans to retire Nov. 1 as chairman of the New York Telephone Company. He is 60 years old and has been with the Bell System since 1928.
Two officers of the defunct Merkel Meat Company of Jamaica, Queens, pleaded guilty yesterday in Supreme Court in the scandal involving adulterated meat.

Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler promised yesterday to expedite a sweeping revision of the city's Building. Code on the basis of a 1,400-page draft that has taken four years to prepare at a cost of $1-million.
Samuel S. Backlar, a Special Assistant Attorney General, will retire Saturday after having served 35 years in the state law office.
BERLIN, Sept. 28 Officials from East and West Berlin reopened talks today on wallcrossing permits for West Berliners.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The proposal of New York State and Connecticut to take over the commuter service of the New Haven Railroad between New York City and New Haven was praised here today by Senator Jacob K. Javits and Representative Ogden Reid.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 27 Lieut. Gov. Patrick J. Lucey is a candidate in search of a winning issue.

TOKYO, Sept. 28 President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines arrived here today for a six-day state visit. Special significahce has been given his visit by the seven-nation conference on Vietnam to be held in Manila next month.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The fledgling National Teacher Corps, grounded before it had a chance to fly, was given a, new set of wings today when the Senate voted to give it $7.5-million.

ATLANTA, Sept. 28 (AP) Lillian Smith, the novelist and essayist, and an early spokesman for civil rights in the South, died today in a hospital. Her age was 68, She had been ill with cancer for many years.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 28 Comdr. Girard Lindsley McEntee 3d, U.S.N. retired, and Mrs. McEntee have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jill South McEntee, to Capt. Donald Catino, Medical Corps, U.S.A. of Fort Benning, Ga. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Catino Jr. of Bloomfield, N.J.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 28 (AP) Hurricane Inez, a storm with top winds exceeding 150 miles an hour, buffeted the eastern tip of the Dominican Republic tonight and headed for the seaport town of Barahona.
ATLANTA, Sept. 28 Lester G. Maddox, who once brandished a pistol and sold ax handles to defend segregation, won the Democratic nomination for Governor of Georgia today.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 28 Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Meadow Brook won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 15th annual senior championship today.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 29 Former members of the Ngo Dinh Diem administration and succeeding pro-Western regimes in Saigon would be welcomed into a "democratic national coalition government" for South Vietnam, the leader of the country's pro-Communist movement said in an interview broadcast by the Hanoi radio yesterday.

The Pulaski parade committee voted last night to bar Senator Robert F. Kennedy and all statewide candidates and officeholders including Governor Rockefeller from marching in its parade up Fifth Avenue Sunday.
Arnold Palmer has been ordered to reduce his activities. The 37-year-old golfing millionaire from Latrobe, Pa., disclosed yesterday the results of a physical check-up at a Pittsburgh clinic.

ATLANTA, Sept. 28 (UPI) Tito Fuentes hit a two-run homer in the fifth inning tonight to lead the San Francisco Giants to a 5-2 victory, over the Atlanta Braves and give Gaylord Perry his 21st victory of the season.
Irish County responded perfectly to the guidance of her rider, Braulio Baeza, in the $29,800 Astarita Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

YONKERS, Sept. 28 Competition in the New York Sire Stakes, a rich series restricted to standardbreds aged 2 to 4 years old whose sires stood at stud in this state, continued at Yonkers Raceway tonight. On the agenda were two divisions of a one-mile trot for 3-yearolds.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 28 Samuel Gordon, founder and president of the Samuel Gordon Agency, Inc., 786 Broad Street, representatives of the Columbian Mutual Life Insurance Company in New Jersey, died today in the United Hospitals of Newark Presbyterian Unit. He was 61 years old and lived at 200 Mount Pleasant Avenue here.

The coordinator of the Bronx Independent Citizens Committee against a Civilian Complaint Review Board clashed yesterday with Negro and Puerto Rican community organizers over his contention that the police review board was especially harmful to minorities.
The J.C. Penney Co. is planning to go into the insurance business through a proposed acquisition of two companies for about $6.6-million cash.
A realignment of senior management was announced yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the nation's largest insurer.
George C. Wheeler, a retired civil engineer and surveyor here, died Tuesday in Tranquil House Convalescent Hospital, a nursing home in Warren, Conn. He was 94 years old.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 28. Charges of influence peddling and political meddling in this city's 520-man police force were answered today with an indignant denial by the Mayor and a bored "so what?" from several party leaders.

DALLAS, Sept. 28--The Protestant unity movement is "some place between Easter and Pentecost," an Ohio lawyer told the closing session today of the International Convention of Christian Churches (Disciples of Christ).
YONKERS, Sept. 28 Mrs. George Barthold has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Allyson Jane Barthold, to Nicholas W. O'Connor. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul O'Connor of Wyalusing, Pa.

EL PASO, Tex., Sept. 28 (UPI) A Louisiana relief train for the Tarahumara Indians of Mexico, held up at the border by red tape since Saturday, was delayed again today, this time until at least early next week.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 28 (UPI) Defense attorneys failed today to have a $110,000 slander suit dismissed against a Central Intelligence Agency agent who is charged by a former Estonian freedom fighter with calling him an agent of the Soviet secret police.
Huntington Hartford has offered his $7.4-million Gallery of Modern Art on Columbus Circle to Fordham University for possible use as its Communication Arts Center.
GENEVA, Sept. 28 The chief United States negotiator in the Kennedy round obliquely prodded the European Economic Community today on several aspects of its role in the tariff cutting negotiations.
From Mississippi now comes fresh proof of the compelling need for enactment of the civil rights bill which the Senate has shelved.
CLASSIC symbolism is a cover plan for Iris Murdoch's excellent melodramas. In her newest and best, "The Time of the Angels," she takes us once more through a fevered world of the absurd.

The annual Fan Ball on Oct. 21 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom will benefit the Children's Cancer Fund of America and honor Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower. The wife of the former President, whose 70th birthday is on Nov. 14, has been the ball's honorary chairman for 15 years.
NAPLES, Sept. 28 When the ship was well out from Gibraltar, the Americans were assembled for a briefing on Italy delivered by a man from Genoa. "Beware of the taxis of Naples," he said.
State officials have decided against requiring air pollution control devices on used cars in New York.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 On Dec. 12 the Department of Health, Education and Welfare will convoke a national conference on air pollution. There have been similar meetings before, but this one will be something of a milestone.

The first application of a new all-risk guaranty by the Agency for International Development was announced yesterday by the Bank of America on a $5,445,000 loan to a kraft paper company in Thailand. The loan was closed yesterday at the bank's international headquarters here.
A new top man at the Horn Hardart Company, operator of the Automat chain, was named yesterday.

Prof. Mary Thornton Harvey , who retired in 1963 after teaching for 37 years in the Hunter College speech department, died Tuesday of a heart attack at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. Her age was 71.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana, the majority leader, joined Southerners today in declaring that the Department of Health, Education and... Welfare was going "too fast" in desegregating schools and hospitals.
WASECA, Minn. "Eating raw oysters in Hong Kong," George Herter said recently, "is something like playing Russian roulette."

There was an earthy eloquence worthy of Nikita Khrushchev at his best in President Johnson's latest appeal for Soviet-American friendship and cooperation. He spoke of the weeds and the rocks he knew in the Texas of his youth; but the terrain of SovietAmerican relations today is even weedier and rockier.

A series of three concerts devoted to the violin sonatas of Beethoven was opened in Carnegie Hall last night. The pianist was Rudolf Serkin, who needs no introduction; the violinist was Pina Carmirelli, who does. But it should be said right away that she is every bit as distinguished an artist as her colleague, and the duo's playing was one of the early delights of a season that promises a great many.

Future operations of the Cunard Line will stress new approaches to the steamship business by a completely new management and a youthful management at that according to Sir Basil Smallpiece, who became chairman and chief executive officer less than a year ago.
Scientists at the Albany Medical Center have achieved 100 per cent accuracy in predicting the sex of babies within three months before birth.

The Bowl-Mor Company, Inc., has filed a petition for reorganization under Chapter X of the Bankruptcy Act, it was disclosed yesterday. The company, which leases and repairs automatic pin-spotting machines, said it could not meet its debts as they mature.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The Senate Appropriations Committee rejected a last-minute appeal today from Secretary of State Dean Rusk that it rescind House cuts in the foreign aid money bill. It then voted to cut the bill $500,000 more.

IN his American Football League career, Gino Cappelletti of the Boston Patriots has caught more than 200 passes. If he catches only one against the New York Jets at Boston Sunday, he will hurt his average. He will hurt Johnny Sample's average, too.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) Vice President and Mrs. Humphrey have sold their suburban home and bought an apartment within a five-minute drive of the Capitol.
President Johnson yesterday approved a new South Pacific route for the British Overseas Airways Corporation, which will have stops in New York, San Francisco, Honolulu, American Samoa and Fiji.

PARIS, Sept. 28 The United States invited its North Atlantic allies today to use its military communications satellite system and to collaborate in the joint development of a new system specifically for the alliance.
The money market has two principal preoccupations: Providing investment outlets for vast sums of temporarily surplus cash.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)--The House Republican Policy Committee called today for scrapping major portions of President Johnson's $1.2-billion housing bill, including a section the committee said could lead to busing of children away from their neighborhood schools.

ROCK SPRINGS, Wyo., Sept. 28 It was over a bowl of chili powerful and hot enough to fuel a Titan rocket that I heard the cafe's dispenser of beverages say to a local customer, "I had no trouble getting my limit by 7 o'clock in the morning."
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 28 Miss Anne Marie Blaesser and Angelo Maria Codevilla will marry on Dec. 30.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The White House announced today that Gen. Hunter Harris, 56 years old, commander in chief of Pacific air forces, would retire Jan. 31.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) House and Senate conferees have agreed on a compromise two-year, $20-million "sea grant colleges" bill to advance the study of marine research.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 Indonesia resumed her membership in the United Nations today without any objections from the 118 other members.
DETROIT, Sept. 28 (AP) The American Motors Corporation kept pace with the automobile industry's big three today by announcing that its 1967 model cars would be covered by extended warranties.

BREWSTER, Mass., Sept. 28 Mrs. William Edward Athearn has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Rosemary Athearn, to Donald Cheney Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Alfred Smith of Lebanon, N.H.
BUFFALO, Sept. 28 (AP) Former Corporation Counsel Ralph Saft was found not guilty tonight of two charges of soliciting a $1,500 bribe.
Edward A. Condon, former Assistant Chief Inspector of Police, died Tuesday at the home of a sister, Mrs. Margaret Gilgan, at 162 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn. His age was 73.

MODEL OF NEW JET SEATTLE, Sept. 28 The Boeing Company said today it expected $2-billion in orders for its giant new 400-passenger 747 airliner by January and predicted a market of $14-billion by 1980.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) President Johnson set up a special committee and a national advisory commission today to attack the problems of rural poverty.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 28--Yugoslav newspaper criticism of the material privileges of party and state officials has provoked a reaction from some of them.
The sharply divided executive council of New York State's merged labor federation decided last night to maintain a neutral position in the gubernatorial campaign.

BONN, Sept. 28 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard said on his arrival at the Cologne-Bonn Airport today from Washington that his negotiations with President Johnson had revealed "hard differences of opinion" but that he was confident "solutions" would be found.

PARIS, Sept. 28 Andre Breton, who as the father of surrealism exercised a worldwide influence on the art and literature of this century, died of a heart ailment here this morning. The poet and critic was 70 years old.
An automatic $100,000 flight protection plan has been started by the American. Express Credit Card Division for its 1,800,000 members, the American Express Company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Officials here are studying with interest, but with some divergence of interpretation, the Hanoi broadcast outlining the National Liberation Front's conditions for a political settlement of the war.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 28 (UPI) The siesta moves one step closer to extinction in Chile Saturday.

LONDON, Sept. 28 Italy was reliably reported tonight to have proposed that British or Italian warships silence three British pirate radio transmitters said to be interfering with an Italian radio and television station.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) President Leopold S. Senghor of Senegal arrived in Washington today and praised President Johnson for his efforts to build the Great Society.
Teamsters conducting an organizing drive on the waterfront have assured the Waterfront Commission that they will not interfere with loading or unloading operations on the piers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The United States Information Agency often provides financial support for overseas editions of books published commercially months or years earlier in the United States.

THE most striking thing about "Ride Beyond Ven geance" its scalding savagery almost does it in. Here is a strangely compelling Western well written, directed and performed that sits apart and pretty much above most medium-budget entries. The Columbia presentation opened, yesterday in neighborhood theaters.
Stock prices tumbled yesterday in moderately active trading. Losses were the sharpest in investment grade and glamour issues where declines ranged to 5 points or more.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Sept. 28 A man whose home is taken for a state project often loses more than $10,000 on the deal, the Joint Legislative Committee on Condemnation and Land Acquisition was told today.

Robert Hamilton returned to Town Hall last night for his first piano recital since his debut, which was not reviewed because of the newspaper strike of 1963. Since then, the 29-yearold Stamford, Conn., pianist has racked up several prizes in con tests here and abroad, the most recent being the First International Busoni Piano Competition in Montevideo, Uruguay, last March. His is a highly promising talent.
Three men were arrested early yesterday and accused of taking $39,500 worth of watches from a truck parked at 135th Street and Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Chinese Communist military chieftains under Defense Ministers Lin Piao appear to be consolidating their ascendancy over "hard-core" civilian party rivals led by China's chief of state, Liu Shao-chi, in the view of specialists on China.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The leaders of 11 labor unions representing 150,000 workers unanimously rejected today contract offers from the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

PARIS, Sept, 25 Five journalists, a Gaullist Deputy and a lemon merchant stood facing one another in the Ben Barka trial today. Taking turns at the witness rail in a sort of grim ballet, the newsmen said the Deputy and the merchant lied, and the Deputy and the merchant hurled the lie back.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The British Chancellor of the Exchequer, James Callaghan, said today that his Government was now ready to bring about and maintain a higher level of unemployment to help defend the value of the pound.
The New York and the American Stock Exchange reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.

OFFICIALLY, the New York Philharmonic starts its season tonight, but it jumped the gun with a Pension Fund concert last night in Philharmonic Hall. Leonard Bernstein chose a Russian program: Rimsky-Korsakov's "Capriccio Espagnol," Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" Overture, and scenes from Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov," with Nicolai Ghiaurov as soloist.
LAUREL, Md., Sept. 28 (UPI) David Jack, a British horse was added to the field today for the $150,000 Washington, D.C. International at Laurel Race Course Nov. 11.

A $12-million sale of 18 turbine powered aircraft to Presidential Jet Airways was announced yesterday by Donnell Rhody, general manager of Aero Commander-Bethany, a division of Rockwell Standard Corporation.
The cost of a conventional, uninsured home mortgage rose during August for the ninth month in row to an average of 6.18 per Cent, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said yesterday.

Thomas P.F. Hoving, Parks Commissioner and cultural director of New York City, will be the host of "World of the Arts," a new weekly series that begins at 2:30 P.M. today on Channel 31. His first guest will be Henry Geldzahler, associate curator of American art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
BOSTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The Boston Red Sox placed added stress on an all-out youth movement today by naming 37-year-old Dick Williams manager.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The United States, encouraged by political and economic developments in Indonesia, is preparing to resume long-term economic aid to that country next year.

TOKYO, Sept. 28 Four defectors from North Korea, who have admitted that they killed seven shipmates aboard a fishing craft in order to make their escape to Japan, were deported to South Korea today. The nine other surviving members of the vessel's crew will be sent back to North Korea, the Government said.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 28 Britain's Commonwealth Secretary, Herbert Bowden, indicated today before leaving for London that he had made no progress toward a settlement with the Rhodesian Government. He voiced permission about the prospects for a settlement.

THE high point of Sal Matera's precocious career came in the third round of the recent United States Open Championship in Seattle. The 16-year-old star, best highschool player in New York City, had the black pieces against the veteran grand master Robert Byrne of Indianapolis.
What God hath wrought, Bergdorf Goodman stands ready to update in the new cosmetics department on its main floor.
A dinner dance aiding the Westchester League for Cardiac Children will be held on Saturday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Gasoline stocks supplies in the United States at the close of the week ended last Friday totaled 179,245,000 barrels, against 177,070,000 a week earlier and 181,531,000 a year earlier, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

MAJOR Eastern college football teams find it in creasingly difficult to compete on an equal basis against intersectionai rivals who practice red-shirting. This situation will probably continue because schedules have been made well in advance by athletic directors who don't seem...
Pan American World Airways said yesterday that a new speed record by a business jet that it sells has qualified for a $25,000 prize offered by a competitor.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28 Argentine nationalists hijacked an airliner at dawn today and forced the pilot to fly 43 passengers and 6 crew members to the desolate Falkland Islands, some 300 miles east of Tierra del Fuego.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Republicans proposed a major rewrite of the Administration's antipoverty program in the House today and suffered a decisive defeat. The Vote was 143 to 115.
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 28 (UPI) Two mild upsets were registered today in the third round of the Pacific Coast international tennis tournament.

The Studebaker Corporation elected a former member of a dissident stockholders' group to its board yesterday in an attempt to end a proxy fight. The dissidents began the fight last spring to try to obtain control of the company and a change in management.
Arthur Krock's last regular column appears on this page today. His first, an exposition on the economic theory of the New Deal, appeared over 33 years ago, on May 4, 1933.

OYSTER BAY, L.I, Sept. 28 The Friends of Raynham Hall, which with the Town of Oyster Bay supports the prerevolutionary homestead Raynham Hall, will begin its annual benefit lecture series Monday in the parish hall of Christ Episcopal Church.
A new center for study of the performing arts will be built at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 28 Connecticut and New York State sent their $80-million salvation plan for the New Haven Railroad to Washington today as commuters voiced cautious optimism about it.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 United States exports held steady and imports declined a little in August, the Commerce Department has reported.

WESTBURY, L.I, Sept. 28 Milton Goldstein, a spokesman for the multifarious owners of Romeo Hanover, disclosed today that a challenge has been issued for a match race between Romeo Hanover and Bret Hanover, regarded by many as the world's outstanding pacers.

BONN, Sept. 28 Rudolf Hess's lawyer said today that Hess, who is serving a life sentence for his actions as Hitler's deputy, is "sure" he will be released from prison at midnight Friday. Two other former Nazi leaders, Baldur von Schirach and Albert Speer, are to be freed then, having completed 20-year terms.
A mechanical failure in one of its huge movable stages forced the Metropolitan Opera to use the scenery for Act I of "La Traviata" for Act III last night.
Indonesia came back to the United Nations yesterday. She should never have left eighteen months ago. It was a special piece of folly by President Sukarno which is now best forgotten.

ASHEBORO, N.C., Sept. 28 Richard M. Nixon, stumping through a gentle rain and fog in the Carolinas, urged today that the Johnson Administration make major changes in its diplomatic effort to end the Vietnam war.

TRENTON, Sept. 28 (AP) United States Senator Clifford P. Case and Warren W. Wilentz, his Democratic challenger in the Nov. 8 election, lent support today to a bipartisan plan to reapportion the State Legislature.
The first time around, the Silverman Klein contest for Manhattan Surrogate was a full-screen spectacular. This time it is like a late-at-night television rerun.

Society turned out in force last night for the gala nonsubscription concert that opened the New York Philharmonic's 125th season. The evening, sponsored by the Philharmonic's auxiliary board as a benefit for the orchestra's pension fund, began with cocktails and dinner for about 400 persons.

A 70-year-old woman sitting by the window in the bedroom of her second-floor apartment in the Bronx was killed yesterday by a stray bullet, apparently fired by a grocer as he chased two gunmen he said had stolen $155 from him. One of the suspects also was killed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The United States is expected to get orders for $20-million to $30-million worth of machinery for the production of automobiles in the Soviet Union under the auto production expansion being carried out by Fiat of Italy.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 28 (UPI) Ron Davis drove in Billy Heath with a double in the ninth inning to give the Houston Astros a 4-3 victory over Cincinnati tonight in the second game of a double-header. The Reds won the opener, 7-1, on Jim Maloney's eight-hitter.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Sept. 28 Mrs. Walter Pease of Plainfield, the defending champion, won the Nielsen Memorial Trophy again today with a two-round total of 151 at Fred Waring's Shawnee Country Club.

IN THE BANKING world, the winds of change are usually mild breezes. So the latest word from the Meadow Brook National Bank should take the residents of Long Island by storm to say nothing of Meadow Brook's competition.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 28 Mrs. Bettie Okin Simberkoff was married today to Donald Merritt Altman, who is assistant attorney general of New Jersey in charge of legislative affairs and counsel to the state treasurer.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 28 Most men and women want to believe in something worthy of religious faith, but they either cannot or will not find it in Christianity.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28--The police bullet that killed a 16-year-old Negro yesterday on a rubble-strewn San Francisco hillside may also have inflicted a political wound on Gov. Edmund G. Brown.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 28 In June Mrs. Victor W. Far ris hung a $7.95 dress in the window of her husband's marine supply store in a lighthouse here, hoping to attract "the distaff mates." A few weeks later she had sold three dozen of them.
The trial of Representative Adam Clayton Powell on charges of criminal contempt of court was adjourned indefinitely yesterday because of a clogged trial calendar in State Supreme Court.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy will campaign alongside Frank D. O'Connor this weekend, four weeks before the Senator had originally planned to join the Council President's race.

For the first time since Intermediate School 201 opened last week, there were no demonstrators outside the East Harlem school yesterday morning.

ASPEN, Colo., Sept. 28--It was hard to believe. For more than three hours Tuesday representatives of museums from all over the United States and Canada discussed their current problems and peered prayerfully and hopefully into the future, and not once did anyone mention the living artist.
Six associates of the Newark architectural and engineering, firm of Frank Grad Sons have been made partners in the company, which has been family-owned since it was founded in 1907.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Because of a casual comment he made at a cocktail party to a columnist, Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach is going to have to cool his heels a few days before he can move over to the State Department as Under Secretary of State.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it had stopped service from Cuba to the United States because of a $2-million balance-of-pay ments problem.

The Douglas Aircraft Company reported yesterday a net loss of $17,061,000 for the third quarter ended Aug. 31. This contrasted with a profit of $4,009,000, or 76 cents a share, reported for the corresponding quarter last year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) The Defense Department reported today that the armed forces totaled 3,184,043 men in August, an increase of 47,738 over July.

MADRID Sept. 28 The Government has postponed until late this year the presentation of its constitutional plan designed to deal with Spain's political life after Generalissimo Francisco Franco leaves power.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 28 The Conservative party gubernatorial candidate, Paul L. Adams, today called Governor Rockefeller's recommendation to study the methods of selecting the members of the New York City Board of Education "a typical example of political temporization."

OTTAWA, Sept. 28 Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson urged members of Commonwealth parliaments today to consider the problem of Rhodesia in the perspective of the challenge of racial equality over the world.

PLAYERS in the metropolitan area who are hunting the red points needed for life master status will be assisted in their quest by a recent decision of the American Contract Bridge League. Two additional regional, or redpoint, championships will be accessible to them in 1967.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 28 The current season of the Indianapolis Symphony has been cancelled because of a labor dispute.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Arthur Krock, three times honored by the Pulitzer Prize committee for distinguished newspaper reporting, rounded out nearly 60 years in American journalism today by letting it be known that he way "going to pasture."

Holly Stores, Inc., a subsidiary of the S. S. Kresge Company, has leased 125,000 square feet in the St. John's Building, a four-block-long, four story-high industrial structure at 340 West Street, between Clarkson and Spring Streets.

The head of a municipal union engaged in contract negotiations with the city said yesterday that a Lindsay administration bill to establish new collective bargaining procedures was "an engaging exercise in glittering gimmickry."

A Queens grand jury heard several witnesses yesterday preliminary to the questioning of 13 reputed Mafia leaders whose conference in a Forest Hills restaurant was interrupted by a police raid last Thursday.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 28 (AP) A 17-year-old girl pacifist who was jailed for refusing to rise when her case was called in court has been released after 68 days of confinement.
HOUSTON, Sept. 28 (AP) America's oldest astronaut and two rookies will fly the second three-man Apollo mission next year, it was learned today. Officials plan to announce their selection tomorrow.

A steel executive asserted yesterday that that the proposed suspension by the Federal Government of the 7 per cent investment tax credit was "ill considered and drastic," as well as "upsetting and expen sive to the entire economy."
A 20-year-old Viennese man leaped from the liner Queen Mary into the Hudson River yesterday in what the police said was an attempt to enter the country illegally.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Representative Theodore R. Kupferman asked Congress today to conduct its own investigation into the adequacy of the Warren report on President Kennedy's assassination.
BERLIN, Sept. 28 (Reuters) The Utah Symphony Orchestra of Salt Lake City got an enthusiastic reception at its concert in the West Berlin Philharmonic hall last night.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 28 Mr. and Mrs. Hilton F. Lusk have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Lois Lusk, to Robert C. Evans Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans of South Salem, N.Y.
After a one-day advance, things were back to what has become normal on the American Stock Exchange prices went down in quiet trading.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The House Judiciary Committee today approved a general revision of the nation's copyright laws that has been 10 years in the making.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 Larry Jaster pitched his fifth straight shutout against the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight and threw the National League pennant race into a scramble with four days to go.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 Rioting bands of young Negroes swept into the Hunter's Point area of southeastern San Francisco tonight, battling the police with rocks and clubs. Some fired pistols.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 28 United States military and State Department representatives offered condolence and assistance today to the families of the 35 people killed and at least 17 others wounded in the bombing of a South-Vietnamese hamlet yesterday.

THE French couple who invited Philip Colleck to dine at their home in Nice last winter, never dreamed that by the time the table was cleared, they would be minus a clock and two commodes. Mr. Colleck, the London-born antiques dealer whose four-floor establishment is at 122 East 57th Street, works even when he eats, he explained the other morning during a preview of his new collection of 18th and l9thcentury English and French antiques.

Three City Councilmen called yesterday for an investigation of a possible conflict of interest in Pan American World Airways' financing of a lavish dinner-dance the city is giving next Monday in honor of chiefs of mission to the United Nations.

LONDON, Sept. 28 The British Government issued its second summons today in the crackdown on pirate radio stations that beam round-the-clock pop music to British teen-agers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Intercity truck tonnage and railroad carloadings in the latest week ended Sept. 24 were both considerably above the volume in the corresponding period of last year.

Broadway's twofer-hunters the audience that waits to see shows until flagging box-office sales induce producers to offer tickets at the price of two for one are gaining in opportunities.

Fights between Negro and white students at John Adams High School in Ozone Park, Queens, led to the posting of 24 patrolmen in the vicinity of the school yesterday.
MACY'S, which bills itself as the largest store in the world, will offer its customers some of the services of a small furniture shop when it opens its Ethan Allen Gallery on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The United States pledged today a "substantial" increase in its aid to the poor countries via the World Bank, but said this depended on assurance that the extra aid would not worsen the United States balance of payments.
HAVERFORD, Pa., Sept. 29 Gordon Hyde Jones, a vice president of the Western Savings Fund Society of Philadelphia, died here today in his home at the age of 60.

WITHOUT thinking much about it, most people would agree that the first duty of language is to be intelligible. WEST CALDWELL, N.J., Sept. 29 Tom Nieporte, 35year-old professional of the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, L.I., won the Metropolitan open golf championship by a three-stroke margin in rain and mist today.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced the arrests yesterday of four Queens men in the investigation of bank robberies committed earlier this month in Queens and Nassau Counties in which more than $56,000 was taken.

THE New York Philharmonic got properly under way last night in Philharmonic Hall, and promptly erased the tonal impression it had made at the Pension Fund concert the night before. At the Pension Fund, the orchestra was pushed far front, to make space for the chorus, and the tone was terribly raucous.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 The Lake Carriers' Association announced today the start of a legal campaign against "predatory and discriminatory" coal shipping-rate practices by major railroads.

SOMEWHERE toward the climax of "The Country Girl," the Clifford Odets drama that was revived last night at the City Center. Jennifer Jones and Rip Torn, who have spent most of the evening loathing each other, come together in a desperate clinch. They clutch. They embrace. They kiss.
Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, James Callaghan, urged American business yesterday to judge his country's investment potential in terms of economic realities rather than myths.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Friday, Sept. 30 (AP) Hurricane Inez lost some of its force during the night as it battered the mountains of southern Haiti, then roared on toward the southeast coast of Cuba. Reports from the Haitian coastal town of Jacmel said there were many deaths from a flood tide whipped up by the storm.

They will use computers to simplify house keeping chores. They will be under a greater strain than ever to obtain notable old works, and even loan exhibitions will be hard to come by.

ATLANTA, Sept. 29 Lester Garfield Maddox is a simple Southern boy who has, through determination and a feel for the popular will, turned adversity into profit.

NO one can accuse filmmakers of not trying to put the art of ballet fair and square on the screen. But one cannot give them many points for success. The latest attempt, which arrived at the Festival Theater and 68th Street Playhouse yesterday is "Bolshoi Ballet 67." It probably started out with the beginnings of a good idea, but got lost in a fog along the line.

TOKYO, Sept. 29 President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines proposed today that a seven-nation meeting to be held in Manila next month on the Vietnam problem be followed by an expanded conference of Asian Governments.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 29 Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., the Liberal party candidate for Governor, today urged the creation of a United Nations "peace-finding" committee on Vietnam.

Anton Kuerti, pianist, gave a long program of beautifully shaped performances last night at Town Hall. It was an interesting program, too, with such rarely heard tidbits as three of Mendelssohn's Preludes and Fugues from Opus 35 and Scriabin's Preludes of Opus 74, complete, his complete Etudes of Opus 65 and four of his Etudes from Opus 8.

PARIS, Sept. 29 A routine security check has led to the arrest of four persons for allegedly collecting information on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for East Germany, the Interior Ministry announced today.
Benjamin J. Levy A Wall Street partner whose career spans the years between the Gold Panic of 1907 and the bear bond market of 1967 will retire today as senior partner of Salomon Brothers Hutzler.

EASTON, Md., Sept. 29 Mr. and Mrs. Francis Howard Collins 2d have made known the engagement of Mr. Collins's daughter, Miss Alice Orr Collins, to Edwin Augustus Keeble Jr., son of Mrs. George Mehaffey Mott of Bronxville, N.Y., and Mr. Keeble of Nashville.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 29 The Belgian Government presented today a narrowly balanced 1967 budget and said it would contribute to a slowdown in inflation. The budget has not been balanced since 1964.
Orville S. Carpenter, courtappointed trustee of the Westec Corporation, said yesterday that he was negotiating "a new line of bank credit" for the company.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 29 Anti-Communist students turned a massive "show of force" in the capital today into their most vocal protest against President Sukarno in months.
The Lindsay administration yesterday released a list of big corporations it had solicited to pay for official city receptions and dinners for visiting dignitaries.

The stock market continued yesterday its sharp downtrend for the second successive session, with investment-grade and glamour issues again showing the largest losses. Trading was only moderately active.

The second major mortgage transaction for a Manhattan skyscraper to be announced within a week has been arranged for the 40-story building to be erected at 1133 Avenue of the Americas by the Durst Buildings Corporation.
YONKERS, Sept. 29 Each of tonight's New York $12,157 Sire stakes one-mile pacing events for 3-year-olds, which attracted 14,449 fans to rain-drenched Yonkers Raceway, presented a 7-to-10 favorite.

PEKING, Sept. 29 (Reuters) The Communist party's newspaper took the rare step today of publishing in advance the movements of Mao Tse-tung, announcing that he would review a National Day parade here Saturday.

MIAMI, Sept. 29 Premier Fidel Castro lashed out last night at old-guard Communist members of his regime for opposing his plan to abolish rent after 1970 and for disliking the independent course of the Cuban revolution.
The Transport Workers Union said yesterday that it hoped to have a final tally by Monday on the membership vote on a new contract with American Airlines.

ATLANTA, Sept. 29 (UPI) Three Federal judges watched movies of the Sept. 6 Atlanta race riot today during a court action in which Stokely Carmichael is seeking to have the Georgia law against rioting declared unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Federal Government was urged here today to reverse its recent decision not to grant draft deferments to American seamen in the face of what have been called serious merchant marine manpower shortages.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 29 (AP)--Hank Bauer, who directed the 1966 Baltimore Orioles to their first American League pennant, received a new two-year contract today.
The Bank of America and the Banque de Paris et des Pay-Bas announced yesterday the formation of a new finance institution to provide capital for industry in Europe.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 29 Co-eds in bikinis were cavorting in the championship pool, students between classes were lounging under bright umbrellas on the plaza, and in a television studio at the Student Union, Richard M. Nixon was denouncing the Democrats and pleading for unity among Republicans.
Four members of the Cosa Nostra family once headed by Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno surrendered yesterday in Brooklyn to begin serving 30-day prison sentences for contempt of court.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 (UPI)--United States District Judge James H. Meredith today refused to set aside a 1937 decree barring Humble Oil and Refining Company and Esso, Inc., from using the trademark "Esso" in 15 Midwestern states. Judge Meredith dismissed the suit filed by Humble and Esso.

TOKYO, Sept. 29--Radio broadcasts and newspapers from Hanoi denounced today recent United States peace overtures and said the only way to end the war in Vietnam... was for the Americans to halt their "aggressions."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) Senator Paul H.Douglas said today that the Senate Finance Committee had approved his bill to provide payment for drugs prescribed for the elderly under the voluntary part of the Medicare progam.
The city's water storage at 8 A.M. yesterday was 314.9 billion gallons, a drop of 1.5 billion gallons in 24 hours.

We should always be able to see "Carmen," it's that kind of an opera. The Bizet work, performed last night at the New York State Theater by the New York City Opera, pleases connoisseurs and uninitiated alike, and given a decent cast, it is bound to come off.

"Book Publishing in America," by Charles A. Madison, will be issued by McGraw-Hill Oct. 5. Mr. Madison was associated for many years with the publishing concern of Henry Holt. His book describes the development of book publishing from its beginnings in the 18th century to the big industry of today. Publishers, editors, authors and their books figure in Mr. Madison's account.
MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (Reuters) Soviet Air Force Units were sent to Communist China to help defend against intrusions from Nationalist China, a Russian newspaper disclosed today.
The Methodist Church announced yesterday that it would contribute $130,000 to the controversial Mississippi Delta Ministry of the National Council of Churches.
ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 29 Dr. Everette Lowell Campbell, obstetrician and gynecologist, died yesterday at Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 367 Highland Avenue here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29--President Johnson asked 11 more Governors today to combat inflation by reducing and delaying their states' spending.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, declared yesterday that the city Board of Education must take "immediate action" to improve the quality of schools in ghetto areas.
Tenants may have to pay higher rents to help defray the costs of incinerator improvements required under the city's new air pollution control law, two city officials said yesterday.
WARSAW, Sept. 29--Poland today for the first time ranged herself unreservedly on the side of the Soviet Union in the dispute with Communist China.
MADRID, Sept. 29--Spain reduced her public expenditures and adjusted bank discount rates today, thus joining the ranks of other West European nations in combatting inflation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) Members of the Senate today lauded Arthur Krock, the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist of The New York Times who is retiring after a newspaper career spanning almost 60 years.

Witness now the first crack in the discotheque scene: Shepheard's, the Establishment au go-go, this week heavily deescalated the frug and the monkey in favor of jazz pianist Dorothy Donegan and her trio.
The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended yesterday all trading activity by Kamen Co. for 10 business days. Abraham Kamen, the brokerage firm's managing partner, was suspended for 90 days.

A luncheon and fashion show with commentary by Jo Hughes of Bergdorf Goodman will be held in the Grand Ballroom at Delmonico's on Wednesday for the benefit of Music Therapy for Children in Hospitals, a division of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

Adopted resolution on Basutoland, Bechuanaland and Swaziland; continued general debate with statements by Denmark, Albania, Turkey, Kenya, Ethiopia, Pakistan, Finland, Bulgaria, Panama, Nigeria and Burundi.
BLUE POINT, L. I., Sept. 29--The body of a young woman bank teller and professional dancer who had been sought on embezzlement charges was found here this afternoon in a rain sump.

Seven reputed leaders of the Mafia are under subpoena to appear today before a Queens grand jury that is investigating rackets, three murders and the inflitration of legitimate business by the national syndicate of organized crime.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 29 John T. McHugh, vice president and director of Geyer, Morey, Ballard, Inc., an advertising agency at 555 Madison Avenue, New York, died yesterday at Valley Hospital, of a heart attack. He was 62 years old.
Three financial and investment companies announced yesterday the election of new officers and partners.

A real estate corporation that made a bookkeeping mistake 10 years ago when it applied for rent increases has been ordered to make refunds, plus 6 per cent interest, to 384 present and former tenants.

Red Barber said yesterday he did not know how a young man could become a sports broadcaster now without being a former athlete. He noted the influx of former athletes behind the microphone and pressure from advertisers as two major changes he had observed in sports advertising since he became a baseball broadcaster in 1933.
Max Factor Co., a cosmetics producer, announced yesterday in Los Angeles the election of Neil Kirkpatrick as a vice president.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 29 Governor Rockefeller suggested today that the Consolidated Edison Company might find an alternative to its controversial Cornwall hydroelectric plant in a gas jet turbine generator being developed in a Genesee Valley factory.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 Negroes demonstrated in the streets for the fifth consecutive night tonight in protest against the fatal shooting of a handcuffed Negro by a police detective Saturday.

AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 29 (AP) Paul L. Adams said to night his Conservative party was not anti-Republican or anti-Rockefeller but opposed to liberals who, he said, had a record "of spending with utter disregard of taxpayers' rights and fiscal responsibility."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 President Johnson gave 11 Governors today a special statement on crime problems, which he said were being fought with "archaic" efforts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 A Congressional investigation into the allegedly harsh methods used by the Government to compel integration in schools and hospitals was pledged today by Representative Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday a sharp increase in the net reserve deficit of the banking system. But bankers cautioned that the increase probably did not indicate a further tightening of Federal Reserve policy.
Bond prices advanced sharply in active trading yesterday.
Motorists will find all roads in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, closed to them on Sunday from 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. to make way for bicycle riders, roller skaters and pedestrians.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 There are no gains without pains, Adlai Stevenson once said, and perhaps that is the best way to read the following array of painful news that greeted this morning's readers:

European visitors to the United States are frequently confused when confronted with a man's hat or a women's bonnet on the little doors tucked away in the rear of restaurants and bars. Or if not confused, irritated.
LONDON, Sept. 29 (Reuters)--Britain began a campaign today to sell rich Americans the same kind of luxury goods the royal family buys.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) The House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, renounced today a $1,000 political contribution from a John Birch Society member because, he said, it carried unacceptable conditions.

HONG KONG, Sept. 29 Peking declared today that the international situation was excellent and pictured the world as being swept by Communist China's concept of "people's wars." It envisaged a future in which, "revolutionary people," owing allegiance to China, would "gain the entire world."
TOKYO, Sept. 29 (UPI) Paul Fuji of Hawaii won the Orient junior welterweight title tonight by knocking out Rocky Alarde of the Philippines in the third round after flooring him twice previously.
AN extinct breed of sailboat that once roamed the Hudson River in buffalo-herd abundance is about to make a comeback.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 In the opinion of some experienced Air Force officers, the bombing raids against North Vietnam are more of a political than a military operation.

The Gallup Poll reported yesterday that resistance of whites to measures for improving the lot of Negroes had reached the highest point since the spring of 1962, when the first survey was taken on the question.

ROME, Sept. 29 (AP) Laureen Cardinal Rugambwa, the Roman Catholic Church's first Negro Cardinal, was once refused a haircut in a barber shop in New York City because of his color, the Vatican weekly L'Osservatore Della Domenica reported today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 29 Mr. and Mrs. Leonard B. Colt of Providence and Little Compton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Colt, to Constantin R. Boden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans C. Boden of Frankfurt, Germany.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The nation's capital faces the possibility of a newspaper strike at midnight tomorrow.
The Greenpoint section of Brooklyn nowadays is a far cry from the days when Alderman Peter J. McGuiness called his bailiwick the "garden spot of the world."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) Representative Samuel S. Stratton, Democrat of upstate New York, charged today that President de Gaulle was trying to undermine the United States economy and urged Americans to stop visiting France and buying French wines.
The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., has added another "s." The total number, it is understood, is now 26.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) President Johnson will confer Monday with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and will meet later in the week with the Foreign Secretaries of France and Britain.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Senate passed today a modified version of the Administration's bill to create a Department of Transportation. The vote was 64 to 2.

BONN, Sept. 29 The West German Cabinet gave its backing today to the unyielding position taken by Chancellor Ludwig Erhard in his discussions with President Johnson earlier this week on purchases of American military equipment. The transactions are designed to offset the local costs of maintaining United States forces in West Germany.

Bernard F. Gimbel, the exuberant merchant who brought Gimbels to New York in 1910 and became one of the world's dominant retailers as he ruled over his family's expanding network of department stores, died early yesterday in his suite at the Pierre Hotel.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Sept. 29 Despite a driving rain that forced him into bogeys on the final three holes, Tony Aldarelli of Jumping Brook scored a 35, 39 74 today to take a 1-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the eighth annual New Jersey State Golf Association seniors championship at the Spring Lake Golf and Country Club.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 29 Howard D. Samuel, who is not running for Lieutenant Governor, stopped city-bound commuters on the station here this morning to tell them what he is running for delegate to the Constitutional Convention.
Friday, Sept. 30, 1966
BUFFALO, Sept. 29 Subpoenas for 10 witnesses, including an official of the Central Intelligence Agency, were issued today in a case involving the flight of seven B-26 bombers to Portugal last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (AP) Integration of teaching staffs in the Philadelphia public schools is being hampered by the reluctance of Negro teachers to join predominantly white faculties, according to Louis R. Ballen, the director of school integration.

Mrs. Wilson Follett of Norwich, Vt., widow of the author and editor whose name appears on a reference work, "Modern American Usage," expressed criticism of the book yesterday. The work is published by Hill Wang, Inc., of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The House approved tonight a $1.75-billion authorization bill to extend the antipoverty program for 1967. Before doing so it wrote in a specific mandate to enforce a provision for "maximum feasible participation" of the poor in the direction of community action projects.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 More than one-third of the nation's leading private-industry economists expect a recession next year, a poll of the National Association of...
CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 29 (AP) The Government and the main foreign oil companies operating in this country have reached a tentative agreement covering taxes in arrears and taxes on dividends.

ATLANTA, Sept. 29 The victory of Lester G. Maddox in the Democratic primary for Governor in Georgia yesterday makes it clear that the South is settling into a new and tougher period of resistance to Negro progress and the Administration of President Johnson.

CANTHO, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 30 (UPI) Premier Nguyen Cao Ky flatly rejected today any peace talks with the Vietcong. He said he would never sit down at the conference table with the insurgents.
Park Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving dedicated the city's 12th vest-pocket park yesterday as a downpour pelted the new facility in upper Manhattan.

ROME, Sept. 29 A discussion today of original sin by a congress of theologians appeared to differ in tone, at least, from a midsummer declaration by Pope Paul VI warning against aspects of the theory of evolution.
The Federal Government has given the city 60 days to submit plans for using a 350-bed hospital on a nine-acre tract in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn, or forfeit title to the property.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 29, (AP) Don Wilson got a victory in his first major league appearance tonight as the Houston Astros defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 3-2, on home runs by Chuck Harrison and Aaron Pointer.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 29 Arthur D. Julius of Metropolis and Frank B. Graven of Sands Point each scored 77 at Westchester Country Club today to share a one-stroke lead halfway through the 13th annual fall tournament of the New York State Seniors Golf Association.
LONDON, Sept. 29 A judge ruled today that a company could not, on the basis of the voluntary freeze on prices and incomes, refuse to pay a wage increase already agreed upon.

Ignoring the pleas of Secretary of State Rusk, the Senate Appropriations Committee has done further damage to the foreign aid program. It not only refused to restore the cut of almost $250 million that was made by the House, it also decided on some changes of its own that increased the funds for military help while reducing the amount that will be available for economic aid.

The older employes at Gimbels gathered in small groups yesterday and swapped stories about Mr. Bernard, as they called him, and over at Macy's, in the executive suite, everybody said that even Macy's was no longer quite the same without Bernard F. Gimbel nearby.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 29 (UPI) Whiskaway Pick, a 9-year-old black gelding driven by Elmer Looney, survived a stretch challenge by Chief Morenci today and captured the American Legion Pace at Freehold Raceway.
Selling pressure continued to weaken most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford, suggested today that the United States could stem the flow of Soviet war material into North Vietnam by destroying the dredges that kept open the port of Haiphong. Such a step, Mr. Ford argued, would prevent the use of the port without the risk of a direct confrontation with the Soviet Union.
KENSINGTON, Md., Sept. 29--Miss Joan Elizabeth Quigley and John Lee Howard plan to marry here in December.
Fordham University detailed its plans yesterday for the use of the Gallery of Modern Art, the museum on Columbus Circle that it hopes to acquire from Huntington Hartford.
ATLANTA, Sept. 29 (AP) Billy Hitchcock was hired today to manage the Braves again next season, and promptly said he thought Atlanta could be a contender with better relief pitching.
A 66-year-old landlord shot and killed one burglary suspect yesterday and subdued another with an iron pipe during a struggle.

The Diamond International Corporation achieved the highest sales and earnings in its 85-year history in this year's third quarter and first nine months, William H. Walters, chairman and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.

IT was the fashion Industry's big night out. After a day of creating, producing, promoting and purveying fashion, more than 700 industry leaders changed into their evening clothes and drew up to the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night to look at some more clothes.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 30--Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Mokotoff have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Steffi Mokotoff, to Robert Berne. He is the son of Gustave M. Berne of Kings Point and the late Mrs. Janet Berne.

A pigmy hippopotamus broke out of its cage in a Kennedy International Airport cargo shed yesterday, charged with freight-train speed at 25 men at work in the building and then boxed itself into a narrow sevenfoot-long passage between two buildings.
FOR Sir Seretse Khama, sworn in yesterday as the first President of the new southern African country of Botswana, the wheel of personal and political fortune has come full turn.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30-- Jeane Hoffman, a former editor of The Police Gazette and an assistant to Walter O'Malley, president of the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball club, died yesterday. Her age was 47.

Daniel J. Lehane, a New York newspaperman since he was 18, was buried here yesterday. A former reporter with The New York Sun, he had been the Federal Court House reporter for the Associated Press for the last 14 years. Mr. Lehane was 52 years old.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 30 --The Government has reopened criminal proceedings against former President Juscelino Kubitschek as a result of efforts by displaced political leaders to form an opposition Democratic Front.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP)-- John Romano's two-out, runscoring single in the 11th inning gave the Chicago White Sox a 6-5 victory over the New York Yankees tonight. The loss insured a 10th-place finish for the once-mighty Yankees.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) k--Francis R. Valeo took the oath of office today as secretary of the Senate, succeeding Emery L. Frazier.

Twenty thousand years, more or less, of the artist's effort to make a picture are cunningly compressed and beautifully detailed in an exhibition that opens tomorrow in the Junior Museum at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, Oct. 1 (AP)--Pressmen at The Washington Post halted work shortly after midnight today when negotiators failed to reach agreement with four Washington daily newspapers.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 30--The saddest place in this teeming, seedy capital is the six-story Project House, an echoing mausoleum of the country's deferred hopes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)--The House Commerce Committee approved today a bill adding veterinary medicine schools to existing Federal construction and student loan programs.

The image of The Times, individual and independent, thundering or scolding, informing and recording from Printing-House Square is fixed as solidly in our concept of London as Big Ben or the Thames or the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace.

HONG KONG, Saturday, Oct. 1 --Mao Tse-tung, the Chinese Communist leader, was given a tumultuous reception when he appeared at a National Day in Peking's Tienamen Square today to celebrate Communist China's 17th anniversary.
The Federal Maritime Commission has won another round in its continuing battle with steamship lines and steamship conferences over the validity of its subpoenas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- The United States Commissioner of Education, Harold Howe 2d, denied under sharp questioning today by Southern critics on the House Rules Committee that he had overstepped his authority in his efforts to effect school desegregation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30-- As public and private agencies intensified efforts to avert further racial outbreaks in San Francisco's poverty areas, 1,000 National Guard troops were sent home today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 30 --A larch tree, its piney branches looking feeble next to the great trees by the Village Hall, was dedicated here today not far from where Peter Jay Munro scattered the first larch seeds from Scotland in the seventeen-nineties.
The election of new vice presidents was announced yesterday by the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Franklin National Bank.
A Swiss bank offered yesterday to purchase for its own account at least 350,000 shares of the common stock of the Columbia Pictures Corporation at $33 a share.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 30--Dr. Henry Rubin, who practiced dentistry in Jersey City for 37 years, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital, Newark. He was 61 ears old and lived at 30 Burr Road here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)--The establishment of a team of medical and other specialists to explore means of improving the attack on emphysema and chronic bronchitis was disclosed today.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Sept. 30--Rodman W. Chamberlain, retired vice president of sales of the Stanley Works, a toolmanufacturing concern, died last night at the New Britain General Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in nearby Kensington.
The London stock market closed yesterday with small declines.

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 30 --Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. John D. Hunter of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Kathleen Hunter, to Hugh T. Kemper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kosciusko Kemper 3d of Roslyn Estates.
HAUPPAGE, L.I., Sept. 30-- Suffolk County police recovered today an automobile rented by a 20-year-old bank teller and part-time go-go girl, whose body was found in a sump yesterday in Blue Point.

SPRING LAKE HEIGHTS, N.J., Sept. 30--Tony Aldarelli, the assistant manager of the Edgemont Country Club in Philadelphia, yesterday won the eighth annual New Jersey Golf Association seniors championship with a 34, 37--71 at the Spring Lake Golf and Country Club.

YONKERS, Sept. 30--Of the $121,676 wagered on the outcome of the New York Sire Stakes trot for 4-year-olds tonight at Yonkers Raceway, $53,733 backed Hicki Hi and the 9-to-10 favorite in the field of five did not let down his followers.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 30 --The engagement of Miss Anne Eliot Christopher to Dr. James Edward Cunningham, son of Mrs. Dorothy H. Drummond of Fresno, Calif., and Joe P. Cunningham of Wichita Falls, Tex., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Christopher.

The Ramsey Lewis Trio, still riding the wave of success on which it rose more than a year ago with "The 'In' Crowd," headed a bill at Philharmonic Hall last night that also included Godfrey Cambridge, the comedian, and Loretta Long, a singer.
The city lost a round yesterday in its surprise battle to keep two questions seeking to abolish the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board on the Nov. 8 ballot.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) President Johnson headed off today a possible strike against Pan-American World Airways Sunday night with the designation of a special emergency board to look into the airline's contract dispute with the Transport Workers Union of America.

Buckpasser, conceded to be the best thoroughbred in training, will undertake to add to his splendid performance and earnings achievements today in the Woodward at Aqueduct. Ogden Phipps's 3-year-old is the 6-5 favorite in the early line to take the 1 -mile weight-forage contest, and if he does, he will become the fifth richest money earner in turf history.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Governor Rockefeller made known today that New York's revenues this year had been a good deal higher than expected, particularly from the state income tax.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30--A meeting of South Vietnam's Roman Catholic bishops got under way today in Saigon with a papal envoy present.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 30-- Britain and Saudi Arabia have virtually completed an emergency program for the defense of the Saudi kingdom's frontier with Yemen against the Egyptians.

PARIS, Sept. 30--Mehdi Ben Barks, the Moroccan Opposition leader who was kidnapped here a year ago and is presumed slain, was tortured by his abductors. This was reported today in the testimony of one witness during the fourth week of hearings in the case.
Government bond prices drifted downward in the lightest trading of the week yesterday, continuing a decline that began in after-hours trading Thursday.
MOSCOW, Sept. 30 (AP)-- The modified miniskirt was introduced in Moscow today.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 30--Dr. and Mrs. R. Burton Power have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bonnie Jeanne Power, to Donald Samuel Reinke, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Samuel Reinke of Blooming Grove, N.Y.A June wedding is planned.
