LONDON, Sept. 30--The Times of London is changing its direction in the way that Britain herself is changingfrom traditional, private, family business to something more impersonal.

Negotiations between the General Electric Company and the International Union of Electrical Workers were scheduled to continue today in an effort to avert a nationwide strike threatened for midnight tomorrow.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that five of the country's leading architectural firms would enter a $100,000 competition to design a $5.7million combined police station house, stable and riding ring in Central Park.
The city's big, bright and almost unbelievably elongated new produce market--a $40million facility spread over 128 acres of cheap land in the Bronx--is the Grand Central Station of broccoli.
The Salute to Eddy Duchin Ball for the benefit of the Leukemia Society will be held in the Grand Ballroom at the Plaza on Oct. 19.
Twelve Episcopal bishops have accused the Right Rev. James A. Pike, who recently resigned as Bishop of California, of having promulgated heretical views and violated his ordination vows.
HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 30--The war in Vietnam, which has long been considered anathema by Hollywood studios, is finally winning the attention of some important filmmakers.

Richard Cunningham Patterson Jr., former Commissioner of Public Events and chief of protocol of New York City and for 12 years its official greeter of distinguished visitors, died last night at New York Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at the Waldorf Towers.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. accused Democratic "bosses" yesterday of conspiring to scuttle Anthony J. Travia for Speaker of the Assembly in favor of Stanley Steingut, the Brooklyn Democratic leader.
SINCE the New York City Opera does many things so well, it is rather a pity that it decided to perform Mozart's "Don Giovanni" so early in its residence at the New York State Theater.
Baeza thrilled the 24,154 customers on hand yesterday with his brilliant riding performances. He scored three victories in five races, his most important one occurring in the feature.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30 (AP)--The Pittsburgh Pirates were kept idle in their attempt to catch the National League-leading Los Angeles Dodgers tonight as their game with the San Francisco Giants was washed out.
The stock market slipped to a new 1966 low for a while yesterday, but recovered in late trading to finish with a narrow gain.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 30--Herbert L. Henschel, manager of the Kennedy Dessert Co., Inc., of Mount Vernon, powdered foods manufacturers, died yesterday in his home, 70 Montgomery Circle. He was 75 years old.

The bright piping voices of the Obernkirchen Children's Choir filled Carnegie Hall with their sound of pure charm last night. The German choir has given 15 concerts here since 1954, and this was the first since 1964 and the first at Carnegie.
The French franc recovered yesterday from its sharp decline of the previous day to regain a level comfortably above parity on foreign exchange markets here and abroad.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Sept 30--Lorenzo Bandini of Italy, with a new V-12 Ferrari, set a one-lap record of 120.577 miles an hour today during the first practice session for Sunday's Grand Prix of the United States. His clocking over the 2.3-mile course was 1 minute 8.67 seconds.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 30--The work of David Smith, the American sculptor who died last year at the age of 59, is currently the subject of a superb retrospective exhibition at Harvard University's Fogg Art Museum. Selected by Jane Harrison Cone, who has also prepared a comprehensive catalogue that is going to be an indispensable work of reference for students of modern sculpture, the show consists of 21 works dating from 1933 to 1965.

TEMPE, Ariz., Sept. 30 (UPI) --David R. Mumbaugh, 18 years old, stood mute today before Justice of the Peace Ralph Fowler as he was arraigned on a first-degree murder charge in the fatal stabbing Sept. 21 of Laura Bernstein, 20, of Fair Lawn, N.J., a student at Arizona State University.

YONKERS, Sept. 30--The twin double, a type of wagering conducted at Yonkers Raceway since Aug. 27, 1963, will be offered to Westchester County harness racing fans for the last time tomorrow night. Abolishment of the twin double was announced late tonight by the track's management.

SARASOTA, Fla., Sept. 30 (AP)--Gov. Haydon Burns reversed a previous decision today and ordered Dr. Carl Coppolino extradited to New Jersey to stand trial in the murder of William E. Farber, a retired Army lieutenant colonel.

Net income of the Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation for the fiscal year ended July 31 amounted to $2,531,000 or 71 cents a share on 3,606,000 shares, the report of Gaylord M. Lamond, president, disclosed yesterday. In the previous fiscal year $2,326,000 or 65 cents a share was cleared.

ROME, Sept. 30--Pope Paul VI, in a message read today in Saigon to the Roman Catholic hierarchy of Vietnam, promised to continue his action for peace "without limits" and without "the least temporal interest."
BALTIMORE, Sept. 30 (AP) --Harmon Killebrew hit home runs off Dave McNally and Jim Palmer tonight as the Minnesota Twins whipped the American League champion Baltimore Orioles, 10-7 and 8-2.
Larry Dierker, a 20-year-old right-hander for the Houston Astros, was on the verge of attaining baseball immortality last night in cool Shea Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized 11 supplemental airlines today to operate foreign charter flights--including package tours--to various parts of the world.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 30 (UPI)-- Eric Fleming, star of the television series "Rawhide," drowned Wednesday during the filming of a motion-picture scene 220 miles northeast of Lima. His death was announced here today by the United States Embassy.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 30--The New Jersey Association of School Administrators today reaffirmed its position that public primary, secondary and higher education should remain under the control of the New Jersey State Department of Education.

UPPSALA, Sweden, Sept. 30 (Reuters)--The Uppsala Seismological Institution said today that it had registered what appeared to be an underground nuclear explosion in the Semipalatinsk area of Soviet Central Asia.
IN an age of battery-operated flour sifters and electric toothbrushes, it is not surprising that someone should introduce an appliance for face steaming.
THERE'S the woman dentist who never practiced and doesn't see herself starting now.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 30 (AP)-- two brothers from Van Nuys, Calif., who had been sentenced for defacing an anti-American poster on Vietname were reported to have been released from prison and expelled from, Hungary today.
HENRI BENDEL, a store that has been undergoing a metamorphosis since Geraldine Stutz became president in 1958, now boasts another transformation.
Four major lumber associations reported a decline of 8.8 per cent in production for the week ended Sept. 24, compared with the level in the corresponding 1964 week.

Prices on the American Exchange continued to decline yesterday, although a late rally reduced some of the earlier losses. The list opened lower and continued to weaken until shortly before 2 P.M., when some issues started to rebound on stepped-up buying.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.-- The completion of a $1-million, three-year forest survey in Greece has brought recommendations for investment there over the next 20 years of some $70-million. The development would be designed to insure self-sufficiency in the supply of forestry products.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 30-- Miss Deborah Altschul of New York and Paul R. Resnick of Wilmington, Del., have made plans to be married in November.
The city's Department of Finance estimates that 275,000 people must file declarations of estimated city income or earnings taxes before the deadline on Monday.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 30 (AP)--Gov. George C. Wallace, campaigning for his wife, says people across the nation have turned sour on both major political parties.
TRENTON, Sept. 30 (AP)-- The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad's proposal to curtail passenger service starting Monday morning was approved today by New Jersey's second highest court.
BERLIN, Saturday, Oct. 1-- Albert Speer and Baldur von Schirach, two leaders of Nazi Germany, emerged as free men early this morning from 20 years at the Spandau War Crimes Prison.
The National Audubon Society appealed yesterday to Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara to keep planned military operations out of Agattu Island in the Aleutian Islands National Wildlife Refuge.
REGULAR auction-goers at Parke-Bernet are in for their second shock in less than six months. Part 2 of the Anton Meister collection comes up for sale next Friday and Saturday.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 (AP) --The powerful Los Angeles defense intercepted four passes thrown by John Brodie tonight and turned three of the interceptions into scoring drives as the Rams swept to a 34-3 victory over the San Francisco 49ers.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 30 (AP)--A three-judge Federal Court upheld today the Mississippi Legislature's redistricting of the state's five Congressional districts, throwing out a complaint by civil rights forces.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- Sherman J. Maisel, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that Federal Reserve policies "are those of expansion and not of contraction."

Institutional investors--penson funds, mutual funds and insurance companies--bought a total of $5.1-billion worth of stock in the second quarter of this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)--The Interstate Commerce Commission today set Oct. 31 as the date for the opening of more hearings on the pending merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 (AP)--The Delaware River basin has "significant" undeveloped potential to meet water shortages and develop hydroelectric power, according to a joint Federal-state study.

Dr. and Mrs. Mortimer M. Kopp have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Matta L. Kopp, to Harry I. Freund, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Freund. Both families are of New York. The wedding is planned for Oct. 30.
LONDON, Sept. 30--The Times of London, that extraordinary British institution, will pass into new ownership under a plan announced tonight. It has been controlled by the English Astors since 1922.

United States maritime policy will be given top priority by the new Transportation Department, whcih may be established as early as January, 1967, Alan S. Boyd, Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation, said yesterday.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 30-- On the eve of her sixth year of independence, Nigeria appears to be on the verge of coming apart at the seams, a victim of rumor.

SHARES of the Admiral Corporation, which set a year's low yesterday in early trading later became a standout in an indifferent stock market after the company announced several bits of encouraging news.

By its overwhelming vote for a new Department of Transportation the Senate has assured creation of a twelfth new department in the Federal Government. Many differences in detail between the Senate version and the one passed by the House last month remain to be worked out, but the basic principle of consolidating in a single administration functions that now are scattered among 35 agencies has been approved.
WASHINGTON, Sept., 30 (AP)--The fall series of Selective Service college qualification tests will be given at more than 500 test centers on Nov. 18 and 19, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- A technique widely used in genetic research is making it possible to detect babies who will be abnormal, long, before they are born.

CAIRO, Sept. 30--President Abdullah al-Salal of Yemen has accused some former cabinet ministers of "collaborating with agents of the United States and Saudi Arabia" and said they would be tried for treason.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)--An objection by Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Bronx Democrat, temporarily delayed House action today on a resolution to finance an investigation of Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Manhattan Democrat.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- Manufacturers' inventories soared by more than $1.1-billion in August after rising $1billion in July, the Commerce Department reported today. These increases compare with an average monthly growth in inventories of $650-million in the first half of this year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- The Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia suggested today that the Organization of African Unity might be a better agent than the United Nations to guide the people of SouthWest Africa to independence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- The index of primary market prices declined one-fifth of 1 per cent to 106.3 during the week ended Sept. 27, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods decreased in price while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30-- The plot suddenly thickened in the National League pennant race tonight when the Philadelphia Phillies reached up from fourth place, knocked off the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-3, and cut their lead to 1 games.

LONDON, Sept. 30--The Labor Government reached today into the heart of "the Establishment" for the man to run the steel industry when it is nationalized. It chose Lord Melchett, 41, investment banker and grandson of the man who created the giant Imperial Chemical Industries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- Arthur J. Goldberg emphasized today that despite a mixed and generally harsh reaction from North Vietnam to recent United States peace proposals, he did not consider that they had been rejected.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP)-- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that recent race riots had been "very depressing" developments.

It was to be expected that Edouard Blitz would be an able cellist, since he is a member of the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, and so he proved to be in his New York debut recital in Town Hall last night. He has a particularly fine tone, resonant and mellow, and a quietly tasteful approach to the music he played.
The late George S. Kaufman, will be the best-represented writer this season on and off Broadway.

MOSCOW, Sept. 30 (AP) --A 26-year-old American has been expelled from the Soviet Union on charges of working for the Central Intelligence Agency and engaging in "hostile activities," Soviet authorities disclosed today

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- The Senate resolved procedural difficulties brought on by a cocktal party comment and approved today the Nomination of Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach to be Under Secretary of State.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30--Adam Malik, Foreign Minister of Indonesia, today reversed an earlier declaration by President Sukarno and promised to hold a plebiscite on the future of West Irian.
MIAMI, Sept. 30--A plane that bombed the Cuban port of Nuevitas in Camaguey Province last night did not fly from United States territory, exile sources said here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30--The French delegation to the United Nations denied today that a gesture made Wednesday by Nikolai T. Fedorenko of the Soviet Union to the French representative Roger Seydoux represented Soviet approval of the speech by Foreign Minister Couve de Murville to the General Assembly.
LONDON, Sept. 30 (Reuters) --More merchant ships were lost in 1965 than in any peacetime year since records have been kept, Lloyd's Register of Shipping said today.
Mrs. Edith Harlan Powell, an independent investment counselor, has been elected president of the Women's Bond Club of New York.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)--Legislation to extend the Federal program for airport construction through the 1970 fiscal year won approval today from the House Commerce Committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) --The Justice Department filed suit today against the nation's three largest manufacturers of dental products. It charged they had tended to create a monopoly by becoming the biggest retail distributors of dental supplies.

In asking help of the Federal Government after this week's riots, the first need stressed by the Mayor of San Francisco was more jobs for the unskilled, untrained youths of the Negro slums. His plea served to highlight a central paradox in the nation's war against poverty: Unemployment among disadvantaged young people is going up while it decreases for every other section of the work force.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- The Senate began consideration today of a $2.5-billion antipoverty bill, with a Republican, Jacob K. Javits, leading off in support of it.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- The Indiana State Police have begun to install in their patrol cars a speed clocker invented by a Virginia realestate broker.
DETROIT, Sept. 30 (UPI)-- The nation's auto industry proruced more cars this week than any week since last June, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)--The project to disperse winter fog at 15 airports will be expanded this year to 20 airports, an airlines director of the program said today.

TOKYO, Sept. 30 (AP)-- India held a 1-0 lead in its Davis Cup Eastern zone finals against Japan today after a second singles match between Koji Watanabe and Premjit Lall of India was called off because of darkness.

MIAMI, Sept. 30--Hurricane Inez, with rising death tolls in its wake, smashed southeastern Cuba today and suddenly changed course to a westerly direction that forecasters said could mean trouble for the United States.

THE oils and water-colors by Jan Cybis in his oneman show at the Finch College Museum of Art, 62 East 78th Street, go back as far as 1949, but most of them are from 1956 on, a mere 10 years. They have the air, however, of having been painted by a moderately forward-looking artist during the 1920's, when a second generation was absorbing the pioneers' lessons in expressionism.

David Sarnoff, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America and a pioneer in electronic communications, declared in a speech last night that, in the future, his industry's "chief concern must be with the spiritual, social and political progress of mankind."

At noon yesterday everything came to a halt at Gimbels as Bernard F. Gimbel's loyal employes and customers paid him a minute of silent respect. Then business was continued as usual --just as Mr. Gimbel had wanted it.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday defended his administration's practice of allowing private sponsors to pay for civil social affairs and denied that such sponsors expected anything in return from the city.

Sir Seretse Khama is blunt about the position of his newly independent country in southern Africa, the huge area formerly known as Bechuanaland and now called Botswana: "For the sake of survival we must live with South Africa."

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor sought in State Supreme Court yesterday to obtain from a shipping company, documents and data pertinent to the agency's investigation of alleged "corrupt" payments made by a stevedoring concern.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30--Fifty-one North Vietnamese were killed in a strip of torn and charred jungle near the northern boundary of South Vietnam yesterday after an intense pounding by United States marine artillery shells and flaming napalm.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 30--At least 11 persons were killed today and about 40 injured when Hindus and Moslems clashed in a central Indian town over the issue of the slaughter of cows.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 30 (AP)--Three Federal judges refused today to order Cov. George C. Wallace to show cause why he should not be cited for contempt of court for alleged interference with school desegregation in Alabama.
MOSCOW, Sept. 30--The Soviet Government made public today the outlines for long debated, sweeping increases in wholesale prices for heavy industry.

Beginning Dec. 1, a suspect picked up anywhere in Manhattan on charges of petit larceny, disorderly conduct, peddling, or any of 440 other minor crimes may get only a summons to appear in court instead of being arrested.
The Union Jack snapped in front of the New York Police Headquarters yesterday--possibly for the first time--as British Home Secretary Roy Jenkins visited Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary.
LONDON, Sept. 30 (Reuters) --The Government's chief medical adviser urged today a complete boycott of cigarette smoking in Britain.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)--A bill to ban the interstate shipment of toys containing hazardous substances was approved today by the House Commerce Committee.

LEO NARDUCCI left the Guy D. showroom one morning this week with a box tucked under his arm containing some of the African print dresses and at-home designs he had just created for the company's upcoming resort and holiday line.

The formal search has started to find a new president for the New York Stock Exchange. Keith Funston, president since 1951, has announced he will step down from the $125,000-ayear post when his contract expires on Sept. 10, 1967.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Administration's bill to restrain inflationary pressures by discouraging business spending for buildings and equipment was passed today by the House, 221 to 118.

DETROIT, Sept. 30--The swinging crowd is moving up, and the sporty look that it supposedly seeks in automobiles has now reached a no less lofty level than the Cadillac Division of the General Motors Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- Chief Justice Earl Warren today, named a committee of Federal judges to study the use of computers for predicting Federal jury requirements.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30--Foreign Minister Joseph M. A. H. Luns of the Netherlands today scored those who demand that the United States make all the concessions to promote peace talks on Vietnam.

Seven suave witnesses, described by Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel as important figures in the national crime syndicate, went before a grand jury yesterday but yielded no information beyond their names and addresses.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP)-- A Federal judge forbade George Lincoln Rockwell's American Nazi party today from demonstrating near any Jewish synagogue on the sabbath or on Jewish holidays.
The chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights accused the Board of Examiners yesterday of discriminating against Negro teachers seeking promotions in the public school system.

ATLANTA, Sept. 30--A move began developing today among Negroes and white liberals to run a write-in candidate in the governorship election Nov. 8 against two civil rights opponents, Lester G. Maddox, a Democrat, and Representative Howard H. Callaway, a Republican.
A million-dollar music festival opens here today with works by Guadagnini, Bergonzi and Montagnana, none of which-- not if two armed guards can help it--will be played.
Miss Roberta Dale Eisenberg has become engaged to Jeffrey Kushner and Miss Vera Bogi to Miss Eisenberg's brother, Philip Lloyd Eisenberg.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- The painters' union today put a trouble-wracked San Francisco district council under trusteeship on the ground that its affairs were being improperly conducted and the rights of its members in jeopardy.
OLEAN, N.Y., Sept. 30-- Frank D. O'Connor won an endorsement and standing ovation today from the leaders of the 65,000-member State, County and Municipal Employes union.

Gary Beban and Buzz Busby will step into the picture on television screens across the nation today and endeavor to duplicate the aerial act that Notre Dame's Terry Hanratty and Jim Seymour put on against Purdue a week ago.

The General Dynamics Corporation, which acquired a 34 per cent interest in the United Electrical Coal Companies in 1959 when the Material Service Company merged into General Dynamics, is endeavoring to gain complete control of the coal company.
Price increases ranging from pennies to a few dollars were announced yesterday by manufacturers in the carton, rare metals, textile and copper industries.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP)-- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that the gradual escalation of the war in Vietnam posed an eventual threat to "the freedoms we are defending" and he advocated the immediate application of "as much force as we need to win."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30--The House approved today, 312-0, a four-year $2,315,000,000 program to help states and cities fight pollution in rivers, lakes and other public waters.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 30 --Mrs. Cosmo Ciminello has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Rose-Marie Ciminello, to Dr. Vincent du Vigneaud Jr. He is the son of Dr. du Vigneaud, Nobel Laureate in Chemistry in 1955, and Mrs. du Vigneaud of Scarsdale and Sheffield, Mass.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30--The Congo's Foreign Minister told the Security Council today that his country felt obliged to help "Angolan patriots" raid Portuguese Angola from the Congo. He also said his country demanded protection against possible raids from Angola into the Congo.
Representative Leonard Farbstein's winning margin in last Tuesday's Democratic primary in the 19th Congressional District rose to 1,092 today with the official recanvass.

When voters of New York pull a "yes" or "no" lever Nov. 8 to say whether they want to make lotteries legal again, it will be the first public expression on a major enlargement of gambling in the state since 1939.
Now that the people of the United 'States have decided that good health is a right of every citizen, they have, through their representatives in the government, enacted new leeislation
CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 (UPI)--Judge Francis J. Talty, who will preside at the second murder trial of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, laid down strict ground rules today for news coverage of the proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- President Johnson, with a good deal of prompting from the political hinterland, appears to have had some second thoughts about the value of his barnstorming for Democratic candidates in the current campaign.
An internationally known weather specialist has begun work on a research project financed by New York State into the nature and probable causes of the five-year drought in the Northeast.
Western International Hotels, Inc., is negotiating to operate 10 hotels in Venezuela owned and operated by the Venezuelan Government.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30--Cambodia sent a letter of protest to the Security Council today charging United States and South Vietnamese forces with an air attack on Cambodian territory on Sept. 20.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., Sept. 30 --Guillermo Otero, 36 years old, and his brother, Victor, 40, went to work at Pete Pati's 15-acre grape and tomato farm in nearby Brocton in July. Felipo Torres went to work there three weeks ago.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Sept. 30--Miss Gale Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Edward Wilson of Rumson, N.J., was married this afternoon to William Lang Shaw Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Shaw of Coral Gables.
SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 1. (UPI) Baylor turned loose a sharp ground attack today to hand Washington State its third consecutive football loss, 20-14.

ARDMORE, Pa., Oct., 1 Miss Virginia Cassandra Nye, daughter of the late Col. Glenn Caflyle Nye, U.S.A.F., and the late Mrs. Nye, was married today to Timothy Arthur Vanderver Jr., son of Mrs. Vanderver of Birmingham, Ala., and the late Mr. Vanderver.

Here, it is a stipple-grained, imitation-morocco box, labeled "Holy Bible" but hollowed out to hide "small objects of value."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1 The British Government is becoming disillusioned with the commonwealth, according to diplomats and officials of Commonwealth countries here.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1 Astronauts from mountain areas such as Colorado or the Caucasus are better qualified, both physically and psychologically, to endure the loneliness and rigors of a flight to the moon than "flatlanders" from places such as New York or Moscow, a Soviet space medicine specialist said this week in a research report.

Egmont Arens, industrial designer and former magazine editor, died of a cardiac arrest Friday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 78 years old and lived at 16 Blair Drive in Huntington, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana suggested today that former President Dwight D. Eisenhower explain in detail to President Johnson what he believes is needed to win the Vietnam war.

MOSCOW, Sept. 26 Radio listeners in Kaluga, 100 miles southwest of Moscow, were enjoying an unusually lively program of jazz. Suddenly a grave voice, speaking "for all the radio stations of the Soviet Union," interrupted the broadcast to warn that United States rockets armed with nuclear warheads were hurtling down toward Soviet cities.

OTTAWA, Oct. 1--Paul F. Hellyer, Minister of Defense who upset military sensibilities last month when he proposed a standard green uniform for all branches of the armed services, is having an easier time with his latest modernization move.

New York, as everyone knows, is like no other city. Even the scale of its troubles is hard to grasp. Its slums are cities in themselves, and its ghettos are the most notorious in the country. More than one million people live in bad housing in declining neighborhoods.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 1 Drivers and mechanics of the Hempstead Bus Corporation went on strike early this morning. The line serves 18,000 riders daily.

A funeral service for Richard Cunningham Patterson Jr., former Commissioner of Public Events and chief of protocol of New York City and for 12 years its official greeter, will be held Tuesday at 11 A.M. in Christ Church (Methodist), 520 Park Avenue, near 60th Street. Burial will be in Arlington (Va.) Cemetery.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector, Oct. 1 David Ben-Gurion will be 80 years old tomorrow and the nation is preparing for the celebration.
RECIFE, Brazil, Oct. 1 A military court sentenced Francisco Juliao, organizer of Brazil's so-called Peasant Leagues, to eight years' imprisonment today "for crimes against the national security."

For the first time in more than four years, the nation's purchasing agents are showing a substantial concern over short-range economic prospects.

PARIS, Oct. 1 With systematic determination, insurmountable French pride, painful attention to detail, and a fortune built on ballpoint pens, Baron Marcel Bich has set his sights on the America's Cup.
"A Hand Is on the Gate," the evening of Negro verse and song at the Longacre Theater, which was to close last night because of poor attendance, has been saved, at least until next Saturday.

Fordham opened its 86th season of football it was club football this time by downing Iona, 19-12, in rain-drenched Coffey Stadium on the Fordham Rose Hill campus yesterday. It was the Fordham club's fifth victory in a row over a twoyear period.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 1 (AP) Al Brenner's 95-yard punt return for a touchdown the longest in Big Ten history and a freak mid-air fumble recovery that sent Pat Gallinagh, a tackle, lumbering 40 yards to score enabled top-ranked Michigan State today to turn back Illinois, 26-10.

CADIZ, Ohio, Oct. 1 There are no deer or antelope playing in eastern Ohio, but steers still roam the range there getting fat on the Hanna Coal Company's crown vetch a vinelike forage that seems to thrive in any drought-plagued area.

WASHINGTON The Civil Aeronautics Board has ruled that domestic air carriers must provide $500 minimum liability for loss, damage or delay in delivery of baggage.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Sept. 27 The wind was chill and the heavy, black storm clouds dropped rain all around the city's edge, but 300 people stood in the street to hear the clipped and reminiscently familiar accent of the junior Senator from Massachusetts.

PICKENS, S. C., Oct. 1 The long-term impact of the Duke Power Company's $700-million Keowee-Toxaway power generating complex on the northwest corner of South Carolina and on the state is bound to be considerable in terms of industrialization, local tax structures, tourism and recreation.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 They marriage of Miss Juliet Irene Merryweather, daughter of George Esselborn Merryweather of Waite Hill and the late Mrs. Elinor Holton Merryweather, to Thomas Goodwin Evans took place tonight. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Thomas Evans of Kirtland Hills.
AUBURN, Mich., Oct. 1 Miss Sharon Kay Barre and William Robertson Keech of Merion, Pa., and Chapel Hill, N.C., plan to marry Oct. 15 at Chapel Hill.

PAGOPAGO, American Samoa, Sept. 27 Fifty-one Samoan chiefs, dressed in a colorful assortment of Samoan and Western costumes, are meeting to consider revising the Constitution of this little American possession in the South Seas.

TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 1 (AP) Dexter Daniels of Winterhaven, Fla., scored a 1-up victory today over George Beechler of Prineville, Ore., to capture the United States Golf Association seniors amateur championship.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 1 Bruce Jankowski scored five touchdowns today as Fair Lawn routed Hackensack, 46-6, in a Northern New Jersey Interscholastic League contest. It was the 19th straight game without a setback for the defending league champion.

Apartments equivalent to private mountaintop homes are being offered in mid-Manhattan. They are four-bedroom suites, with 2,406 square feet of floor space, on the 28th through the 47th floors of a building that when completed will be the tallest apartment house in New York City.

Mrs. Zina McCarthy Hodges, wife of George H. Hodges, manager of the marine department of the Babcock Wilcox Company, manufacturers of steam generating plants, died Friday in her home at 530 East 72d Street. Her age was 64.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The Patent Office is tackling the problem of protection for computer programs, which control an increasing share of the operations in today's industry and business.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 (UPI) Ron Willis, a rookie, retired Ron Santo and Ernie Banks with the bases loaded in the ninth inning today to preserve Bob Gibson's 21st victory and give the St. Louis Cards a 4-3 triumph over the Chicago Cubs.

The metronomic regularity with which organized labor lines up behind Democratic candidates for national, state and local office makes the neutrality of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. in the New York gubernatorial campaign a noteworthy political event.

GREENVILLE, Del., Oct. 1 Miss Mercer Logan Wellford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Carter Wellford of Wilmington, was married this afternoon to Peter Drayton O'Hara, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sydney O'Hara of Old Lyme, Conn.

October has so many virtues one hardly knows where to begin. The woodland color is spectacular, but it really is only the backdrop, the setting which enhances blue skies, widening horizons, crisp nights, mild days and the whole satisfaction of ripeness and achievement. Even Indian summer, a specialty of October's weather, is a kind of seasonal exultation.

SENATOR Robert F. Kennedy is a television drop out. He tried watching it a few times and found it boring. His children are getting bored with it, or so he thinks. But the New York Democrat also thinks television is a great medium for politicians, especially Democrats. Without it, he believes, he could not have been elected in 1964.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y. Oct. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Graham have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Irene Adelaide Graham, to Vincent Edward Gallagher. He is the son of Mrs. Andrew J. Gallagher of Rumson, N.J., and the late Mr. Gallagher.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries set new records for operating revenues and net income in the three-month and 12-month periods ended Aug. 31.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 The New Left movement in California opened a two-day conference today with exhortations for voters to boycott both Gov. Edmund G. Brown, Democrat, and his Republican challenger, Ronald Reagan, in the November election, terming them "too far to the right."

CAIRO, Oct. 1 Egypt's most influential newspaper printed today accusations that Jordan and Saudi Arabia, under direction of the Central Intelligence Agency, were mounting a plot to overthrow Syria's leftist government and replace it with a pro-Western regime.
Federal mediators met with union and management negotiators here yesterday in an effort to avert a strike by 125,000 employes of the General Electric Company threatened for midnight tonight.

ATLANTA, Oct. 1 (UPI) Stokely Carmichael, a civil rights leader, admitted in Federal court today that he had been present during a riot in Atlanta on Sept 6, but he denied he had done anything to start the violence.

ATHENS, Oct. 1 Prof. Andreas Papandreou, 47-year-old son of former Premier George Papandreou, was accused at a court-martial today of having been a political leader of Aspida, a group of army officers who allegedly plotted to seize political power in Greece.
Governor Rockefeller ordered an immediate investigation yesterday into conditions in New York City's municipal hospitals.
Heating engineers have developed a home heating system that may also be used to heat a backyard swimming pool, making it possible to use the pool from early spring to late fall.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 1 Rich Szaro scored four touchdowns and converted twice to lead St. Francis Prep to victory over Archbishop Stepinac, 26-12, today in the first televised high school game of the season. It was also the opening contest of the Catholic High Schools Football League.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Oct. 1 (UPI) Chi Chi Rodriguez of Puerto Rico fired a 67 today to take the third-round lead in the $100,000 Canadian open with a five-under-par 208.

A joint mortgage-lending program to help ease the scarcity of money for home buyers, and thus to help solve the problems of the people who supply the materials for the houses, has been suggested by a leader of the industry.

WINNIPEG, Man., Oct. 1 (AP) The Pan-American Sports Organization has rejected proposals that trapshooting and canoeing be included as official competitions at the Pan-American Games here July 22-Aug. 7, 1967.
AMES, Iowa, Oct. 1 (AP) A home-made mine exploded today on the 46-yard line of Clyde Williams Field about three hours before kickoff time for the Nebraska-Iowa State football game.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1 By sweeping today's double-header, 5-4 behind Juan Marischal, and 2-0 on Bob Bolin's onehitter, the San Francisco Giants eliminated the Pittsburgh Pirates from the National League pennant race and kept their own slim chance alive.

Miss Judith Ann Small of New York and David John Nash of London and New York were married here yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Warner of 2 Sutton Place South. Mrs. Wagner is the bride's godmother. Judge Justine Wise Polier of the Family Court of the State of New York performed the ceremony.
Soviet planners have decided on a substantial increase in the capacity of their inland waterway system by 1970 within the framework of their current fiveyear plan.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 1 Nine Republican members of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors, insisting on quick action on a reapportionment plan, appealed today far special daily meetings until one or more plans can be approved.
Representatives chosen by 62,206 of central Harlem's poor in street-corner "people's elections" held their first meeting yesterday.
Walt Alston, the quiet-spoken manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, is being discovered again.
The Coast Guard Auxiliary is offering free public boating courses at a number of sites in New York and New Jersey.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1 The housing situation in the developing countries is going from bad to worse and can be improved only through the development of a dynamic and energetic policy, with the United Nations taking a greater role in leadership.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 1 Miss Karen Vera Fogg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Edgecombe Fogg, was married this evening to Richard H. Saudek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Saudek of Bronxville, N.Y.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1 (UPI) Bobby Leo, a Harvard halfback, raced for three touchdowns today as the Crimson crushed Tufts University, 45-0.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1 A South Vietnamese Air Force fighter-bomber that failed to pull out of a barrelToll during a Vietnamese Boy Scout air show today crashed in the heart of the heavily populated Tansonnhut Airport.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The world took another step this week toward eventual creation of a new international money to supplement gold. The occasion was the annual meeting of the 105 members of the International Monetary Fund. Ironically, while there was some progress, at least procedural, toward a new international money, a number of important nations at the meeting emphasized their belief that this was not now an urgent problem.
BOSTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) A 23-year-old woman who had been treated with a fertility hormone gave birth tonight to septuplets. All seven died within minutes of their births.

Willie Shoemaker had another assignment yesterday besides his participation in the Woodward. The world's leading money-winning rider made the presentation of the Ralph Lowe award for sportsmanship to Raymond R. Guest, the United States Ambassador to Ireland, at a buffet luncheon held in the trustees room at Aqueduct at noon. The trophy was provided by Shoemaker, too, at his own request.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 1 Syracuse rallied to turn back Maryland, 28-7, in a football victory that was especially significant for Floyd Little, halfback, Jim Del Gaizo, sophomore quarterback, and Coach Sen Schwartzwalder.
Consumers are getting a break as a result of a relatively new trend in the beer industry.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Oct. 1 The Tri Club's annual Last Chance Regatta was held in a rugged northeast storm on Long Island Sound today with H. Strauss's Doki, Dr. H.E. Wood's Woodwind and Charles Hazard's Yankee winning the division prizes.
MONTREAL, Oct, 2 The Ladies' Morning Musical meets on Thursday afternoon, the hemlines on women "of a certain age" cover the knee, and it is rare indeed for guests to be taken out to dine.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 Ronald Reagan is winning promising notices on a tryout run for the biggest role of his career Governor of California. He may even wind up a hit.

IF a homeowner knew that his underground oil tank had developed a steady leak he would most like ly take immediate steps to have the necessary repairs made and thus cut off the needless waste of expensive fuel oil. Yet this same homeowner may accept an even greater loss of fuel by allowing heat from inside his house to be steadily dissipated to the outside.
What would peace in Vietnam a sudden, dramatic ceasefire within the next few months mean for the stock market?
STORRS, Conn., Oct. 1 (UPI) The University of Vermont held off a second-half rally by the University of Connecticut and gained its second victory of the season, 14-10.

ALTHOUGH most gardeners welcome the idea for growing hardy plants that will flour ish for years without any care, they should think twice before giving room in the border to certain herbaceous perennials and vines that are said to "grow and flourish almost anywhere."
With taxes and costs so high, Gerald Carter of Walnut Creek, Calif., will not remodel his barbershop after all.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 A scientific study of Negro attitudes shows that Negroes feel more friendly toward Jews than toward other whites, the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith reported today.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 7 The Union College football team played to a 7-7 deadlock today against Kings Point. Joe James, the Garnet sophomore fullback, tallied on an 18-yard sprint off left tackle in the second quarter on the rain-soaked field. The run was one of 26 rushes for James, who ran a total of 68 yards. Frank Pizzica's conversion gave Union a 7-0 half-time lead.

WASHINGTON, Oct.1 For reasons that have long been understood by economists and financiers but which always seem to hit the general public with surprise the housing industry has a tendency to be depressed just at the time when other things are booming.
The mile-long center section of the 7.4-mile San Mateo-Hayward Bridge being built over South San Francisco Bay is expected to have a pronounced effect on long-span bridge building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Representative Adam Clayton Powell's airline credit card, payable with Federal funds, has been canceled by the House Administration Committee, a member of that group said today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 Among the 61 women delegates registered so far for the General Assembly session, Mrs. Halima Warzazi of Morocco has attracted much attention.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 1 At 1 P.M. today, Heinz Arntz finished plalying his favorite march, "Alte Kameraden," sat back on his piano stool at the Long Island Fair and said: "I think I'll play concerts now."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 1 Miss Ann Carroll Cullom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Cullom, was married this afternoon to Robert Powell Burwell. He is the son of Mrs. John Armistead Burweil of Middleburg, Va., and the late Mr. Burwell.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 1 (UPI) Dr. Carl A. Coppolino will be arraigned in New Jersey Wednesday on a first-degree murder indictment in the 1963 death of William E. Farber, a retired lieutenant colonel in the Army.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 1 In grasping for the public pulse, the challengers in Suffolk's two Congressional Districts are questioning the price of bacon and olives as often as the costliness of the Vietnamese war.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 1 (AP) Dan Rogers, a freshman kicked three consecutive field goals to give Montclair State a 9-6 victory today over Ithaca College.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The official proposals for a peace in Vietnam have had a cool reception in the world, not because they are unfair or unrealistic, but simply because they are not believed.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1 (AP) Harbor View Farm's Swinging Mood won the $28,325 Atlantic City Handicap by five lengths today under a welljudged ride by Earlie Fires. The mile-and-one-eighth grass test was run over a course that was officially listed as sloppy and soft and the race was contested in the rain.
Students will be asked to design the uniforms American athletes will wear at the 1968 Olympics, the United States Olympic Apparel Committee has announced.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Joseph Evers of Brooklyn Heights and Watch Hill, R.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Eulalie Evers, to Robert Oscar Carlson, son of Mrs. Oscar E. Carlson of Erie, Pa., and the late Mr. Carlson.

THE name of Andre Masson is unlikely to mean much to young painters nowadays, at least out side his native France. Yet 20 years ago Masson's work, and the ideas that animated it, counted for a good deal.

IT would be not unnatural, upon seeing the title of this volume conjoined with the name of Sir Maurice Bowra, to suppose it his biography, for he is by now himself one of the more prominent landmarks in the field of Greek literature. The author or editor of a decade of volumes concerned with Classical studies, he embodies at once an Alexandrian learning and an Athenian spaciousness of perspective.

Hans Ewald Heller, music director of Hearst Metrotone News, died yesterday at the Parkway Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 72 years old and lived at 76-36 113th Street in Forest Hills.

A modern-day Betsy Ross, named Dorothy Gillespie, figured last week that she had cut, snipped, shaped and painted about 3,500 stars of mylar, aluminum, plastic and sundry materials for her onewoman show devoted to representations of the American flag.

A net estate of $1,067,645 was left by Lucretia Bori, the lyric soprano who died in 1960 at the age of 71, according to an estate appraisal filed Friday in Surrogate Court.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Oct. 1 The Boston Celtics scored their second exhibition victory over the New York Knicks tonight, 108-104, in the I.B.M. field house. The victory left the National Basketball Association defending champions with a 2-2 won-lost preseason mark, while the loss was the fifth in five tries for the Knicks.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 1 The Yugoslav Communist Central Committee is scheduled to meet Tuesday to begin a radical reorganization of the leading party bodies.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 1--A 17-year-old boy was charged with first-degree murder here today in the fatal stabbing of an 84-year-old woman to whom he daily delivered papers.

ROME, Oct. 1 The trick in Rome is to go down to the old Roman, Forum and conjure up Great Caesar's Ghost. This is done by standing in front of the Temple of Jupiter and exercising a powerful sense of history.
NEWMARKET, England, Oct 1 (AP) Persian Lancer held off a challenge from C.E.D. today and won the Cesarewitch Stakes and first money of $16,856.
Club football, a testament to undergraduate exuberance, goes big-time this year as teams from 10 local colleges start their seasons.
St. Mark's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Gillian Margaret Mailey to Philip Norman Ross Jr.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 1 (AP) Charles O. Finley, the owner of the Kansas City Athletics, expressed his gratification today over his team clinching seventh place in the American League and announced he was giving the team's manager, Alvin Dark, a raise. Dark originally had signed a two-year contract for the 1966 and 1967 seasons at $35,000 a year.
Miss Suzanne Katherine Foley and John Strawbridge 3d plan to be married in December.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 1 (AP) Middlesex County will delete from future primary election forms a pledge by the voter to support his party's nominees in the general election.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 1 Army hit with the fury it usually reserves for Navy today and, in 60 minutes of boiling action, enlivened further by fumbles, interceptions and some almost fantastic punting, confounded favored Penn State in a solidly earned 11-0 triumph.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 1 The Government is preparing legislation designed to end the legal anomalies that still differentiate between black Africans and people of European and Asian origin.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1 Small armed teams of former Vietcong guerrillas are being employed increasingly by the South Vietnamese Government in an unorthodox campaign to increase defections from enemy ranks.

WE have seen our favorite series detectives pass love, marriage, fatherhood and many other milestones of life; but John Creasey is, it seems to me, attempting something unprecedented in confronting Chief Superintendent Roger ("Handsome") West with the nervous and emotional problems of the man who is nearing his 50th birthday (is milestone which both Creasey and I passed within fairly recent memory).

AUTUMN'S brightest memories can be preserved and enjoyed all winter long in bottled bouquets. Displayed inside clear containers, the dried fall arrangements have a lifelike, luminous glow. Little material is needed and the arrangement will last indefinitely without becoming an unsightly dust-catcher.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Americans for Democratic Action, in an anlysis of Congressional votes, said today that a "narrow majority" continued to support moderate social advances but did not go far enough.

ATHENS The long political siesta that Greece has been experiencing for more than a year was probably ended this weekend by publication of an official report on political conspiracy in the army. The army, which is supposed to stay clear of politics, is one of the few real power factors here and is generally regarded as a stanch supporter of the crown.
Governor Rockefeller, who only a couple of weeks ago was calling himself the underdog in his campaign for re-election, acknowledged yesterday that he seemed to be coming up fast.

Last month President Johnson directed the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to begin a "major study" of rising medical costs. Studies by the Labor Department have shown that medical costs have been rising faster than the total costs of living.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 1 (AP) Danny Talbott, a quarterback, directed North Caro lina to two touchdowns on short drives following fumble recoveries and scored once himself today in leading the Tar Heels to a 21-7 upset victory over Michigan.

A new shuttle bus service from New Jersey and the usual special train from Westchester will be provided today for those attending the New York Giants' football game at Yankee Stadium. The purpose in both cases is to ease automobile traffic, around the stadium.

PAGO PAGO, American Samoa The Chinese are notorious for their ethnocentricity, but theirs is a pale imitation of that harbored by the Samoans. The traditional belief here is that the world, as originally created by the Samoans' supreme diety, Tagoloa Lagi, consisted only of their own lovely South Sea archipelago and the neighboring, somewhat lesser islands known as Tonga and Fiji.

The Cleveland Browns, poised, skilled, seasoned and out to defend their Eastern championship, will be formidable opponents today for the New York Giants, young, confused and injured, as the National Football League season opens at Yankee Stadium. Because all tickets were sold long ago to a loyal clientele, the stadium will be filled to its football capacity of 64,000.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 30 The Beirut newspaper Al-Hayat reported today that King Faisal of Saudi Arabia had strongly criticized the Lebanese Government for slowness in prosecuting the men accused of assassinating Kamel Mrowa. the publication's conservative publisher, Mr. Mrowa was slain here last May.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y. Oct. 1 Paul B. Zuber has been retained by 50 white and Negro parents here to start legal proceedings to spur integration of the public schools.

A fund of $173.4-million will be needed to introduce containerized operation to the Japanese merchant fleet on routes to the United States, according to a report by Japan's Ministry of Transport, made available yesterday.

In a stunning about-face, the San Francisco Giants yesterday ended the Pittsburgh Pirates' pennant hopes by sweeping a double-header. The twin triumphs assured the Los Angeles Dodgers, whose game against the Philadelphia Phils was rained out, of a tie for the National League pennant.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 The Los Angeles Dodgers were rained out of their game with the Philadelphia Phillies tonight after spending a rainy afternoon the way millions of other Americans did: Watching on television as the San Francisco Giants eliminated the Pittsburgh Pirates from the National League pennant race.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 1 Cornell's well-rounded attack, compared with a limited one offered by Colgate, made the big difference today as the Ithacans posted a 15-to-14 triumph over the Red Raiders before 20,000 fans at Schoellkopf Field.

COLOGNE, Germany The Photokina World's Fair of Photography that opened here yesterday is by far the largest and most important regular photographic event of its kind in the world. A 19 per cent increase in display space since the last Photokina, held in 1963, makes this year's show the industry's biggest trade exhibition ever.
ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 1 The Orlando Panthers squelched the surging Brooklyn Dodgers' hopes for an upset tonight and gained a 31-16 victory in a Continental Football League game at the Tangerine Bowl.
GREENLAWN, L. I., Oct. 1--The Suffolk County Kennel Club dog show's field of 989 braved a daylong rain and cold, with the 2-year-old Irish setter, Ch. Webline Rio Hondo, emerging victorious.

The Puerto Rican Economic Development Administration has leased the top six floors and additional space on the ground floor of an 11story office tower nearing completion in San Juan.

To be free ... to make every day Saturday night, to climb impossible mountains, to take a trolley car to the moon, to deflate stuffed shirts.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 1 Amherst College used a bruising ground attack on a rainswept field today to score an easy 48-7 triumph over American International College in Springfield.

AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Oct. 1 Dick Hall kicked three field goals, one from 48 yards, and Sonny Litz passed for a touchdown as the Air Force Academy upset Navy, 15-7, today for their first interservice victory over the middies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The White House has apparently left up to Congress the fate of another attempts to give home rule to 800,000 citizens of the District of Columbia, 63 per cent of them Negroes.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Oct. 1 Patrick J. Feeney of 78 Henshaw Avenue, president of the General-Feeney Sales Corporation of Newark, a shoe material concern, died Thursday of a heart attack while on a business trip in Hershey, Pa. His age was 49.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 At the suggestion of a Philippine legislator, the "Far East" division of the Peace Corps has changed its title to "East Asia and Pacific Region."
Fifty miles from New York City, in the clear air of Sterling Forest near the town of Tuxedo, laboratory mice, hamsters and donkeys are breathing some of the foulest pollutants known to man.

RIO DE JANIERO, Oct. 1 The Brazilian Government flew Senators and Deputies to Brasilia today for the election of Marshal of the Army Artur Costa a Silva as President on Monday. The day has been declared a national holiday.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 1 The Government has banned the film production "The Ten Commandments," produced by the late Cecil B. DeMille. The move was viewed here as a concession to the country's orthodox Moslem elements.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) Justice William O. Douglas, who aroused Congressional criticism when he married for the fourth time last summer, has been dropped from the Green Book that makes up Washington's social register. The social list was published this weekend.

A leading Federal appeals judge warned yesterday that the recent landmark ruling on confessions by the United States Supreme Court might turn out to be a "pious fraud" unless suspects got lawyers in the police station.
BUFFALO, Oct. 1 (UPI) A research program to obtain better understanding of powersteering systems on cars has been announced by Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory.

TIKAL, Guatemala A pick-up truck carry ing vacationisits on the track of the ancient Mayas swings out of the Guatemalan rain forest and into the center of Tikal, a vast ceremonial city built up over 1,100 years by Indians long since departed.
HONG KONG, Oct. 1 (AP) A Chinese author, Lao She, killed himself in Peking this week because of harassment by the Red Guards, the Hong Kong Start reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 Despite State Department objections, the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee published classified documents today on departmental security procedures in a 1962 case.

A 35-story apartment building that will offer 591 suites, 90 per cent of which will be one-bedroom or studio units designed for business couples or single executives, is being erected at 300 East 40th Street by Rose Associates.

WELLESLEY, Mass. Oct. 1 Miss Ann Chapman Puffer and John Lewis McGoldrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Leslie McGoldrick of Levittown, Pa., were married this afternoon, The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Puffer Jr.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Oct. 1 Miss Tracey Ann Haag, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Edgar Haag Jr., was married at noon today to Charles Eneu McCarthy 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. McCarthy Jr. of Columbia.
The following nonprofessional choruses and orchestras in New York and the metropolitan area will be holding auditions this week for new members:

THERE should be little doubt at this point that Elizabeth Taylor is convinced that the family that plays together, stays together. Miss Taylor, who has made no fewer than four feature films with her husband, Richard Burton, again will team with him in "The Comedians," the drama Graham Greene is adapting from his own best-selling novel, which Peter Glenville will produce and direct for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, starting in December.
SPRING GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 1 Mr. and Mrs. William Luskin have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Luskin, to Arthur Lawrence Flink, son of Mrs. Michael Mushkat of the Bronx.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 28 Sweat-soaked Marine Corps riflemen agree with Army planners in Saigon that the enemy's jungle cover must be removed to hamper the North Vietnamese Army's efforts to push south from the demilitarized zone, especially when the northeast monsoon begins next month.

ON Broadway or off, Norman Mailer wants in. The novelist, whose latest book is "Can nibals and Christians," has joined Leo Garen and James Walsh for the sponsorship of "The Deer Park," his adaptation of his much discussed novel of the same name.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 1 Miss Jill Warren Edwards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Newton Edwards was married this afternoon to Frederick Bittner Jr. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bittner of Poughkeepsie, N.Y.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 Twelve Quakers tried unsuccessfully today to mail money and medical supplies to North Vietnam by way of Canada.

Early Nantucketers were said to have salt water in their veins and whale oil in their joints. They had to have something to survive on that 15-by-3-mile sandbank 30 miles off the Massachusetts coast. The Indians called the island, which was settled in 1659 by mainlanders escaping the oppressions of Puritanism, "Natocket" or "At the Land Far Out at Sea."

HISTORY will be kinder to Harold Macmillan than his contempo raries were. It will not judge him as Supermac, Mac the Knife or Mac the Bookie, the tired genie of spurious good times. It will see him as the Honest Broker between the old world and the new.
HONG KONG, Oct. 1 A militant nation hostile to the outside world this was Communist China today on the 17th anniversary of its founding.

Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor told a conference of business and labor executives last week that an experiment by the Federal Government in hiring mentally retarded persons has proved that they make very satisfactory workers.
The airlines have told Congress that they need communication satellites for the continued safety of air travel with the faster jet planes of the future.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 Miss Edith Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walker Smith of Chicago, was married this evening to Raymond Walter Apple Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Apple of Akron, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. Lester Lewis, assisted by the Rev. David Gerberding of Minneapolis, performed the ceremony in All Souls Unitarian Church here.

HARTFORD, Oct. 1 In their first two campaign appearances together, Gov. John N. Dempsey and Clayton Gengras illustrated this week their sharply different approaches to Connecticut's gubernatorial race.
WATERVILLE, Me., Oct. 1 (UPI)--Colby College today named Otis Chandler, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, its 15th Elijah Parish Lovejoy Fellow.
American religious leaders are showing a new interest in finding ways to teach "about" religion in the public schools.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 1 (UPI) Jerry Bradley returned a punt 76 yards for a touchdown today in the fourth period to help California to a 30-15 victory over Pittsburgh. The loss was the third straight for the Panthers.
The high cost of money is continuing to have its effect on the retail industry as stores from coast to coast ponder the question: To anticipate or not to anticipate.
The president of one of the nation's most successful and diversified companies got his career off to an auspicious start through an unsolicited letter to a company president.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1 Princeton eked out its 16th consecutive victory today over Columbia, but the Lions gave the favored wearers of the orange and the black the scare of their lives before succumbing, 14 to 12.
A special study group has recommended to Mayor Lindsay that New York build 450,000 apartments in the next 10 years and reorganize its housing and planning operations under a single administrator.

WESTBURY, the "Show of Distinction," has joined the ever-increasing list of fixtures that have limited their entries. Because of space limitations at Phipps Polo Field, Post Avenue and Jericho Turnpike, Old Westbury, L.I., the 44th annual event today has been held to 1,500 dogs.
HARRISON, N.Y., Oct. 1 The Willow Ridge Country Club here will become a town club for all the 21,000 Harrison residents if plans of a citizens committee succeed.
HARTFORD, Oct. 1 Trinity College defeated Bates today, 24-8, under rainy skies at Trinity Field.
GENEVA, N. Y., Oct. 1 (AP)--St. Lawrence University crushed Hobart College, 42-6, today in Boswell Bowl. The Larries led, 35-0, at half time.
NUTLEY, N.J., Oct. 1 Charley Hinton raced 75 yards with a punt to give East Orange its second victory of the season, a 7-2 victory over Nutley at rainy Oval Park today.

YONKERS, Oct. 1 (AP) Danny Row Gil, barred from the betting in the 19,983 New York Sires Stake for 4-year-old pacers, finished first, 8 lengths ahead of Runnymede Chuck before 17,530 at Yorkers Raceway tonight. The time for the mile was 2:07 3-5 over a sloppy track.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1--Tugboat workers went on strike in the Port of Philadelphia early today.

LEONIDAS MATSOUKAS is a Homeric hero behind on his rent in a Chicago slum. As the oracle of the Pindar SuperCounseling Clinic, he dispenses cut-rate guidance on love, masturbation and real-estate. A lion of the Greek resistance in World War II, he has come to the New World and made his name as a Hellenic wrestling champion and a pillar of the gambling room behind the Minoan Music Shop.

Families planning to move into the New York area have long complained that there is no central place to obtain information about the many and varied suburban "bedroom" communities that surround the city.
The Conservative party candidates for Governor and Lieutenant Governor visited Queens on a handshaking and walking tour yesterday, undaunted by rain, a chill wind and sparse crowds on the streets.

ALMOST everyone has a member of the squirrel family for a neighbor. Even in the city the nearest park probably harbors a family of these engaging little mammals. They are so irrepressible they can get along almost anywhere.

TOKYO, Oct. 1 (AP) India took a 2-1 lead over Japan in the Davis Cup interzone tennis matches today when Ramanathan Krishnan and Premjit Lall defeated Koji Wanatabe and Osamu Ishiguro in doubles, 6-2, 6-3, 6-3.
Alfred J. Ball of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, who retired in 1952 as foreign freight traffic manager of the Pennsylvania Railroad, died yesterday in Chestnut Hill Hospital. He was 84 years old.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 1 Several thousand Israelis will make a hot and dusty pilgrimage to the desert kibbutz of Sde Boker to honor the 80th birthday tomorrow of the father of Israel, David Ben Gurion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) President Johnson issued a proclamation today setting Oct. 19 as a national day of prayer. Mr. Johnson observed that the nation already was praying for an end to the war in Vietnam.
HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 1 Stevens Institute of Technology has five members of the faculty, Dr. Preston R. Clement, Dean of the faculty, announced this week.
Dr. and Mrs. Oscar Shea Stern have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Stern, to State Senator Harrison J. Goldin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry Goldin of the Bronx.
BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 1 (UPI) Colorado stopped Kansas State's runners, Ossie Cain and Cornelius Davis, and went on to score a 10-0 victory in the Big Eight conference opener for both teams.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 Miss Celeste Christine Gleeson daughter of Gerald Anthony Gleeson, Judge of the Court of Common Pleas 7, and Mrs. Gleeson, was married today to Dr. Donelson Reeve Manley of Philadelphia. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Vincent Manley of North Little Rock, Ark.
No one is more concerned about the search for a site for a fourth metropolitan area jetport than the United States Customs Bureau staff at Kennedy International Airport.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1 The United Nations is staking out a claim to become the world's largest mineral prospector a discoverer of gold and copper, iron and coal, lead and zinc.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1 (UPI) Kentucky turned a blocked field-goal attempt and a fumble recovery into touchdowns tonight in defeating Auburn, 17-7, in a Southeastern Conference game.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Oct. 1 Oklahoma, intent on its state fair, university football teams and the first cold snap of the fall, barely took time out this week to notice a struggle by Democrats to win back control of its state government.
West Eighth Street in Greenwich Village, the area's "Main Street" and principal shopping district, is getting its first completely new commercial building in many years.
CHICAGO; Oct. 1 (AP) Hobeau Farm's Handsome Boy, ridden by Leroy Moyers, led most of the way today as he won the $62,250 Diamond Jubilee Stakes before 21,899 at Hawthorne.

THE British failure at the beginning of World War II was exceedingly strange. British forces fought with their characteristic determination. The bulk of the military innovations of the war were of British origin radar, jet aircraft, tanks, special-purpose tanks, aircraft carriers, mulberries (portable docks), operations research and the blitzkrieg were all products of British genius.
MOSCOW, Oct. 1 (AP) The Soviet Government replied today to criticism of its hospitals by an American doctor, charging that medical care in the United States was expensive and of poor quality.

PRESIDENT JOHNSON, signing into law on Sept. 9 the new Highway and Traffic Safety Acts of 1966, said: "The automobile industry has been one of our nation's most dynamic and inventive industries. I hope and I believe that its skill and imagination will be able to build in more safety ..."
EXETER, N.H., Oct. 1 Exeter Academy used a fast backfield and an alert defense today to open its home football season with a 40-6 victory over Choate School of Wallingford, Conn.
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 1 (AP) Hofstra scored a touchdown and a field goal the first two times it had the ball, then held on to defeat Lafayette, 9-6, in a Middle Atlantic Conference football game today.
A major new community on a 688-house tract was opened last week with a display, of six model homes by Levitt Sons in Manalapan Township, N.J.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 1 Carlos Marcello, one of 13 alleged underworld leaders seized in a New York City restaurant on Sept. 22, was arrested at his home here today and charged with assaulting an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
TOKYO, Oct. 1--In 20 years according to an official report published today, ordinary Japanese will be living the same abundant life that they believed most Americans to be enjoying now.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y. Oct. 1 Miss Sybil Loughran Rhoads, daughter of Mr. and Mr. Elbert L. Rhoads, was married this afternoon to Joseph Falcone Jr., son of Mrs. Falcone of Bethlehem, Pa., and the late Mr. Falcone.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 1 (UPI) A system demonstrated at Danbury Airport may allow greater air traffic in and out of congested areas where land for runway space is scarce.

PARIS, Oct. 1 The French Government, embarrassed by the riots in French Somaliland during President de Gaulle's visit there six weeks ago, is searching for a formula to keep the East African territory French while offering it independence.

BRASILIA, Oct. 1 A synthetic-rubber plant built with United States aid and inaugurated as "the greatest industrial venture of Brazil's northeast region" was awarded a $4-million dollar subsidy today to keep from closing.

Salman Yefroiken, educational director of the 85 Jewish secular schools operated by the Workmen's Circle, died of a heart attack yesterday while reading a report to the annual meeting of the circle's national executive committee. He was 71 years old and lived at 212 East Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The Supreme Court convenes tomorrow for the ceremonial opening of its 1966 term, amid indications that the pendulum is swinging back from the high point of its liberalizing impact on American life.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., the Liberal party candidate for Governor, promised yesterday to draft a "state social bill of rights" to update New York's welfare programs if he is elected.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 1 In the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church this afternoon, Miss Patricia Lloyd Bond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Bond, was married to Ronald Allen Kovas, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Allen Kovas of Glencoe, Ill. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. David Watermulder and a reception was held at the Merion Cricket Club.

MOSCOW, Idaho, Oct. 1 (UPI) Ray McDonald, an allAmerica fullback, thrilled a Homecoming Day crowd of 12,500 by scoring three touchdowns today as the University of Idaho routed the University of Pacific, 28-7.
Performance plans and schedules for an opera company in Flushing and symphony orchestras in Huntington, L. I., and the Hudson Valley were announced last week for the 1966-67 season.

Mrs. Ethel Kahn Kelly, of 256 East 206th Street, the Bronx, died yesterday of a heart attack at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Barbara Hostomsky in Suffern, N.Y. She was 65 years old and was the widow of John J. Kelly, a warehouse salesman.
Mayor Lindsay told the Board of Education yesterday that he had no intention of staying out of city school affairs.

CHARLES S. MURPHY, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, in an address before the Wings Club is New York recently, gently reminded the domestic trunk airlines that the C.A.B. believes the industry can continue on a course "of providing a constantly improving product for the public at lower prices."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--A special panel of the American Bar Association proposed today drastic new restrictions on the release and publication of information about persons accused of crimes.
MOSCOW, Oct. 1 Icy and minimal protocol marked the Kremlin's recognition today of the 17th annual celebration of Communist China's national day.

A leading apparel producer will advise some 500 specialtystore customers around the country in a few weeks that he can no longer afford to sell them merchandise. The reason: His sales to each of these stores have been less than $1,000 a year and although their combined volume is avout $500,000, the business is not profitable.

Rabbi Judah Nadich, spiritual leader of the Park Avenue Synagogue, and Mrs. Nadich of 993 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leah Nessa Nadich, to Lawrence Meyers. His parents are Mr. and Mrs, Abraham Meyers of Buffalo.

WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 1 The eighth annual Grand Prix of the United States, which is the seventh race of the season for the road-racing championship of the world, will be run here tomorrow over a 2.3 mile course. The schedule calls for 54 laps or 248 miles starting at 2 P.M.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 1 The Rev. John A. Boland, the newly appointed dean of students at St. Peter's College of Jersey City, is spending the fall semester at Rutgers University, preparing for the post.
The New York County Democratic organization urged yesterday that the minimum voting age in the state be lowered from 21 to 18.

STOCKHOLM. IN the gloom of this rainy fall evening, the ponderous five-story apartment building has a special air of patrician reserve, as if not quite part of the neon-glittering city around the corner. A sign is the lobby announces that it is indeed patrician enough to house the embassy of the Socialist People's Republic of Algeria.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 1 Walter Gubelmann's Windigo won the annual White Trophy race conducted by the Sewanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club on Long Island Sound today.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 A proposed eight-mile strip of interstate highway has become the issue in a bitter controversy here.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 At noon today a French military detachment took over from a British unit the elaborate security ritual of the Spandau four-power prison to guard Rudolf Hess, last Nazi prisoner of the World War II Allies.
A member of the Federal Maritime Commission last week called for a uniform accounting system by ocean carriers, so their freight rates could be measured against their costs of doing business.
Exhibiting championship class through every sloppy step of the 1 -mile Woodward Stakes, Ogden Phipps's mighty 3-yearold, Buckpasser, recorded his 10th straight triumph at Aqueduct yesterday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1 "Our people are more naturally friends than enemies," President Johnson told the Soviet public this week through the pages of the U.S. Governments magazine Amerika. "We have more in common than we sometimes realize."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Government has lost none of its vital interest in basic medical and biological research John W. Gardner, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today.
FORT WORTH, Oct. 1 (UPI) Twelve semifinalists were named today in the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition.
Interest rates shot up throughout most of July, August and September. Recently, however, they have backed down, touching off a hot debate over the course they will take in the fourth quarter.

"Velikovsky is right!" his supporters are saying with renewed conviction. They argue that recent discoveries in space have demonstrated, at the least, that his cataclysmic concept of the world's history must be taken seriously. Among these discoveries, foreshadowed, they say, by the writings of Dr. Immanuel Velikovsky, are the Van Allen radiation belts around the earth, the "solar wind," the radio emissions of Jupiter and the high temperature of Venus.

A series of noon record concerts will begin Tuesday at the Donnell Library Center of the New York Public Library, 20 West 53d Street. The first concert will include selections from Handel's opera "Xerxes." The series will be held on alternate Tuesdays, from noon to 2 P.M.
Two men were shot and killed by law enforcement officers in separate incidents in Brooklyn yesterday.

WHEN it was announced last February that David Nadien, 40, would succeed John Corigliano, 65, as concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic this season, a few eyebrows went up in those odd corners of the world of music where esthetic guilt-by-association is still a fact maybe even a way of life.
NEWARK, Oct. 1 The New Jersey A.F.L.-C.I.O. took a neutral stand today in the coming election for United States Senator.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 The executive council of the American Federation of Teachers protested today an attack by Representative L. Mendel Rivers, Democrat of South Carolina, on the United States Commissioner of Education, Harold Howe 2d.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 1 Misery came to the Dartmouth football team today on a perfectly miserable afternoon. Its 11-game winning streak, the longest of any major college in the nation, ended when Holy Cross, an 11-point underdog, scored a 7-6 victory.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1 The Vietcong failed notably in its attempt to disrupt the South Vietnamese national election on Sept. 11, but some knowledgeable observers believe the guerrillas now mean to try to influence the coming Congressional election in the United States.

VICTORIA OCAMPO of Buenos Aires, with her distinguished literary magazine called SUR and her publishing house of the same name, has for 35 years been recognized as the first lady of the SpanishAmerican literary scene. Other magazines have risen and fallen, other publishing houses have bulkier lists. But Victoria's fame, still undisputed if not uncriticized, lies in the quality of her taste and the breadth of her cultural interests.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) Communications satellites will make live television coverage from the battlefields of Vietnam a technical possibility within a year, Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Company said today.
