Anthony F. Shannon, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter, was appointed director of Public Information for the Departments of Health and Hospitals last week.

HANDEL'S "Julius Caesar" was introduced last Tuesday by the New York City Opera Company, and it sent me back to the "Spectator" papers which, alas, I had not read for some years. Addison had a great deal to say about Italian opera in general and Handel in particular.

THE most exotic product ever turned out by St. Cyr, the starchy French military school founded by Napoleon, is not a warrior but a furrier a benign, fun-and-culture-loving pelletier named Jacques Kaplan (pronounced Ka-plahn). As director of Georges Kaplan, a Fifth Avenue pelt salon founded by his father, Kaplan fils has come a distance from his World War II days at St. Cyr, where he was trained as an officer in the Free French Army.

Several American ships and aircraft are preparing to speckle the western edge of the Gulf Stream orange, yellow, red and silver this week in an attempt to understand the complexities of its flow pattern.
In the old days, Barney Pressman used to physically pull his customers in off the sidewalk to buy his clothes. Now, he lets his advertising do it.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 1 "Really," a Salisbury businessman said, "it's a holding operation. We cannot go back on independence. As long as sanctions last, we cannot go forward. We cannot do much more than wait, and hope for the best."

Mrs. Carolyn Hicks Dorsett Taggart, the widow of Rush Taggart, a New York lawyer, died of a heart attack yesterday in her home on Sunset Lane in Rye, N.Y. She was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The President's Cabinet soon will be enlarged to 12 members by the addition of Secretary of Transportation. This was assured when the Senate passed an Administration bill Thursday to create a Department of Transportation.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 (AP) An earthquake was felt in the Los Angeles area at 10:12 o'clock tonight, but there were no immediate reports of damage.

Jesse Cleare, a halfback and one of the holdovers from last year's Division II championship team, accounted for five touchdowns yesterday as Jefferson High overwhelming Lincoln, 30-12, at Boys High Field in a Public School Athletic League football game.

At least disk buyers are able now to build excellent libraries of music at roughly half of what it used to cost them, the main reasons being the flowering of discount houses, the repeal of the excise tax, and, more important than either of these, the proliferation of new low-priced labels offering high-priced repertory and performers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) Mrs. Katie Louchheim has been appointed Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Education and Cultural Affairs, the State Department announced today.
EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 1 Terry Hanratty, the sophomore passer, and Jim Seymour, the sophomore receiver, made their second varsity appearance for Notre Dame today and proved they are for real.

One of the towering apartment buildings that cluster growing numbers on the heights of Fort Lee overlooking the Hudson River, the George Washington Bridge and the Manhattan skyline, is a building whose facade is dominated by balconies that were formed in Florida.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 Miss Ellen Jane Lowenthal and Jonathan Lance Goldstein plan to marry in December.

MATTITUCK, L. I., Oct. 1--A 5-year-old boy was killed and his parents and a sister were injured when their station wagon was struck by an eastbound Long Island Rail Road train at the Factory Avenue grade crossing at 11:15 A.M., today.
DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 1 (AP) The Ford Motor Company said today it was replacing the bolts that anchored seat belts in 65,000 1967 passenger cars and 10,000 trucks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 As politicians count the days, it is a long time until November, 1968. Much can happen between now and then, but it still seems possible to say that Lyndon Johnson has fallen into political trouble that is not likely to be entirely swept away by 1968.

THEY say that we should be strong enough not to be too much affected by the sheer physical presence of our surroundings, that we should rise above such base considerations and that we can do so if we are sufficiently developed in the Spiritual Department.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 1 Peter Cooper, sailing the International Class sloop, Mischief, scored a 15-length victory over Cornelius Shields Jr., at the helm of Aileen, on Long Island Sound today in the fifth regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club postseason series.

REPRESENTATIVES of 100 of the world's leading airlines, meeting in Honolulu to set fares for a two-year period beginning next April 1, have encountered such stiff roadblocks on a number of their issues that impasses now seem likely in many areas.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa. Historic Valley Forge State Park, the serenely beautiful Revolution ary War shrine that served as the site of the Continental Army's heroic winter encampment in 1777-78, is a yearround tourist favorite today. And big changes are in the offing for the crowds who flock here in all seasons.

Floyd B. McKissick, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, gave a six-way definition of "black power" last night, and then told a predominantly student audience of 300 in the Loeb Student Center of New York University that "it takes shock to wake this nation up."
THE charity ball season is here again and New York's most popular single men are planning accordingly.

ORONO, Me., Oct. 1 (UPI) George Platter, a reserve quarterback, ran 8 yards for a touchdown and a sophomore center, Dale Scribner, kicked the extra point today to give Maine a 7-6 upset victory over Bucknell.
About 30 men and women stood in the rain for more than an hour opposite United Nations headquarters today in a "silent vigil" for peace in Vietnam.

ROCK SPRINGS, Wyo., Oct. 1 It really wasn't diffi cult getting up at 4 A.M. The evening before, Bob Tynsky, a local desert-mineral expert and sometime hunting guide, said: "I think we'd better get an early start in the morning. We're going to cover a lot of ground, and I'm going to show you country you wouldn't believe exists."

BLUE POINT, L.I., Oct. 1 A Suffolk County detective investigating the murder of a 20year-old bank teller and parttime go-go dancer said today that the victim "had contacts with individuals who may be involved in questionable enterprises."

The businessmen of Jamaica, Queens, have watched their community slip toward the shabby second-best that has become the familiar lot of many of New York's older neighborhoods. But now they are doing something to remedy the situation.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1 (AP) United States B-52 bombers pounded enemy troops in South Vietnam in two raids today in the second day of saturation bombing.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 1 Westchester County was told this week that a modernization of its 18th-century local court system, coupled with a centralized police department, would curb thousands of criminal careers in their early stages.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt. The narrow blacktop road, laid out for the horse-drawn vehicles of another day, still predominates in large parts of Vermont and New Hampshire. The development of the divided highway and Interstate systems has added to the charm of these small roads by drawing off enough cars so that the byways can continue to offer an escape from annoying traffic and roadside commercialism.

Baseball Commissioner William D. Eckert has authorized a tour of New York Met players, headed by Promotion Director Arthur Richman, to Thule Air Force Base in Greenland. The trip will take place shortly after the close of the 1966 baseball season.

MANY enthusiasts of rubber bridge dabble in duplicate play, but then return to their first love. Some dislike the artificialities of tournament scoring, some are irritated by the proliferation of conventions and others miss the fi nancial incentive of the rubher game or the sheer luck introduced by the deal.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 1 (AP) United States assistance was being rushed today to the Barahona Peninsula, 100 miles west of here, ravaged by Hurricane Inez Thursday.

PEKING, Oct. 1 Sovietbloc diplomats walked off the reviewing stand at today's Chinese Communist National Day parade in protest against a speech by Defense Minister Lin Piao charging the Kremlin with plotting with Washington over Vietnam.

IT is the unassailable premise of Dexter Masters's enter taining polemic that the normal relationship between buyers and sellers is all-out war. For two thousand years or so, he observes, sellers have been treating buyers with contempt and buyers have been deserving it.
TRENTON, Oct. 1 Mayor Carmen J. Armenti was married today after receiving permission of the Vatican.

TO many pool owners, winterizing their swim ming pools has assumed new meaning in recent years. With water shortages in many locations, and with the increasing cost of water in others, fewer and fewer pool owners can afford to pull the plug and drain their swimming pools.

RIVER VALE, N.J., Oct. 1 In 1963, Carol Hofmann rode Salem, a 7-year-old brown gelding in the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden. She was so impressed with the horse that she tried to by him from his owner. Eleanora R. Sears.
A policeman was arrested yesterday in his studio apartment in the Riverdale section of the Bronx and charged with possessing heroin and the paraphernalia to operate a majorsize narcotics "factory."

Bill Jackowski, Al Pelekoudas and Mel Steiner of the National League and Nestor Chylak, John Rice and Cal Drummond of the American will make up the umpiring staff for the World Series, Baseball Commissioner William D. Eckert said yesterday.

YEARS ago, when I worked as a public-relations man for General Electric, I was rated by three of my co-workers every six months anonymously. Then I had to go over the comments with my boss, promising to improve. One comment about myself that sticks in my mind for some reason: "No personality." This may be why I am now being sent so many novels about depersonalized people for comment and review.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 For President Johnson, the 1966 political campaign began formally at a partisan rally here last May, at which he recalled Will Rogers' quip, "I am not a member of any organized political party I am a Democrat." Dr. Nachman Bench, the Israeli computer expert whose appointment as deputy city administrator in the Lindsay administration was declared 11legal because he was not a United States citizen, is now working full time for the city.

THE Miranda decision of the Supreme Court takes its name from one of four cases in which the Court last June 13 reversed convictions of men who had confessed to crimes of rape, robbery and murder. In the best-known case, Ernesto A. Miranda, a 25year-old mentally retarded Arizonan, was convicted of kidnaping and raping an 18-year-old girl and received concurrent 20-to30-year sentences.

ON a quiet Friday last July, the country was shocked to learn of the brutal slaying of eight student nurses in Chicago. Within hours a nationwide manhunt was ordered and within two days the prime suspect, Richard Speck, was located in a skid-row hotel and taken into custody.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The Soviet Union has informed the United States that Thomas R. Dawson, a Peace Corps volunteer, will be released soon. He has been detained for two weeks in Baku, capital of the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.

Morris Forgash, president of the United States Freight Company, the nation's largest freight-forwarding organization, died of a heart attack last night in his home at 150 East 69th Street. He was 65 years old.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 1 (AP) A West Coast Airlines DC-9 with 20 persons aboard was missing and feared down tonight.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) A system for displaying television pictures without using a picture tube and related components was disclosed today by the Zenith Radio Corporation.

The Lindsay administration, now in its 10th month, is striving to achieve as much of its governmental reorganization and consolidation program as possible without risking a veto in the Legislature.

LONDON, Oct. 2 Honeywell Controls, Ltd., the British branch of the American computer manufacturer, has acknowledged in effect that it will never really make people understand computers. BALDWIN, L.I., Oct. 2 Frank D. O'Connor told today about a previously undisclosed preconvention agreement to bar personal attacks from the campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

PARIS, Oct. 2 The United States can achieve price stability, balanced international payments and a 3 per cent unemployment rate by 1970, according to an analysis of economic prospects for the nonCommunist industrial powers published here over the weekend.

THE New York Giants are improving. If it wasn't too apparent on the playing field at yesterday's Yankee Stadium home opening, the evidence was posted on the scoreboard. After yielding an average of slightly more than 40 points to their first three opponents, the Giants held the Cleveland Browns to a mere 28 while submitting to a 28-to-7 defeat before 62,916 somewhat embarrassed witnesses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 All 50 states have decided to set their own water quality standards rather than have Federal rules imposed on them.

Oxford University Press will publish "The Oxford Companion to American History," by Thomas H. Johnson, on Oct. 13. NEW DELHI, Oct. 2 The Mizo rebellion, which Indian officials dismissed last spring as just a momentary emergency, has become one of this country's most chronic and difficult security problems.

HONOLULU, Oct. 2 Former representative Thomas P. Gill appeared today to have swept to a resounding 3-to-1 Democratic primary victory over Gov. John A. Burns's choice for Lieutenant Governor.
Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, said today that he generally supports the "broad objectives" of the Administration's policies in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 American corporations cut their flow of dollars abroad for direct investment in the first half of this year by even more than called for in the Government's voluntary program of restraint.

Dines Carlsen, an artist, died on Saturday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Falls Village, Conn., and Summerville, S.C.

CAIRO, Oct. 2 Communist China's "proletarian cultural revolution," whose aims include the purging of bourgeois tendencies, has reached nearly 5,000 miles from Peking to the Chinese Communist Embassy here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 With no fanfare, not even an announcement, the Securities and Exchange Commission has put into operation a "stock-watching" system designed to give fast warning of fraud and manipulation in the market for over-the-counter securities.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 Tempers will flare and lights will burn late as Congress opens the big push this week for midmonth adjournment.
The 13 alleged Mafia leaders who were arrested Sept. 22 may be granted immunity from prosecution in an attempt to make them testify before the Queens County grand jury today.
BRIGANTINE, N. J., Oct, 2 Justice Vincent S. Haneman of the New Jersey Supreme Court refused today to halt a, reduction in Erie-Lackawanna, Railroad passenger service, scheduled to begin tomorrow.

MACON, Ga., Oct. 2 (UPI) A bomb threat Sunday resulted in the evacuation of a Baptist church where the congregation a week ago dismissed its pastor in a dispute over admitting an African exchange student to services.

LITTLE by little the New York City Opera is re furbishing its repertory, and every season sees new productions of old friends, adapted to the needs of the stage of the New York State Theater. On Saturday evening it was the turn of Puccini's "La Boheme."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 Sandy Koufax pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to the National League pennant today by winning the 162d and last game of the baseball season and keeping the Dodgers from falling into the clutches of the on-rushing San Francisco Giants.
HONOLULU, Oct. 2 (AP) Riley H. Allen, editor of The Honolulu Star-Bulletin for 48 years, died today in Queen's Hospital here. He was 82 years old.
BONN. Oct. 2--Former Chancellor Konrad Adenauer threw his support today behind Dr. Eugen Gerstenmaier, president of the West German Bundestag, as a successor to Chancellor Ludwid Erhard.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 2 (AP) Jim Cosman, a right hander making his first appearance in the major leagues, allowed only two hits today and pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to a 2-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs. The Cardinals scored off Dick Ellsworth in the fourth inning. Mike Shannon and Tim McCarver drove in the runs.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 2 A Westchester County health official contends that the State Public Service Commission has not enforced its own order for improvements in a local water system that community residents charge has been intolerable for a decade.

IT would not be overstressing the point to say that the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Richard Strauss's "Die Frau ohne Schatten," given last night, is the most elaborate production ever put on by the company. Not the company that goes back to the opening of the new house several weeks ago, but the company that goes back to 1883.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 2--Dr. Subandrio, who was Indonesia's Foreign Minister from 1957 until his arrest last March, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he aided Communists plotting to seize power here a year ago.

BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 2 (UPI) Prime Minister Wilson was shouted down today by demonstrators attacking his support of United States policy on Vietnam as he tried to read the Bible lesson at a Labor party church service.

Mayor Lindsay's recent announcement that New York's renewal funds will now be concentrated on "the three hardcore ghetto areas that are the shame of the city," Harlem, Bedford-Stuyvesant and the South Bronx; is right in line with the recommendations of the city's Study Group on Housing and Neighborhood Improvement just made public.

WYANDANCH, L.I., Oct. 2 This community's new elementary school was named the Milton L. Olive School today in honor of an 18-year-old Negro paratrooper who died last year in South Vietnam.

Two Michigan scientists have found that one road to greater food production may be paved with a layer of asphalt two feet under the surface of sandy soils.

BOSTON, Oct, 2 "Paper tigers," a local newspaper said of the New York Jets, and for three periods against the Boston Patriots today the Jets were little more. Then, 17 points behind starting the last quarter, they stormed back on Joe Namath's record passing performance and tied the Patriots, 24-24, in a tingling finish.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 2 Under the direction of Jackie Kemp, who threw two touchdown passes, the Buffalo Bills stormed back from a 14-6 deficit today to whip the Kansas City Chiefs, 29-14.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 2 (UPI) Bart Starr threw touchdown passes to Marv Fleming and Carroll Dale today and Don Chandler kicked three field goals as the Green Bay Packers defeated the Detroit Lions, 23-14.

A Harlem committee representing parents and community leaders has proposed that the new Intermediate School 201 be put under a special board composed of parents, university educators and representatives of the Board of Education.

Dr. Paul William Freeman, a dentist, died yesterday at Putnam County Community Hospital in Carmel, N.Y., of injuries suffered on Friday when his automobile collided with another in Carmel. He was 59 years old and lived in Carmel.

SALISBURY; Rhodesia, Oct. 2 Salisbury is not a ghost town. It just looks that way on a Sunday afternoon. The whites who were at church this morning have gone to play badminton or to sip gin and tonic at their homes in the suburbs of Avondale or Highlands.

Mrs. Rachel Connwell Holmes Ingalls, widow of Fay Ingalls, who was president of Virginia Hot Springs, Inc., which operates The Homestead and other resort enterprises on a 17,000acre preserve in Hot Springs, Va., died Saturday.

Dr. Richard Edwin Shope, a physician and animal pathologist internationally recognized as an authority on the field of virology, died of cancer of the pancreas yesterday at James Ewing Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Kingston, N.J.

Miss Jane Ellen Brody, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Brody of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Richard Engquist, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Rodney Engquist of Scandia, Minn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 Four radio stations in New York State, including WMCA in New York City, adopted today a code of restrictions on crime reporting that is intended to protect the rights of persons accused of crimes.
PARIS, Oct. 2 A Gaullist coalition scored a victory today over a left-wing slate in munic-, ipal council elections in Brive, in south-central France.
FREDERICTON, N. B., Sept. 26--A war on poverty is being initiated in New Brunswick with a 10-year, $114-million federal-provincial program in two depressed rural areas.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 2 Miss Judith Isa Chemers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Chemers of Rockville Centre, was married this evening to William Frederick Levine. He is the son of State Supreme Court Justice Manuel W. Levine and Mrs. Levine of Port Washington.

SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 2 Dr. and Mrs. Louis R. Murphy have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Regina Murphy of New York, to John Thomas Fleckenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Fleckenstein of Huntington, W. Va. The wedding is planned for Nov. 26.

The conciliatory tone of Mayor Lindsay's letter to the Board of Education ought to put an end to the name-calling episode that followed the conflict over Intermediate School 201. The letter also serves as a reminder that the city's education problems cannot be resolved by legalistic debates.
SAN DIEGO, Oct. 2 Nat Young of Sydney, Australia, won the men's title at the world surfing championships today in a skillful display at Ocean Beach, Calif.
TITOVO UZICE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 2 (AP) All 500 teachers and professors in this Serbian industrial city refused today to accept their salaries for October, demanding a 30 per cent increase.

Average interest rates charged by New York City banks on short-term business loans rose during the first half of September to 6.07 per cent, the highest level since 1929, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 (UPI) Johnny Roland returned a punt 86 yards for a touchdown today and Larry Wilson ran 91 with an interception as the unbeaten St. Louis Cardinals routed the Philadelphia Eagles, 41-10, for their fourth National Football League triumph.
One of Ireland's leading popmusic groups, the Royal Showband, made its Carnegie Hall debut Saturday night. About 1,000 listeners braved the rain to hear the seven-man group.

GENEVA, Oct. 2 The Kennedy round of trade negotiations is basking in an unusual glow of goodwill these days and it is probably a good thing. The differences among the 53 participating nations are deep. High-ranking officials expect to peer over the brink of total breakdown more than once before the negotiations end next spring.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 2, (AP) The wreckage of a DC-9 jet plane that crashed and burned in a mountain ravine last night was found this afternoon. All 18 persons aboard were dead.
"They're cheaper and they're stamped the way they should be, so I assume they're all right."

Peter Lawford, a former brother-in-law of President Kennedy, announced yesterday that his film company would produce a series of 26 one-hour documentary programs about the late President's 1,000 days in office. Mr. Lawford will be executive producer of the television series, "J. F. K.: The Man."
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 2 A new sound rang out over the city this afternoon as Yale University dedicated 44 new bells in Harkness Tower.
Izso Szekely, assistant publisher of the Hungarian daily, Amerikai Magyar Nepszava here, died Saturday night in French Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 315 East 88th Street.
Eight American newsmen have been awarded fellowships in the Advanced International Reporting Program at Columbia University for the current academic year.
Players of the Philadelphia Orchestra, note on strike, say that they are organizing a concert season of their own, independent of the orchestra's management.
About 12,000 members of the Transport Workers Union will vote today on a contract agreement reached by the union's officials and American Airlines.

GARRISON, N.Y., Oct. 2 About $1,500 was raised today for a floating Hudson River museum, thanks to Pete Seeger and about 1,000 people who paid to hear him sing "My Dirty Stream" and other ballads about the Hudson.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 2 Troops in the Northern Region city of Kano mutinied last night and joined civilian mobs in attacking members of the Eastern Region's Ibo tribe. More than 300 Ibos were reported killed, and this was said to be a conservative estimate. Hundreds were injured.
NEWARK, Oct. 2 (AP) Two of Newark's oldest Episcopal congregations voted to merge today, forming what is believed to be the nation's largest predominantly Negro Episcopal congregation.

BONSALL, Calif., Oct. 2 (UPI) Mickey Wright of Dallas won her fourth namesake tourney, the 72-hole Wright invitation, at the San Luis Rey Golf Club today when she scored a final round one-underpar 71.
EAST MEADOW, L.I., Oct. 2 The wedding of Miss Svetla Menschik and Peter Talbot Harkness took place today at Holy Trinity Russian Orthodox Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Daniel Hubiak.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 2 While their husbands campaigned on a somewhat different level, the wives of Wisconsin's two candidates for Governor tangled last week over the remodeling and refurbishing of the Executive Mansion.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 2 The marriage of Miss Ellen Florence Grob, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Grob of Scarsdale, to Mark Allan Levy took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Levy of Chestnut Hill, Mass.
Ed Winrow set a course record yesterday in winning the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union four-mile cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 Naval gunfire, which played such an important role in World War II and in Korea, is proving very useful against the Vietcong and the North Vietnamese regulars in South Vietnam.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 2 (AP) Fred Stolle of Australia won the Pacific Coast international tennis championship today by beating Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico, 6-4, 2-6, 6-4, in the final.

In late August, a 19-year-old boy was arrested outside a store in Spanish Harlem carrying a string-mesh bag filled with unpaid-for articles. In Criminal Court not long afterward, he was convicted of shoplifting.
Offerings of tax-exempt bonds outnumber corporate sales by a wide margin on this week's newissue calendar. Dollar volume is relatively light in both sectors.
Sales of Stokely-Van Camp, Inc., Indianapolis food processor, rose during the first quarter, but net income showed a slight dip, compared with the corresponding period of last year.

The 250 millionth passenger to use one of New York City's three airports since the Port of New York authority undertook their development and operation nearly 20 years ago passed through one yesterday, unknown and without fanfare.

Congressman Paul Findley of Illinois deserves high marks for his persistence and thoroughness in probing into the strange history of a 20-mm. gun, first urgently required by the Army almost six years ago and not yet delivered.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 2 A. Pekingese, Ch. Coughtan's Sungable of Perryacre, was chosen as best in show today at the Old Dominion Kennel Club show. The winner is owned by Mrs. Ralph West and Mrs. Elaine Rigden of Livonia, Mich., who imported him from England nearly two years ago.
The New York State A.F.L.C.I.O. executive council announced the endorsement yesterday of 37 Democratic and four Republican candidates in the state's 41 Congressional contests.
A radical change has taken place in the economics of the nation's larger airports, according to the Air Transport Association.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 2 The control and predominant ownership rights of the world's largest underground copper mine, El Teniente, which was operated by American interests for 61 years and is to be taken over by Chile, was announced at noon today.
DACCA, Pakistan, Oct. 2 (Reuters) The port city of Chittagong was reported today to have suffered severe damage in an eight-hour battering by a cyclone last night.
BRICKTOWN, N.J., Oct. 2 Runyon Colie Jr. of Philadelphia and the Mantoloking (N. J.) Yacht Club, won the Atlantic Coast Penguin Class sailboat championship at Metedeconk River Yacht Club today.

Gene Hickerson and John Wooten, a 500-pound pair of guards who used to do the heavy work the blocking for Jim Brown, did it for Leroy Kelly in Yankee Stadium yesterday as their team, the Cleveland Browns, beat the New York Giants, 28-7.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 2 (AP) Jim Perry, with relief help, hurled a four-hitter and drove in the game's only run with an eighth-inning single today as the Minnesota Twins won the second game, 1-0, and gained a split of a doubleheader with the American League champions, the Baltimore Orioles.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 2 Probably no Tennessee voters raised their eyebrows on learning that Gov. Frank G. Clement, the Democratic nominee for the United States Senate, had appeared before a group of Negro leaders here yesterday asking for their support.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) Capitol Helicopter Airways, a newly formed Delaware corporation, has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for a certificate to operate scheduled helicopter service in the Washington-Baltimore area.

Take the delightful nonsense of a fairy-tale fantasy, dress it up with Mstislav Douboujinsky's colorful sets, costumes and masks, add a generous portion of Charles Weidman's lively choreography, combine everything with infectious performances by a spirited, well-trained cast, and you have the New York City Opera's irresistible production of "The Love for Three Oranges."

NEWARK, Oct. 2 Five men who the Secret Service said were leaders in a ring that had flooded northern New Jersey with counterfeit $10 bills were arraigned late yesterday after a series of arrests in Paterson.

ST. JOHN, N.B. The peace of the gentle St. John River valley is being shattered these colorful autumn days by the greatest construction effort in New Brunswick's bucolic history the $114-million Mactaquac hydroelectric project.
ALBANY, Oct. 2 (AP) Dr. Israel Zwerling, professor of psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, has been appointed director of Bronx State Hospital.
TEL AVIV, Oct. 2 Leading Israeli rabbis today lit 70 candles in a cave on Mount Zion in a prayer for world peace.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 2 (AP)--A United States satellite designed to televise daily picture coverage of the world's weather patterns was launched today into a nearly perfect polar orbit.
THE Rip Van Winkle sectional championship at Grossinger's upstate resort ended yesterday afternoon.

LISBON, Oct. 2 Lisbon's 77year-old Roman Catholic patriarch has made it clear that he will not retire until the Pope says so but is ready to share some of his burdens of church government with a council of priests.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Oct. 2 (UPI)--Don Massengale shot his fourth straight round of 70 today and withstood a closing challenge from Chi Chi Rodriguez to win the Canadian open golf tournament with a score of 280.

DENVER, Oct. 2 (UPI) Gary Kroner kicked four field goals, including a 46-yarder with 27 seconds left, to give the Denver Broncos a 40-38 triumph over the Houston Oilers today in an American Football League game.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 The United States Information Agency plans to spend about $6-million over the next 12 months to subsidize books for use as propaganda overseas.
A chair in urban anthropology, which will deal with the study of man as a city dweller along with his problems in an urban society, has been established at New York University.
HONG KONG, Oct. 2--Analysts here felt there was an undercurrent of uncertainty beneath the surface self-assurance of the Chinese Communist hierarchy as China celebrated its National Day yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 2 Charles T. O. Rennie, the 19year-old son of John O. Rennie, a British diplomat, was being held in Mercer County jail in nearby Trenton today on charges of possession of narcotics.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 2 When the lines were finally drawn last spring for the First New Jersey Congressional District, the Republicans cried "foul" and "gerrymander" and the Democrats, smelling victories ahead, told funny stories.

RIVER VALE, N.J., Oct. 2 Carol Hofmann, a 23-year-old brunette from North Branch, N. J., scored an unusual double today when she captured both the open and green jumper championships at the Holiday Farm's Horse Show.

The intervention by President Johnson led last night to a two-week postponement of a strike that had been set for midnight against the General Electric Company by the International Union of Electrical Workers.
Met fans the long and the tall, but mostly the short were honored at Shea Stadium yesterday as the Mets concluded their most successful season.

The Canal-Randolph Corporation of New York, which has widespread residential and commercial properties, has purchased an eight-acre office building complex in Orange, a city in Orange County in southern California, just north of Santa Ana.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 Something "popped" behind Sandy Koufax's left shoulder during the fifth inning of his pennant-winning game today, but the Los Angeles Dodger star finished the game after medication and was expected to be all right for the World Series.

Businessmen predict widespread unemployment on farms and higher prices for food, hotel rooms and various merchandise as a result of the higher Federal minimum wage signed late last week by President Johnson.

GRAND MASTER ARTHUR BISGUIER of Yonkers usually goes along with an opponent's opening innovation. Within a few moves, however, he gives the debut an unexpected twist, and the innovator off guard is diverted from his main theme.
ATLANTA, Oct. 2 (UPI) The unbeaten Dallas Cowboys routed the Atlanta Falcons, 47-14, today on the passing of Don Meredith and the running of Dan Reeves.

Federal agencies, including the State, Agriculture and Defense Departments were blamed yesterday for the present low state of the United States Merchant Marine in a study made public by a leading maritime labor leader.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 2 (UPI) National officials of the Fraternal Order of Eagles and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will meet in New York City on Oct. 19 to discuss the order's all-white membership policy.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 2 Vietcong mines ripped into two South Vietnamese Navy river craft this morning, sinking one and damaging the second.

"A Hand Is on the Gate," which was to have closed Saturday night, has been extended through emergency contributions of $7,000. The program of Negro folk music and poetry that opened Sept. 21 at the Longacre will continue for at least another week.
Ted Bates Co., has announced the creation of a new post and the appointment of a man to fill it Walter Carlson, for the last 21 months advertising columnist for The New York Times.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 2 (AP) The Coast Guard Academy captured First place today in the two-day Denmark Trophy intercollegiate sailing competition by compiling 227 points.
JAKARTA, Monday, Oct. 3 (AP) Indonesian students seeking the fall of President Sukarno were bayoneted and clubbed today as they charged his palace.
Michigan and Ohio State came tumbling down in the biggest shocks registered on college football's seismographs Saturday, and Dartmouth and Yale were engulfed, too.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 The Supreme Court will face a docket heavily weighted with criminal law issues when it meets tomorrow for the official opening of the 1966 term.

A series of three Sundayafternoon concerts devoted to chamber music for string instruments and piano began at Town Hall yesterday with a program offering Schubert's Trio in E flat (Op. 100) and Dvorak's "Dumky" Trio (Op. 90).

Lincoln Bouillon, an engineering consultant and president of the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers, died Friday at the Swedish Hospital in Seattle. He was 66 years old and lived on Mercer Island off Seattle.
MADRID, Oct. 2 Spain is preparing to increase pressure on Gibraltar as negotiations with Britain over the future of the colony remain stalemated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach left the Justice Department today with a prediction that a fair housing civil rights bill would eventually pass and that Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen would vote for it.
WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 2 Hundreds of fairgoers surrounded Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. today as the Liberal party candidate for Governor shook hands and toured exhibits at the Long Island Fair.

ALGIERS, Oct. 2 The Algerian police have arrested 19 Europeans, mostly Frenchmen, in the western port of Oran on charges of procuring prostitutes from France for brothels and of illegally transferring French francs out of Algeria.

A man-high slate sculpture by Isamu Noguchi was toppled from its pedestal and broken yesterday as an eager crowd of several thousand persons pushed and squeezed through the new Whitney Museum of American Art.

HARTFORD, Oct. 2 Footnotes to dance history were being written this afternoon at the Bushnell Memorial Hall here. Martha Graham and her dance company gave the opening performance of their national tour.
The Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., will embark this November on a pace-setting one-year study of automation that could lead to its becoming the nation's most thoroughly computerized hospital.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould Jr. of Laurel and Seager, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lydia Comstock Gould, to Michele Barbieri of Pisa, Italy. A spring wedding is planned.
Two massive outdoor demonstrations were held yesterday to protest the Soviet Union's suppression of the religious, spiritual and cultural rights of three million Soviet Jews.

As Michael Moore, a 20-yearold Marine private, crossed Goulden Avenue at Bedford Park Boulevard in the Bronx at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, he heard some noises coming from the trunk of a parked cab.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that he would ask the city's Board of Ethics to study the whole question of private contributions to city activities and to advise him on how to handle them.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 2 (AP) Francis Cabell Brown, president and chairman of the Schering Corporation of Bloomfield, N.J., a leading pharmaceutical manufacturer, was killed this afternoon in an automobile collision in a traffic tunnel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York sided with President Johnson and disagreed sharply with two prominent fellow Republicans today on Vietnam issues.
Applicants for Medicaid will be able to register for the state medical assistance program at 23 welfare centers throughout the city starting today.
Theodore Bache Bleecker, who retired 10 years ago as a stockbroker with Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at Charlottesville, Va. He was 73 years old.

Barry Goldwater said yesterday that if Gov. George Romney of Michigan were seriously seeking the Republican Presidential nomination for 1968 he would have to explain "why he didn't support the Republican ticekt in 1964."

SMITH CENTER, Kan., Oct. 1 The Midwest farm country fanning out from this geographical center of the United States is fat. It is rich in crops. Farm prices and income have climbed as surpluses of wheat and feed grains disappear.
WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 2 Jim Clark of Scotland had an eeasy time of it today as he won the Grand Prix of the United States.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 Saved by a career substitute named Ossie Virgil and carried forward by Willie McCovey's home run and Lindy McDaniel's relief pitching, the San Francisco Giants defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7-3, in 11 innings today and left Forbes Field with their National League pennant chances still alive.
A major planning problem for a person building a fund for a specific long-term objective is in deciding how best to draw on that fund when the objective is at hand.
Days are getting short for New Yorkers who have not yet registered to vote in the general elections on Nov. 8.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the matter of the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board was the most important issue to be decided on a local ballot in years.

One of India's chief instruments to assist the country's capital-hungry economy, the Indian Investment Center here, passed its fifth birthday yesterday hopeful that the list of American companies venturing onto the subcontinent would expand and become more varied soon.

Cardinal Hayes, with plenty of experienced players and a fast backfield, routed Xavier, 35-7, in its season opener at Randalls Island yesterday. Bobby Spillane, the quarterback, scored one touchdown and passed to Peter Martin for another to spark the Cardinals' success.
Final tribute was paid yesterday to Bernard F. Gimbel, the gregarious patriarch of New York's retail merchants, who died Thursday at the age of 81.
SDE BOKER, Israel, Oct. 2 The 80th birthday of David Ben-Gurion was marked today in the middle of the desert the former Premier has been seeking to tame.

Mao Tse-tung sought to project an image of Chinese strength this weekend at the Peking celebration of his regime's seventeenth anniversary. He put Chinese nuclear power closer to the center of his propaganda campaign than ever before. He had Lin Piao deliberately provoke a walkout by Soviet and pro-Soviet diplomats on the scene. And he provided a dismaying demonstration of the extreme lengths to which his public deification is now being carried.
WHEN Urleene Chaplain started designing clothes, she made "drop dead" dresses for Hollywood starlets.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3--Striking tugboat workers returned to their jobs in the Port of Philadelphia today after ratifying a new labor contract calling for a 39-cents-an-hour wage increase spread over three years.
Miss Babette Kass of 930 Fifth Avenue and Jacob M. Miller of 233 East 69th Street plan to marry in January.
The 50,000-member National Maritime Union plans to defer the reopening of its long-term contract with American ship, owners until next year in the expectation of greater gains.
Stock prices tumbled yesterday in one of the sharpest setback's of the year.
STEVE ALTMAN, one of New York's most promis ing young experts, no doubt feels that he is the victim of a jinx.
WAUKEGN, Ill., Oct. 3 (AP) Mayor Robert Sabonjian said today he would be a write-in candidate for Senator in the Nov. 8 election.
HOUSTON, Oct. 3 With the opening of the new Jesse H. Jones Hall for the Performing Arts, this city tonight began a month of cultural, social and civic festivities.
MANILA, Oct. 3 (AP) President Ferdinand E. Marcos tonight set Oct. 28-29 as the tentative dates for the sevennation conference on peace in Vietnam.
Honeywell, Inc., announced yesterday it would introduce "selective increases" in the rental and purchase prices of its Series 200 computer equipment, effective Dec. 15.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Republican leaders said today they had found the race issue to be of increasing concern to Americans and moved to give it more prominence in the current political races.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Secretary of Defense McNamara will leave Saturday for a sixday visit to South Vietnam, a Pentagon spokesman announced today.
MIAMI, Oct. 3 (AP) Hurricane Inez started a slow drift tonight on a south-southwest path that increased her danger to Florida's heavily populated southeast coast.
A ranking Federal judge has called proposals to restrict the reporting of crime news "the most dangerous threat to the American ideal of free speech and press since the days of Joe McCarthy."
LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 3 A round-the-clock airlift was started today to evacuate thousands of beleaguered Ibo refugees in Nigeria's vast Northern Region.

NEWARK, Oct. 3 William L. Maude, former chairman of the board of managers and former president of the Howard Savings Institution here, died yesterday in his home, 74 Beverly Road, Upper Montclair. He was 72 years old.
JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 3 (UPI) The life sentence of a young Hattiesburg man convicted of raping a teen-age Negro girl last year was upheld today by the Mississippi Supreme Court.

MARIE-CLAUDE LALIQUE, pretty, petite and French, is currently rushing around New York viewing every thing from the Bowery to a Lalique exhibition at Ginori Fifth Avenue with wide brown eyes clearer than her own crystal.
The Port of New York Authority yesterday stood by its estimate of the cost of constructing the controversial World Trade Center.

SUSANNAH YORK, the young British actress who is best known to American audiences for her role as the ingenue in "Tom Jones," flew into town Sunday night armed with four trouser suits by Foale Tuffin and a goodly supply of English cigarettes.
Brother Clement Francis Charters, dean of Manhattan College's School of Business since 1961, died yesterday of cancer in St. Joseph's Hospital, Yonkers. His age was 60.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Maxwell Jr. of New York and Cotuit, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Lyon Maxwell, to William Martens Lee, son of Mr, and Mrs. Arthur C. Lee of Yorktown Heights, N.Y.
The Administration put direct pressure yesterday on the General Electric Company and its unions to settle their contract disputes without causing any interruptions of vital defense production.
Stocks closed sharply lower with some major market averages falling to new 1966 lows; volume, 6.49 million shares.
A 54-year-old clerk was found stabbed to death in his midtown apartment yesterday, his hands tied behind his back.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) The Treasury Department said today it had decided that teachers who take additional courses to improve their professional standing normally can deduct the cost from their income tax.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) The House passed and sent to the White House today a bill providing Federal penalties for thefts from oil and gas pipelines.

The Times Square area will have a new showcase when the 225-seat Bert Wheeler Theater, named in honor of the 71-yearold comedian, opens Oct. 25 with the musical comedy "Autumn's Here." The theater will be situated in the Hotel Dixie, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, 10 steps above the entrance at 250 West 43d Street.
LONDON, Oct. 3 Shortening days and darkening skies have combined with the economic squeeze and freeze and the decline of British fortunes to cast a pall of gloom over this island.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 3 It is a common saying here that when the price of beans is greater than the price of coffee, Brazil's main export, the Government is in trouble.

KINGSTON, Jamacia, Oct. 3 (AP) The Government declared a state of emergency today in parts of western Kingston and neighboring St. Andrews, the scenes of gun battles and bomb explosions in the last few months. Troops moved into the troubled area and 30 persons were reported arrested.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 3 (AP) The United telephone system, the nation's third largest, will extend its operations into Texas early next year with acquisition of the Gulf States Telephone Company, the two organizations announced today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 The Treasury bill rate dropped substantially at today's auction by comparison with the level last week, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
DETROIT, Oct. 3--The Ford Motor Company described today a new battery system to power small cars and said the company could be in the electric car business within 10 years.

LONDON, Oct. 3 Reginald Maudling, second-ranking leader of the Conservative party, returned from Rhodesia today, convinced that differences between Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and the British Government were "not so wide as to be incapable of being bridged."
The spot rate on the British pound improved yesterday in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here.

WASHINGTON, Oct.3 (UPI) President Johnson's hopes for the nation's future in a rapidly changing world, and the guiding principles of foreign policy, were set out today in a prologue and epilogue written for a new book, "This America."
A reputed Mafia chieftain surrendered to the police yesterday on a charge of having killed a Mafia gunman who had testified against Vito Genovese in a 1946 murder trial.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Members of Congress looked at the nation's merchant marine today and found it in a sorry state.
DETROIT, Oct. 3 (AP) Three auto companies built more cars last month than in any previous September as they hurried to get 1967 models to market.
SUVA, Fiji, Oct. 3 Fiji's multiracial population is voting for a new legislature that will take this British crown colony a long step toward complete self-government.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Benedict J. Ticho have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Roberta, Ticho, to Herman R. Charbonneau, son of Herman E. Charbonneau of Cos Cob, Conn., and the late Mrs. Charbonneau. The wedding is planned for Dec. 26 in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here.

NEWARK, Oct. 3 (AP) The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company announced today that it reached a contract agreement over the weekend with the Telephone Workers of New Jersey, affiliated with the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

The C.I.T. Financial Corporation, a commercial finance company, announced here yesterday the election of Francis J. Palamara as a vice president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) Separate bills to provide a supplemental pension system for railroad employes and benefits for children of deceased railroad employed were passed today by the House and were sent to the Senate.

A favorite and a long shot took divisions of the Long Island Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Paoluccio, of the Greentree Stable, was the popular choice to score, at $4.80 for $2, taking his half of the 1 3/16 turf event by 1 lengths over the Buckland Farm's Gallup Poll. Mostar was third.

The Franklin National Bank, the largest bank on Long Island, reported yesterday that its net operating earnings for the first nine months of 1966 were $8,780,952, or $2.26 a share, up 20 per cent from the $7,312,147, or $1.88 a share, reported for the same period of 1965.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the 12 months ended Aug. 31.
The New York Mets yesterday rehired their coaching staff including Yogi Berra.

Pierre A. Rinfret, an economist whose, views have in the past been espoused by President Johnson, declared yesterday that the nation's five-year boom in capital spending by corporations would slow down sharply in 1967.

The Rev. Alfred L. Beck, currently president of the New York Synod of the Lutheran Church in America, has been named president of the denomination's new Metropolitan New York Synod.

Max Schonfeld, chairman of the admissions board and a founder of the Menorah Home and Hospital, 871 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, died there yesterday. He was 90 years old.
The striking members of the Philadelphia Orchestra will put on their own concert on Oct. 14, independent of management. Leopold Stokowski, who led the Philadelphians from 1912 to 1941, will conduct.

Nigeria observed its sixth anniversary as an independent country not with parades and celebrations but with prayers and mourning. Its regional and tribal strife has intensified to the point where no one can be sure this giant of the new Africa will be intact to observe a seventh birthday in 1967.
Henry M. Christman was sworn in by the Mayor yesterday as director of the City Record.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 3 Former Foreign Minister Subandrio conceded on the witness stand here today that he had failed to tell President Sukarno of reports last year of an impending Communist-supported uprising.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 3 (UPI) A dispute about a proposed increase in a tax levy today caused a one-day walkout by nearly one-fourth of the public school teachers here.

The middleweight title fight between Emile Griffith, the champion, and Joey Archer was postponed yesterday from Oct. 21 to Nov. 10 because Archer is suffering from a virus, a spokesman for the Madison Square Garden Boxing Club, the promoters, announced.
The election of M. Frederik Smith to the board of directors of the American Motors Corporation was announced yesterday.

Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority since 1936, and Miss Mary A. Grady, an assistant secretary of the agency, were married yesterday at St. Aedan's Roman Catholic Church in Jersey City.

The National Endowment for the Arts announced yesterday it would award $625,000 to the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, which operates station WNDT (Channel 13) here. The money, to be given in January, will be used to produce a Sunday evening series on the arts.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 106.5 on Friday from 106.2 on Thursday.
Perry P. Hart, an assistant treasurer of the Bankers Trust Company, died Monday in Bellevue Hospital. He was 42 years old and lived at 2550 Independence Avenue, the Bronx.
A new Yiddish-English dictionary, the first in more than 40 years, will be published in the spring and will contain such words as "launching pad" and "slumlord."
SALAMANCA, N.Y., Oct. 3 (AP) Paul L. Adams, Conservative party candidate for Governor, discounted today the importance of endorsements given to two of his opponents by organized labor.

Two-thirds of a group of Roman Catholic priests who replied to a poll by the Catholic pictorial monthly Jubilee, favor a reappraisal of the law of clerical celibacy, the magazine has announced. The remaining third were adamantly in favor of the ancient discipline.

Allen Dulles, former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, tells of the moves that led to surrender of German forces in Italy in World War II in "The Secret Surrender," to be published by Harper Row next Monday. Mr. Dulles guided Operation Sunrise that led to the surrender.

For the first time, Frank D. O'Connor explained publicly yesterday how he stepped aside and let Abraham D. Beame seek the Democratic nomination for Mayor last year.
DETROIT, Oct 4 (AP)--Mike Tresh, former Chicago White Sox catcher and father of Tom Tresh, New York Yankee outfielder, died today in Oakwood Hospital in suburban Taylor Township. He was 52 years old.

"SECONDS," a suspense drama starring Rock Hudson, directed by John Frankenheimer and produced by Edward Lewis for Paramount, is the attraction at the Forum Theater, Broadway and 47th Street, the RKO 58th Street at Third Avenue, and the RKO 23d Street at Eighth Avenue.
TOKYO, Oct. 4--Millions of Japanese baseball fans are pulling for the Dodgers to win the World Series.
Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, advocated last night public investment in securities firms as a future goal for the Big Board.

BERLIN, Oct. 4--Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, disclosed plans today to establish an international research center at the villa in Wannsee, the West Berlin suburb where Nazi leaders in 1942 laid their plans to wipe out Europe's Jews.

ATHENS--Greece's political situation is once again polarizing dangerously toward left and right. The amorphous center is being impelled to choose between leaders who wish closer relations with the Communist world, neutralism and withdrawal from NATO, and those ready to go to extremes in support of conservatism and the monarchy. Communism on the one hand and the crown on the other are being made into distorted symbols.
In Newark, there's a jeweler who is "steeped in his art" and thinks like Thomas Carlyle, the Scottish essayist and historian. Pesin, Sydney Bernard Advertising Inc., is planning to make him famous.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct. 4 (Reuters)--Four members of the Soviet Embassy were ordered tonight to leave the country within 48 hours. The Government said they had intervened in labor affairs and incited strikes.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 4-- Bill Collins, whose home club is over the wall from the eighth hole, scored a 66 at the Century Country Club in the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today.

Twelve fellow Democrats joined Councilman Robert A. Low yesterday in a resolution calling for a City Council investigation of the city's policy of soliciting funds from private corporations and individuals to pay for official city entertaining.

A series of jazz concerts, designed for "an intimate atmosphere," made its debut Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall in circumstances that were appropriate and auspicious: The audience was small, but it was enthusiastic.

Bankers are apparently having increasing success in translating surging interest rates into higher profits. This was the principal conclusion to be drawn from yesterday's crop of thirdquarter and nine-month bank earnings reports.
MORRISTOWN, N.J.--The Fifth New Jersey Congressional District consists of two counties, Morris and Somerset. They are described in the guidebooks as "typical" and "inside."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4-- The difficulties of reconciling the conflicting schedules of seven heads of state and government have held up the planning for President Johnson's trip to Asia late this month.

Hyman Bress brought a heavy program of violin and piano music to Philharmonic Hall last night. The violinist, who has impressed favorably on occasions in the past, was decidedly below par. Pitch was questionable, vibrato either too fast--as in quavering high sections--or nonexistent; attacks were often crude, and the bow arm lacked sparkle.

FRANK SCHNEIDER of Lambertville, N.J., who set the record for average speed at 81.884 miles an hour for the 100-mile sportsmanmodified stock car race at Langhorne, Pa., is one of six former winners entered in the 16th annual running on Sunday afternoon. Schneider was...

LONDON, Oct. 4--A revival of confidence in the pound was seen today in the Treasury's announcement that Britain's gold and foreign currency reserves rose in September for the first time in a half year.

A reception honoring those who are taking part in the annual fund campaign of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York will be held on Monday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria at 3 P.M. The goal for 1966 is $1,008,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4-- Thomas R. Dawson, a teacher in the United States Peace Corps, who was arrested by Soviet authorities when he crossed the border from Iran three weeks ago, was released last night at the Soviet-Iranian frontier.
The New York Telephone Company will furnish the scores of World Series games. The number is ME 7-1212, the company's time bureau.

PARIS, Oct. 4--A former chief of the Moroccan security police, accused of being one of the kidnappers of Mehdi Ben Barka, the Moroccan Opposition leader, testified today that he was not a policeman at all. He said he was only a sort of feudal bodyguard to Gen. Mohammed Oufkir, except for brief intervals when he was a student in Paris.

Dr. William A. Stocker, a dentist with an office at 1067 Fifth Avenue, died Monday in University Hospital after a brief illness. He was 33 years old and lived at 40-59 Junction Boulevard, Corona, Queens.

Hurricane Inez, described as packing the force of 100 onemegaton atom bombs in its winds and rain over a 24-hour period, ran into an immovable wall of high pressure air over the Atlantic Ocean Monday.

The Philadelphia and Reading Corporation, a diversified manufacturing company, sold the assets and business yesterday of its wholly owned subsidiary, the DeLuxe Reading Corporation, for about $49-million.

The International Longshoremen's Association would like to consolidate with the Pacific Coast's International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union, Thomas W. Gleason, I.I.A. president, said here yesterday.

BRASILIA, Oct. 4--President-elect Arthur Costa a Silva said today that he was in favor of the establishment of an inter-American military peace force to act in the Western Hemisphere against "external subversion."

Cardinal Spellman presided at a special Mass for Peace yesterday in honor of the first anniversary of the Pope's visit. The service took place at the Holy Family Church, 315 East 47th Street, where last year the Pope met with Jewish and Protestant leaders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4-- Harold Howe 2d, the United States Commissioner of Education, astonished a Congressional committee today by suggesting that states take over from the Federal Government the enforcement of antidiscrimination laws in school systems.

Anna Lesznai, a HungarianAmerican writer and artist, died Monday in her home at 246 Lexington Avenue. Her age was 81. In private life, she was the wife of Tibor Gergely, an artist and illustrator of children's books.

The election of Marshal Costa e Silva as Brazil's next President means that the nation will make a smooth transition on March 15 from President Castelo Branco's regime. The President-elect had no opposition, since the theoretical opposition party, the Brazilian Democratic Movement, refused to nominate a candidate with all the cards stacked aginst him.
Prices continued to fall on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, but the declines were not as steep as the day before.
IT was the only ballet performance in years where someone could mention the name "Rudi" in the intermission and not mean a longhaired Russian called Nureyev.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Oct. 4 --J. Walcott Brown of Manasquan, the defending champion, scored 39 36-75 today at Baltusrol to take the lead in the 45th annual New Jersey State Seniors Golf Association championship.
MOSCOW, Oct. 4 (Reuters)-- Regular color television transmissions between Paris, and Moscow will begin soon, using the Soviet communications satellite Molnia-1, it was announced here today.
About 250 persons held a vigil outside the United Nations last night in remembrance of Pope Paul VI's visit a year ago and as testimony to their prayers for an end to the fighting in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4-- Army Secretary Stanley R. Resor said tonight that the Defense Department was considering whether to order a temporary halt in the program that permits young men to enlist for six months of active duty in the Reserves or National Guard.

Time is so clearly running out for an effective treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons that the hope must persist for some "give" in the rigid stance of the Soviet Union. It is in part to explore this possibility that President Johnson has invited Andrei Gromyko to the White House next week.
Government bond prices, which began to recover late Monday because of the stock market's sinking spell, continued to work their way upward yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) --The Justice Department has notified Congressional leaders it does not plan to appeal to the Supreme Court in the case of three antiwar protesters who refused to testify at a closed session of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
Charles K. Feldman, who, like many successful Hollywood producers, has been working almost exclusively in Europe for the last several years, continues to think big, Californiastyle.

SAIGON, Wednesday, Oct. 5 (AP)--The commander of United States Marine forces in South iVetnam, Lieut. Gen. Lewis W. Walt, was struck in the head by a tiny piece of metal when a bullet hit his helicopter yesterday. The wound "didn't even need a Band-Aid," an aide said.

Domestic trunk airline traffic dropped 15.3 per cent in August compared with August, 1965, the Air Transport Association of America reported yesterday. The decline was the result of the five-week machinists' strike against five major carriers, which ended Aug. 20.

LILI KRAUS has always been known as a Mozart specialist, and last night she laid the cornerstone of what will be a complete structure after eight more concerts. Playing in Town Hall with the Mozart Chamber 'Orchestra under Stephen Simon, Miss Kraus started a series that will take in all 27 Mozart piano concertos.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--Foy D. Kohler, the United States Ambassador to Moscow, warned today that an American blockade of North Vietnam would be "a dangerous

BEAUMONT, Tex., Oct. 4 (UPI)--Thomas D. Palmer, who disappeared from Nashville 35 years ago and who was found in Texas in 1953 with a new name, a new wife and a new family, died here yesterday. He was 64 years old.

Four hundred persons, including many diplomatic, government and industry figures, attended a funeral service yesterday for Richard C. Patterson Jr., former Commissioner of Public Events and chief of protocol of New York City and former Ambassador to Yugoslavia, Guatemala and Switzerland. Mr. Patterson died Friday at the age of 80.
Governor Rockefeller disassociated himself yesterday from a policy statement by the national Republican Coordinating Committee asking stern repression of civil rights disorders.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 4--The Mexican Government announced tonight that a group of local investors had made an offer to purchase 66 per cent of the Mexican operation of Pan American Sulphur Company of Houston.
DETROIT, Oct. 4--The American Motors Corporation, smallest of the nation's car producers, increased prices today on its 1967 models by an average of $79 a car.
BOSTON, Oct. 4--Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today it was "impossible to understand how some can say the process of desegregating schools in the South is proceeding too fast."
Las Vegas, Nev.--Ferd Hernandez, 164 pounds, Las Vegas, knocked out Rod Thompson, 156 , Portland, Ore., 6 rounds.

BUFFALO, Oct. 4--A state commission preparing for the 1967 Constitutional Convention heard sharply clashing views today on whether the prohibition against state financial aid to parochial schools should be repealed.
David Merrick and his wife, Jeanne, were divorced yesterday in Juarez, Mexico.
Down was the word for the grains and soybeans yesterday.
An illegally parked motorist and a passer-by ran head-on into the Police Department's towaway program last night. The motorist got off with a fine, but the passer-by got a summons.
The bill to protect the Indiana Dunes as a national lakeshore comes up for a critically important vote in the House this week.

ANKHE, South Vietnam, Oct. 4--Rescue teams worked late into the night today to evacuate about 30 soldiers of the United States First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) who were in a transport plane that crashed into the side of a hill.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that he would fly to Puerto Rico in December for three days of high-level talks with Puerto Rican officials on problems of mutual concern to the city and the commonwealth.

DETROIT, Oct. 4--Union and company negotiators met today in an effort to resolve a labor dispute that could make idle more than 40,000 Chrysler Corporation workers this week and halt production of the company's 1967 model automobiles.
The head of Texaco, Inc., said yesterday there was a need for an improvement in the oil industry's rate of return on its assets if it was to meet the huge capital requirements of the future.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 4-- Dr. Carl A. Coppolino is scheduled to be arraigned in Superior Court here tomorrow in the 1963 murder of his Middletown Township neighbor, William Farber. But his trial probably will not begin until Nov. 7-- two weeks after the date originally set.

Mayor Lindsay began his citywide sidewalk campaign in support of the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board yesterday and was given a chilly reception in two middle-class neighborhoods in Brooklyn.
ONE of the more difficult aspects of coaching a team in sports is to keep the team keyed up for each succeeding game. This is especially true of football.

A reputed Mafia leader and two co-defendants pleaded not guilty yesterday in Queens, to the first-degree murder in 1964 of Ernest Rupolo, an underworld figure who had testified against Vito Genovese in a murder trial.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 4-- Dr. and Mrs. John P. Bowler have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Bowler, to James Morey Fitzgibbons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Fitzgibbons of Duxbury, Mass.

THE Greater New York Bridge Association's dou ble knockout team championship for 1966-67 has begun with an entry of 58 teams. The Flight B event, restricted to players with fewer than 100 master points, will be contested by 22 teams.
HOUSTON, Oct. 4--Ernest M. Hall Jr., former president of the Westec Corporation, denied today any violation of Federal securities laws.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4--Abba Eban, Israel's Foreign Minister, proposed today that Secretary General Thant help, bring the United States and North Vietnam together to discuss existing and future peace proposals in detail.

Four reputed members of a multimillion dollar gambling operation that allegedly paid 25 Westchester housewives $75 to $125 a week to answer telephones were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating interstate gambling laws.

"I SAW something move a little among the dead," says one of the survivors of Auschwitz in "The Investigation" as she recounts her horrified crawl through a chamber matted with corpses. So, I think, will you-though you may be a shade surprised at what you do see.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--A Federal District Court judge has summarily thrown out of court an attempt, by the Investors. Overseas Services to block a Government inquiry into its activities and that of the mutual funds it controls, including the $400-million Fund of Funds.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4--The Los Angeles Dodgers and Baltimore Orioles worked out today for baseball's 63d World Series, which will open before 55,000 fans tomorrow in Dodger Stadium. The game will start at 4 P.M., New York time.
ROCK SPRINGS, Wyo., Oct. 4--With a successful antelope hunt completed, the attention of this hunting party turned to the opening of the mule deer season.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 106.3 on Monday from 106.5 on Friday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--Portly Dan H. Kuykendall strolled into a backyard party at the Memphis home of Curtis Lemmons, a salesman, one day recently, pushing a supermarket cart full of groceries.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--The House voted today to increase the maximum amount of Government insurance on bank and savings and loan deposits to $20,000 from $10,000.

YONKERS, Oct. 4--Floridians, Ohioans and Pennsylvanians are familiar with the driving prowess of Bill Pocza, a 40year-old reinsman, whose 40horse stable has seen action this year at Pompano Park, Fla.; Northfield Park, Ohio, and the Meadows, Washington, Pa.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4--The Communist leaders of Eastern Europe are in the midst of intensive discussions that apparently are aimed at coordinating a joint stand to discredit Communist China's violent "cultural revolution."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) --An Agriculture Department official said today, after turning in his resignation, that the 1961-65 period covered by the Kennedy-Johnson Administrations had been the farmers' "worst five years."

A Bronx longshoreman who spent four years in the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane because psychiatrists refused to believe a bizarre story that was subsequently proved true was awarded $16,350 yesterday by the Court of Claims.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 4 (UPI)--The Danish Parliament today gave its approval for the marriage of Princess Margrethe, the heiress to the throne, and HenriMarie-Jean-Andre Count de Laborde de Monpezat.
Two little sisters who disappeared from their mother's locked station wagon in Brooklyn last night were found early today in bushes in Canarsie Park.

President and Mrs. Johnson are the honorary patrons of the United Nations Ball, to be held on Oct. 21 at the Waldorf-Astoria. Benefiting will be the United Nations Association of the United States of America, which conducts a program of education and research on United States participation in the United Nations and other international groups.

CAIRO, Oct. 4--The United States's hopes for a favorable private response from North Vietnam to the latest American proposals for a phased de-esclation of the war have been rebuffed, informed sources reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) --The House today sent to the White House a bill setting up a $20-million, two-year program of aid to sea grant colleges to further development of marine resources.
A special three-judge Federal Court, in a 2-to-1 decision issued here late yesterday afternoon, refused to delay further the merger plans of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads.
LAS VEGAS, Oct. 4--The Federal Bureau of Investigation has become an issue in the extremely close campaign for the governorship of Nevada.

The Swedish-built Saab 1967 models were introduced yesterday, and the, company announced that the economy cars would sell for about $200 less than the 1966 models to make them more competitive with other small imported cars.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 5 (UPI)--A brigade of 4,000 American infantrymen landed in South Vietnam today increasing the United States military strength to more than 320,000 troops.
Hyman Meltzer, president of three men's apparel manufacturing concerns, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 63 East Ninth Street.

A slight rise in sales and earnings was shown by the Clevite Corporation, the Cleveland-based diversified industrial concern, in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, William G. Laffer, president, said yesterday.
THE Columbia Broadcasting System gave convinc ing evidence last night that it was runnin gout of subjects on which to give television tests.

ATLANTA, Oct. 4 (AP)-- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Sr., father of the civil rights leader, stunned a citizens' meeting seeking a write-in candidate for Governor tonight by urging a move to draft Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday in Pittsburgh receipt of a contract to build two massive nuclear reactor systems and turbine generators for the Virginia Electric and Power ComPany.

The National Maritime Union, often at odds with the Defense Department over shipping policy, received high-level assurances yesterday that the defense establishment was keenly aware of the future problems of the American merchant marine.
A fear that had clouded the recent dramatic results achieved with silver nitrate in treating severe burns was eased here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) --The Federal Trade Commission denied today a petition by Montgomery Ward Co., Chicago, to reconsider a July decision ordering the concern to stop making what the commission called deceptive guarantee claims.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--The Senate Finance Committee approved today a plan for financing Presidential election campaigns out of Federal income taxes.
Dr. Max Taschman, a former chest specialist here, died Monday in a nursing home in Wheaton, Md. He was 86 years old and lived at 305 Riverside Drive.

Within the last week, automobile dealers across the nation have been pulling out more stops than ever before to induce Americans to participate in that great national pastime--looking at, feeling, sitting in and even kicking the new 1967 cars.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday swore in Samuel Ganz as the city's first Commissioner of Manpower and Career Development in the new Human Resources Administration.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 4--Mayor Theodore R. McKeldin urged local tavern owners today to break with tradition and begin serving Negroes during the World Series.
Ernie Cardone's ability to get horses into the winners circle and Mako's failure to carry 171 pounds highlighted yesterday's Program.
BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 4 --Prime Minister Wilson today made his strongest commitment to secure the rights of the black majority in Rhodesia.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 4--President Tito carried out a far-reaching reorganization of the Communist party leadership today despite reservations expressed by the rank-and-file membership.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4--The World Series is nothing new to Hank Bauer, the manager of the Baltimore Orioles. He played in nine of them for Casey Stengel's New York Yankees between 1949 and 1959, and seemed as happily relaxed and unperturbed as ever as he entered one for the first time as master strategist.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 4-- The military Governor of the Eastern Region ordered today that Northerner's be repatriated following random retaliatory attacks on Northern Hausa tribesmen living in the East.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 4--Miss Deborah Donkin and William Allen Wells 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Orin Vernon Wells of Rome, plan to be married in January.
George I. Marcus of 280 Prospect Avenue, Hackensack, N.J., a lawyer and president of the Marcus and Vogel Construction Company, Hackensack, died here Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. His age was 64.

WESTON, Mass., Oct. 4--Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. West Jr. have announced the engagement of Mrs. West's daughter, Miss Dorothy Ridgway Macy, to Lawrence Barton Damon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Damon of Chestnut Hill and West Harwich, Mass.
MIAMI, Oct. 4--Hurricane Inez, churning backwards from the Bahamas, cut across the Florida Keys with winds up to 110 miles an hour today, then drove into the Gulf of Mexico.
BUFFALO, Oct. 4 (AP)--A United States Attorney said today the general counsel of the Central Intelligence Agency could testify at the trial of two men on conspiracy charges in a bomber-export deal.
Richard D. Peters has been named to the editorial board of The New York Times, it was announced yesterday by John B. Oakes, editor of The Times editorial page.
MIAMI, Oct. 4--Cuba, East Germany and the Soviet Union signed a $24-million agreement today for the purchase of electrical equipment to modernize Cuban sugar mills.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 4--Postal couriers were stayed from the swift completion of their appointed rounds in one of Fairfield County's most elegant neighborhoods yesterday, and the tremors reached all the way to the halls of Congress.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4-- Gov. Edmund G. Brown today courted the votes of California real estate men, with whom he fought vigorously over housing discrimination in the 1964 campaign.

An 11-ton tan concrete panel, dotted with coin-sized brown pebbles, and two Ushaped smaller sections were hoisted into place yesterday as workmen started putting up the exterior of the 13-story Madison Square Garden Sports and Entertainment Center.

Although all key members of Georgia Tech's undefeated football squad were considered surprisingly healthy yesterday as they prepared for Saturday's nationally televised meeting with unbeaten Tennessee, all was not well in the Engineers' camp.
