HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 4-- The engagement of Miss Anne Gellermann, daughter of Mrs. Ellen Meservey Gellermann of Hanover and the late Dr. Josef E. Gellermann of Washington, to John Rogers Chamberlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Waldo Chamberlin of Hanover, has been announced by the prospective bride's mother.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (UPI)-- Charles H. Percy returned from two weeks of seclusion in Colifornia tonight to resume the Republican senatorial campaign that was interrupted by the slaying of his daughter Valerie.
For the second time since early Monday morning, a cab driver has been robbed and locked in the trunk of his taxi.

GOLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Oct. 4--At 7:45 A.M. Saturday, Mrs. S. Trevor Pardee was out at "Aunt Nan's Beach" near here, in blustery winds and 45-degree temperature, dressed in tennis sneakers, ski jacket and bright floral print pants, picking mussels off the rocks at low tide.

Lynda Bird Johnson, 22year-old daughter of the President, was back in New York City yesterday doing two things she has done so often lately--checking employment opportunities and visiting with her frequent escort, George Hamilton, the actor.
TRENTON, Oct. 4--Couples adopting children through the state are no longer required to give their religious affiliation and be recommended by a religious leader.
Reeling like a dazed boxer, the stock market stumbled through periods of price drops and advances yesterday before closing in a thoroughly confused state.
TECUMSEH, Mich., Oct. 4 (AP)--The Tecumseh Products Corporation moved yesterday to fill the gap caused by the sudden resignation of Lewis Lamm, but it left Mr. Lamm's departure unexplained.

BUFFALO, Oct. 4--Paul L. Adams, the Conservative candidate for Governor, said today that Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.'s candidacy was the result of an "arrangement" between the Liberal and Republican parties.

WHEN Sondra Lee, dancer, actress, painter and home-furnisher extraordinary, opened her door one morning on 34th Street near 10th Avenue, a Victorian sofa almost fell on her. Quite a bit the worse for wear and down to its muslin, the sofa bore a tag saying: "Love and kisses."

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 4-- Mrs. Murray Gordon of Elmwood, the defending champion, scored 40, 41-81 at the 5,849yard, par 74 Fenway Golf Club today for a two-stroke lead after the first round of the 33d annual women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester counties.
Five critics of the Warren Commission Report on the assassination of President Kennedy will participate in a threehour discussion on Channel 5 at 9 P.M. Saturday, Nov. 12.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--The cost of the war in Vietnam increased the yearly rate of defense spending by $3-billion or a little more in the third quarter of this year, according to preliminary Government estimates.

The New York Giants regrouped yesterday at Yankee Stadium to hear about their most recent deficiencies, Tuesday being known as "chew out" day. That is what Ray Wietecha the former Giant center of renown, labeled Tuesday in reference to the weekly critical coaching review of the film of the last Sunday's game.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (UPI)-- The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit upheld today the conviction and five-year prison sentence of James R. Hoffa, teamsters union president, on charges of fraud and conspiracy involving the union's pension fund. The ruling was a 2-to-1 decision.

The concern expressed by Gardner Ackley, President Johnson's chief economic adviser, over the inflationary impact of the American Airlines wage settlement is unquestionably well founded. But his indignation at the company's agreement to a two-year increase of 15 per cent would come with more grace if Dr. Ackley had acknowledged the extent of the Administration's responsibility for the development.

The managing director of the International Monetary Fund cautioned American businessmen yesterday that it would be 1968 "at the earliest" before a plan for a new international currency to supplement gold would be ready.

The British have stopped losing gold and foreign exchange reserves. The small gain registered last month suggests that the Labor Government's severe measures to restore foreign confidence in the pound and to produce a surplus in the British balance of payments are finally working.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 4--When Ho Chi Minh and David BenGurion were revolutionaries plotting their respective people's independence in the same hotel in Paris 20 years ago, the Vietnamese leader invited the Zionist to set up a Jewish government in exile on Vietnamese soil.
MADRID, Oct. 4--Yankeestyle Cervantes won over the Spanish-style Cervantes in the judgment of Madrid theater critics and audiences this week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--The Senate passed an antipoverty bill tonight after cutting it to the $1.75-billion approved by the House last week. The vote on final passage was 49 to 20.
ROME, Oct. 4 (UPI)--Mrs. Carol Lopez, formerly the stepmother of Lord Snowdon, the husband of Princess Margaret of Britain, was fatally injured in an automobile accident today.

Dr. Rene Jules Dubos, who pioneered in discovering antibiotic drugs to fight germs and who is now exploring ways in which early biological influences set the pattern for life, was named yesterday as 1966 winner of what is called "an American Nobel prize."

MADRID, Oct. 4--Spain moved tonight to close the land frontier with Gibraltar to all trade and vehicular traffic. It was another step designed to force Britain to accept Spanish sovereignty over the colony.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 (AP)--Willam B. Dickinson, president of the Associated Press Managing Editors Association, declared today that restrictions on pretrial news coverage proposed to the American Bar Association by a special panel "would deny the public information regarding crimes to which it is entitled, and which it must have."
WILTON, Conn., Oct. 4--Mr. and Mrs, William Eynon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susannah Gale Eynon, to Emory Wilson Sanders, son of Dr. and Mrs. James Sanders of Rye, N.H.

The Cunard Line and the Bermuda Trade Development Board said yesterday they had reached agreement on major points for a Cunard passenger service between New York and Bermuda next year.

Sherman Billingsley, for more than 36 years host to hundreds of social, political, business and theatrical personalities at the Stork Club, died early yesterday at his apartment, 500 East 83d Street. He was 66 years old.

Paperboard production rose 7.1 per cent with 472,400 tons in the week ended Oct. 1, from 440,900 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

Major civil rights groups have joined with community leaders in circulating a petition that accuses the city school system of providing "criminally inferior education" to children in Harlem and other ghetto communities.

With the football season only three weeks old, no major college is unscored on, according to National Collegiate statistics issued yesterday.
As the World Series opens today on the other side of the continent, New Yorkers at least have the consolation of knowing that both their teams made baseball history in the season just past.

The International Business Machines Corporation demonstrated at a news conference yesterday its first commercial model of a machine, known as the IBM 1287, that reads or recognizes handwritten numbers from 1 to 10, as well as five handwritten letters. The letters are C, S, T, X and Z.

HONOLULU, Oct. 4--The world's airlines remained stalemated yesterday on the question on putting international fares across the Pacific on a per-mile basis.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4--What do Dave McNally and Jim Palmer have in com mon with Don Drysdale and Sandy Koufax? This is a query that would draw a blank stare from the average man in the street. He could quickly identify Drysdale and Koufax, the Gold Dust twins of the Dodgers, because they have become household names. But McNally and Palmer would ring no bells.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 4-- The chairman of the Federal Power Commission, Lee C. White, assured gas-industry leaders here today that his commission had no anti-industry sentiments.

A poet has been discovered in the Department of State. Her name is Katie Louchheim (Mrs. Walter C. Louchheim Jr.), and she has just been appointed deputy assistant secretary of state for educational and cultural affairs. Her colleagues are pleased, but a bit apprehensive about her first book.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5--The Senate voted $2.93-billion for foreign aid today after cutting $110-million from the amount recommended by the Appropriations Committee. The vote was 52 to 22.

Tentative plans include having Walter Cronkite, Harry Reasoner and Mike Wallace do a walk-on at the end of a Garry Moore comedy sketch.
PARIS, Oct. 5 The French Cabinet approved today the nominations of six outstanding French athletes to the National Order of the Legion of Honor.

PATERSON, N.J. A personable young Republican insurance broker named Richard Michael De Marco is trying to replace Representative Charles Samuel Joelson, Democrat, in the Eighth Congressional District this year. Or maybe in the election of November, 1968.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 This morning, Jim Palmer kept pacing around the Baltimore Oriole clubhouse, picking up a magazine from another player's locker, leafing through it, dropping it, then picking up another. Finally, he looked up.
YONKERS, Oct. 6 Choice Line, the 4-year-old chestnut owned by Lee Benson of West Hempstead, L.I., finally found the winners' circle at Yonkers Raceway tonight after two close misses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Supermarket customers were told today by the President's Committee on Consumer Interests what most had long suspected: Their food budgets can be stretched if they leave their husbands and children at home while they shop. WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) The Senate approved a new approach to the problem of narcotic addiction today by passing a bill providing for civil commitment and treatment.

TWINSBURG, Ohio, Oct. 6 (AP) Striking United Auto Workers Union members voted tonight to end their strike at the Chrysler Corporation's Twinsburg stamping plant and will return to work at 7 A.M. tomorrow, union officials reported.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 6 Governnor Rockefeller assailed today the Campaign tactics of Frank D. O'Connor, his Democratic opponent, calling Mr. O'Connor "toally unqualified" and "unworthy" to be Governor.
Job shifts and pay rises that were put into effect on Sept. 26 have added $117,000 a year to the city payrolls, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Under Secretary of the Treasury Joseph. W. Barr indicated today that the Government was seriously considering forming a new corporation to raise funds to finance all of the Government's many direct-lending programs.

ATHENS, Oct. 6 A heated political argument has developed here following publication of an article by C.L. Sulzberger on the editorial page of The New York Times yesterday on King Constantine's views on Greece's future.
HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 6--The moon "is not a cold, dead, lifeless place" but a still-evolving body "very nearly as dynamic as the earth."
The spot rate on the British pound was substantially higher yesterday in active trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
This week's creeping bullishness in the bond market continued to gain strength yesterday, helped by a feeling that this year's crest in demand for capital may have definitely passed.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 6 (UPI) Jim Kaat, a 25-game winner for the Minnesota Twins this season, called the loss of Johnny Sain, the team's pitching coach, and Hal Naragon, the bull pen coach, a "great mistake" yesterday.

LONGBINH, South Vietnam, Oct. 4 In this town, 15 miles northeast of Saigon, the United States has begun building a vast military "suburb" designed to help get about 35,000 American servicemen out of Vietnam's overcrowded capital.
LONDON, Oct. 6 A Welshborn journalist says he has found new evidence to support a theory that the illegitimate son of a Welsh king founded a colony in America 300 years before Columbus.

**La Stella, 102-11 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, IL 9-9511. Of course, you may not know who is dining next to you at La Stella and the police have been known to interrupt a meal midway, but the kitchen of this small establishment in Forest Hills has much to recommend it.
Pledging conference for Development Program -- Heard statements by Secretary General and by administrator of the Development Program; received pledges of $86.9-million from 101 Governments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 President Johnson made a fervent plea today for Congressional passage of the demonstration cities bill, the keystone of his program to rescue the nation's cities from decay and poverty.

The forthcoming report by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York on fair trial and freedom of the press will differ drastically from the recent American Bar Association panel's report suggesting stringent curbs on news media and the police.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The Administration sought today to calm fears that the declining stock market might be signaling an economic recession.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 (AP) Moe Drabowsky, the pitching hero of yesterday's first World Series game, was accidentally doused with a pot of hot coffee today at a Los Angeles hotel.
The Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade association, announced here yesterday the election of Francis S. Williams as chairman of the board of governors.

Governor Rockefeller's annual budget review can make New Yorkers, excessively serene about the state's fiscal position. It is, of course, welcome news that increased income will guarantee the state a balance if not a surplus despite outlays estimated. at over $4 billion.
BERLIN, Oct. 6 East and West Germans arranged today to reopen a special passes office to hand out permits to West Berliners to cross the Berlin wall for visits on urgent family matters.

Glimmers of a thaw in the frozen climate of Soviet American relations provide grounds for a measure of cautious optimism, though the shadow, of Vietnam still hangs heavily over both Moscow and Washington. The weight of that shadow was unhappily illustrated by the debate over priorities in the United Nations Political Committee yesterday.

MONROE, Mich., Oct. 6 (AP) Officials at the Enrico Fermi atomic power plant near here sought today to learn the cause of a radioactive argon gas leakage Wednesday that caused a plant shutdown that is expected to last three weeks.

GLENEAGLES, Scotland, Oct. 16 (AP) A four-man team from Colonie, N.Y., shot a 14-underpar 54 over the Gleneagles Queen's Club course today in the professional-amateur fourball foursomes handicap golf tournament.

SAN DIEGO, Oct. 6 The care, feeding and ultimate preservation of the Indonesian giant Komodo dragon, the Tasmanian thylacine, the Arabian oryx and other such exotic creatures were scrutinized and debated today at a meeting of 91 wildlife specialists from around the world.
The Canadian potato crop is doing fine, and as a result potato futures in New York dropped again yesterday, to continue a recent trend.

Postponement of the Diamond Centennial Ball, planned for Oct. 27 at the Americana Hotel, was announced yesterday by its three chairmen, Mrs. Edward R. Murrow, Mrs. Lytle Hull and Mrs. Charles W. Engelhard. In telegrams to those who have made reservations, the chairmen gave no subsequent dates, nor reasons for the postponement.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Oct. 6 Jay Samuel Stowell, an official of the Congregationalist, Presbyterian and Methodist churches for more than 40 years and the author of 20 books and numerous religious and secular articles, died here Tuesday evening. He was 83 years old.

Senator Clifford Case of New Jersey carries a strong record into his campaign for re-election. He is a progressive Republican who has shown both independence and responsibility in assessing public issues and voting his convictions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Jack Hood Vaughn, Director of the Peace Corps, left today for Africa to investigate, among other things, an unusually large number of complaints by corpsmen about living allowances and conditions in Nigeria.
The Right Rev. James A. Pike has struck back at his chief accuser, the Right Rev. Henry I. Louttit, Episcopal Bishop of South Florida.

ATHENS The great Greek poet Cavafy once inquired: "And now, what will become of us without barbarians? They were a kind of solution." For postwar Greece the Communists for a long time served the role of ancient "barbarians," a unifying menace.

State health officials found 15 staff nurses on duty for 1,039 patients yesterday afternoon at the Queens Hospital Center. They also learned that the center's recovery room was closed on weekends and patients were transferred directly from the operating room to the understaffed wards.

President Johnson's remarks about plans for his expanded trip to Asia later this month were a mixture of hopes, desires and pessimism on the progress of efforts to find a peaceful solution to the Vietnamese war.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 6 It seems that it was only yesterday that Dartmouth and Princeton, both with perfect records, met for the 1965 Ivy League football championship and the Tigers suffered their first defeat in two years and gave up the title.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 Maury Wills, the captain of the Los Angeles Dodgers, who will tour Japan right after the World Series, was asked if his forces could bounce back after losing the first two games to Baltimore.

Frank D. O'Connor called for state constitutional amendments yesterday to provide stronger home rule in fiscal and other fields, a halt to "deception" in bond issues, a merit system for selecting judges, and a primary for naming statewide candidates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner has recommended that Mohawk Airlines' routes be realigned and simplified to include virtually all the changes the Utica-based airline had requested.

Gardner Ackley, chairman of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers, yesterday called anew for labor and management to exercise self-restraint in-forthcoming wage and price considerations. At a luncheon at the National Industrial Conference Board's one-day. "Business in 1967" meeting, the chief economic adviser to the
Sears, Roebuck Co., announced yesterday in Chicago that it achieved record sales in September for the 65th consecutive month.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 106.1 on Wednesday from 105.8 on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Fifteen major American manufacturers of plumbing fixtures were indicted today on charges of participation in a criminal conspiracy to fix prices.
President Johnson will visit the metropolitan area today to deliver a foreign policy address at the National Conference of Editorial Writers here, and to speak at a Democratic rally in Newark.
Sponsors of the Adele Rosenwald Levy Memorial proposed for Riverside Park have abandoned it, they informed Mayor Lindsay yesterday.

Sixteen high school students who swarmed onto a Brooklyn bus yesterday without paying, climbed over seats and tussled in the aisles found themselves arrested for disorderly conduct and carried to a station house in the bus.
LONDON, Oct. 6 Britain offered today to put the issue of her right to the Rock of Gibraltar before the International Court of Justice.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Oct. 6 J. Wolcott Brown of Manasquan finished with 14 consecutive pars today as he fired a 40, 36 76 to successfully defend his title in the 45th annual New Jersey State Seniors Golf Association championship with a 151 at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 6 Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexel 3d of Stonor Lodge, Newport, and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Noreen Drexel, to Bradford Hastings Walker of New York and Richmond. He is a son of Mrs. James A. Burden of Locust Valley, L.I., and Aiken, S.C., and of the late Bradford Hastings Walker of Richmond.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 In the long catalogue of distinguished American public servants none has earned more respect or affection in the major world capitals than Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., the newly appointed U.S. Ambassador to the Soviet Union.
WHEN you begin to dream, you're home.
THE death of Albert H. Morehead came as a sad shock to hundreds of bridge players who knew him personally and thousands more who enjoyed his writings during the last three decades.

Radio station WOR-FM, which has been broadcasting rock 'n' roll music without interruption by announcers, will add the chitter-chatter of four disk jockeys, beginning tomorrow. A station official asserted, however that WOR-FM would not become a "screaming station."

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6--How values and reactions have shifted over the years, in baseball and in life, was demonstrated today by the case of William Henry Davis, resident center fielder of the Los Angeles Dodgers.
David S. Peoples and William S. Smith Jr. have been elected executive vice presidents of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 House and Senate conferees agreed today on a foreign aid appropriation of $2,936,000,000 for the fiscal year ending June 30. The "compromise" agreement was identical with the amount voted yesterday by the Senate.
Corporate bond prices advanced with some vigor yesterday, but other divisions of the bond market appeared to be shutting down early for the weekend.
This country's first "theological university" is rapidly taking shape in Berkeley, Calif

MANHASSET, L.I., Oct. 7 Miss Olivia King Sedlmayr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius H. Sedlmayr of Plandome, was married this afternoon to Olcott Whitman Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Olcott D. Smith of Farmington. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph E. MacGinnis at Christ Episcopal Church here:
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 7 (AP) Robert DePugh, leader of the militant anti-Communist Minutemen, pleaded not guilty today to violating the National Firearms Act.

Three Transit Authority detectives one hidden in a motorman's cab and the two others posing as passengers arrested 72 DeWitt Clinton High School boys on a Jerome Avenue IRT train yesterday when the boys began roughhousing and pulled the emergency cord.
Dr. Edmund Prince Fowler a leading ear specialist who also invented several significant medical devices, died yesterday in his home, 319 East 50th Street. His age was 93.

MOUNT FUJI, Japan, Oct. 7 (AP) Scotland's Jim Clark turned in the fastest unofficial time today in the initial warmup practice at the Fuji Speedway for Japan's first Indianapolis-style auto race Sunday.
The election of Marco Buitoni, 35 years old, as president and chief executive of the Buitoni Foods Corporation was announced here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) The House voted today to remove 20-year-old restrictions on the appointment of women generals and admirals.

Two small boys testified in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday that they had seen Ernest Gallashaw with a gun near the corner where 10-year old Eric Dean was slain, but the young witnesses told conflicting stories.
DETROIT, Oct. 7 (UPI)--The nation's automobile makers plan to complete their one-millionth 1967 model next week, Ward's Automotive Reports stated today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 Citizens who had not yet heard that Milton J. Shapp "makes sense for Pennsylvania" and is "a man you can trust" as Governor began getting the message this week from a bright autumn forest of 1,200 orange billboards and from almost every frequency on the radio dial.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 7 Vice Admiral A.R. Khan, commander in chief of the Pakistani Navy, was appointed Defense Minister today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AR) The Government asked a Federal District Court here today to dismiss a suit filed by the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association and 12 member concerns seeking to block enforcement of new Federal regulations on dietary supplements and vitamin and mineral fortified foods.

Fillies will be out for the big money at Aqueduct today when nine of them compete in the one-mile Frizette. With this number the gross value will be $132,925, the richest of all 14 runnings of the test for 2year-olds. The winner's share will be $95,425, a sum that would seem to warrant the attraction of three supplementary nominations, at $5,000 each, which happens to be the case.
The spot rate on the British pound was steady yesterday, closing at $2.7918 on active trading on foreign-exchange markets here.

CHILDRESS, Tex., Oct. 7 (UPI) A man who admitted he was high on pep pills hijacked a Continental Trailways bus tonight and threatened to kill an 18-year-old girl before a highway patrolman knocked him senseless with a blow to the jaw.
NEWARK, Oct. 7 President Johnson switched from world affairs to home-front politics while crossing the Hudson today to make his sharpest attack of the year upon the Republican party.
Efforts to resolve the controversy over Intermediate School 201 in East Harlem have been slowed down by the fact that the negotiators are trying to keep two separate issues in mind.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 7 (UPI) A 28-year-old Long Island woman received a suspended sentence and three years' probation today on her guilty plea to reduced charges in the fatal beating of her sixyear-old son.

THE National Educational Television Playhouse opened last night with a handsomely mounted production of Tennessee Williams's dark and obscure one-act play, "Ten Blocks on the Camino Real," over Channel 13. It was an odd choice to inaugurate a major series of television theater under noncommercial auspices.

The state is buying Prospect Hospital in the Bronx, Mother Cabrini Hospital in upper Manhattan and Mount Morris Park Hospital in Harlem for its new narcotics program, Governor Rockefeller's office has announced.
GENEVA--The red, blue and white neon signs along the lake advertise airlines, watches and chocolate. They tell much of Geneva's story.
DETROIT, Oct. 7 (AP) The full production of the Chrysler Corporation's 1967 model cars was in sight today as workers returned to their jobs at a stamping plant in Twinsburg, Ohio.
A Federal grand jury in Manhattan has indicted two men on charges of committing perjury in denying that they touted the stock of Fotochrome, Inc.

YONKERS, Oct. 7 If Speedy Rodney trots as fast as he did the last time he appeared here; if All Aflame manages to "stay flat;" and if Earl Laird, an 18-time winner this season gets racing luck, a lot of harness racing fans may be in for a surprise tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.

Howard J. Samuels, Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, urged yesterday that future candidates for Attorney Generals and Controllers be picked by the Governor from lists put forward by nonpartisan commissions.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7 (AP) Howard W. Johnson was inaugurated as 12th president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology today in ceremonies attended by leading educators.

RENO, Oct. 7 Mrs. Sarah Spencer-Churchill Russell was granted a divorce today from Edwin F. Russell of New York, a former publisher of Vogue magazine. He is now publisher of The Harrisburg (Pa.) Patriot-News.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 7 (AP) A Federal grand jury indicted Carlos Marcello, an underworld figure, today on a charge of assaulting and intimidating an F.B.I. agent.
The city yesterday turned over the Essex Street market, where business is conducted in English, Spanish, Italian and Yiddish, to the l20 merchants who operate their stands there.
The James Weldon Johnson Community Centers will gain from a supper dance at Il-Mio Discotheque at Delmonico's Hotel next Tuesday after a benefit preview of "The Apple Tree" at the Shubert Theater.

Joel J. Tyler, Commissioner of Licenses, said yesterday that used car dealers and junkyard operators who refused to cooperate with the Police Department's crackdown on vehicle thefts faced the loss of their licenses.

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, charged yesterday that Governor Rockefeller was spending "outrageous" and "unconscionable" amounts of money to buy the election next month.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7--The Wholesale Price Index, which generally foretells consumer price trends some months in advance, remained stable in September for the first time in six months.

Passers Will Lead Jets and Chargers Here Tonight The San Diego Chargers and the New York Jets, the American Football League's division leaders, meet at Shea Stadium tonight. The game may be momentous for both teams, two young quarterbacks and anyone arriving late by automobile.
The New York Telephone Company will furnish the scores of World Series games. The number is ME 7-1212, the company's time bureau.

A meeting of Senators Jacob K. Javits and Robert F. Kennedy and Mayor Lindsay to discuss the campaign to retain the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board was abruptly postponed last night and scheduled for Wednesday "due to unexpected scheduling complications."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 The House and Senate quickly passed a $2.94-billion foreign aid appropriation today, sending it to President Johnson a day after the compromise was whipped together
MONTREAL, Oct. 7 Nineteen students were reported killed tonight when a bus en route to a high school dance was struck by a train heading for Toronto.
BERLIN, Oct. 7 Using shovels to dig their way under border barriers and taking advantage of a darkened "death strip," four young East Germans made their escape to West Berlin early today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 Milton J. Shapp, Democratic nominee for Governor of Pennsylvania, asked Supreme Court Justice John M. Harlan today to delay the proposed merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads. Mr. Shapp said he was a Pennsy stockholder.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) Maj. Gen. William Clyde Baker Jr., assistant to the secretary of the American Battle Monuments Commission here, died Wednesday night in Walter Reed Army Hospital at the age of 62.

Two youths walked down the street. Each wore luxuriant hair not only down to their brows but below their turtlenecks. A middle-aged woman with a tight mouth and pixie glasses turned to look at them in scorn and distaste, and said, to no one or anyone: "I think it's disgusting. If they were mine, I'd shave every hair off their heads!"
HALIFAX, N.S. Persons in Nova Scotia will be required soon to disclose interest or finance charges both as an annual percentage and as a dollar amount.
PANTS suits may be today's fashion fad, but tomorrow they will be a permanent part of a woman's wardrobe.
THE NEW YORK Jets and New York Giants bump into unbeaten division leaders this weekend, and both local teams are underdogs.

President Johnson outlined yesterday some steps toward reconciliation with Eastern Europe and suggested that cutbacks of Soviet and United States forces in Germany might improve prospects for a lasting peace.
Irwin M. Berliner, a corporation, real estate and estates lawyer, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 1111 Park Avenue. He was 72 years old.
ATHENS, Oct. 7 Extreme leftists called on the Greek people today to stand by and "crush any dictatorial attempt."
Mrs. Rose Finkenthal Goldberg, a retired actress of the Yiddish theater, died Thursday in Community Hospital, Brooklyn. She was 78 years old and lived at 125 Brighton 11th Street, Brooklyn.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped sharply yesterday in the heaviest trading since Aug. 30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 A State Department spokesman said tonight that he had no knowledge of a specific United States request to Foreign Minister Malik for aid in ending the Vietnam war.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 7 A fleet of 70 cruising yachts set sail off Flat Neck Point at sunset today on Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual Stratford Shoal overnight race, traditionally the last distance sailing event on Long Island Sound.
Salvatore Pinto, a painter, engraver and photographer, died on Wednesday at Temple University Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 61 years old and lived at Harvey Cedars in Long Beach Island, N.J.
MOSCOW, Oct. 7 The Soviet Union today ordered the expulsion of all Chinese students tn retaliation for Peking's equivalent action against Soviet students last month.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 Textiles, chemical products, some types of machinery and metal goods are the principal kinds of goods that henceforth can be freely exported to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.

ROME, Oct. 7 Foreign Minister Amintore Fanfani has proposed to members of the Atlantic Alliance a technological "Marshall plan" designed to bridge the widening gap between technical accomplishments of Europe and of the United States.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 7 The Tattersalls fall standardbred yearling sale closed last night with a record gross of $2,535,000 for 336 horses.

DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 7 (AP) Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, and Mayor Orville Hubbard, a Republican, clashed today over a plan to ask Dearborn voters whether the United States should withdraw its troops from Vietnam.

Jacob R. Kramer, president and founder of J.R. Kramer, Inc., butter dealers of 45-10, 94th Street, Elmhurst, Queens, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 68 years old and a resident of 2 Fifth Avenue.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 7 (AP) A granite stone from the tomb of Queen Isabella of Spain was presented to the City of St. Louis today for the cornerstone of the Spanish Pavilion in St. Louis.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 7 The Baltimore Orioles returned home to a roaring civic celebration today as the World Series moved east with the American League champions leading the Los Angeles Dodgers, two games to none.
Some jittery holders of long cocoa contracts sold yesterday, and cocoa futures dropped sharply for a while. Then, buying by a big cocoa manufacturer pushed prices up a little.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 7 Ronnie Boss of the Narragansett (R.I.) fleet won the national sailing championship of the Herreshoff Class S on Long Island Sound today. The three-race series was among representatives of Narragansett and Western Long Island Sound Class S fleets.

The chief purchasing officer for the Pentagon in the New York area has branded as "unequivocally false" a charge by George A. Murphy, chairman of the Irving Trust Company, that the Defense Department had been noticeably slow recently in paying its bills.
WHILE some Wall Street brokerage houses try to discourage their customers from doing it, short-selling in this bear market continues at a pace that is surprising the experts.
Peter, Paul and Mary reminded everyone in the audience at Philharmonic Hall last night that they have been together six years now.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) About 22,000 Western Electric installers have turned down a proposed labor contract negotiated by the company and the Communications Workers of America.

The Schering Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with Farbenfabriken Bayer, A.G., of West Germany to form an organization in the United States, which will market the German company's pharmaceutical products.

IN the introduction to an article on the Vietnam protest movement included in his new book, Irving Howe remarks: "I wrote as someone who supported the movement, but was uneasy about some of its methods and allies." It is a characteristic statement. A large part of this new collection of political pieces is devoted to defining...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7--The United States Government said today it was "very disappointed" in the proposal on agricultural tariffs that has been made by the European Common Market.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 8 (AP) Both Communist and non-Communist nations have asked Indonesia to take an active role in seeking a peaceful settlement of the Vietnam war, Foreign Minister Adam Malik of Indonesia said here today. "We have been requested by several sides to take an active role to help solve the Vietnam problem."

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 Ronald Reagan joined Mayor Samuel W. Yorty at the Mayor's monthly press luncheon at City Hall today, but, like his opponent, Gov. Edmund G. Brown, the Republican candidate came away without any endorsement of his gubernatorial cause.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 7 Brig. Gen. Shaban Opolot, chief of Uganda's defense staff, has been arrested by order of President Milton Obote.

THE New York City Opera is giving a little Mozart festival within the scope of its season at the State Theater in Lincoln Center. Last night it turned to the second of the four Mozart operas in its current repertory, "The Abduction From the Seraglio."
"There is too much emphasis on the drama of sex, violence and introspection today,"' said the tall, blond, blue-eyed actress with a trace of a German accent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board today blamed the crew of a jetliner for a crash that killed 58 persons near Cincinnati last fall.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 A new way of administering general anesthetics was viewed today as offering hope of substantially increasing their effectiveness and versatility.

Arthur R. Brissel, secretary and treasurer of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union, died of a heart attack on Thursday at Samaritan Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 74 years old and lived at 440 Lenox Road in Brooklyn.

President Johnson's aims for the Atlantic alliance, Europe and East-West relations are strikingly similar to those Foreign Secretary George Brown expressed to the British Labor party conference this week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 Senate leaders of both parties moved today to head off a Southern filibuster against a belated effort to restore an elected city government to the District of Columbia.
ALVIN ROTH has had considerable success in at tracting expert players to his Mayfair House of Bridge, as the old Mayfair Bridge Club at 119 West 57th Street is now styled.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 7 Arthur G. McDowell of Philadelphia, a long-time labor leader and, until 1941, an official of the Socialist party, died yesterday in Harrisburg Hospital of injuries he suffered in an automobile accident. He was 57 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) The National Mediation Board set aside today the representation election involving three unions seeking bargaining rights for some 5,000 employes of Pan American World Airways.

"The basic fact we must face is rising costs and declining profits," Jackson Martindell, chairman of the American Institute of Management, said yesterday. He addressed a daylong meeting of the institute in the Hotel Plaza that was attended by more than 200 executives of big and small companies.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 7 The International Control Commission made up of representatives of India, Canada and Poland said today that "conditions have not been considered sufficiently secure" to permit full, normal patrolling of the demilitarized zone in Vietnam despite the recent pause in the bombing of a small part of it.
AUCKLAND, N.Z., Oct. 7 (AP) One of the world's top track and field coaches, Arthur Lydiard of New Zealand, has quit the job of coaching Mexicans for the 1968 Olympic games.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 7 (UPI) An earthquake jolted the Anchorage area today.
I'm a little baffled by this room. It makes a speaker have to talk out of both sides of his mouth.

OTTAWA, Oct. 7--Steven Truscott told the Supreme Court of Canada today that he had forgotten both the testimony and the names of five Crown witnesses at the trial that convicted him seven years ago of the rape killing of 12-year-old Lynne Harper, a schoolmate.

Dame Rebecca West, gratified at good reviews for her new book and its choice by the Book-of-the-Month Club, making it a best seller, finds pleasure in telling that she had the story in mind for 50 years. The book is "The Birds Fall Down," published by Viking Press.
WHEN Miriam Makeba moved to the United States from South Africa in 1959, the closely cropped hairdo she had worn all her life was virtually nonexistent among Negro women here.

GREENPORT, L.I., Oct. 6 Shell fishermen are looking with alarm into the cold blue waters of Peconic Bay, and gourmets might well join them. The succulent Peconic scallop, a mainstay of Long Island's fishing industry and sea food restaurants, is in drastically short supply.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 7 Vice Adm. John Louis Chew, U.S.N., and Mrs. Chew have announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Margaret Adams Chew, to Capt. Hawes Campbell 3d, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Campbell Jr. and the late Dr. Campbell of Richmond.

The furnishings and fixtures of the soon-to-be demolished Astor Hotel will find new homes, mainly in hotels and restaurants as far west as Illinois. An auction of the 600-room hotel's contents that began last Monday ended yesterday. There were 750 buyers, most of them hotel people.

Doubleday will publish the Apocrypha, "the lost books of the Bible," in six or seven volumes within the Anchor Bible. The books of the Apocrypha were included in early Latin and Greek editions of the Bible, but not in the Hebrew Bible.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct.7 Security officials are bracing for the sudden ending of the long, unexplained lull in major Vietcong terror in Saigon.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 7 The Los Angeles Dodgers looked so flat in losing the first two games of the World Series at home that the opinion of the experts, always willing to shift with the slightest breeze, now leans toward a Baltimore victory in five or even four games.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 7 Allied troops, continuing major campaigns on the central coastal plain and at the southern border of the demilitarized zone separating North Vietnam and South Vietnam, were reported yesterday to have killed 162 enemy soldiers in the last 24 hours.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 7 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Tran Van Do criticized a British Government peace plan for Vietnam today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 7 President Johnson and Secretary General Thant conferred for 50 minutes today on Vietnam and other world issues.

Continental Airlines has ordered three giant Boeing 747 superjets that it plans to convert for simultaneous passenger and cargo traffic, the company has announced. The planes will be delivered in the fall of 1970, and the company has an option for a fourth 747 for delivery in July, 1971.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 (AP) Clergy and church board members of the 7,500 Episcopal churches in the United States are being urged to send petitions to the Presiding Bishop, the Right Rev. John E. Hines, in New York, regarding the operation of the Episcopal Church pension fund.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 7 Two more deaths were reported today in student-police clashes in Uttar Pradesh.
HAMDEN, Conn., Oct. 7--Richmond Lennox Brown, a lawyer in New Haven, died last night in his home at 153 Armory Street. He was 81 years old.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 7 A car operated by Doris Duke, the 53-year-old heiress to one of America's greatest fortunes, struck and killed an old friend and house guest at the Duke estate here this afternoon.

In his important speech on East West relations yesterday President Johnson linked dramatic announcement of concrete actions with an eloquent statement of inspiring goals. This time, at least, he gave effect to a "deeds" as well as "words" policy one we have long advocated by announcing a radical reduction in the present barriers to American economic contact with Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, along with a strongly affirmative program of political reconciliation.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 7 (UPI)--The $61,602 Kentucky Futurity took a back seat in interest at the Lexington trotting track today as Bret Hanover stole the spotlight with a 1:53 3/5 mile for a world record.

Justice Joseph A. Brust issued an order in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday restraining the Board of Elections and the State Attorney General's office from requiring registrants to fill out their affidavits of literacy before inspectors at registration places.
PITTSFIELD, Mass, Oct 7 (AP) A prototype lighting system that cost only $39,000 was installed here recently. It permits small planes to land at night.

Winn-Dixie Stores, Inc., which operates a food chain of more than 675 stores, had a net income of $5,173,229, equal to 41 cents a share in the 12 weeks ended Sept. 17. This compares with $4,706,893, or 37 cents a share for the period last year. Sales rose $9,878,363, to $227,021,000.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell told the lawyer for a Harlem widow who had a $164,000 defamation judgment against him that "I will be old and senile and you will be a senior citizen before you will see a dime of this case," the lawyer testified yesterday.
MOSCOW, Oct. 7 (AP) Peking and other cities are still crowded with Red Guards and violence continues in China, Tass reported today.
Four major lumber associations reported a decline of 11 per cent in production for the week ended Oct. 1, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 7 Lord Haire of Whiteabbey, Northern Ireland, who came to the United States last month on a lecture tour sponsored by the British Information Service, died early this morning at Middlesex General Hospital.

A better method for selecting judges than the elective system that now prevails is one of the more important problems to be taken up by next year's constitutional convention. An inheritance from the era of Jackson, the present method has shown grievous faults that urgently demand a change.
LONDON, Oct. 7 (AP) The polluted air in the world's cities must be cleaned up quickly, 1,200 experts from 25 nations concluded today.

Directors of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad elected two new directors yesterday. The board decided not to select now a president to succeed Louis W. Menk, who became president of the Northern Pacific Railway on Oct. 1.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 7 (AP) South Carolina's Attorney General, Daniel R. McLeod, filed suit today against the Federal school desegregation guidelines in Federal District Court.

THE final harvest of ripe tomatoes is often too bounti- ful to be eaten fresh in spite of the many ways of preparing the fruit as a vegetable, salad, soup, stew or casserole ingredient. Some tomatoes can be preserved for future enjoyment in the form of tomato marmalade, a colorful and spicy confection.

BONN, Oct. 7 The public prosecutor in Cologne disclosed today that an investigation had been opened into the courtmartial and execution of two German Navy deserters five days after the end of World War II.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 7 The John Birch Society was criticized today by the president of St. Vincent College for allegedly curtailing a college forum this week at which a member of the Communist party was to speak.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) The State Department reported today that more than 50,000 immigrants who otherwise would still be awaiting United States entry had come to America under the new immigration law.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)-- The Senate voted today to appropriate $4,139,244,000 for public works projects throughout the country.

Roy Wilkins, executive director of the N.A.A.C.P., criticized yesterday an amendment to the school aid bill as "the latest and perhaps most devastating blow in the current campaign to destroy the civil rights advances of the last few years."
PARIS, Oct. 7 (AP) Hill Rise was scratched today from the Prix de L'Arc de Triomphe, Europe's richest horse race.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 7 Mrs. Murray Gordon of Elmwood, the defending champion, retained the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy today by scoring a 39, 39 78 at the Westchester Hills Golf Club for a 54-hole total of 241.
ADEN, Oct. 7 President Abdullah al-Salal purged the Yemeni Army of nearly 100 senior officers today.

AT a cocktail party in Washington in 1947, the host turned to Dr. Edward Uhler Condon, then head of the National Bureau of Standards, and asked him what he knew about unidentified flying objects. "Dr. Condon," he pleaded, "tell us all about it."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 The Secretary of Commerce, John T. Connor, invited the public today to offer "suggestions, opinions and proposals" on Federal safety standards for automobiles and other highway vehicles.

SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 7 Political tension grew again today as opposition members walked out of the National Assembly in protest against the way the Government had handle a saccharin-smuggling scandal.

BEVERLY, Mass., Oct. 7 (AP) Maj. Gen. Sherman Miles, who was acting chief of military intelligence in Washington when the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor in 1941, died today at Beverly Hospital after a long illness. He was 83 years old.
MIAMI, Oct. 7 A massive search began today for 44 Cuban refugees feared drowned when Hurricane Inez overturned the 24-foot boat in which they were fleeing their country earlier this week.

Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel is prepared to give immunity to some or all of the 13 reputed Mafia leaders who were seized by the police on Sept 22, it was learned yesterday. These men, who were seized in a Forest Hills restaurant, have been under bail of $100,000 each as material witnesses in a grand jury investigation.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that 450,000 copies of a booklet spelling out the rights and obligations of tenants are now being distributed.
The Italian Communists have been on a downward slope for many months. As their power diminishes, a major and beneficial shift is taking place in Italian politics.
YONKERS, Oct. 7 Forty of the 390 waiters employed at the two restaurants at Yonkers Raceway walked off their jobs at 6 o'clock tonight, two hours before post time.

The Metropolitan Tribunal of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York upheld this week the Brooklyn Diocesan Tribunal in its refusal to intervene in the ouster of 15 professors from St. John's University last January.

Prices on the London stock market closed with small but widespread losses yesterday after a quiet trading session.

A new choral group is being sponsored by the New York Choral Society to encourage choral activity of quality by young men and women of high school and college age. Called the University Chorale, it will be open to qualified amateur singers between the ages of 17 and 21. A repertory of major choral works will be sung under the direction of Martin Josman. Rehearsals begin today at 10 A.M. at 2 West 64th Street.

DAVID and Ann Gillespie are a young British couple who gross $180,000 a year designing "everything from stamps to elephants." They are quick to point out, however, that one of their elephants was banned from Britain's expressways because it was too lifelike.

One of the hotels is even installing seven-foot beds to accommodate professional basketball players.

NOT only the threat but the use of tactical nuclear weapons is advocated by Bernard Brodie. BALTIMORE, Oct. 8--Paul Blair should stay this lucky all his life. Originally signed by the New York Mets, of all teams, the 22-year-old outfielder was snatched away in the first year draft by the Baltimore Orioles in 1962 for the usual ransom price of $8,000. If he had remained with the dear, old Metsies, he could have rejoiced in their phenomenal rise to ninth place.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Rowe Brine have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Muriel Alison Brine, to John Fredric Rogers, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Cochrane, Rogers of North Cornwall.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Oct. 9 Miss Adrienne Gostin, daughter of Mrs. George J. Gostin of Metuchen and the late Mr. Gostin, was married today to Robert David Kivelson. He is the son of Mrs. Herman Kivelson of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Kivelson. Rabbi Herschel Matt performed the ceremony at Far Hills Inn. He was assisted by Cantor Benjamin Stein.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) The Government awarded today $1.8-million in contracts for 24 research projects aimed at developing a better and cheaper artificial kidney.

BUFFALO, Oct. 9 (AP) After a 90-minute discussion with Customs officials, a small group of Quakers today succeeded in taking into Canada $75 worth of medical supplies. Their leader said the supplies might eventually get to North Vietnam.

HOW do you feel about moon reindeer? Can you, here and now, identify with girls who enter into pacts with magicians so that, while they get the man their hearts crave, they are transmogrified into white reindeer who lure young men over deathly precipices? It is difficult. Few of us know reindeer at all intimately, and it is difficult to accept as very significant those of our acquaintances whose best friends are reindeer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today that he would run for re-election in 1970.

Miss Susan Carla Berns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Berns of New York and Westhampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Van Wolf, son of Mrs. Chauncey B. Wolf of Baltimore and the late Mr. Wolf. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony in the Appleman Chapel of the Park Avenue Synagogue. He was assisted by Cantor David J. Putterman.
Marilyn Aschner of Queens College won the Eastern women's college tennis championship yesterday for the second straight year.

Yeoryia Megremis's New York debut recital at Carnegie Recital Hall late yesterday afternoon offered a program of quality interpreted intelligently by a singer with a good voice but with an unfortunate method of vocal production.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Charlie Taylor scored two touchdowns one on an 86-yard pass play as the Washington Redskins gained a 38-20 victory today over the Atlantic Falcons in a National Football League game.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 9 Morelia was quiet today as Mexican troops kept a watchful eye on a university strike that has rocked the capital of Michoacan State with demonstrations and disorders for a week.

WLOCLAWEK, Poland, Oct. 9 The two principal forces of Poland the Communist state and the Roman Catholic Church clashed today in a profound argument over which is the true shaper and guardian of Polish culture.
TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 10 (AP) The Vietcong today joined North Vietnam in rejecting a British plan for peace in Vietnam.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 9 The Rye Community Synagogue was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Susan Sachs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Sachs, to Robert Michael Schack. He is the son of Mrs. Louis Schack of New York and the late Mr. Schack.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 9 (AP) Jay Mazzone, a batboy, renewed acquaintances with Vice President Humphrey at the World Series game today.

VIENNA, Oct. 9 The state visit of the Soviet President, Nikolai V. Podgorny, which was due to begin tomorrow, has been postponed "owing to unforeseen illness" for several days, it was announced here tonight.
ITHACA,. N.Y., Oct. 9 A Cornell University junior drowned in Lake Cayuga today when the boat he and his roommate were rowing sank.
The Rev. Leo McLaughlin, president of Fordham University, took up the question yesterday of whether a Catholic university can be great.
PARIS, Oct. 9 (Reuters) The Chrysler Corporation is to buy a 21 per cent interest in Simca do Brazil, a subsidiary of the French car manufacturer, it was announced here over the weekend.
EAST ORANGE, N.J. A jobless Negro slum dweller in Newark's central ward shares little else with a comfortable commuter from Maplewood. But both are represented by the same member of Congress.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 9 (UPI) While Hurricane Inez ripped the Gulf of Mexico and threatened Texas today, a tropi cal storm dubbed Kendra blew up in the eastern Atlantic off the African coast.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9 As if predestined to produce the most astonishing result in modern baseball history, the 1966 World Series ended today with the Baltimore Orioles sweeping the Los Angeles Dodgers in four straight games.

Jeff Podesta of Montclair Academy, seeded first, defeated Brian Zevnik of Fordham Prep, 6-1, 6-2, in the quarter-finals of the 34th annual Eastern private schools tennis championship yesterday at Columbia University's courts.
Miss Harriet Rose Loria and Dr. Martin Popowitz were married yesterday afternoon at the Park Avenue Synagogue by Rabbi Judah Nadich.

A list of major committees appointed by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York for 1966-67, published in Sunday's New York Times, omitted the Committee on Bankruptcy and Corporate Reorganization.

SYDNEY, Oct. 9 Bill D. Moyers, the White House press secretary, denied in Canberra today that President Johnson's visit to Australia was designed to influence coming elections in this country and the United States.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Oct. 9 The blue-eyed young man with the swooping sandy forelock peered out through the television lights that bathed the stage of the Orpheum Theater, looking for the owner of the voice that was trying to open the question period.
FORT WORTH, Oct. 9 Radu Lupu, a Rumanian who has been playing the piano for 15 of his 20 years, won the first prize in the second Van Cliburn International Quadren nial Piano Competition Yesterday.

MADRID, Oct. 9 Space scientists of the world gathered here today to begin the weeklong 17th International Astronautical Congress, an annual review of the technical progress man is making in his quest to reach beyond his own planet.
The city's school system yesterday asked the public to help find classroom space for kindergarten children.
WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 9 Collegiate radicalism and freewheeling morality are distinctly minority positions on the American campus, according to Prof. Seymour M. Lipset, a Harvard sociologist.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Oct. 9 The first clamp-down ever known to be imposed in Zambia on news reports has been placed by the Government on all official information regarding copper and coal supplies and movements, and on import and export figures.

PARIS, Oct. 9 Bon Mot, a 3-year-old French colt, won the $374,000 Prix de L'Arc de Triomphe, Europe's richest horse race, today at Longchamp race course, beating Mme. Jean Stern's Sigebert by a half length.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 9-- Kenya's Opposition leader, Oginga Odinga, who flew to Uganda under an assumed name Friday, was seized at the border by the Kenya police on his return today and detained for more than two hours.

The proposed conference of hemispheric chiefs of state has been put off again, this time until next April or May. That should be the last postponement. It will have been a year since President Johnson first proposed such a meeting while on a trip to Mexico. If a conference cannot be prepared in that length of time it should be put aside to an indefinite future when hemispheric and world affairs provide a propitious climate.

A quiet enterprise pointing toward a significant municipal advance reached an important milestone the other day when the draft of a proposed new building code was presented to the city. The new code would overhaul a complex set of regulations last revised three decades ago and today generally conceded to be drastically inadequate in light of the vast technological advances made in the intervening years.

Because big increases in corporate spending on new plant and equipment have given the boom a great deal of its strength and staying power, the report that spending, may rise only slightly next year is something of a shocker.
A $5-million apparel distribution center will rise on a 30acre site in Secaucus, N.J., for a concern that will move from quarters it now occupies in several Manhattan locations.
The New York Chapter of the Epilepsy Association of America will hold a luncheon tomorrow at the Pierre. W. Walter Watts is chairman of the event.

"TOSCA" is back with the New York City Opera, and not just an ordinary "Tosca" either. With Jeannine Crader in the title role, Sherrill Milnes as Scarpia, with uncluttered staging by Tito Capobianco and with highly skilled conducting by Anton Guadagno, the new "Tosca" is a success.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 Governor Rockefeller today criticized a Federal report on the development and conservation of the Hudson River Valley as "shallow" and "self-serving." He suggested it was politically motivated.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 The Massachusetts campaign has entered the eye-gouging stage, and the script is becoming as shopworn as those for the old wrestling matches between the good guys and the bad guys at the Boston Arena.

THOMPSON, Conn., Oct. 9 Ken Duclos of Worcester, Mass., drove a Chevrolet-powered Cicada to victory in a 20-mile feature race of the Area One sports car championships here today. He took the lead at the start and withstood a determined challenge by John Meyer of Locust Valley, L.I., in a Cooper-Ford.
PARIS, Oct. 9 Ken Scott, the American designer who works in Milan, opened hist first boutique here last week at 4 Rue de la Paix, and it doesn't look like anybody else's. It is a soothing place.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 Steel officials were studying markets closely last week for signs of a basis weakening of demand.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 9 (AP) Police control units and fire trucks were called out tonight to quell a near-riot by fans of the Baltimore Orioles in the honkytonk district.
PANAMA, Oct. 9 With Panama's Presidential election still 18 months away, some political figures here are beginning to wonder if it will ever take place.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (UPI) About 1,000 volunteer postal workers toiled today to clear a backlog of a million pieces of mail at the main past office.

ATLANTA, Oct. 9-- An integrated crowd of 800 to 1,000 turned out here today to support a write-in governorship campaign for former Gov. Ellis Arnall against segregationist Democrat and Republican candidates.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 9 Ed Winrow of the New York Athletic Club won his third national title of the year today by capturing the Amateur Athletic Union's 25,000-meter championship run.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 9 More than 8,000 men, representing Roman Catholic parishes in 20 communities in this area, marched here today in the annual parade of the Union County Federation of Holy Name Societies.
When the sun set at 6:27 last night, it would have been hard to find many New Yorkers who didn't want to live Oct. 9 all over again.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 9 (AP) Reconnaissance photographs show the North Vietnamese have established sites for some of their surface-to-air missiles in populated areas, a United States intelligence officer said today.

BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 9 The Spanish Government appears to be experimenting with conciliatory new policies toward the restive people of the prosperous Catalonian provinces, which stretch from the Pyrenees southward along the Mediterranean.
PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 9 The Blind Brook polo team won the Governor's Cup today by defeating the New Haven quartet, 9-1, with a seven-goal second half at Blind Brook Polo Club.

ROME, Oct. 9 The Most Rev. Sergio Pignedoli, special Papal representative at a recent South Vietnamese bishops' conference, returned to Rome today "optimistic" over the possibility of peace in Vietnam. He said he had noted "a new spirit of cooperation" among Buddhist and other religious leaders.
Passenger ship operators are faced with a union damand for more liberal conditions for ships' crews while the vessels are being turned around in port for their next voyages.

Miss Suzanne Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Robinson of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Benjamin Beard Hoover, son of Mrs. Francis Oswald Hoover of Pacific Grove, Calif., and the late Mr. Hoover.

When Mayor Lindsay spoke out so fervently last Week for a larger measure of home rule for New York City, he was merely echoing a long line of his predecessors. Virtually every Mayor since Greater New York was formed almost seventy years ago has pleaded that it should be allowed to manage its own affairs.

The Moscow Chamber Orchestra played at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon in its first appearance here since 1963, and the group was its usual, eloquent, masterly self. It played with grace, fire, precision and unaffectedly healthy musicality.
Edward H. Alsop of 190 East 72d Street, a former president of the Transylvania Railroad, died yesterday in the Medical Arts Hospital after a short illness. His age was 74.
Agreement was reached early this morning between metropolitan area funeral parlors and their employes, averting a strike that had been set for 12:01 A.M. today.

AT most levels of the game the quality of the dummy play is considerably higher than the quality of the defense. Many players who are quite capable of executing a squeeze would fail to find the defensive play required on the diagramed deal.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex. Oct. 9 (UPI) Hurricane Inez turned toward the Texas coast again today, paused in the Gulf of Mexico, and then started a 200mile run toward a point just south of Brownsville and Matamoros, Mexico, across the Rio Grande.
ALBANY, Oct. 9 Governor Rockefeller announced today that Maj. Gen. W. Reynolds Carr would retire Oct. 29 as commanding general of the New York Guard.

IN leading a platoon of warweary marines through Japanese-held islands, or getting the last bit of energy from ballplayers after the long season is ended, Henry Albert Bauer has asked for just one, simple thing from the men under him: 100 per cent effort. "I ain't running.

Col. Alf S.H. Helmer, a veteran of both World Wars and the Mexican Border conflict died Saturday night in the Veterans Administration Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 69 years old and lived at 648, 53d Street, Brooklyn.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 9 William Gage Brady Jr., who was president and chairman of the National City Bank of New York, died today in MemorialMission Hospital, He was 78 years old.

A car in which three Puerto Ricans were riding was attacked twice, late Saturday night and early yesterday by about 300 Hasidic Jews in front of the Sotmen Synagogue, 550 Bedford Avenue, near Ross Street in Brooklyn.
Harry H. Nadel, a certified public accountant, died yesterday at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged. He was 75 years old and formerly lived at the Hampton House, 28 East 70th Street.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Albom have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Myrna Albom, to Gerald Howard Braffman, son of Mrs. Samuel Braffman and the late Dr. Braffman.

When the Mayor places his "John V. Lindsay" on incorporation articles this week, the Metropolitan Regional Council will be back in business on a firmer footing than ever as co ordinating agent for tristate area planning and development.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 9 Harvard dethroned Princeton as the team champion and Charlie Hoveler of Dartmouth became a double winner as the annual Eastern Collegiate. Athletic Conference fall tennis tournament ended today at Army's courts.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 After three weeks of public debate and private discussion, there is a slightly better understanding in the General Assembly of the United States position in Vietnam.
Dr. Maxwell Silver, retired banker, author and a former rabbi, died yesterday at his home, 227 Riverside Drive. His age was 75.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) President Johnson has agreed to accept an award from the nation's leading birth control organization.
KENILWORTH, Ill., Oct. 9 (AP) As the investigation of the slaying of Valerie Percy entered its fourth week today, the police were still without a substantial lead.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 (UPI) George Mira, a substitute quarterback, led the San Francisco Forty-niners to a 21-20 inset victory over the Green Bay Packers today.

Shinichi Suzuki, the Japanese violinist and teacher who may be revolutionizing the teaching of music to the young, brought 10 of his Japanese pupils to Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon to demonstrate some of the results of his work. The results were impressive.

DUBLIN, Oct. 9 (AP) The New York Gaelic football team was chased off the field today by an angry crowd at Croke Park after defeating Longford, 10 points to 9, in the National Football League championship series.

Miss Roslyn Eva Agulnick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Agulnick of Rego Park, Queens, was married yesterday at noon to Dr. Sheldon Noel Capp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Capp of Detroit. Rabbi Immanuel Jakobovits performed the ceremony in the Fifth Avenue Synagogue.

Sitting under a tree in a Lower East Side park and occasionally dancing, 50 followers of a Hindu swami repeated a 16-word chant for two hours yesterday afternoon to the accompaniment of cymbals, tambourines, sticks, drums, bells and a small reed organ.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.'s executive assistant, William W. Holzman, resigned yesterday.
The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, one of the largest of the major American film producing distributing companies, is looking for young blood.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 9 The chief executive officer of the United Presbyterian Church today called upon the denomination's local congregations to make "friendly overtures" to the Roman Catholic hierarchy.
TUSKEGEE, Ala. Oct. 9 President Johnson commended Tuskegee Institute today for providing "new avenues of service for Negro Americans, for the South and for the nation."
RED LAKE, Minn., Oct. 8 Roger Jourdain spoke in the tribal council room on the Red Lake Indian Reservation and punctuated his words with gestures.
The Maritime Administration is holding discussions with ship lines that receive Federal subsidies in an effort to simplify the system and reduce the cost of administering it.
Short-term interest rates, which have edged down during the last few weeks, will be tested this week when the Traesury auctions tomorrow $3.5-billion of six-and eightmonth tax anticipation bills.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman of Thailand said today that his Government "Knows for a fact" that some elements in both Communist China and North Vietnam are eager to accept as soon as possible the United States' bid for a conference to end hostilities in South Vietnam.
Malachy T. Murray, a retired advertising executive with the Pepsi-Cola Company, died yesterday at his home, 290 Atlantic Avenue, East Rockaway, L.I. His age was 69.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 9 Early this morning a Korean-war model of the Navy A-1 Skyraider shot a North Vietnamese jet fighter out of the skies over the Phuly Bridge, 35 miles south of Hanoi.

Miss Lydia Hamza, daughter of the Rev. Andrew Hamza of New York and Denville, N.J., and Mrs. Karoly Horvath of Budapest, was married yesterday afternoon to Charles Frederick Emmons at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. GOTEMBA, Japan, Oct. 9 (Reuters)-- Jackie Stewart, a 27-year-old Scot with two years of professional racing experience, won Japan's first Indianapolis-style car race today on the Mount Fuji course.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, indicated today that a halt of United States bombing attacks against North Vietnam was Moscow's primary condition for responding to President Johnson's appeal for greater Soviet-United States cooperation.
Mrs. Burton Pierce, daughter of Ralph J. Bunche, was found dead early yesterday in the front courtyard of the Bronx apartment house where she lived.

Mrs. Estelle Drew Kempf of 171 West 71st Street died on Saturday of cancer at Roosevelt Hospital. She was the 79year-old widow of Paul Kempf, who prior to his death in 1947, had been chief copy editor of the society and obituary desk of The New York Times.

A bill is to be introduced in the City Council this week to provide both the Board of Estimate and the City Council with more information on the city's proposed capital budget and with more time to study it.

Three persons were killed and four overcome by smoke in a fire that swept a frame house in the South Ozone Park section of Queens yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Oct. 10 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara arrived in Saigon today and said he would ask South Vietnamese leaders their opinion on "possible additions in United States assistance."
Dr. Abraham H. Chaikin, a dentist for 55 years in Lower Manhattan, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 165 West End Avenue.
ATLANTA, Oct. 9 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that he would meet with top advisers this week to decide whether to repudiate and oppose all "black power" organizations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 A leading Republican Senator charged tonight that the Johnson Administration has secret public opinion surveys that show a sharp rise in criticism of United States foreign policy by Europeans.

Charles Aznavour is a diminutive man with a shabby look, the look of a Franch postman rundown at the heels, down on his luck. He is that insignificant fellow lost in the shuffle of life, the fellow who gazes at the stars and knows that he can never reach them.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9 After a long, tingling season of cliff-hangers, the Los Angeles Dodgers fell off the cliff for keeps on this afternoon of glorious sunshine and disappeared totally from view. As they toppled from sight, the World Series ended abruptly in the unlikeliest fashion. The Orioles had swept the proud palladins of the National League into ignominious discard with four straight victories, contrary to all odds and all expectations.

High-ranking spokesmen for the Republican, Democratic and Conservative parties called yesterday for steps to keep lobbies for special interests from taking control of the 1967 Constitutional Convention.

John Frankenheimer, a motion-picture director for the last six years, will return to television to direct William Hanley's play "Flesh and Blood." The two-hour play, recently purchased by the National Broadcasting Company, will be televised before it is presented on Broadway.
GWYNEDD VALLEY, Pa., Oct. 9 Ch. Foremark Ebony Box of Foxden, on his third birthday, was named best in show today in a field of 608 dogs at the all-terrier Montgomery County Kennel Club fixture.
MOSCOW, Oct. 9 (UPI)-- Communist China's Red Guards are breaking up the party organization in Sinkiang, a strategic province adjoining the Soviet Union, Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 The New York Giants played sound winning football for 55 minutes today, but unfortunately these pro football games endure for 60 minutes. In the last five the St. Louis Cardinals, behind, 1914, rallied to score the winning touchdown and take the game, 24-19. They added an unimportant field goal in the last 56 seconds to top off an effort that by their standards was less than good.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 The racial issue is likely to flare anew as Congress struggles this week to break up a huge logjam of pending legislation.

Irving Trust Company's net operating earnings for the first nine months of this year totaled $13,900,111 after taxes, it was reported over the weekend. This represented an increase of 6.5 per cent above the $3,052,359 earned in the corresponding period of 1965.
"MICHAEL, you're going to get clobbered," yelled Mrs. Robert Stricks, rescuing her 17-month-old son from under the seesaw at the northeast playground in Washington Square last Thursday afternoon.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct, 9 (UPI) Tom Flores, given his first start of the season at quarterback, threw three touchdown passes today as he led the Oakland Raiders to a 21-10 victory over the Miami Dolphins in an American Football League game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) Vice President Humphrey and former Vice President Richard M. Nixon disagreed today over the willingness of Democratic Congressional candidates to link themselves to the coattails of the Johnson Administration.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 9 The marriage of Miss Carol Julie Stein to Michael E. Bleier, son of Charles Bleier and the late Mrs. Tina Rosen Bleier, took place here this afternoon. Mrs. Lena Gurian Blumberg, vice president of the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital in Brooklyn, died Saturday night in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. She was 84 years old and lived at 135 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Oct. 9-Victor J. Shankey of Haverstraw, a leading Hudson Valley funeral director and a Rockland County Democratic leader who had been a member of the Rockland County Board of Supervisors for 36 years, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, Poughkeepsie, after a short illness. He was 74 years old.
HONG KONG, Monday, Oct. 10 Defense Minister Lin Piao has called on the Chinese Communist Army to carry the study of Mao Tse-Tung's works to a new stage.

FRANKLIN, N.J., Oct. 9 Thousands of "rockhounds" descended yesterday and today on this little northern Jersey town, north of Lake Hopatcong, the home of nearly 200 minerals ranging from Albite to Zoisite.
DHARAN, Nepal, Oct. 9 Balkumar Rai became a British soldier today. It was an event he had been dreaming of for most of his 18 years.

HOME storage conditions can affect the cooking quality of potatoes. They should be kept in a cool, dark, well-ventilated place, but not in the refrigerator. A few days' exposure to light may cause potatoes to turn green and have a bitter flavor.

CAPETOWN, Oct. 9 Dr. Anton Rupert, the head of an international tobacco empire, confirmed today that he intended to take a year or two off to become an unpaid industrial adviser to the Government of Lesotho. President Johnson's appearance here yesterday undoubtedly gave the Democratic state campaign a lift. He drew large crowds and his attack on the Republic can record in Congress was well received.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk appealed tonight to the enemy in Vietnam for favorable consideration of the United States' peace proposals and offered to enter into private discussions to clarify them.
