DURING the World Series the extremely likable Mayo Smith shook more hands than did Vice President Humphrey, a professional handshaker of enormous indefatigability.
The Public Bank of Detroit, the biggest bank to fail since the Depression, was declared insolvent early yesterday morning, but steps were immediately taken to protect de positors from loss.
A change of presidents was announced yesterday by two large Midwestern railroads.
UNITED NATION, N.Y., Oct. 12--Following is the text of the statement made today in the General Assembly by Arthur J. Goldberg, United States representative, on the question of South-West Africa:
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 12-- Syria announced today the com pletion of all preparations to counter any aggression from Israel or elsewhere.
ATHENS, Oct. 12--The United States has cautioned Greece that all military and economic aid may be cut off this year if Greek ships continue to trade with Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13-- President Johnson emphatically rejected today a suspension of bombing that would leave soldiers in Vietnam fighting with "their hands behind their back."
The city's upstate water supply dropped 1.4 billion gallons during the 24-hour period ended at 8 A.M. yesterday, but it was still nearly twice that of a year ago.

The engagement of Miss Barbara Nan Gelfand, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. H. Harold Gelfand of New York and Long Beach, L.I., to Barry S. Coller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Coller of Jamaica Estates, Queens, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13-- Assistant Attorney General Fred M. Vinson Jr. told the Supreme Court today that James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, had mounted a "large scale" attempt to corrupt a Nashville, Tenn., jury in 1962.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 13--An attempt by liberals to strike a reference to the controversial anti-open housing slogan, "Your home is your castle," from the 1966 Maryland Democratic platform was crushed today at the party's state convention.

William Zeckendorf Jr., former president of Webb knapp, Inc., was charged yesterday in a suit filed in Federal Court here of taking a $92,500 brokerage commission that allegedly belonged to Webb Knapp.

The president of City College, Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, was burned in effigy at the college yesterday afternoon because of plans to turn a wooded lawn into a parking lot and to construct temporary prefabricated classrooms.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 13 --More than 600 persons have helped to prepare "A Fair with a Flair," a sale sponsored by the Junior League of Greenwich to be held Saturday at the Ekman Center in Old Greenwich. The league's Community Trust Fund will gain support for several projects, including prekindergarten and tutoring programs, a canteen for teen-agers and a workshop for retired citizens.
BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 13--Conservative leaders broke today with the Labor Government's Rhodesian policy on two major points.
ONE day in 1911 Henry James the novelist, was being shown through the Rockefeller Institute in New York and met a young physician who was introduced as its director of cancer research.
Jerome J. Greene, president of the Beejay Music Printing Corporation at 43 Bond Street, died yesterday in his home at 1718 East 28th Street in Brooklyn. His age was 46.

Housewives and others who are willing to stuff and label envelopes in their homes for low wages are jeopardizing the jobs of thousands of low-income workers here, union officials and an employers' association' in the direct mail industry said yesterday.
The conviction of David J. Miller, the first person arrested in the country for burning his draft card, was upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

Dog shows hardly ever are canceled, come hail or high water, but one fell victim to the war in Vietnam yesterday. The annual Bronx County Kennel Club event, which was to have been held for the 45th time on Oct. 30 in the Kingsbridge Armory, became a war casualty because the building would be occupied that day by National Guardsmen returning with their equipment from weekend maneuvers at Camp Smith in Peekskill.

UINTAH AND OURAY INDIAN RESERVATION, Utah, Oct. 11--The deer hunting for this party visiting the Ute Nu Tuveep Hunting Expedition operation ended successfully after we were getting discouraged about getting a nice mule deer head.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13--Eleven Arab nations defended Syria today against a complaint by Israel that Syria had committed "acts of aggression."

MOSCOW, Oct. 13 (Reuters) --Soviet authorities are holding two former United States Army lieutenants in Leningrad pending an investigation of charges of stealing a bronze statue of a bear from a hotel, the United States Embassy said today.

More than 50 members of the Police Department's tactical force have been assigned to a 15-block area on Manhattan's Upper West Side to combat a wave of derelicts, prostitutes and narcotics users who have turned the section into a "problem neighborhood."
George MacCall, the United States Davis Cup captain, has picked a five-man squad for the interzone semi-final tennis matches against Brazil starting Nov. 5.
A new men's clothing store will open on Fifth Avenue next spring in a corner space formerly occupied by the John David store.

LONDON, Oct. 13--September was the best month of this year for British trade, the Government reported today. The trade gap--the excess of Britain's imports over exports--narrowed to 49-million ($137.2million) from August's 67million ($187.6-million).

Laurance Rockefeller, a member of one of the wealthiest families in the world, wants to move from his Fifth Avenue apartment as soon as possible to eat, sleep and work for $12.50 a week in the slums of Harlem.
A member of the carpenters union was charged last night with having beaten a union Official to death early yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) --Milton Lehman, a former war correspondent and a biographer of Dr. Robert Goddard, the developer of rockets, died of a heart attack today at his home in Rockville, Md. He was 48 years old.
Two threats on President Johnson's life--both of them empty--were made during his visit here.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 13 --Miss Jamie Kleinberg and Alan Bennett Shalleck have made plans to be married next month.

The Bank of America, San Francisco, the nation's largest bank, reported yesterday record net operating earnings for the third quarter of $29,486,157, or $1.04 a share, up 10.5 per cent from the $26,693,196, or 94 cents a share, in the yearearlier period.
Brentano's, the 113-year-old bookseller, announced recently a program of expansion that will increase the number of its stores from 17 to 19. Tomorrow,...
The D'Arcy Advertising Company got some big good news and some little good news yesterday. The big has seven digits and the little one only six.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 (AP)--The State University's Board of Trustees today approved operating and construction budgets totaling $571.5-million for the next fiscal year. This is an increase of $177.3-million over the current record outlay.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13-- President Johnson, ebullient after two days on the political stump, swatted cheerfully at Republicans and other critics at a White House news conference today.

PARIS, Oct. 13--Steve Passeur, a leading French dramatist of the between-the-wars generation, died yesterday after having been stricken at the premiere of Harold Pinter's "The Homecoming" in the Th atre de Paris. He was 67 years old.
Tight money and rising interest rates have virtually choked off Federally backed private investment in new housing here, particularly in the slums, according to city and state officials.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 13 (AP)--Ronald Reagan, seeking the governorship of California, says he is unaware of $400,000 in campaign funds allegedly contributed to his campaign by Connecticut Republicans.
President Johnson asked yesterday that world leaders seeking peace help convince President Ho Chi Minh of the necessity for "unconditional discussions" to end the war.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 13--Bill Mangin and Nat Choderker of Alpine fashioned a 34, 32--66 today at the Rock Spring club to win the 31st annual New Jersey State Golf Association better-ball stroke play championship.
Macy's New York and Sears, Roebuck Co. announced yesterday a joint purchase of a 132acre site to be developed into a major shopping center in Staten Island.
A $25-million containership project for the New YorkPuerto Rico trade was announced here yesterday by American Union Transport, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)--The Senate approved today an Administration bill intended to increase foreign investment in the United States. The vote was 58 to 18.

IT is safer to be a quarterback in the National Foot ball League this season than heretofore. Only one, Pittsburgh's Bill Nelsen, has gone down for the count so far and the films show that Nelsen's one good knee gave way all by itself with no one near him.

NEW HAVEN--The Vietnam war has become a lively issue in the campaign in Connecticut's Third Congressional District, but not even that appears to have roused the voters to a major political shift on Nov. 8.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 13-- Despite 50-mile-an-hour winds golf was played in the second round of the $100,000 Sahara invitation tournament today. Competitors and officials could not recall similar prevailing conditions in an event. when the winds abated to 20 miles midway in the afternoon, it seemed a lull by contrast had settled over the Paradise Valley Country Club course.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 13-- Two United States researchers in cancer were jointly awarded the 1966 Nobel Prize for Medicine today, crowning a long list of their achievements and honors dating back to 1910.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 13 --Mr. and Mrs. Leonard C. Adams have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Arline Marie Adams, to Richard D. Emery Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Emery of Rumson.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)--Hopes dimmed today for Congressional approval of a bill that would clear the way for the merger of the National and American Football Leagues.
Lee MacPhail, the man who rebuilt the Baltimore Orioles, was hired yesterday to rebuild the New York Yankees.

The New York Philharmonic was supposed to continue Leonard Bernstein's survey of 20th century symphonic forms last night. Instead, it concentrated on war--specifically the horrors of mass murder and bombings; patriotism, pacifism and victory.
LONDON, Oct. 13--The British Government sent a revised version of its proposals for settlement of the Rhodesian problem to Salisbury today.

Dr. Francis Peyton Rous discovered more than 55 years ago that he could transmit cancer from one chicken to another with what was then some mysterious substance. This gave rise to a "germ theory of cancer."

The Administration's failure to recommend improved legal machinery for averting national emergency strikes is reflected once again in the strike deadlines now at hand for General Electric and Westinghouse, two pivotal suppliers of military equipment for Vietnam. A two-week truce at G.E. obtained by President Johnson expires at midnight Sunday; the Westinghouse crisis-point comes at midnight tonight.

MANY American experts refuse to open the bid ding with any four-card major suit, although standard methods permit this in some circumstances if the suit is relatively strong. In Europe the tendency is in the opposite direction; hardly anyone insists on a five-card suit and many experts are prepared to bid a four-card suit.

In the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Mary Luke Langben, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Manmade fur for men's wear will become the new fad in the not too distant future, Chester H. Roth, president of the Kayser-Roth Corporation, said yesterday following the annual shareholder meeting.

The 69th Regiment Armory, scene of the famous 1913 Armory Show that introduced bold new concepts of European art, played host last night to an art extravaganza whose sponsors proclaimed it as "the first serious encounter between art and technology." It was the opener in a series of "Nine Evenings: Theater and Engineering," a collaborative project between Bell Laboratories engineers and dancers, artists and musicians.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13-- A three-day run on a Chinatown savings and loan association, caused by a telephone campaign, ended late today with $3.7-million withdrawn by depositors.

Eckert, abandoned the scrupulous propriety that normally governs him and cheered unrestrainedly for the Baltimore Orioles.

Three Republicans spoke last night at the annual dinner honoring the memory of a famous Democrat, Alfred E. Smith. Democrats were annoyed because all they could do was listen.

Today is the deadline for the Indiana Dunes. The House of Representatives is scheduled to take a final vote on amendments tentatively approved earlier this week and on final passage of the bill to protect the dunes by establishing them as a national seashore.

NEWARK, Oct. 13 (AP)-- Mrs. May E. Maher, a Democrat, was appointed to the Essex County Board of Freeholders today to fill the unexpired term of Miss Inez Stanziale, a Republican.

An East Harlem housewife associated with one of the area's antipoverty agencies was named to the citywide Council Against Poverty yesterday, causing a protest demonstration by a rival agency that halted the council's meeting.

LONDON, Oct. 13.--William the Conqueror has become Britain's top salesman of 1966. DETROIT, Oct. 13--Apathy among Michigan voters troubles Republicans and Democrats alike as next month's elections draw nearer. There are some close races, but as yet, none of them has really caught fire.

The Western Union Telegraph Company said yesterday that net income for the first nine months would be about $14.9-million, equal to $1.65 a share.

THE second drawing in this posthumous collection of graphic Thurberana shows a woman sitting in a sailboat. She is a typical Thurber woman, all imperious determination, poised precariously (or is the precariousness just a pose?) on the starboard gunwale of her ship, and dressed in what looks like an athletic director's shift or slip or nightgown (anyway, no frills).
Hunger is already an urgent problem in many parts of the world. The annual report of the Food and Agriculture Organization provides a grim and ominous warning that worse may be in store.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Oct. 13 (AP)--Clifton Webb, the actor known for his dignified stance and strong personality as a movie character, died tonight, apparently of a heart attack, at his home. He was 74 years old.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Friday, Oct. 14--The military prosecutor asked early today that Indonesia's former Foreign Minister, Dr. Subandrio, be sentenced to death by the military tribunal trying him on charges of subversion.

HONOLULU, Oct. 13 (AP)-- Reports of discrimination against African students trying to find housing in Hawaii were voiced today by the director of the University of Hawaii's international student office.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 13-- Prof. Allan R. Holmberg, an anthropologist who aided the Indians of South America, died today in Ithaca Hospital after a brief illness. He would have been 57 years old on Saturday.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 13 (AP) --What is thought to be a major cancer-causing element in cigarette smoke has been discovered and can be eliminated, a member of the United States Surgeon General's advisory committee said today.

GREENWICH, Conn.--The voters have a familiar choice this year in Fairfield County. Representative Donald J. Irwin and Abner W. Sibal are running against each other for Congress, as they have done twice before.

City officials are "thinking about" turning over the ownership and operation of the 21 municipal hospitals to private voluntary institutions, Dr. Howard J. Brown, the Health Services Administrator, said yesterday at City Hall.

An official of the Flying Tiger Lines, which was held liable early this week for damages growing out of a 1962 plane accident that took 107 lives, has announced that the underwriters of Lloyd's of London intends to appeal the ruling of a Federal court.

Mrs. Aileen B. Ryan, Democratic candidate for the House of Representatives in the Bronx's 24th District, urged an investigation yesterday into "a possible backroom deal" between Representative Paul A. Fino, her Republican opponent, and "some members of the Conservative party."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13-- Defense spending increased at a rate of $4.2-billion a year during the July-September quarter, a rise that was $1.2-billion higher than Government officials estimated less than three weeks ago.

Deputy Commissioner Charles Leedham of the Department of Marine and Aviation said yesterday that a three-year target had been set for construction of a major new heliport along the East River in midtown Manhattan.

The world of duplicating machines became a little more competitive yesterday. The Xerox Corporation announced changes in five high-speed machines and the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation's Bruning division released a new pricing plan aimed at lower costs for highvolume users.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 13--The tumult of the last three and a half months in the leadership of the Yugoslav Communist party died suddenly this week.

Arthur M. Tode, who devoted most of his life to the support of the American merchant marine, died Monday at the Bronxville Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 612 East Grassy Sprain Road, Yonkers.
Frank D. O'Connor announced yesterday that his campaign expenditures had totaled $220,000 since his nomination. He called on Governor Rockefeller to make a similar disclosure.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 13 (AP) --Charles Hickok of Phoenix, Ariz., and Claudia Kolb of Sunnyvale, Calif., captured gold medals today in the first swimming finals of the Little Olympics.

MRS. JOHN V. LINDSAY spent a couple of hours on Seventh Avenue yesterday and gave every indication of enjoying herself thoroughly. She promised she'd be back, not only as part of her husband's campaign to build up New York as a fashion center but also because she liked to see the clothes.
The American Stock Exchange made its third consecutive advance yesterday, although the gains were not large as those made on Wednesday.

YONKERS, Oct. 13--Henri Levesque, the standard-bred owner from Beauzeville la Bastille, France, who had been delayed en route, rushed into Yorkers Raceway this morning. He was eager to attend the drawing of post positions for next Tuesday's $100,000 United Nations Trot.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) --The Post Office Department said today that a massive pileup at the Chicago Post Office had caused delays of as much as 10 days in the delivery of mail.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 13--For the third straight week American combat casualties in Vietnam were higher than those of the Saigon Government's troops.
A citywide poll on the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board has disclosed that the board's supporters face an uphill, but close, fight in the Nov. 8 referendum.

City Controller Mario A. Procaccino urged yesterday that the city restrict its borrowing to finance construction projects so that, "hopefully," it might be able to stem the upward trend of its outstanding debt within five years.
THE influence of Blair Catterton at Sloane's has spread past the antiques department, which he heads, and the House of Years model rooms, which he decorates, into the area of furniture reproductions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)--The Senate Appropriations Committee backed the House today in chopping $3.1million from funds the Office of Education sought to assist states and communities in carrying out school desegregation.

LOS ANGELES--Individualism is considerably more rampant in the widely separated wholesale showrooms here, where spring collections have just been presented, than in the closer confines of Seventh Avenue, possibly because the designers have less opportunity to fraternize.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13-- Once upon a time, according to President Johnson, there was an old codger named Uncle Ezra, who was hard of hearing and liked hard liquor. If you want to hear, said his doctor, cut out the hootch; but Uncle Ezra kept right on drinking because, as he said, he liked what he drank so much better than he liked what he heard.

ROME, Oct. 13--Italy's Communist leaders ended a three-day meeting today with a sharp condemnation of Communist China. They also gave indications of concern over de clining party membership and the threat of Socialist rivalry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13-- The Interstate Commerce Commission notified the Supreme Court today that if it was going to delay temporarily the merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads, it believed the court should expedite an appeal hearing on a lower-court ruling denying an injunction that would indefinitely delay the merger.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13-- Economists and industry leaders generally forecast today a steady improvement in business for 1967. They tempered their forecasts, however, by pointing out that the war in Vietnam, higher taxes, tight money, inflation and increased militancy by labor unions would have a marked effect on the 1967 economy.
WARSAW, Oct. 13--The Soviet Union appears to be facing mounting demands from its Eastern European allies and trading partners to pay for at least some of its purchases in dollars or gold.
PARIS, Oct. 13--The chef of a noted Paris restaurant that had been publicly criticized by food experts has killed himself with a shotgun.
MADRID, Oct. 13--The Government-sponsored student association was rejected today at the University of Barcelona as nearly 2,000 students booed the president of the national organization.

THERE may be more purely exciting dancers in the world than the Ukrainian Dance Company, which arrived last night for an alltoo-brief season at Madison Square Garden, but if such paragons exist, I am at a loss to recall them. Of their type--those spinning, grinning, winning folk dancers-- these Ukrainians, now on their second visit here, remain unsurpassed by all, and unequalled except by their spiritual cousins, the Moiseyev dancers.

Once upon a time Knute Rockne, the cornerstone of Notre Dame football, mentioned that "everything in football began at Yale." Maybe on the field. But off it, Notre Dame has introduced the electronic cliche.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--The nation's electric utility companies were warned today to develop better means of forecasting demands on their capacity so other cities can avoid emergency shutdowns in home service such as those St. Louis experienced last summer.
A Chilean-bred mare who had never raced here, Bruno Ferrari's Karola, was the longestpriced horse among the eight that competed in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 13--A slate made up of members or Former members of the old board of directors of the Jersey City antipoverty program won all of the positions in a lightly attended election for a new board, which was completed Wednesday night.

NOW that the stock market is showing signs of life, many traders who still have faith in the stocks that tumbled in the bear market would like to take their losses and reinvest in the same securities.

Justice Irving Ben Cooper reserved judgment in Federal Court here yesterday after a group of stockholders asked him to order the Columbia Pictures Corporation to produce a separate financial report on the company's movie-making operations.
More than 800 members of the Columbia University community gathered at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia campus yesterday to attend a memorial service for the late Prof. Moses Hadas.

New York's "businessmobile" made an appearance this week in Long Island City, Queens. Despite a big sign proclaiming it as the city's "one-stop business service," one of the first inquiries was of quite a non-commercial nature.
A State Supreme Court jury acquitted Ernest Gallashaw last night of charges that he killed 10-year-old Eric Dean during racial violence in East New York last July.
Prices on the Paris Stock Exchange recovered slightly yesterday from the sharp setback of the previous day.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13-- President Johnson's plan for erasing city slums--the Demonstration Cities Program--became caught up in racial controversy today as the House opened debate on the measure.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 13 --Mr. and Mrs. Cadwallader Washburn Kelsey Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elise Graham Sharwood Kelsey, to John Griswold Gurley Merrow 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Griswold Merrow of Noroton.

Events today: Strauss's "Die Frau ohne Schatten," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Bizet's "Carmen," New York City Opera, New York State Theater, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15; Miriam Makeba, folk songs, Carnegie Hall, 8:40.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
PARIS, Oct. 13--President de Gaulle talked privately for an hour today with Bulgaria's Premier, Todar Zhivkov, mostly about Vietnam.
The Fifth Avenue store of Best Co. is expected to become a promotional, high-fashion specialty store, with emphasis on mass merchandising, much in the nature of Alexander's Department Stores.
ALBANY, Oct. 13--After years of tallying nods, hand signals and even counting empty seats, leaders of the 1967 Legislature will total votes on bills electronically.

Salvatore (Bill) Bonanno, son of Joe Bonanno, reportedly deposed head of a Cosa Nostra "family," surrendered yesterday to District Attorney Aaron E. Koota of Brooklyn to begin serving a 30-day jail sentence for contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--A $3.6-billion program to clean up the nation's interstate lakes and streams--the most sweeping financial commitment to fight water pollution ever fashioned by Congress--was agreed on today by Senate, and House conferees.

***The Gauguin Room, Gallery of Modern Art, 2 Columbus Circle, LT 1-2311. Visitors to afternoon or evening performances of Lincoln Center should not overlook The Gauguin Room on the ninth floor of the Gallery of Modern Art. It is one of the pleasantest dining rooms in New York.

BONN, Oct. 13--The defense committee of the West German Bundestag or lower House of Parliament today approved the immediate construction of four antiaircraft corvettes armed with American Tartar missiles. Six more corvettes will be built later.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 13 (UPI)--A Congressional staff investigation is under way into the reasons why the Commerce Department has refused to make public a report on St. Lawrence Seaway tolls, it was learned today.
Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen, welcome back to the White House.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (UPI)-- Dr. Charles Huggins gratefully accepted the "favorable recognition" of the Nobel Prize today and then went back to the seclusion of his campus laboratory.
MOSCOW, Oct. 13--Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin angrily charged today that Communist China had prevented a Vietcong victory by refusing to cooperate in joint Communist-bloc assistance.
WE played like sandlot players against Har vard. I missed tackles all afternoon. I'll see to it I do better this Saturday in the Yale Bowl."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)--President Johnson urged the nation tonight to join him in a drive to "tear down what is ugly" and make the United States live up to its title of "America the beautiful."
DENVER, Oct. 18 (AP)-- The first major snowfall of the season quilted parts of Wyoming, Idaho and Utah today.

THERE is one thing about the new production of "The Alchemist" that Ben Jonson might have liked. When George Voskovec, all decked out in brown Elizabethan braid, finally snatches his plumed hat off to reveal a forehead that goes up and up until it seems in competition with Mount Rushmore, he looks--all of a sudden and possibly by accident--exactly like Ben Jonson's old friend, Wm. Shakespeare.

EUSTIS, Fla., Oct. 13--Eva Best Simpson, who led the first contingent of Marine Corps Women Reservists into the Pacific theater during World War II, died last night in Waterman Memorial Hospital here. She was 61 years old.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--The Citizens' Crusade Against Poverty withdrew today as a combatant in the fight to get new Head Start funds for the Child Development Group of Mississippi.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 13 (Reuters)--The United States qualified for the final of the pairs event in the world lawn bowling championships today, with a double victory in the last two sectional rounds.
A children's coloring book, designed to create in youngsters an image of policemen as their friends, is being offered to public and private schools in the city.
Richard W. Ince, a partner in G.C. Haas Co., said yesterday that the general partners of the brokerage firm had formed the Haas Securities Corporation.
Governor Rockefeller presided yesterday at the signing of an architect's contract for a $14million, 20-story state office building to be erected in Harlem.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--President Johnson expressed hope today that his two-hour talk at the White House Monday with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, might have paved the way for an over-all improvement in United StatesSoviet relations.
The Contemporary Chamber Ensemble, a group that resides at Rutgers University and is made up of some of New York City's top freelancers, opened its second season at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

Seven national Negro leaders have repudiated the black power concepts of the Congress of Racial Equality and the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee without naming either organization or using the controversial term.
The Monsanto Company had record sales for the three months and nine months ended Sept. 30, but earnings declined, the company's interim report disclosed yesterday.
The Board of Education's conditional boycott of textbooks printed by the strikebound Kingsport Press was voided yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice George Postel.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 14 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky has rejected demands by six of his Cabinet members that he oust Gen. Nguyen Ngoe Loan as Director of the National Police, informed sources said tonight.
WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 14 Wellesley College, approaching its centennial, acquired a new president today officially. Actually, Ruth Marie Adams, blue-eyed specialist in Victorian literature.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 Senate leaders dealt a death blow tonight to plans of House members to push through an immediate cost-of-living increase in Social Security benefits.

Fordham Hospital officials told state investigators yesterday that more than $100,000 worth of equipment purchased for the city institution had been turned over to Misericordia Hospital, a nonprofit private institution that administers Fordham under an affiliation contract.

MIAMI Oct. 14 (UPI) Led by a halfback who knocked himself cold scoring the game's only touchdown, Miami played Georgia-style football in the second half tonight and knocked the 11th-ranked Bulldogs from the undefeated ranks, 7-6.

"DIFFERENT" dessert is often the most difficult part of the meal for a hostess to plan. One idea is a honey and lemon flavored rice custard baked in a saltine and coconut pie shell. It would also be an ideal midafternoon or late evening snack.
The city's high school principals sharply criticized the Superintendent of Schools yesterday for siding with two Queens boys who defied school authorities by, refusing to cut their long hair.

Events today: "Don Giovanni," Metropolitan Opera. 2 P.M.; "The Barber of Seville," New York City Opera, New York State Theater, 2:15; Shella Schonbrun, soprano, and Richard Anderson, baritone, and others, Town Hall, 2; HeifetzPiatigorsky Concert, with orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30: Ernesto Farago, violinist, Town Hall. 5:15: Salvation Army...
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 14 The passing and running of Dean Lynch paced Englewood School for Boys to a 33-to-6 football triumph today over McBurney.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14 A resolution to strengthen the enforcement of the General Assembly declaration of 1963 against all forms of discrimination was adopted by the Social Committee today.
Since it performed here in 1964, the Pacific String Trio seems to have been busy hunting offbeat, music to introduce to the United States.
The Queens District Attorney's office was ordered yesterday to provide detailed reasons why it feels seven reputed Mafia leaders should be cited for criminal contempt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) A bill providing antitrust immunity for the merger of the National and American Football Leagues was approved today in the Senate as a rider on the Administration's antiinflation program.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Oct. 13 Three Israeli soldiers were wounded early today when their vehicle was fired on by Arab terrorists about two miles inside Israel.
The four major lumber associations reported a decline of 12.8 per cent in production for the week ended Oct. 8 compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.
Robert F. Hurleigh announced last night his resignation as president of the Mutual Broadcasting System. He said "personal reasons" led to the decision.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -President Johnson signed today a proclamation, a bill and an executive order designed to increase the international flow of books, audio-visual educational materials, scientific instruments and art.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy's office confirmed yesterday that Mrs. Kennedy was expecting a 10th child in the spring.
The Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company, Philadelphia, announced yesterday the election of James F. Bodine and Robert O. Fickes as directors.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14 The Security Council voted unanimously tonight to accept Portugal's statement that she was not allowing her African territory of Angola to he used for subversive activities against the neighboring Congo but to ask her not to do so in the future.

Robert M. Stiefler, President of the Guest Pac Corporation of Mount Vernon, N.Y., died Wednesday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 49 years old and lived on Bardion Lane in Harrison, N.Y.

This week the Reproducta Company, a greeting card manufacturer employing 100 persons in a 60,000-square-foot factory in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, decided to relocate in Port Chester, N.Y. "We did not want to do it," Rudolph B. Schulhof, president of the company, said yesterday.

If the opponents of the heliport atop the Pan American Building get their way, 2,000 or more persons will try to crowd into the Board of Estimate room in City Hall Thursday to protest the renewal of a permit to New York Airways to operate the helicopters to Kennedy Airport.
GENEVA, Oct. 14 The Swiss Government announced today the lifting of the last of the restrictions imposed more than two years ago on foreign investment in Swiss securities.
No reviewer assessing Sean Hignett's first novel, just imported from Europe and accompanied by assorted huzzahs, will please more than part of his audience.
Eugene Tillinger, American correspondent for Paris Jour, a French daily newspaper, died of a heart attack Thursday night in his home at 321 West 78th Street. His age was 58.
British Government bonds continued to show firmness on the London Stock Exchange yesterday but industrial issues retreated in quiet trading.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 14 (AP) Four Negroes attending a Roman Catholic women's meeting were turned away from the Governor's mansion Wednesday when they arrived with others for a tea.

Municipal bond dealers continued to report yesterday a pick-up in purchases of taxexempt securities. Treasury bonds slipped and then recovered while the most actively traded corporate bonds declined slightly.

LUBEC, Me., Oct. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Carleton M. Pike of Lubec and Chestnut Hill, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Pike, to Robert Shaw Oliver Harding, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Harding of New York and Rumson, N.J.

Princess Stanislas Radziwill, sister of Mrs. John F. Kennedy, is expected to fly here from her home in London to attend "An Operatic Salute to the World's Children" on Oct. 23 at Philharmonic Hall. She is honorary chairman of the evening.

THE Smetena Quartet, the Czechoslovak ensem ble that opened the chamber music series at Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night, has personality, at least. Whether this quality was always suitable to the music played is debatable, but whatever the results stylistic comfort or clash the performances were not run-ofthe-mill, and had a decided fascination.
THE line-for-line copies of couture imports that semi annually attract thousands of women to stores that specialize in them are apparently more alluring this year than ever before.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 14 Sixty-five businessmen, bankers and manufacturers gathered at Fairfield University today for an all-day seminar. They heard a 1967 economic forecast that was almost as bright as the weather on this Sunny, Indian summer day.
WASHINGTON, Oct.14 (AP) -The House approved today by a vote of 204 to 141 a bill to establish an Indiana Dunes national lakeshore.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14-- Members of the Philadelphia Orchestra, on strike since Sept. 19, played a special benefit concert here tonight under the baton of Leopold Stokowski, their former musical director.

Miss Claire Wever, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George DeWolf Wever of New York and the Onteora Club in Tannersville, was married yesterday to Bartolo Bracaglia, son of Mrs. Silverio Bracaglia of Rome and the late Mr. Bracaglia.
RUXTON, Md., Oct. 14 Mrs. Wren Kellogg has announced the engagement of her daughter Miss Wren Devereux Winslow, to Timothy Endicott Wirth son of Mrs. John J. Wiebenson of Denver.
Tokyo-Fujio Mikami, 132 pounds, Japan, outpointed Chukyo-Shin, 135, South Korea, 10 rounds,

TULSA, Okla., Oct. 14 A Self-made, publicity-shy oil and ranch millionaire has left about $100-million to education and health science in three Southwestern states. The bequest has overnight more than doubled the endowment of the major beneficiary, the University of Tulsa.
MONTREAL, Oct. 14 An explosion that shattered the Monsanto Canada Ltd. chemical plant in suburban LaSalle last night killed 11 persons.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 Robert M. Shelton Jr., Imperial Wizard of the United Klans of America, received today a maximum sentence of one year in prison and a $1,000 fine for contempt of Congress.

Governor Rockefeller refused yesterday to "dignify" with an answer a charge by Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. that the Governor's nomination in 1958 had resulted from a "deal" engineered by political bosses.
WASHINGTON, Oct, 14 (AP) -The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a bill to ban hazardous toys, and ether children's articles containing hazardous substances, from interstate commerce.

Some 2,000 hospital workers and 250 patients at Coney Island Hospital are receiving injections of gamma globulin following the deaths of two special-duty nurses with symptoms that might indicate infectious hepatitis.
ROME, Oct. 14 (AP) Worldwide demand for rice is expected to increase by 100 million tons in the next 20 years, but experts doubt whether production can meet the rising need.
The Board of Estimate moved yesterday to end a tie-up that has delayed pension payments to former city employes for up to 10 months.
NEW DELHI, Oct, 14 India has appealed to the United States and North Vietnam to avoid further escalstion of military activities in the demilitarized Zone of Vietnam.
The wholesale commodity price index was 103.6 on Thursday, unchanged from Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) The National Community Television Association has asked the Federal Communications Commission to investigate the relationship between Bell System companies and Community Antenna Television systems. The association complained Thursday about rates the companies charge.

BELMOND, Iowa, Oct. 14 (AP) A tornado swooped down with little warning on this north central Iowa town today, minutes after a high school homecoming parade broke up. It demolished the business district and left at least six persons dead.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 14 Dr. J. Kenneth Catlaw, director of surgery at St. Francis Hospital here and at the Hudson County Hospital for Mental Diseases in Secaucus, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital. He was 55 years old and resided at 321 Stegman Parkway.
BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 14 Britons were told today that the Conservative answer to their economic maladies was competition instead of compulsion.

Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon charged last night that President Johnson had jeopardized bipartisan support for his Manila trip with "a vicious, unwarranted and partisan assault upon the Republican party."

The Mary Poppins statue proposed for Central Park is atrociously bad art, as New York City's esthetically sophisticated Parks Commissioner must know. It is also an unjustifiable encroachment on park land, of which Commissioner Hoving, with his newly laid and loudly publicized policies of nonencroachment, must be equally well aware.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct, 14-- Mike Turnesa of Knollwood, who held a two-stroke lead at the halfway mark, won the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association seniors championship today by one stroke with 145.
The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, Inc., announced yesterday it had started construction on the fourth and fifth plants of its oil-refining and petrochemical complex at Penuelas, P.R.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 Britain's Foreign Secretary, George Brown, offered today to help the United States find an honorable solution to the problem of the war in Vietnam.

PARIS, Oct. 14 The public prosecutor today asked for prison sentences ranging from 3 to 20 years for those arrested in Paris for the kidnapping of Mehdi Ben Barka, the exiled leader of the Moroccan Opposition.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 14 (AP) Samuel H. Sheppard's second murder trial will be held in the same courthouse here where he was convicted 12 years ago, unless efforts to seat an impartial jury fail, a judge ruled today.
A Yugoslav citizen who is here on vacation said yesterday that he would seek political asylum in this country to avoid arrest in Yugoslavia.
James Monroe blanked Roosevelt High School of Yonkers, 28-0, at Monroe Field yesterday. It was Monroe's second victory in three games and Roosevelt's third straight defeat.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Oct. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Milton A. Gibbons have announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary P. Murphy, to Capt. William J. Dieal Jr., U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dieal of Bedford Hills.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 14 Harold Howe 2d, United States Commissioner of Education, urged universities today to "build an appraisal of teaching ability into their promotion procedures" if they were serious about improving the quality of teaching.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 The Glidden Company has made the Southern pine tree a major source of such fragrances and flavors as lavender, rose, bergamot,...
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Oct. 14 (AP) Clifton Webb, a child actor who became the star of smart Broadway shows and went on to win his greatest fame in the movies, died last night of a heart attack.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) A railroad executive advocated today that the Port of Chicago and other Great Lakes ports band together to develop a full line of favorable import and export rail rates to and from Great Lakes ports.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 14 Gone today were the 50-mile-anhour winds as sub-par scores were recorded in the third round of the $100,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament. No one equaled or bettered par yesterday.
Seaboard World Airlines has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to operate all-cargo jet service to Spain and Portugal, with five DC-8F freighters.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 14 Mr. and Mrs. William E. Miller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Anne Miller, to Capt. Paul Francis Fitzgerald, Medical Corps, Air Force, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis M. Fitzgerald of Rockville Centre, L.I. An April wedding is planned.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 14 United States fighterbombers flew a record total of 173 multiplane missions against North Vietnam yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 The index of primary market prices remained unchanged at 106.1 during the week ended Oct. 11, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products increased in price while processed foods decreased. Industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

The situation in the Near East has reached one of its frequent points of high tension with the exacerbation of Israeli-Syrian relations. Last weekend four Israelis were killed and several wounded by Palestinian terrorists operating from and defended by Syria.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 14 The United States announced today that it would resume bombing the easternmost part of the demilitarized zone "if there is North Vietnamese Army or Vietcong military action in the area."

LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP)-- Four major paintings from the collection of Henry Ford 2d will be auctioned at Christie's on Dec. 5. They are Matisse's "Girl Reading," Signac's "St. Tropez," Vuillard's "Interior" and a small Picasso. Mr. Ford paid $43,000 for the Signac at a New York auction in 1963.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 (AP) Americans won four gold medals today in swimming competition at the Little Olympics.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14--The House handed President Johnson one of his biggest legislative victories of the year tonight when it approved by 178 to 141 a billion dollar...
Noise levels in the nation's communities are reaching the point where they are causing significant hearing impairment among Americans, a researcher who has been studying the problem said yesterday.

Richard Cappadona, a fullback, scored 19 points yesterday in Riverdale's 25-0 victory over Stony Brook School at Memorial Field, Riverdale. It was the Indians' second victory in three games and Stony Brook's second setback of three outings.
TRENTON, Oct. 14 Gov. Richard J. Hughes announced today that the Federal Government had agreed to provide $5million for the purchase of 35 commuter cars for the Pennsylvania Railroad.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14 (UPI) Two major daily newspapers, prevented by a wildcat work stoppage from printing daily editions, said today they would print special weekend editions.
Record sales and profits and an increased quarterly dividend were disclosed at the annual meeting of stockholders of the Consolidated Foods Corporation held yesterday in Chicago.
An off-duty policeman killed a holdup man in a barroom gun duel in Brooklyn yesterday.

The two surviving members of a three-man team who over the last 41 years have developed Farrell Lines, Inc., into a highly successful and far-ranging shipping operation are to "swallow the anchor" at the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, Oct.14 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of William Haddon Jr. of New York for the new post of traffic safety administrator under legislation designed to reduce the highway accident toll.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara returned today from a four-day trip to South Vietnam and reported to President Johnson this afternoon.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 14 (UPI) Federico de Onis, one of the world's leading scholars of Spanish and Latin-American literature, died here today at the age of 80. According to the police, he killed himself by firing a bullet into his right temple at his home.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 The United States acknowledged today that because of "pilot error," two American helicopters attacked a Cambodian army post near South Vietnam on Sept. 20.
Ernest S. Pisko, until last year a member of the overseas news staff of The Christian Science Monitor, died Oct. 5 in Frankfurt, Germany, while on a trip. He was 70 years old and had lived in Boston.
MARION, Iowa, Oct. 14 Another bit of Americana was plowed under today. The last National Corn Picking Contest ended this afternoon to join the horse-drawn plow as a part of agricultural history.

Signed proclamation on Beirut Convention; saw British Foreign Secretary Brown; attended Senate luncheon at Capitol; saw Defense Secretary McNamara. White House announced that threat of strike against General Electric Company had been averted.
TENAFLY, N.J., Oct. 14 Arcady Dubensky, composer and former member of the violin section of the New York Philharmonic, died at his home here today. He was 82 years old.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 Ferdinand Lewis Alcindor, a basketball player of renown before he has played his first minute on the varsity, made his formal debut today before newsmen at the University of California, Los Angeles.
Sardi's Restaurant, at 234 West 44th Street, will open the Club Sardi, a new room for first-nighters and actors, on Tuesday. It will be on the second floor.
DUBLIN, Oct. 14 (Reuters) The Dublin Theater Festival will not be staged again unless 10,000 ($28,000) can be raised Brendan Smith, the festival's director said here today.
The American Machine and Foundry Company has announced the appointment of George A. Fowlkes as a division vice president.
Congress has made another substantial advance in the long struggle to check the foul tide of pollution and restore the nation's rivers and lakes to safe and usable, if not absolutely pure, condition.
Judge John R. Bartels of the United States District Court has upheld the Port of New York Authority's right to restrict jet flights on one runway at La Guardia Airport as a noise-abatement measure.

PARIS, Oct. 14 (AP) Louise Thuliez, a companion of the British nurse Edith Cavell in World War I and an anti-Nazi underground worker in World War II, died yesterday in the Saint Joseph Hospital of Paris. She was 85 years old.
The McCrory Corporation announced yesterday its purchase from Best Co. Stores of Delaware, Inc., of 16 of the company's 21, specialty stores and the name "Best Co."
The city made its first award yesterday under its new "Good Samaritan" law, which provides for payments to persons injured while preventing a crime and to survivors of those killed.
Bernhardt Cohen, an inventor of many textile manufacturing processes, including machinery extensively used in the ribbon industry, died yesterday at his home, 101 West 12th Street. His age was 65.
Mayor Lindsay and Austin N. Heller, the city's new Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, were guilty of considerably overselling their clean air program when they announced it a few days ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 Joseph A. Califano Jr. is expected by industry sources to be named the nation's first Secretary of Transportation.
LONDON, Oct. 14 The Government's wage freeze reached down today to specific worker groups.
DENVER, Oct. 14 (UPI) A storm dumped up to 17 inches of snow on the Rocky Mountain region today, killing at least eight persons and trapping 500 hunters in the Snowy Range in Wyoming.

"The Bettmann Portable Archive." a selection of 3,669 pictures from the Bettmann Archives, a collection of pictures on more than 5,000 subjects, will be distributed by Picture House Press on Tuesday. Dr. Otto Bettmann, founder of the archives, selected the pictures.
A second order for the arrest of Representative Adam Clayton Powell as a debtor was issued yesterday but, like the first one, it cannot be carried cut while Congress is in session.

Strong pressure is developing throughout New York State for eliminating or weakening the ban on the use of public funds for schools operated under religious auspices. We believe that next year's constitutional convention should stand firm in maintaining the fundamental principle that tax money should not be used for such purposes.
THE three unbeaten teams in pro football the New York Jets, the Dallas Cowboys and the St. Louis Cardinals will be on display tomorrow an local television.

Columbia's lightweight football team lost the first game of its season yesterday, bowing to Rutgers, 22-8, at Baker Field. The Lion defense was no match for the aerial attack of Rutgers, paced by James Yore, the Scarlet's quarterback.

The 19-year-old wife of a young African diplomat threw her two babies out the window of her East Side apartment yesterday morning and then leaped to her own death to the concrete courtyard 18 stories below.
MONTREAL, Oct, 14 (Canadian Press) Montreal's new subway system, gleaming with the French touch, was officially opened today.

LAST night's performance of "Theater and Engineer ing" at the 69th Regiment Armory proved, to my mind, one thing fairly conclusively: If the American engineers and technologists participating in this performance were typical of their profession, the Russians are sure to be first on the moon.
TODAY is the final day for the New York Antiques Fair at the armory at Park Avenue and 34th Street. It is worth a visit to see a fine cross section of the sort of antiques people are collecting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it would appeal a lower court's denial of a preliminary injunction against certain officers and directors of Great American Industries, Inc., whom it had charged with making false statements.
SAN FRANCISCO California vintners, taking stock of the 1966 grape harvest, face an intriguing problem.
Mrs. Florence Hays Corn, widow of Joseph J. Corn, a lawyer, died yesterday in her home, 125 East 87th Street, at the age of 84.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., Oct. 14 (UPI) A field of 11 fillies and mares was entered today for tomorrow's $50,000 added Vineland Handicap at Garden State Park. Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Straight Deal, Harbor View Farm's Swinging Mood and Golden Triangle Stable's Lady Pitt head the field.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 Industrial production, after advancing every month for a year, declined slightly in September, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct.14 Mr. and Mrs. William McKissack Chapman have announced the engagement of Mr. Chapman's daughter, Miss Ellen Montague Chapman of New York, to William Francis Reilly Jr., son of Mrs. Reilly of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and the late Mr. Reilly. A Nov. 19 wedding is planned.
Pamela L. Travers, the "Irish" author who created Mary Poppins, is playing a large part in the planning for a Central Park statue of the wonderworking governess.
Mrs. Alvina Dean, whose 10year-old son was killed last summer during racial violence in East New York, packed the dead boy's clothing into paper bags yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14-- After two days of berating the Republicans on the hustings as the party of fear, President Johnson went up to the Senate today and heaped praise on "my loyal opposition" for its help in making the 89th Congress "the greatest Congress" in history.
Thieves preying on elderly persons who live alone, murdered a woman in the Bronx yesterday and a man in East Harlem, the police reported.

MADRID, Oct. 14 -- Madrid's Royal Theater, where Caruso once sang and Igor Stravinsky watched his work performed as ballet, came back to life last night to the strains of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony after 41 years of silence.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14 Israel accused Syria tonight of planning to destroy her by war.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Oct. 14 (AP) The light-heavyweight champion, Josh Torres, was an 8-5 favorite today to retain his title in a 15-round bout against a Scottish challenger, Chic Calderwood, tomorrow night.

MADRID, Oct. 14 A Soviet space official said today that his nation, which has not sent men into orbit in 19 months, is "doing very serious preparatory work" for another manned mission that would be a "serious new step" in space exploration.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 14 Mrs. B. Louise Mueller Hoffman of the Chateau Lafayette, long a leader in garden club activities, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, at the age of 77. She was the widow of Dr. Charles Hoffman, a chemist.

A group of shareholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is going ahead with plans to fight the Securities and Exchange Commission, contending that the commission is trying to restrict its freedom of speech.
DENVER, Oct. 14 (UPI) Cookie Gilchrist, the Denver Broncos' absent fullback, said today he would return to the Broncos even if it meant a pay cut.

BERLIN, Oct. 14 The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, reported to President Walter Ulbricht on the state of Soviet-American relations and other international questions at a meeting today in East Berlin.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., Oct. 14 Mrs. Alfred King of Rumson won a New Jersey Women's Golf Association one-day tournament today with a 41, 41 82 at the Spring Lake Country Club.

Mrs. Julia Lytle Chambers of 8 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, a former secretary of the New York Kindergarten Association and a former language teacher, died on Thursday in a Brooklyn hospital. Her age was 82.

Lyndon B. Johnson, whose acknowledged political hero is Franklin D. Roosevelt, has had difficulty of late deciding which of his hero's political styles he would emulate. He started off in August as if he would copy the wide-ranging Roosevelt of the 1930's and campaign in all 50 states.
LONDON. IN the early 1920's a rocket shot out of Russia, started fires mainly around Germany for four years, returned to Russia in 1925, and has now been more or less forgotten by the world at large.

NOAH'S ark has been such a popular favorite with children's book writers that one would expect it to survive, as do so many alphabet and counting books today, as an exhausted clich . These two books, however, are refreshingly original. Totally different in approach, each treats the theme with all the excitement of the new, and the results are striking evidence that age-old themes, properly handled, are inexhaustible wells of inspiration.

THE world of bridge has lost two of its greatest citizens in the last six months. The death earlier this month of Albert Morehead, author of this column for almost 30 years, followed soon that of his close friend, Ewart Kempson of England.
MISSOULA, Mont., Oct. 14 Senator Lee Metcalf appears to have a thin lead over Gov. Tim M. Babcock in one of the year's definitive confrontations of opposing philosophies.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 8 Just about the only issue on which diplomats are in agreement these days is their desire to see U Thant remain as Secretary-General.

NOT many decades ago it was popular to refer to China as a "sleeping" lion or dragon. The choice in animals perhaps reflected differences in attitude as to what the beast would do when finally awakened, but all agreed that it was dormant. No one feels that way now.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 15 Freehold Raceway, a 114-year old harness racing layout 48 miles and 60 minutes from Times Square, finished its 60day meeting today in 75-degree warmth, with a reasonable profit and in an atmosphere of good fellowship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Dr. Ross Gunn, a physicist, described in a resolution submitted to Congress three years ago as one of the "true fathers of the nuclear submarine program, died here today. He was 69 years old and since 1958 had been a research professor of physics at the American University.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 12 A mop-haired singer has become the symbol of a social eruption by Brazil's youth.

PARIS, Oct. 15 When Premier Todor Zhivkov of Bulgaria came to Paris this week on his first official visit to a Western European country, the Communist daily L'Humanite noted his arrival on the lower half of its front page. LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 16 (AP) Prince Rainier of Monaco says Aristotle Onassis has lost interest in the development of Monte Carlo.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 The Ford Company unveiled here yesterday a prototype gas turbine engine for tractor-trailers. The engine is virtually noiseless and according to a company engineering spokesman, emits only onetenth of the pollutants that a diesel engine of similar capabilities would emit.

ON Election Day the voters of New York City will decide whether they want civilians to sit on a board to hear citizens' complaints against the police. Natwar-Singh has chosen, but because of the difficulties inherent in selection and translation from the 14 national languages now formally recognized by the Constitution of India.

All of the struggles have had factors in common with Vietnam and thus throw some light on the nature of that conflict.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 President Johnson, in a major foreign policy speech a week ago, cited as one of the great "unfinished" tasks of our generation the task of "making Europe whole again." Beach, father of the author of this book, had his men ready to get the ship under way on an hour's notice.

WALLINGFORD, Vt. "If you don't ski or skate, then snow shoe." That is the advice snowshoeing enthusiasts keep offering to those winter sportsmen who are skeptical about their ability to maneuver on skis or on ice skates. And, although skiing and skating are conceded to be sports with more appeal, snowshoeing is picking up its share of followers every year.

THE HAGUE, Oct. 15 Premier Joseph Cals offered his resignation to Queen Juliana today after losing a confidence vote yesterday. ANTI-AIRCRAFT guns and guided missiles have been crowded in around Hanoi so tightly that U.S. pilots now call it "Dodge City." NORTH TROY, Vt. Although aerial tramways for skiers are found frequently in Europe's snow country, they are still relatively rare in the United States. Indeed, the 7,800-foot two-cabin tram that will be operated at nearby Jay Peak this season is only the second such installation in the East. The other one, a smaller system, is on Cannon Mountain in New Hampshire's White Mountains.

Sonatas by Franck and Prokofiev were the major works in the violin recital given at Town Hall yesterday afternoon by Ernesto Farago, a former member of the National Symphony of Washington.

THE versatile chess veteran, Grand Master Larry Evans of New York, topped a 201-man field to win the recent Canadian Open at Queen's University in Kingston, Ont. Evans posted eight victories and two draws to tally 9-1 in this 10-round Swiss system.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 15 (AP) Quarterback Alan Pastrana brought Maryland out of its shell late in the first half by passing for two touchdowns, and the Terrapins went on to a 28-9 football victory over West Virginia today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15--The nation is lagging seriously in the building of hospitals, nursing homes and facilities for professional schools in the health field, according to Wilbur J. Cohen, Under Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 (AP) Sophomore Sam Havrilak, a second string quarterback who also plays end, guided Bucknell to three second-half touchdowns, scoring the key one himself, as the Bisons upset Penn, 28-21, today at Franklin Field.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 15 Jack Nicklaus won $20,000 by taking the Sahara golf tournament by three strokes today. The setting was tranquil, with the high winds of two days ago only a memory. The only noticeable breeze was created by the booming shots Nicklaus hit in a final 66 over the Paradise Valley Country Club course.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 16 Gen. Moshe Dayan, former Israeli Chief of Staff, who observed the war in Vietnam for five weeks, wrote admiringly today of the Americans' military fire power and the aggressive spirit.

The nation's railroads and private car lines took delivery in August of 9,482 new and rebuilt freight cars. This brought the number of such cars added to the national fleet to 69,269 in the first eight months this year and the total fleet to 1,810,259.

Of all the migrant birds, the wild goose seems most to typify the restless spirit of autumn. A part of this comes from the fact that geese are big, spectacular birds and travel in flocks, often huge flocks. But another part is the garrulousness of geese. Most birds travel in silence, but not the goose. In the air or on the water, it chatters and gabbles, gossips and confers. Geese are not reticent birds.

LATE one afternoon in June, 1965, Lyndon Johnson was stretched out on the foredeck of his cabin cruiser idling slowly up the Texas lake that bears his name. It had been a good day. Now, he was doing one of the things he loved most watching the sun sink slowly behind the Texas hills.

COMMACK, L.I., Oct. 16 Firing the puck goalward 59 times through the smoke-filled haze that blanketed the Long Island Arena, the New York Rangers staged their annual rout tonight over their country cousins, the Ducks.

Poland's Jewish State Theater from Warsaw will make its first American appearance here in March for a month's engagement at a Shubert house to be designated later. A post-Broadway journey of three and a half weeks will include stops in Montreal and Philadelphia.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 15 At 2 P.M. last Friday, as David F. Cargo was walking into an Albuquerque high school, a man wearing a Stetson hat and a business suit hailed him, clapped him on the back, and pressed a small wad of currency into his hand.
The General Electric conference board of the International Union of Electrical Workers approved yesterday a new three-year contract with the company.

Michigan state's Spartans, trailing Ohio State, 8-3, in the last quarter, and Alabama, behind, 10-0, against Tennessee both just managed to avert disaster Saturday, but they will undoubtedly be topped by Notre Dame in the football ranking polls this week.
Lione Jodis, contralto, who sang at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, is a thoughtful, accomplished musician. She gets to the root of each song and aria with intelligent pacing and well-placed nuance.
Aqueduct will launch a lively week of racing (four stakes in six days) today with the $25,000-added, six-furlong Interborough Handicap for fillies and mares.

MADRID, Oct. 16 (Reuters) A century-old bullfighting dynasty ended here tonight when 44-year-old Antonio Bienvenida killed six bulls alone and then allowed his pigtail, symbol of the torero, to be cut.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 The Republican party has accused President Johnson of deliberately trying to distort the G.O.P.'s legislative record on Social Security and Medicare.

The annual fall dinner dance given by the Women of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest will be held on Oct. 28 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. Benefiting from the event will be the Youth Program fund of the parish.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 (UPI) Yoshinobu Miyake, a 26-yearold featherweight from Tokyo, won his fifth world weight-lifting title tonight, defeating Mieczyslaw Nowak of Poland and his brother, Yoshiyuki Miyake.

WROCLAW, Poland, Oct. 16 The most important city that Poland won from Germany after Worm War II gave Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski two triumphant days that ended tonight in a jubilant procession at an open air mass.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 16 Hunt House a prerevolutionary landmark, was badly damaged by fire early this morning.

Harvey R. Burke has been appointed vice president, manufacturing, of the F.W. Dodge Company, marketing and information subsidiary of McGraw-Hill, Inc. Mr. Berke was formerly with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

A champagne preview of paintings by 26 exiled Hungarian artists will be held on Friday afternoon in the Carnegie International Center at 345 East 46th Street. Commissioner of Public Events John S. Palmer will open the show, a benefit for the Hungarian Freedom Fighters Fellowship Fund. The exhibition will be open to the public through Oct. 28.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., Oct. 16 George E. Dennen, a former Brooklyn Assemblyman and newspaperman, died yesterday in the Floral Park Nursing Home. He was 82 years old and lived at 82 Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to place two small monkeys in orbit for six months to a year in an effort to learn more about the impact of weightlessness.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 16 With a probable deficit of more than $1-million expected for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine for 1966 and a larger one for 1967, Lawrence Michelmore, the agency's Commissioner General, sought guidance today from the General Assembly.
One in four Americans will be stricken with cancer if the current rate continues, the American Cancer Society predicted yesterday. It said an American would die of cancer every two minutes next year.
Shuttle buses, staggered curtain times and a new underground garage are among the plans being considered to ease traffic congestion at Lincoln Center.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 16 Philip Dollin of Sea Cliff (L.I.) Yacht Club, sailing Mabel, won the annual singlehanded race of the Western Long Island Sound International Class today off Larchmont Yacht Club.
A 4-year-old boy was killed yesterday by a car that mounted a curb and struck a group of pedestrians at a bus stop in Jamaica, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 A bitter struggle between supporters and opponents of extensive additions to the urban freeway system in Washington has apparently been won by the highway partisans.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 16 Edward A. Frohling, former executive vice president of the First National Bank of Princeton and a pioneer income-tax consultant, died at his home here today. He was 79 years old.

Two buildings at the Sea View Hospital and Home on Staten Island were inspected for four hours yesterday to determine if violations of fire regulations could be corrected so that 194 elderly patients would not have to be moved to other city institutions.
East Harlem parents and community leaders will meet with the Board of Education at 1 P.M. today in a new attempt to compromise differences over the operation of Intermediate School 201.
Justice William T. Cowin of Brooklyn, who has been appointed to the bench six times since 1960 by Governor Rockefeller, hopes finally to win a seat by election.
The United States producers shipped 113.8 million pounds of acetate filament yarn and rayon in September, a 6.5 percent decrease from August, the Textile Economics Bureau reported over the weekend.
Several large offerings of corporate bonds and the biggest competitive tax-exempt sale in more than a month will highlight the financing calendar this week.

The Internal Revenue Service issued a regulatory proposal recently that could have tremendous impact on employe pension plans in terms of the size of benefits to employes and the total cost to employers.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 16 (Reuters) Premier Youssef Zayen of Syria tonight formed a new 22-man Cabinet that included four members outside the ruling Baath party.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 Miss Joanna Crawford and Robert B. Radnitz were married this afternoon at the Bel-Air Hotel by Judge Andrew Weisz of the Los Angeles Municipal Court.
Stepping smartly under a bright afternoon sun, units of the armed forces, veterans groups and patriotic societies marched down Fifth Avenue yesterday in the 45th annual Massing of the Colors.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 The white backlash is once again a major factor in an American political campaign.
A leading maritime trade group announced yesterday that it would move its top management to Washington, where it has maintained a subsidiary office for many years.

Members of Teamster Local 237 will meet at 7 P.M. today in the Manhattan Center, on 34th Street near Eighth Avenue, to decide whether to strike the New York City Housing Authority and other city agencies.
A 34-year-old man dangled for an hour from a fourth-floor window ledge last night and then jumped into and out of a police emergency net.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn. "He won last time because of President Johnson. Now I think he'll lose again for the same reason," said Thomas J. Meskill, a 38-year-old Republican lawyer, who is running hard to capture the Sixth Congressional District.

The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday issued an appeal to college and university faculty members across the country to "resist vigorously current pressures of superpatriots" trying to curtail academic freedom.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Oct. 17 (AP)--Finance Minister Au Truong Thanh revived South Vietnam's political crisis today with a threat to resign unless the complaints of southerners in the Cabinet are satisfied.
The Gogolak brothers, Pete of the New York Giants and Charlie of the Washington Redskins, opposed each other for the first time as professional place-kickers yesterday at Yankee Stadium.

NEWARK, Oct. 16 The Rev. Dr. Benjamin Martin Washburn, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark from 1935 until his retirement in 1958, died today at his home, 11 Barrack Hill Read in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 79 years old.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 An impatient Congress, tired of itself and of the issues at hand will push this week for adjournment, already four months overdue.
CRESSKILL, N.J., Oct. 16 Miss Lynn Zeichner was married here today to Eugene S. Darvin, in the Tammy Brook Country Club by Rabbi Solomon Rothstein.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 16 (UPI) Fran Tarkenton passed for three touchdowns, scored one and set up a fifth today to lead the Minnesota Vikings to a 35-7 victory over Los Angeles, knocking the Rams out of a first-place tie in the Western Conference of the National Football League.

IF you like farce Highly, beautifully stylized, zany, nutty farce go see "Eh?" No, the title is not enticing (though in terms of meaning, it's accurate enough), but this little British comedy by Henry Livings, which opened last night at the Circle in the Square, is, if nothing else, good boffo fun.

The American Broadcasting Company network was reported yesterday to be close to a decision to start televising motion-picture feature films from 9 to 11 P.M. each Wednesday. The change, which could occur in January, would give A.B.C. a second night of movies, evening it up with the Columbia Broadcasting System and National Broadcasting Company networks.
ATLANTA, Oct. 16 A South Carolina school board thought the United States Office of Education was bluffing earlier this year, when it handed down its guidelines for school desegregation.
HENDERSON, Ky., Oct. 16 (AP) Frank Wallace, a retired song-and-dance man and former husband of Mae West, the actress, died yesterday. He was 73 years old and had lived here since 1949.

About 40,000 business and trade executives are expected to journey this week to Chicago's McCormick Place to see what to expect in the way of office machines and furniture. The occasion will be the annual Business Equipment Exposition, which opens today for a weeklong run.
There were 1,000 people on line yesterday afternoon for an exhibition that is to museums what "Fiddler on the Roof" is to theater.

MOSCOW, Oct. 16 Communist leaders of Eastern Europe are converging on Moscow for a summit conference this week. The Kremlin is expected to press for censure of Communist China and thereby free the Soviet Union to indicate a new flexibility in foreign policy, including diplomacy on the war in Vietnam.

WOODMERE, L.I., Oct. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Roger Sanderson Hewlett have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Putnam Hewlett, to Robert Oscar Johnson, son of Mrs. Robert O. Johnson of San Francisco and the late Mr. Johnson.
Net assets of the American Research and Development Corporation stood on Sept. 30 at $74,484,646, or $48.52 a share, the concern reported yesterday.
Matthew J. Culligan, who resigned as head of the Curtis Publishing Company in October, 1964, is going to work today as president and chief executive officer of the Mutual Broadcasting System.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 16 Three generations of more conservative Tafts must have stirred uneasily today as Senator Jacob K. Javits came to Ohio to campaign for the fourth generation.

Complaints by three anti-Vietnam war draftees about their treatment as Army prisoners were made public here yesterday. They were rebutted by an Army spokesman who said the men had been shifted into cells with other prisoners last week after showing "good behavior."

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell was installed as president of the New York Theological Seminary yesterday and used the occasion to chide "go-go" theologies whose adherents are always "doing something."
TOLEDO, Spain, Oct. 16 Jews returned to the historic synagogue here this morning after nearly 500 years.

Two major industrial giants the Eastman Kodak Company and the Continental Can Company reached the billion-dollar sales mark for the first time in the nine months ended with September, according to their reports released yesterday.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy has obtained one foundation grant and applied for several others in a pilot slum-rebuilding program here designed to get business to join foundations and government in aiding the ghettos.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Oct. 16 President Johnson, taking a last political fling before departing tomorrow for a tour of Asia, helped consecrate today a huge Roman Catholic shrine intended as a symbol of unity for Polish-Americans.

ATLANTA, Oct. 16 (UPI) A Democratic official said today that the party's segregationist candidate for Governor, Lester G. Maddox, had made a secret pact to support three Negroes running for the state Legislature and the party's 1968 Presidential nominee.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 16 (AP) Lee Roy Yarbrough, who hadn't finished a major event all year, kept his purple and gold Dodge Charger together today and won the national 500-mile stock car race after leading most of the way.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16 Charles H. Percy deplored today the prospect of white backlash voting next month but conceded that it would be a factor in the Illinois Senate race.
PARIS, Oct. 16 (UPI) David Piper and Michael Parkes of Britain drove their Ferrari to victory today in the Paris 621mile automobile race.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 16 (Reuters) The Chilean Congress gave itself and president Eduardo Frei Montalva's Government sweeping new powers today to decide on expropriation of property.

Residents of the Hamilton Grange neighborhood on the Upper West Side began circulating petitions yesterday asking the Federal Government not to remove Alexander Hamilton's 1802 country house, which gives the community its name.
BORDEAUX, France Growers of some of the finest wines in France are seeking to revolutionize their ancient craft. They are trying to eliminate "bad years."
William F. Buckley Jr. had but never used a signed endorsement from Barry Goldwater, the 1964 Republican Presidential candidate, in his Conservative party race for Mayor last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 The Securities and Exchange Commission, to the outrage of another Government agency, is on the brink of backing down on one of the most strongly worded stock market reform proposals contained in its Special Study of Securities Markets.
DETROIT, Oct. 16 Gov. George Romney's shadowy campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination inched further into the sunlight last week.
