BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 16 The Government ordered a three-day bank holiday tonight in the wake of the closing of Intra Bank, Lebanon's largest financial house, because...
THONAONHAN, South Vietnam, Oct. 15 United States Marines marched along the edge of the demilitarized zone today and found that North Vietnamese pack elephants had been there before them.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16 The largest crowd ever to watch a sports event in St. Louis 50,673 was treated today to one of the strongest defensive games in recent professional football seasons as the Dallas Cowboys and St. Louis Cardinals battled to a 10-10 tie in Busch Memorial Stadium.
The United States turned a fateful corner with its proposals to the United Nations on South-West Africa last week, and it came about in an unusual way.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 More than 800 radio stations throughout the country have asked the United States Public Health Service for spot announcements on the danger of cigarette smoking.

Another Bach concert, this one the beginning of a six-event Bach series, was given at Philharmonic Hall last night. It presented the Esterhazy Orchestra conducted by David Blum with Ralph Kirkpatrick as harpsichord soloist.
The auction room at the Parke-Bernet Galleries is small, intimate, informal as concert halls go, and the performers are practically in the audience's laps.
GAITHERSBURG, Md., Oct. 16 A homebred kerry blue terrier was chosen best in show today among 1,282 dogs in the Rock Creek Kennel Club's allbreed event.
Plans for a general cargo marine terminal capable of berthing up to 14 oceangoing ships simultaneously were made public over the weekend by the Philadelphia Port Corporation.

THE miracle of "Brigadoon" took place once more Sat- urday night, this time before a nationwide television audience. One can only hope that we won't have to wait another 100 years before we see it again.
"I think God has white skin," said Jonathan Coleman. "I don't like my curly hair. I don't look pretty. I don't like myself."

LEE MacPHAIL is about to move into the same general manager's post with the New York Yankees that his father once held about two decades ago. Even their legal names are the same. Leland Stanford MacPhail Jr. and Sr., with the son called Lee and the father Larry. But that doesn't begin to indicate how much they differ.
SHELTON, Conn. An energetic 37-year-old lawyer named Romeo G. Petroni sipped a whisky sour in Rapp's Restaurant after a brisk handshaking tour through the Goodrich plant here.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 16 The United States Equestrian Team will have to play catchup in international jumping competition at the Pennsylvania National horse show, but Coach Bert deNemethy isn't particularly worried.

Montana which has produced nationally famous Senators from the Thomas J. Walsh and Burton K. Wheeler of an earlier era to Mike Mansfield, the majority leader today has an outstanding public servant in its junior Senator, Lee Metcalf. He deserves to be better known.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 16 "There is a fort in the South where a few years ago a murder was committed." So begins Carson McCullers's 1941 novella "Reflections In a Golden Eye," and also the extremely belated movie version, which is about to end a week of location shooting at Mitchel Field here before work is resumed in Rome.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 16 Syrian fighter planes flew over Damascus and several other Syrian cities in a show of force commemorating the Syrian Air Force's 20th birthday, the Damascus radio said today.
PARIS, Oct.16 Intra Bank's interests are involved in a legal action here relating to control of the shipyards at La Ciotat in southern France.
DETROIT, Oct. 16 (AP) Perty Andrews's Model T Ford rose from the grave after 40 years today, rusty but recognizable.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16 (AP) Union printers returned to their jobs today for the first time since last Tuesday night. A spokesman for the Pulitzer Publishing Company, which prints the two major daily newspapers here, announced, "We're back in full swing."
A survey of how American newspapers report on the performing arts is being undertaken by the Twentieth Century Fund, a private research organization.
ATLANTA, Oct. 16--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. clarified his position today on the civil rights controversy over black power.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (UPI) Two pass interceptions and the hard running of Jim Taylor and Paul Hornung gave the Green Bay Packers a 17-0 National Football League triumph over the Chicago Bears today. It was the Bears' first shutout in two years.

There will be no music for dancing, singing and listening in some of the city's major hotels and nightclubs tonight unless a musician's strike called late yesterday is settled.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said yesterday that he had "serious doubts" about the part of Governor Rockefeller's narcotics program that provides for the compulsory commitment of addicts for treatment.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 16 In a sudden shift of tactics, the O'Connor-for-Governor campaign produced two sharp attacks on Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. today.

HOUSTON, Oct. 16--When the New York Jets routed the Houston Oilers, 52-13, four weeks ago at Shea Stadium, Coach Weeb Ewbank of the Jets took pains to point out that the Oilers weren't that bad. Today, to Ewbank's disgust, the Oilers proved it.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 16--United States Senator Clifford P. Case was overwhelmingly endorsed for a third term here today by the State Industrial Union Council, which represents New Jersey unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Manitas de Plata, the gypsy guitarist from France, returned to Carnegie Hall for a display of flamenco fireworks at a midnight concert Saturday. The guitarist was assisted by his cousin, Jose Reyes, a singer who accompanied him on his successful debut in America a year ago.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 16 (UPI) Customs policemen seized $500,000 in contraband gold today in the luxurious home of an alleged international gold smuggler, then captured him aboard his yacht after a chase on the Arabian Sea.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 17 Premier Levi Eshkol today offered Syria a choice between peace and a military confrontation.

LONDON It was months ago that London was supposed to stop "swinging." Many Britons, who bore up bravely but are now bored, hoped this would happen. Even the pale young people ripping open still another tiny, dark boutique wince at the word.
Jerome, Ark., has postponed "for a few days" its $20-million proposed bond election. Voting on the taxexempt issue, to finance a knitting mill, had been scheduled for yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 17 The Court of Appeal rejected today an appeal by Myra Hindley against her conviction for the murder of children in the Pennine Moors.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 17 Billy Steinkraus won the in ternational jumping event at the Pennsylvania National horse show by a razor-thin margin from Anneli Drummond-Hay of Britain as 5,000 fans watched tonight.
THERE is a moment a little more than half way through "Georgy Girl" when Lynn Redgrave, the improbably fey heroine, complains that "God always has another custard pie up his sleeve."
The annual luncheon of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York will be held today in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Operations of the Xerox Corporation in the third quarter and first nine months resulted in the highest revenues and earnings for these periods in the company's history, according to the report issued yesterday by Joseph C. Wilson, chairman and chief executive officer.

PARIS, Oct. 17--Cleo de Merode, one of Europe's most celebrated dancers at the turn of the century, whose name was romantically linked with King Leopold II of Belgium, died of arteriosclerosis today in her apartment here. She was 91 years old.

In his speech at the East-West Center in Honolulu, President Johnson laid great stress on the establishment of a new Center for Educational Cooperation within the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and on a World Conference on Education to be held in Hawaii next year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) The Senate approved today a compromise version of a controversial omnibus crime bill for the District of Columbia.
THE pro football team that has two quarterbacks, both apparently equal in their skills and their inconsistencies, also has a problem. Al-...
There is no need to question the likelihood that Soviet-American relations would be much improved by peace in Vietnam, and even by partial steps such as the end to the bombing of North Vietnam.
AFTER some 40 years away, George S. Kaufman's "The Butter and Egg Man" doesn't really stand up, but every onee in a while it sits down rather pleasantly.

LONDON, Oct. 17 The British Treasury said tonight that Burma had withdrawn from the sterling area the group of countries representing about one-quarter of the world's population that finances overseas trade in sterling.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Federal insurance guaranteeing the safety of bank deposits and savings-and-loan shares has been increased to $15,000 for a single account from $10,000.

Louis Harris, in a survey published in yesterday's New York Post, said public confidence in President Johnson's ability to keep the nation prosperous had sagged to a new low a month before the election despite the longest and strongest peacetime economic expansion in history.

Steere de Montfort Mathew, former supervisor of radiotransmission costs and coordinator of traffic for the National Broadcasting Company, died Sunday night in Trafalgar Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 160 West 73d Street.
LONDON, Oct. 17 A jury today returned the first known conviction under a 1965 statute making it a crime to stir racial hatred in Britain by speech or publication.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 17 A strike of about 170 tugboat workers against three towboat companies, now in its sixth day, continued today to slow vessel movements in this port.
The appointment of Per Ditlevsen as president of Stolt-Nielsen Chartering, Inc., was announced yesterday by Jacob Stolt-Nielsen Jr., founder and first president of the seven-year-old company.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., the nation's largest chemicals producer, showed its first drop in earnings since the second quarter of 1963, according to the report issued yesterday for the three months and nine months ended Sept. 30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Senate-House conferees are expected to agree on a compromise tomorrow to soften the impact of recent House action aimed at slowing school desegregation in the South.

MOSCOW, Oct. 17 The Kremlin's closest allies gathered in Moscow today, apparently to chart a unified strategy for war and an eventual settlement in Vietnam and to exploit China's isolation in the world Communist movement.

Walt Alston was named the National League's manager of the year in the annual United Press International poll yesterday, while John (Boog) Powell of the Baltimore Orioles, the type of power hitter Alston's Los Angeles Dodgers could use, was named the American League's comeback player of the year in the Associated Press poll.
DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 17 A Nobel Prize winner in physics urged the National Academy of Sciences today to foster research on the effects of heredity, including race, on human behavior.
The Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria will be the setting Sunday for the second annual tea dance for the Helpers of the Holy Souls Convent. Miss Amy Bosley Gristede is benefit chairman.

AT this time a year ago, Dick McGuire was a printing salesman who found solace and relaxation in shooting bas kets at whatever basketball court or playground he could find handy. Basketball had been such a vital part of his life that he couldn't quite get it out of his system. Then, without warning he was back in the middle of it again.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17, The Maritime Administration said today that it had taken a number of steps and was considering others to help alleviate the manpower shortage in the American merchant marine.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) President Johnson has signed bill extending the United States exclusive fishing zone to 12 miles off the coast from the old limit of three miles.

SEGREGATION in the church has been an issue that tel- evision by and large has either sidestepped or dismissed in a few hasty bulletins. Last night a program called "A Time for Burning" brilliantly spoke to the contradiction of a white congregation professing obedience to the teachings of Jesus but refusing to open its hearts to those of another color.

VIRGIL THOMSON has written a zestful account of a zestful life. He seems never to have had a boring day and if circumstances were not always as he would have wished them, there was something even of the worst of them worth preserving in the memory. There were many years when his music was unplayed, unpaid and unpublished.

PARIS, Oct. 17 (Reuters) The International Automobile Federation announced today changes in the point scoring for next year's world drivers' championship aimed at maintaining interest until the end of the season.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 Burton S. Wirtschafter, director of the National Handbag Association, died at the New England Baptist Hospital here Saturday. He was 51 years old and lived at 25 Clifton Avenue in Newark. He also maintained a residence in Furlong, Pa.
British Government bonds continued to provide a strong investment feature on the London stock market yesterday as share Prices generally closed with fractional losses.
BONN, Oct. 17 Wieland Wagner, the director of the Bayreuth Wagner Festival and the grandson of Richard Wagner, the composer, died last night in a Munich hospital. He was 49 years old.
TRENTON, Oct. 17 Gov. Richard J. Hughes announced today the start of a $30-million, three-year overhaul of railroad commuter service from Monmouth County to northern New Jersey and New York City.

Yigael Yadin, professor of archeology of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, last night at Town Hall told 2,000 mem bers of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization, the story of explorations of Masada, the fortress rock by the Dead Sea where 960 Jews committed suicide in 73 A.D. rather than surrender to the Romans.

Scott, Foresman Co. and William Morrow Co., Inc., have reached an agreement in principle for a merger that reflects the increasing tie between books produced for general readers and books for the educational market.
WASHINGTON Oct. 17 The Supreme Court rejected today a suit by Delaware and 12 other states charging that the present system of electing Presidents discriminates against citizens of small states.

THERE are few subjects on which the general public is so uninformed as the principles of wildlife management. And we must include a good part of the 33-million American sportsmen who last year spent $4-billion on hunting and fishing.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Tuesday, Oct. 18 (Reuters) R.S. Garfield Todd, once Prime Minister of Rhodesia when it was known as Southern Rhodesia, became a free man today. Evidently on account of his political views, he had been restricted for the last year to his farm about 200 miles from here.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct, 17 Squads of mounted and truckborne policemen broke up scores of small but noisy demonstrations by Peronist workers here tonight. About 200 people were arrested but were later released. Three persons were injured and three cars were set afire.
RED-SHIRTING, the process by which an athlete spreads his three varsity seasons over a five-year academic span, may be eliminated by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The general easing of interest rates, which began to become apparent in the money market in recent days, showed clearly today in today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills.

Mrs. Cleo Blackwell Maher, the mother of James F.B. Maher, wire-room manager for The New York Times, died Sunday in Caledonian Hospital, Brooklyn. She was 72 years old and lived at 5120 19th Avenue, Brooklyn. Her husband is James F.J. Maher.

MILLBROOK, N.Y., Oct. 17 Mr. and Mrs. James T. Aspbury have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Anne Aspbury, to Edward Lewis Ballantyne, son of John Ballantyne of Boston and the late Mrs. Ballantyne. A December wedding is planned.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 President Johnson moved today under the Taft-Hartley Act to prevent scattered strikes against the General Electric Company from hampering the Vietnam war effort.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 House-Senate conferees agreed tonight on a compromise version of the Administrations antiinflation tax bill.

WHITE PLAINS Joseph L. Hunter, a 33-year-old Democratic lawyer, who, along with a Conservative, is challenging Representative Ogden R. Reid's bid for a third term in the House, tells a story about a little man who stopped him one night and asked why he was running for Congress.

Two former convicts were arrested yesterday in Queens on charges of having shot and wounded another former convict, who had been scheduled to testify against a union official accused of income-tax fraud.
The Radio Corporation of America and the Hertz Corporation, the nation's largest car and truck rental and leasing organization, agreed yesterday to merge.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Oct. 17 Brass gongs resounded in the cool highland air today as Jarai tribesmen in loincloths killed a water buffalo tied to a stake festooned with sacrificial emblems of bamboo.
WELLINGTON, New Zealan, Oct. 17 All arrangements for President Johnson's visit here Wednesday and Thursday were reported today to be in order.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 17 Frank D. O'Connor, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, accused the Rockefeller administration today of sweeping the state's ills under the rug to please the populace, the way Potemkin did at the behest of Catherine the Great of Russia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The Post Office Department plans to extend door-to-door mail service to 4.2 million homeowners who for more than three years have had to brave snow, rain, heat and gloom of night to fetch letters and packages from curbside boxes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17 Syria's delegate at the United Nations identified Arthur J. Goldberg of the United States with Zionism today in an apparent effort to impugn the American delegate's impartiality in disputes between Israel and her Arab neighbors.
A Bell Telephone researcher has found evidence that an unusual form of molecule, at very low temperatures, can move through crystals as readily as an electron.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 17 Mrs. William M. Vogel Jr. of Somerset Hills and Mrs. Michael Burke of Deal shared the medal today in the New Jersey Golf Association women's matchplay championship at the Spring Brook Golf Club.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17--Cambodia denounced the United States today and warned that, if the Vietnam war continued to escalate, this session of the General Assembly might "be the last."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Following are the texts of President Johnson's statement today at Dulles International Airport, before his departure for Hawaii, and of his speech prepared for delivery at the East-West. Center in Honolulu:

CAPETOWN, Oct. 17 The trial of Dimitrio Tsafendas, who assassinated Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd Sept. 6, opened today in a crowded courtroom with a psychiatrist testifying that the assassin was an incurable schizophrenic, whose life was "dominated by a delusionary tapeworm."
LONDON, Oct. 17 The Soviet Union has signaled a new willingness to play a role in possible moves toward a settlement in Vietnam, officials said today.

"That was a pretty bad bunch of horses we beat out there, wasn't it?" asked an ebullient Les Lear after Native Street had just taken the $27,350 Interborough Handicap by five lengths over the Wheatley Stable's Queen Empress at Aqueduct yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 17 The Democratic candidate for the Assembly in the 17th District charged today that Nassau County housewives are being defrauded of millions of dollars a year by the mislabeling of cuts of meat.
Three members of one of the nation's largest accounting firms and the former president of a now-bankrupt corporation were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on stockfraud charges.
Family of Man awards will be presented to six men who have "contributed massively to the whole family of man."

New York Supreme Court Justice George Postel denied yesterday an application by a shareholder of the Paramount Pictures Corporation to halt a meeting tomorrow to vote on a proposed merger with Gulf and Western Industries, Inc.

ISLIP, L.I., Oct. 17 Mr. and Mrs. Earle Thomas Oakes have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Bayard Oakes, to Donald Lauriston Lauve, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Lauve Jr. of Wilmington, Del. A February wedding is planned.

BONN, Oct. 17 Defense Minister Kai-Uwe von Hassel said today that Bonn's payments to offset the cost of keeping United States troops in West Germany would be limited to $350-million a year when the current agreement expires next June 30.
Steel production fell one per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

YONKERS The election in he 25th Congressional District will show whether a freshman Representative, who was swept into office two years ago in President Johnson's landslide, can now stand on his own Democratic feet in a segment of suburbia that has been predominantly Republican for 57 years.

Without any fanfare and without even a few well-trumpeted rumors, the New York Mercantile Exchange announced yesterday a new futures trading contract mercury. Trading in the metal will begin "within 60 days."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 President Johnson left today on a "hopeful mission" to the Far East and expressed the belief that it might advance the cause of peace in Vietnam, and of eventual reconciliation with Communist China.

Of no modern artist would it be more accurate to Say, "The style is the man himself," than of Oskar Kokoschka, the veteran Austrian painter whose immense exhibition 68 paintings, 57 water-colors and drawings, and a selection of recent graphics opens tomorrow at the Marlborough-Gerson Gal lery, 41 East 57th Street.
The spot rate on the Britsh pound eased in moderate trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 In the Supreme Court of the United States today, the following proceedings were had:
The shooting of Joe Pepitone when he was a high school boy in Brooklyn was recalled yesterday before a jury by the classmate who did it.

Mr. and Mrs. David Rockefeller of 146 East 65th Street and Pocantico Hills, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Neva Goodwin Rockefeller, to Walter J. Kaiser, associate professor of English and comparative literature at Harvard University. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter O. Kaiser of Bellevue, Ohio.

An experiment to determine whether a standard passenger bus can be adapted to run on both highway and railroad for possible use between Manhattan and Kennedy International Airport was authorized by the Port of New York Authority yesterday.
IN his heyday Dr. Subandrio, who stood before a special military tribunal in Jakarta yesterday powerless and pleading for his life, knew almost limitless power.
In the past, the United Hospital Fund campaign, the nation's oldest cooperative plan for the care of the medically indigent, has appealed to the "charity" of New Yorkers.
HO-HO-KUS, N.J. (UPI) The wife of a Paramus night club owner was found dead behind the wheel of her car Sunday, shortly after she returned home with her husband.

Members of the American Guild of Authors and Composers are preparing an original program with music for the guild's annual ball Oct. 27 at the Plaza Hotel. The ball will mark the 35th anniversary of the organization, formed to protect members with improved contracts, royalty collections, copyright-renewal aid and legislative action.

PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 17 (AP) Richard H. Guelich Jr. of Buffalo, a former TransMississippi senior champion, led a field of 368 today in the first round of a 36-hole qualifying test in the North-and South men's senior golf tournament.

The women's planning committee of the Japan International Christian University Foundation will give a luncheon Friday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Proceeds will go to the university in Tokyo. James A. Perkins, president of Cornell University, will speak on "The University at Home and Abroad."

New York's newest career girl began work today, arriving three hours late, eluding a crowd of photographers with the aid of her Secret Service escorts and later facing a crowd of reporters and photographers. For the new employe, Lynda Bird Johnson, it was not exactly a normal day, and her boss, Robert Stein, editor of McCall's magazine, conceded it was not "a normal day at McCall's," either.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 17 John J. Kuhn, retired director of electromechanical development at the Bell Telephone Laboratories in Whippany, at his retirement in 1956, died yesterday in Elizabeth General Hospital of injuries received in an automobile accident. He was 75 years old and lived at 421 Forrest Drive, Union.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 17 South Vietnamese Government troops, supported by United States helicopters and river patrol boats, attacked 150 to 200 Vietcong sampans, in a Mekong delta canal about 50 miles west southwest of Saigon yesterday.
LITCHFYELD, Conn., Oct. 17 George Carson Smith, who retired in 1963 as a partner in the Cleveland architectural concern of Small, Smith, Reed Draz, died today in his home here. His age was 78.
Paul L. Adams, the Conservative party candidate for Governor, charged yesterday that Governor Rockefeller was using a large number of state employes in his campaign for reelection.
TORONTO, Oct. 17 C. Powell Morgan, former president of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation and central figure in Canada's biggest financial collapse in 40 years, died today in a Toronto hospital.

DENVER, Oct. 17 (UPI) Thousands of housewives some dressed in slacks and chanting "down with frills, stamps and gimmicks," started a boycott today against five major supermarket chains. Their goal was lower food prices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration announced today it had moved to block marketings of Stendin tablets a timed-relief aspirin made by Abbott Laboratories. It cited lack of evidence to support claims made for the product.
The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for banknotes at New York. These rates do not apply to regular exchange business transacted by banks.
STONY BROOK, L.I., Oct. 17 The letters KKK and nigger have been smeared in red paint on a house newly rented by a Negro scientist, and Suffolk County officials today investigated the incident.

Jack Sterling can sleep late this morning. Radio station WCBS announced last night that the "Jack Sterling Show," a 5:30 A.M. rise-and-shine program he had conducted for 18 years, had been terminated by "amicable agreement."

Twenty-two social workers who had been staging a protest live-in at the office of the City Department of Labor were arrested last night after seven days of sleeping, washing clothes and cooking in the halls.

A State Senate committee opened a hearing on the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board yesterday, quickly beat back a motion to adjourn and then listened to an exchange of charges and countercharges over the need for such a board.
A Teamsters Union strike was authorized last night against the Housing Authority, Hospitals Department and about 20 other city agencies.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 17 Senator John J. Williams said today that Justice William O. Douglas's acceptance of payments from an educational foundation with Las Vegas connections had raised questions about his continued presence on the Supreme Court.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 17 Bill Parker, the home club's assistant professional, shot a 68 today to win the individual prize and a share of the team championship in the third annual Dodge bonus golf tournament at the Crestmont Country Club.
The American Stock Exchange made its fifth consecutive advance yesterday in stepped-up trading.

United States Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr. yesterday refused to intervene in a suit that Miss Helen C. Frick, daughter of Henry Clay Frick, is pressing in a Pennsylvania court against a historian who made some critical references to her father in a book.

Prof. Stephen Smale of the University of California is both a brilliant mathematician and a vigorous opponent of United States policy in Vietnam. Last summer he used a grant from the National Science Foundation to attend a mathematical congress in Moscow. There he received much publicity for his attacks both on the American military action in Vietnam and on the Soviet intervention in Hungary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 A Federal Maritime Commission examiner today ruled that that free time and demurrage rules on import cargoes at the Port of New York were not unjust or unreasonable, but recommended that they be amended in regard to strikes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) The National Associations of Home Builders said today a housing shortage is developing in this country be- cause of crippling credit con- ditions in the mortgage markets.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 17 Breaking into sobs after a composed three-hour rebuttal of subversion charges against him, Indonesia's former Foreign Minister, Dr. Subandrio, threw himself on the mercy of the court here today.
At least two firemen were killed and 10 were missing early today in a fire that raged uncontrolled through three buildings on Broadway between 22d and 23d Streets.
DETROIT, Oct. 17 (AP) Bob Swift, who three times posted winning records as an acting American League baseball manager, died of cancer today in Grace Hospital here. He was 51 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 (AP) New United StatesFrench studies of the atmosphere of Mars have rekindled hope of finding life on that planet, Dr. Lewis D. Kaplan of the California Institute of Technology's Jet Propulsion Laboratory said today.

A New York State tax collector failed yesterday to collect $2,116 from the New York Racing Association on the ground that he was under age when he lost that sum on parimutuel bets at Aqueduct race track. The track is operated by the association.

HONG KONG, Oct. 17 (UPI) The Chinese-language newspaper Sing Tao Ih Pao, which has the largest circulation in Hong Kong, criticized President Johnson today for having omitted the Chinese Nationalistruled island of Taiwan on his tour. It said there was "uneasiness" that this might be linked with "a scheme of appeasing and pacifying the Communist regime on the mainland."

BELGRADE, Oct. 17 The Balkan Express leaves Vienna at 10:04 P.M. with passengers waving beer bottles and cold sausage from open windows. Nobody comes aboard any more looking for intrigue. In fact, nobody who is anybody comes aboard at all these days.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) Most of the 350 licensed practical nurses at Cook County Hospital called in sick today to protest unmet demands for higher pay. The hospital stopped all admissions except in emergencies.
Substantial increases over last year in both sales and earnings enabled the General Electric Company to show records for both during the three-month and nine-month periods ended Sept. 30.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Tuesday, Oct. 18 (AP) The official Central News Agency said today that seaborne Chinese Nationalist commandos sank two Chinese Communist gunboats and badly damaged two others in a battle Saturday near the Nationalist island fortress of Matsu, at the northern end of the Formosa Strait.

LEO RITTER of Ritter Brothers admitted that, although he has included a few tent coats in his fall collection, shown recently, his own favorites and the biggest sellers in the last five years have been flat furs in shaped and fitted styles. He said he
The Swedish American Line has announced a reorganization of its trans-Atlantic cargo ship operations in light of next year's entry into service of new roll-on, roll-off containerships.
HONG KONG, Oct. 16 Hong Mui gestured, almost gaily, toward the jade-green valley outside her room at this British crown colony's spotless leprosarium.

BUFFALO, Oct. 17--Senator Jacob K. Javits, seeking to stir interest in the election of delegates to the 1967 Constitutional Convention, suggested today that state court judges might be appointed rather than elected.
The New York Stock Exchange, which now in effect prohibits trading between Big Board members and nonmembers in listed stocks, is moving closer to lowering its bars.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 17 A teen-ager tracked down by five members of a youthful "posse" was arraigned here today on charges of having been the hitrun driver who killed a motorcyclist Friday. The posse of 75 had been organized by friends of the dead cyclist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The Marine Corps imposed today a one-year freeze on resignations or voluntary retirements of regular marine officers below the grade of colonel in aviation and other combat support arms.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, announced today that he planned to visit South Africa again next summer. He said he had been invited...

What is scheduled to be the last season of basketball in the present Madison Square Garden will begin tonight when the New York Knickerbockers face the Los Angeles Lakers in their first home game of the National Basketball Association campaign. The Knicks' game will...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

BONN, Oct. 17 Like a forbearing wife who has caught her husband in one indiscretion too many, Bonn has finally worked itself into a state of indignation over what it regards as Washington's callous infidelity to basic West German interests.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The Supreme Court agreed today to review a major test case of the Federal Trade Commission's power to bar mergers of large concerns producing related products. At issue is
Dr. Solomon J. Miller, a cardiologist, died Sunday of a heart attack in his home, 386 Kosciusko Street, Brooklyn. He was 64 years old.
Complaints to the Department of Air Pollution Control increase sharply when fall comes and the weather turns chilly.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The Supreme Court sidestepped today a chance to decide whether alcoholics can be punished for public drunkenness.

TRENTON, Oct. 17 (AP) The Appellate Division of Superior Court reduced today a brokerage commission to be paid to an Asbury Park real estate agency by a motel corporation. It cut it to $7,500 from more than $11,000.

SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, Oct. 17 Mr. and Mrs. James M. Bailey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Bradshaw Bailey, to William Thomas Ingram, son of Mrs. Helen Young Ingram of Lakewood, N.Y. The wedding is planned for the end of next month.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--Personal income recorded one of the largest advances of the year in September, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 George Meany has thrown organized labor's strong sup port behind seven Negro civil rights leaders in their repudiation of black power concepts.

Antiques, glass, china, pewter, games, dolls, puzzles and something for just about every member of the family will be on sale in McKinnon Hall from 2 P.M. to 6 P.M., on Saturday. The occasion is the second annual auction and flea market for the benefit of St. Ignatius Loyola Library. The library is connected with St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church at 980 Park Avenue.

In a long, green-walled room on the second floor at 25 Cliff Street, business agents for the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association were busy yesterday sorting address cards and dividing the union's 10,500 members into political action squads.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) Sargent Shriver said today that he had cut off funds for a Mississippi antipoverty project because his inspectors had uncovered nepotism, payroll padding, excessive salaries and improper diversion of Federal money.

Mrs. Thomas J. Sheridan of 14 Stuyvesant Oval and Spring Lake, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Natalie Agnes Sheridan, to Michael Edgar Ford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar M. Ford of Chevy Chase, Md.
QUITO, Ecuador, Oct. 17 (UPI) A coalition of conservatives appeared today to have won a majority of the 67 constituent assembly seats at stake in elections yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 A Senate-House conference committee approved late today a $1.3-billion measure aimed to develop new attacks on urban blight and suburban sprawl.

Harlem parents and community representatives threatened a new boycott of Intermediate School 201 last night after ef forts to resolve the controversy over the showcase school collapsed earlier in the day.
Paced by an assortment of blue-chip and glamour stocks, the stock market resumed its advance in relatively quiet trading yesterday.
TRADERS who were waiting for the stock of Co- lumbia Pictures to show up on the ticker tape yesterday were disappointed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) House and Senate negotiators agreed today to legislation granting the proposed merger of the National Football League and American Football League limited immunity from antitrust laws.
SENECA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 17--Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Liberal party candidate for Governor, said today that he opposed the use of public funds for parochial schools.
SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 17 (AP) David Bryant of Britain scored three victories today to take the undisputed singles lead in the world bowls championships at Kyeenmagh.

A new hunt for alternatives to the Consolidated Edison Company's controversial Hudson River power plant at Cornwall, N.Y., was pressed yesterday, but the utility said alternatives would sharply increase costs.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct, 17 The chairman of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Commission said today that $196,902,50 had been collected from private sources by himself and two associates to create the Lyndon B. Johnson State Park in front of President Johnson's ranch near Johnson City.
The Bronx Savings Bank announced yesterday the election of Roscoe C. Ingalls Jr. as a trustee.

NEWPORT, Tenn., Oct. 17 William B. Stokely Jr., chairman of the board of StokelyVan Camp, Inc., one of the nation's major food-processing companies, died of a heart attack today at his boyhood home here. He was 66 years old.
The Lehman Corporation, the large investment company, reported yesterday net assets on Sept. 30 of $384,854,083, or $31.55 a share. This compares with $433,183,428, or $35.51 a share, a year ago.
Harold P. Orens, senior vice president of the Royal National Bank of New York, died of a heart attack yesterday in the Polyclinic Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 300 West 55th Street.
LIMA, Peru, Oct. 17 A severe earthquake jolted this capital and its neighboring port of Callao today, bringing death, panic and destruction.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The Administration is considering possible modifications in its voluntary program aimed at correcting the chronic balanceof-payments deficit.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 17 (UPI) Two Czechoslovak cyclists, a Dane and an Italian qualified today for the semi-finals to be run tomorrow in the individual 4,000-meter pursuit against the clock, opening a new phase in the Little Olympics.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The senior member of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Mrs. Aileen Hernandez, has submitted her resignation to the White House, effective Nov. 10.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 17 Business activity here was at a standstill today, with the country's 93 banks and the stock market closed. Cash was at a premium and the Lebanese pound fell in value in relation to the dollar and other foreign currency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The award of a $394,590 Maritime Administration contract to the General Dynamics Corporation for development of a nuclear-power plant for ships was halled here today by Senators Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.

The program for Henry Livings's British comedy, "Eh?," which opened Sunday night at Circle in the Square, credits Roger Short as the director. There is no director by that name enrolled with the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers, according to an official of that group.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17 Harvard University formally created an Institute of Politics today and named 10 fellows as the nucleus of an experimental program for the academic year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Jack B. Weinstein, a Columbia law professor whom Senator Robert F. Kennedy pushed for a spot on New York State Democratic ticket this year, was nominated for a Federal district judgeship today by President Johnson.
Manufacturers and retailers of men's apparel got an advance look at the new lines for spring and summer 1967 yesterday and discovered that youth was not necessarily spelled M-O-D.
The Independent Citizens Committee Against Civilian Review Boards, which two weeks ago began its newspaper advertising campaign aimed at the voters, branches into radio and television today.
Negotiations in the musicians' strike here broke off last night after agreement on a major issue could not be reached.
ROME, Oct. 17 Views held by American Communists on many basic issues conflict with those of the Chinese, Gus Hall, United States party leader, said today.
A gala benefit party for the Association for Mentally Ill Children will be held Oct. 26, the second night of the National Horse Show, at Madison Square Garden.
TARAPOTO, Peru, Oct. 17 A space photograph of Peru presented by two visiting United States astronauts brought a cry of recognition from President Fernando Belaunde Terry.
Msgr. Edward D. Head was named the new executive director of Catholic Chararities of the Archdiocese of New York last night by Cardinal Spellman.
The Central National Bank of Cleveland will be a major tenant in a 21-story office building to be built in that city by the Tishman Realty and Construc- tion Company of New York.
The unemployment rate in New York City has dropped to 4.1 per cent, the lowest rate since 1957, according to figures announced yesterday by Henry Shemin, City Labor Commissioner.
What appeared to be a visionary proposal earlier this year helicopter discharge of cargo containers for Vietnam may become reality next year.

HONOLULU, Oct. 17 President Johnson arrived today in Hawaii, midway in his transpacific journey, to offer a general definition of his policy toward Asia and to request patience and unity in support of his policies in Vietnam.
BERLIN, Oct. 17 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard flew here today from Bonn for a two-week visit during which talks on West Germany's policy toward Eastern Europe are expected to top the agenda.
SUFFERN, N.Y., Oct. 17 Governor Rockefeller picked up new labor support today as he carried his re-election campaign into suburban Rockland County.
"Martha, Graham: Portrait of the Lady as an Artist," with text by LeRoy Leatherman and photographs by Martha Swope, will be published next Monday by Knopf. The combination of...

WASHINGTON, ,Oct. 17 Representative Charles L. Weltner said today that Southern moderation had rested on a very narrow margin of the voters, and that this was wiped out during the summer because of impatience with riots.
The nonprofit corporation planned by Sen. Robert F. Kennedy will be formed in BedfordStuyvesant this month in an attempt to attract industries, stores and other enterprises into the slum section.
DETROIT, Oct, 17 (AP) The nation's auto makers set their sights today on a second consecutive 200,000-plus week as customer demand for 1967 cars remained high.
WASHINGTON, Oct, 17 (AP) The House passed and sent back to the Senate today a compromise fair packaging and labeling bill. The roll-call vote was 242 to 6.

SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 17 Premier Kim Il Sung of North Korea, who is also the head of the Communist party there, appears to have strengthened his position by purging some of his critics and reorganizing the Communist hierarchy at a party congress that ended last Wednesday.
An appeal in the second conviction of George Whitmore on charges of the attempted rape of a nurse has been filed in the Brooklyn Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.
The election of N. W. Freeman as president and a director of Tenneco, Inc., was announced yesterday in Houston, Texas.
In New York, a leading naval architect called yesterday for a major Government effort to develop nuclear-marine propulsion for merchant ships.
The Police Department's new Civilian Complaint Review Board appears to be developing as a bridge rather than a barrier between police and public.
A woman who found the police trying to tow away her illegally parked car yesterday climbed onto the hood and sat there defiantly for two and a half hours.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The White House announced today that President Johnson would appoint Rutherford M. Poats as deputy administrator of the Agency for International Development.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 103.7 on Friday from 103.6 on Thurs- day.

ATLANTA, Oct. 17 (UPI) The National Communicable Disease Center in Atlanta, which predicts epidemics on the basis of the past habits of a disease, says there should be no widespread outbreaks of either A or B strains of influenza during the 1966-67 season.

The United States Golf Association announced yesterday a new handicap sytem that it hopes will cut down on the inequality in handicapping that usually crops up when a man from Seattle plays his cousin from Miami in Dallas.
MOSCOW, Oct. 17 (Reuters) Negotiations for a direct New York to Moscow air service will open in Washington this week, the United States Embassy said today.

YONKERS, Oct. 17 Reports, which management at Yonkers Raceway would neither confirm nor deny, persisted today that the $100,000 United Nations Trot with which the old hilltop racing course will conclude its year's activities tomorrow night, is either to be dropped or the monetary value of the event is to be cut drastically.

WHILE the walls came tumbling down around them, Mr. and Mrs. Yung Wang made their home in a tent fashioned of plastic drop cloths, warmed themselves by a small electric is heater, bathed at homes of friends (who frequently fed them) and decided they would never recommend the experience to anyone.
The city's Budget Director yesterday put some of the blame for the city's hospital crisis on poor administration, not just on lack of funds.
Arnold Constable has appointed Emanuel Asher as executive vice president, Merwin Bayer, president, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 More than $30-million worth of office equipment, much of it never shown publicly before, was displayed today at the Business Equipment Manufacturers Association Exposition in McCormick Place here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 When President Johnson tried to leave the Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa at Doylestown, Pa., after a speech Sunday afternoon he was virtually mobbed by a crowd estimated by the police with only a little license at about 100,000.
"I want to finish out my days taking care of my 'child' Saks Fifth Avenue," observed its president, Adam L. Gimbel, yesterday.

The New York Mets purchased Larry Stahl, a left-handed-hitting outfielder, from the Kansas City Athletics yesterday for "a sum in excess of $50,000," and shuffled 17 other players in bookkeeping maneuvers connected with the roster freeze that went into effect at midnight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 A leading utilities specialist warned today that "knowledgeable investors" would turn away from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company unless it was permitted a rate of return of "8 to 8.3 per cent and is permitted to increase annually."

Since a good chamber-music ensemble needs a name of some kind to attach a reputation to, the five men who played at Carnegie Recital Hall last night are justified on that count in calling themselves the Lark Quintet. It should be noted right off that they do not specialize in mindless chirping.
HAWORTH, N.J., Oct. 17 --Residents here are urging the Immigration and Naturalization Service to ease one of its regulations so that a science teacher may bring his Israeli bride to this country.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 Paul Jacobs, author and commentator on left-wing politics, was found not guilty today of charges in the recent San Francisco riots.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 17 (AP) An aide to the leader of the Black Muslim sect in St. Louis and Kansas City died tonight of bullet wounds suffered when he, another assistant and the Muslim leader Clyde X were shot in front of the Shabazz Restaurant, which is owned by the sect.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 17 (UPI) The body of a Chicago theologian and civil rights leader was found in the guest room of an Ohio State University Christian center today. The police said he had been beaten to death.

William O. Morrow Jr., secretary and counsel of Central Registry, a division of the Magazine Publishers Association, Inc. died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 44 years old and lived at 21 Willow Street, Norwalk, Conn.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 17 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky said today that if he were President Johnson, he would consider it a "duty" to visit American troops in South Vietnam.

As Congress drives for adjournment this week, one of the many important measures still to be put in final form is the unemployment compensation bill.

An advertising feud between two lines of shoes started a month ago in national magazines ana there is very little chance it will stop. As a matter of fact, it will probably get more heated since it is being engineered by the same ad agency for the one company that makes both lines.

The political crisis in the Netherlands is another evidence of the disturbed economic and financial troubles characteristic of many countries today: inflation, high production costs, over-employment, tight credit, budgetary difficulties.
The election of Fred R. Raach to the new post of senior vice president for finance and administration was announced yesterday by the Wallace-Murray Corporation, a producer of construction products.

LONDON, Oct. 18--Influential Jewish leaders from nine nations met here tonight to inaugurate the International Committee of the Hebrew University Institute of Contemporary Jewry in Israel.

Trans-Atlantic passenger ship operators are seriously considering the establishment of a third, or intermediate, season in 1968 in an effort to stimulate ship travel at rates halfway between summer and thrift season levels.
A courtly Dutchman who has been a pioneer in the field of astronomy and also tried his hand at scientific diplomacy was presented last night with a gold medal and $25,000.
THERE are some who consider it a color and others who don't, but no matter; black is back.
The three-day musicians' strike against 32 local hotels over terms of a new contract was settled yesterday.

Gilbert P. Talbot, who retired last year as director of the New York Transit Authority's employe counseling service, died on Monday in a Brooklyn hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 36 Hamilton Avenue in St. George, S.I.

MEXICO CITY, Oct 18 (AP) --Neil Steinhauer of the University of Oregon gave the United States its first track and field gold medal at the Little Olympics by winning the shot-put today. But Tommie Smith, the San Jose State sprint star, was beaten by Enrique Figuerola of Cuba in the 100-meter final.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 18 --Frank Chapot of Wallpack, N.J., and Jim Day of Canada tied in the Puissance International jumping event tonight at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show, both breaking the show jumping record by clearing the wall at 6 feet 9 inches.

The manager-coach of the Blue Shirts stood alongside the Iceland rink yesterday and beamed proudly as his bruisers circled past in skating warm-ups, their final exercises before opening the season against the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark said last night that he would ask the Board of Regents and the State Education Commissioner to investigate school conditions in the city to determine "what action should be taken in regard to the Board of Education."

The University of Oklahoma's defense has allowed only two touchdowns in five games and hasn't permitted a score by air. This defense, though comparatively small in the size of the players, may present the strongest opposition so far this season to Notre Dame's aerial attack when the two unbeaten teams meet at Norman, Okla., Saturday.

A union official was indicted here yesterday in the city's alleged multimillion-dollar paint scandal. He was charged with having taken $840,000 in bribes from 1957 to last year.
Frank D. O'Connor stood on a New York Central station platform in Harlem yesterday and said that the elevated tracks there should be torn down and put into an underground tunnel.
BERLIN, Oct. 18--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard cautioned West Berlin's Mayor, Willy Brandt, today against too frequent contacts with Soviet officials.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 18-- Mrs. Salvatore F. La Corte has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Kathryn La Corte, to William F. Long, son of Mrs. William H. Long of Bricktown and the late Mr. Long. The wedding is planned for Nov. 19.

DURING the recent bear market--which Wall Street devoutly hopes is over --one was considered a brain if he held his losses to something less than the tumble taken by the Dow-Jones industrial average.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18--A Federal judge ordered 5,900 strikers at a key General Electric Company jet engine plant back to work today for 80 days. He acted after the Government had said the walkout threatened the Vietnam war effort.
CARLTON (COOKIE) GILCHRIST, the well-trav eled 250-pound fullback, delighted yesterday both his old team, the Denver Broncos, and his new one, the Miami Dolphins.

STOWE, Vt., Oct. 18--Billy Kidd, the injured American international star, received a silver bowl for his contributions to New England skiing as the New England Council's 21st annual winter sports conference ended today.
LONDON, Oct. 18--Cries of "Bloody Americans" and calls for nationalization marked a day of labor strife at General Motors' Vauxhall car factory at Luton today.

DENVER, Oct. 18 (UPI)-- Thousands of housewives clutched their pocketbooks and grocers held their breaths today in the second day of a boycott of five major supermarket chains that threatened to spread into a nationwide war on food prices.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 18--A landmine blew up an Israeli mili-, tary patrol vehicle today, wounding one soldier. The blast occurred in the "Galilee Finger," a wedge of land in Israel's northeastern corner between Syria and Lebanon.

FRANCIS JAMES LOVE, the ranking assistant chief in the Bureau of Fire, leaned his elbows on a crude wooden stand yesterday, clutching a green ball-point pen in one hand and a two-way radio in the other.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18--The prolonged slump in the homebuilding industry deepened during September, the Commerce Department reported today.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 18-- Kenneth Toler, one of the South's best-known and re spected political writers, who covered the State House here for The Memphis Commercial Appeal for 34 years, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

A HIGHLY generalized review of the problems of penology was presented last night by "C.B.S. Reports" on Channel 2. Under the title of "Men in Cages," the Columbia Broadcasting System program gave cursory coverage to the kind of men who become prisoners and to the varied efforts to restore them to usefulness in society.

DENPASAR, Bali, Oct. 16-- President Sukarno's influence and popularity are steadily declining on Bali, a stronghold of the outlawed Indonesian Communist party before last fall's unsuccessful Communist uprising.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)--Losses of ornamental trees and shrubbery during the severe drought in the Northeast may be deducted for income tax purposes in some cases, the Internal Revenue Service said yesterday.

Charles A. Taylor, president of the Chuck Taylor Management Corporation, a music talent management concern at 119 West 57th Street, died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 34 years old and lived at 392 Central Park West.
ROME, Oct. 18--The Vatican announced today the establishment of an official press service.
Unless India receives "a massive transfusion" of food in the next five--years, at least onequarter of her population will face starvation, an economist predicted yesterday.
The Federal Reserve Board is shedding its long tradition of silence to defend itself against mounting attack from critics of its anti-inflationary tight money policies.

For the first time in 20 years, a student organization at City College is openly claiming kinship to the Communist's party. The new organization, whose formation was announced yesterday, will be called the Communist Forum.
The nation's big retail chains moved past the year's threequarter mark with a solid 10.3 per cent sales increase above the similar 1965 period.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18--Arthur J. Goldberg, United States chief delegate to the United Nations, challenged today those who doubt the sincerity of his peace plan for Vietnam to call on him "to make good through deeds what he offers in words."

The New York Stock Exchange, which abandoned plans this summer for its $80-million building complex at nearby Battery Park, now is facing delays in setting up . an electronic systems center out-of-state.

LONDON, Oct. 18--William Oliver Smedley, 54-year-old businessman and former vice president of the Liberal party, was acquitted today of manslaughter in the fatal shooting last June of the head of one of Britain's pirate radio stations.
Pagopago, which President Johnson visited yesterday, is the administrative capital of the six islands that make up American Samoa.
DETROIT, Oct. 18 (AP)-- The General Motors Corporation said today it had raised prices on its 1967 model trucks by an average of $76 or 2.9 per cent over this year's models.
Charles Revson, chairman of Revlon, Inc., was presented with a plaque last night by the New York Fashion Designers, Inc., in appreciation of his support of American fashion designers.

Dr. Leonard W. Larson, president of the American Cancer Society, said here yesterday that the society would place greater emphasis on persuading adults to take cancer detection tests at their family physicians' offices.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)--Congressional action was completed today on legislation to establish the long controversial Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore.
The American Stock Exchange continued to extend its recent gains yesterday as advances led declines by almost two-to-one.
Their period of adjustment over, the New York Rangers start their 41st National Hockey League season tonight against the Chicago Black Hawks.
OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 18--Mrs. Barbara Wakeman Bullard Bradshaw, wife of Richmond Bradshaw, interior designer, died yesterday of cancer at her home at 1 Tait Road.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Oct. 18-- Mr, and Mrs. Benjamin Schnall have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Seena Schnall, to S. David Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Levy of Schnall, to S. David Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Levy of Washington.
The election of Fred R. Sullivan as chairman and Franc M. Ricciardi as president of Walter Kidde Co. was announced yesterday in Belleville, N.J.
Commodity futures trading is continuing at record levels this year, according to the latest figures published by the Association of Commodity Exchange Firms, Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18-- Milton J. Shapp, the rich Democratic iconoclastic candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania, has tickled some ribs as well as set some toes to tapping by promising to hold a barefoot inaugural ball, if elected, "to signify the return of government to the people."
HONG KONG, Oct. 18--This year's grain production in Communist China will be the lowest in five years, agricultural experts predicted today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP)-- An official of the supermarket industry said today Denver housewives who are boycotting to end high prices "are not ready to listen to logic."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18-- In the wake of the $116-million default by the Pioneer Finance Company of Detroit, James J. Saxon, the Controller of the Currency, has moved to tighten Federal supervision of loans made by national banks to finance companies.

The failure of Austria's Creditanstalt in 1931 is generally viewed as one of the more melancholy milestones in economic history: the event that marked the beginning of the breakdown of the international financial structure before World War II. The failure of Lebanon's Intra Bank, one of the biggest financial institutions in the Middle East, inevitably suggests that history may be repeating itself.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 18-- The Soviet Union and United States financial interests were reported today to be bidding to take over the biggest bank in Lebanon, which closed its doors last Friday.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 --George W. Burpee received the annual award of merit here tonight from the American Institute of Consulting Engineers at the organization's annual dinner in the Sheraton Hotel.

TETERBORO, N.J. Oct. 18 (AP)--Two occupants of a small plane were injured and nine parked cars badly smashed today when the aircraft crashed into a parking lot while coming in for a landing at Teterboro Airport.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18--The House, after an unusually bitter floor, exchang, voted tonight to cite two Chicago residents for contempt of Congress because they refused to testify before the Committee on Un-American Activities last year at an inquiry into alleged Communist connections.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) --President Johnson has named seven state and local leaders, including two Governors, to a special consulting committee on manpower problems, the White House announced today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18-- Communist China is preparing for its fourth nuclear test, perhaps of an experimental hydrogen bomb device, Atomic En ergy Commission sources said today.

Paperboard production rose 4.8 per cent with 460,500 tons in the week ended Oct. 15, from 439,200 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18-- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon charged in the Supreme Court today that Life magazine deliberately lied in its 1955 review of the Broadway play "The Desperate Hours."
State Senator Norman F. Lent, Nassau Republican, called yesterday upon Governor Rockefeller to send the state police into the municipal hospitals to combat pilferage estimated at $500,000 a year.

A 20TH anniversary was celebrated last night at the Hunter College Playhouse. It was exactly two decades ago that the Juilliard String Quartet gave its first concert, and it did not take long for the brilliant group to establish itself as one of the world's best. Since then there have been two changes in personnel.
TEL AVIV, Oct. 18--The Israel state radio reported today that Shmuel Yosef Agnon, a Hebrew writer living in Jerusalem, will receive the 1966 Nobel Prize for literature.
The alarm bell above the scarred old desk gave a dull clank. Tautly, the men in the firehouse on 31st Street, just east of Seventh Avenue, watched it and listened.
John Donovan was groping through the smoke-filled Wonder Drug Store late Monday night, searching for his buddies from Engine Company 18 when, suddenly, there was no floor under him.

A hearing opened here yesterday on the complaint of three Negro employes of the National Labor Relations Board that the agency had discriminated against them and denied them promotions because of their race.
British Government bonds maintained a strong uptrend on the London stock market yesterday as share prices continued a moderate downward drift.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18--The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that the $3.1-million First State Bank of Tuscola, Tex., was closed over the weekend, and its assets were taken over by the newly organized First State Bank in Tuscola, which bears the same name as its predecessor.
PARIS, Oct. 18 (UPI)--JeanPierre Peugeot, head of one of France's most famous automobile families, died at his home here today. He was 70 years old.

Five hundred acres of Florida land with "valuable mineral rights and ideal for retirement," which were sold to the public for $150,000, were exposed yesterday as swamp land-- under water most of the year.
PAGOPAGO, American Sam- oa, Oct. 18--President Johnson arrived in Pagopago today and was greeted by men and women in colorful lava-lava skirts carrying rain umbrellas against the midday sun.

WASHINGTON, Oct.18 (AP) --The Air Force is buying 99 improved Phantom jets equipped for the first time with a built-in gun and designed to give the United States clear superiority over Russian-made MIG 21s in Vietnam.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP)--A logjam of mail in the Chicago Post Office has been broken, officials said today.
LONDON, Oct. 18--Queen Elizabeth granted a full pardon today to Timothy John Evans, who was hanged 16 years ago for the murder of his infant daughter.

Lack of financial support is prompting John D. Mitchell, president and co-founder, with his wife, of the Institute for Advanced Studies in the Theater Arts, to move the organization from New York to Los Angeles or abroad.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 18--Almost half the 4,800 missions flown by the United States Air Force over North Vietnam in the last three months have concentrated on a strip of jungled mountains and coastal plain extending south 30 miles from Donghoi to the demilitarized zone.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)--A Senate-House conference committee agreed today on a bill providing for a civil commitment and treatment of narcotics addicts.
A new telephone number for information on park events was announced yesterday by Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving. The number is 755-4100.

LONDON, Oct. 18 (AP)-- Despite big gains by Japan and Liberia, Britain retains first place in the expanding world merchant shipping fleet, according to Lloyd's 1966 statistics published today. The United States fleet lost ground.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) --The Army Corps of Engineers, contradicting other Army sources, said today the body of President Kennedy would not be moved to a new grave until next year.

PARIS, Oct. 18--A group of Lockheed Aircraft executives is touring Europe, conferring with most of the major airlines on the merits or Lockheed's plan for the American supersonic transport. Today they met officials, of Air France and Union de Transport Aeriens.

The crushed and charred bodies of 12 firemen were removed yesterday from a burned-out commercial building on 23d Street just east of Broadway after the worst Fire Department disaster in its 101year history.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 18--The City Council of Jersey City, by a vote of 6-3, defeated today a proposal for a $5.3-million bond issue to finance the building of a combination City Hall and municipal civic center in the Journal Square vicinity.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Oct. 18 --The president of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute warned here today that "the virtually unrestrained flow of textile imports is gnawing at the vitals" of the textile industry, machinery manufacturers and related businesses.

A FOLIO--SIZED volume measuring 10 by 14 inches and sumptuously gotten up, "The Flowering of the Middle Ages" consists of nine lengthy essays and a wealth of illustration in line, color and black and white. The plates, the editor points out, are not to illustrate the text; they are part of the text.
Doorbells were rung in Queens and Long Island yesterday morning as softly as doorbells could be rung, but to one Fire Department chaplain the sounds they made were the sounds of despair.

Merton L. Haselton, who retired in 1957 as a vice president of the Teleregister Corporation, of which he was a founder in 1928, died on Monday in his home at South Dennis, Mass. He was 74 years old and had a winter home in Jupiter Inlet, Fla.
ALBANY, Oct. 18--The State Court of Appeals dismissed today an appeal by a New York City resident, who objected to the designation of a churchcontrolled hall as a polling place.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 19--Seven Ministers in the South Vietnamese Cabinet resigned today, throwing the Government of Premier Nguyen Cao Ky into a crisis less than a week before the Manila conference.

BARRIE, Ont., Oct. 18--The Rev. Dr. Albert B. Cohoe, who was pastor of the First Baptist Church of Montclair, N. J., from 1920 till his retirement in 1947, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 89 years old.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 18-- Philip G. Schanerman, a Newark lawyer, died of a heart attack yesterday during a trial in Union County District Court here. He was 49 years old and lived in West Orange.

BRIDGE literature often neglects the human factor in card-play. An expert declarer will sometimes abandon the "book" play of a card combination because his judgment of the situation, based on the behavior of his live opponents, suggests that it will fail.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) --The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today the arrest of a Louisiana man on charges of trying to bribe the backfield stars of the Louisiana State University football team.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 18--Connecticut Republicans closed an important breach in their ranks today as the man who had been Clayton Gengras's strongest rival for the gubernatorial nomination warmly endorsed him.
A committee representing major Jewish organizations made public yesterday a resolution commending and endorsing the statement "Crisis and Commitment" issued last Friday by a group of Negro leaders.
Jesse O. Sims, a geophysicist who had been stationed overseas for the last 10 years, drowned Sunday while swimming in Lagos, Nigeria. He was 53 years old.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 18 (AP) --Buford M. Brown, president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation Defense and Space Center here since 1963, died of a heart attack today. He was 57 Years old.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18-- Senate-House conferees agreed today to set a 90-day limit on Federal deferment of funds to schools suspected of practicing discrimination.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18--A House-Senate conference committee agreed today to increase income tax deductions that doctors, lawyers and other professionals may make on their contributions to private retirement funds.

Friends of Mr. Menotti in New York said yesterday that the Broadway presentation depends how "Medea" is received in Rome. If the reception is favorable, no trouble is anticipated in raising the backing.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 18--Former Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak announced today that a three-week nationwide campaign to raise funds to aid refugees in Africa and Asia and fight world famine would begin on Oct. 24--United Nations Day.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18-- Legislative conferees on the $7.4-billion Food for Peace bill agreed today to seek House and Senate approval of a modified ban on food aid to countries doing business with Cuba.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (UPI)-- Guy Rodgers scored a field goal and a free throw in the final 64 seconds tonight to break a 116-all tie and lead the Chicago Bulls, the new entry in the National Basketball Association, to their second victory, a 119116 triumph over the San Francisco Warriors.
HOUSTON, Oct. 17--Negro voters may help elect three Republican Congressmen in Texas this year by defecting from the Democratic party they have traditionally supported.
TOKYO, Oct. 17--An exhibition here of "Two Decades of American Painting" has awakened the keen interest of Japanese students of art.

The film version of "The Sound of Music," which had its world premiere March 15, 1965, at the Rivoli Theater, will end its 94-week engagement Dec. 13 to make way for the world premiere of another 20th Century-Fox Film, "The Sand Pebbles."

Milt Plum, the tidy, quiet quarterback who never had his hair mussed, is out for the season with an injured knee and the Detroit Lions, who do not need more problems, designated Karl Sweetan yesterday as Plum's successor to the most important spot on any football team.

Harry E. Dolan, a 38-yearold Negro playwright and author who attended Budd Schulberg's writing classes in the Watts section of Los Angeles, said in a telephone interview yesterday: "Wow! At last I'm a real writer!"
ATLANTA, Oct. 18--A lawsuit was filed here today in an attempt to legalize paste-in ballot stickers as a write-in device at the Georgia general election Nov. 8.
The spot rate on the British pound closed unchanged at $2.7923 in moderate trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 (AP)--Raymond Cuelemans of Belgium, the world billiard champion, defeated Danny McGoorty of Los Angeles, 60-45, in 58 innings early this morning in the world three-cushion billiards tournament.
PARIS, Oct. 18--The Ben Barka case took a sensational new turn today.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18-- Gov. Edmund G. Brown called a news conference on the lawn of his temporary Los Angeles residence today to announce that he was embarking on a new tack in the final three weeks of his campaign for a third term.
MOUNTAINHOME, Pa., Oct. 18--Sebastian Spering Kresge, founder of the S.S. Kresge Company's network of 930 general merchandise stores throughout the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico, died today.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 18-- Nassau County will mourn the death of 12 New York City firemen by flying national, state and county flags at half-staff.
Improved technology was chiefly responsible for a sharp increase in third-quarter profits of the Republic Steel Corporation, the company reported yesterday.
Spokesmen for two major electric light bulb producers said today that light bulbs could be either dimmer and last longer or shed a better light at their present life expectancy, but not both.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark and his wife, Dr. Mamie Phipps Clark, received Columbia University's Nicholas Murray Butler Medal in Silver yesterday for "their influential humanitarian work" over the last 25 years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18-- The State Department moved today to link the United States academic community more closely to the Administration's foreign policy.

Two candidates for Governor have told the New York Civil Liberties Union how they feel about the so-called Blaine provision in the State Constitution, which bans direct or indirect aid to parochial schools.
Thomas E. Lovejoy Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Manhattan Life Insurance Company of New York, was elected yesterday to the additional post of chairman.

Patrolman John Lieto was standing in front of a boardedup brownstone off upper Broadway yesterday morning, nursing his new 3-pound, walkietalkie, Call No. M416. A woman stepped up to him and asked: "Any crime happened?"

Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery announced last night that he had established a special fund for contributions to go to the widows and families of the firemen who were killed in Monday night's fire.

Notre Dame took over first place in both the United Press International and The Associated Press major-college football polls yesterday. Michigan State dropped to second and the University of California, Los Angeles, rose to third.

The National Horse Show, which will begin an eight-day run in Madison Square Garden next Tuesday, will be one of the largest and best balanced ever held. It could have been larger had there been space to accommodate all those who wanted to enter.
Five major financial concerns have expanded their office space at 37 Wall Street, the 25-story tower owned by the Franchard Corporation.

WESTON, Conn., Oct. 18-- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Woodhull Green have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Noel Green, to Walter Stuart Baker, son of Mrs. John Rea Baker of Baltimore and the late Mr. Baker. A November wedding is planned.

A Christmas shopping center that lends support to charities and social agencies will materialize on Nov. 1 when Les Boutiques de Noel opens for the seventh year. The sale, cus tomarily held in a home lent for the occasion, will take place this year at 11 East 84th Street, lent by the Fribourg Founda tion, Inc.
BABYLON, L.I.--"This would be a tough campaign for demagogues," the incumbent Congressman, James R. Grover Jr., said, loading a carton of Groverfor-Congress matches into his red sports car.
The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that the city could place two questions instead of one before the voters in November on the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board.
YONKERS, Oct. 18--All along, M. Henri Levesque of Beuzeville la Bastille had insisted that roquepine, his stylish, speedy and durable 5-year-old mare, was the greatest trotter in the world.
Yonkers Raceway ended a three-month harness-racing meet last night with the Government the biggest loser--$8-million in taxes never collected from twindouble winners because of fraud.
A wall crumbled into the once-elegant living room of an old brownstone in Park Slope yesterday, signifying the start of an ecumenical venture in rehabilitation.
PARIS, Oct. 18--France rejected today the latest effort to get her into negotiations about her future relations with the Atlantic alliance, informed sources said.

Seven hundred newspapers that are members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association will run a common house ad this week to publicize the medium's service to the community, as well as the rewards of newspaper work.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Wednesday, Oct. 19--President Johnson's visit to New Zealand comes at a time when differences between New Zealanders over the Vietnamese war are being sharpened by a national election campaign.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18-- The Administration's high-priority Demonstration Cities Bill survived a last-minute threat today and then was approved by the Senate, 38 to 22.

Louis E. Wolfson, the industrialist, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges of conspiring to breach the securities laws, perjury and filing "false and misleading" annual reports.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) --The House, Under pres sure from the Republicans, acted today to block President Johnson's announced plan to step up trading with European Communist nations.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 18 (UPI)--About 50 policemen spread out along "fraternity row" near Ohio State University today in a search for the weapon and motive in the bludgeon slaying of Dr. Robert W. Spike, theologian and civil rights leader.
WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Oct. 18--Max A. Boxer, tax attorney for the town of West New York for two decades, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital, Jersey City. He lived at 162d Street here.

Andrzej Wasowski's Chopin program last night at Carnegie Hall was a subdued, subtle affair that brought out the poetic side while leaving untouched the heroic. Chopin without fire, flair and bravura is not the whole story.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 18--Tens of thousands of people spared by yesterday's earthquake gave public thanks today to an image of a brown-skinned Christ venerated as having miraculous powers.
