MINNEAPOLIS--Minnesota kitchens are gener ally thought of as being Swedish. One of the finest in this city is, however, out-and-out Danish, and it is the kitchen of Mrs. Olaf Juhl, a sweetfaced, soft-spoken, 70-yearold grandmother.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation is observing its fiftieth anniversary with the highest earnings and operating records in its history in the third quarter and first nine months this year, E.L. Steiniger, chairman and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.

RIC ZIMMERMAN, Harvard's left-handed junior quarterback, flopped against Dartmouth last year. In his first and only starting varsity appearance as a sophomore, he never got his team past its 30-yard line. His fumble on the Harvard 8 led to Dartmouth's second touchdown in its 14-0 victory.

ROME, Oct. 18--Opera performances that never took place and promised presentations of new works that turned into tired old "Bohemes" and "Rigolettos" have produced a resounding scandal over Italian state subsidies to the lyric theater.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18-- Communist China is not able and does not intend to intervene massively in the Vietnamese war, Donald S. Zagoria, associate professor of government at Columbia University, said here tonight.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 18--Governor Rockefeller today described state aid to schools as the major key to whether state taxes would have to be raised. The cost of the new state narcotics program is another "unknown factor," he said.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the nation's largest tobacco manufacturer, achieved record sales and earnings for the third quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30. The results were aided by the inclusion of the operations of Penick Ford, acquired in June, 1965.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 18-- Repeal of the State Constitution's Blaine Amendment that curtails state aid to parochial and other private schools became a goal today of the Westchester Democratic County Committee.

LONDON, Oct. 18--Cheshunt College, founded by, the Countess of Huntington in 1768 to prepare ministers for the Protestant evangelical churches is for sale. The college moved from Wales to its present two-acre site near Cambridge in 1913, the year the mock-Tudor building was completed.
A cross was burned outside a Negro family's apartment in a racially mixed section of Jamaica, Queens, early yesterday.

The woman who sat on the hood of her car for two and a half hours and defied the police to tow it away Monday, called Mayor Lindsay's office yesterday to say she was not angry at anyone and did not "want to be pitted against the law-enforcement system."
LIMA, Peru, Oct. 18--Peru has agreed to provide landlocked Bolivia with new means of road transport to the Pacific Ocean, liberating Bolivians from their dependence on Chile for maritime access.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today that his heavy schedule of national campaigning would be poor strategy for any Democrat who was concentrating on getting his party's Presidential nomination in 1972.
Buckpasser will start today at the Big A in a race originated to give 3-year-olds a chance to "realize" the promise they had shown as 2-year-olds.

RIVERHEAD, L.I.--For some political observers, the race for the First Congressional District ended last March when Otis G. Pike, the incumbent Democrat, turned down a highsalaried judgeship offered by the Republicans.
A bloody brawl interrupted the New York Knickerbockers' 122-119 basketball victory over the Los Angeles Lakers last night in the home team's opener at Madison Square Garden.
PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 18 (AP)--Curtis Person of Memphis and Richard H. Guelich Jr. of Buffalo tied for the medal today with 143's in the North and South senior golf tournament.

BUCHAREST--Over the past ten years life here has changed vastly for the better and there is no doubt that Communism has benefited Rumania as a whole. One no longer sees the barefoot peasants of a generation ago nor perceptible gaps between poverty and wealth. There is much home building, widespread television.

A bronze, very likely by Cellini, and other evidence of a banner year for acquisitions by the Metropolitan Museum of Art went on display yesterday. Other accomplishments of 196566 are reviewed in the museum's just-published annual report.

Nine reporters from three cities outside Ohio who covered the trial of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard in Cleveland in 1954 have voiced a private dissent to part of the recent Supreme Court decision that referred to commotion among the press within the courtroom.

"Three Ways of Asian Wisdom;" by Nancy Wilson Ross, will be issued by Simon Schuster on Oct. 31. Miss Ross presents the history, tenets and practices of Hinduism. Budahism and Zen. She couples this exposition with an account of the carrying of these religions to the West and their influence on Western thought. The book contains more than 100 reproductions of works of art illuminative of the religions.

CAIRO, Oct. 18--The improvement in relations between President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and the Syrian Baathist govern- ment has been given another nudge forward by the inclusion of four pro-Egyptian unionists in the new Syrian Cabinet.
The stock market extended its advance yesterday as prices rose sharply in a fast-paced rally in which leading blue-chip stocks made substantial gains.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) --The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that over-the-counter trading in the common stock of the First Standard Corporation of New York, may be resumed Monday after a five-week suspension.

The Manhattan Guild has given the title of Art Nouveau Ball to its 18th annual dinner dance, Oct. 29 at the Plaza Hotel. Plumes and palms will decorate the Terrace Room and the Grand Ballroom, and the tables will be lit by reproductions of Tiffany lampshades.
Monday night's toll of 12 firemen was the highest in the 101year history of the New York City Fire Department.
A nationwide group of religious, educational, labor and civil rights leaders has protested the cancellation of Federal funds to a controversial Mississippi antipoverty project.

OUTDOOR recreation is almost totally oriented to the robust, healthy and wellmuscled. How often are outdoors activities and facilities designed with an eye to the special needs of the handicapped or the aged? Not very often, this corner has found.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 18 (AP)--They South African Foundation said today it had issued no invitation to Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, to visit South Africa next year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18-- The Administration's program for suspending the 7 per cent investment-tax credit and rapid amortization features of the Federal income tax has clouded what had been a "promising financial outlook" for the nation's motor carriers, according to a top banking official.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 18 (UPI)--The Coast Guard said today that a Mexican gunboat had attempted to stop an American shrimp trawler in international waters and fired warning shots when the trawler fled.

Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham, (Elizabeth Arden), who built a multimillion-dollar business in beauty salons, cosmetics and clothes and who was one of the country's leading race-horse, owners, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at Lenox Hill Hospital.

The National Broadcasting Company's "Today" show will be off to England next month to check on the National Theater, doings in London's Carnaby Street, the intellectual community at Cambridge University and other British activities.
UPPSALA, Sweden, Oct. 19 (AP) A new Soviet underground test explosion in the Semipalatinsk area in Central Asia was recorded today by the Seismological Institute here.
AT a witch hunt in Louis XIV's court the prosecutor asked the Duchesse de Bouillon whether she had seen the Devil, and, if so, what was he like?
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Senate-House conferees unexpectedly approved today a plan to finance Presidential campaigns from Federal income taxes by a checkoff system.
PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Oct. 19 Harold Henning of South Africa, an international golfer, became a surprise graduate of the Professional Golfers' Association training school today.
Peter Duchin and his orchestra played at the Plaza last night for a ball dedicated to the memory of his father and benefiting the Leukemia Society.
The short interest position of shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange rose to a record 12,641,001 shares in the month ended Oct. 14, the exchange reported yesterday.
I'M not going to tell you the plot of the new suspense melodrama at the Barrymore, because that would be giving away too little. But I'll be happy to fill you in on some of the incidental details.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 19 The Rev. Ian Paisley, leader of Northern Ireland's extreme Protestant faction, upon his release from Belfast Prison today declared his intention of defying the authorities. Later however, he changed his mind.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 19 (AP) A raspy-voiced man sought for questioning in the bludgeon slaying of a prominent theologian and civil rights leader was cleared tonight of any connection with the crime.

The Union Camp Corporation dedicated a $37-million expansion of its paper mill in Franklin, Va., yesterday. The new construction will increase the mill's output of white paper and paperboard to 1,000 tons a day by early 1967.

The Technical Measurement Corporation, which had a loss of $2,854,000 in the fiscal year ended June 30, is in "a critical cash position," Robert M. Ghen, chairman, told the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The company, based in North Haven, Conn., makes electronic instruments and special-purpose computers.

KATONAH, N. Y., Oct. 19 Mrs. Grace Wells Deatly, wife of Robert N. Deatly, president of the Minette Sales Corporation, a textile agency in New York, died here today at her home, 108 Lily Pond Lane. She was 49 years old.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 19 Billy Ringrose, giving his horse a daring ride, won the international fault-and-out for Ireland at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight.
Stuart T. Saunders, chairman of the Pennsylvania Railroad, expressed confidence yesterday that the merger of the Pennsy and New York Central railroads "is relatively near at hand."

Horn and Hardaxt has opened its first take-out store providing hot meals. Called an Out-o-Mat, the store, at Lexington Avenue and 79th Street, is open from 8 A.M. to midnight Monday through Friday and from 11 A.M. to midnight on Saturday and Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI) Congress, spurred by two disastrous fires at sea in the last year, sent to the White House today a bill requiring the operators of foreign ocean liners to tell United States travelers how safe their ships are rated.

Like Lincoln, Senator Paul H. Douglas is a son of Illinois by adoption, having been born and reared in New England. He has the craggy independence on which "Down East" Yankees pride themselves. Although a devout Quaker and man of peace, he was impelled by his conscience to join the Marines at age fifty during World War II and saw front-line service in the Pacific.

SANA, Yemen, Oct. 19 (AP) Security officials said today that 100 to 120 persons, including the Deputy War Minister and the Minister for Tribal Affairs, had been arrested for having conspired to return former Premier Hassan al-Amry to power.
GARDEN CITY, L. I. Four candidates concerned with the high cost of living, the war in Vietnam, and the fear of increased Federal taxes seek election in Nassau County's Fourth Congressional District.

HONG KONG, Oct. 19 The struggle for power between supporters of Mao Tse-tung and Lin Piao and their opponents is mounting to a new climax, analysts here be- lieve. Despite the purges of the last year, supporters of Mr. Mao appear to be meeting continuing resistance within the policy-making councils of the Chinese Communist party.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Waldo Gifford Leland, director emeritus of the American Council of Learned Societies, died of cancer today at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 87 years old.

The Henry Street Settlemente has named A. Fairfield Dana, a partner in the New York City law firm of Devevoise, Plimpton, Lyons Gates, as president, Mr. Dana had been on the settlement's board of directors since 1959 and chairman of its executive committee since 1963.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (UPI) Guy Rodgers scored 34 points tonight to spur the new Chicago Bulls to their third straight victory in the National Basketball Association with 134-124 triumph over the Los Angeles Lakers despite Elgin Baylor's 45 points.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 1 The International Finance Corporation, the venture capital offshoot of the World Bank, announced today that it had been granted a 15-year, $100-million line of credit by its much larger parent organization.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector) Oct. 19 Three Arab infiltrators and an Israeli border sent from Syria, and an Israeli border policeman were killed today in a clash three miles from the Lebanese border in Israel's Upper Galilee.
BELGRADE, Oct. 19 "Go to Belgrade," they said in Washington, "see live Communists in action."

Bobby Hull is getting bald--and better. The 27-year-old Golden Jet helped celebrate the National Hockey League's golden anniversary season opening at Madison Square Garden last night with two goals in a 6-3 Chicago Black Hawk victory over the New York Rangers.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 19 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that her Government might introduce voluntary "selective national service" for young people this winter.

Civic groups strongly supported at a hearing yesterday a proposal to build a park instead of a complex of big apartment buildings on 12.5 acres of ocean-front land in Coney Island--New York's "country club for low-and middle-income people."
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 19 A new labor union for Roman Catholic priests opened its national office today and announced the start of a nationwide organizing drive.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Thursday, Oct. 20 President Johnson began his tour of the western Pacific today by appealing to North Vietnam to give up a war that he said it "cannot win" and to accept instead his help in a war on Asian poverty.

BRASILIA, Oct. 19 The president of the Chamber of Deputies, Abaute Cardoso, turned down today a face-saving formula suggested by the President Humberto Castelo Branco formula suggested by Presito end a crisis over six purged Deputies.

Record profits of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, indicate the third successive year of peak performance for the major manufacturer of electric and electronic products.

SUSAN STARR got around to playing her first New York recital last night at Carnegie Hall, and it was an eye-opener. Miss Starr attracted attention in 1962 when she was co-winner of second prize in the Moscow International Tchaikovsky Competition. She played here with an orchestra then, but after her marriage appeared seldom.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 19 The Government Minister in charge of the revamped rural pacification program has acknowledged that the effort has fallen short of its goals.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 19--The Lebanese Cabinet announced tonight it would submit an urgent draft law to the Parliament authorizing the Government to spend up to 50 million Lebanese pounds ($16.5 million) "to guarantee the rights of small depositors" in the largest bank in Lebanon, which closed its doors last Friday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 19 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky appeared tonight to have damped down a Cabinet crisis that threatened to embarrass his regime just before the Manila conference, which opens Monday.
British Government bonds lost their recent strength and eased along with share prices in quiet trading on the London stock market yesterday.
Frank Wille, State Superintendent of Banks, brought suit yesterday against the nation's three largest banks to recover funds he said were owed to the New York branch of Lebanon's troubled Intra Bank.
SELMA, Ala., Oco. 19 Voters of Dallas County will choose between two central figures of the Selma civil rights demonstrations of 1965 when they elect a sheriff on Nov. 8.
A quiet attempt, the first in almost 10 years, is being made along the waterfront to organize the 1,000 hiring agents and pier superintendents.

ROSLYN, L. I. Vietnam, inflation and the busing, of pupils for integration have emerged as the central issues in the Third Congressional District, where the Nassau County telephone directory lists two Congressmen.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 19--Governor Rockefeller announced plans today for a $5-million State Institute for Heart Research. He said it would combat "the No. 1 killer disease that causes 60 per cent of the state's deaths."
THE OUTLOOK for the auto stocks in 1967 is "merely very good," in the view of a leading brokerage house, and this attitude is reflected in two other reports on this key segment of the stock market.
"The doctors have kept me going when I thought I would have to give up and just lie...
The leaders of 4,000 construction plumbers who have been on strike in Manhattan and the Bronx for 88 days rejected last night a new contract offer by building contractors.

The appointment of Kenneth G. McKay as vice president in charge of engineering was announced yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. He succeeds Richard R. Hough, who was named vice president of the long lines department of A.T.
Another victory, his 11th in a row, was registered by Ogden Phipps's wonder horse, Buckpasser, in the $54,600 Lawrence Realization at Aqueduct yesterday.

MANILA, Oct. 19 Informed sources said today that the Philippine Government might ask President Johnson during the Manila conference opening Monday for a moratorium on bombing attacks on North Vietnam for a specific period after the conference.
ROME, Oct. 19 (AP) Pope Paul VI said today that bad behavior by many members of the Roman Catholic church often caused the Church to appear as a "deformation of Christ."

WASHTNGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, charged tonight on the House floor that a witness at last August's hearings of the House Committee on Un-American Activities was paid $1,000 by Congress after he had testified.
The Melfra Realty Corporation has contracted to buy the five-story building at 133 East 62d Street that now serves as headquarters for the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 19--American air raids in North Vietnam dropped yesterday to their lowest level of intensity in several months.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 19 (UPI) Ralph Boston leaped 26 feet 5 inches in the Little Olympic long jump today and the United States swept the three top places in the men's discus throw to move closer to an over-all victory in the games.
Plans for a park in East Harlem to mark the contributions of Negroes to American culture were announced yesterday.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Thursday, Oct. 20 President Johnson received a big, friendly and often enthusiastic welcome during a 24-hour visit to the capital of New Zealand yesterday and today.
Philip Morris, Inc., the cigarette producer, announced here yesterday a broad realignment of its operational and managerial structure.

AN Alaskan buying trip has netted the American Indian Arts Center some intriguing examples of Indian and Eskimo handicrafts, ranging from offbeat apresski accessories to ivory carvings and primitive masks.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 19 Ingmar Bergman has added to what Swedes call his "myth as a moviemaker with a film about intense personal loneliness, "Persona."
The final fadeout of the Paramount Pictures Corporation as an independent company was played here yesterday before a few hundred of its owners.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 19--Sir Morrice James, the British Commonwealth official who has brought to Salisbury Britain's terms for a solution of the countries' dispute, met for 75 minutes with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith today.

Though mortgage money remains relatively scarce in the continuing tight money market, the person having only a small amount of cash still may be able to buy his home with the aid of a Federa Housing Administration-in sured mortgage.

The Brotherhood of Painters placed its New York District Council 9 in trusteeship yesterday following the indictment of Martin Rarback, the council's secretary-treasurer, on charges of having taken $840,000 in bribes.

DURING the World Series the umpires performed with such quiet efficiency that few fans even noticed that they were there. This thought popped into mind when news came that George Magerkurth had died at the age of 77. No one ever could say that the Maje Was never noticed when he was wearing the blue serge suit. It was impossible to miss so dominating a figure.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) Chances for a quick increase in Social Security benefits died today when the House Ways and Means Committee gave up efforts to draw a bill for enactment by the present Congress.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) The Post Office Department will hire 150,000 temporary Christmas employes a month earlier than usual this year to prevent mail from piling up as it did for several weeks in Chicago.
LONDON, Oct. 19 Jerry Lewis and Sammy Davis will top the bill at this year's Royal Variety Performance at the London Palladium.

Brahms's First Piano Concerto, with its big symphonic proportions, made a fine vehicle for Gary Graffman, last night's soloist with the New York Philharmonic in Philharmonic Hall. The performance was one to which no exceptions could be taken; that is saying a great deal where a work with plenty of technical and interpretive hazards is concerned.
WARSAW, Oct. 19 Bright October sunshine returned to Warsaw today, suffusing the autumn gold of the trees. There was a pleasant bite in the air. Just as it was 10 years ago, people recalled.
The State Health Department intervened in the operation of the 21 municipal hospitals yesterday by ordering the city to purchase life-saving equipment and to revise procedures on patient transfers.
Indian Head, Inc., a diversified manufacturing company, announced yesterday the election of Andrew Kalman to the new post of executive vice president. He was also elected a director.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Oct. 19 Frank D. O'Connor, the Democratic candidate for Governor, accusesd Governor Rockefeller today of "cynicism" and 'inherent dishonesty" and the "raw use of naked power" and of vast sums of money in a massive effort to "brainwash" the state's voters in seeking reelection.

A MUDDLED drama about a neurotic detective bent on administering a psychological third degree to suspects was last night's feature on the American Broadcasting Company's "Stage 67." The play, entitled "The Confession," came from the usually able pen of David Karp; but he became entangled in a situation that was rooted in an unpleasant situation and never interestingly developed.
The fifth annual International Ski and Winter Sports Show will start a four-day stand at the New York Coliseum today with more than 160 exhibits covering a 90,00-squarefoot area.
The Teamsters Union said, yesterday that it would picket today's Oktoberfest in Bryant Park if the Parks Department carried through plans to serve imported rather than domestic beer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The Federal Trade Commission today charged Lenox, Inc., Trenton, N.J., makers of fine china, dinnerware, giftware and artware, with unlawfully fixing and maintaining resale prices among its franchised dealers.
Investors redeemed fewer mutual fund shares in September than they did in August. For the sixth month in a row, investors also purchased fewer shares than in the preceding month.

RAIN forced Army indoors yesterday to continue preparations for its game against Pittsburgh and Ed James, the nation's 18thranked collegiate passer. James has completed 62 of 128 aerials and will lead the unsuccessful Panthers against the cadets, who have enjoyed...
Three suits have been filed against the Douglas Aircraft Company, charging the big airframe maker with failure to disclose in recent proxies that it faced large losses.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) The White House approved today the purchase by Braniff Airways of Pan American-Grace Airways (Panagra).

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 19 S. Stanley Kreutzer was installed tonight as president of the newly formed Long Island Council of the American Jewish Congress at Temple Israel of Great Neck, 108 Old Mill Road.

GLENCOE, N.M. This is the land of Billy the Kid, and now in October the air is wildly perfumed with the scent of apples and the sweet, good smell of burning applewood. The countryside is mottled with autumn in the boughs of poplar, box elder and cottonwood.
The State Department agreed yesterday that a seven-man team could represent the United States in the 17th Chess Olympics in Havana beginning next Tuesday and continuing until Nov. 20.

The New York Daily News said last night that the first tabulations in its straw poll for Governor, put Governor Rockefeller out in front by a narrow margin. But Frank D. O'Connor, the Democrat, "was treading on his heels."

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (UPI) A husky, blond youth, arrested for running a red light suddenly screamed "I killed Percy's daughter!" today as he was waiting in a suburban police lockup for a court appearance.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 19 Mrs. Mabel Vanderhoof Pace, widow of Homer St. Clair Pace, who founded Pace Institute (now Pace College) in 1906, died today at her home on Lloyd Harbor here after a short illness. She was 86 years old.

Two rivals for Governor Frank D. O'Connor and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. bumped into each other in a narrow hallway on Morningside Heights yesterday. After a fleeting moment of uncertainty, and when it was plain that no escape was possible, the two men staged a toe-totoe, mouth-to-microphone debate of immense uncordiality.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 19 Nearly everything went wrong tonight, as Roosevelt Raceway's third and final meeting of the season got under way. The opening feature, the Westbury Futurity for 2-year-old trotters, was won by the Clearview Stables' favored Pay Dirt.

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 19 (AP) The defending champion, Dave Goldman of Dallas, and Curtis Person of Memphis, the co-medalist, triumphed in the first round of the North and South senior golf tournament today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) The House voted, 255 to 0, tonight to set up a 12-member select committee to recommend regulations "to insure proper standards of conduct" by members and employes.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) Britain is preparing for the immediate withdrawal of 10,000 troops from Southeast Asia to cut defense costs, the Minister of Defense, Denis Healey, said in the House of Commons today.

"It was like a horror film," said Alfred Leslie, the painter and filmmaker. "My whole studio burst into flames. I stood on the street and saw my paintings burning through the windows. All I could do was watch."
The New York Hilton's Trianon Room will be the setting on Monday evening for a party marking the 50th anniversary of the Louise Wise Services, an adoption agency.
The Board of Education announced yesterday that it would set up a citywide "task force" of educators, public officials and community leaders to help improve education in ghetto schools.

President Johnson's promising initiative to broaden contact with Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union is in danger of being balked by a recalcitrant Congress that seems to be thinking only in terms of the coming elections.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 19 Sweden, whose last major strike was in 1945, was heading tonight for a labor conflict that would deprive half a million students of their teachers.
Joseph M. Green of 137-04 73d Terrace, Queens Village, a knitting executive, died last night in his home of a heart attack. He was 83 years old.
The election of Elias Paul as president of the Cudahy Packing Company, Chicago, was announced yesterday.
THE happy quacks and honks of ducks and geese are filling the hearts of the country's waterfowlers with joy as an abundance of birds not seen in a decade comes winging down the flyways.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) Prime Minister Wilson agreed today to act personally against labor unrest spreading through Britain's automotive industry. His opponents charge the industry is plunging into chaos chiefly because of the Government's economic squeeze.

WHETHER the coming generation of experts will match or exceed the skill of their fathers is a question that cannot be answered. But if a match played last week can be taken as a guide, the omens are favorable.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 "Are you trying to commit suicide?" a supporter recently asked Spiro T. Agnew, the Republican candidate for Governor of Maryland. "You've been endorsed by The New York Times, the A.D.A. and the Rabbinical Association."

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 19 Mr. and Mrs. John K. Breese have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Kathleen Breese, to Peter Coffin Vincent. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Vincent of Bedford Hills.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The chief spokesman for the nation's home builders today urged restoration of the consumer credit controls that were in effect during the Korean War.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) Spurred by gains in the aircraft industry, new factory orders for durable goods increased substantially during September after two months of decline, the Commerce Department reported today.
PAGOPAGO, American Samoa, Oct. 19 (AP) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson is the first woman ever offered the royal ava drink, the highest honor Samoan chiefs can bestow on a visitor. She drank it, too.
A Manhattan grand jury has been considering charges that a Park Avenue art gallery has been selling scores of forged paintings attributed to Marc Chagall, it was learned yesterday.

An Attempt by the two sisters of the late Billy Rose to challenge his will was dismissed yesterday by Manhattan Surrogate Joseph A. Cox. The will left most of his estimated $50million estate to charity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--Senator George D. Aiken made a "far-fetched proposal" today for achieving peace in Vietnam: that the United States declare that it has won the war.
LONDON, Oct. 19 There is a strong movement of opinion within the Labor Government toward making an unequivocal declaration of intent to enter the Common Market.

Otto L. Dietz, who retired two years ago as president of the Duane Fabrics Corporation here, died Tuesday in St. Joseph's Hospital, Paterson, N. J., after a short illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 550 Berdan Avenue, Wayne, N.J.

A television theater critic who gave a negative review to a recent play sponsored by the David Merrick Arts Foundation said he was barred last night from the premiere of "We Have Always Lived in the Castle," a Merrick production.

There is a political crisis in Saigon. Putting it on ice until after the Manila conference cannot disguise this fact. A military clique, headed by Marshal Ky, and not a combined military and civilian government, is in power.
A young woman hostage was found stabbed to death in a Bronx apartment yesterday after police tear gas had routed a 250-pound suspect in two murders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) The Government banned from the market today certain prenatal prescription drugs containing fluoride that have been promoted for prevention of tooth decay in children when taken by expectant mothers.
National Airlines announced yesterday that it had sold its entire fleet of 17 turbo-prop Electra airlines to the Pan Aero International Corporation of Miami for an undisclosed sum.

BOSTON, Oct, 19 (AP) Chinese-American public school children in Boston have been officially declared white by the School Committee in the latest phase of the controversy over racial imbalance in schools.

COMO, Italy, Oct. 19 A policeman masquerading as an art dealer willing to handle "hot" goods sprang a trap near here yesterday that gathered in stolen art works worth from $250,000 to $300,000 and three men suspected of the theft.

Joe Pepitone lost his law suit against the Board of Education for $100,000 last night. An all-male jury voted unanimously to reject his claim after deliberating for three and a half hours in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) A former Navy pilot in Vietnam says that many officers feel the war is being "run by uninformed potential voters who want a quiet war, one that will not make hardships for them at home."
DUNEDIN, N. Z., Oct. 19 (AP) Bob Charles of New Zealand, a left-hander took a six-stroke lead over Arnold Palmer today in the first match of a four-match series.

MALVERNE, L. I., Oct. 19 The school board announced tonight what it called a "freedomof-choice" plan under which parents may request transfers of children in kindergarten through the fifth grade to any of the three schools in the Malverne district.
ROME, Oct. 19 (AP) Pope Paul VI and a Methodist leader, Bishop Fred Pierce Corson of Philadelphia, met today in private audience and discussed Roman Catholic-Protestant talks on Christian unity.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 19 The Monmouth County Welfare Board unanimously rejected two proposals here today to prosecute the unwed parents of children on welfare and then adopted a motion to crack down on parents who abandon or abuse their children.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Management of the Columbia Pictures Corporation conferred in New York today with two stockholder groups that together have more than a majority interest in their company.

Park Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving said yesterday he hoped to set up a "sort of revolving world's fair" in Cen tral Park beginning next year.

Charles Kimmelman, board chairman of the Barbizon Hotel and operator of many large properties here and in Chicago, died Tuesday night at his home, 870 Fifth Avenue, after a brief illness. He was 82 years old.

Weatherly, the successful America's Cup defender of 1962, will help Columbia, the 1958 winner, get ready for her effort to try again for yachting's foremost prize.

Thousands of uniformed firemen from this city and across the country will march on Fifth Avenue tomorrow in final tribute to their comrades who perished in the 23d Street fire.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 Britain joined the United States today in declaring that South Africa had forfeited her right to retain her mandate over the neighboring territory of South-West Africa.
Three cars of the PennTexas Express, arriving from St. Louis, were derailed yesterday morning entering Pennsylvania Station.

Foreign traders of this country will have to increase their sales abroad by 50 per cent in the next 10 years to maintain the United States' position in world commerce, a Department of Commerce official said last night.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 19 Without throwing a single punch, the New York Knickerbockers flattened the Baltimore Bullets tonight, 131-109, with a blazing 78-point second-half after a slow start.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 For the first time in 20 years, a major college football team appears to have two backs so superlative that all-America selectors may be compelled to pick both of them.

Max Hirsch, the 86-year-old trainer, was consoled by many at Aqueduct yesterday at the loss of the 3-year-old Buffle, the colt that he had brought along so well for its owner, Robert J. Kleberg Jr. of the King Ranch.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The pacification program in South Vietnam is one of five that have been attempted there in the last four years.

Mrs. Mary Mason, a retired librarian, an author of children's books and a former member of the editorial staff of the Reader's Digest, died Friday in a La Jolla (Calif.) hospital. She was 78 years old and had lived in La Jolla since she retired from the Digest staff 10 years ago.

A NUN in the white nursing habit and fluted bonnet of the Sisters of Charity found herself Tuesday night in the unusual position of presenting a fashion show. "This is a result of Vatican II," Sister Anthony Marie, administrator of St. Vincent's Hospital, said as student nurses...
Profit taking weakened most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in moderate trading.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 Senator Paul H. Douglas, caught in the toughest re-election struggle of his long political career, is beginning to lash out at his recently bereaved opponent.
Anyone for statistics? In a recently conducted poll of 100 college kids interested in the ad game, only two "offered a clear over-all opinion that 'advertising is unethical."'

Frank D. O'Connor accused Governor Rockefeller last night of having assigned state troopers to the Queens District Attorney's office to make a "frantic" search of the files for material that might be used against him in the gubernatorial campaign.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 A tough new crime bill for the District of Columbia that cuts deeply into two landmark Federal Court decisions cleared Congress today.

ALMOST anybody can learn to groom dogs acceptably, but those who become really superb groomers have some artistic talent, said Ben Stone, the director of the New York School of Dog Grooming in Manhattan. He mentioned artists, barbers and hairdressers as particularly suited for...

MILTON, Mass., Oct. 19 The engagement of Miss Charna Tenenbaum to Lance Heiko, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Heiko of Glen Cove, L. I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Myer Tenenbaum of Milton and Westford.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Summing up the outgoing 89th Congress and "our times," Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen said today that under the "calcimine" of the Great Society lies a nation beset by "uncertainty, queasy doubts and bewilderment."

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 19 (UPI) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today that a final decision had been made naming three astronauts Lieut. Col. Virgil I. Grissom, Lieut. Col. Edward H. White 2d and Lieut. Roger B. Chaffee as the crew of the Apollo spaceship now being prepared for flight.
Corporate and municipal bond prices advanced again yesterday as the market continued under the influence of its October optimism.

Net income of the American Electric Power Company rose to record levels in the month of September and the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, Donald C. Cook, president of the seven-state utility system announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The head of the Rockefeller Fund for Theological Education said today that five influential Protestant denominations in the United States were ignoring their Negro congregations.
Cocoa futures traders who have been awaiting production figures for the 1966-1967 crop year got a surprise yesterday.
A major airline has decided to ask air travelers to help it design the interiors of a fleet of airliners it has on order.
OSLO, Norway, Oct. 19 The Nobel Peace Prize Committee of the Norwegian Storting (Parliament) announced today that it had decided to defer the award of this year's prize until next year.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 19 Some 250 young Negroes, including many nonstudents, ran wild at Oakland's Castlemont High School today. They beat five white teachers and three white students and forced the 2,700-student school to close early.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 A spokesman for the United States Mission said tonight that Arthur J. Goldberg, the chief United States delegate to the Unied Nations, was not seeking a change of post. He said there was "absolutely nothing" to reports to that effect.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The Middle East Institute announced today that Mr. Hare would succeed Kermit Roosevelt as the institute's president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) The Senate Appropriations Committee cleared the final appropriations bill of the Congressional session today and set the scene for a possible battle with the House over trade with Communist bloc nations.
The nation's electric power production rose 8.8 per cent in the week ended Oct. 15, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
Dr. Randolph Richard Henderson, a physician in Harlem since 1926, died yesterday in his home at 214 West 138th Street, where he maintained a general practice. He was 71 years old.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Mayor Lindsay were greeted warmly in a chilly drizzle yesterday as they campaigned together for the first time to keep the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board.
PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 19 (UPI) Government policies are an important factor in the cause of high food prices, a food processing executive said today.
Two lawyers, one of them a former assistant district attorney, were indicted for fraud and forgery in Queens yesterday, charged with failing to report the fees they received in negligence cases.

Hugh McGauley, manager of the St. James Theater, will be the guest of honor at a testimonial dinner given by his colleagues on Saturday night in the Hotel St. Moritz. Mr. McGauley, who is 58 years old, began his career as a runner in a ticket brokerage office at the age of 11.
Dr. Randolph Richard Henderson, a physician in Harlem since 1926, died yesterday in his home at 214 West 138th Street, where he maintained a general practice. He was 71 years old.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Mayor Lindsay were greeted warmly in a chilly drizzle yesterday as they campaigned together for the first time to keep the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 19 The Nobel Peace Prize Committee of the Norwegian Storting (Parliament) announced today that it had decided to defer the award of this year's prize until next year.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 19 Some 250 young Negroes, including many nonstudents, ran wild at Oakland's Castlemont High School today. They beat five white teachers and three white students and forced the 2,700-student school to close early.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 A spokesman for the United States Mission said tonight that Arthur J. Goldberg, the chief United States delegate to the Unied Nations, was not seeking a change of post. He said there was "absolutely nothing" to reports to that effect.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The Middle East Institute announced today that Mr. Hare would succeed Kermit Roosevelt as the institute's president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) The Senate Appropriations Committee cleared the final appropriations bill of the Congressional session today and set the scene for a possible battle with the House over trade with Communist bloc nations.
The nation's electric power production rose 8.8 per cent in the week ended Oct. 15, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 19 Another merger was arranged today in the French financial community.

The Seamen's Church Institute, which began providing lodgings for merchant sailors a century ago to combat the practice of shanghaiing from waterfront boarding houses, announced plans yesterday for a new $7.5-million building that will rise 23 stories above Battery Park.

The New York Drama Critics Circle is planning to expand its membership from 15 to 20. A meeting will be called in November or December to consider candidates from publications having "considerable impact in New York City that treat the theater seriously."
TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 20 (AP) North Vietnam's official news agency today gave additional details on the capture of three American pilots shot down in August and September.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI) The Supreme Court took under advisement today an attack by lawyers for Life magazine upon New York State's right-to-privacy law.

THE former world champion, Mikhail Botvinnili of the Soviet Union, now 56 years old, scored 7 -1 to capture first place in the grand masters' section of the recent Sixth I.B.M. Annual International Congress in Amsterdam. He was followed by the former child prodigy Arturo Pomar of Spain with 5 -3 . Salo Flohr of the Soviet Union was third with 5-4.
The women's auxiliary of the Rainbow Division Veterans' Father Duffy Chapter will hold a luncheon on Saturday in the American Room of the Internatioanl Building at 630 Fifth Avenue.

MANILA, Oct. 19 The Philippine Foreign Office forwarded to President Ferdinand E. Marcos today a request from Tass, the official Soviet press agency, and Izvestia, the Soviet government newspaper, to send correspondents to cover the top-level conference here on Vietnam beginning Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The Justice Department filed suit late today to block the proposed merger of the First City National Bank and the Southern National Bank in Houston on the ground that it would violate Section 7 of the Clayton Antitrust Act by "substantially reducing competition and increasing concentration in commercials banking in Harris County (Houston) and the Houston metropolitan area."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI) An official of the United States Information Agency said today that a new book about President Johnson was not recommended for the agency's overseas libraries because it would not "help the fortunes of the United States."
The regional scholarship fund of Bryn Mawr College will benefit from a gala on Sunday evening at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 19 Dr. Subandrio, the former Foreign Minister, strongly indicated at his trial today his belief that President Sukarno was solely responsible for the activities of his Cabinet Ministers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) Brig. Gen. Charles Hines, U.S.A., retired, who commanded an antiaircraft unit in the 1944 landings at Utah Beach in Normandy, died on Monday at his home of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.
Miss Jennifer Lyman and Allard K. Lowenstein will marry on Nov. 25 in Waltham, Mass.
A United States nun and a Mexican priest urged yesterday that the Roman Catholic Church endorse contraception as essential to responsible family planning.

Roy L. Reierson, senior vice president and chief economist at the Bankers Trust Company, took a close look yesterday at the Fedaral Reserve System's present policy. He suggested, among other things, that the Reserve adopt a system of flexible rate ceilings.
The art collections of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rosensaft, Mr. and Mrs. Sam Salz and Mrs. Nathan B. Spingold will be on view Saturday to aid the Children's Blood Foundation.
A sudden disaster like the 23d Street holocaust raises serious questions for those who live and work in a closely built, crowded metropolitan area.
LONDON, Oct. 19 Britain has been embarrassed by the charges of a Swedish doctor that political prisoners are being tortured in the jails of Aden. The Foreign Office has denied the allegations.

A man foolish enough to have stood in a bucket on any corner in town from 11:52 P.M. Tuesday until 11 o'clock last night would have found his insteps awash with rainwater and the level rising to his ankles.
The spot rate on the British pound eased sightly in moderate trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.
RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 19 (AP) Three Negro defendants won new trials today because a judge in Mecklenburg Superior Court described them in his charge to the jury as "three black cats in a white Buick."

ALBANY, Oct. 19 "How come you're willing to marry someone who has had two divorces?," a friend asked Dr. Robert S. Herman, assistant state budget director who has just taken on the job of running a temporary state commission that has suffered two major...

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 19 Kenya's two houses of Parliament the Senate and the House of Representatives are to be merged into a single house under the terms of a parliamentary constituencies review order published today.
Stock prices declined in moderate trading yesterday as sellers moved in to nail down profits made in the market's recent advance.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Oct. 19 Prime Minister Forbes Burnham reported today that Venezuela had rejected his protest against Venezuelans occupying territory claimed by Guyana Island, Amkako 200 miles southwest of here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) The Senate passed today the $6.1-billion compromise education bill providing funds to continue the grade and high school aid program for a second and third year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The first of two satellites that will extend commercial space communications to two-thirds of the world is scheduled to be launched next Wednesday.

Mrs. Emma Robbins Walbridge, whose family was among the first settlers in the Point O'Woods colony on Fire Island, in the late 1890's, died Tuesday in her winter home in Babylon, L. I., after a brief illness. She was 78 years old and had a summer home at Point O'Woods.
Seven commercial banks have agreed to lend $7-million at low interest rates to revive the lagging rehabilitation program in a West Side urban renewal area.
MADRID, Oct. 19 (Reuters) Dr. Casimiro Morcillo, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Madrid, ruled today that Spain's official Catholic Action Movement must keep out of politics.

DETROIT, Oct. 19 (AP) American automobile manufacturers told the Federal Government today that they would have difficulties in meeting all 26 safety requirements set by the General Service Administration for the 1968 cars it will purchase.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 20 (UPI) President Johnson held a brief reunion Tuesday with two physicians who treated him for a fever during World War II, Dr. Paul Brunette and Dr. Derek Ryder, both of Nelson, New Zealand. Dr. Brunette is a general practitioner and Dr. Ryder is a surgeon.
The New York and the American exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.
A closing favorite with the crowd of 22,421, George D. Widener's King's Jest proved the right horse in the feature race of seven furlongs at Aqueduct yesterday.
MACON, Ga., Oct. 20 (UPI) Members of the First Baptist Church of Macon, the city's largest, have voted for an opendoor policy at the church.

LAWRENCE, L.I., The race in the Fifth Congressional District in Nassau County involves the incumbent Democrat, a Republican and a candidate of the United for Peace party, who is considered by his opponents to be a "spoiler."
HONG KONG, Oct. 20 (AP) Anti-Communist Hong Kong newspapers said today that more than 400 Communists and Red Guards were killed or injured Oct. 10 in an explosion in Swatow.
A half dozen ulcer patients at Prospect Hospital, 730 Kelly Street, the Bronx, demonstrated on the street for an hour in their pajamas yesterday to protest hospital conditions.

The Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, the Right Rev. John E. Hines, took action this week to head off the first move toward a heresy trial for the Right Rev. James A. Pike, Retired Bishop of California, it was learned yesterday.

Gerold Frank's "The Boston Strangler" is not as neat and tidy as Truman Capote's "In Cold Blood," nor as pretentious (there will be none of the "nonfiction novel" chatter that was created for the earlier book), nor as provocative: at the end of "The Bos- ...

Retailers and textile manufacturers must establish a closer relationship to achieve the fast reaction necessary to profit from changes in apparel trends, an executive of Sears Roebuck Co., said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20(AP) Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio, proposed today that the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps consolidate their recruiting stations and staff them with retired military personnel.
HONG KONG, Oct. 20 The people of Communist China have been called upon to defend Chairman Mao Tse-tung with their lives.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) The Vietnam war pushed military spending to an unprecedented "peacetime" annual rate of almost $63-billion in the first three months of the fiscal year 1967.
ARNE JENSEN, Columbia University's leading ground-gainer, has given up football. Buff Donelli, the Lions' coach, said Jensen made the decision so that he might devote more time to his studies.

FREEHOLD, N.J. Oct. 20 The widow of a retired Army officer allegedly murdered by Dr. Carl A. Coppolino told authorities that she had tried to kill her husband with a drug but that Dr. Coppolino had finished the job while she watched, according to a statement she made that was disclosed today.

HUELVA, Spain, Oct. 20 (AP) Spain's second venture into space failed here yesterday when a sounding rocket fell within a few hundred yards of its launching point. Officials blamed a failure in the guidance system. The first of a series of small space rockets was fired successfully Oct. 16 in a project to collect scientific data from an area 30 to 60 miles above the earth.

Edgar L. Schlesinger, vice president of the United International division of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., died yesterday in the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 135 East 83d Street and in South Salem, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) An apparent Soviet nuclear test has been reported by the Atomic Energy Commission. The commission said that it detected seismic signals from the Soviet nuclear test area equivalent to those, of a nuclear blast of between 20,000 and 200,000 tons of TNT.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 20 All banks except the big Intra Bank opened here today after a three-day holiday, did brisk business and were able to meet demands without apparent strain.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 20 Martin P. Nelson, mayor of this borough from 1938 to 1944, a Bergen County Freeholder and a State Assemblyman, died at the Hackensack Hospital last night. He was 65 years old and lived at 55 Barrows Avenue.
ALL FOOLS' DAY, by Edmund Cooper (Walker, $3.50). Novel about a decimated world run by neurotics.
The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, turned in glowing results for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, according to the figures reported yesterday.

Capt. Harold E. Gray, president of Pan American World Airways, and five other persons who made the first passenger flight across the Pacific 30 years ago will retrace their course tomorow, the anniversary of the flight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) The Senate confirmed today President Johnson's nomination of Senator Donald S. Russell, Democrat of South Carolina, to be a Federal judge for the western district of South Carolina. He succeeds the late Judge Charles Cecil Wyche.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20 As ground action slackened, United States casualties in South Vietnam decreased to 500 last week, spokesmen said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) Negro voter registration has almost doubled in five Deep South states since enactment last year of the Voting Rights Act.
RICHMOND, Oct. 20 James J. Kilpatrick is resigning after 15 years as editor of The Richmond News Leader.
New York University has raised $54.6-million in the last two years for its capital program, Dr. James M. Hester, the university president, said last night.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 20 (AP) A six-man majority of the Miami Beach City Council has refused to permit a closed-circuit television broadcast of Cassius Clay's Nov. 14 title bout at Houston.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 20 (AP) White hunters flown in by helicopter have shot 300 elephants in Kenya's overcrowded Tsavo National Park. The operation may become the biggest elephant slaughter in history.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 20--President Tito of Yugoslavia and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic arrived today on what is being described here as a rescue mission.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 Chief S.O. Adebo of Nigeria called on the Security Council today for stricter enforcement of the 1949 Palestine armistice agreements as the only means of ending violent clashes on the border between Israel and Syria.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 The United States was urged by a panel of prominent citizens today to adopt a policy that would permit both Communist China and Nationalist ...

THE New York northern zone big-game season will open on Tuesday and the Conservation Department is assuring applicants for party permits that the necessary documents will be in the hands of hunters by this weekend.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) The House approved a bill today to give the National and American Football Leagues the antitrust immunity they wanted to go ahead with their merger into one league.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 20 (AP) Ten Copley newspapers, headed by The San Diego Union and The Sacramento Union, have endorsed Ronald Reagan for Governor of California.

NORWICH, N.Y., Oct. 20 Governor Rockefeller fought back against tax critics today with the assertion that the annual personal income in New York State had risen $18-billion since 1958 during his efforts to improve the economic climate. State taxes, he said, are taking only $2-billion of this rise.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 20 (UPI) Roberto de Vicenzo of Argentina and Kel Nagle of Australia fired fourunder-par 69's today to share the first-round lead in the Wills Masters golf tournament.
JERUSALEM (Israel Sector). Oct. 20 A few days ago wellwishers crowded the once quiet house of Shmuel Yosef Agnon to congratulate the author on his impending Nobel Prize.
A sale of 110 modern paintings and sketches at the Parke. Bernet Galleries last night brought $976,300.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 20 Anakonda, a 10-year-old gray mare, bore Mrs. Frank Chapot of the United States Equestrian Team to a fast and flawless round over 10 fences for victory in the international jumping tonight at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

HAGEN, Germany, Oct. 20 (Reuters) A former Nazi concentration camp official sobbed in court here today as the prosecutor demanded a life sentence for his part in the murder of 70,000 Jewish inmates. Franz Wolf, 59 years old, is one of 10 former low-ranking guards at the Sobibor camp in Poland on trial here for murder or aid in the killing of at least 250,000 jews.

The A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company in Decatur, Ill., is taking its grocery products advertising worth just under $3million in billings from Clyne Maxon, Inc., in New York and moving it closer to home to the Chicago office of CampbellMithun, Inc., of Minneapolis.

After much fumbling and delay, the Board of Education has come up with a proposal which could, if carried forward with imagination and urgency, both put an end to the conflict over Intermediate School 201 and chart a new course for improvement of the slum schools.

A thoroughly realistic policy toward admission of Communist China to the United Nations is put forward in a report released today by a citizens' group headed by former Under Secretary of the Treasury Robert V. Roosa.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 The North Vietnamese Government attributes great importance to a United States assurance of an eventual troop withdrawal as a condition for negotiations, according to a Hungarian source qualified to reflect Hanoi's views.
LONDON, Oct. 20 The Labor Government announced today the highest unemployment in more than two and ahalf years.
CHINA'S relentlessly shrill efforts to deify Mao Tse tung and the cheers and songs of the Red Guards in Peking are coming directly into the New York area on shortwave radio.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) The appointment of James S. Fish of Waysata, Minn., as a nonsalaried special consultant for Savings Bonds promotion was announced yesterday by Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler.
WOODBURY, L.I., Oct. 20 A medical sampling of Nassau and Suffolk Counties by the Waldemar Medical Research Foundation showed that 204 of 595 persons examined had some form of disease.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Oct. 20 The Icelandic freighter, The Brunafoss, loaded with 1,200 tons of frozen fish consigned to Coldwater Seafoods, Inc., at Nanticoke, Md., steamed out of the Cambridge deep-water port today with her cargo still in the hold.

Harry Flood Byrd of Virginia was a born autocrat, a self-made millionaire, and a true gentleman. Sociable and intelligent, he had great energy and imposing political gifts that helped make him the boss of Virginia and a power in the United States Senate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) The Senate passed by voice vote today its final appropriations bill of the year, a $5.1billion measure with a foreign policy feature that could produce an adjournment-eve battle with the House.

BERRYVILLE, Va., Oct. 20--Former United States Senator Harry Flood Byrd, a major force in American politics for 30 years and the dominant figure in Virginia politics for even longer, died at his country estate here this morning. He was 79 years old.
ALBANY, Oct. 20 An expansion of State Health Department Services, sparked by new programs, such as Medicare and water-pollution control, will call for 763 new positions in the department.
SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 20 (Reuters) Arthur Hartley of Clearwater, Fla., won two matches and suffered one defeat when the singles event continued today at the world lawn bowling championships.

GREAT NECK,. L.I., Oct. 20 Dr. and Mrs. Phillip E. Lear have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Phillis Lear, to Roger Elliot Swaybill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Swaybill of New York. The wedding is planned for December.
Dr. Henry Guterman, for the last 57 years chief orthodox rabbi of the city of Scranton, Pa., died there Wednesday in the Mercy Hospital. He was 83 years old.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 20 Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. charged today that Governor Rockefeller had deprived thousands of youths of a college education by tardy development of the State University and "hostility" to free tuition.
SAIGON South Vietnam, Oct. 20 For South Vietnam, the conference in Manila on Monday and Tuesday will be primarily an opportunity to bind its allies closer to it, diplomatic sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20--The House gave final Congressional approval today to a bill authorizing $6.2-billion in aid to elementary and secondary education for the next two years.
LANSING, Mich., Oct. 20 (UPI) A Detroit truck driver testified today that he was with a State Senator at the time the lawmaker is charged with asking a college coed to perform in obscene movies.

LONDON, Oct. 20 (Reuters) A British Council of Churches report that did not censure sex outside marriage was condemned today by the 1,400 delegates at a conference of the national Assembly of Evangelicals. They called for absolute standards of sexual moralty.

The New York Yankees, whose image plummeted as badly as their baseball invincibility last season, made a move yesterday to win back friends. They created a special-projects department and named 34-yearold Howard Berk as director.

DICK LYNCH, the seasoned cornerback who has been with the New York Giants since 1959, is back on the active roster. Smith Reed, a spare halfback who jammed some fingers in practice, was waived out as an injured player yesterday and Lynch, who had been hurt earlier,
WHITINGHAM, Vt., Oct. 20 Hamilton W. Greene, an illustrator of books and magazines, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 62 years old.
PARIS, Oct. 20 The Roman Catholic dioceses of the Paris region have been reorganized on an experimental basis designed as a model for other very large cities.

CAPETOWN, Oct. 20 Dimitrio Tsafendas, the assassin of Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd of South Africa, was declared insame today by the Capetown Supreme Court and was ordered to be detained in prison indefinitely.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I. Oct. 20 A par 4 on the first extra hole by Gene Borek of Pine Hollow enabled the medalist and Jerry Lambo, Rockrimmon, to defeat Frank Cardi Rockaway Hunt, and John Malesky, Glen Head, in the first round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association pro-pro championship at the Cedar Brook Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) The National Park Service said today that the Christmas tree for Washington's pageant of peace would come this year from Emmigrant Gap in California. The 75-foot tree highlights the holiday attraction in front of the White House.

Put Roy Emerson on a squash court and what do you have? A darn good squash er, squash tennis player who, according to the sharp-eyed gallery pundits at the Yale Club, could go right to the top, as he has in tennis, with just a few more matches.

Poor road business is curtailing the tours that had been booked for "Where's Charley?" and "The Desert Song," two of the four road productions organized by the newly established American Musical Theater Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 A Presidential committee has recommended more Government spending cuts and a follow-up increase in individual and corporate taxes if the Administration's present programs do not curb inflation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20 A three-week-old Cabinet crisis apparently under control, Premier Nguyen Cao Ky said today that he would go to Manila Sunday to seek "more assistance" from South Vietnam's five fighting allies.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 20 (PA Mrs. Ann Quast Welts of Mount Vernon, Wash., playing with a borrowed driver and a museum putter, carded a oneunder-par 71 to send the United States into a one-stroke lead over Italy in the first round of the women's world amateur golf championship today.
Howard D. Samuel has been elected a vice president of the 385,000-member Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, the union announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 20--The announcement today of plans to build a studio that eventually may have 105 sound stages has underscored the atmosphere of change and ferment that has overtaken the film production industry here.

The New Leadership division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York has arranged a dinner and fashion show this Sunday at the Pierre's Grand Ballroom. Proceeds will go to the 130 health and welfare agencies affiliated with the federation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) Secretary of State Rusk, leaving for the Manila conference, said today that the heads of the Government at the meeting would "go over the entire situation and consider the possibility of bringing the Vietnam war to an early conclusion."

Residents of Manhattan's East Side waged a last-ditch fight yesterday to shut down heliport operations atop the Pan Am Building, in the face of a Federal Aviation Agency recommendation, made "without reservation," that it be continued.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 20 Prime Minister Minister Ian D. Smith said on radio and television tonight that it appeared to him that the dispute between Rhodesia and Britain was "coming to a climax" and that he felt it was important to "keep negotiations going."
Dr. Byron Stookey, neurosurgeon, died of a heart attack yesterday morning near his home at 455 East 57th Street. He was 79 years old.

Joe Danilcyzk of the Brownsville Boys Club and Art Reyer of Rockaway defeated Ken Holmes and Walter Ulbrich of the New York Athletic Club tonight to advance to the final of the United States Handball Association's national one-wall championships.
Splendiferous, the women's specialty store that was started at Third Avenue and 75th Street less than four years ago, will soon open a five-story "house of contemporary fashion" off Fifth Avenue.

The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association has accused Mayor Lindsay of engaging in a vendetta against 17 unemployed ferry officers and of "throwing the weight of his great office against 17 defenseless ferry officers."

SAIGON, Oct. 20 (AP) United States headquarters announced that a total of 331,000 American servicemen were in South Vietnam at the close of last week, an increase of 7,000 over the previous week. The total for other allied forces not counting South Vietnamese, was put at 50,000 men, an increase of 3,000.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 20 Two of three Indian ships seized by Pakistan during last year's warfare sailed today for Bombay. Two of three Pakistani ships seized by India are on their way to Karachi.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 21 (UPI) Plans for a paralyzing nationwide strike to protest United States policies in Vietnam fizzled today when Japan's 4 million trade unionists staged only token walkouts. No major incidents were reported, although there were a few arrests in some cities.
A new Eastern Air Lines commercial points out the advances made in air travel in the last few decades with an analogy to the technical progress made in filming since the twenties.
David Burge, who played at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, is a pianist with great power, steel-trap exactness of rhythm and an immense variety of weights and colors.

The city's Council Against Poverty refused yesterday to endorse the Board of Education's request for an estimated $65-million in Federal funds to help poor children, charging that the board had failed to consult and cooperate with antipoverty groups in drawing up its plans.
ATHENS, Oct. 20 (AP) Sergio Sorrentino of Italy sailed Aretusa Due to victory in the fifth race today and took the over-all lead in Dragon Class competition for the King Paul Trophy.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 20 Hopes of increased demand for heating oil, coupled with a decline in the nation's crude-oil stocks, led the Texas Railroad Commission to raise oil-production quotas here today for November.
A tugboat captain blinked in the glare of flashbulbs and quartz lights as he stood beside Mayor Lindsay yesterday. "It's brighter here than it was at the Alva Cape," he said.

The portrait is the work of Mrs. Mary Swensen, a grandmother, who spent 100 hours creating it from a picture of the President. It will be a gift from the state of Victoria.

He was 43 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 Strange things are happening in California politics, as usual. This sunny paradise has never looked more prosperous or sounded more quarrelsome. Democratic registration is up, but the Democratic Governor, Pat Brown, is in trouble. The state is changing so fast that many of the major roles and arguments of the 1962 Governor's race between Brown and Richard M. Nixon now seem to be reversed.
