A Baltimore widow, who supported her family as a clothes presser, won a judgment of $180,000 yesterday for injuries sustained when her hand was caught in a hot pressing machine.
A blind man was injured slightly yesterday when he fell from a subway platform and was brushed by one car of an incoming train.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21--The Army is conducting a study that may form the basis for a possible reorganization of the National Guard this winter or early next spring.
MOSCOW, Oct. 21 (Reuters)--Russian engineers today set off a giant explosion to divert a dangerous river away from Alma-Ata, capital of Soviet Kazakhstan.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21 Senator Robert F. Kennedy set out on a tour of California tonight to assist the campaign of Gov. Edmund G. Brown for reelection.
The spot rate on the British pound eased yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.

ABERFAN, Wales, Saturday, Oct. 22 An avalanche of 2 million tons of rain-soaked coal waste slipped 500 feet down a mountainside yesterday morning at this tiny village in South Wales and engulfed a schoolhouse, a farm, and at least 13 miners' cottages.
MIAMI, Oct. 21 (AP) Capitalizing on one of many fumbles, the Miami Hurricanes splashed to a 14-7 victory over Indiana tonight in the worst rainstorm to hit a game in the Orange Bowl in five years.
The real Keith Funston was on a tour of five Eastern European nations with 24 other executives, but somebody who looked like him was on stage at the Hotel Americana last night.

NEWBERG, Ore., Oct. 21 (AP)--Former Representative Scott Leavitt of Montana, who served in Congress from 1920 until 1933 and who was a former commander in chief of the United Spanish War Veterans, died yesterday at his home here. He was 87 years old.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 21 Billy Haughton's Stable will have a three-horse entry going tomorrow night in the $52,149 Roosevelt Futurity at Roosevelt Raceway. The entry of Romulus Hanover, Nardin's Byrd and Meadow Elva rules as the 1-5 early favorite to win the mile race for 2-year-old pacers.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 21 (AP) A Brown University student group has withdrawn an invitation to George Lincoln Rockwell, head of the American Nazi Party, after criticism from Dr. Ray L. Heffner the university's new president.

Taps was sounded on a strangely hushed Fifth Avenue just after noon yesterday as the bodies of 10 firemen killed in the line of duty were borne slowly down the avenue, their coffins atop 10 fire trucks.
Mihir Sen, a 36-year-old Calcutter lawyer, said yesterday that he had been given permission by the State Department for an attempt to swim the length of the Panama Canal.
Fordham Hospital closed one operating room yesterday under pressure from the state and promised to air-condition two remaining rooms.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) The Defense Department announced today the development of a system of installing radar in helicopters that can provide the copters with night eyes for use in Vietnam.
WHAT is Rudi Gernreich up to today? Holes, that's what. Carved out of plastic playdresses as if they were so much Swiss cheese. Then cutouts are pasted on the rest of the body.

MANILA, Oct. 21 Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the neutralist Premier of Cambodia, was reported today to have sent a message through the Philippine Government for delivery to President Johnson on his arrival here Sunday for the allied conference on Vietnam.
Li Ming, chairman of the Chekiang First Bank, Ltd. in Hong Kong and chairman of the Consolidated Securities Corporation in New York, died in Hong Kong yesterday. He was 78 years old.
A Protestant organization in the Bronx has dissociated itself from support for the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board, it was announced yesterday.
LEWISBORO, N.Y., Oct. 21 Town officials announced today the issuance of a permit for an interracial country club headed by Jackie Robinson, the former Brooklyn Dodger.

THE five women sitting around a table in the Riverside Church tower on a recent morning never once looked around at the charming leaded windows in the 11th floor room or peered out at the misty view. Heads bent, they were much too intent on the embroidery in front of them.

These days, Melina Mercouri is not quite so bouncy as film fans may remember her in the movie "Never on Sunday." She aches all over, but that's the price of becoming a dancing star for the Broadway musical taken from the 1960 film, due here in March.
William F. Morse, former vice president and director of R.C. Rathbone Son, Inc., insurance brokers, died Tuesday In Ridgewood, N.J., where he lived. He was 72 years old.

LONDON, Oct. 21 (Reuters) Ian Fleming, creator of the fictional secret agent James Bond 007 described his hero as "that cardboard booby" and became bored with his own fame, according to a biography published here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 The House reversed today its decision refusing President Johnson the right to use Federal financing to promote trade with the Communist countries of Eastern Europe.
CLIFTON, N.J., Oct. 21 (AP) Clifton police could be excused for looking a bit redfaced today. They were still looking for the thief who took $3,000 from police headquarters yesterday.
Prices weakened slightly on the American Stock Exchange yesterday for the third consecutive session.

LYNN, Mass., Oct. 21 The engagement of Miss H. Joanne Fox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Fox, to Leonard I. Brumberg has been announced by the parents of the prospective bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Brumberg of Baldwin, L.I.A wedding next June is planned.

There was a hint yesterday that Alexander Rittmaster, a former director of the MerrittChapman Scott Corporation, might become a Government witness against Louis Wolfson, chairman of the construction company, and other defendants in a stock fraud case.
THE Museum of Early American Folk Art has or ganized a brilliant survey of its field. It will be on view at the Time and Life Exhibition Center, Avenue of the Americas and 50th Street, until Nov. 20.

OYVIND FAHLSTROM, the Swedish artist who devised last night's theater piece in "Theater and Engineering," the festival at the 69th Regiment Armory, has called it "initiation rites for a new medium, Total Theater." But it might better be labeled Theater of Effects.
John Gilman McCarthy, president of the Television Program Export Association, has been elected as the new president of the American Australian Association.

Congress gave final approval yesterday to a bill granting the National and American Football Leagues the limited immunity from antitrust laws they had sought. A voice vote in the Senate completed the action and eased the way for the two leagues to merge into one.

Mrs. Florence Black Henderson, a retired public school teacher and the widow of Luther L. Henderson Sr., who was a professor at Langston University, Fulton, Mo., died Wednesday in Elmhurst (Queens) General Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived at 109-15 Ditmars Boulevard, Elmhurst.

IN a country whose fighting men have often shown a marked tendency toward pacifism, Brig. Gen. Thao Ma, commander of the small but effective Royal Laotian Air Force, has stood out for his martial qualities. Yesterday, it appears, he showed how little inclined he was to shy away from a fight by ordering a ...
LIDO BEACH, L. I., Oct. 21--White liberals and Negro moderates were assailed tonight in a strong speech by a leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) A new approach to the treatment of drug addicts, calling 'for medical care rather than imprisonment, was approved by Congress today.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct 21 Manhattan College suffered its first loss of the season tonight, dropping a 20-19 decision to Iona Club eleven at Mount Vernon Memorial Field. The Jaspers had won their first two starts. The Gaels' won-lost record is 3-1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) A Federal grand jury at Newark is looking into the sale of vegetable oil to foreign countries under a Government foreign assistance program.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 21 A dispute over a key word of testimony has introduced a puzzling new element into the case of Dr. Carl Coppolino, a young anesthesiologist who is awaiting trial for murder.
The Police Department may borrow a technique long used by car thieves in its campaign to make life still more difficult for persons who park illegally in mid-Manhattan.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21 Roy Arthur Hunt, former president and executive committee chairman of the Aluminum Company of America, collapsed and died early this afternoon in front of the Duquesne Club in downtown Pittsburgh. He was 85 years old.
Arthur Levitt has made an outstanding record in his three terms as State Controller. We support him in his bid for a fourth term.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 Personal frictions with President Joseph D. Mobutu of the Congo have led Ambassador George McMurtrie Godley to return here for what are described as "indefinite consultations."
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 21 A chanting, catcalling crowd of 1,000 Yale students tried to attend an experimental film here yesterday that featured "18 minutes of the act of creation itself."
Lulu Mae Hubbard, an actress and the wife of Paul McGrath, the stage and film actor, died yesterday at a nursing home in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 59 years old and lived at 77 Park Avenue.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 21 (AP) The police went on 12-hour shifts today in an intensive manhunt for a sadistic killer blamed for five rape-stranglings in the Cincinnati area during the last 10 months.
Four of the most aggressive candidates in the current campaign are the men running for Lieutenant Governor an office politicians have traditionally regarded as a passport to obscurity.

ABERFAN, Wales, Oct. 21 (UPI) The history of Wales is dotted with disasters involving mines, but today's tragedy in Aberfan in which the death toll may be 200, is the first known major accident involving pit waste.

TORONTO, Oct. 21 Testimony given by C. Powell Morgan 5 months before he died was made public today by an Ontario Royal Commission investigating the tangled affairs of the insolvent Atlantic Acceptance Corp.
Two senior officials of the Paramount Pictures Corporation were elected yesterday to the board of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., which absorbed Paramount earlier this week.
ENUGU, Nigeria, Oct. 21 The prevailing winds in the capital of Nigeria's Eastern Region indicate that its secession is inevitable.
A Federal study group of specialists in lung diseases urged yesterday that every available means be used to prevent or discourage cigarette smoking.

THE Maxwell Anderson fantasy "The Star Wagon" achieved a touching poignancy in the third act of its revival last night by the "National Educational Television Playhouse" on Channel 13. For the first two acts, the play was often very arduous going because "The Star Wagon" is a vehicle that moves with all deliberate reluctance.
A street rally here yesterday to protest the anti-Communist policies of Indonesia's military leaders drew 50 demonstrators and at least 100 uniformed policemen and plainclothes men.

The Continental Insurance Company of New York, which has been seeking for some time to enter the life-insurance business, announced its intention yesterday to buy a 17.7 per cent interest in the Franklin Life Insurance Company for $95,749,980.

SINGAPORE (Saturday, Oct. 22) Brig. Gen. Thao Ma, Chief of the Laotian Air Force, who staged a revolt yesterday, has crossed into Thailand and surrendered to military authorities there, informed sources said here today.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., Oct. 21 Paul Kelly of Sleepy Hollow and Frank Strazza of Round Hill teamed superbly to win two matches and lead the way into the semi-finals of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association pro-pro championship at Cedar Brook Golf Club today.

Percy E. Sutton, who has been serving as Borough President of Manhattan since the elevation of Mrs. Constance Baker Motley to the Federal bench, has been nominated by the Democratic and Liberal parties to fill the three remaining years of her term.

Norman H. Strouse, chairman and chief executive officer of the J. Walter Thompson Company, will head the 1966-61 fund drive of the New York Public Library. The advertising leader headed last year's campaign, which raised $836,000.
A "divorce early warning" program has been announced here by the Commission on Synogogue Relations of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) The State Department said today that a series of underwater explosion detection tests would begin late this month in the North Pacific 75 miles from the nearest land mass and 212 miles at the farthest point from Soviet territory. The tests will continue until the end of the year.

PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 21 (AP) Dave Goldman of Dallas and Curtis Person of Memphis gained the final of the North and South senior golf tournament today on the 7,000-yard, par-72 No. 2 course of the Pinehurst Country Club.

BERRYVILLE, Va., Oct. 21 Vice President Humphrey will fly here from Minnesota on Sunday to attend a funeral service for former Senator Harry F. Byrd, who died Thursday of a malignant brain tumor at the age of 79.
Seventeen years ago, on Oct. 20, 1949, a banquet-birthday party was given for a man ninety years old. It was a birthday celebration for John Dewey, philosopher and educator.

CAIRO, Oct. 21 The Egyptian Government, caught in the tightest foreign-exchange squeeze of the last few years, is engaged in the most drastic cutbacks ever undertaken in its development program, informed sources disclosed today.

A man who raises a claim of conscientious objection after he has received a notice inducting him into the Armed Forces, still must be granted a hearing by his Selective Service Board, the United States Court of Appeals here ruled yesterday.
MOSCOW, Oct. 21 (UPI) The Soviet press derided President Johnson's Asian tour today as a "Hollywood Panorama" to influence voters at home and promote his "imperialist policy" abroad.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), Oct. 21 Israel accused Syria today of a new bomb attack and sabotage efforts.

Detectives from the Queens District Attorney's office seized yesterday the files of Local 13 of the Laborers International Union of North America, a local which the police say is under the control of the Mafia.
LISBON, Oct. 21 Three leading Socialists have been arrested in northern Portugal.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21 Liu Chieh, Nationalist China's permanent representative at the United Nations, today described as "ill-timed" and "unrealistic" a proposal by 27 prominent Americans that the United States adopt a "twoChina" policy in the United Nations.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Oct. 22 A meeting of the leaders of nine Communist nations ended officially today with a statement confirming that the visitors had witnessed Soviet rocket and satellite launchings but stating no conclusions from their four days of discussions.

BONN, Oct. 21 The chiefdelegates at the United StatesBritish-West German conference on European defense problems ended their two-day meeting today with a pledge that their governments would continue to support the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and "maintain the strength, cohesion and vitality of the alliance and its integrated system of defense."
BERLIN, Oct. 21 The Rev. Billy Graham made his fifth appearance last night in Berlin and for the fifth time a crowd of some 10,000 people pressed into the city's largest sports hall.
PARIS, Oct. 21 Agreement is expected soon on a date for a visit here by the three ranking leaders of the Soviet Union.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct 21 Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. toured the North Country today, trying to find traces of a Liberal groundswell or, at least, some Liberals.

The New York Knickerbockers will undergo a severe test when they meet the world champion Boston Celtics in Madison Square Garden tonight at 8:30. The game will mark New York's final appearance in the Garden until Nov. 3.
The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company announced here yesterday the election of William D. Hobbs and Curtis H. Judge as vice presidents.

GENEVA, Oct. 21--The World Meteorological Organization warned today that it would be "foolhardy" for man to attempt to modify the weather on a large scale with his limited knowledge of atmospheric forces.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 The index of primary market prices declined two-tenths of 1 per cent to 105.9. During the week ended Oct. 18, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods moved lower in price while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Oct. 21 New regulations aimed at curbing the foreign exchange black market here were announced today the the Congo.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 21 The American Lutheran Church today hailed the growing di alogue between Protestants and Roman Catholics but warned that no Lutheran pastor may take part in a wedding in which the parties promise to rear children in the "Roman faith."

A local school board that covers part of Harlem threatened yesterday to resign unless the Board of Education resumed negotiations within 10 days to resolve the controversy over Intermediate School 201.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 21 President Humberto Castelo Branco was reported today to be preparing a purge of more office-holders after ending an open revolt in Congress by calling a recess of both houses.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct. 21 Five Suffolk County policemen reported having observed early this morning a multicolored light "far brighter than any star" moving slowly through the night sky.

Bond prices made their biggest advance yesterday in eight weeks. Long-term Government bonds jumped more than a point and Treasury bill prices climbed enough to lower bill rates by 10 basis points or more.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 21 (AP) Carlos Ortiz, the world lightweight champion, predicted today he would knock out Sugar Ramos within nine rounds of their scheduled 15-round title bout tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) The House Committee on Un-American Activities approved a bill eight days ago aimed at Ku Klux Klan terrorism but made no public announcement of the fact, the committee's staff director said today.

BUFFALO, Oct. 21 Mrs. George R. Metcalf of Auburn was elected president of the New York State Association for Mental Health at its annual meeting tonight in the Statler Hilton Hotel. Mrs. Metcalf is vice president of the Community Health Boards Association of New York State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) George F. Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., has sent a letter to Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, praising his record and wishing him success in the election against Warren W. Wilentz, Democrat.

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes yesterday forgot his history of heart trouble but remembered his 10 years of police training and helped to thwart a man's attempt to stab his estranged wife with an ice pick.
ABERFAN, Wales, Oct. 21 (UPI) This village of 5,000 is just like hundreds of others in the grim, gaunt valleys of the Rhondda District, where the Welsh have been mining coal for a century.

ROME, Oct. 21 (UPI) Sandro Lopopolo of Italy retained the world junior welterweight title on a seventhround knockout tonight when the Venezuelan challenger, Vincente Rivas, gave up because of a sprained muscle in his left arm.

IT should have been a wonderfully enjoyable evening, at Carnegie Hall, but somehow it wasn't. Here was the Vienna Johann Strauss Orchestra, brought all the way from Austria to amuse us. Here was the conductor, Eduard Strauss, black-haired and handsome, the greatgrandson of the first Johann Strauss and great-nephew of Johann 2d, he of the "Blue Danube" and "Fledermaus."

THE New York Jets and New York Giants, both of whom did something about their unblemished records last Sunday, are expected (at least by the oddsmakers) to return to their old ways tomorrow. The Jets, who suffered their first loss of the season, are one-touchdown favorites over the ...

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Oct. 21 (AP) Julia Davis, 19 years old, a Mount Holyoke College sophomore from Rumson, N.J., was killed early today when the car in which she was riding left Route 116 and hit a utility pole.
Frank D. O'Connor has edged ahead of Governor Rockefeller in the straw poll conducted by The Daily News.
STONY BROOK, L.I., Oct. 21 Arthur E. Beggs of Stony Brook, former president of a group of outdoor advertising agencies, died last Friday at the age of 88.
GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Oct. 21 Guyana today rejected a claim by Venezuela to the eastern half of divided Amkoko Island.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Oct. 21 Divisional supremacy and the richest plum ever offered for fillies or mares are the major goals in tomorrow's $196,020 Gardenia Stakes at Garden State Park.
Four major lumber associations reported a decline of 10.4 per cent in production for the week ended Oct. 15 compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (UPI) William S. Paley, board chairman of the Columbia Broadcasting System, called today for revolutionary changes in university libraries to meet the "almost inconceivable rate" at which knowledge is accumulating.
WESTWOOD, N.J., Oct. 21 Joan Trumbour Wiarda, president and advertising director of Metals and Plastics Publications, Inc., died yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson. She was 59 years old.
Quick-fisted Johnny Persol, his left flashing up and across like a butcher's hook, outboxed and outslugged Amos Lincoln in the 10-round main event at Madison Square Garden last night.
Robert S. McNamara, Henry H. Fowler and Roger W. Blough will be playing a new game, if the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation has its way.
Some of the biggest brand names is art Picasso, Dali, Rouault will be available at the world's biggest department store.

The Pacific Telephone and Telephone Company registered yesterday with the securities and Exchange Commission $130million of 36-year debentures and 10,956,942 shares of common stock a $327-million package.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 21 The leaders of India, Yugoslavia and the United Arab Republic expressed concern today at the growing threat to world peace.

"The Negro market" as a target for marketers still exists despite gains made in integration, it was asserted yesterday by Donald A. Wells, executive vice president of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., one of the country's largest advertising agencies.
Britain stands alone in the Western world as the only country whose computer industry is not dominated by American manufacturers.
Portland, Me. Boston Jacobs 182 pounds, New York, outpointed Greatest Crawford, 176 Brooklyn, 10 rounds.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Oct. 21 (AP) The Very Rev. Michael Zembruski, director of the new $25-million Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa here, announced today that he would join the younger daughter of President Johnson to dedicate a mosaic at a Polish shrine in Texas.
The record of the new Civilian Complaint Review Board on the basis of its first three months proves how wrong are those who attack it as a detriment to the police and an invitation to anarchy.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 21 (AP) A biochemical reason for differences in the color of human skin has been reported at the University of Oregon Medical School.

A driver for The New York Daily News was killed last night when his delivery truck collided with a taxicab on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. He was Benjamin Gordon, 63 years old, of 30 Lake Shore Drive, Lake Hiawatha, N.J.

Every fresh study reaches the same grim conclusion: The world is on a treadmill when it comes to feeding the growing population of developing countries. It must run hard to stay in the same placeand just to stay in the same place will not head off starvation and chaos.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 21 A Vietcong mine exploded in a Mekong delta market place 75 miles southwest of Saigon this morning, killing nine South Vietnamese and wounding at least 49 others.

The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad reported a net income yesterday of $4,235,577 for the first nine months this year. This compared with $481,276 in the like period last year. For all of 1965 the carrier's earnings were $3.8-million.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21 (UPI) Contract talks between the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and four unions neared the showdown stage tonight. The Government's top labor troubleshooter joined the negotiations in an effort to head off a threatened nationwide strike by 75,000 employes.
The future of your nation offers unlimited opportunities. Vast Australia is still largely untapped.

Michigan State and Purdue, desperately pressed to avert defeat a week ago, play before television cameras and 78,000 in East Lansing, Mich., today in the game that is likely to determine the winner of the Big Ten championship.

The Levin-Townsend Computer Corporation announced yesterday it had filed a complaint in the Superior Court of New Jersey against the G.C. Computer Corporation in an effort to block G.C. Computer from terminating an agreement by which Levin-Townsend acts as sole computer representative for the company.
DETROIT, Oct. 21 (UPI) Auto production this week soared to its highest level since last spring, Ward's Automotive Reports said today, but fell short of output for the same week a year ago.
The American Women's Voluntary Services will hold a luncheon at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof next Wednesday to raise funds for its national program.
Smith Kline French Laboratories reported yesterday a slight drop in sales and earnings for the the third quarter this year.

Anyone who wonders if chamber music in its more austere forms is losing its appeal for audiences here should have been at the Hunter College Playhouse last night. The Beaux Arts Trio was playing the first of its three concerts there this season. The skeptic would probably have been able to get in, but he would have had very little choice of a place in the 700-seat hall.
Army's 150-pound football team defeated Columbia, 43-0, yesterday at Baker Field. The Lion defense was no match for the running of Van Evans, an Army back.

LOGAN PASS, Mont., Oct. 21 (AP) Forest rangers barricaded today the Going-tothe-Sun Highway, sealing off the mighty glacier country and leaving it to the grizzly bear and mountain goat until next spring.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Oct. 21 (AP) Eight American oil organizations, one French and a South African, company have been granted concessions to prospect for oil and gas on the country's continental shelf, Mines Minister Jan Haak said today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 21--Except for South Vietnamese who are flocking to the West German hospital ship Helgoland for treatment, no one is completely satisfied with the converted North Sea cruise ship now tied up in the crowded harbor here.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21 (AP) The California condor may be, having a population explosion, the State Department of Fish and Game reported yesterday.
CHESHIRE, Conn. Freshly pressed apple cider downed with a wedge of farm-baked apple pie can be among the rewards of a day's trip through the Connecticut countryside.
The Olympic development program of kayak and canoe races for boys and girls of high school age will hold a regatta today on Lake Sebago at Bear Mountain, N.Y., starting at 2 p.m.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, said today that the House Committee on Un-American Activities had hired four former Communists and an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation as consultants after they testified before the panel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of Rutherford M. Poats to be deputy administator of the foreign aid program.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 21 The first practice session for Sunday's fifth Grand Prix of Mexico was held on the 3.2-mile course in Mexico's elaborate Sports City today. All the regular Formula One cars but that from Ferrari of Italy are here, with prospects for a field of 18 to 20 starters.
Dr. Ernest W. Lampe, former clinical professor of anatomy at the Cornell University Medical College, died Wednesday of a heart ailment in his home at 625 Park Avenue. His age was 69.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 21 Mr. and Mrs. John Elijah Walker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Sue Walker, to Louis Shaw Marohnic, son of Mrs. Mary Shaw Marohnic and Louis Z. Marohnic, both of Pittsburgh.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 21 (UPI) A 10-year-old girl was recovering today at the Ohio State University Medical Center from heart surgery in which the aortic valve from a dead boy was transplanted in her chest to replace a defective valve.
The election of Richard E. Bennett as a senior vice president was announced here yesterday by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 The Tobacco Institute today issued the following statement in response to inquiries concerning the forthcoming article and earlier published reports on the subject of tar and nicotine:
IS the Beatle brow just the beginning? There are those in New York who believe the long hair fad is the first step in a return to styles of long ago.
The appointment of a committee for the 100th anniversary celebration of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1970 was announced yesterday by Arthur A. Houghton Jr., the museum's president.

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 21 (UPI) A Michigan legislative subcommittee will investigate the collapse of the Public Bank of Detroit "because of the widespread impact and questionable aspects" of the closing.

Several Department of Sanitation supervisors have admitted having made payoffs to department officials to get promoted to higher-salaried positions, a source high in the administration of Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 21--The spreading rebellion of housewives against high food prices is foredoomed to failure, the head of one of the nation's largest food processing companies said today.

PARIS, Oct. 21 The Government announced today that "a satisfactory agreement" had been worked out with Washington for the lifting of the United States ban on the sale of several advanced computers to France.
The London stock market closed with little net change yesterday after a late revival of demand.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 21 (AP) Alan Murray, an Australian touring pro who quit the circuit a year ago, shot a hole-in-one, two eagles and three birdies today for a record 66 on the par 73, 6,767-yard Victoria Club course. He took a three-stroke lead at the halfway mark in the Australian Masters with a 137.

CANBERRA, Australia, Saturday, Oct. 22 In 10 days Lyndon Johnson has campaigned his way through autumn in New York, summer in Samoa and springtime in Australia. But on his trail it is hard to realize that he has really come halfway round the world.

Negotiations have come to a dead end in the plumbers' strike that has impeded all building construction in Manhattan and the Bronx for three months. Extension of the tie-up threatens to force a shutdown of all crafts, even though every one of New York's 23 other building trades unions including the Brooklyn and Queens plumbers' local has concluded new contracts since the strike began in July of this year.
DETROIT, Oct. 21 (AP) Four members of an anti-Communist organization disrupted the appearance of the Moscow Chamber Orchestra here tonight.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 21 Al fred J. Friedlander, a member of the boards of the FifthThird Union Trust Company, the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, the Jewish Hospital and the Associated Jewish Agencies, died here today. He was 63 years old.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 21 The current bank crisis has revived an old story. A scorpion on the bank of the Nile asked a frog to ferry him to the other side.

Supporters of National Aid to Visually Handicapped will have a champagne party Thursday from 5:30 to 7:30 P.M. at the Frank Rehn Gallery, 655 Madison Avenue. The art show there will represent work of 50 American painters.
The executive committee of the regular Bronx Democratic organization designed former Chief Assistant District Attorney David Getzoff as its candidate for civil court judge yesterday.

Ludmila Dvorakova will sing her first Isolde with the Metropolitan Opera in Wagner's "Tristan Und Isolde" in the season's ninth week, which begins Nov. 21. Tickets go on sale at the box office tomorrow.
"How much is he going to make it cost us?" That was the big question being asked in the executive suites of Sixth Avenue's TV towers yesterday.

SELDOM have two novels, chosen at random, had so little in common. So little? Nothing really. Each possesses what the other lacks. If a reader prefers one over the other, the reason will lie less in the books than in the reader.
Harry Van Arsdale Jr., the president, and other top officers of the New York City Central Labor Council have been reelected, the council announced yesterday.

CARLSBAD, Calif., Oct. 21 (AP) Jim Ferree of Savannah, Ga., and little Judy Torluemke of North Key Largo, Fla., shot a record eight-underpar 33, 31 64 today and grabbed a two-stroke lead at the halfway point of the $60,000 alternate-shot Haig mixed scotch golf championship with a 36-hole total of 135.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP) A field of eight, headed by the odds-on favorite, Bold Bidder, was named today for tomorrow's $100,000 added Hawthorne Gold Cup day, but the Gold Cup itself is missing.
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday after a slow-paced recovery in the afternoon trimmed small losses that were registered in morning trading.

ROME, Oct. 21 Vice Premier Pietro Nenni, long-time Italian Socialist leader, said today that emphasis in the new, unified Socialist party would be on the solution of concrete problems rather than on "theories."
SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, Oct. 22 This premier city of Australia gave President Johnson a massive and largely enthusiastic reception today following Melbourne's huge turnout for him yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 21 (AP) Mrs. Theodore Boddie of Shreveport, La., and Mrs. David Welts of Mount Vernon, Wash., gave the United States an eightstroke lead over the defending champion, France, in the second round of the women's world amateur golf team championship today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 21 A maritime transport agreement between Communist China and Pakistan was signed today at Rawalpindi, Pakistan's interim capital.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 21 (UPI) A proposal to form a voluntary integrated class systern between a predominantly white parochial school and a predominantly Negro public school has been approved by the school board of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence.
The richest grass race on the New York Racing Association's calendar, the Man o' War at one and five-eighths miles, will have its eighth running today at Aqueduct.
MIAMI, Oct. 21 Barry Goldwater, whose major political strength in the 1964 Presidential election was in the Deep South, will begin a political speaking tour through that area tomorrow.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 102.6 on Thursday from 103.1 on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service said today it had revoked the tax-exempt status of an organization founded by Billy James Hargis because of its poitical and lobbying activities.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) Congress voted today to permit children to play football on a vacant lot on Capitol Hill. The same bill authorizes a $140-million world studies program.

The terms of the new Federal antipoverty legislation approved yesterday have thrown confusion and dismay into the city's antipoverty program and raised the strong possibility that the city may get less Federal money than it had expected.
BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP) John Havlicek scored 28 points last night as the Boston Celtics routed Baltimore, 111-91, for their second straight National Basketball Association victory.

Mrs. Slava Estrin Ben-Ami, wife of Jacob Ben-Ami, an actor in the Yiddish and the American theater for more than 40 years, died Thursday in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx, after a long illness. She was 77 years old.
Shunzo Suzuki, president of Suzuki Motor Company, Ltd., predicted here yesterday continued predominance by Japan of the United States motorcycle market.
Perhaps the most interesting news about futures trading yesterday came from Paris. The French Government apparently hopes to promote more trading in commodities.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (UPI) Charles H. Percy, the Illinois Republican candidate for the Senate, said today he would probably drop out of politics if he failed to defeat Senator Paul H. Douglas Nov. 8.

Willy Brandt drove from West to East Berlin the other day to talk and dine with the Soviet Ambassador to East Germany. Until recently such a visit by West Berlin's Mayor and the leader of West Germany's Social Democratic party would have been politically unthinkable.

Michelangelo Antonioni's prize-winning film "L'Avventura" will be televised on Channel 13's "N.E.T. Playhouse" at 8 P.M. Friday. The film, which stars Monica Vitti, is a powerful comment on a wealthy but emotionally bankrupt Italian society. The 2 -hour motion picture received a special jury prize at the 1960 Cannes Film Festival "for a new movie language and the beauty of its image."

PARIS, Oct. 21 Baron James Nathaniel Charles Leopold de Rothschild, a 70-yearold widwer, married Miss Yvette Honorine Croquet, 27, today in a civil ceremony here. No members of the family were present.

Because of deficiencies in the merchant marine the emergency sealift in the Vietnam war is costing the Government about $225-million a year "in excess costs," according to Representative Hugh L. Carey.

Lily Lynn, Inc., a leading maker of women's dresses in large sizes, has run afoul of the young slim trend.

Paul Schoenfield is wasting no time. He played a debut piano recital at Town Hall in 1965, appeared with the New York Philharmonic in a children's concert last spring, and he returned to Town Hall last night armed with a massive program. He is 19 years old.

Several lending institutions are examining the Technical Measurement Corporation's financial position, Robert M. Ghen, president of Technical Measurement, announced yesterday. He said they were discussing the possibility of substantial additional advances to ease the company's cash crisis.

The Marine Midland Corporation became yesterday the second bank to be listed on the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange. The symbol for the Buffalo based holding company is MM, the same as used on the New York Stock Exchange since 1930. Baldwin Maull, chairman of the Marine Midland board, estimated that the additional listing will provide 80 extra... trading days a year for the stock.

Elmer Winter, a tall, graying, one-time Midwestern lawyer, is the employer of 150,000 young, attractive, intelligent women. His only problem is finding another 50,000 in the next year.
The 95 employes of a young and growing electronics company took an hour off one recent Friday, got into buses and traveled the 12 miles from their Clark, N.J., plant to an industrial park in Edison.
NEWARK, Oct. 22.--The Millburn-Verona school football game was canceled today because of Verona injuries and illness and was not rescheduled.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--In every American city, except this one time is set aside in the lower criminal courts' daily routine when the drunks are herded in to be sentenced to jail. It is a perfunctory thing, with no lawyers and little testimony as the derelicts file past to receive 10, 15, perhaps 30 days in the workhouse.

BELGRADE--Nowhere is paradox more appreciated than among the Yugoslavs who enjoy attempting the impossible and frequently suffer for it. They are now in the process of trying to achieve Marxist dreams by using capitalist incentives and a leavening of private enterprise while curbing the Communist party itself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Miss Marjorie Henriette Marie Larre, daughter of Rene Joseph Larre, financial minister at the French Embassy, and the late Mrs. Monique Bailac Larre, was married today to Robert Power Gullett. He is the son of Comdr. John H. Gullett, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Gullett of Washington.

Pete Boatti, a sophomore quarterback who wears No. 10 on his jersey, threw touchdown passes with 10 minutes gone in the game and 10 minutes to go, to lead Wagner College to a 13-7 victory over Albright at Grymes Hill, Staten Island, yesterday.

BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 22-- Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Warren have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Warren, to John Chapin Foley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Foley Jr. of Morristown. N.J.

Cazzie Russell made his first real impact on the New York basketball scene last night. By giving the New York Knickerbockers a brief spark in the closing moments of the first half of what ended as a 126-97 defeat at the hand of the Boston Celtics, Cazzie sparked disproportionate excitement in the hearts and voices of a capacity crowd of 18,499 at Madison Square Garden.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 22--South Vietnam's 117member Constituent Assembly wound up the preliminaries today and got ready to choose officers and write a constitution.
A spokesman for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation reports that the reactor for the French-Belgian nuclear power plant at Chooz went into preliminary operation last week.
The American Motors Corporation reports that its export shipments of automobiles rose to a record of 45,991 in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30.

As winter approaches, homeowners become more aware of rising fuel bills. Several suggestions for saving on fuel costs, irrespective of the type of heating plant installed in a house, are offered by the National Better Heating-Cooling Council.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 22, --Hart Darlington, retired United States manager of the Norwich Union Fire Insurance Society, Ltd. Co., of New York, and president of the Eagle Fire Insurance Co., a subsidiary of Norwich Union, died today at Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived at 28 Woodland Road here.
Minnesota's non-farm labor fore grew slightly in September and unemployment was at the lowest seasonally adjusted rate for any September since 1949.

Dr. Paul L. Adams of the Conservative party toured the northern Bronx yesterday, emphasizing that he was the only gubernatorial candidate opposing the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 22--A professor at Yale's lave school who says his late-evening walks have been interrupted by the police has questioned their right to stop persons on the street without a specific reason doing so.
STILLWATER, Okla., Oct. 22. --Craig Kessler kicked a 38yard field goal late in the third period today to give Oklahoma State a 10-7 victory and break the Cowboys' string of seven losses to Kansas.
MEMPHIS, Oct. 22 (UPI)-- Bruce Newell moved Mississippi's offense today and the defense hamstrung Houston as the Rebels whipped the Cougars 27-6.

BETHPAGE, L.I., Oct. 22-- Navy gained its third straight victory in the seventh annual Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference golf championship today over the 6,288-yard, par36, 36--72 blue course at Bethpage State Park.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 22--The United Nations, reported today that its truce supervision organization had found armistice violations by both Israel and Syria in the demilitarized zone between their territories but no evidence of an aggressive military build-up by either side.

DONCASTER, England, Oct. 22 (AP)--Charles W. Engelhard of New York added $56,366 to his racetrack winnings today when his 2-yearold colt, Ribocco, triumphed in the Observer Gold Cup.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 22 (UPI)--Mel Farr, a powerhouse runner, scored one touchdown on a 20-yard run and another on a 16-yard pass reception today as he led the undefeated University of California, Los Angeles Bruins to a 28-15 victory over California.
MOSCOW, Oct. 22 (Reuters)--Soviet industry is likely to exceed its planned 6.7 per cent growth rate for 1966, according to figures made public today.

Defending his Government's stewardship of the mandated territory of South-West Africa, the Foreign Minister of South Africa asked the United Nations General Assembly: "Who gives anyone the right to experiment with the very essentials of life and wellbeing of half a million people?"

TOWNSVILLE, Australia, Sunday, Oct. 23--President Johnson renewed today the United States offer to stop the bombing of North Vietnam and to schedule a withdrawal of American forces if the enemy will say what it is prepared to do for peace.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 22--Dr. and Mrs. Marshall Fletcher Driggs of Englewood and Stockbridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Louise Driggs, to William Francis Farley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Farley of Pawtucket, R.I.
The city administration has set up an "industrial space bank" designed to help bring in new industry and to help find expansion space for companies already here.

NEWARK, Oct. 22--The New Jersey American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations struck back at the white-backlash vote today with a four-page tabloidsize pamphlet entitled "Can You Talk About Race Without Losing Your Temper?"

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 22-- A committee that already has won reductions in transit fares for the elderly here will ask the town's 600 retail merchants to offer 10 per cent discounts to residents 65 years of age.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--The 89th Congress adjourned today. Its two-year life continues until Jan. 10, when the 90th Congress will convene, but its work is done, barring an unexpected recall by President Johnson.

AFTER five weeks of intensive debate on proposed air-fare changes, the 100 member air lines of the International Air Transport Association have ended their meeting in Honolulu with few accomplishments as far as the North American market is concerned.

KANSAS CITY, Kans., Oct. 22--In a strictly nonpartisan, statistical way, Vice President Humphrey gently dropped the suggestion into this farm state today that it had never had it so good and might even have it better.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--The space age is bringing a communications revolution to the nations of Africa, which have long had difficulties keeping in touch with one another and with the outside world.

OUR attitude toward Rousseau has entered a new phase: we are more and more willing to read him objectively, on his own terms and for his own sake. We are gaining distance on him; Rousseau, for all his continuing relevance to our social and political situation, is finally becoming a historical figure for us.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 --The leader of the American Nazi party, George Lincoln Rockwell, was ordered out of San Francisco's Civic Center, and left with about 20 followers, today when trouble developed at a Nazi demonstration.

Miss Barbara Ann Bennett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Storrs Bennett of West Hartford, was married yesterday afternoon to David Watson Ulrich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arvine A. Ulrich of Massillon, Ohio.

LEXINGTON, Va., Oct. 22 (UPI)--George Washington defeated Virginia Military Institute, 13-0, today for its third straight upset and dropped the slumping Keydets out of first place in the Southern Conference.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--With 1,400 patents being issued every week for such things as lasers, computers, atomic reactors and space capsules, it is small wonder that some intriguing inventions escape public notice. Among these may be listed a cigarette filter made with cheese, a water pistol that often squirts the shooter in the face and snakeproof trousers.

SUNBURY, Pa., Oct. 22--Mr. and Mrs. Sigfried Weis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Lynn Weis, to Joseph Harris Wender, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Simon H. Wender of Norman, Okla.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 22-- Miss Ethel Pew Benson, daughter of Richard Benson of Ardmore and the late Mrs. Benson, was married here today to William Rotch Wister Jr., son of Mrs. Mitchell Wister of Towson, Md., and William R. Wister of Old Wick, N.J.
TORONTO, Oct. 22 (AP)-- George Royal, the favorite caught Orbiter in the final yards and won the $50,000 Canadian International championship for the second straight year at Woodbine Race Track today.

The United States, however, may be vital to them--if not today, then tomorrow. This is the tie that binds the seven nations that are meeting this week in Manila to discuss their common effort in the Vietnam war.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 22--As a freshman in the diplomatic ranks, Ambassador Patricia Harris finds the job of representing the United States at the United Nations considerably more intensive then she had realized.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 22 --Herbert E. Lyon, a village trustee of Tarrytown and formerly a collegiate and professional basketball star, died yesterday of cancer on Friday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown. He was 39 years old and for the last two years had been manager of recruitment and college relations for the Continental Can Company.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 --Philadelphia has met a challenge created by the phenomenal growth of industrial parks in the suburbs in recent years.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 22 (UPI)--Frank Phillips and Kel Nagle of Australia and Roberto De Vicenzo of Argentina shared the 54-hole lead in the Australian masters golf championship today by one stroke with totals of 210.

While barnstorming his way up the western edge of the Pacific last week, President Johnson found much virtue in necessity. Against the specter of what he called a tragic and vicious war in Vietnam, the President proclaimed an awakening American interest in "a new Asia" and heralded a new spirit of cooperative defense development among Asians.
GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 22 --Mike Jacobs scored two touchdowns as Great Neck North tumbled Port Washington, 26-0, for its third straight victory in Division II, North Shore Athletic Association today.

ABIQUIU, N.M., Oct. 22 (UPI)--A group of 150 Spanish-Americans overran today a police barricade into Kit Carson National Forest, claimed the land as their own and "arrested" three employes of the United States Forest Service.

MANILA, Sunday, Oct. 23 (AP)--The American-owned 7,598-ton freighter Golden State collided with a Philippine coastal steamer last night. Twenty-six persons from the Philippine ship, the Pioneer Leyte, were confirmed dead.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 22--The leaders of India, Yugoslavia and the United Arab Republic-- socialists all--talked of imperialism today in the room where Britain's viceroys played bridge.

David L. Malbin, a retired State Supreme Court Justice, was installed last week as the first administrator of a panel that will provide lawyers for indigent defendants in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.
Nathan C. Bernstein of 1165 Park Avenue, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his country home in Danbury, Conn. His age was 71.

NEXT Friday the title character of Richard Strauss's "Elektra" will stride the stage of the Metropolitan Opera in a new production. The following night another operatic creature named Electra will turn up at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. She is a principal figure in Mozart's "Idomeneo," which will be given its first professional New York performance by the newly formed Academy Opera Theater Company.

MANILA, Sunday, Oct. 23-- President Johnson said today that he had no doubt that the Manila conference could reach agreement on overtures to end the Vietnam war by negotiations.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 22-- Jack Brabham of Australia, the three-time world champion driver, will be in the first row tomorrow for the start of the fifth Grand Prix of Mexico. He set a record clocking of 1 minute 53.95 seconds on the 3.1mile course with his BrabhamRepco Formula One car.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 22--A New York architectural firm has added stature to the new four-story State Supreme Court building here by putting the $13-million structure on a podium.

Andre Previn, the 37-yearold pianist, composer and conductor, will become chief conductor of the Houston Symphony next season. Sir John Barbirolli, the 66-year-old Briton who has held that post for six years, will become conductor emeritus.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 22--To many of the 330,000 American servicemen in South Vietnam, the Nov. 8 Congressional elections are a remote event.

St. George's Episcopal Church at Stuyvesant Square will present four concerts by the newly organized Baroque Players and a production of Massenet's "Le Jongleur de Notre Dame," by the Friends of French Opera. Sonya Monosoff is director of the Baroque Players, who will open St. George's musical season on Nov. 9. The Massenet opera will be given in April under the direction of Robert Lawrence.

ALBANY, Oct. 22--The Old English sheepdog, Ch. Fezziwig Raggedy Andy, was selected as the best in show at today's Albany Kennel Club fixture. Owned by Serena and Hendrik van Rensselaer of Basking Ridge, N.J., he won in a field of 950 dogs. This was the limit set by the show committee to help ease the crowded situation that existed in the past at the Washington Avenue Armory.

CLOSTER, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Col. Edward K. Louden, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Louden, have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Sandra Kay Louden, to Earl Stanley Trimble 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Trimble Jr. of Hampton, Va.

BUCHAREST--Finding facts about travel in Rumania, which is very much in the news these days, is difficult in New York. Although I scoured book and map stores, I could find neither a guidebook nor a dictionary nor a good road map.

INTERSTATE 5, a 308mile freeway through Oregon, is now open in its entirety. The road, which took more than 10 years to construct at a cost of nearly $290-million, was financed largely by the Federal Government.

THE most extensive stamp exhibition in the United States is the permanent display of the Division of Philately and Postal History of the Smith sonian Institute in Washington. Known as the National Postage Stamp Collection, it contains more than 10 million objects, including proofs, models, postal relics and other memorabilia.

SARASOTA, Fla., Oct. 22.-- Barry Goldwater, beginning a speaking tour in behalf of Southern Republican Congressional candidates, today accused President Johnson's Administration of "dishonesty." He said the President had told a "lie" to the American people about the Southeast Asian situation.
WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 22-- That world record harness racing minus win-pool of $7,109.80, believed to have been set last night at Philadelphia's Liberty Bell Park by Romeo Hanover, didn't last long.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 22-- Ernesto Arthur Miranda, who has helped to make legal history, faces a new trial in Maricopa County Superior Court here Monday.
OTTAWA, Oct. 22--A new Government white paper calling for tighter screening of immigrants has created a stir in Canada, where "new Canadians" are urgently wanted but greatly feared.

The long-term use of anticoagulant drugs, which tens of thousands of American victims of heart attacks take in hopes of preventing renewed attacks, does not help them, a team of Portland, Ore., researchers reported yesterday.

LAKEWOOD, N.J.--Stepping out of an airplane and parachuting to earth just for the fun of it may not be everyone's idea of a suitable weekend sport, but visitors to this area have the opportunity to take a close look at the jumpers from both the ground and the air. Some visitors even decide to try a jump themselves.

A cocktail dance will be given at 1 P.M. next Sunday in the Grand Ballroom of the Statler Hilton Hotel by the Young Leadership division of the United Jewish Appeal. The cochairmen are Miss Sherry I. Klein, Miss Lois Wiener and Mark B. Haiken.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Oct. 22-- Three gunmen forced their way into the home of a well-to-do garment manufacturer here early this morning and escaped with more than $25,000 in jewelry and several hundred dollars in cash after binding the man's wife, daughter and a nurse. DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Oct. 22--President Julius K. Nyerere, flanked by armed steel-helmeted riot policemen today expelled 390 students from Dar Es Salaam University. The students had demonstrated against his Government's plan for compulsory national service for university graduates and high-school dropouts.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22-- Princeton returned to its winning ways today by downing Pennsylvania, 30-13, before 20,844 spectators in sun-drenched Franklin Field. It was the third victory against two defeats for the Tigers this season while it was Penn's third straight loss after two victories.

ALBANY, Oct. 23--The state is planning to enlist housewives as "health guides" who will search out people needing medical help and tell them how to get it.
TOKYO, Oct. 23--As many as 80 per cent of human cancers may be due to environmental causes, a noted British scientist told the opening session of the Ninth International Cancer Congress here today.
MANILA, Oct. 23--President Johnson received a tumultuously warm welcome today from the residents of Manila, a city in which Americans are said to feel more at home than anywhere else in the Far East.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23--Following is a summary of the Johnson, Administration's proposals for major legislation and of the action taken on them by the 89th Congress:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23-- Interest charges on business loans at the nation's banks, already the highest in almost 40 years, are likely to stay high, and possibly could go even higher, Archie K. Davis, the retiring president of the American Bankers Association, predicted here today.

A four-cornered race in the Seventh Congressional District has served up to the voters in southern Queens a broad sweep of political viewpoints on issues ranging from Vietnam and inflation to the Police, Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Oct. 23-- A spokesman for Zambia's Industrial Development Corporation disclosed here over the weekend that three bids had been received for construction of an oil-products pipeline from Dar es Salaam to Ndola.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 (UPI)-- Larry Garron scored three touchdowns today and led the Boston Patriots to a 35-17 American Football League upset victory over the San Diego Chargers, who had beaten the Patriots by 24-0 in San Diego last month.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23 (UPI)--Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the Federation of Westinghouse Independent Salaried Unions, representing 14,000 white collar workers in 32 Westinghouse plants across the nation, reached agreement today on a three-year contract.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP)-- Senator Paul H. Douglas, the Illinois Democrat who is campaigning for a fourth term, today discounted straw votes that showed him trailing his Republican opponent, Charles H. Percy.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association took its campaign against the Civilian Complaint Review Board into the Coney Island and Brighton Beach areas of Brooklyn yesterday with go-go girls, Jewish songs and sharp criticism of Mayor Lindsay.
Juan Serrano, the flamenco guitarist who made his American debut in August, 1962, gave a recital Saturday night at Town Hall.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Oct. 23--After 20 years of conclaves in Old Virginia, the Association of National Advertisers has gone West.

DENVER, Oct. 23 (AP)-- Bert Coan's four touchdown runs--for 35, 19, 19 and 18 yards --and Len Dawson's passing led the Kansas City Chiefs to a 56-10 victory over the Denver Broncos today and moved the Chiefs into first place in the American Football League's Western Division.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 23 (AP)--The World Boxing Association will continue to recognize Carlos Ortiz as world lightweight champion, Robert Evans, president of the W.B.A., said today.

CAIRO, Oct. 23--With a frankness and an approach surprisingly similar to that of Western specialists, a highlevel Soviet economic team is reported to have advised the United Arab Republic to introduce more incentives and "capitalist...

This is the season of the year, in which all incumbent politicians delight, when Albany's state fiscal position looks rosiest. No one--except the staid and silent professional bookkeepers--has taken the trouble to project next year's frightening expenses.

Harry B. Helmsley, president of Helmsley-Spear, Inc., real estate concern, has been elected to the Board of Directors of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York. He is chairman of the association's property owners committee.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (UPI)-- Richard Speck, charged with the slaying of eight nurses in their town house dormitory July 14, is scheduled for another court appearance here tomorrow.
Are Federal tax laws fair to those who heed the Biblical injunction to "honor thy father and thy mother"?

THE use of Federal income taxes to finance Presiden tial campaigns is a numbing prospect for the television viewer. Apparently it is not enough that the taxpayer should have to look at the wretched political spot announcements that make a farce of civilized governmental processes; now he is being invited to pay for them.

BERLIN, Oct. 23--A West Berlin newspaper said today there were indications that the Russians were reassessing their strategic concept in Europe with a view to reducing Soviet military forces massed in the heart of the continent.

The Democratic and Republican parties received a princely going-away present from the 89th Congress in the form of a tax check-off to finance future Presidential campaigns. If enough taxpayers avail themselves of the option to assign a dollar of their individual returns to the campaign fund, each party will start the 1968 Presidential battle with a $35million nest egg.
MANILA, Oct. 23--As the Manila conference proceeds, a recurring South Vietnamese nightmare becomes more acute.

ALBANY, Oct. 24--The names of 1,405 persons who passed the state examination for admission to the New York State Bar were announced today by the State Board of Examiners. A total of 1,924 persons took the test, 1,864 for the first time.

IT WAS a random observation when made some 15 years ago, but it took recent events to give it any sort of significance. Gabe Paul was then the general manager of the Cincinnati Reds and the one ballplayer who caught his fancy most was an oversized first baseman-outfielder named Joe Adcock.

In the instant of dead silence before the lines hit, Gary Pettigrew, the rookie, fought to keep his mind from going blank, to keep his eyes flicking from tackle to guard, to keep thinking. He was the youngest of the four, and he didn't want to blow it for them all.
WINCHESTER, Va., Oct. 23 (AP)--Harry Flood Byrd was buried today in a simple Episcopal funeral service against a backdrop of flaming autumn foliage here in his cherished Shenandoah Valley.

The election of William B. Rand, president of United States Lines, as chairman of the Committee of American Steamship Lines for 1967 has been announced by Capt. J.W. Clark, present chairman and president of Delta Steamship Lines, New Orleans.
From the moment Dr. Janet A. Kennedy, a psychiatrist on the staff of Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx, spoke to the 34-year-old woman she knew she had a serious problem on her hands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23--The National Committee for an Effective Congress said today it had detected a right-wing trend among voters that might significantly affect the outcome of the Nov. 8 Congressional elections.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24--It is hard to find anyone in this state, a prophetic image of America-to-be, who confidently believes that Gov. Edmund G. Brown can defeat Ronald Reagan and win a third term for the Democrats. Even those who maintain that the Governor can yet win in the final two weeks of the campaign speak in terms of a desperate rescue effort.

PARIS, Oct. 24 Paris dripped tonight, it did not sparkle. It was an expensive drizzle, too, for Paramount Pictures had spent $100,000 to dramatize the premiere of their film "Is Paris Burning" the story of the liberation of the city in 1944 and some of their best-laid plans were washed out.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 24 The leaders of India, Yugoslavia and the United Arab Republic called on the United States today to stop the bombing of North Vietnam immediately "without any preconditions."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The Supreme Court agreed today to consider the constitutionality of the dispersal by the police of anti-Vietnam war demonstrators in the heart of Manhattan in 1964.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Air Force announced today the appointment of J. William Doolittle, a Justice Department lawyer, as its general counsel.

MANILA, Oct. 24 Following are excerpts from statements by Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South, Vietnam and Gen. William C. Westmoreland, Commander of United States forces in Vietnam, at the Manila conference today:
LONDON, Oct. 24 The Sudan is preparing an attempt to mediate the intensifying conflict between the Arab Republic and Saudi Arabia over Yemen and South Arabia, diplomatic informants said today.
The Pennsylvania Railroad reported yesterday a gain in consolidated profits for the third quarter and first nine months of this year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Yields on Treasury bills dropped to their lowest point in more than a month in today's auction, the Treasury announced tonight.

The proponents and opponents of Government subsidies to the arts were equally divided last night at a symposium of the Committee on the Law of the Theaters of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. The meeting Was held at The Lambs, 130 West 44th Street.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 24 Sweden's biggest labor dispute in 20 years broadened today when 15,000 state employes began a three-day strike in sympathy with 20,800 teachers locked out of high schools and universities.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Oct. 24 (UPI) A ranking Administration official said today he understood how housewives felt when they organized widely separated supermarket boycotts to protest rising food prices.

A ship with a cargo of sugar soon to be landed at a British port apparently had an impact on world sugar prices yesterday. In any event, all sugar contracts in New York sank to new lifetime lows yesterday and closed at or near the low levels.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 24 (AP) The Toledo Blade and Times, the daily newspapers in this city of 325,000, were struck tonight by the International Typographical Union. Publication was halted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The Communications Satellite Corporation reported today that its revenues from the operation of the Early Bird satellite totaled $3.19-million for the nine months to Sept. 30. The Early Bird went into commercial service on June 28, 1965. In the first, half of this year its revenues were $2,107,000.

Student tuition fees have been producing surpluses in 17 of 21 upstate community colleges, and Controller Arthur Levitt and the State University reported yesterday the result of these savings would be either reduction of fees or moves to enrich programs.

Furniture with badly scarred finishes can now be treated to instant antiquing with a new aerosol paint spray called Easy Way Antiquing Kit. Designed for the amateur, the process involves two steps: a push-button application of a base coat, and a finishing coat.
GRENADA, Miss., Oct. 24 About 200 Negroes were arrested today during a noisy demonstration set off by the alleged harassment of Negro students at two recently integrated schools.

Gordon S. Bjorkman, director of the art and publications services of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died Sunday of a cerebral hemorrhage in Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 9 Ridge Road, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

Mr. and Mrs. Malcom Percell McLean of New York and Mobile, Ala., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Croom McLean, to Geoffrey Van Buskirk Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Coe Parker of Mexico City.
A sharp price drop in Great American Industries was the main feature of trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the list was hit with its fourth consecutive loss.
"Sweet Charity," the hit Broadway musical based on an Italian movie, has come full circle. A Hollywood movie will be made from the musical.
GOLDSBORO, N.C., Oct. 24 (AP) A number of Goldsboro residents, including airmen at nearby Seymour Johnson Air Force Base, reported having seen unidentified flying objects last night.

Dennis Ralston, Arthur Ashe, Cliff Richey and Charlie Pasarell were named officially yesterday to the Davis Cup tennis team that will meet Brazil Nov. 5 in the interzone semifinal round. The announcement was made by the United States Lawn Tennis Association here.
PASSAIC, N.J., Oct. 24 Dr. and Mrs. Max A. Malkin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynda Malkin, to Allan Braunstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max L. Braunstein.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 24 (AP) The authorities checked various leads today in the slaying of a top state education official and his daughter, but their main hope seemed to lie with the official's critically wounded wife.
Three men, none of whom is eligible for the draft, were convicted yesterday in Federal Court of destroying their draft cards during an anti-Vietnam war rally in Union Square last Nov. 6.
Tarzan and Jane were found in a Brooklyn phone booth early yesterday.
AN entire book on the subject of making sauces and gravies seems incredible until one stops to think how many dishes hot, cold, savory and sweet one or the other goes into.

A legislative investigation of alleged violations of the State Civil Service Law, in connection with the city's action in the case of 17 unemployed ferry officers, was urged yesterday by Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky.
NAVY is the next team to feel the might of Notre Dame, the No. 1 college football power. This will take place at Philadelphia's John F. Kennedy Stadium Saturday.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 24 The engagement of Miss Gay lord Sheldon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Sheldon of Scarsdale and Nantucket Island, Mass., to Dennis Guild Devere, son of Mrs. F. Guild Devere of Scarsdale and the late Mr. Devere, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. Plans have been made for an April wedding.

The leaders of two major Orthodox Jewish organizations strongly endorsed and voiced confidence yesterday in President Johnson's current move "to bring to a peaceful conclusion the conflict" in Vietnam.

Isaac Albert, a retired importer and manufacturer of lighting fixtures, died yesterday at the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 78 years old and lived at 20 Plaza Street in that borough.

TAGAYTAY, the Philippines, Oct. 24 (AP) Escorted by five jeeploads of soldiers carrying machine guns, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson came to this country village with four other First Ladies today. They had lunch in view of a volcano.
Stanley Dancer, the driver from New Egypt, N.J., has exceeded the $1-million mark in purse winnings for the second time in three years, the Harness Pacing Institute said yesterday.
Warren, Mich., Oct. 24 (UPI) A strike of municipal workers severed all services except police and fire protection here Monday.
President Johnson's request for advice from select groups of business and labor leaders on what to do about inflation has elicited some tame and confused responses.

From what developed at last week's Pennsylvania National Horse Show, it appeared the other teams would not pose a serious threat to the United States Equestrian Team in the international jumping at the National Horse Show that begins today in Madison Square Garden.

The martial strains of bugle, fife and drum will echo in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom Nov. 2 as officers of the Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New York lead honor guests to the society's 69th annual banquet. Col. S. Victor Constant, U.S.A., retired, governor of the society, will head the precession with Col. Nathaniel Claiborne Hale, U.S.A., retired, of Wynnewood, Pa.
